headline: Not Telling
text: The desire to write my first novel was a desire for privacy. I was writing short stories, and had said out loud more than once that I would never write a novel, maybe because I knew publishers preferred novels, and I was telling anyone who happened to care that I wouldn’t write to please publishers. But the thought of a novel had always been alluring as well — alluring and daunting.

headline: The Things She Carried
text: THE injury wasn’t new, and neither was the insult. Rebecca, a combat veteran of two tours of duty, had been waiting at the V.A. hospital for close to an hour when the office manager asked if she was there to pick up her husband.

headline: Beware the April Fools’ Jokes Coming From Madison Avenue
text: SOCIAL media like Facebook and Twitter have been given credit for reviving interest in watching television live so comments about unbelievable catches, undeserved awards, unexpected plot twists and unfashionable dresses can be shared in real time with family and friends. Those social platforms also seem to be having a stimulative effect on the interest along Madison Avenue in April Fools’ jokes.

text: Over recent days the notices have gone out, an annual ritual of dashed hopes.

headline: Should Parents Opt Out of Testing?
text: When Mom and Dad, not teachers and principals, tell their children to put down their pencils.

headline: Sanctions or Not, Russian Sway in London May Be Bluster
text: Russian listings on the London Stock Exchange; Russians buying multimillion-dollar homes in Chelsea, on streets called Billionaires’ Row; Russian children in Britain’s most exclusive schools, while their parents shop at Harrods and Asprey; Russians running soccer clubs and newspapers and cellars that sell some of the world’s most expensive wines.

headline: Judge Won’t Block Rules on Abortion Drug in Arizona
text: A federal judge in Tucson has refused to block some of the strictest rules in the nation on the use of abortion drugs.

headline: The Employer’s Creed
text: Dear Employers,

headline: Competition Intensifies in Vietnam’s Aviation Sector
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Chien Anh, a restaurant manager here, used to fly on either Vietnam Airlines, the state-owned flag carrier, or the budget airline it mostly owns, Jetstar Pacific. But after the private VietJet Air started flights in 2011, Mr. Anh’s loyalty began to shift.

headline: In Gary, Ind., a ‘Gateway’ Has Become ‘the Eyesore’
text: GARY, Ind. — If one building could tell the story of this city’s hope and heartbreak, it would be the Sheraton Hotel.

headline: 3 Toyota Plants in Ontario Set to Vote in a Union Drive, as the Company Resists
text: OTTAWA — Workers at three Toyota assembly plants in Ontario will vote next week on whether to join Canada’s largest union, an effort that could create the carmaker’s only unionized shop in the country and the United States.

headline: The Pitinos Gather for a Garden Reunion
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The childhood memories came flooding back as Richard Pitino, the son of Louisville Coach Rick Pitino and a coach himself at Minnesota, told a story in his office last week. Pitino closely resembles his father, with the trademark piercing eyes and sweptback hair, and speaks with the cadence and confident manner of someone who has lived in New York all his life.

headline: Japanese Rush to Buy Before Rise in Sales Tax
text: TOKYO — March was a boom month for Askul, but the online retailer is far from happy. Shoppers racing to beat an impending increase in Japan’s national sales tax swamped Askul’s systems, snapping up toilet paper, instant rice and other essentials that will be more expensive when the rate goes up to 8 percent on Tuesday, from 5 percent.

headline: Leading the Country on Pre-K
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has every right to call the agreement between Gov. Andrew Cuomo and legislative leaders in Albany to finance a vast expansion of prekindergarten in New York City a major victory — for him politically and for tens of thousands of children who will be put on a path to a better future.

headline: Landslide’s Debris Hampers a Search for Remains
text: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The debris field left after the landslide above the community of Oso stopped its roaring downward path has drawn awe-struck comparisons to the moon, in its gray starkness apparently devoid of life, and to the volcanic landscape after Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980 near Portland, Ore.

headline: Cobalts Were Seen as Lemons From Start, State Data Shows
text: Long before the Chevrolet Cobalt became known for having a deadly ignition defect, it was already seen as a lemon. Owners complained about power steering failures, locks inexplicably opening and closing, doors jamming shut in the rain — even windows falling out.

headline: Fault Runs Deep in Ultrafast Trading
text: “The United States stock market, the most iconic market in global capitalism, is rigged.”

headline: Scrutiny for Wall Street’s Warp Speed
text: Wall Street traders are used to waking up before dawn. But on Monday, they didn’t rush to read the overnight news from Asia — it was the latest from Michael Lewis.

headline: Winner of the Wager
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle has an element in it that I, personally, find quite fun and amazing from a construction standpoint. Your mileage may vary, of course, but it seems to me that you’d have to be quite a cynic not to love a grid where two different answers fit equally well in the same square. You may be reminded of another puzzle that is the Platonic Ideal of this technique, which is the 1996 BOB DOLE/CLINTON wonder that hedged its bets by allowing either side as the winner of the presidential election.

headline: Climate Signals, Growing Louder
text: Perhaps now the deniers will cease their attacks on the science of climate change, and the American public will, at last, fully accept that global warming is a danger now and an even graver threat to future generations.

headline: A Step Toward Justice in College Sports?
text: If you were going to hold up a school as being exemplary in the way it puts athletics in, as they say, “the proper perspective,” Northwestern University would certainly be one you’d point to. For instance, although it lacks the kind of winning tradition — at least in the big-time sports — that other schools in the Big Ten can boast of, it proudly points to the 97 percent graduation rate of its athletes.

headline: Climate Study Puts Diplomatic Pressure on Obama
text: WASHINGTON — A sweeping new study on the effects of climate change — which the report says is already disrupting the lives and livelihoods of the poorest people across the planet — creates a diplomatic challenge for President Obama, who hopes to make action on both climate change and economic inequality hallmarks of his legacy.

headline: An 8th Grader, a Gun and a Bus Rider in the Way
text: Kahton Anderson had all the status symbols a 14-year-old in his world could want: Air Jordans and Reeboks, sometimes a new pair every month. Name-brand sports clothes. A new PlayStation 4.

headline: Riding the Triangle to the Pinnacle at Stanford
text: STANFORD, Calif. — One of the mysteries surrounding the Knicks’ hiring of Phil Jackson as president is whether he will hire a coach who will deploy the triangle offense. Though it is the system his teams in Chicago and Los Angeles used to win 11 championships, it exists only in bits and pieces in the N.B.A.

headline: Singapore’s O.C.B.C. Reaches Deal for Hong Kong Bank
text: HONG KONG — One of Singapore’s oldest banks said Tuesday it would pay nearly $5 billion for one of the last major family-owned banking groups in Hong Kong.

headline: After N.C.A.A. Snub, Larry Brown and S.M.U. Look Forward, Not Back
text: The band played, the cheerleaders cheered, and more than 1,000 fans joined the Hall of Fame coach Larry Brown and his players at Moody Coliseum on March 16 in anticipation of celebrating Southern Methodist’s first berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1993.

headline: Officials Urge Calm as Protests Take a Turn in Albuquerque
text: ALBUQUERQUE — After demonstrations over a string of fatal shootings by the police became so heated over the weekend that officers in riot gear lobbed tear gas at an unruly crowd, the governor of New Mexico and Albuquerque city officials urged calm on Monday and reassured a jittery public that investigations of the shootings were underway.

headline: Gas Pipes From East Harlem Blast to Undergo Further Tests
text: Parts of several pipes — some installed more than a century apart — will be tested at a laboratory in Washington as part of the investigation into the deadly gas explosion in East Harlem last month.

headline: For the Mets, a 90-Victory Goal, if Not a 90-Victory Team
text: The Mets really want to contend this season. They want their fans to believe it, and they want their players to believe it. Opening day and optimism go well together, so there was no better time for Sandy Alderson, the general manager, to deliver a rallying cry: “This team is now about being successful.”

headline: Photos: A Damp Spin Through Brooklyn
text: If you looked up through the heavy rain Saturday in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, you could just make out the silhouettes of its industrial landscape: warehouses, dock cranes, factory chimneys, even the barely discernible Statue of Liberty. If you looked left or right between umbrellas, you could see beards, tattoos, cow bells and colorful caps with inadequate brims. If you looked down, you could see drops of blood in some rain puddles. And if you blinked, well, you would have missed the point: ridiculously fast, brakeless, fixed-gear bike racing.

headline: Behind Barbed Wire, Shakespeare Inspires a Cast of Young Syrians
text: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — On a rocky patch of earth in this sprawling city of tents and prefab trailers, the king, dressed in dirty jeans and a homemade cape, raised his wooden scepter and announced his intention to divide his kingdom. His elder daughters, wearing paper crowns and plastic jewelry, showered him with false praise, while the youngest spoke truthfully and lost her inheritance.

headline: Play Ball!
text: All the action from around the major leagues in a full slate of openers.

headline: Rivals for New York Casino Licenses Must Pay Millions to Play
text: It will cost $1 million to even apply for a license.

headline: If You’re the Victim of a Tax Fraud, Tell the I.R.S.
text: Q. I got an aggressive telephone call from someone claiming to be from the Internal Revenue Service, saying I owed money. I was suspicious and hung up. If this is a fraud, is there a place to report it?

headline: Sabathia Is Sharper, Stronger and Ready to Lead Yanks
text: HOUSTON — Just as it was last season when he played for the Boston Red Sox, Jacoby Ellsbury will see the first pitch of the Yankees’ season Tuesday. Last year, Ellsbury saw a strike thrown by C. C. Sabathia.

headline: At Mozilla, a Chief’s Support of Gay Marriage Ban Causes Conflict
text: Updated. Noted that Mozilla board members left the company two weeks ago.

headline: Man Who Shot at White House Gets 25 Years
text: A federal judge sentenced an Idaho man on Monday to 25 years in prison for firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House in November 2011. A federal grand jury indicted the man, Oscar Ramiro Ortega-Hernandez, on a charge of attempting to assassinate the president and on 16 firearms and assault charges. He pleaded guilty to reduced firearms and property damage charges related to terrorism. In a video recorded before the shooting, he called himself “the modern-day Jesus Christ” and expressed frustration with the government.

headline: Capitol Corruption Panel’s Demise Angers Watchdogs
text: ALBANY — It was a quiet and sudden end to what had started as a high-profile battle against Statehouse corruption.

headline: Detroit’s Revised Debt Plan May Cut Pensions Deeper
text: The city of Detroit on Monday evening proposed new details, including potentially larger cuts to pensions for some retirees, for its plan for paying off portions of its debts and emerging this year from the nation’s largest municipal bankruptcy.

headline: Japan: Man Freed From Death Row Faces New Effort to Block a Retrial
text: Prosecutors filed an appeal on Monday to block a court from granting a retrial to a former boxer convicted of murder whose release last week after 48 years on death row exposed problems in Japan’s justice system. Prosecutors in the central city of Shizuoka challenged the decision by a district court, which said the police might have fabricated some of the evidence used to convict the former boxer, Iwao Hakamada, now 78, of killing a family of four in 1966. While the appeal will not affect the court’s decision to release Mr. Hakamada, it is seen as a face-saving move by prosecutors to prevent further scrutiny of their reliance on forced confessions and possibly shoddy police work to obtain Mr. Hakamada’s conviction and possible others.

headline: Years After Obama Hailed Warming Ties With India, the Temperature Has Fallen
text: NEW DELHI — When President Obama visited India in 2010, he called the warming relationship between it and the United States the “defining partnership of the 21st century.” Decades of disagreements, from Cold War ideological battles to squabbles over the United States’ close relationship with India’s archrival, Pakistan, would take a back seat to the many shared interests of two of the world’s largest and most diverse democracies.

headline: For a Ground Zero Developer Seeking Subsidies, More Is Never Enough
text: The developer and philanthropist Larry A. Silverstein has cut a striking figure in New York City. He owns the H.M.S. Bounty-size yacht favored by his peers and has dominated the rebuilding of ground zero for a decade.

headline: Corrections: April 1, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 1, 2014
text: “It’s a bit strange to me that you think you need to carry a gun when you’re having a cheeseburger.”

headline: Concussion Testing for Nationals’ Harper During Game
text: In the second inning of the first game of a season, Washington’s Bryce Harper charged toward second base to break up a potential double play and, in a reward for his efforts, hit his head against the leg of the Mets’ second baseman, Eric Young Jr.

headline: With Connecticut Project Stalled, Renowned Decorator Falls Out of Favor
text: THOMPSON, Conn. — Mario Buatta has decked out aristocratic homes for America’s nouveau riche, freshened up dowdy landmarks in the nation’s capital and in just five years completed a top-to-bottom transformation of a California chateau, where 98 rooms awaited his attention.

headline: Erratic Knicks Linger Just Outside a Playoff Berth
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The Knicks are a team of extremes. They build big leads, then lose them. They win close games one night, then get blown out the next. Their addiction to variety was on full display on a five-game trip that concluded Monday night with a 92-83 victory over the Utah Jazz.

headline: Runaway Barge Irks Tappan Zee Officials
text: Propelled by high winds and muscular swells, a runaway barge carrying long tubelike steel piles rushed down the choppy Hudson River on Sunday afternoon, no tugboat steering the way.

headline: Intersection: Lisbon’s Stylish Crossroads
text: In the trendy Bairro Alto neighborhood of Lisbon, Rui Palma, a college student, wears a vintage look with shiny leather boots inspired by the Velvet Underground’s “Venus in Furs.”

headline: Linda Rodin’s Memory of Her Mother, in a Bottle
text: This Mother’s Day, May 11, Linda Rodin will introduce Rodin Bis, the newest scent in her eponymous beauty line. It’s a re-creation of the way her mother smelled, as she explains here.

headline: The Refined Couch Potato
text: Three design no-nos — a sectional sofa, a swivel chair and a TV-dinner table — come together to make sloth awfully stylish.

text: Also on the Minute, open enrollment for health care ends and a look at a gun law that may affect restaurant business.

headline: Michael Stipe, Tom Morello and Questlove Among Rock Hall of Fame Presenters

text: magisterial•\ˌma-jə-ˈstir-e-əl\• adjective

headline: Lorenzo Semple Jr., Creator of TV’s ‘Batman,’ Dies at 91
text: Lorenzo Semple Jr., a playwright and screenwriter who would probably be best known for his scripts for films like “Papillon” and “Pretty Poison” if he hadn’t put the Zap! and the Pow! in the original episodes of the arch, goofy 1960s television show “Batman,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Ultraluxury Apartment Sales Drive Records in Manhattan Real Estate
text: The Manhattan real estate market got off to a robust start in the first three months of the year, as signed contracts for ultraluxury apartments in new developments began to close, many with multimillion-dollar price tags, according to reports to be released by major brokerages on Tuesday.

headline: A Comedy’s Final Twists Lead to Love and Ratings
text: A thousand and one nights came to an end in less than 60 minutes. “How I Met Your Mother” closed down on Monday with an hourlong finale crammed with all the deflection, distraction and guile that made this CBS comedy the Scheherazade of prime time.

headline: Years After Revolt, Chinese Village Glumly Returns to Polls
text: WUKAN, China — After staging a very public revolt against official corruption and then voting in remarkably unfettered democratic elections, the people who live in this southern Chinese village returned to the polls on Monday amid torrential rains and growing fears that the Communist Party was taking back control of their local government.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 5:50 P.M. (Encore) PLEASANTVILLE (1998) Gary Ross wrote and directed this fantastical tale of two teenagers, David (Tobey Maguire) and Jennifer (Reese Witherspoon), above, who are transported from the 1990s into a 1950s television sitcom. Everything is perfectly swell, until David and Jennifer accidentally jump-start artistic and sexual awakenings in some of the show’s monochromatic inhabitants (Jeff Daniels, Joan Allen and William H. Macy, among others). Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said “much of the interest here is in watching how the black-and-white scenes (filmed on color stock) begin to flower, often to the characters’ embarrassment.” She added that the film’s “unsung heroine is Jeannine Oppewall (‘L.A. Confidential’), the production designer who wittily turns the fantasy of Pleasantville into an actual place. Watch the sidewalks crack and the skirts grow less poufy as reality sets in.”

headline: Caring for the Dead: It’s the Thought That Counts
text: Too busy to care for your dead relatives? Can’t afford a train ticket home? Chinese who cannot go home and sweep family graves this weekend for the traditional “tomb sweeping” festival, known as Qingming (pronounced Chingming), can rent professional tomb sweepers from online companies.

headline: Puebla Keeps U.S. Players
text: The Mexican club Puebla said it would not release its two American defenders, DaMarcus Beasley and Michael Orozco, to join the United States national team for Wednesday’s exhibition game against Mexico in Glendale, Ariz. That is Puebla’s right, as the game does not fall on a FIFA international match date, but the decision did not sit well with United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

headline: Tortorella and Vancouver Experience Frustrating Turnabout
text: VANCOUVER — When the Rangers visit the Vancouver Canucks on April 1, there should be no doubt which team has played the fool for most of 2014.

headline: Rural Health Care Blamed for Infant Deaths in Kolkata
text: KOLKATA, India — The national headlines in September were grimmer than usual, with newspapers blaring “Infant Death Horror” and “West Bengal Health Care in I.C.U.” on their front pages after 41 newborns died in B.C. Roy Memorial Hospital over a span of six days.

headline: Junk Bond Default a Sign of China’s Slowing Growth
text: HONG KONG — China’s nascent market for domestic junk bonds has had its first default, a report in the state-run media said on Tuesday, just weeks after the country experienced its first default in the domestic corporate bond market.

headline: Actress to Take on Congress Scion in Parliamentary Race
text: NEW DELHI — A popular television actress and a Supreme Court lawyer will be challenging the two Gandhis of the Indian National Congress in the Bharatiya Janata Party’s fight for their parliamentary seats in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: 2 Koreas, After Exchanging Fire, Rearm With Insults
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A day after exchanging artillery fire across their disputed sea border, North and South Korea hurled insults at each other on Tuesday, with the North rejecting an ambitious overture from the South’s president, Park Geun-hye.

headline: American Students Test Well in Problem Solving, but Trail Foreign Counterparts
text: Fifteen-year-olds in the United States scored above the average of those in the developed world on exams assessing problem-solving skills, but they trailed several countries in Asia and Europe as well as Canada, according to international standardized tests results released on Tuesday.

headline: Test Yourself | History, April 1
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Rattlesnake Wranglers, Armed With Gasoline
text: In “Rattlesnake Wranglers, Armed With Gasoline,” Manny Fernandez writes about rattlesnake politics in Texas.

headline: What Pranks, Jokes, Hoaxes or Tricks Have You Ever Fallen For or Perpetrated?
text: Happy April Fools’ Day! How, if at all, do you “celebrate” this day? Do you tend to play tricks? To have tricks played on you? What is your reaction, in general, to pranks and hoaxes, whether those you’ve been involved in personally or famous public hoaxes like those highlighted in the Top 100 April Fools’ Day Hoaxes of All Time?

headline: An Evolving View of Animals
text: The portrait has a blunt simplicity. A chimpanzee sits with his back facing the camera. His gently lit body is nearly hairless from alopecia, and only a few strands of gray hair remain on his sandpapery scalp. A spotlight on his head reveals a reddish scar that has yet to fully heal.

headline: Hong Kong Banking Regulator Opens Inquiry Into Currency Manipulation
text: HONG KONG — The global investigation into currency market manipulation spread to another major market on Tuesday, with Hong Kong’s banking regulator saying it had opened an inquiry into several banks.

headline: Hey, Robot: Which Cat Is Cuter?
text: One recent morning, while contemplating writing this column, I scrolled through thousands and thousands of listings for mundane microgigs on Mechanical Turk, or Mturk, a decade-old platform created by Amazon. On Mturk, which advertises paid “human intelligence tasks,” I could review and correct transcriptions. I could tag images, perform a Google search, write a few sentences on a given topic, rate jokes or list items found on a receipt. For each, I would make a nickel or a quarter.

headline: Diamond’s New Venture Plans to Acquire African Bank
text: LONDON – The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by the former Barclays chief executive Robert E. Diamond Jr., has made its first purchase, a majority stake in a venture focused on the African financial sector.

headline: 1889: Among the Clouds
text: The completion of the Eiffel Tower, already announced in the HERALD, was yesterday officially commemorated by a little fête in the Champ de Mars. Towards two o’clock about a hundred and fifty persons responded to the invitation addressed to them by M. Eiffel by assembling at the foot of the tower, and afterwards toiling laboriously up the workmen’s staircase to the second platform. Among the number were several political notabilities, over a dozen Municipal Councillors and a group of ladies, undaunted by the difficulties and inconveniences of the ascent. The number of those who climbed was considerably decreased up to the third platform, and a veritable falling off took place ere the last little platform was reached, only eleven persons accompanying M. Eiffel to that elevated place.

headline: Japan Ends Decades-Long Ban on Export of Weapons
text: TOKYO — Taking his nation another step away from its postwar pacifism, the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe discarded a nearly half-century ban on the export of weapons and military hardware on Tuesday, a move aimed at helping Japan assume a larger regional security role to offset China’s growing military might.

headline: New York Today: Egg Hunting Season
text: Good Tuesday morning. It’s going to be sunny.

headline: Britain Orders Inquiry Into Muslim Brotherhood in London
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron has ordered an inquiry into the activities of the Muslim Brotherhood to determine whether it is using London as a base for planning extremist attacks after the military crackdown in Egypt, officials and news media reports said on Tuesday.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Unemployment Malaise Lingers in Euro Zone
text: PARIS — The labor market in the euro zone remains in the doldrums, official data showed on Tuesday, as the unemployment rate ticked higher in France and rose to a record in Italy.

headline: U.S. Envoy Resigns, but Grievances Linger in New Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — The resignation of the United States ambassador, Nancy J. Powell, was greeted by many in New Delhi’s diplomatic community Tuesday with a sense of hope that some of the grinding disputes between the United States and India might soon be settled.

headline: Bouygues Extends Offer for SFR and Adds Breakup Fee
text: LONDON – In the battle for Vivendi’s mobile telephone unit SFR, the French conglomerate Bouygues said on Tuesday that it had extended its revised offer by two and a half weeks and added a breakup fee of 500 million euros, or about $690 million.

headline: Merchants Disappointed by Court Ruling on Debit Swipe Fees
text: More than 20 years ago, Tom Robinson, who owns a chain of gas stations in the San Francisco Bay Area, tested a new gizmo at one of his Rotten Robbie locations. “This was before you had multi-grade dispensers and card readers and all those cool things,” Mr. Robinson said recently. “We did an early test with Bank of America where we mounted these funny little boxes on top of the dispensers on one of our locations.” The machine allowed customers to swipe a debit card to pay for their gas.

headline: Climate Report From the I.P.C.C.
text: The panel warned that rising oceans will disproportionately affect the low-lying coastal communities in developing countries.

headline: Shakespeare in the Desert
text: Syrian children at a refugee camp in Jordan performed Shakespeare’s “King Lear,” a tragedy that briefly took their minds off their own miseries.

headline: British Watchdog Says Royal Mail Sale Did Not Achieve Best Value
text: LONDON – The British government took a cautious approach in pricing the initial public offering of Royal Mail and thus failed to get the best deal for the taxpayer, the National Audit Office said on Tuesday.

headline: 11 Detained After Protesting ‘Black Jail’ in China
text: Updated, 7:47 a.m. | Eleven people, including four well-known human rights lawyers who were protesting against a “black jail” in Heilongjiang Province have been sentenced to administrative detention for “using cult activities to endanger society,” according to a notice issued Monday by the police in Jiansanjiang, a city near China’s northeastern border with Russia. The case highlights an ultra-sensitive issue — the existence and treatment of adherents of the Falun Gong, a banned religious group.

headline: Metso Confirms Offer From Rival, Sending Shares Up 20%
text: LONDON – Shares of the Finnish company Metso rose nearly 20 percent on Tuesday after it confirmed that it had been approached by a Scottish rival, the Weir Group, about a potential takeover.

headline: Abbas Takes Defiant Step, and Mideast Talks Falter
text: JERUSALEM — The Middle East peace talks verged on a breakdown Tuesday night, after President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority defied the United States and Israel by taking concrete steps to join 15 international agencies — a move to gain the benefits of statehood outside the negotiations process.

headline: Bright Passages
text: Before the fault-finding resumes, here’s another small sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions.

headline: Taking On Flash Trading
text: In his new book, “Flash Boys,” Michael Lewis describes how high-frequency trading works, highlighting a system on Wall Street that has allowed certain professional investors to pay hundreds of millions of dollars a year to locate their computer servers close to stock exchanges so they can make trades milliseconds ahead of everyone else. “There is only one problem with Mr. Lewis’s tale: He reserves blame for the wrong villains,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: World Bank to Lift Lending to Developing Countries
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank announced on Tuesday that it was nearly doubling its potential lending to so-called middle-income countries like China, India and Brazil, adding about $100 billion in new financing capacity over the next decade.

headline: A Whale of an International Court Ruling Against Japan
text: Japan has agreed to abide by a ruling from the International Court of Justice that its whaling expeditions to the Southern Ocean are not scientific research and thus forbidden under a longstanding moratorium.

headline: Escaping a Mouse Invasion
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Daily Report: Supreme Court Seems Wary of Software Patent Case
text: In a case with the potential to reshape the software industry, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed poised to issue fresh limits on patents for computer-based business methods, Adam Liptak reports.

headline: An Artist in Absentia
text: On the verge of two forthcoming painting shows, the artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel describes what it’s like to escape into his creations.

headline: JPMorgan Names Co-Heads of Equity Capital Markets for the Americas
text: JPMorgan Chase has named two specialists in initial public offerings as co-heads of equity capital markets for the Americas, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Transcript From Lost Jet Is Released By Malaysia
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Radio communications between the cockpit of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and air traffic controllers before the plane disappeared early on March 8 provide no apparent indication why the plane suddenly veered from its intended flight path to Beijing and vanished, according to a transcript released Tuesday by the Malaysian authorities.

headline: British Regulator to Use ‘Big Data’ in Antitrust Enforcement
text: LONDON – Britain’s newly formed competition regulator plans to use “big data” to identify industries where traditional players are stifling competition from online rivals, the regulator’s chairman said on Tuesday.

headline: Grandeur Under Siege
text: Shock waves rarely travel across centuries. But at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, where Lolita Chakrabarti’s “Red Velvet” opened on Monday night, you can experience firsthand what it must have felt like to be part of one seriously rattled London theater audience in 1833.

headline: The Rich Girls Are Going to Lose, for Once
text: Are there any souls out there brave enough to admit they were popular in high school? O.K., maybe Gov. Chris Christie, but that wasn’t a good career move.

headline: Permahawkery
text: Martin Feldstein warns us that the Fed isn’t taking the risk of rapidly rising inflation seriously enough. Certainly nobody can accuse him of that failing: he’s been warning about looming inflation for four years, eleven months,and two weeks, and hasn’t let the fact that inflation has kept falling below target alter his concerns in the slightest.

headline: Corporate Lobbyists Assail Tax Overhaul They Once Cheered
text: WASHINGTON — Just two days after he proposed a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s tax code, Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan, traveled to Park City, Utah, for a glittering fund-raiser attended by lobbyists from some of the nation’s largest corporations, all with enormous stakes in the tax battle to come.

headline: Seven Million
text: Many news reports are doing their best to somehow spin the final Obamacare surge as a negative story — yes, the website did go down a couple of times due to volume, which never, ever happens to commercial sites. The narrative of Obamacare-as-failure must not be challenged!

headline: In Our Pages: April 2
text: 1914: Pégoud to Fly Backwards?

headline: Ukraine Moves to Disarm Paramilitary Groups
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s Parliament on Tuesday ordered law enforcement agencies to immediately disarm unofficial paramilitary groups, signaling growing resolve in the interim government to confront nationalists and other vigilantes who played a big role in the overthrow of Viktor F. Yanukovych, the country’s pro-Kremlin former president who was deposed more than a month ago.

headline: Authorities Release First Comprehensive List of Mudslide Dead and Missing
text: Updated, 1:54 p.m. | The Snohomish County Medical Examiner’s Office announced the death toll from the Washington mudslide has risen to 27, up from 24, Reuters reported.

headline: Chefs’ Fridges by the Numbers
text: In this year’s Food and Drink Issue, we pried our way into the refrigerators of 11 New York City chefs to learn what kitchen professionals keep in stock at home. We were surprised to find a number of similarities among them, including a decidedly low supply of fresh food (with a few notable exceptions), and a high supply of indulgences like alcohol and sweets. Here’s an incomplete and unofficial tally of the more interesting items we noticed in the chefs’ fridges:

headline: What Were the First Books You Felt You ‘Should’ Read?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Dana Stevens and Anna Holmes discuss the first books they felt obliged to read.

headline: Photos: A Race Defined by Snow Finds Itself With Little
text: With 35 pounds of gear on their bikes, competitors in the Iditarod Trail Invitational in Alaska race along a 1,000-mile course as frigid and isolated as anywhere in the world.

headline: Consumers Are Still Seeing Seams in the Mobile Wallet
text: LIBBY CATHEY and her sorority sisters fumbled with pesos as they split the bill at Señor Frog’s in Cancún, Mexico, over spring break last month.

headline: American First Lady’s Visit Highlights Social Media’s Importance in China
text: Having petted a panda and trod the Great Wall, the American first lady, Michelle Obama, left China last week after a visit filled with friendly photo opportunities but also with political messages about issues such as freedom of speech.

headline: Tech Titans Are Vying to Be Your Pocketbook
text: Over the last 20 years, big technology companies like Google, Amazon and Apple have revolutionized the way people discover information, find new products and buy goods and services, like athletic socks and airline tickets.

headline: Tavern on the Green Accepting Reservations
text: It has been two years since renovations started on Tavern on the Green in Central Park, but the finish line is in sight. The restaurant will open to the public for dinner on April 24, and reservations are now being accepted.

headline: Ryan’s Budget Would Cut $5 Trillion in Spending Over a Decade
text: WASHINGTON — The unveiling Tuesday of Representative Paul D. Ryan’s newest Republican budget may have redrawn the battle lines for the 2014 election, detailing what his party could do with complete control of Congress and allowing Democrats to broaden the political terrain beyond health care and the narrower issues of the minimum wage and unemployment benefits.

headline: Tibetans Repressed in Nepal, Rights Group Finds
text: BEIJING — Under enormous pressure from China, the Nepalese government restricts the political freedoms of Tibetan refugees living in Nepal, subjects them to abuse and harassment by the security forces, and spies on them for Chinese officials, according to a report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch.

headline: Safety Delayed Is Safety Denied
text: When Congress passed a law in 2008 mandating rear-view technology in new cars, it gave the Department of Transportation until February 2011 to issue a rule telling automakers how to comply.

headline: Salonen Will Hear Lots of His Own Music in New Zurich Post
text: The composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen has been appointed to the new position, Creative Chair, at the Tonhalle Orchestra Zurich for the 2014-15 season, the orchestra announced. The position includes workshops and lectures, as well as a new work, to be commissioned jointly by the Swiss orchestra, the New York Philharmonic, the Bamberg Symphony, the Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra and the Swedish Radio Symphony Orchestra.

headline: U.N. Issues New Warnings on Central African Republic
text: GENEVA — Fighting involving Christian militias, Muslims and foreign troops has killed more than 60 people and wounded more than 100 in the past 10 days in Bangui, Central African Republic, United Nations officials said Tuesday, warning that security was deteriorating and appealing for more peacekeeping troops and police officers.

headline: National Front Wins Support and Elections
text: PARIS — The vast exposition hall in the dilapidated southern French town of Perpignan was standing room only on a recent Saturday, and the crowd was chanting, as if for a sports star: “Marine! Marine! Marine!”

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Modest Mouse and Flaming Lips to Headline Hudson Project Festival
text: Kendrick Lamar, Modest Mouse and Flaming Lips are among the acts who will perform at the inaugural Hudson Project, a three-day festival of music and art that will be held in Saugerties, N.Y., in July, its organizers said on Tuesday. The Hudson Project, which was announced last month and will run from July 11 through 13, will feature more than 85 different musical artists across four different stages.

headline: If Ivy League Is the Endgame, I’m Not Sure I Want to Play
text: “A consultant got my daughter into uptown Montessori,” one mom said. We were nearing decision week and we mothers were huddled in the indoor playground, frantically discussing — what else — our preschool attempts. “It’s a Dalton-feeder.”

headline: New Bikes for Bordeaux
text: With the launch of the first fleet of Philippe Starck-designed bicycles in Bordeaux, the city’s image as one of Europe’s most cycle-friendly metropolises is getting an update.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Yankees Lose Season Opener in Houston
text: The Yankees could not recover from C.C. Sabathia’s ugly start and lost the season opener, 6-2., to the Houston Astros. Continue reading for highlights and analysis.

headline: GrubHub Raises Price Range for I.P.O.
text: GrubHub, the online food ordering service familiar to legions of office workers, has raised its expectations for its Wall Street debut.

headline: At Justice Department, a Watchdog on Graft Finds Its Teeth Again
text: WASHINGTON — When Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., two months into his tenure, dismissed all corruption charges against former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, it was an embarrassing nadir for the Justice Department section responsible for prosecuting politicians accused of misconduct.

headline: Diet’s Link to Longevity: After 2 Studies Diverge, a Search for Consensus
text: Two rival research groups set out in 1987 to answer a tantalizing question: Could a diet kept meager in calories pay off in longevity?

headline: For Some, a Relic Stings as a Shrine to Nazism
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — A lonely fireplace chimney sprouts two dozen feet high from a tidy vacant lot, not far from the tidal push and pull of the Ashley River. The only heat it gives is from being at the center of a dispute over that most mundane of issues, zoning.

headline: Professor Says Cable Channel Suspended Her Interview Series With Modi
text: NEW DELHI – Until Tuesday, the Indian cable channel News X was breathlessly billing its six-part series featuring the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister as “Narendra Modi’s first interview” before the elections, while its executives went on Twitter to hype the “new details” the controversial politician would reveal.

headline: Rolling Stones to Resume Tour
text: The Rolling Stones will resume their “14 on Fire” tour at the Telenor Arena in Oslo on May 26, the group announced on Monday. The Stones had canceled its concerts in Australia and New Zealand after the fashion designer L’Wren Scott, who was Mick Jagger’s girlfriend, was found dead in her New York apartment on March 17. The group said at the time that those concerts would be rescheduled, but the new dates have not yet been announced.

headline: Today in Small Business: Erosion
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Report Traces Port Authority’s Flaws to a Crumbling Business Model
text: For years, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been an easy target — a behemoth so politicized that its role in the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge last year is perhaps the scandal’s least surprising element.

headline: In Performance: John Douglas Thompson
text: John Douglas Thompson performs a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” Terry Teachout’s play about the life of the singer and trumpeter Louis Armstrong.

headline: Before a Hearing on G.M. Defects, Document Points to an Inconsistency
text: WASHINGTON — As a House subcommittee prepared to open a hearing on the Chevrolet Cobalt defects and why it took so long for General Motors to issue a recall, House investigators released a document Tuesday that showed a G.M. engineer approved a critical change to a faulty ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Chinese Ambition With a Hefty Price Tag
text: The Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation is paying a hefty price to expand in China. The Singaporean company is realizing a long-held ambition by acquiring the Wing Hang Bank of China. But the deal, at almost $5 billion, looks expensive at a time when growth on the mainland is slowing and the Federal Reserve’s tapering is threatening to push up deposit costs.

headline: Mortar and Bricks Divide a Charleston Community
text: A chimney built by German P.O.W.s now sits on land owned by a Jewish family with deep roots in Charleston.

headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ Gets Its Best Ratings for Finale
text: CBS’s hit comedy “How I Met Your Mother” exited to what amounted to a standing ovation on Monday night — from viewers, if not critics — scoring the best ratings in the show’s nine-season history.

headline: Obama Claims Victory in Push for Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared victory Tuesday in the government’s aggressive push to enroll seven million people in private health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act, even as his senior aides braced for an escalated political battle over the law ahead of the fall’s crucial midterm elections.

headline: New York Tax Credit to Encourage Theater Productions Upstate
text: New York has passed a tax credit aimed at persuading Broadway producers and others to use upstate theaters as rehearsal halls and construction shops for shows going out on national tour. The 2014-15 state budget, passed by the legislature on Monday, includes a credit that would cover 25 percent of production-related costs for shows that prepare their road tours at theaters outside of the five boroughs. Theaters in upstate cities like Buffalo, Rochester, Elmira and elsewhere are most likely to be used, given their size and availability.

headline: Back Surgery Puts Woods Out of the Masters for the First Time Since 1994
text: Knee problems could not keep Tiger Woods out of the Masters. He placed second in 2008 in the fifth of six starts he made before having season-ending surgery.

headline: Red Hook Criterium
text: Amid rain and fog, more than 280 riders of all levels participated in the Red Hook Criterium in Brooklyn, N.Y., last Saturday.

headline: Le Pen Reacts to Provisional Results
text: As talks of a government reshuffling grew, the leader of France’s National Front party, Marine Le Pen, spoke about the record win in local elections for her far-right party on March 30.

headline: A Reporter Clutches Life After a Loss That Hits Home
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — I once asked my mother sarcastically why she and my dad had six children. She looked at me patiently and said, “Because we were not sure that all of you would survive.”

headline: Universal Music Group Breaks Up Its Island Def Jam Division
text: Universal Music Group, the giant record company that sells almost 40 percent of the world’s music, made a series of structural changes on Tuesday, splitting up one of its major divisions and displacing Barry Weiss, the former Sony executive who was brought in three years ago to run the company’s East Coast operations.

headline: Spanish-Language ‘Vagina Monologues’ to Play at Westside Theater
text: Eve Ensler’s theatrical feminist empowerment manifesto, “The Vagina Monologues,” was a hot property for the Westside Theater, where it ran for 1,381 performances between 1999 and 2003. Now the show is returning to the Westside, but in a new form – as “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” a Spanish version modeled on the production that has been running in Mexico City for the last 14 years. Performances begin on May 6.

headline: A Blazing Iditarod Trail
text: Alaska’s unseasonably warm winter created long stretches of snowless track and record finish times for the Iditarod Trail Invitational.

headline: Elbow Injury Threatens Parnell’s Season
text: It had not been an easy spring for Mets closer Bobby Parnell. He was trying to regain his strength after having neck surgery last September, but his progress seemed slow. The Mets shrugged it off, but on Monday, when he blew a save in the first game of the season, his velocity was still too low. Afterward, he complained of tightness in his right forearm, and on Tuesday, he was examined at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe: I’d Love to Do ‘Rosencrantz and Guildenstern’
text: Daniel Radcliffe may be focused on starting performances April 12 in his next Broadway play, “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” but he also has other shows in mind that he would like to do in the future. During a TimesTalk event on Monday night, Mr. Radcliffe – a box office draw after playing the title character in the eight “Harry Potter” films – was asked about plays and musicals that he might like to do in the years ahead.

headline: Image of the Day: April 1
text: A man taking a bow before a bronze bull outside the Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Victims’ Families on Cobalt Problems
text: Family members of those involved in crashes of the Chevrolet Cobalt spoke at a press conference in Washington ahead of a House hearing about General Motors on Tuesday.

headline: Rice University Picks Design Team for New Opera Theater
text: A new opera theater for Rice University’s music school in Houston will be designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the university is to announce Wednesday.

headline: Times Minute | A Day of Israeli Diplomacy
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Israeli Diplomacy
text: On the Minute, how American students excel at problem solving and record times on this year’s Iditarod Trail Invitational.

headline: In Performance: John Douglas Thompson of ‘Satchmo at the Waldorf’
text: This week’s video features the actor John Douglas Thompson in a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show, written by Terry Teachout, about the life of the jazz trumpeter and singer Louis Armstrong. In this scene Mr. Thompson plays both Armstrong and Joe Glaser, his manager of 40 years. The show, directed by Gordon Edelstein, is at the Westside Theater.

headline: Bookshelf | A Guide to New York’s Hidden Oases of Calm
text: Somewhere in Manhattan, a lone peacock struts past the quince and laurel in a churchyard garden; further uptown, a Beaux-Arts mansion opens its doors onto a massive, storied collection of Spanish art; in Brooklyn, hung-over yogis rise and unroll their mats under a ceiling draped in silk. These are the sorts of tranquil scenes toward which Siobhan Wall’s “Quiet New York” (Frances Lincoln, out today)— a slim, illustrated guide to the city’s “hidden corners and unexpected vistas” — steers both tourists and natives seeking solace and refuge in a city where both are hard to come by.

headline: Federal Funding for Maternal and Infant Visits Extended — Briefly
text: It’s the quip that extends across class and culture: Babies don’t come with instruction manuals. But for parents of means, they can come with help in the form of visiting doulas or night nannies, and for parents with local family, help (or “help”) might be readily available. The universal is that every new parent needs a hand, and many families find it in what are formally known as Maternal, Infant and Early Childhood Home Visiting Programs.

headline: Highlights From House Hearing on G.M. Defects
text: As our colleagues Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald report, Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, and David Friedman, the nation’s top auto safety regulator, faced a House panel Tuesday investigating why both the automaker and regulators failed to act for more than 10 years on an ignition defect that G.M. has now linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Families Urge G.M. to Get Defective Vehicles Off the Road
text: WASHINGTON — Relatives of accident victims who died in cars recalled by General Motors joined members of Congress in urging G.M. to tell people to stop driving vehicles with defective ignition switches until repairs are made.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs, British All Around
text: My dinner date had eaten in this room before. A Williams College graduate, she remembered its earlier incarnation as the school’s alumni club.

headline: Inventive Kitchen Mixes Chocolate and Chicken
text: LOS ANGELES — The creators of Umami Burger, who boasted of producing a whole new taste and who went on to expand from a single Los Angeles restaurant to a national franchise, are hoping to do the same thing again, this time with chicken. And chocolate.

headline: Russia Tightens Pressure on Ukraine With Rise in Natural Gas Price
text: MOSCOW — Even as American and Russian diplomats groped toward a settlement that would halt further Russian military intervention in Ukraine, Gazprom, the Russian energy company, stepped up the economic pressure on Tuesday by sharply raising the price it charges for natural gas.

headline: Inside the (Smaller) Bank Branch of the Future
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio – Inside the low-slung, nondescript beige building on the edge of an industrial parking lot here, JPMorgan Chase executives are conducting a vast experiment to construct bank branches of the future — complete with cash machines unlocked by palm and iris scanners instead of debit cards. They hope the new branches will fundamentally upend Americans’ relationship with banking.

headline: Steelhead Drive Is Gone After Mudslide, Along With Many Lives Lived on It
text: OSO, Wash. — The words, recorded by the Snohomish County emergency response system in the frantic minutes after a giant wall of earth slid down the mountain here on the morning of March 22, were breathy and labored. “All the homes on Steelhead Drive are gone,” a man said with long pauses between his words.

headline: A Big Biden Deal
text: Now that Obamacare has finished with an amazing surge in signups, apparently passing the 7 million mark for the exchanges, there have been two main responses. Republicans are in full-on denial — the books are cooked! Nobody has paid! It’s only because people have been forced to do it! Benghazi! Vince Foster! Meanwhile, progressives are full of caution. It’s just a start, we don’t know how well this will work in the longer run, too soon to celebrate.

headline: Essay: The Real Competition to Virtual Currency
text: BITCOIN enthusiasts may want to study a satirical etching, published in 1792, that is now in a collection at London’s National Portrait Gallery. In one half, titled “French Liberty,” an emaciated French revolutionary gnaws on raw onions. In the other, “British Slavery,” a corpulent Englishman feasts on a giant slab of meat. The etching’s message — that a revolution is a farce if it fails to provide the basics — hangs uneasily over the world of virtual currencies.

headline: Marijuana by the Washington Monument
text: You may soon be able to gaze at the Washington Monument with marijuana in your pocket, risking nothing more than a small fine.

headline: Anna Gunn and Billy Magnussen to Star in ‘Sex With Strangers’
text: The Emmy Award-winning actress Anna Gunn (“Breaking Bad”) and the Tony Award-nominated actor Billy Magnussen (“Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike”) will star this summer in Second Stage Theater’s production of Laura Eason’s drama, “Sex With Strangers,” the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Addressing Harassment on the Streets and Subways of New York City
text: City Room asked readers in February to share their stories of street and subway harassment in New York City. We received almost 200 blog comments and emails.

headline: G.M. Hires Lawyer Specializing in Disaster Payouts
text: WASHINGTON — As families of crash victims lined the back of the House hearing room, displaying photos of their lost loved ones, Mary T. Barra, the General Motors chief executive, told lawmakers that the company was considering paying damages to victims of accidents in the millions of cars recalled for defective ignition switches.

headline: Stupidity in Economic Discourse 2
text: I’ve written before about the myth of the stupid progressive economist.Many conservative economists have a fixed idea in their heads — it’s more than just a presumption, because it seems completely impervious to evidence — that progressive economists are dumb guys who don’t understand basic economics. And because of this fixed idea, conservatives appear literally unable to read what my side writes; they criticize the dumb things they’re sure we must have said, without checking to see if that’s what we actually said.

headline: NATO to Firm Up Its Presence in Eastern Europe as It Halts Cooperation With Russia
text: BRUSSELS — NATO’s foreign ministers vowed on Tuesday to strengthen the alliance’s military presence on the territory of its Eastern European members because of Russia’s military intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Sharon Jones and Robert Cray to Play Blues Festival in Lower Manhattan
text: Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings and the Robert Cray Band are among the groups that will perform at the Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, a pair of free outdoor concerts at Brookfield Place in Battery Park City on July 16 and 17. The festival, now in its fourth year, is presented by Arts Brookfield, a real estate concern that presents free arts programming at Brookfield Place, formerly the World Financial Center, and at several of its other properties.

headline: Goldman Explores Sale of Market-Making Unit
text: Goldman Sachs, a fixture on Wall Street for more than 100 years, has decided to part with a business at the symbolic heart of the industry: the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: The Gun Report: April 1, 2014
text: An article on the front page of today’s Times tells the story of Kahton Anderson, the 14-year-old who climbed aboard a bus in Brooklyn, N.Y., on March 20, armed with a silver .357 revolver he meant to fire at another teenager. Instead he hit 39-year-old Angel Rojas, who was on his way home between his two jobs, killing him. The story also offers a snapshot of gang life in New York City, where small slights between rival crews loom large both on the turf they inhabit and on the Internet.

headline: After Rough Winter, Auto Sales Jumped in March
text: The auto market rebounded in March from a harsh winter that stunted steady sales gains in the United States. On Tuesday, automakers reported strong growth, exceeding analysts’ expectations and suggesting that in spite of sharp declines early in the year, some companies might meet quarterly targets.

headline: Let Us Introduce Ourselves
text: Ever wonder not just about what is in the news but how decisions about the news are made?

headline: On the Verge | Into the Light
text: The avant-garde designer Philippe Malouin steps out of his famous mentor’s shadow.

headline: European Finance Ministers Approve New Loans for Greece
text: ATHENS — Euro zone finance ministers, meeting in Athens under tight security on Tuesday, approved the release of 8.3 billion euros in rescue loans to Greece, pointing to signs that the country is emerging from its economic crisis.

headline: A Nudge on Digital Privacy Law From E.U. Official
text: BRUSSELS — The top data protection official for the European Union called Tuesday for member governments to restore public trust in the Internet by pressing ahead with an overhaul of the bloc’s electronic privacy laws by the end of this year.

headline: A Primer on Northwestern Players’ Quest to Unionize
text: Two months ago, a group called the College Athletes Players Association submitted a petition to the National Labor Relations Board in Chicago seeking to have Northwestern’s football team recognized as a union.

headline: With Plane Still Missing, Legal Moves for Payouts Start
text: BEIJING — For 10 days, Monica R. Kelly and her American law firm’s aviation lawyers have stalked the dim hallways of the Lido Hotel here to make their pitches to relatives of passengers aboard missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Online Reviews? Keep This in Mind
text: The size and racial makeup of a city, the price of a meal and even the weather can skew the quality and quantity of online restaurant reviews, according to the first large-scale academic study to analyze how outside factors affect crowd-sourced review sites.

headline: Owner of American Lawyer Said to Put Publisher Up for Sale
text: The owner of American Lawyer, one of the mainstay magazines for the legal industry, has put the magazine’s publisher up for sale, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: The Scuffin Takes the Cake
text: Last week, we reported on a surge of creativity in American bakeries inspired by the Cronut: a croissant-doughnut hybrid that has brought its creator, the New York pastry chef Dominique Ansel, fame and fortune. The race to invent the next celebrity Frankenpastry is afoot, and we asked you to pick among some front-runners — like the mallomac (part Mallomar, part macaron) and the pie milkshake (a miniature pie blended into a shake) — as the recipe you’d most like to make at home.

headline: A Bowl of Berries Left to Dry in the Sun
text: Lydia Davis’s short stories are difficult to describe, but people like to try. A friend of mine likens them to mosquitoes. Some you swat away, he says. Others draw blood.

headline: On Coates v. Chait
text: Over the last two weeks, New York Magazine’s Jonathan Chait and The Atlantic’s Ta-Nehisi Coates, two of the internet’s most admired liberal journalists, have engaged in an extended back-and-forth about the legitimacy of public critiques of cultural dysfunction in poor, inner-city African-American culture — and particularly the kind of critiques offered by President Obama, who often speaks exhortatively about personal and parental responsibility in addresses to black audiences. My impression (drawn from Twitter) is that many readers following the debate felt that Coates essentially won it with his most recent entry, a rich brief for the proposition that even (or especially?) coming from the lips of an African-American president, a disproportionate rhetorical focus on black pathology, black moral failure, and black dysfunction simply perpetuates modern American society’s habit of (to rewrite a famous Malcolm X line that Coates quotes) congratulating itself for pulling its knife partway out of black America’s back and then blaming the victim when he still has trouble walking.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic, One of Soccer’s Brashest Stars, Reveals a Quieter Side
text: PARIS — For more than a decade, Zlatan Ibrahimovic has carried a reputation as soccer’s bad boy, not so much a 6-foot-5 striker but a highlight-making, coach-criticizing, teammate-punching lightning rod whose inflated scoring totals were matched in size only by his ego.

headline: G.M.’s Barra Apologizes
text: The chief executive of General Motors, Mary Barra, opened the hearing with an apology to the families of the victims involved in crashes of the company’s cars.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, China, Greece and Ukraine.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Book Riles Tempers on CNBC
text: The new book by Michael Lewis has inflamed passions across Wall Street, stoking a debate over the business of high-frequency trading.

headline: Alvin Ailey to Bring New Work to Koch Theater
text: A world premiere from Robert Moses, the company premiere of Asadata Dafora’s 1932 solo “Awassa Astrige/Ostrich” and new productions by David Parsons and Hans van Manen are among the highlights of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s two-week engagement at Lincoln Center from June 11 to June 22.

headline: Checking In on the Members of Our Business Group
text: We started the She Owns It business group more than two years ago to offer a window into the real-life business challenges of owners who happen to be women. Since then, the group has met monthly to discuss topics such as hiring, health insurance, manufacturing, growing pains and customer service. Its composition has changed over the years as members have rotated in and out.

headline: Do The Right Thing: Making Ethical Decisions in Everyday Life
text: Overview | Something happens — a moment of injustice, a threat to the nation, a potentially criminal act. Why do some people speak out or take action, while others remain silent? And how can we encourage more people to recognize the moment when bravery is required?

headline: Running Late? Push Federal Tax Day Back to October
text: Two weeks remain before the April 15 deadline for filing your federal income tax return. But what if you don’t think you will be able to file your return on time?

headline: Artful Knives, a Guide for Beginner Chefs, an Icy Cocktail and More
text: To Wield: An Artful Collection Forged by Hand

headline: Japan Center Questions Stem Cell Breakthrough
text: TOKYO — A study once hailed as a breakthrough in creating stem cells contained fabricated and doctored images that cast doubt on its findings, a Japanese research institute concluded on Tuesday in a blistering investigation into a case that has become a major embarrassment for the country’s scientific community.

headline: Getting the Jump on Mosquitoes
text: Thwack! Bitten. Again.

headline: Lynda Carter’s Travel Tips, From Water to Walking
text: Although most people know Lynda Carter from her memorable role in the “Wonder Woman” television series, she has actually spent more time singing jazz than swinging a lasso of truth. She left Phoenix, her hometown, in the late 1960s, when she was still a teenager, to sing with different bands, touring from the Las Vegas Strip, in its ’70s heyday, to the Catskills and back again.

headline: Ridgefield, Conn.: Upscale Americana
text: People moving to Fairfield County from other regions of the country often suffer sticker shock when they begin house-hunting. But that was not the case for Rebecca and Peter Cook, who relocated to Ridgefield from San Francisco two years ago for Mr. Cook’s job with IBM. Coming from one of the most expensive housing markets in the country, the Cooks weren’t intimidated by Ridgefield’s $600,000-plus median home price. Rather, they were entranced by the three-century-old town’s signature village center, with its broad, tree-lined Main Street, grand historic homes and charming downtown storefronts.

headline: Checks Are Expendable, but in Legal Tender We Trust
text: THE financial industry may be fixated on virtual currencies and credit card technologies, but don’t declare cash an endangered species just yet.

headline: The Cashless Society Meets the Loose-Change Economy
text: MAJ. RON BUSROE of the Salvation Army has no doubt that people are carrying a lot less cash.

headline: Howard M. Lorber
text: Mr. Lorber, 65, is the chairman of Douglas Elliman Real Estate, as well as the president and chief of both the Vector Group and its real estate investment subsidiary New Valley Realty, which is a majority owner of Douglas Elliman. He is also the executive chairman of the fast-food chain Nathan’s Famous.

headline: The Credit Card of Tomorrow: Software, Not Plastic
text: SINCE the 1970s, paying with plastic has been pretty standard everywhere: Customers swiped their cards, signed receipts and took home their purchases.

headline: To Instill Love of Bitcoin, Backers Work to Make It Safe
text: SAN FRANCISCO – BITCOIN’S future may not rely on stabilizing its price swings or signing up more merchants to accept the virtual currency. Rather, it may rely on its image.

headline: Tessa Opens, a Restaurant With a ‘Mostly Mediterranean’ Approach
text: Headliner

headline: Tap to Pay (Not So Much in the U.S.)
text: LONDON — Science fiction writers have long envisioned a cashless society. But some places have taken bigger steps in that direction than others.

headline: A Nostalgia Ride With a Driving Ensemble Behind the Wheel
text: At a single concert on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s audience got what amounted to two recitals for the price of one. That was the good news.

headline: From Slave Ship Shackles to the Mountaintop
text: MEMPHIS — The climax of the sweeping new exhibition at the National Civil Rights Museum here is almost painfully mundane. An open container of milk and a half-drunk cup of coffee sit on a table near a 1960s television topped by rabbit-ear antennas. A peach-colored bedspread is pulled back, and the remains of a catfish lunch are nearby. Pale yellow curtains are open to the balcony outside. We are looking at Room 306 of the Lorraine Motel.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 72
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: The Critics’ Take: What You Should See, Hear, Visit Now
text: You’re busy and looking for guidance. You want to know what The Times’s culture critics think you should see, hear or read this month. Here’s what they recommend.

headline: A Skype Founder and a Famous Smoothie Maker Swap Tales in London
text: LONDON — On a wet British morning, small groups of entrepreneurs sat huddled around tables in a converted warehouse in East London, swapping advice and stories about their companies.

headline: NYT Newsroom Timelapse
text: What it’s like inside The New York Times Newsroom

headline: Scribd Adds Lonely Planet Guides to Its Roster
text: While travel trend reports continue to predict the death of the printed guidebook, Lonely Planet seems to have found a way to keep its popular printed guides very much alive, through a more digitally friendly, and lighter, interface.

headline: Cleveland’s Thriving Theater Hub Lures Residents
text: CLEVELAND — When a national tour of “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat” played here last month, Vincent Wil Hawley walked from his apartment at Residences at Hanna, a new 102-unit conversion in a renovated office building annex, and was in his seat five minutes later.

headline: Letter Tells of U.S. Searches for Emails and Calls
text: WASHINGTON — United States intelligence analysts have searched for Americans’ emails and phone calls within the repository of communications that the government collects without a warrant, according to a letter from James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, to Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon.

headline: Delayed by Stubborn Winter, Spring’s Colors Are Ready to Burst
text: When scattered snowflakes fell on the last day of March, New Yorkers might have been forgiven for thinking spring would never arrive. But with the weather predicted to warm up this week, plant experts say they may finally be in for a treat: a simultaneous burst of color, as flowering species that normally bloom in succession instead paint the landscape pink, yellow and white all at once.

headline: Dangerous Roads, Constant Crises: Adam Nossiter on Central Africa
text: After covering the American South for two decades, Adam Nossiter became the West and Central Africa bureau chief for The Times in 2009. Since then, he has seen villages charred by fires set in the Central African Republic during a sectarian civil war. He has reported on France’s intervention in the war in Mali, the bloody end to the 2013 hostage crisis in Algeria and Nigeria’s continuing fight with the terrorist group Boko Haram. He has also portrayed the everyday lives of people whose countries are working to build the kind of governments that many outside the continent take for granted. His beat extends across at least 25 countries.

headline: Obama on Health Care Enrollment Numbers
text: President Obama delivered a statement after more than seven million people signed up by a deadline for health insurance through exchanges under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Laurie Colwin: A Confidante in the Kitchen
text: Emily Gould stood in an Upper West Side kitchen on a Saturday evening and gazed into a crumb-encrusted pan full of creamed spinach. “It kind of suffered on the subway a little bit,” she said.

headline: Wells Fargo Names New C.F.O.
text: Wells Fargo reshuffled some its top executives on Tuesday, naming a new chief financial officer and a new head of wholesale banking.

headline: Where’s Satoshi Nakamoto?
text: Bitcoin was created by an anonymous computer programmer, or group of computer programmers, known only as “Satoshi Nakamoto.” See if you can spot him here.

headline: Nothing Up His Sleeve, Just a Knack for Deception
text: On the night I attended “Charlatan,” a solid magic show decked out in theatrical finery, its star, Vinny DePonto, first appeared on a video screen before the sound went mute and the production ground to a halt. After a break, he ditched the opening and started again, this time live onstage. Embarrassing? Sure. Did the technical difficulties hurt the evening? Yes and no.

headline: Meryl Streep to Star as a Rocker for TriStar
text: LOS ANGELES – Meryl Streep, hard rocker?

headline: Old Forecast of Famine May Yet Come True
text: Might Thomas Malthus be vindicated in the end?

headline: Not Giving an Inch in a Battle of Wits and Words
text: In 2003 the journalist Hart Seely published “Pieces of Intelligence: The Existential Poetry of Donald H. Rumsfeld,” a book that arranged some of the public pronouncements of that secretary of defense into spiky, evocative morsels of free verse. Mr. Rumsfeld may have been an accidental poet, but “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris’s new documentary about him, nonetheless makes an implicit argument for his literary distinction. Not only does Mr. Rumsfeld revel in his status as the proud and prolific author — via his beloved Dictaphone — of memos known at the Pentagon as “snowflakes,” but he also shows himself to be a man fascinated by language and delighted by his ability to use it.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Revolution in Money
text: Imagine it’s 2040.

headline: A Wild Ride Returns. Confused?
text: It takes a wild, warped and sweeping literary imagination to join Jean-Paul Sartre, Condoleezza Rice, Britney Spears and Wassily Kandinsky in a single script. John Jesurun has one. Since 1982, he has written and directed “Chang in a Void Moon,” an absurdist serial about a businessman’s efforts to bilk a wealthy family. Last week, after a nine-year hiatus, the first of three new episodes debuted at Incubator Arts Project. (The next runs Friday through Sunday; the third runs April 11 to 13.)

headline: Tuneful Paul Simon Tribute Bridges Decades
text: Folkies, pop crooners, punks and soul singers could all latch onto something from the catalog of Paul Simon on Monday night at Carnegie Hall. “The Music of Paul Simon,” with about two dozen performers playing a song each, was the 10th annual all-star songwriter tribute at Carnegie Hall produced by Michael Dorf of City Winery. It’s a series of benefit concerts that has raised nearly a million dollars for music education. Among the performers was a duo of 13-year-old songwriters, Megan Doyle and Snow Guilfoyle, from one of the beneficiary institutions, the Church Street School for Music and Art, singing the contrapuntal “Scarborough Fair/Canticle.”

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
text: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.

headline: Bid to Free Ex-Marine Held in Iran Cites Father’s Health
text: The doctor for the terminally ill father of Amir Hekmati, the 30-year-old former Marine imprisoned in Iran, has written to the Iranian judicial authorities asking them to release Mr. Hekmati on compassionate grounds so he can return home, according to a copy of the letter shared by the family on Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Today Detroit, Tomorrow the World’ Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A French Artist’s Vision of Voguing
text: Frédéric Nauczyciel can’t remember when he learned about voguing, the dance form characterized by the poses that emulate those in the pages of Vogue, or the first time he saw “Paris Is Burning,” the iconic 1990 documentary on New York’s ball dance culture that touched on the city’s vogue scene. “It’s like it’s always been there for me,” he says. But three years ago, contemporary voguers in two cities an ocean apart began to captivate Nauczyciel so much that they are now the subject of his first New York exhibition, “The Fire Flies (Baltimore / Paris),” which opens tomorrow at Julie Meneret Contemporary Art.

headline: Here is your evening in photos.
text: All you need to know in photos.

headline: Low Vitamin D Levels Linked to Disease in Two Big Studies
text: People with low vitamin D levels are more likely to die from cancer and heart disease and to suffer from other illnesses, scientists reported in two large studies published on Tuesday.

headline: An Enigma, Bound by Chaos, Staged by a Veteran Choreographer
text: Any opportunity to see the dancer Cori Kresge is welcome. When she was a member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company’s Repertory Understudy Group, her steely, sensuous strength and staggering facility made you question her status as an “understudy.” In works by the Cunningham alumni Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener, she has been just as incisive, if more animal, almost otherworldly, in what seems like her insatiable need to be dancing.

headline: Inhaled Insulin Clears Hurdle Toward F.D.A. Approval
text: A government advisory committee on Tuesday recommended approval of a form of insulin that is inhaled rather than injected. The endorsement could lead to a new option for millions of Americans with diabetes and vindication for the persistent billionaire who spent a large amount of his fortune to develop the product.

headline: The Profits and Losses of Fugitive Tracking
text: A tough, tender little movie, “The Retrieval” tells a story of divided souls wandering a divided land. It takes place in 1864, the year before the Civil War ended, and opens in the dead of night. As cannons boom in the distance, a 13-year-old black boy, a seeming runaway, takes refuge in a barn guarded by a white woman with a long gun. Shortly after the boy settles in next to a few black fugitives — one silently hands him food — he slips out to alert his employers, white bounty hunters who quickly torch the barn and capture the fugitives, who fetch as much as $600 a head.

headline: Here is your evening in photos.
text: All you need to know in photos.

headline: Cartier Moves North From Perch on Fifth Avenue
text: For the next two years, Cartier’s signature spotted panther will loom over the jeweler’s Fifth Avenue flagship store, gazing intently from the top of a mesh drape over the building as it undergoes extensive renovation.

Free a Spy to Help Save the Mideast Talks?

headline: Good Wine, Bad Companions and a Nude Stroll in an Olive Grove
text: There is, perhaps, only so much to say about a movie that opens with a man delivering a soliloquy about his penis. When you first see the title character of “Dom Hemingway,” a violent British comedy about a gangster who talks the hard-boiled talk with verve and gutter lyricism, he’s speaking and staring into the camera. His arms are stretched out to the side, Christlike, and while the camera doesn’t show the full monty, the shot is wide enough for you to see that Jude Law has packed on a few pounds to play this flamboyant tough guy and hasn’t taken a Gillette to his chest.

headline: Emotional Learning
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Church’s Efforts to Prevent Future Child Abuse
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chamber Works of a Chameleon, Sonorous to Surreal
text: It has been up to the Austrian Cultural Forum the past few months to provide what the Vienna Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall’s Vienna: City of Dreams festival largely did not: a range of Austrian composers who were suppressed by the Nazis.

headline: Wearing Three Hats, All From One Seat
text: The sight of a star soloist simultaneously conducting and performing a concerto has become fairly common. But the violinist Joshua Bell, who took over as music director of the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields nearly three years ago, reaches back to an 18th-century tradition in that he also leads performances from the concertmaster’s chair: He’s not just having his cake and eating it — he helps bake it, too.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Aging Church Passes Digital Collection Plate
text: ROME — Not far from the banks of the Tiber River, the 800-year-old church of St. Francis at Ripa has never been one of Rome’s most famous destinations. A quietly glorious Baroque sanctuary, with a famous statue by Bernini tucked into a side chapel, it has often been overlooked by tourists and Roman Catholics in a city so rich with other splendors.

headline: A Home Fixup Campaign for the Web
text: IKEA is sending five American employees on a yearlong road trip to provide families with makeovers that use merchandise from local Ikea stores. The results will be featured in a web video series chronicled by the employees and produced by Ikea.

headline: Ebola Reaches Capital of Guinea, Stirring Fears
