text: DAKAR, Senegal — An outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in the West African nation of Guinea has reached the crowded capital, Conakry, prompting new fears about its spread, health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Landslide Debris Slows Search
text: The division supervisor for the eastern portion of the landslide in Oso, Wash., said there was a vast amount of material to move, including crushed vehicles and downed trees.

headline: Newly Enrolled, but Not Counted by Insurance Exchanges
text: Millions of newly insured people are hiding in plain sight.

headline: Boy Scouts Dismiss a Gay Troop Leader in Seattle
text: Nearly a year after announcing that it would admit gay boys but still prohibit openly gay leaders from its ranks, the Boy Scouts of America has dismissed a gay scoutmaster.

headline: House Members Grill G.M.’s Barra
text: Members of the House Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee questioned Mary Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, during a hearing on the company’s safety problems.

headline: Student Athletes Shouldn’t Unionize
text: NEWARK, Del. — LAST week’s ruling by a regional director of the National Labor Relations Board that players on Northwestern University’s football team were school employees, and thus eligible to unionize, has been celebrated by those who believe that it will benefit student athletes everywhere.

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
text: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament,” captures the mind and eye of the late war photographer. But to those who knew him, it’s a chance to continue conversations started long ago.

headline: Venezuela: A Call for Peace
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — THE recent protests in Venezuela have made international headlines. Much of the foreign media coverage has distorted the reality of my country and the facts surrounding the events.

headline: Final Four Games Get Local Accents, Sort Of
text: Turner and CBS Sports stretched a bit to find announcing teams for Saturday’s Final Four teamcasts — the university-specific productions on TNT and truTV that will be shown against the traditional versions of the games on TBS. Only one announcer chosen called a full season of the colleges’ games on radio. The rest are from local, regional or conference TV — and not all are directly associated with the Final Four teams.

headline: Dr. Lefebvre’s American Dream
text: On April 15, 1861, the day the Civil War was declared, citizens in the town of Paris, Mass., gathered with “the fervor of a crusade” to send off their volunteers. The community’s doctor, René Lefebvre, joined the crowd with his son and future son-in-law and most of his neighbors. Dr. Lefebvre’s wife and daughter, like the other women of the town, offered prayers and encouragement as they valiantly held back tears. The celebration of patriotism and liberty convinced Dr. Lefebvre that “this soil, opened and fructified by the Puritans, can bring forth naught but liberty.”

headline: Follow the Money
text: If you follow the debates about Ukraine, you can see three trends: those who use the crisis for humor, those who use it to reinforce preconceived views and those trying to figure out if it’s telling us something new about today’s world.

headline: Mayor Signs Marijuana Law
text: Mayor Vincent C. Gray on Monday signed into law a bill decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana. Congress has 60 days when at least one chamber is in session to review the law before it is enacted.

headline: The Aliens Have Landed
text: In the ’30s, as Germany rearmed, we said, “Yeah, France can handle that.” Earlier this week, the Panzer Corps of climate change zoomed right around our Maginot line of denial, and we all became the retreating French.

headline: Arizona: Abortion Ruling Is Appealed
text: Opponents of tough new state rules governing abortion-inducing drugs appealed a federal judge’s decision allowing the rules to go into effect. Planned Parenthood Arizona and Tucson Women’s Center asked the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on Tuesday to block the law, which requires doctors to follow protocols approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2000. The original F.D.A. rules limited so-called medication abortions to the first seven weeks of pregnancy and called for high doses of one of the drugs. Most clinics now use methods backed by major medical groups as safer, using smaller doses through the first nine weeks of pregnancy. Opponents say the law makes medication abortion harder to get. On Monday, Judge David C. Bury of United States District Court denied the groups’ request for a temporary restraining order.

headline: New Effort Gives Tech Workers Additional Way to Donate to Charity
text: Very soon, the tech industry will be out of excuses when it comes to giving back to local philanthropies and causes.

headline: Keeping Track: April 2, 2014
text: A new feature with updates on issues and subjects we follow.

headline: At Hearing, Caterpillar Defends Tax Practices
text: Officials of Caterpillar sparred with members of a Senate panel on Tuesday, defending more than a decade’s worth of tax practices that put most of the company’s profits out of reach of United States tax authorities.

headline: A Billion-Dollar Bracelet Is the Key to a Disney Park
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Walt Disney World has spent more than a year rolling out a $1 billion system that changes how visitors do everything from enter their hotel rooms to ride Space Mountain. But a few weeks ago a front desk agent at one of Disney’s marquee hotels was still wrestling with the technology.

headline: Jury Convicts Second Man in 2011 Killing of a High School Basketball Star
text: Had Tayshana Murphy lived, her parents would probably be watching her play college basketball this year. As one of the country’s top-rated point guards at Murry Bergtraum High School in Lower Manhattan, Ms. Murphy, 18, was being scouted by colleges like St. John’s and Miami University when she was gunned down in Harlem three years ago.

headline: Terror Suit Against Jordanian Bank Tests U.S. Diplomacy and Secrecy Laws
text: WASHINGTON — In 2004, relatives of some American citizens killed or injured by terrorist attacks in Israel sought redress in an unusual way. They filed a multibillion-dollar lawsuit against Arab Bank, the largest financial institution in Jordan, accusing it of transferring funds to Hamas leaders and other terrorists responsible for the attacks.

headline: Apple and Samsung Reprise Patent Fight (With Google a Shadow Presence)
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — As lawyers for Apple and Samsung made their opening statements in their patent trial in a federal courthouse here, they could not even agree on what the fight was about.

headline: Authorities Kill Gang Leader, Mexico Says
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican authorities said on Tuesday that they had killed another leader of the feared Knights Templar drug gang, adding to a string of successes against the organization that seemed to leave only one boss still at large: a former schoolteacher believed to be hiding in the hills of the Pacific state of Michoacán.

headline: Music Industry Pushes Unified Message on Compensation
text: When it comes to the music industry’s lobbying efforts in Washington, it is time for some harmony.

headline: Athletics Embrace the Sour Smell of Sweet Success
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — There was something in the air Monday night when the Oakland Athletics opened their season at home.

headline: Albany’s Perilous Oil Boom
text: Daniel McCoy, who manages Albany County and its port on the Hudson River, decided last month, that he had to do something about the dangers presented by the rumbling oil tank cars carrying crude oil from North Dakota’s Bakken fields to Albany, from which it is then shipped to refineries in the Northeast.

headline: To Protect Foreigners, Afghanistan Shuts Down Their Hangouts
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government, battered by a series of pre-election attacks aimed at foreigners in Kabul, the capital, has come up with a novel way of protecting them: Close their hangouts.

headline: Bad Move on Jonathan Pollard
text: The emergence of the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard as a bargaining chip in Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations is a lamentable sign of America’s desperation to keep both sides talking. Peace between Israelis and Palestinians can be achieved only if they want it for themselves, something that is very much in doubt right now.

headline: Unusual Events Force Exceptional Turnover in Charlotte Mayor’s Office
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — For much of this city’s recent history, there has been an unwritten tradition of regular turnover in the mayor’s office: With a single exception, none of Charlotte’s mayors since 1977 have held the post for more than four years.

headline: Mr. Ryan’s Faith-Based Budget
text: The Republican budget for 2015, released Tuesday by Representative Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, will never come close to being law, so it doesn’t have to pretend to be serious. This is a document designed solely to be reduced to a few bullet points so House Republicans can have something to show their most antigovernment voters.

headline: Checking for a Concussion With the Clock Running
text: For all the lore about baseball having no clock, the Washington Nationals sure had to beat one on Monday when Bryce Harper sustained a possible concussion while sliding into second base.

headline: Holder, in New York City, Calls Terror Trials Safe
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. made a high-profile visit to New York City on Tuesday, meeting with federal prosecutors who last week won the conviction of a former top adviser to Osama bin Laden and forcefully reiterating, at a news conference, his view that the case had “proven beyond any doubt” that terrorism trials can “safely occur” in the city.

headline: Police Confront Rising Number of Mentally Ill Suspects
text: ALBUQUERQUE — James Boyd, a homeless man camping in the Sandia Foothills here, could hear the commands of the police officers who were trying to move him out.

headline: Bishops Follow Pope’s Example: Opulence Is Out
text: The archbishop of Atlanta had a plan to resolve the space crunch at his cathedral: He would move out of his residence so priests could move in, and then he would build himself a new house with donated money and land.

headline: An Accounting of the Victims
text: On Tuesday, officials released names of 22 of the 28 confirmed dead from last month’s landslide in Oso, Washington. At least 20 more are still missing.

headline: Hawks in a Playoff Race That Isn’t Their Priority
text: ATLANTA — For any N.B.A. devotee, much less someone associated with the league, the standings are required daily reading during the ticktock to the playoffs.

headline: Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Is Implicated in New Case
text: John G. Rowland, a three-term Republican governor of Connecticut who resigned in 2004 under a cloud of corruption charges, has been implicated in a new investigation of improper campaign financing, according to legal filings and statements made in court this week.

headline: Afghan Women See Hope in the Ballot Box
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Mariam Wardak is one of those young Afghans with her feet in two worlds: At 28, she has spent much of her adult life in Afghanistan, but she grew up in the United States after her family fled there. She vividly remembers the culture shock of visits back to her family’s village in rural Wardak Province a decade ago.

headline: To Curtail Departures, SAC Pursues 2-Year Pacts
text: The billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his investment firm together, as the once-powerful hedge fund awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges.

headline: Out of This World
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I stared at my finished grid for quite a while before I understood what the theme was, yet there it was, staring back at me the entire time. Hands up if this one by David Levinson Wilk took you a while.

headline: Chicago Mayor Seeks Alterations to Repair Badly Underfunded Pension Plan
text: CHICAGO — Contending with one of the most poorly funded pension systems among the nation’s major cities, Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s administration has begun an urgent push to require some city workers to pay more for their retirement benefits and to raise property taxes for Chicagoans.

headline: Nets’ Surge Earns Jason Kidd a Second Award
text: Jason Kidd on Tuesday was named the Eastern Conference coach of the month for the second time this year, providing another indicator of how complete the Nets’ turnaround has been this season.

headline: Global Warming and the Developing World
text: What should be done to address the effects of climate change in developing countries?

headline: Strong Start in Deal-Making
text: Led by announced acquisitions like Comcast’s $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, the dollar volume of mergers worldwide rose 35 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with the same period a year ago. It was the strongest start for deals since 2011.

headline: For Hiroki Kuroda, Every Season Begins a New Chapter
text: HOUSTON — Hiroki Kuroda walked through the visiting clubhouse at Minute Maid Park on Monday, holding a white, three-ring binder under his arm. The contents of the book were largely empty before Kuroda’s first scheduled start in what could be his final season in the major leagues. But as the season progresses, he plans to fill it with the kind of information that has helped him along his road to becoming the stingiest Japanese-born starting pitcher in major league history.

headline: House Approves Funds for Ukraine
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives passed legislation on Tuesday that provides a $1 billion loan guarantee for Ukraine and imposes new sanctions on Russia for its annexation of Crimea.

headline: Man to Serve Three Months in Jail for His Affair With Student
text: A former administrator at a Manhattan high school who admitted to having affairs with students will serve three months in jail after pleading guilty on Tuesday to one count of third-degree rape in a deal with prosecutors, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

headline: Half of New York’s Tech Workers Lack College Degrees, Report Says
text: The fast-growing technology industry in New York is often cited as a magnet for graduates of the nation’s top universities. But a new report to be discussed in a speech by a deputy mayor on Wednesday found that almost half of the technology jobs in the city are filled by people without college degrees.

headline: At a Momentary Peace With Albany, de Blasio Sees an Opportunity to Reboot
text: The conversation flowed easily, becoming by turns serious and playful, with sober talk of budgets and taxes mixed in with banter about youthful dreams of baseball stardom, and the congeniality of Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ starting catcher.

headline: Is the American Middle Class Losing Out to China and India?
text: President Obama may be right: Free trade is a winning strategy that will lower consumer costs and expand employment in exporting industries.

headline: Earthquake Hits Off Coast of North Chile
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — An 8.2-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile on Tuesday night, forcing a massive evacuation along the country’s long coastline. At least five people were reported to have died.

headline: S.M.U. Holds Off Clemson to Advance to N.I.T. Final
text: Southern Methodist Coach Larry Brown recently referred to his tenure as Knicks coach during the 2005-6 season as “humiliating.”

headline: Turkey: Police Break Up Protest Over Voting Irregularities
text: Police in Ankara on Tuesday used water cannons and stun grenades to disperse crowds protesting voting irregularities in one of the closest races in Sunday’s local elections, which brought a landslide victory nationwide for the Islamic-rooted governing party. Television reports showed two antiriot vehicles moving along a street and firing water cannons at groups calling for a recount. Mansur Yavas, the opposition mayoral candidate, filed an appeal at the Supreme Electoral Board for examination of irregularities in light of findings by more than 1,000 volunteers working to pin down fraud. Photographs of dozens of ballot box information forms posted on Twitter, which the government moved to shut down last month, showed discrepancies between handwritten vote counts for the opposition party and entries in the digital counting system. The Supreme Electoral Board said on Tuesday that the official count was a legal process and urged parties to remain calm.

headline: Small Area Open Near Fukushima
text: TOKYO — Japan reopened a small part of the 12-mile evacuation zone around the destroyed Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Tuesday, allowing residents to return to live in their homes for the first time since the accident three years ago.

headline: Missing From Christie’s Proof-of-Innocence Claim: The Proof
text: As of Tuesday afternoon, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was refusing to make public the interviews that, his lawyer asserts, “vindicate” the governor in the traffic-jam-as-punishment scheme run by his aides.

headline: Yanks’ Rebuilt Lineup Is Quickly Picked Apart
text: HOUSTON — The first indication that things were going wrong came early. After an off-season of binge spending by the front office and a winter spent healing old injuries, it was finally time for the 2014 Yankees to showcase their revamped lineup and their supposedly reinvented No. 1 pitcher, C. C. Sabathia, looking to make up for the worst season of his career.

headline: Last Clashes for Nets and Knicks
text: The Nets and Knicks have met twice this season, taking turns embarrassing each other. The Knicks had a blowout 113-83 victory on Dec. 5 at Barclays Center, and the Nets returned the favor on Jan. 20, pounding the Knicks, 103-80, the indignity made worse by the “Brooklyn” chants that broke out at Madison Square Garden as the game got out of hand.

headline: Two Dollar Bill Is Oddity, but Some Love the Tender
text: Move over, Bitcoin. There is another uncommon tender angling for a spotlight, or in this case, a comeback: the $2 bill.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 1, 2014
text: April 1, 2014

headline: Scenes From Steelhead Drive
text: Kirk Johnson of The New York Times recorded these scenes from the town of Oso, Wash.

headline: Self-Driving Cars Will Make Accident Claims Easier
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: How Exercise Can Help You Live Longer
text: Having unhealthy cholesterol numbers, elevated blood pressure or an expanding waistline substantially increases your chances of developing heart disease. But an encouraging new study finds that exercise may slash that risk, even if your other risk factors stay high.

headline: Word of the Day | oscillate
text: oscillate•\ˈä-sə-ˌlat\• verb

headline: Marc Platt, 100, Stage and Screen Dancer, Dies
text: Marc Platt, a lively and versatile dancer who had standout roles onstage and in films, including in the original 1943 Broadway production of “Oklahoma!” and as one of the virile young woodsmen seeking spouses in the 1954 film musical “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,” died on Saturday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 100.

headline: Once Stumbling, Nets Are Surging Into Playoffs
text: The Nets on Tuesday clinched their second consecutive playoff berth, beating the energetic but depleted Houston Rockets, 105-96, at Barclays Center. While securing a postseason ticket seemed to be a formality, it was a testament to how good the Nets have become these last three months.

headline: Times Minute | A Health Care Milestone
text: Today on the Minute, how yesterday’s health care milestone will affect the debate on health care and the expansion of medicaid.

headline: Frankie Knuckles, 59, Pioneer House D.J., Dies
text: Frankie Knuckles, a club disc jockey, remixer and producer who was often called the “godfather of house” for helping that percussive genre of dance music spread from Chicago nightclubs to global popularity and influence, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 59.

headline: Times Minute | A Health Care Milestone
text: In the Video

headline: Irene Fernandez, Champion of the Oppressed in Malaysia, Dies at 67
text: Irene Fernandez, a champion of the oppressed in Malaysia whose indefatigable advocacy for better treatment of foreign migrant workers prompted her government to denounce her as a traitor and human rights groups to shower her with awards, died on March 25 in Serdang, Malaysia. She was 67.

headline: Democratic Primary
text: Live results from the Democratic primary for Washington, D.C., mayor.

headline: Jets Add Receiver Jacoby Ford
text: The Jets continued to revamp their receiving corps by signing Jacoby Ford, a 5-foot-9-inch speedster who also returns punts and kickoffs. Ford, who has been hampered by injuries throughout his four-year career, caught 13 passes for 99 yards last season with the Raiders. He will be reunited with Sanjay Lal, his position coach in Oakland. Aside from Ford, the Jets have signed Eric Decker and released Santonio Holmes, and they are likely to select a receiver in the early rounds of the draft in May.

headline: D.C. Mayor Is Defeated in Upset at Primary
text: WASHINGTON — Muriel E. Bowser, whose activist father introduced her to signature-gathering and door-knocking as a girl, won a stunning upset on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for mayor in a race that turned on the integrity of the incumbent, Vincent C. Gray.

headline: Charles Keating, 90, Key Figure in ’80s Savings and Loan Crisis, Dies
text: Charles H. Keating Jr., who went to prison and came to symbolize the $150 billion savings-and-loan crisis a generation ago after fleecing thousands of depositors with regulatory help from a group of United States senators known as the Keating Five, has died. He was 90.

headline: China’s Cofco to Buy Majority Stake in Noble Agriculture Unit
text: HONG KONG — The Cofco Corporation, a huge Chinese state-owned foodstuffs conglomerate, agreed on Wednesday to pay $1.5 billion for a majority stake in the Noble Group’s agriculture business.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9:05 A.M. (Starz Cinema) THE SECRET IN THEIR EYES (2010) A retired Argentine court investigator (Ricardo Darin, above) and a judge (Soledad Villamil) revisit a hauntingly brutal crime from decades earlier — and their former lives toiling alongside a boozy colleague (Guillermo Francella) — in this drama directed by Juan José Campanella. The film alternates between the present and the 1970s, when Argentina was embarking on a military dictatorship. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film “an attractive, messy drama riddled with violence and edged with comedy that comes with a hint of Grand Guignol, a suggestion of politics and three resonant, deeply appealing performances.”

headline: Jerry Roberts, 93, Code Breaker for Britain
text: Jerry Roberts, the last surviving member of the British code-breaking team that cracked strategic ciphers between Hitler and his top generals, helping to hasten the end of World War II, died on March 25 in Hampshire, England. He was 93.

headline: Rangers Set Road Record With Win in Vancouver
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Benoit Pouliot scored the winning goal in the first period as the Rangers earned their franchise-record 25th road win, beating the Vancouver Canucks, 3-1, on Tuesday at Rogers Arena.

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Library of Congress Beefs Up Recordings Collection, but Watch Out for That Barber
text: Sweeney Todd, the murderous barber who sent his victims to their Maker impeccably shaved, is being sent to his own just reward: a permanent place in the Library of Congress.

headline: Nest’s Thermostat Is Going Global
text: LONDON — Months after Google agreed to buy Nest Labs, the maker of Internet-connected home devices, for $3.2 billion, Nest is finally taking its thermostat global.

headline: Pivotal Offers a Big Data Bundle
text: The technologies that fly under the banner of “big data” may be new, but the business strategies have a familiar look.

headline: Tech Spending Recovers, but It’s Different
text: It isn’t what you spend, it’s how you spend it.

headline: Chinese Government Expands Freedom of Information
text: Amid concerns over increasing restrictions to freedom of information in the United States, the Chinese government appears to be moving in the opposite direction, issuing new, broader guidelines for “public information.”

headline: AIDS Patients in Andhra Pradesh Find Fear at State Hospitals
text: WARANGAL, India — As M. Balakrishna, a 38-year-old AIDS patient, pushed his gaunt body out of bed with his skinny arms, his knees wobbled as his feet hit the floor. His apartment was covered with spare motorbike parts, relics of a time when he was still able to work as a mechanic.

headline: Death Sentence Is Upheld for Doctor’s Killer
text: A court in China has upheld a death sentence for a man who fatally stabbed one doctor and severely wounded another in the coastal city of Wenling last year. Attacks on medical staff occur regularly in the country, a fact that has the government worried.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 2, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks
text: In “With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks,” Jane Brody writes about the injuries caused each year by extreme sports.

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
text: Whenever Chris Hondros returned to New York City after a long assignment, it was like a roving professor holding office hours. One meeting at Caffe Reggio in Greenwich Village would morph into drinks or dinner with out-of-towners visiting Brooklyn. Friends came and went, but the discussion was always rich and lively. That’s what I miss the most about him.

headline: What Makes a Good TV Show Finale?
text: Are you a “How I Met Your Mother” fan? What did you think of Monday night’s finale? What other television show finales have been memorable for you? Why?

headline: Applus Services Seeking to Raise $414 Million in I.P.O.
text: The Spanish testing and certification company Applus Services said on Wednesday that it planned to raise as much as 300 million euros, or about $414 million, in an initial public offering in Spain.

headline: After Protests, City Tries to Ease Fear of Chemical Plant
text: Government officials met with popular local bloggers in a town in China’s southeastern Guangdong Province that has been hit by days of protest over plans to build a petrochemical plant. The meeting, part of an effort to reduce residents’ concerns about the plant, comes a day after the vice mayor of Maoming city met with some protesters.

headline: As Lufthansa Pilots Walk Out, 900 Canceled Flights but Relative Calm
text: PARIS — Advance planning by Lufthansa, one of Europe’s busiest airlines, seemed to be paying off Wednesday, at the beginning of a three-day strike by pilots, despite the cancellation of about 900 flights worldwide.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: New York Today: Let Fountains Flow
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Postcolonial Resentments Loom Over Meeting of Europeans and Africans
text: Scores of European and African leaders and officials gathered in Brussels on Wednesday for a major summit meeting overshadowed by bloodletting in the Central African Republic and lingering postcolonial resentments.

headline: Hope for Negotiations Stays Alive in Mideast
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian leadership on Wednesday formally submitted applications to join 15 international conventions and treaties despite opposition from the United States and Israel, reflecting a deep crisis in Middle East peace talks. Yet all three parties appeared ready to seek a formula for continuing the negotiations.

headline: No More Ms. Nice Guy
text: ‘If an injury is to be done to a man, it should be so severe that his vengeance need not be feared.’ — Niccolo Machiavelli

headline: In Our Pages: April 3
text: 1914: Wells Easily Defeats Lurie

headline: Daily Report: Old Rivalry Aired Again in Patent Case Between Apple and Samsung
text: As lawyers for Apple and Samsung made their opening statements in their patent trial in a federal courthouse in San Jose, Calif., they could not even agree on what the fight was about, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Unit of Deutsche Börse Faces U.S. Criminal Inquiry
text: Deutsche Börse, the German stock exchange, said on Wednesday that its Clearstream unit was the object of a criminal investigation into potential violations of United States money laundering laws and sanctions against Iran.

headline: Going to the Show
text: TIMES INSIDER — Welcome to the inaugural crossword puzzle post for Times Insider. If you are a subscriber to Times Premier, you’ll have monthly access to a special, handpicked selection of past New York Times crossword puzzles, so step up to the plate and take a swing at your April challenge. Then come back here and tell me how it felt to run those bases.

headline: A Gothic Night of Suspense
text: How reassuring to know that in some corner of the globe, it will always be a dark and stormy night. And that’s not just because of different climate and time zones, but also because somewhere a production of Charles Ludlam’s “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful” is surely playing. Since its debut in 1984, this animated catalog of all things gothic has been performed in theaters of all stripes throughout the world, with two actors embodying a host of glamorously creepy characters in a plot that borrows from the Brontë sisters, Daphne du Maurier and Universal horror flicks.

headline: Student of History Is Making Some
text: Darby English is an uncommonly thoughtful art historian who says that interpreting a work of art is never straightforward. He specializes in African-American art history and deplores the tendency to reduce black art to a vehicle for ready-made arguments about injustice and social uplift. Lest he himself be flattened into a type — an African-American man whose tastes are defined by some presumed community — he requested, only half-jokingly, that this article not be accompanied by artwork by Jacob Lawrence, perhaps the most acclaimed black painter of the 20th century.

headline: Stemming Departures at SAC
text: Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his once-powerful hedge fund together as it awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. Mr. Cohen is aiming to curtail a slow but steady departure of top portfolio managers by pressing those who remain to sign two-year contracts that would bind them to him until the end of 2016.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Austerity, Part II (Debt)
text: Link fixed

headline: If You Like Immersion, You’ll Love This Reality
text: The news that Facebook paid $2 billion for a virtual reality start-up, Oculus VR, might strike you as a bit zany. Like flying cars and robotic maids, the idea of donning a pair of computerized glasses and slipping into a digital world feels like a snapshot from yesterday’s future.

headline: The Will To Believe
text: Just belatedly finished the slides for my 8:30 class (saw Lake Street Dive Monday night — awesomely good, but I don’t handle late nights too well). And what strikes me again, just as it did for my last class, is how thoroughly the austerity debate was a case of the will to believe overpowering any and all critical assessment of evidence.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Firm Virtu Is Said to Delay I.P.O.
text: The high-frequency trading firm Virtu Financial has decided to postpone its initial public offering by at least a week, amid a storm of negative attention over its industry’s business model, two people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Pollution and Dust in Britain Bring Health Warnings
text: LONDON — A combination of air pollution and dust from the Sahara on Wednesday prompted British authorities to issue a smog alert and a health warning for the elderly and for people with heart or lung problems.

headline: French Leader Approves a Cabinet of Mixed Messages
text: PARIS — President François Hollande of France approved a new cabinet on Wednesday, putting some high-profile figures — including Ségolène Royal, his former partner — in key positions, but sending mixed messages about his plans for France’s troubled economy.

headline: When in India
text: On the outskirts of Mumbai, homegrown concept shops are starting their own suburban sprawl.

headline: How to Explain Bitcoin to Your Mom!
text: A guide to the system of virtual currency.

headline: After Sobs, Prayers and Illness in Court, Pistorius May Testify
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Listening to the prosecution lay out its case against him at his murder trial over the past month, Oscar Pistorius could not keep silent, or still. He sobbed, prayed, threw up, buried his face in his hands and covered his ears, a response to the graphic and upsetting evidence, and, perhaps, to the grim reality of his own changed circumstances.

headline: Chrysler Recalls Over 850,000 S.U.V.s
text: Chrysler is recalling more than 850,000 sport utility vehicles because of a possible braking problem. The recall covers the 2011 to 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango models, including about 644,000 in the United States.

headline: Bomber Kills Six at Interior Ministry Entrance in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed six policemen after detonating his explosive vest at the entrance gates of the Interior Ministry headquarters on Wednesday, ministry officials said, penetrating nearly to the heart of the Afghan security establishment.

headline: What Is New York Missing?
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Kerry on Stalled Mideast Peace Talks
text: Secretary of State John Kerry said it was “completely premature” to write off the Israeli-Palestinian peace process even as negotiations faltered.

headline: Modern Mermaids
text: Not every little mermaid has to follow in the wake of Hans Christian Andersen’s beloved fairy tale. Two new mermaids with tales all their own swim to the surface in “The Mermaid and the Shoe,” written and illustrated by K.G. Campbell, and “The Mermaid’s Shoes,” written and illustrated by Sanne te Loo. These modern mermaids make for a refreshing and amusing departure from their famous predecessor.

headline: A Few Auto Industry April Fools’ Day Pranks
text: April Fools’ Day comes but once a year, and inevitably it catches some people unaware. The automotive industry always seems to generate some pranks, and although things were relatively quiet this year, a few high jinks came to light, including these:

headline: A Memorial Inscription’s Grim Origins
text: Who are “you”?

headline: Scholarly Perspectives on Inscription at the 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: “No day shall erase you from the memory of time,” says the inscription on the repository of unidentified remains at the National September 11 Memorial Museum, which opens next month. The line — “nulla dies umquam memori vos eximet aevo” — is taken from Virgil’s “Aeneid,” in which “you” are not nameless, numberless, innocent citizens, but two bloodthirsty young Trojan soldiers. The Times asked a few classicists to share their thoughts about the appropriateness of this quotation. Here are three responses:

headline: Highlights from Senate Hearing on G.M. Defects
text: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, faced tough questions during a Senate hearing Wednesday about the company’s failure to address safety issues, as our colleagues, Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald report.

headline: Feeding Teenagers: The Days of Control Are Gone
text: I had better control of my teenagers and their eating years ago. When my four children were younger, I was the woman in charge. I made the meals, packed the lunches and decided what snacks would be eaten after school. I manned the schedule and scheduled the meals. I closed the kitchen and opened it. I approved and refused food. I was the food manager.

headline: The Wealth Gap in America Is Growing, Too
text: It is, by now, well known that income inequality has increased in the United States. The top 10 percent of earners took more than half of the country’s overall income in 2012, the highest proportion recorded in a century of government record keeping.

headline: Responding to Quake, Chile Uses Lessons of Past
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Soon after an 8.8-magnitude earthquake hit southern Chile in 2010 near the end of President Michelle Bachelet’s first term, officials failed to issue a tsunami warning before a massive wave killed a large number of the 525 people who died in the disaster. Looting then plagued hard-hit areas after Ms. Bachelet delayed allowing the military to move in.

headline: After Push by Obama, Minimum-Wage Action Is Moving to the States
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The more President Obama talks about the need to raise the federal minimum wage, the less likely it appears that Republicans in Congress are inclined to do it.

headline: Will G.M. Compensate Victims?
text: Congressional hearings are often more theater than substance. That was certainly true of a four-hour House hearing on Tuesday into why it took General Motors and a federal safety regulator more than a decade to identify a defect in 2.6 million cars that has been linked to at least 13 deaths.

headline: By Design | Renzo Piano Reflects
text: Forty years later, the architect remembers one of his most meaningful Italian commissions.

headline: Despite Slowdown in China, Rio Tinto Stays Committed to Mining Plans
text: LONDON — Rio Tinto, one of the world’s largest mining companies, has big plans for pulling even more iron ore from the earth.

headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Overall Political Donation Cap
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its abolition of limits on election spending, striking down a decades-old cap on the total amount any individual can contribute to federal candidates in a two-year election cycle.

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
text: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.

headline: To Cement Berlin’s Start-Up Success, a Bridge to U.S.
text: Berlin boasts one of the fastest-growing start-up communities, as engineers and designers have flocked to the German capital in recent years, attracted by the underground music scene, cutting-edge art galleries, stylish bars and low rent.

headline: G.M. Chief Faces Ire of Senators in Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — The questions came faster and harder at Mary T. Barra on Wednesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: It’s Never Too Late to Start Up
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: NATO Commander Says He Sees Potent Threat From Russia
text: BRUSSELS — NATO’s top commander said on Wednesday that the 40,000 troops Russia has within striking distance of Ukraine are poised to attack on 12 hours’ notice and could accomplish their military objectives within three to five days.

headline: Malaysia Police Chief on Investigation
text: The inspector general of the Malaysian police, Khalid Abu Bakar, said that only the passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been cleared and not the crew.

headline: Minneapolis Newspaper Gets a New Life, but I Remember the Old One
text: By now it’s a familiar story: a once-mighty regional newspaper is brought low by punishing economics and a series of owners who could not change that math, and is now being scooped up by the local rich guy. In the instance of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis. Glen Taylor, who owns a vast array of businesses —including pro basketball’s Minnesota Timberwolves, an egg producer, a medical device company and a host of printing operations — is making a bid to add the dominant local paper in the Twin Cities to his holdings.

headline: Same As He Ever Was
text: Update: I forgot to mention that centrist infatuation with Ryan didn’t just involve ignoring the manifest dishonesty of his budget proposals; it was also a stunning misjudgment of character. Think about it: I don’t do up-close-and-personal, I mostly just do numbers, and I had him pegged as a con man right away; meanwhile, people who claim to be experts on judging the man saw a saint.

headline: Karen Joy Fowler Wins PEN/Faulkner Fiction Prize
text: Karen Joy Fowler, a novelist known for her science fiction and for stories set in the 19th century, is the winner of the 2014 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for “We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves” (G.P. Putnam’s Sons), a novel with a contemporary setting. The $15,000 prize, which was announced on Wednesday by the directors of the award, will be presented at a ceremony at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington on May 10.

headline: Reaction to the Supreme Court’s Campaign Finance Decision
text: The Lede chronicled much of the reaction to the Supreme Court’s campaign finance decision on Wednesday that struck down limits on federal campaign contributions. As our colleague Adam Liptak reports, the ruling, issued near the start of a campaign season, will change and most likely increase the role money plays in American politics.

headline: Cairo University Is Rocked by Several Explosions
text: CAIRO — Several explosive devices detonated near the campus of Cairo University on Wednesday, killing a senior police official and wounding several officers in the first major attack in the capital since the beginning of Egypt’s presidential campaign just days ago.

headline: In Crimea, Russia Showcases a Rebooted Army
text: PEREVALNOYE, Crimea — The soldiers guarding the entrances to the surrounded Ukrainian military base here just south of the capital, Simferopol, had little in common with their predecessors from past Russian military actions.

headline: Seeking Even Faster Growth, an E-Commerce Company Stumbles
text: JIMMY BEANS WOOL is an online yarn and fabric retailer with a brick-and-mortar store in Reno, Nev. The company, which has 37 employees, was founded by a married couple who are former software engineers, Laura and Doug Zander, in 2002. After five years, sales were $1 million. They topped $7 million in 2013.

headline: How Can Jimmy Beans Wool Get Its Growth Back on Track?
text: We just published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, an online yarn and fabric retailer with a brick-and-mortar store in Reno, Nev. Founded in 2002 by Laura and Doug Zander, the company began as a small storefront yarn shop and developed a loyal following online through its creative use of social media, most notably YouTube videos. From 2007 to 2012, sales grew organically at an annual rate of as much as 50 percent. They topped $7 million in 2013.

headline: A New Hotel in the Versace Mansion
text: The former Miami Beach home of the late Gianni Versace, the Italian clothing designer, is seeing its second incarnation as a luxury boutique hotel, this time under the ownership of another fashion mogul.

headline: House Hunting in ... Byron Bay, Australia
text: AN ECO-FRIENDLY MODERN HOME ON AUSTRALIA’S EAST COAST

headline: NYT Now: Kerry on Mideast Peace Talks
text: Secretary of State John Kerry says it’s too early to draw conclusions about Israel-Palestinian talks after negotiations stalled.

headline: Security Camera Footage of Chilean Quake
text: Closed-circuit television cameras in a pharmacy in northern Chile captured the moment an earthquake struck.

headline: McCutcheon: Another Blow to Democracy
text: The Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 ruling on Wednesday striking down aggregate limits on political campaign contributions is no less destructive for being so widely predicted.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, the Bad Plus, Fred Astaire and More
text: BEETHOVEN: Piano Concertos No. 2 in B flat and No. 4 in GLeif Ove Andsnes, pianist and directorMahler Chamber Orchestra(Sony Classical)The superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes continues “The Beethoven Journey,” as he calls his thoughtful exploration of the composer’s works, with the second installment in his survey of the five piano concertos. This recording pairs the ebullient Second Concerto, which can often sound like an audacious extension of Haydn, with the noble, and mercurial, Fourth Concerto, in which Beethoven takes the genre into realms of the poetic and the mystical. In these elegant, vibrant performances, Mr. Andsnes intriguingly reveals the magisterial qualities of the earlier work and the classical directness of the later one. He does double-duty as pianist and conductor, drawing impressive playing from the remarkable Mahler Chamber Orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Tackling Mass Incarceration
text: Nine years ago Molly Baldwin found herself in a curious position. Roca, the teenage pregnancy and violence prevention program she’d founded in her 20s, had a multimillion-dollar budget, a two-story building in downtown Chelsea, Mass., a portfolio of programs addressing everything from poverty to immigrant rights and a measure of fame for using Native American peacemaking circles to heal gang-impacted youth. The only problem was, those cathartic conversations weren’t translating to change.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 29 in Washington State Landslide
text: The death toll rose to 29 on Wednesday in the landslide more than a week ago that buried a Washington community as searchers continued the grim task of looking through the tangled muck for more victims.

headline: With Fire TV, Amazon Seeks a Beachhead in the Living Room
text: Amazon is a retailer that makes and sells entertainment. On Wednesday, it took a big step toward a future in which shopping and video are tightly linked, perhaps even inseparable.

headline: Bomb Blasts at Cairo University Caught on Camera
text: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Egyptian journalists who rushed to the scene of a bombing near the campus of Cairo University on Wednesday captured two subsequent explosions on video.

headline: Jason Kidd’s Bad Rap, Now 20 Years Old
text: Through 20 years in professional basketball, Jason Kidd has earned a Rookie of the Year award, taken home two Olympic gold medals and won an N.B.A. title. His team, the Brooklyn Nets, is storming toward the playoffs, and Tuesday he was named the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference coach of the month.

headline: A Pivotal Financial Crisis Case, Ending With a Whimper
text: The regulatory cloud has lifted for Kenneth D. Lewis. Last week, the former head of Bank of America received a modest penalty, paid for by his former employer, and a temporary ban from an industry he is no longer a part of.

headline: Mozilla Chief Tries to Separate Views on Gay Marriage and Business
text: Can a chief executive run an open-source software company while simultaneously holding views some say are antithetical to the ethos of the open-source community?

headline: Handler, Leucadia’s Chief, Takes Pay Cut in New Role
text: When he ran the Jefferies Group, Richard B. Handler was one of the better paid chief executives on Wall Street. Now, after the Leucadia National Corporation acquired Jefferies, his compensation has fallen by more than 80 percent.

headline: A Sweet, Springlike Confection of a Bag
text: Spring has sprung. But April showers and freezing morning temperatures aren’t exactly sending New Yorkers forward in their warm-weather best. It might not be time yet for shift dresses and wraparound sandals, but a new everyday bag is a sure way to liven up this dreary start to the season. Bottega Veneta’s most recent confection of a cross-body bag may be compact in size, but it makes a powerful statement with its sugary mint-green shade and multitextured surface incorporating edgy snakeskin and the house’s signature woven leather. It complements drab winter wear for now, and will be a welcome addition to a lighter wardrobe come May.

headline: Photos of Survival in Congo
text: Azayi Kabunga was an important man, a village chief and schoolteacher. I first met him in his village deep in Eastern Congo in 2009, in the North Kivu region. Within a year, Azayi Kabunga was in a camp for displaced Congolese in distant Goma, broken and ashamed that he was no longer able to support his family. He remains displaced today, unable to go home because of violent militias.

headline: Aldrich Art Museum Celebrates Anniversary With Six Exhibitions
text: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, in Ridgefield, Conn., is kicking off a yearlong celebration of its 50th anniversary with six exhibitions, including one, “Standing in the Shadows of Love,” that looks back at the museum’s first decade, with works by Robert Indiana, Robert Rauschenberg, Robert Smithson, Ree Morton and Robert Morris.

headline: A Final Image of Lincoln, Hastily Sketched at City Hall, Is to Go on Display
text: Starting at noon on Monday, April 24, 1865, through noon the next day, perhaps as many as 100,000 people trooped through City Hall. The line of mourners came through the basement doors, wended its way up the stairs through the Governors Room, where New Yorkers paid their final respects to the martyred President Abraham Lincoln, and snaked back down to City Hall Park.

headline: NYT Now: CCTV Shows Chilean Quake
text: Security cameras inside a pharmacy captured the moment a magnitude 8.2 earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile.

headline: Walking the Talk
text: On Saturday mornings, Cyndi Mariner puts on her Nikes, grabs a hat, and heads for Shoreline Park in Mountain View, Calif. Joining a handful of other people caring for elderly parents, she walks for an hour along San Francisco Bay. The walkers watch the kayaks and sailboats on the water, notice the hummingbirds buzzing across the trail. And they talk about things like how not to scream when your loved one with dementia has asked you the same question five times in a row.

headline: In Singapore’s Center, but a World Away
text: It’s not often that you can find yourself completely alone in densely developed Singapore, not a building or road in sight and the only sound the trilling of birds overhead.

headline: Recipes for Kids: Black Bean and Corn Quesadillas
text: It’s a Mexican grilled cheese sandwich, with tortillas instead of bread.  We like whole-grain or corn tortillas better than white flour tortillas because  they have lots of flavor and more nutrients. (Corn tortillas are smaller, so if you use them here, use 2 per quesadilla, with the cheese  between them.)

headline: Browse Without Prying Eyes
text: Molly Wood explores services that allow you to search online without compromising your privacy.

headline: A Fashion Nod to ‘Venus’ in Portugal
text: The Bairro Alto neighborhood in Lisbon is known as a noisy place. From outdoor cafes bustling with students to loud bars and fado houses, the historic Portuguese area is a hangout for young people. Rui Palma, who lives around the area, was walking to class wearing a vintage cobalt coat, a shirt with a printed interpretation of a painting by the Pre-Raphaelite Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Dr. Martens, which he bought in London because they reminded him of the lyrics “shiny, shiny, shiny boots of leather,” from the Velvet Underground song “Venus in Furs.”

headline: Sweeping Away a Search History
text: YOUR search history contains some of the most personal information you will ever reveal online: your health, mental state, interests, travel locations, fears and shopping habits.

headline: A Reading of “Self Help” by Katie Peterson
text: The American poet reads her ode to deep self-exploration.

headline: Brothers of Invention
text: There is no epiphanic moment of invention in “Silicon Valley,” Mike Judge’s new HBO comedy series about the socially awkward, emerging center of the world. Remember the lightbulb-flash scene in “The Social Network,” “A Beautiful Mind” or any other pop-cultural depiction of high-functioning nerdery, the moment when, in a fit of mania and caffeine, our hero scribbles out some groundbreaking bit of math on a slab of glass? In “Silicon Valley,” as in Silicon Valley, the process of discovering the next big thing is much more authentically dull.

headline: Image of the Day: April 2
text: Saina Nehwal, an Indian badminton player, during the Yonex-Sunrise India Open 2014 tournament in New Delhi.

headline: Lashing Out in Verse
text: LEIPZIG, Germany — Like many teenagers, Yahya Hassan does not lack for bravado. But his way of expressing it stands in stark contrast to that of most of his peers: At just 18, the Danish-Palestinian Mr. Hassan has emblazoned himself on Denmark’s consciousness with a poetry collection that appeared with a first print run of 800 last fall and has since sold more than 100,000 copies.

headline: A New Barcelona Boutique Hotel, Scented With Fresh-Baked Bread
text: What’s the only thing better than a chic new hotel in Barcelona? A chic new hotel in Barcelona that serves — and smells like — freshly baked bread. Opening this week in the Gaudí-building-studded Eixample district, the Hotel Praktik Bakery would be an attraction for its airy interiors, by the designer Lazaro Rosa-Violán, alone: the 74 rooms feature subtle antique-industrial touches on a restful white palette. But it’s the vast lobby — with its outpost of the acclaimed local breadsmith Anna Bellsolá’s Baluard bakery churning out loaves and pastries morning, noon and night — that makes the place a must-book. And for an establishment devoted to the possibilities of dough, the hotel doesn’t require all that much of it: rates begin at less than 100 euros per night.

headline: Times Minute | G.M. Faces Congress
text: On the Minute, Matt Wald on the investigation into General Motors’ faulty switch. Did G.M. withhold information and the next steps for Congress.

headline: Senators Clear Path for Release of Detention Report on C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON — Two members of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Wednesday announced their support for declassifying parts of a long-delayed report on the C.I.A.’s defunct detention and interrogation program, all but assuring that the committee will approve the report and send it to President Obama for eventual release.

headline: Times Minute | G.M. Faces Congress
text: In the Video

headline: N.H.L. Teams Pass the Hat, or Shovel, or Maybe a Belt
text: The Broadway Hat, Duffy’s Shovel, the Starter Jacket, the Haida Hat. They are the talismans of victory for N.H.L. players, odd objects of pride and fun. Most of all they are the emblems of teamwork and camaraderie, curios that help cement the bonds of a hockey club.

headline: Power Surge for Donors as Terrain Is Reshaped on Campaign Money
text: Big donors, leaders of political parties and candidates with access to wealthy supporters will be the biggest beneficiaries of the Supreme Court decision issued on Wednesday, a ruling that could fundamentally reshape the political terrain in the 2014 elections and beyond.

headline: What Michael Lewis’s Book Has to Do With Your Money
text: Do you consider yourself an investor or a trader?

headline: Wheelies: The Non-Detroit Electric Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Opera America Names Eight Grant Winners
text: Late last year, Opera America set out to encourage women composers to write new operas, and offered incentives, by way of a two-year grant program, underwritten by the Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation. The organization announced the first group of recipients of its Opera Grants for Female Composers on Tuesday. Eight composers, and their proposed projects, were chosen from among 112 eligible applicants. Each will receive a $12,500 grant to help develop her opera.

headline: Polls Show Broad Support for Campaign Spending Caps
text: Even as the Supreme Court moved on Wednesday to remove limits on campaign donations, the public remains broadly supportive of them, surveys show.

headline: Before and After the Supreme Court’s Ruling
text: How Wednesday’s decision in McCutcheon v. Federal Election Commission changes the total amount individual donors can contribute to federal candidates, national parties and political committees.

headline: Despite Impressive Season, Rockets Do Not Look Like Contenders
text: After losing to the Nets at Barclays Center on Tuesday night, the Houston Rockets (49-24) acted as if they had had enough of the N.B.A.’s grueling 82-game regular season. They played that way, too.

headline: Barry Diller Says Aereo’s Survival Depends on Justices’ Decision
text: With crucial Supreme Court arguments over the legality of Aereo scheduled for later this month, one of the streaming service’s major investors, Barry Diller, said on Wednesday that its viability as a business was riding on the decision.

headline: Commodity Chief Blythe Masters to Leave JPMorgan Chase
text: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | A prominent executive is leaving JPMorgan Chase as her powerful trading operation has stopped performing up to expectations, underscoring that Chase, the nation’s largest bank, is not immune to the boom and bust cycles that periodically sweep through Wall Street.

headline: Confessore on Money Ruling
text: Nick Confessore, The Times’s campaign finance reporter, on what the Supreme Court’s action to strike down aggregate limits on federal campaign contributions means.

headline: Knoedler Forgery Lawsuit Names Art Historian as Defendant
text: A respected Swiss art historian and curator has been drawn into the legal tangle surrounding the sale of dozens of high-priced forgeries by the shuttered New York art gallery Knoedler & Company.

headline: Reasons for Virtu to Remain Private
text: It’s a good thing Virtu Financial doesn’t really need to go public.

headline: Is That an R-330Zh Zhitel on the Road in Crimea?
text: PEREVALNOYE, Crimea — As Russian troops and extralegal militias swiftly seized Crimea from Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin maintained a falsehood. The impressively equipped and disciplined conventional troops that enveloped Ukrainian military bases, he said, were not Russian.

headline: The West Village: Wish List Satisfied
text: The M21 bus, which runs across Houston Street, is viewed with fondness by Vicki Baum and Steven Roth. Forty years ago, that’s where they met. Both residents of the West Village, they got on the bus at the same stop one day and recognized each other from the neighborhood.

headline: Lyft Raises $250 Million From Alibaba, Third Point and Others
text: Lyft, one of the big players in the nascent-but-booming ride-sharing industry, said on Wednesday that it had raised $250 million from a group that includes the Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba Group and the investment firm Third Point.

headline: Giving a Debtor a Big Club Against Lenders
text: A federal district court’s opinion in Meridian Sunrise Village v. NB Distressed Debt Investment Fund Ltd. is one of the most important recent decisions for distressed debt investors and loan investors generally. It is also one you haven’t probably heard of. Indeed, but for a brief mention in one of Bill Rochelle’s invaluable columns on Bloomberg Law a few weeks back, I would have missed it myself.

headline: Meet Microsoft’s Cortana, a More Personal Siri
text: REDMOND, Wash. — When Microsoft was developing Cortana, a virtual assistant for its mobile operating system that was unveiled Wednesday, the company thought, naturally, about how it could improve on Siri, Apple’s sometimes bumbling assistant for the iPhone.

headline: By Design | One Man’s Trash
text: Two creative teams on different continents prove that repurposed furniture doesn’t have to look like junk.

headline: Openings and Events for the Week of April 3
text: Openings and Events

headline: NATO and Russia on Suspension
text: NATO’s secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, and the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Alexander Lukashevich, discussed the suspension of military cooperation between the alliance and Russia.

headline: Budget Fun on the California Coast
text: Most of the signs outside DJ’s Mini-Mart in Santa Cruz, Calif., were like those you might see on any convenience store in America: “Budweiser,” “ATM Inside,” the current Powerball jackpot amount. But another, more prominent one caught my attention: “Welcome Disc Golfers.”

headline: A Big Sur Bath by the Light of the Moon
text: It was 12:45 a.m. when I pulled off Highway 1 in Big Sur and joined a half-dozen couples and small groups of friends waiting quietly in rental cars under a twinkling black horizon. Was that a shooting star? The breeze was redolent of redwoods and sea salt, and the surf sounded rhythmically below like the soft breath of children, already asleep.

headline: Deliveryman Fatally Shot on a Street Many Avoid
text: For Richard Salvia, it was a new job: carting Chinese food around northern Staten Island in his Chevrolet Impala. For the restaurant he worked for, it was a relatively new spot for deliveries — a dead-end street of scattered homes that had, in the past, been deemed too dangerous for regular visits.

headline: Pondering How Tales Are Told
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Theater is fundamentally a storytelling medium, and at the 38th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays here, the manner in which tales are told — be they fantastical, historical or ripped from the headlines — became a recurring theme in the five full-length plays on offer. The finest of the bunch was Lucas Hnath’s “The Christians,” in which a debate over the meaning of that big book of stories known as the Bible causes a dangerous rift in a thriving evangelical church.

headline: Reaction to Cairo University Blasts
text: Two witnesses spoke out after explosions near Cairo University in what appeared to be a militant attack targeting security forces.

headline: 10 Tentacles, 12 Recipes
text: Squid made easy.

headline: Hank Lauricella, 83, Last of a Football Breed
text: Hank Lauricella, the last of the great football single-wing tailbacks and all-around players, who was known as Mr. Everything at the University of Tennessee, died March 25 in Jefferson, La. A Louisiana legislator for 32 years, he was 83.

headline: Venture Capital’s Need for Secrecy Collides With Public’s Right to Know
text: California is home to some of the biggest venture capital firms and many of the young companies they invest in. So it is not surprising that the state has been a major battleground in efforts to strike a balance between the venture industry’s need for confidentiality and the public’s right to know about investments made by public agencies.

headline: Another Warning for the Northwest From Chile’s Earthquake Hot Zone
text: As disaster agencies tally scattered deaths and damage from the 8.2-magnitude earthquake (and thankfully modest tsunami) off the coast of northern Chile on Tuesday night, earthquake experts have been stressing two facts:

headline: 9 Novels Both Girls and Boys Can Love
text: The Motherlode contributor Jessica Lahey appeared on the Today show discussing “closing the chapter on boy vs. girl books.” Smart topic — as a passionate reading child, I actually cared a whole lot about whether the protagonist of most books was a boy or a girl (for a rare few it didn’t matter at all), but my favorite books were the ones in which both sexes got equal playing time, either because gender didn’t matter in a particular storyline, or because the book or series followed multiple characters, both male and female.

headline: Abortion Providers in Texas Sue Over a Restrictive Rule That Could Close Clinics
text: Health clinics offering abortions in Texas filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday to block a new state rule that could shut down more than half of the state’s remaining providers this fall, forcing women seeking an abortion in southern and western Texas to drive several hundred miles each way or go out of state.

headline: Gannett Makes Deal With Weinstein to Develop Entertainment Material
text: LOS ANGELES — Gannett joined the ranks of journalistically oriented media companies trying to make show business connections, announcing on Wednesday a deal that gives the Weinstein Company a first look at Gannett journalism with an eye toward developing movies, television shows or material for other types of media.

headline: The Gun Report: April 2, 2014
text: Colorado, which suffered through the Columbine High School and Aurora movie theater massacres, passed a law in July limiting the size of ammunition magazines to 15 rounds and expanding background checks to both online and private firearm sales. But Second Amendment advocates are taking the state to court over it.

headline: Mental Health Groups Split on Bill to Overhaul Care
text: Lawmakers, patient advocates and the millions of Americans living with a psychiatric diagnosis agree that the nation’s mental health care system is broken, and on Thursday, Congress will hear testimony on the most ambitious overhaul plan in decades, a bill that has already stirred longstanding divisions in mental health circles.

headline: Disney Soundtrack Freezes Out Shakira
text: The “Frozen” soundtrack is a hit. We already knew that. But now we know that it is a really, really big hit. Like, on the Adele-Taylor Swift scale.

headline: JPMorgan Executive May Trade Corporate Saddle for a Real One
text: Blythe Masters is looking forward to taking “some well-deserved time off” when she leaves her job as a top executive at JPMorgan Chase later this year, the bank said in an internal memo on Wednesday.

headline: The Perpetual Bubble Economy
text: Want a thriving labor market? Blow a bubble.

headline: ‘I Believe in the Valor of Pallor’
text: Daughter of Arie Kopelman, the former chairman of Chanel, and sister-in-law to Drew Barrymore, Jill Kargman, 39, is known for writing lighthearted novels including “The Ex-Mrs. Hedgefund” and “Arm Candy.” More recently, she released a collection of essays called “Sometimes I Feel Like a Nut” and is working on a scripted comedy for Bravo. A native of New York, she lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Harry Kargman, and their three children, and approaches beauty with as much humor as she does her writing.

headline: App Smart: Converting Units
text: A suite of apps can help you easily convert pounds to dollars, meters to feet and even more obscure units of measurement.

headline: A Singer Confidently Following Her Heart
text: Alexa Ray Joel, the 28-year-old daughter of Billy Joel and Christie Brinkley, has her father’s eyes. Large, round, heavy lidded and soulful, they express a confidence and brash, forthright attitude that is also conveyed in singing whose rough timbre and piercing high notes at times bring to mind a soprano answer to Stevie Nicks. Her sound, though not beautiful, is many shaded and emotionally high pitched. She has no problems with intonation.

headline: FIFA Fines and Bans Barcelona From Transfer Market
text: Barcelona has been banned from acquiring new players until the summer of 2015 by FIFA, which punished the Spanish club Wednesday for what it said were repeated violations of the rules for signing teenage players.

headline: Weights or Measures, Converted on the Fly
text: DO you automatically know how many kilograms are in a pound? I do. It’s 0.45359237. I have to know this because I also write about tech outside the United States, and while feet and pounds are used to measure some things in America, almost every other country has adopted the metric system.

headline: Teaching About Climate Change With The New York Times
text: Updated: Nov., 2015

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 71
text: The fashion police cordoned off a section of the Internet Tuesday and gleefully took some pepper spray to the new away uniform the United States men’s and women’s national teams will be wearing on soccer fields around the world, including at the World Cup in Brazil. Definitely not an April Fools’ Day joke.

headline: Senate Questions Barra on G.M. Safety
text: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri and Senator Dean Heller of Nevada questioned the chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra, during a hearing on the company’s safety problems.

headline: Leaving Few Clues Behind
text: The first sign that something was not right came when Jay Ott’s co-workers at the Dock Group began to gather at their Chelsea office on Monday morning last week.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,400,000
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Plum Picks from Jean Paul Gaultier’s Archive Go Up for Sale at Matches
text: Jean Paul Gaultier’s most iconic looks, from the cone bra to the corset, were canonized in an exhibition last fall at the Brooklyn Museum, “Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk.” Now, those who coveted the vintage pieces in the show can buy similar ones with the click of a mouse. The British online boutique Matches Fashion has partnered with Cameron Silver, the owner of the Decades vintage emporium in Los Angeles, to offer up a range of exclusive pieces from the Gaultier vault. The online sale, beginning today and lasting 10 days, features unworn items spanning 20 years that Silver culled from the archive of Gaultier’s parent company AEFFE; it coincides with the London debut of the same museum retrospective at the Barbican, which runs from April 9 to August 25.

headline: Where the Amazon Fire TV Fits Into the Living Room
text: Amazon on Wednesday announced its very own streaming media box, the Amazon Fire TV. It costs $99 and will stream Netflix, Amazon Instant (of course), Hulu Plus, Showtime Anytime, Crackle and Vimeo, and more to be named.

headline: The Rail Content Is On the Move
text: Thank you for visiting The Rail. This blog’s regular features, including live race analysis and news and notes from Joe Drape, Melissa Hoppert and others, can now be found on the sports home page. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely horse racing news.

headline: What to Take on the Ark? Songs, of Course
text: Laundry detergent. Light bulbs. Tulip bulbs. Warm underwear. Fish hooks for fish on a Friday. These were among the 92 items on Noah’s packing list as he prepared to set sail on his ark, according to “Ark Luggage,” a new song with music by David Lang and words by the filmmaker Peter Greenaway that had its American premiere on Tuesday evening at the National Opera Center in Manhattan.

headline: G.M. Secrecy on Crashes Adds to Families’ Pain
text: There is anger that General Motors did not come forward sooner with information about its faulty cars. There is grief that loved ones were lost in crashes that might have been preventable. And there is outrage that federal safety regulators did not intervene.

headline: Parting With DeSean Jackson, the Eagles Added a Kick
text: For six seasons the Philadelphia Eagles basked in the glow of their star receiver DeSean Jackson. Philadelphia tagged him as its franchise player two years ago, and in 2013 he rewarded the Eagles with a Pro Bowl season, catching 82 passes for 1,332 yards.

headline: Terminal Tossing and Turning
text: The kernel of inspiration for Karen Russell’s new novella, “Sleep Donation,” appears to come from Gabriel García Márquez’s classic “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” which described a plague of insomnia that comes to the mythical Latin American town Macondo — a plague that makes the afflicted unable to sleep for days and causes such memory loss that objects, plants and animals need to be labeled. A sign hung around the neck of a cow reads: “This is the cow. She must be milked every morning.”

headline: Amazon Unveils Fire TV
text: Amazon’s vice president for Kindle, Peter Larsen, announced the set-top device as part of its plans to merge shopping and entertainment.

headline: Where a Laugh Track Is Do-It-Yourself
text: Certain television comedies seem more insecure than ever these days, appearing to amplify the laugh track or studio-audience giggles to deafening proportions to make sure viewers know that something funny just happened. So shows that let you make your own decisions about what’s worth a laugh are refreshing if for no other reason than that they demonstrate a certain respect for the audience.

headline: Bookshelf | Choice Bits
text: Musings from Diane Keaton’s upcoming memoir, in which she confronts Hollywood’s (and perhaps her own) preoccupation with youth and beauty.

headline: The Jonathan Pollard Case, Explained
text: Jonathan J. Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel, is the only person in U.S. history to receive a life sentence for spying for an American ally.

headline: A Cruise Line Adds Women to the Dancer Pool
text: Gender equality hits the high seas as Crystal Cruises will add women to the until-now all male host pool, dancers hired to cha-cha, waltz and jitterbug with solo or partnerless cruisers on three coming trans-Atlantic itineraries.

headline: Embracing Spring Fashion With Colors and Prints
text: Congratulations, you’ve made it to the other side. It’s officially spring, and even if you haven’t completely thawed, the days are longer, the sun is out and it’s time to brighten (and lighten) up. Start by embracing color and print, and wear something with a dash of humor — say, a sweet pair of emoji slippers. This is the happy season.

headline: Program Looks to Give Bees a Leg (or Six) Up
text: LOCKEFORD, Calif. — Helping America’s beleaguered bees could start with something as humble as planting a shrub.

headline: Tavi and the Taviettes
text: She counts among her friends the actress Emma Watson, the singer Lorde and the fashion designer Rachel Antonoff (“She has gravitas”), but the real impact of Tavi Gevinson, the 17-year-old fashion-prodigy-turned-publishing-mogul, can be seen most clearly in the young women who circle in her orbit.

headline: Her Mother’s Life as a Prequel
text: Maggie Betts grew up with money, thanks to her father, Roland W. Betts, the developer, owner of Chelsea Piers and close friend of George W. Bush. She has powerful friends, including famous filmmakers and flamboyant fashion designers. And she likes going out, with enough appearances on the party pages to fill a large photo album.

headline: For the Tech-Savvy With a Need for Speed, a Limited Choice of Towns With Fiber
text: If you’ve ever drummed your fingers waiting for a web page to load or a file to download, you know that the latest apps and devices are only as good as your Internet connection. And yet, in the United States only 7.7 percent of broadband subscribers have optical fiber connections, the fastest and highest quality available.

headline: Look Out! That Song Is Going to Hit You Right in the Head!
text: Kraftwerk, the German band whose music predicted pop’s electronic future back in the 1970s, hasn’t forgotten an old-fashioned precept: A concert is a physical, spatial event. Even as all sorts of experiences — arts, communication, commerce — migrate to two-dimensional computer screens, “An Evening With Kraftwerk: 3-D Concert” played up the sensations of a particular performance in a particular room. Kraftwerk’s current tour found an ideal setting on Tuesday night as the band started a two-night stand at the ornate United Palace Theater in Washington Heights.

headline: Showing Off More Than His Arm
text: With Tim Tebow out of the N.F.L. and off to a career in broadcasting, the league is in need of a new fresh-faced, polarizing star.

headline: A Timeout for Art
text: LOS ANGELES — “I’m not here for the free drinks,” said the pop star Katy Perry, hoisting up her cocktail in a mock cheer. “I’m here for an art education. I want to stimulate my neural pathways.”

headline: Black Bear in Williamsburg
text: A decade ago, when Williamsburg reigned as the coolest neighborhood in the land, North Sixth Street and its cluster of Asian-fusion restaurants were already a stomping ground for tourists. Today, the strip is even more suburbanized, with an Urban Outfitters to come. It’s an odd habitat for Black Bear, a beer-and-a-shot joint that opened last fall and quickly became a congenial den for hibernation.

headline: No Charges for Officer in Hostage’s Death
text: A Nassau County police officer who accidentally shot and killed a college student last May while confronting an armed hostage taker will not face criminal charges, the county’s district attorney said on Wednesday.

headline: A Muddy Tract Now, but by 2020, China’s Answer to Wall St.
text: There isn’t much to see in Qianhai today except for a tract of muddy, mostly undeveloped land that has been reclaimed from the sea in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, near the border with Hong Kong.

headline: Parsing Microsoft’s Decision to Cut Windows Fees
text: Microsoft’s new virtual assistant for its mobile operating system got the most attention at a company developer conference on Wednesday, but a decision by Microsoft to drop licensing fees on some Windows devices is the news from the event that will very likely have the most lasting consequences for the company.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, Kenya, Afghanistan and Brazil.

headline: BlackBerry Breaks Up With T-Mobile
text: While BlackBerry’s dismal market share in the United States might suggest that it needs all the retailers it can get, the Canadian smartphone maker has now cut off one prominent American customer. Weeks after a public spat between the two companies’ chief executives, BlackBerry said that it would not allow T-Mobile US to sell BlackBerry phones after April 25.

headline: For Many Germans, Pilots’ Walkout Crosses a Line
text: FRANKFURT — As with so many situations in Germany, there is an orderly way to do things and then there are ways that are not socially acceptable. That principle, it turns out, applies even to labor strikes.

headline: Normcore Street-Style
text: Joan Smalls and other street style examples of normcore.

headline: Jeff Bezos, Please Call Your Office
text: Amazon’s news conference on Wednesday solved one of the biggest riddles in technology — when would Amazon ever introduce one of the devices it has been endlessly rumored to be working on?

headline: The New Normal
text: Normcore (noun) 1. A fashion movement, c. 2014, in which scruffy young urbanites swear off the tired street-style clichés of the last decade — skinny jeans, wallet chains, flannel shirts — in favor of a less-ironic (but still pretty ironic) embrace of bland, suburban anti-fashion attire. (See Jeans, mom. Sneakers, white.)

headline: Moving a Slab of Museum Wall, Artfully
text: A handful of art-and-dance lovers dodged cranes on Friday afternoon while making their way to the West Village construction site of the future Whitney Museum of American Art to watch a performance piece as part of the Whitney Biennial. Hard hats were passed out; release forms were signed.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: She Can Remember Everything, Even Her Show’s Various Time Slots
