text: “Unforgettable” is a well-made cop show on CBS that could have easily been a distant memory by now. Instead, it begins the second half of its second season on Friday night, a case study in how to give more chances to a decent show that didn’t find its natural home immediately.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Kiev Women’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what the gals are wearing this season.

headline: The Many Classes of Google Stock
text: The price of Google shares is going to be cut in half on Thursday.

headline: Two Stolen Paintings Are Found in Italy
text: In 1975, a factory worker at Fiat, the Italian carmaker, bought two colorful paintings for about $70 at an auction in Turin of objects left unclaimed by train passengers. For years, they hung on his kitchen wall. One was a still life with fruit and a small dog, the other showed a woman in white seated in a verdant garden.

headline: Carters Return to Capital, Onstage
text: WASHINGTON — Jimmy Carter was never a creature of Washington, and so after he lost re-election in 1980 — “I was involuntarily retired,” he often says — he seldom looked back. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter will return to the capital in the strange role of spectator to his often-maligned presidency.

headline: In Dallas, Echoes of an Olympiad
text: DALLAS — On Sunday night, the last day of the Spring North American Championships here, three major titles were decided.

headline: Peabody Awards Honor News Coverage, ‘Scandal’ and Foreign Dramas
text: The annual Peabody Awards, more plentiful than ever, were announced on Wednesday with winners honored for everything from news coverage of typhoons in the Philippines to the guilty pleasure of the ABC drama “Scandal.”

headline: Paris St.-Germain Beats Chelsea but Loses Ibrahimovic
text: PARIS — The ball had barely settled in the back of the net, and José Mourinho, Chelsea’s unpredictable manager, was already on his way to the Paris St.-Germain bench. While the P.S.G. players and coaches celebrated Javier Pastore’s last-minute goal, Mourinho somewhat bizarrely walked around shaking hands with the ecstatic home side, too.

headline: Dean Wareham, Longtime New Yorker, on Why L.A. Is the Land of Milk and Honey
text: For as long as indie rock has been a genre, Dean Wareham has been a part of it. Galaxie 500, the band the New Zealand-born singer and guitarist formed with a pair of Harvard classmates in the late ’80s, informed a generation of shoegazers and remains a make-out-session staple today. Equally beloved is his ’90s dream-pop band Luna, through which he met his wife, the singer and bassist Britta Phillips. Together, they’ve spent the last decade or so writing and touring as Dean & Britta. They’ve also been regular collaborators of the director Noah Baumbach, scoring “The Squid and the Whale” and playing the co-hosts of an awkward dinner party in last year’s “Frances Ha.”

headline: State Actions on the Minimum Wage
text: President Obama’s proposal to increase the federal minimum wage to $10.10 from $7.25 is unlikely to pass through Congress, but several states have been tackling the issue on their own.

headline: Deals at Rizzoli, Modani, Pollack and Treillage
text: During Pollack’s warehouse sale, through Monday, fabrics including sheers, velvets, silks and embroideries are up to 90 percent off (Peachy upholstery fabric in a color called Carrot Cake, originally $155 a yard, is $20 a yard); 629 Grove Street (16th Street), Jersey City; 212-627-7766, pollackassociates.com.

headline: Homes Worth Aspiring To
text: Ron Broadhurst’s new book “The Urban House” (Rizzoli, $45), is a sensory splash of 25 pristine dwellings in cities around the world. Nearly half are in New York and 11 were designed by women, including Andrée Putman, Annabelle Selldorf and Jeanne Gang. Richard Meier wrote the foreword and is represented by a floor-through white palace in the Sherry-Netherland.

headline: Cozy Up to the Campfire With Color and Ease
text: Tae Kim, the founder of Alite Designs, a San Francisco company specializing in stylish camping equipment, had the molded fiberglass chairs of Charles and Ray Eames in mind when he designed Bison ($200). Even the four colors of the new chair’s water-resistant removable sling seat (black, Tiburon blue, Presidio green and Jupiter orange) are out of the midcentury-modern playbook. But Bison is nothing if not evolutionary.

headline: If Cherry Trees Came with Gold Dust
text: Lindsey Adelman’s Cherry Bomb lighting fixtures, to be introduced next week at the Nilufar Gallery in Milan, were inspired by cherry trees she admired in Japan. The lights, which resemble brass vines that creep up walls or across ceilings, are also named after the fireworks that are illegal in many states.

headline: Making a Scene, Onstage and Off
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — For years, the crystal chandelier that Eugene Lee salvaged back in the 1980s, when the original Helen Hayes Theater in Times Square was being demolished, presided over Studio 8H at Rockefeller Center, adding a little elegance to the rarefied air around “Saturday Night Live” cast members like Eddie Murphy and Dennis Miller.

headline: Loving Trees, Even the Messy Ones
text: In 1993 Enzo Enea, a landscape architect, bought out his father’s garden ornament business in Switzerland. Today he has nearly 200 employees who have landscaped corporate headquarters, churchyards, rooftop gardens, vacation homes and condominium projects in Miami, where Mr. Enea, 49, has a satellite office. His next Florida project, the Oceana Bal Harbour condominium building, designed by the architect Bernardo Fort-Brescia, is on a 5.5-acre oceanfront site that sits across Collins Avenue from the Bal Harbour Marina and will be home to two giant outdoor Jeff Koons sculptures. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: Should I Add Lighting to Closets?
text: Q. My home has deep, dark closets. Should I add lighting to make them more of a selling feature?

headline: Ticking and Tocking in Playful Ceramics
text: Heath Ceramics is venturing into wall clocks in partnership with House Industries, a Delaware design firm best known for its vintage-inspired typefaces. Their clock called Stencil features numbers in a newly created font that Andy Cruz, a House Industries founder, said was inspired by “19th-century French stencils, Shaker tin stencils and your standard American G.I. stencil.” The Ornament clock has a pattern one might expect to see on a Nordic ski sweater.

headline: A Painter Stretches
text: It’s hard to believe, but there was a time when being a starving artist in New York could have real estate advantages. Tom Levine is proof.

headline: Gathering Moss
text: BREVARD, N.C. — Look up, Mossin’ Annie Martin told me, look up on the tin roof of the “bulimia treatment center.” Can you see the rust-green clump waiting to be rescued by a loving hand? That’s Entodon seductrix: what she, and no one else, refers to as “shiny, sexy moss.”

headline: Iraq Veteran at Fort Hood Kills 3 and Himself in Rampage
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — A soldier who was being evaluated for post-traumatic stress disorder opened fire at Fort Hood on Wednesday, killing three people and wounding 16 before killing himself, the authorities said. The shooting set off a huge police response and shut down the sprawling Army base, the same facility where a deadly rampage by an officer resulted in 13 deaths in 2009.

headline: Stone Furnishings: Petrified, in a Good Way
text: Gregory Buntain and Ian Collings, partners in the Brooklyn design firm Fort Standard, love materials with a sense of permanence and age: thick white oak, like the wood they use for the oversize legs on their Column tables, for instance, or the rough cast-bronze they chose for their chunky Sprue candelabra.

headline: NBC Sports Isn’t Paying Elliott to Be on the Bench
text: Josh Elliott joined NBC Sports on Wednesday and compared himself to being “the last man on the bench of the Showtime Lakers with the best seat in the house.”

headline: Mets Fall as Their Pitching Concerns Grow
text: The Mets are often asked what reasons they have to be optimistic. Lately, their unequivocal response has been starting pitching. It is their obvious strength, now and for the future. They consider Matt Harvey, Zack Wheeler, Noah Syndergaard and Rafael Montero precious assets. The Mets plan to be cautious with them, bring them along at the right pace and eventually ride them to relevance.

headline: An Illness, Inherited?
text: EDINBURGH — I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside. I don’t know what meds were administered to me in that developing stage. I lived in the belly of a woman I would never know. But my relationship with something dubiously entitled mental health was already established.

headline: Lofty Newspaper Project Is Closed After Two Years
text: It started as a way to solve one of the thorniest problems in the newspaper industry — how to transition from the high margins yet declining circulation of print to the less profitable but fast-growing readership of the web.

headline: New Mexico: Albuquerque Seeks Police Monitoring
text: Mayor Richard J. Berry of Albuquerque asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to monitor the city’s police force, roiled by a rash of shootings resulting in 23 deaths and 14 injuries in four years. In a news conference, Mr. Berry also announced plans to certify all of the department’s 426 field officers in crisis intervention so they can better handle calls involving people with mental illness, who made up the majority of the victims in the shootings, and implement an evaluation system for the officers. The changes depend on extra funding, as well as approval by the police union and the Justice Department, which has been investigating allegations of civil rights violations by the police for 16 months.

headline: Iran’s Choice for U.N. Post Fuels Tension With U.S.
text: UNITED NATIONS — Six months after President Obama made a groundbreaking telephone call to his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani, the administration has made clear that expectations of a complete thaw in relations between Iran and the United States are premature.

headline: Ex-Contractor Sentenced for Leak to Fox News
text: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a former State Department contractor to 13 months in prison for leaking information about North Korea to a Fox News reporter. The former contractor, Stephen J. Kim, pleaded guilty in February in exchange for a deal that would limit his prison time to that duration. Mr. Kim is the sixth person to be convicted under the Obama administration after being accused of leaking information to the public, and two other cases remain open.

headline: Updates on the Fort Hood Shooting
text: As our colleagues Manny Fernandez and Ashley Southall report, four people were shot and killed, including the gunman, and 16 others were injured in a shooting at Fort Hood in Texas on Wednesday, stirring memories of a mass shooting at the same base almost five years ago. Authorities said the gunman died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The Lede followed media coverage of the event in the first hours after the news broke.

headline: E.P.A. Faulted for Failure to Report Risks
text: The Environmental Protection Agency failed to consistently disclose health risks, including possible cancer risks, to research study participants who were exposed to dangerous pollutants, an agency watchdog report has found. An E.P.A. inspector general’s report released Wednesday said that when the agency exposed 81 people to soot and diesel exhaust emissions in studies in 2010 and 2011, the risks were not always consistently represented and did not include information on cancer risks associated with long-term exposure. The E.P.A. said risks associated with cancer in the study, which only briefly exposed participants to the pollutants, were so minimal that they were not included on consent forms obtained from the subjects.

headline: A Union Aims at Pittsburgh’s Biggest Employer
text: PITTSBURGH — For decades, United States Steel was this city’s dominant employer, but now the biggest employer is the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, with its 22 hospitals and 62,000 workers.

headline: Early Warning
text: Someone at the Supreme Court got an assignment last week: start drafting a majority opinion to answer the question whether a for-profit company can claim a religious exemption from the federal requirement to include particular products in any employee insurance plan.

headline: Upfront Season Swells as Media Companies Compete for Ads
text: THERE are so many upfront presentations these days, as media companies compete for advertising dollars ahead of the 2014-15 television season, it often seems as if you can’t tell the players without a program.

headline: Report Finds Hispanics Faring Better Than Blacks
text: Hispanics generally fare better than blacks in rankings of inequality in American life, according to a new report by the National Urban League to be released on Thursday.

headline: The Price of a Slur
text: MINNEAPOLIS — THE idea of the “Indian giver” has always been deeply ironic, since it’s Indians who have been on the receiving end of some very bad gifts indeed. Last week’s offering from Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, was only the latest.

headline: War and Unrest Provide for a Scarred Campaign Trail in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There is much about Afghanistan’s presidential campaigns that Americans would probably find familiar. Chartered jets carry candidates to corners of the country where they would ordinarily never set foot, political operatives try to spin skeptical reporters, and rich men hand over bundles of cash to curry favor with their next potential president.

headline: Tax the Childless to Help Parents?
text: Does it make sense for people without children to subsidize tax breaks for the costs others bear for being parents?

headline: We’re Not No. 1! We’re Not No. 1!
text: We in the United States grow up celebrating ourselves as the world’s most powerful nation, the world’s richest nation, the world’s freest and most blessed nation.

headline: Fake Meats, Finally, Taste Like Chicken
text: Last May, Whole Foods recalled two types of curried chicken salad that had been sold in some of its stores in the Northeast.

headline: Health Enrollment Numbers Lift Democratic Hopes
text: WASHINGTON — After months of pummeling by Republicans and with a grim election season approaching, Democrats on Tuesday had a rare bright day. President Obama’s announcement that the new health care plan had enrolled 7.1 million Americans coincided with the release by Representative Paul D. Ryan of a new Republican budget that proposes changes in Medicare and deep cuts in spending.

headline: Campaign of Resilience
text: Afghans voted in the first election in the nation’s modern history with the potential to bring a peaceful change of leadership.

headline: Surprise! The Rich Won One
text: Today, we are going to discuss the Supreme Court decision on political donations. Already, we have run into a terrible problem, which is the difficulty in having a fun conversation about campaign finance laws.

headline: In Florida, Bid to Cut Voter Rolls Is Set Back
text: MIAMI — Gov. Rick Scott’s effort to remove voters who are not American citizens from voter registration rolls, a subject of continuing political controversy, has suffered a one-two punch in the past week.

headline: Afghan Candidates Make Final Pitches
text: Before Saturday’s presidential election, Afghan candidates campaigned under tight security amid worries of violence and voter fraud.

headline: Washingtonians Get to Know Democrat They Picked Over the Mayor
text: WASHINGTON — Four days before the vote, a worker hurrying into the Anacostia Metro station during the morning rush said he was unhappy with Mayor Vincent C. Gray and would vote for his leading rival. “I kind of like that one,” he said, fumbling for a name. “The lady. She’s real good.”

headline: The Court Follows the Money
text: The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its crusade to knock down all barriers to the distorting power of money on American elections. In the court’s most significant campaign-finance ruling since Citizens United in 2010, five justices voted to eliminate sensible and long-established contribution limits to federal political campaigns. Listening to their reasoning, one could almost imagine that the case was simply about the freedom of speech in the context of elections.

headline: At Trial, Queens Doctor Is Accused of Recklessly Prescribing Drugs
text: One patient was found dead in his bed from an overdose, with a prescription for painkillers from a Queens doctor on the night stand. Another was discovered lifeless and slumped over in his car, a pill bottle naming the same doctor under his body.

headline: Measuring the Success of Health Reform
text: More than seven million people have signed up for insurance on the new federal and state health exchanges, President Obama said this week. Millions more could be added to that total once insurers tally up the people who bought policies directly from them and when those who tried to apply on balky websites are able to complete the process.

headline: What’s Next for Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The first open enrollment period for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has just ended, and consumers, insurers and federal officials now face many immediate chores and challenges that will help determine if the law works as intended.

headline: NASA Breaks Most Contact With Russia
text: NASA said Wednesday that it was suspending most contacts with Russian space agency officials, underscoring just how rapidly the Russian-American relationship is deteriorating in the wake of the Kremlin’s annexation of Crimea and hinting at further ramifications that will go beyond previous rifts.

headline: Risky Games in the South China Sea
text: Undaunted by China’s aggressive rhetoric and expansionist claims to nearly all of the South China Sea, the Philippines has filed a legal case against Beijing with an international arbitration tribunal in The Hague. This is an appropriate venue to resolve a major dispute peacefully and in accord with global norms. The strategy of the Philippines has implications for others with similar claims against China — Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei and Taiwan — and thus deserves support from the international community.

headline: As He Cultivates a Star Prospect, Ovechkin Shows His Own Growth
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — A banner that hangs from a balcony overlooking the ice at the Washington Capitals’ practice complex here reads, “Congrats Evgeny — 1st NHL Goal.”

headline: Medicare to Share Information on Pay for Physicians
text: Medicare said on Wednesday that it planned to make available to consumers and others detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association and other groups. The information will include data on the $77 billion paid by Medicare in 2012 to more than 880,000 health care professionals for 6,000 types of services and procedures. Patient information will remain private. “Data like these can shine a light on how care is delivered in the Medicare program,” said Jonathan Blum, principal deputy administrator at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, in a blog post. “They can help consumers compare the services provided and payments received by individual health care providers. Businesses and consumers alike can use these data to drive decision-making and reward quality, cost-effective care.” Medicare, the federal insurance program for the elderly, was prevented from releasing information on individual physicians until a ruling last year by a federal judge in Florida. In a statement issued by the A.M.A., the medical group raised concerns that Medicare’s broad release of the payment information could “mislead the public” and recommended that doctors be allowed to review and correct any information before it was made public.

headline: Psychologist Helps Huskies Forge Lasting Bonds
text: In 2012, Leon Tolksdorf arrived in Storrs, Conn., from Germany, unsure of how to interact with some of his teammates. He knew his fellow Berliner Niels Giffey and had played on a club team with the brother of another German player on the roster, Enosch Wolf, but relating to his peers from Brooklyn or Chicago was a new experience.

headline: In Bullet-Ridden Afghan Districts, Free Vote Seems an Empty Promise
text: CHARKH, Afghanistan — One of the few polling centers in this part of Logar Province is the government’s district headquarters, a building so devastated by rocket attacks and Taliban gunfire that it looks more like a bomb shelter than an administrative office.

headline: True to Kentucky, a Fan Base Wields Its Own Megaphone
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Kentucky lost to a middling Arkansas team at home on Feb. 27 and, two days later, fell on the road to lowly South Carolina. The preseason No. 1 team in the country, the Wildcats were 21-8, and they soon dropped out of the top 25.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 2, 2014
text: April 2, 2014

headline: Facing the Skepticism in Adoption, in Qatar and in the U.S.
text: In the United States, when others voice their confusion about why parents adopt, it is simple enough to smile and ignore it. In other cultures, that gap in understanding may not be so easily handled. I read the story of Matthew and Grace Huang, the Los Angeles couple sentenced last week in Qatar to three years in prison after being found guilty of killing their 8-year-old adopted daughter, with familiar sorrow. In January 2013, the Huangs rushed their daughter, Gloria, to a hospital in Qatar, where they lived with their three African-born children. After her death, the couple was arrested and accused of withholding food and water from the girl for four days, which they deny.

headline: Bringing Big Money Out of the Shadows
text: Once again, a narrow majority of the Supreme Court has knocked down a campaign finance limit, and, once again, court watchers have gone ballistic. Yet for those who worry about the polarizing effect of money on politics, the McCutcheon decision gives us a little hope. A world in which individuals can give limited, disclosed amounts of money to an unlimited number of politicians is preferable to one in which large chunks are given only to “super PACs” and other unaccountable outside groups.

headline: How Not to Enforce Campaign Laws
text: WASHINGTON — THE Federal Election Commission is failing to enforce the nation’s campaign finance laws. I’m in a position to know. I’m the vice chairwoman of the commission.

headline: Chorus Starter
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh, this one hits my sweet spot. Perhaps a bit easy for a Thursday, but the theme highlights one of my favorite songs by David Bowie, “CH-CH-CH-CH-CHANGES.” But that’s not all.

headline: A Doctor, and a Conflicted Soldier
text: Over time, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan grew more religious and more outspoken against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, according to relatives and acquaintances.

headline: Cuomo Drops Plan to Use State Money to Pay for College Classes for Inmates
text: In an important speech at a gathering of black and Latino lawmakers in February, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unveiled what he billed as a bold plan to attack the problem of high rates of recidivism: The state would pay for college classes for prison inmates.

headline: A Student of the Game, on the Golf Course and Off
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The week of the Founders Cup in Arizona, Karrie Webb sat for an interview with filmmakers for a feature-length documentary on the 13 women who started the Ladies Professional Golf Association. The project intrigued Webb, a seven-time winner of major tournaments and a World Golf Hall of Fame member whose excellence in the game is surpassed only by her encyclopedic knowledge of its history.

headline: Greece: Immunity Lifted for Lawmakers
text: As part of a widening effort to clamp down on the activities of Golden Dawn, a party widely condemned as neo-Nazi and violent, Greece’s Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the party’s lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization. Of the party’s 16 legislators, 13 now face prosecution. Meanwhile, in a potentially serious blow to the coalition of Prime Minister Antonis Samaras, a close aide to Mr. Samaras resigned after a video posted online appeared to show him accusing the prime minister of influencing an investigation into Golden Dawn in order to gain votes. In a note announcing his resignation on Wednesday, the aide, Panagiotis Baltakos, said he made the comments, which were secretly recorded, to “relieve pressure” on him by Golden Dawn. He said the party officials had accused him of conspiring against the party.

headline: Israel: Foreign Ministry Strike Ends
text: Employees of Israel’s Foreign Ministry on Wednesday announced the end of a general strike over pay and working conditions that had shut down the ministry’s offices and the country’s 103 missions abroad for more than a week. The labor dispute disrupted visits of Israeli officials abroad and visits of foreign dignitaries to Israel and left hundreds of Israelis who had passport problems stranded in foreign countries. It ended with the signing of a document of principles that will serve as the basis of an agreement pledging an improvement in conditions, including financial incentives for diplomats serving abroad in countries considered hardship postings.

headline: China Extends Tax Break Program to Spur Economy
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government on Wednesday announced a modest package of economic stimulus measures, the latest sign of concern by Beijing that growth may be slowing more than expected.

headline: Woman Mauled by Chimp Can’t Sue Connecticut
text: A woman who was mauled and blinded by a 200-pound chimpanzee in 2009 will not be able to sue the State of Connecticut, a legislative judiciary committee in Hartford ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Japan Says It Will Abide by Whaling Ruling
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica. Separately, officials in the Agriculture and Fishing Ministry said Japan would cancel that annual hunt in the Southern Ocean this year, which had been conducted within a loophole in a moratorium on commercial whaling that allowed killing for research purposes. However, the ministry left open the possibility that it might restart the hunt in the future under a different legal reasoning. The international court’s ruling said that the scientific output from Japan’s whaling program “to date appears limited” and suggested that the hunt was continued because of politics and logistics, rather than science.

headline: Playing Like a Playoff Team, the Knicks Move Into Eighth
text: Madison Square Garden has been the site of so much sadness this season. So much flimsy defense. So much losing. So many boos.

headline: A Victory, and a Knife in the Side
text: Did you know that Mayor Bill de Blasio persuaded Albany to pay for UPK and won a great victory?

headline: On the First Stop of a Farewell Tour, Jeter Does a Ceremony in a Flash
text: HOUSTON — As Derek Jeter stepped into the batter’s box Wednesday evening, the members of the Houston Astros who were not on the field emerged from their dugout and applauded him in the first of what will surely be many gestures by opposing teams to honor him throughout the season. Jeter has announced that this will be his final season, and most teams are expected to honor him during pregame ceremonies.

headline: De Blasio Naming Ex-Banker as Economic Development Corp. Chairman
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a complicated relationship with New York City’s business elite, many of whom view his populist agenda with skepticism and, in some cases, disdain.

headline: Deposed Ukrainian Leader Calls Crimea Annexation a ‘Tragedy’
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Viktor F. Yanukovych, the deposed president of Ukraine, called Russia’s annexation of Crimea a “tragedy” on Wednesday and said he would try to negotiate the region’s return from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: It’s Dark, It’s Raining, It’s Ugly Out There
text: Is anyone else beginning to wonder if the sun ever shines in “The Americans”?

headline: Criminal Inquiry Said to Be Opened on Citigroup
text: Just as Citigroup was putting a troubled past of taxpayer bailouts and risky investments behind it, the bank now finds itself in the government’s cross hairs again.

headline: Lacking Discipline, Nets Meet Punishment
text: As the Nets let the Knicks run away with the game, they let their emotions get away from them, too.

headline: Passing Concussion Tests, Harper Returns to Lineup
text: Shortly after the first group of Washington Nationals finished batting practice, Manager Matt Williams casually asked outfielder Bryce Harper if he was feeling well. Harper nodded and continued running into the dugout.

headline: Worker Is Killed in Fall at a Midtown Hotel
text: A worker died after he fell onto scaffolding at the Dream New York hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday, the police said.

headline: Stringer to Increase Oversight of New York City’s Computerization Contracts
text: A contractor revamping New York City’s 911 system billed the city $147 an hour for tasks that included opening an office door and having a large bug killed in the bathroom. A company hired to build an online procurement system for school principals bolstered profits by hiring low-paid programmers in India and Turkey, though it was supposed to employ only New Yorkers.

headline: Obama Discusses Fort Hood Shooting
text: President Obama discussed the shooting at Fort Hood on Wednesday.

headline: Richard Black, 92, Artist Who Conjured ‘Mr. Clean,’ Dies
text: Richard Black, a commercial artist who illustrated the original Mr. Clean, Procter & Gamble’s trademark “genie in a bottle,” died on Sunday at his home in Kettering, Ohio. He was 92.

headline: Robert Slater, 70, Journalist Covering Israel and Author
text: Robert Slater, a journalist and the author of more than two dozen books, including biographies of figures as diverse as the Israeli leader Golda Meir, the businessman Jack Welch and the billionaire and philanthropist George Soros, died on March 25 in Jerusalem. He was 70.

headline: Sensory Perception
text: Indulging his inner synesthete, the Turner Prize-winning artist Richard Deacon refracts Katie Peterson’s verse on the metamorphosis of the mind.

headline: Discovery to Make Scripted Online Videos With Oscar Winners
text: LOS ANGELES — A cable giant that specializes in nonfiction programming is teaming up with two movie superpowers to make scripted online videos.

text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: After Jeter Is Honored, Yankees Suffer Indignity: Another Loss to Astros
text: HOUSTON — As Derek Jeter stepped into the batter’s box in the first inning at Minute Maid Park on Wednesday, the members of the Houston Astros not on the field emerged from their dugout and applauded him in the first of what is destined to be many gestures of homage by opposing teams throughout the season.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 6:15 P.M. (MoreMax) MUNICH (2005) Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this story’s historical impetus — the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli athletes and coaches were killed by members of a Palestinian group known as Black September — to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath: Israel’s apparent campaign of vengeance, using five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects for years. Eric Bana portrays the film’s moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the deaths. Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Hanns Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz (above left with Mr. Zischler) play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas. “An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, ‘Munich’ is by far the toughest film of the director’s career and the most anguished,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But more than anything, she added, “ ‘Munich’ is a slammin’ entertainment filled with dazzling set pieces and geometric camerawork.”

headline: Mon Levinson, 88, Op Art Sculptor, Dies
text: Mon Levinson, who used plexiglass and other nontraditional materials in becoming a prominent Op Art sculptor, creating work that actively affects the viewer’s perception, died on March 25 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Cuomo Played Pivotal Role in Charter School Push
text: It was a frigid February day in Albany, and leaders of New York City’s charter school movement were anxious. They had gone to the capital to court lawmakers, but despite a boisterous showing by parents, there seemed to be little clarity about the future of their schools.

headline: Priscilla Morgan, Cultural Matchmaker, Dies at 94
text: Priscilla Morgan, a doyenne of international culture, longtime official of the Spoleto arts festival and all-around facilitator for artists of many stripes — including the painter Willem de Kooning, the theater composer Jerry Herman and the sculptor and designer Isamu Noguchi, who was also her longtime romantic partner — died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: Zoo Teams Up to Highlight Animal Mistreatment at Shows
text: A mace-wielding clown lashes at a bear cub. An elephant stands on its rear legs on the point of a stun gun, electric arcs running through its body.

headline: Japan Cancels Whale Hunt Off Antarctica After Ruling
text: TOKYO — Japan has canceled this year’s whale hunt off Antarctica, just days after an international court ruled against the killings, which had drawn worldwide criticism.

headline: Proposal Would Provide New York Police With Kits to Combat Overdoses
text: With deaths from heroin and opioid prescription pills soaring, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman on Thursday is expected to announce a push to have law enforcement officers across the state carry a drug that is effectively an antidote to overdose.

headline: Officials Discuss Fort Hood Shooting
text: Authorities at Fort Hood and Scott and White Memorial Hospital discussed the shooting at the Army base that killed 4 and wounded 16 on Wednesday.

headline: Gujarat Experiments With Expansion of Public Health Insurance
text: AHMEDABAD, India — After Yasin Mirza, a 65-year-old auto-rickshaw driver, suffered a heart attack while sitting on his bed at home after eating dinner, he required expensive triple bypass surgery. As a person who was officially classified as poor, he knew to use the Mukhyamantri Amrutum Yojana, Gujarat’s state health insurance plan, when seeking care at the government V.S. Hospital here.

headline: Hunt for Jet’s Black Boxes Is a Race Against Time
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — With only a few days left before the batteries on the data and voice recorders of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 are set to die, a multinational search force resumed its hunt on Thursday with 10 aircraft and nine ships sweeping a patch of the Indian Ocean about 1,050 miles west of Perth, Australia, and a British nuclear submarine preparing to join the hunt.

headline: In a More Rigorous Test, Consumer Reports Looks at Infant Seats

headline: Chad, Amid Criticism, Will Pull Troops From Force in Central Africa
text: UNITED NATIONS — Facing repeated criticism of its conduct, Chad announced Thursday that it would withdraw its troops from an African Union-led peacekeeping force in the neighboring Central African Republic.

headline: Does It Matter Where You Go to College?
text: It’s April, and that means colleges and universities are notifying high school seniors across the nation about whether they were accepted, rejected or wait-listed.

text: Updated, 10:40 a.m. | LONDON – Just Eat, an online food ordering service, said on Thursday that it had raised 360.1 million pounds, or almost $600 million, in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Vivendi Blocks Activist Group From Accessing Documents in SFR Sale

headline: Chinese Tech Company Kingsoft Seeks U.S. Listing for Mobile Subsidiary
text: HONG KONG — The latest Chinese technology company to seek a stock market listing in the United States comes with heavyweight backers and is a rare attempt at an offering by a parent company already listed in Hong Kong.

headline: China Leans Toward More Stimulus Measures
text: HONG KONG — China’s leaders are issuing increasingly clear signals that they plan another round of economic stimulus programs, as evidence accumulates that the economy is slowing more than expected this year.

headline: Israel Halts Prisoner Release as Talks Hit Impasse
text: ALGIERS — Israel said on Thursday that it would not go through with an already delayed release of Palestinian prisoners and was considering further sanctions against the Palestinians as the threat to the peace talks deepened further despite Secretary of State John Kerry’s concerted efforts to keep the process alive.

headline: Pakistani Ex-Leader Narrowly Misses Blast
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A bomb apparently directed at Pervez Musharraf, the former Pakistani military ruler, went off early Thursday, minutes after his convoy had passed an intersection in Islamabad, the capital, police officials said.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing

headline: New York Today: Cloud Show

headline: Out of Work, Out of Benefits, and Running Out of Options
text: BOSTON — Abe Gorelick has decades of marketing experience, an extensive contact list, an Ivy League undergraduate degree, a master’s in business from the University of Chicago, ideas about how to reach consumers young and old, experience working with businesses from start-ups to huge financial firms and an upbeat, effervescent way about him. What he does not have — and has not had for the last year — is a full-time job.

headline: The Campaigns for Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Most politicians’ homes I have visited here are heavy on fake gilt and rococo furniture, but Ashraf Ghani, one of the leading candidates in Saturday’s presidential election, is known as a technocrat and a sophisticate. “It’s a beautiful house,” I said, looking around at the exquisite Nuristani carved chests and Persian miniature paintings that decorated his living room. “It is,” replied Naseem Sharifi, one of Mr. Ghani’s campaign managers, beaming. Then he frowned. “The other day, they collected three or four kilos of human flesh off the roof.”

headline: TV Duel in Britain Is Seen to Favor Anti-European Party
text: LONDON — Heated and sometimes ill-tempered exchanges in the second of two television debates about whether Britain should leave the 28-nation European Union were judged on Thursday to have favored the United Kingdom Independence Party, further polarizing Britain’s discussion on the matter.

headline: Ukraine Implicates Ex-President and Russia in Protesters’ Deaths
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian authorities said Thursday that former President Viktor F. Yanukovych and Russian security agents were involved in plans for elite police units to open fire on antigovernment protesters in February, killing more than 100 people in the days immediately before the downfall of his government.

headline: Investcorp Joins Rush to Invest in European Distressed Debt
text: Investcorp, an investment firm based in Bahrain, made a splash investing in European luxury brands like Gucci and George Jensen.

headline: Credit Suisse Sets Millions Aside in Justice Dept. Case

headline: The Founder of Reputation.com Answers Reader Questions
text: Last week, The Times published a conversation with Michael Fertik, who founded Reputation.com, a reputation management company that helps businesses and people play down their negative search results, protect their personal information, gather positive reviews for their businesses and in general buff their images online.

headline: From Online News Alert to the Front Page
text: Editors of The Times meet every morning at 10 for about a half-hour to discuss the day’s news. On some days there is more news than others.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon’s Fire TV Is a Bid to Take Over the Living Room
text: The streaming media device that Amazon began selling on Wednesday, Fire TV, is part of the company’s multibillion-dollar effort to move from selling goods produced by others, which is traditionally a low-margin business, to presiding over the entire process of creation and consumption, David Streitfeld reports. Physical formats such as books, CDs and DVDs are disappearing, replaced by downloads and streaming.

headline: 2 Women Are Kidnapped From a Resort in Malaysia
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Gunmen kidnapped a Chinese tourist and a Filipino hotel worker, both women, from a beach resort on an island off the coast of Malaysian Borneo, the Chinese and Malaysian authorities said Thursday, spurring an international manhunt.

headline: Missing Some Stars, Davis Cup Has Plenty of Sparkle
text: The tennis band still known as the Big Four is split in two this week. Roger Federer and Andy Murray are playing in the Davis Cup quarterfinals, while Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic are resting for the clay-court tussles soon to come.

headline: Qualcomm Muscles Up in the Home
text: The airwaves are getting too crowded — in your living room. By treating the home the way it treats outdoor cellphone networks, Qualcomm hopes to make big business from your problem.

headline: Imgur, the Image-Sharing Site, Raises $40 Million From Andreessen Horowitz
text: If you spend any measurable amount of time on the Internet, you’ve likely visited — or at least looked at — an image hosted on Imgur (pronounced “image-er”).

headline: Shadows Over Citigroup
text: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroup’s Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the giant bank, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook. The investigation, overseen by the F.B.I. and prosecutors from the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, is focusing in part on whether holes in the bank’s internal controls contributed to the fraud in Mexico.

headline: E.U. Lawmakers Approve Tough ‘Net Neutrality’ Rules
text: LONDON — European lawmakers approved new rules on Thursday aimed at guaranteeing equal access to the Internet and cutting cellphone charges across the 28-member European Union.

headline: European Central Bank Hints at Bond-Buying Program
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank gave its strongest signal yet that it was considering action to stimulate the euro zone economy. But the bank immediately faced criticism that talk of large-scale bond purchases — the same method used by the Federal Reserve to help restart the United States economy — was little more than a bluff.

headline: Political Cacophony Challenges Musicians
text: On Feb. 12, the charismatic Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel led a youth orchestra in Caracas to celebrate the 39th anniversary of El Sistema, the government-supported program that has organized hundreds of thousands of children across Venezuela into instrumental ensembles, serving as a model of using music education for social uplift. As the performance was underway, a crackdown on peaceful demonstrations was being enforced in the streets. People were protesting the policies of President Nicolás Maduro’s government, along with the pervasive crime, crippling inflation and scarcities that plague Venezuela today.

headline: Chasing the Money for Families of Passengers on Missing Flight
text: Growing up in Peru in the 1970s, Monica R. Kelly, who specializes in aviation accidents, dreamed of becoming a diplomat and traveling the world.

headline: India Ranks 102nd on Social Development Index
text: NEW DELHI — As the world’s largest democracy heads to the polls in less than a week, and as politicians vying for a governing coalition tout their plans for economic and social development, a report published by an American nonprofit shows that India performs poorly on a range of social development indicators, ranking 102nd among the 132 countries surveyed.

headline: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Mexico (2)
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — In its final exhibition game before the opening of next month’s World Cup training camp, the United States national team played to a 2-2 draw with arch-rival Mexico on Wednesday night before a pro-Mexico crowd at the University of Phoenix Stadium.

headline: Fort Hood Gunman Was Being Treated for Depression
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The commanding general of Fort Hood said on Thursday that the soldier who killed three people and wounded 16 others during a shooting the previous day might have argued with at least one other soldier shortly before the attack.

headline: As Narendra Modi Rises, His Grip Over His Party Tightens
text: NEW DELHI — On Monday, Lal Krishna Advani, the doyen and one of the founders of India’s opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, spoke at a rally in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. Mr. Advani observed that Narendra Modi, the party’s prime ministerial candidate and thrice-elected chief minister of Gujarat, was not “the only one who has scored a hat trick in elections.”

headline: Liberty Media Will Sell Most of Its Investment in Barnes & Noble
text: Updated, 7:55 p.m. | Nearly three years ago, Liberty Media had grand ambitions to acquire Barnes & Noble, before settling for a big stake. Now it appears that the media conglomerate has had enough.

headline: John Paul Stevens: By the Book
text: The former Supreme Court justice and author of “Five Chiefs: A Supreme Court Memoir” and, most recently, “Six Amendments: How and Why We Should Change the Constitution,” feels indebted to Norman Maclean, who taught him poetry at the University of Chicago.

headline: Air and Space Museum’s Main Hall to Be Renovated and Renamed
text: The Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum in Washington is overhauling its central exhibition space with the help of a $30 million donation from the Boeing Company.  This main hall, now called Milestones of Flight, is currently home to the superstars of aviation and spaceflight history like the Wright Brothers’ plane, the 1903 Wright Flyer; Charles Lindbergh’s Spirit of St. Louis; and John Glenn’s Mercury capsule, Friendship 7.

headline: Switching Names to Save on Taxes
text: Call it the banality of tax avoidance.

headline: Ai Weiwei Shows ‘Evidence’ in Berlin
text: The Martin-Gropius-Bau opened a one-man show of Ai Weiwei’s work titled “Evidence.” It spans three decades of the dissident Chinese artist’s career.

headline: Research on Children and Math: Underestimated and Unchallenged
text: We hear a lot about how American students lag behind their international peers academically, especially in subjects like math. In the most recent Program for International Student Assessment, commonly known as PISA, students in the United States ranked 26th out of 34 countries in mathematics. On the surface, it would seem that we’re a nation of math dullards; simply no good at the subject. But a spate of new research suggests that we may be underestimating our students, especially the youngest ones, in terms of their ability to think about numbers.

headline: Brookstone Files for Bankruptcy and Plans to Sell Itself
text: Brookstone, the struggling retailer known for its consumer gadgets, massage chairs and other home furnishings, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday, with plans to sell itself to the owner of the Spencer’s retail chain for about $147 million.

headline: The Fifth Freedom
text: Never mind freedom of speech, freedom of religion, freedom from want, freedom from fear. What America’s embattled billionaires are demanding, as their birthright (and I mean that pretty much literally), is something much more important: freedom from criticism. Making a desperate stand in the maquis the Wall Street Journal, heroic, oppressed men like Tom Perkins and now Charles Koch have been telling it like it is: anyone who says anything negative about them is just like the Nazis, or maybe Stalin.

headline: Yorgen Edholm of Accellion, on the Motivation of Passion
text: This interview with Yorgen Edholm, chief executive of Accellion, a developer of software for mobile file sharing, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

text: The president delivered a statement on Wednesday following a shooting at Fort Hood.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Paschal’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Paschal” by Robert Pinsky and the article “Put Yourself in the Story of Passover” by Edward Rothstein.

headline: Hand-Held Treatment for Overdoses Is Approved
text: Federal health regulators approved a drug overdose treatment device on Thursday that experts say will provide a powerful lifesaving tool in the midst of a surging epidemic of prescription drug abuse. Similar to an EpiPen used to stop allergic reactions to bee stings, the easy-to-use injector — small enough to tuck into a pocket or a medicine cabinet — can be used by the relatives or friends of people who have overdosed.

headline: Kerry Pushes Leaders on Peace Talks
text: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a pointed warning on Thursday to Israeli and Palestinian leaders, saying they must “lead” if they want to preserve the chances for a historic Middle East peace.

headline: This Time, Jim Jarmusch Is Kissing Vampires
text: The filmmaker Jim Jarmusch is old school. He writes all his scripts out by hand and then dictates them to a typist. Ideas are jotted down in small, color-coordinated notebooks and, despite the presence of an iPad and iPhone in his life, he doesn’t have email. “I don’t have enough time as it is to read a book or make music, or see my friends,” he said. “People don’t believe me, too. They think I’m just saying that because I don’t want to give it to them. But no, I do not have email.”

text: “He’s back?” my colleague asked, eyes widening as she passed the patient’s room. “He’s in the hospital again?”

headline: Co-Stars Again, but Hardly Strangers
text: It was love at first rehearsal, or so the story goes. In the spring of 2000, Megan Mullally, then at the start of her fame as the acerbic millionairess Karen Walker on the sitcom “Will & Grace,” was kicking off her hiatus from the TV season in an unlikely venue: a sawdust-floored warehouse near downtown Los Angeles, where the Evidence Room, a theater company, was opening a cavernous new space with an ambitious staging of Charles L. Mee’s “Berlin Circle.”

headline: D.I.Y. Accountability
text: Here is the story so far on the Central Intelligence Agency’s interrogation program: The C.I.A. illegally detained terrorism suspects, tortured and abused them at secret prisons, denied that it was happening and then destroyed videotaped evidence. It misled lawmakers about what happened, stonewalled Congressional inquiries, withheld the results of its own investigation from Congress, and interfered in various ways with a Senate probe — even breaking into Senate staffers’ computers and deleting files.

headline: New Jersey’s Largest Newspaper Announces Big Staff Cuts in Reorganization
text: The Star-Ledger of Newark, New Jersey’s biggest newspaper by print circulation and among the largest in the nation, announced on Thursday that it would cut 167 jobs, including 40 newsroom positions.

headline: The Second Issue of a Truly Great International Magazine
text: Read all about it! The second issue of ZEITmagazin – the Berlin State of Mind is out today. Culling a half-year’s worth of editorial highlights from ZEITmagazin — which comes out with Die Zeit, Germany’s biggest weekly newspaper — the semiannual journal of culture, politics and art has a print run of 10,000 and is available in just about any international city where you can get an Uber. With a 28-page spread of Instagram photos curated by Ai Weiwei and pictures of surreal Tuscan food taken by Juergen Teller, the Teutonic glossy clocks in at 260 pages. Michael Douglas talks post-cancer life and of an adolescent encounter with Liberace; François Hollande and Angela Merkel take to bed with a plate full of pretzels; and a cadre of stars including Boy George, Juliette Binoche and Stephen King recount their dreams. Photographic subjects run the gamut from Berlin teenagers to Brad Pitt to a Chinese burial ritual. Ja, bitte.

headline: Elephants and Pajamas: It’s the Marxfest of Course
text: An excuse for a festival devoted to the Marx Brothers should probably not be necessary. But a group of Marxophiles (“they were going to call themselves Marxists, but they thought better of it,” a spokesman said) have banded together to present Marxfest, an eclectic series of screenings, talks, concerts and events of other sorts (a trip to the Bronx Zoo to look at elephants, for example), to be presented from May 1 to 31 at sites all over New York City. And they have an occasion to commemorate: 2014 is apparently the centenary of the poker game at which the comedian Art Fisher coined the nicknames by which the brothers became known – Groucho, Harpo, Chico and, in those days, Gummo, who was soon replaced in the family act by Zeppo.

headline: An Artist on His First Exhibit: ‘Wow, George Bush Is a Painter’

headline: The Gun Report: April 3, 2014
text: For the second time in five years, there has been a mass shooting at the Fort Hood military base in Killeen, Tex. In 2009, in what some consider an act of terrorism, Nidal Malik Hasan, a U.S. Army Major and psychiatrist, opened fire, killing thirteen people and wounding thirty others. Yesterday, after a dispute with another soldier, Specialist Ivan Lopez, 34, a National Guardsman, opened fire in two locations, killing three people and wounding 16 others. When a soldier confronted him, he shot and killed himself.

headline: A Sisterhood of the Snow in Alaska
text: The loud, industrial buzz of the helicopter dulled down to a steady purr through my thick headphones. Wedged tightly between three seatmates in the back of the AStar, I was outwardly calm, but inwardly I was having an “Oh, my God, I can’t believe I’m actually doing this” moment. We were being shuttled to a remote spot among the seemingly endless peaks of the Chugach Mountains in southeast Alaska where, ultimately, nine of us, all women, would click into fat powder skis or strap into snowboards for descents we’d been dreaming about all winter. Ranging in age from early 30s to mid-40s, we had come together to Valdez for this ultimate bucket-list ski trip.

headline: Salsa, Flirting With Bok Choy

The beans, too, are not the usual congealing muddle, but discrete drops of heirloom yellow-eyes, scented with coriander.

headline: Epic Fail
text: Books about failure put both their authors and their readers in awkward positions. Writers are at pains to abase themselves somewhat, to show that they know the terrain by sacrificing some dignity without losing all credibility. Many readers, meanwhile, may be willing to ponder how they fail or why they fear it, but few will pick up a book for people who think of themselves as “failures.” Add to this the fact that all books fail to be everything their authors hoped and that almost all books fail to sell, and it becomes clear why books about failure remain few and far between.

headline: The Case Against Savings Accounts (but Not Savings)
text: My 8-year-old daughter saves money in a jar in her bedroom. As her goals got bigger (and relatives started giving her money for birthdays and holidays), I wondered whether it was time for her to have an actual savings account at a real bank or credit union.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Under the Skin’
text: In this video, the director Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film “Under the Skin,” about a predatory extraterrestrial played by Scarlett Johansson. In this sequence, that character walks down a street in Glasgow where she trips and falls. The sequence was shot with hidden cameras on a street in Glasgow, Scotland. A photo that was snapped during one of the takes eventually became a meme last fall. Here, Mr. Glazer discusses his ideas behind the scene and how it came together.

headline: Jack White Plans to Record and Produce a Single on Record Store Day
text: Record Store Day – April 19, this year – has typically brought stacks of collectible rarities and limited-edition pressings, made available just for the day, usually on vinyl only, and only at physical record stores, an endangered species these days. Collectors snap these discs up, and so do speculators: it often seems as if most items find their way to eBay before the day is out.

headline: A Vegetarian and Gluten-Free Guide to Paris
text: Vegetarians in France are odd ducks. Culinary deprivation is neither sexy nor patriotic here. Regional specialties like the pulpy oysters of Isigny, the velvety foie gras of Périgord, the textured andouillette sausage of Lyon and the black-and-white Coucou chickens of Rennes are meant to be savored, not censured. And although there is no European consensus on exactly what the word “vegetarian” means, less than 2 percent of the French identify themselves as such (compared with four times as many Britons and Germans). Rare is the French host who asks guests before they come to dinner if they have dietary preferences or restrictions. Explain that you’re a pescatarian, vegan or even gluten-free and you’re likely to be met with confusion, bewilderment and a pile of raw vegetables on your plate.

headline: Mets Find Woes Growing and Crowds Dwindling

text: David Letterman, the longest-running host in the history of late-night television, will retire from his CBS show next year, the latest shake-up in a roiling talk-show lineup.

headline: A Hotel Suite With a Museum’s Touch
text: Guests staying in the Made in the USA Suite at the Park Hyatt Washington will be surrounded by art and design inspired by the Phillips Collection’s newest exhibit, “Made in the USA: American Masters from the Phillips Collection, 1850-1970,” featuring American art, design and furnishings.

headline: Rebellion in South Sudan
text: South Sudan’s former vice president, Riek Machar, speaks about plans for his rebels to attack oil fields that supply revenue to the government of Salva Kiir.

headline: A Soulful Safari, Stalking the Spiritual
text: Boyd Varty was not the kind of child who did his learning in the classroom. He was raised in Kruger National Park in South Africa, where his family has operated the Londolozi Game Reserve for more than 80 years. He still lives and works there.

headline: At Quiet Rebel Base, Plotting an Assault on South Sudan’s Oil Fields
text: NASIR, South Sudan — There are only four bullets in the rifle that Liep Wiyual plans to use against government troops on the front lines in South Sudan.

headline: Reunion Tour
text: Sometime after Charles Dickens and before Jonathan Franzen, the heart on the shirt sleeve seems to have gone out of style in the literary world, replaced by irony, satirical remove and a more subdued, presumably cleareyed, emotional palette. But once in a while, it’s nice to get your eyes wet and your heart beating rapidly to a nostalgic tune. Nickolas Butler’s “Shotgun Lovesongs” is a good old-­fashioned novel, a sure-footed and unabashedly sentimental first effort that deserves to be among the standouts in this year’s field of fiction debuts.

headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
text: A sex comedy can sometimes get by, even if it is deficient in one of the two things that term promises. But a sex comedy that is short on both sex and comedy is unlikely to please anyone.

headline: Taking Time and Earning Trust
text: The shutter became a lot less heavy once Carolyn Van Hooten realized she had earned the confidence of her subjects.

headline: Borrowing the Maximum
text: With property values rising in many markets, and the threat of higher interest rates on the horizon, some borrowers might think the best strategy is to buy the most home they could afford. After all, why not max out on a mortgage while values are headed upward and interest rates still relatively low.

headline: West Village Mansion in the Rough
text: A formidable limestone-and-brick building on a historic West Village corner that had been used as a Catholic elementary school, as a nursing school affiliated with St. Vincent’s Hospital, and most recently as a locus for child-abuse and protection services administered by the New York Foundling, one of the city’s oldest charities, is about to enter the market at $47.5 million.

headline: Improv Night At The Oligarchs’ Ball
text: OK, it was pretty funny when Fix the Debt tried to make itself hip by hiring a flash mob to promote deficit scoldery. But this — which is either real or a very subtle spoof — is cosmically weird:

headline: Upper East Side Block of Genuine Interest
text: So maybe you think you’re pretty good at “Where’s Waldo.” But can you spot the impostors on East 80th Street between Park and Lexington? Mostly it’s a block of demure 1920s high-style mansions and private houses unchanged since 1930.

headline: The Fashion World as a Good Neighbor
text: Next month, some big names in fashion will host a fund-raiser at Highline Stages on West 14th Street for the Meatpacking District Improvement Association. Diane von Furstenberg and Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory, are presiding over the event, along with the hotelier André Balazs.

headline: 36 Hours in Hood River, Ore.
text: Hood River’s multifaceted climate is a little like Sochi’s — only without palm trees. Popularized as a windsurfing destination in the 1980s, this waterfront town in the Columbia River Gorge is blessed with mild to balmy temperatures nine months of the year, while nearby Mount Hood never runs out of snow. The result is an outdoor adventurer’s playground, and the saying “the Gorge is my gym” has inspired a blog of the same name, featuring daily wind and snow reports. The ultimate workout is the hat trick — a sport on snow, water and earth in the same day. It could be ski, paddleboard and bike; or snowboard, windsurf/kiteboard and hike. Or perhaps Nordic ski, white-water kayak and rock climb. And don’t forget fly fishing for steelhead. Once you’re hooked, the hardest part is the decision.

headline: Steve Coogan on ‘Alan Partridge’
text: The actor discusses the character he has played for more than two decades.

headline: Glimpses of the Past and a High-Tech Future
text: Walking around SoHo on a sunny weekend, when the shoppers are out, you may find it hard to remember that the neighborhood once belonged to artists. But between the boutiques are little oases of contemporary art and reservoirs of local history. Artists Space and the Drawing Center, two nonprofit sites, have been renovated and revitalized; Walter de Maria’s “New York Earth Room,” at 141 Wooster Street, and his “Broken Kilometer,” at 393 West Broadway, are still under Dia’s meticulous care. Best of all, last year’s transformation of Donald Judd’s home and studio at 101 Spring Street into a public museum has given us a time machine to the SoHo of the 1970s.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 4-10
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Spain and Rwanda.

headline: Winning Style Points on the Street
text: “Flex Is Kings,” a documentary about a street dancing style — from East New York, Brooklyn — reminiscent of vogueing, break dancing, and miming, concentrates on two performers. One is Flizzo, who says in the film that his grandmother described these dancers as looking as if they were having strokes.

headline: Musical Tributes for Mexico’s Dead
text: In Iztapalapa, a violent Mexico City neighborhood, two musicians with a guitar and an accordion are hired to ease the strains of grief, celebrate the dead and remind mourners of more festive memories.

headline: With Instruments and Odes, Comforting Mexican Mourners
text: MEXICO CITY — The gravediggers tossed dirt onto the gray coffin, the dust adding tears to weepy eyes. A young man in a T-shirt poured out a little beer for his cousin, who died at just 27. Then came the surge of music.

headline: The Power Grid
text: When Chris Davis hit 53 home runs in 2013, he filled one of the few blanks in the arc that stretches from 1 to 73. Only one home run number now remains untaken from 1 to 60; more gaps exist from 61 to 73. Here’s a closer look at all the numbers, and some stories behind them.

headline: Theater Listings for April 4-10
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pointing Fingers Over Bulging Bellies
text: Is there nothing for which Richard M. Nixon cannot be blamed?

headline: Courage, Loyalty, Honor, Kablooey
text: It’s a bird, it’s a plane — oh, wait, it’s Captain America.

headline: Hard Times Take Their Toll on a Singapore Family
text: “Ilo Ilo,” Anthony Chen’s small, wonderful first feature film, is an acutely perceptive examination of middle-class life in Singapore during a 1997 financial crisis that sent tremors of panic through Asia’s developing countries. Its semi-autobiographical story focuses on a family of three, with a baby on the way, suddenly facing uncertainty.

headline: Chasing a Dream and an Unalloyed Ethos
text: ARRIVE in Brooklyn, and you’ve entered the belly of contemporary art. It’s our 19th-century Paris or 18th-century Rome, with one of the largest concentrations of artists in the world. Here, you’ll find both commercial galleries and nonprofit and artist-run spaces — and thousands upon thousands of places you can visit during open-studio weekends scattered throughout the year.

headline: A Much Darker Hitchhiker’s Guide
text: Scarlett Johansson as an extraterrestrial femme fatale cruising the streets of Glasgow in Jonathan Glazer’s cerebral sci-fi horror fantasy “Under the Skin” is an indelible personification of predatory allure. Wearing a dark wig and a fake-fur jacket, her character, an alien with a sinister agenda, is as fetishized an object of desire as Marlene Dietrich admired through the lens of Josef von Sternberg. You may also think of Ava Gardner, as perfect a female specimen as Hollywood ever produced, coldly working her wiles.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
