text: Who the heck is manufacturing all these superpowered mirrors? There’s the one in “Snow White” that knows who is fairest of them all. There’s the one in “Beauty and the Beast” that has Google Earth-like abilities. The Harry Potter stories have both the Mirror of Erised, which shows the user his deepest desires, and the two-way mirror, a person-to-person communication device.

headline: A Bold Bid to Combat a Crisis in Legal Education
text: Brooklyn Law School is hardly alone in facing a crisis in legal education. Five law schools have closed in the last two years, more than at any other time in American history.

headline: One Word That Should Never Follow ‘I Love You’
text: I don’t remember the exact day, or the exact reason, or even the exact words, but I know it started with “I love you, but …”

headline: The American Woodcock’s Love Song at 300 Feet
text: The American woodcock is one of the Northeast’s most peculiar birds, with a humble, lovable beauty that has inspired myriad nicknames. Bogsucker, mudbat, Labrador twister and timberdoodle all describe a shy brown bird only 10 to 12 inches long. Incredibly well camouflaged, woodcocks are almost invisible by day, resting and feeding among the bristling, messy shrubs of old fields, meadows and young woodlands. But in early spring, as the sun’s fleeting warmth fades into the chill night, the bird performs one of nature’s most curious courtship displays.

headline: Peninsula Hotel Will Open in Paris
text: Peninsula Hotels, the Hong Kong-based luxury brand, enters Europe for the first time, with its 10th location scheduled to open in Paris this August.

headline: C.E.O. of The Times Co. to Publish a Book on Language
text: Mark Thompson, the president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, is writing his first book, an examination of language in the digital age, his publisher, St. Martin’s Press, said. The book, to be titled “Enough Said,” draws from a series of lectures at Oxford that Mr. Thompson delivered in 2012 as a visiting professor at the university.

headline: In L.A., a Group Show Explores the Art of the Obscured
text: As its name suggests, “Veils” — a 40-artist group exhibition opening Saturday in the West Adams neighborhood of L.A. — offers interpretations of the physical act of concealment. But the show’s curators, Jhordan Dahl and Ariana Papademetropoulos, also made a point to stretch the concept, exploring ideas about public personas and the occult. The works on display range from Jeffrey Vallance’s 1992 series of clown makeup imprints on linen handkerchiefs to an eerie watercolor self-portrait by the artist (and occultist) Marjorie Cameron to “Long-Banged Angel,” an eight-foot-high Eric Yahnker drawing of Farrah Fawcett in her glory days, lustrous feathered hair completely obscuring her eyes.

headline: The Gun Report: April 4, 2014
text: Thanks to National Rifle Association-backed legislation, the commanding officers of the Fort Hood shooter were barred from asking him about the privately owned handgun he used to carry out this week’s shooting, Media Matters reports.

headline: Investors Return to Anadarko After Record $5.1 Billion Settlement
text: Stock investors seem to have a firm grip on Anadarko Petroleum’s toxic waste settlement. The record $5.15 billion settlement on Thursday, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range, which had a midpoint of $9.8 billion. The 15 percent jump in the oil company’s market capitalization after the settlement was announced is mostly explained by those numbers. And it brings Anadarko’s 12-month stock performance nearly back in line with the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index after a bumpy ride.

headline: Three Soldiers Killed at Fort Hood Are Identified
text: Updated, 5:04 p .m.When Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at Fort Hood late Wednesday afternoon, Sgt. First Class Danny Ferguson leaned up against a door to prevent the gunman from entering a room packed with military personnel.

headline: Why Mozilla’s Chief Had to Resign
text: What conclusions should we draw about Silicon Valley from what happened at Mozilla?

headline: Just the Facts, With Tweaks
text: “I think here there are two kinds of truths: dramatic truth and documentary reporting,” the trailblazing French filmmaker Jean Rouch once said in an interview. “But pure documentary is very rare, and maybe it’s inevitable that a film have some drama in it.” He was talking in 1977, giving context for films he’d made in the 1950s.

headline: Osteoporosis
text: This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.

headline: In a Tale of the Nation’s First Spy Ring, a Spotlight on Colonial New York
text: Before it was the wonder city of eight million stories, New York in the autumn of 1776 was just 25,000 strong. Under indomitable British occupation – indeed, New York was the colonial headquarters of the British military – it was at a hinge in its history.

headline: Struggling to Film in America’s Chokehold
text: MEXICO CITY — In Hollywood terms, it was small change. But for Miguel Coyula, a Cuban filmmaker accustomed to working on a tiny budget, the $5,200 he raised on the crowdfunding site Indiegogo.com last year would have bought some lighting equipment, a Steadicam and a tripod, all crucial for his science-fiction feature, “Blue Heart.”

headline: After Playing, Parting Is Such Sweet Sorrow
text: When people learn that I’m a music critic, they often ask what my instrument is. I’ve always answered, “I play the cello.” If I’m feeling expansive, I say I’m a cellist.

headline: Trading Flaming Skull for Inner Dad
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — After playing, among other characters, a one-eyed dad who drinks beer out of his enemy’s skull (“Drive Angry”) and a motorcyclist from hell who can make his head burst into flame (“Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance”), Nicolas Cage had gotten a reputation as a guy whose love of action pictures had, over the last decade, pulled him away from what he does best, namely, act. Quirky comedies and thoughtful indies were set aside for films heavy on bloodletting and explosions. Critics, even longtime champions like Roger Ebert, yearned for the Nic of old.

headline: 50 Years of the Ford Mustang
text: It was love at first sight for Fred Glazier, who saw the Ford Mustang at the 1964 World’s Fair. Soon after, he bought his own, and he still drives it today.

headline: Chocolate Caramel Macarons
text: Melissa Clark takes the best parts of a French macaron and an American macaroon and creates a sweet sandwich cookie for Passover.

headline: Seeking College Application Essays About Money From This Year’s Seniors
text: Last year, I put out an open call for college application essays about money, work and social class and hoped that high school seniors would send them in. Several dozen young men and women did, and we featured the best of the essays in a Your Money column. I particularly enjoyed getting to know Lyle Li, now a New York University freshman, whom we featured in a video.

headline: A Pizza Party
text: For Yosuke Masuko, the goal of operating a pizza company in Vietnam is ‘‘delivering wow and happiness.’'

headline: Books, and Compassion, From Birth
text: Last year, when I was visiting a public school in Sunset Park in Brooklyn for teenagers with boundless difficulties, my host, a poet who teaches at various city schools, mentioned a student who had become pregnant. Hoping to start a library for the child soon to arrive, the poet told the young woman embarking on motherhood that she would like to give her some books — books of the kind her own grandchildren growing up in a very different Brooklyn had by the dozens. The offer was met skeptically. “I already have one,” the girl said.

headline: Closing the Seder With Something New
text: Here’s the secret to the best Passover desserts: stick to recipes that never relied on flour to begin with. Why make a chocolate cake with matzo flour when a flourless chocolate torte is going to be so much better anyway? This is why flourless tortes, candies and nut- or coconut-based cookies are the usual end to many a Seder.

headline: Wheelies: The Kia People Mover Edition
text: ■ Kia announced Thursday that it would unveil an all-new eight-passenger vehicle at the New York auto show this month. Details were scant, but the new model would probably take the place of the Kia Sedona minivan, which was scheduled for replacement. (Kia)

headline: My Little Pony, 50 Years Later
text: When the Ford Mustang was introduced 50 years ago this month, it was first to break from the gate in a market class that would come to be known as pony cars.

headline: A Ford Mustang That’s Not a Mustang
text: If a dump truck can be a Mustang, can a Mustang be a T5? That conundrum can be answered in the positive, the result of a German manufacturer of trucks having copyrighted the Mustang name long before Ford’s pony car was released in the 1960s.

headline: Five Injured After Bus Smashes Into Upper Manhattan Building
text: A New York City Transit bus collided with a minivan and then smashed into a building in Upper Manhattan on Friday morning, injuring five people, according to fire officials.

headline: Federal Panel Rejects Design for Eisenhower Memorial
text: In the latest setback for a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for Washington’s National Mall, Frank Gehry’s current design was rejected and sent back for revisions on Thursday by the panel that oversees the nation’s monuments.

headline: Prosecutor on India Rape Case Sentencing
text: Ujjwal Nikam, the special prosecutor in a Mumbai gang rape case, spoke to the news media Friday after three men were sentenced to death.

headline: When the Final Curtain Isn’t So Final
text: On a frigid February day in 1999, I gave my final performance as Radioman Harold Bride in the Broadway musical “Titanic.” I’d been offered a new role in a downtown play. It was harder than I ever imagined saying goodbye to the company; to the beloved duet I’d performed nightly with the ship’s stoker, played for most of the run by Brian d’Arcy James, who sang a message of love to his landlocked girl while I, a Marconi geek, waxed poetic over my telegraph. I stepped downstage for the last scene of the show, tears streaming, as we all waved farewell to the doomed ship and belted out the final notes of Maury Yeston’s luscious score: “Fortune’s winds sing God’s Speed to thee!” A few weeks later, after more than 800 performances, “Titanic” closed.

headline: Corporate Profits Grow and Wages Slide
text: CORPORATE profits are at their highest level in at least 85 years. Employee compensation is at the lowest level in 65 years.

headline: Is That Jesus in Your Toast?
text: TAKE a close look at your breakfast. Is that Jesus staring out at you from your toast?

headline: Activists Seen as Possibly Circling Symantec
text: Symantec is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase to defend the enterprise technology company against activist investors, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Big Ticket | At $30 Million, It’s All About the Views
text: A vista-infused apartment near the peak of the south tower at the Time Warner Center with unencumbered Central Park views to the east and Hudson River scenes to the west sold for $30 million after a brief bidding war and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Should I Swap My Rent-Stabilized Apartment?
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Ophira Eisenberg’s Walk-Up Cave
text: There are certain people who simply don’t understand the concept of apartment buildings without elevators. It just so happens that some of those baffled individuals share a last name with Ophira Eisenberg.

headline: Syria Ships Out More Chemicals After a 2-Week Lapse
text: GENEVA — Syria has delivered a consignment of chemical weapons materials for export and destruction overseas for the first time in more than two weeks, a delay that revived concerns about the country’s readiness and ability to meet newly extended deadlines for completing the task this month.

headline: The Weight of Executives’ Personal Beliefs
text: Should executives be held to account for unpopular or even offensive views, or does such a stand repress free speech?

headline: Music Writer’s Opus, Now With Sound
text: As a college classics major, the music historian, writer and critic Peter Guralnick once submitted a paper comparing the Roman poet Catullus’s “Little Bird, Delight of My Girl” to Robert Johnson’s “Stones in My Passway.” “It was not well received,” he recalled recently, but it helped establish a template that has served Mr. Guralnick superbly in writing groundbreaking books on blues, country and soul music, and biographies of pop music figures like Elvis Presley and Sam Cooke.

headline: A Long Way From South Dakota
text: On the cover of her new album, “The Future’s Void,” the South Dakota-raised noise-rocker EMA sports an Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, but the photograph was shot before that company’s recent $2 billion purchase by Facebook. And she wrote the song “Satellites,” which rages against government surveillance, months before the National Security Agency scandal broke.

headline: Q. and A. | Kelis Explains How She Got from ‘Milkshake’ to Her Own Cooking Show
text: Kelis Rogers, who broke out in 2003 with her booty-popping come-on “Milkshake,” has a history of surprising her fans. The Harlem native’s 2006 album, “Kelis Was Here,” staged a rebellion against the pop sound that established her, forgoing the signature Neptunes production of her first three albums in favor of an eclectic sound with a wide-ranging cast of collaborators. She followed up four years later with yet another new direction, the boundary-pushing electro-dance riot “Flesh Tone.” If that wasn’t enough to prove her restlessness, somewhere in the middle she also attended culinary school, becoming a Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef; she even hosts her own Cooking Channel show, “Saucy & Sweet.”

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Kelis and Alejandro Jodorowsky
text: Alejandro Jodorowsky, surrealist Chilean-born director and self-described “psychoshaman” whose new autobiographical film, “The Dance of Reality” — his first in 23 years — opens in May, takes on Kelis, Grammy-nominated pop star and Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef whose sixth album, “Food,” comes out later this month. She also has a line of sauces in the works.

headline: From Slavery and Shiloh to the Post-Bellum World
text: “Civil War: The Untold Story” delivers on the promise of its title only intermittently.

headline: NYT Now: India Rape Case Sentencing
text: The special prosecutor in a Mumbai rape case, Ujjwal Nikam, discussed the sentencing of three men.

headline: Turns From a Gospel Singer and a Jazz Saxophonist
text: Erica Campbell

headline: Review: 2015 Subaru WRX STI
text: Budget conscious automotive enthusiasts who worship at the altar of performance know the Subaru WRX STI is an answered prayer.

headline: Weekend Reading: High-Frequency Reading
text: This week we take an ultrafast look at the financial headlines.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Running in Circles Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 23-year-old man with episodes of aggressive, manic behavior that couldn’t be controlled. Nearly 1,000 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. More than 300 of you got the right class of disease, and 21 of you nailed the precise form of the disorder. Amazing!

headline: Another High-Speed Trading Investigation
text: The list of federal and state agencies investigating the practice of high-frequency trading continues to grow.

headline: Iran’s Reformers Include More Than One Former Hostage-Taker
text: Updated, Saturday, 2:44 p.m. | As my colleagues Somini Sengupta and Thomas Erdbrink reported, there has been discomfort and anger in Washington since Iran applied for a visa to let a veteran diplomat who played a part in the 1979 hostage crisis move to New York and serve as its ambassador to the United Nations.

headline: Kazuo Ishiguro Readies First Novel in 10 Years
text: Alfred A. Knopf will publish “The Buried Giant,” Kazuo Ishiguro’s seventh novel and his first in nearly a decade, in spring 2015. Mr. Ishiguro’s British publisher, Faber & Faber, announced the forthcoming novel in advance of the London Book Fair, which starts Tuesday.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Buzz From Tokyo to Toronto Evokes Another Yankee Debut
text: Across the Yankees universe on Friday night, all eyes were on Toronto, where the team’s prized off-season acquisition from Japan, pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, made his major league debut against the Blue Jays. Battalions of Japanese reporters were on hand to document the milestone, and baseball fans in Japan, coffee mugs in hand, woke up early on Saturday to watch the game live.

headline: Come Here, Look Back, Move Forward
text: The choreographer Stephen Petronio does not like to go backward. He says that moving in reverse — say, on a train — makes him feel mentally disturbed and physically ill. Nevertheless, there is a lot of backward in his life these days.

headline: Stripper With a Heart of Gold
text: TESTED 2014 Volkswagen Jetta SE

headline: Still a Wild Child After Reform School
text: Let the other guys worry about self-steering cars, blind-spot beepers and onboard Wi-Fi connections.

headline: Subaru’s Blue Streak
text: The 2015 WRX and its track-ready STI version deliver unmitigated driving pleasure at a relatively affordable price.

headline: Keeping Tabs, Just in Case
text: Most histories trace antiterrorism squads to the Haymarket bombing in Chicago in 1886, after which American police departments devoted a new zeal to gathering intelligence.

headline: A Peace Process in Which Process Has Come to Outweigh Peace
text: JERUSALEM — The crisis that engulfed the ailing Middle East peace process this week was much more about preserving the process than finding a path to peace.

headline: Fabric Art, Made From the Fighting
text: Building on last year’s touring exhibitions of Civil War art and photography, “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War” reminds us that textiles were also a big part of wartime culture (and, not incidentally, one in which women played a major role). Organized by the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., the show has just arrived at the New-York Historical Society. (It will travel to the Shelburne Museum in Vermont next fall and the Nebraska State Historical Society in the winter of 2015.)

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 69
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: How the Centuries Will Play Out
text: For music lovers, Thursday brings a clear choice between older and newer, both options tantalizing. Uptown, the repertory could hardly be more classic, as the eminent conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi leads the New York Philharmonic in Schumann’s stirring Symphony No. 2. But the main event may well end up being the performance of Brahms’s galvanic Piano Concerto No. 1, with the exhilarating British pianist Paul Lewis. (7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5030, nyphil.org.)

headline: NYT Now: Perry on Fort Hood Shooting
text: Governor Rick Perry of Texas addressed the media about the deadly Fort Hood shooting on Wednesday.

headline: Tappers, Striking New Ground
text: The rhythm of tap expresses itself aurally when metal slaps and strikes the ground. For many, this dance is still associated with Broadway-style showmanship or fluttering jazzlike improvisations. But tap today has a broader theatrical scope and emotional range. This week the pioneers of a new age of tap bring their vision to “Rhythm in Motion,” presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation and featuring some furiously inventive women, like Brenda Bufalino, Michelle Dorrance and Chloe Arnold, among other innovators. (Tuesday through Sunday, Theater at the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, Manhattan, 212-780-0800, atdf.org.)

headline: Festival Offers a Fuller Brubeck
text: Long before his death in 2012, the legacy of the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck was often reduced, in popular conversation, to his biggest album, “Time Out,” and its ageless hit, “Take Five.” Jazz at Lincoln Center will offer a broader, richer portrait with its Dave Brubeck Festival, from Monday through next Sunday in the organization’s home, Frederick P. Rose Hall.

headline: Ruling Spurs Rush for Cash in Both Parties
text: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader in the House, wasted little time on Thursday blasting the Supreme Court’s latest decision freeing donors to spend more money on campaigns. The founding fathers, Ms. Pelosi said at a news conference on Thursday morning, had fought for “a government of the many, not a government of the money.” Democrats, she said, will not “unilaterally disarm.”

headline: The Journey to Humanity
text: When the paleobiologist Neil Shubin looks at his fellow humans, he sees ghosts of animals past. The way we grip with our hands? We can thank our primate forefathers. Our ability to hear so many sounds? Distant ancestors the size of a shrew. And the further back we venture, the stranger things get. We don’t describe our skin as scaly for nothing.

headline: For Photography, the Biggest Show on Earth
text: Eighteen years ago four Toronto art dealers decided to whip up a little excitement around photography. Dismayed that the city had no museum devoted to the subject, and that curators at the big arts institutions seemed slow to embrace it as an art form, they issued an open invitation to museums, galleries, art centers and coffee houses to take part in a monthlong festival they called Contact ’97. To their surprise, 50 exhibitors responded. Stephen Bulger, the owner of the city’s only gallery showing photography year-round, predicted, “In five years, this will be an international event.”

headline: Friday Night Music: Figaro
text: Yes, I know it’s only Friday afternoon. But my friend Emily Mann, artistic director at the McCarter Theater, has invited me to the opening of the first part of McCarter’s production of the Figaro plays, starting with dinner tonight. Strictly speaking I have the wrong play here — tonight’s play is The Barber of Seville — but I’m much more of a Mozart guy than a Rossini guy, so what the heck:

headline: Immigration Bill Splitting House G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — A push to give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military is roiling the immigration debate in the House, dividing Republicans and reviving some movement toward substantive immigration legislation this year.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fish With Morocco in Mind
text: In Morocco, fish is fried, grilled or simmered, just as it is everywhere else, but there is this essential difference: The first step in nearly every Moroccan fish recipe requires the fish to be slathered, anointed or rubbed with a mixture of herbs, spices and olive oil.

headline: High Line Chief Does Her Relaxing Uptown
text: Jenny Gersten, 45, who became executive director in January of Friends of the High Line, which runs the elevated park in Manhattan, had been the artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts. Theater runs in her family: her mother, Cora Cahan, is the president of the New 42nd Street, which revitalized theaters in the area, and her father, Bernard Gersten, recently retired as executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. Ms. Gersten’s husband, Willie Reale, 56, writes musical theater with his brother Robert and is a supervising producer of “Blue Bloods,” the CBS police drama. They live in the West 80s with their sons, Augustus, 15, and Leonardo, 11, and their black Labrador retriever, Penny.

headline: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
text: Anja Niedringhaus, 48, an internationally known German photographer, was killed while on assignment in eastern Afghanistan on Friday. Some of her closest colleagues offered deeply personal accounts of her life and career.

headline: Golden Corral
text: Among the fans who will be celebrating the Mustang’s 50th birthday will be some owners who bought the car when it first went on sale.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Week in Pictures for April 4
text: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Perry and Cruz on Base Shooting
text: Gov. Rick Perry and Senator Ted Cruz delivered remarks after meeting with military personnel wounded Wednesday in the shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.

headline: Inside Prison With Ponte
text: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed correction commissioner, has plans for reform. But Rikers will be a far bigger challenge than Maine’s jail system, where he instituted key changes.

headline: Grandma’s Diamond Is Forever
text: Ian Ross’ paycheck as a freelance EMT wasn’t enough for bills and an engagement ring. So like many millennials, he turned to a family heirloom when he asked Madlyn Wendell to marry him.

headline: No Spring Thaw in the Job Market
text: One of the many good things about the arrival of spring is that politicians, economists and other policy makers can no longer blame the winter weather for the slow economy and the grinding pace of job growth.

headline: Weinstein Releases 2 French Films Without Fanfare
text: LOS ANGELES — As others roll out blockbusters, the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein is serving up seasonal fare that has become almost as rare as a good croque madame: French films.

headline: Ryan’s Plan: To Balance the Budget, Hurt the Poor
text: The House leadership is trying to muscle Paul Ryan’s 2015 budget plan through the Republican caucus, and the amount of effort required is revealing. The budget is full of breathtakingly unfair spending cuts, but many Republican House members don’t like it because they think it doesn’t go far enough.

headline: Brazilian Firm Magnifies Focus on Distressed Debt
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The investment firm Jive Investments Holding, which acquired some of Lehman Brothers’ Brazilian assets in 2010, is raising a new $100 million distressed-debt fund focused on nonperforming corporate loans, according to people briefed on the firm’s plans.

headline: Under a Shiny Shroud, Cloaked in Mystery
text: “Otro Teatro,” the Spanish title of Luciana Achugar’s latest work, translates as “other theater” or “another theater,” with the possible connotation of an alternative one. The New York premiere on Wednesday took place in the conventional setting of the theater at New York Live Arts, but Ms. Achugar has some unconventional notions of what might transpire there for performers and audience. A handout suggests a project “to grow ourselves a new body,” “a utopian body,” “an anarchic body, “a body in pleasure.”

headline: Saying ‘Yes’ Before a Studio Audience
text: After exchanging emails and briefly talking on the phone, Sanjeev Sirpal knew it was time to meet a woman he had first encountered on Match.com.

headline: Weibo Seeks to Raise More Than $380 Million in I.P.O.
text: If all goes according to plan, the biggest of China’s Twitter-like microblogging services will raise more than $380 million in its coming initial public offering.

headline: A Quick Take on an Unusual Book Review
text: On Thursday, The Times published a rare review of a digital-only book. The book, “Sleep Donation,” by Karen Russell, was reviewed positively by Michiko Kakutani. In 2012, the book critic Dwight Garner reviewed 15 journalistic minibooks published for digital readers.

headline: David Letterman’s Legacy
text: Bill Carter, a media reporter for The Times, discusses David Letterman’s late-night legacy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Kenya, South Africa and England.

headline: Lusty Warriors, Panting Anew
text: Television shows that deal routinely with death usually get it out of the way early: Someone dies at the beginning of the episode, and everyone else spends the rest of the hour talking about it. “Game of Thrones” turns that formula around. In the early weeks of this HBO hit’s fourth season, which begins on Sunday, people mostly talk for an hour — reminding us of who they are, which family they belong to, what castle they call home — until the episode ends with an operatic, in one case game-changing, killing.

headline: Understanding Particulars of G.M.’s Safety Recall
text: If you drive one of the 2.6 million General Motors cars recalled because of a faulty ignition switch, you’re probably eager for the part to be replaced. Dealerships say they are gearing up to schedule the work as soon as the necessary parts become available — which is expected to happen starting Monday, according to G.M. But it could take months to repair all the affected cars.

headline: Classical, as It Meets Club Scene
text: When the Unsound Festival, a highly regarded annual experimental-music series that started in Poland in 1993, first planted its flag in New York in 2010, it arrived with a vaguely precise mandate. “Advanced music,” Mat Schulz, the festival founder, put it in an interview in The New York Times that year: “a kind of approach to making music rather than strict definitions.” Accordingly, of-the-moment electronica jostled against outlier strains of classical music.

headline: TPG and Others Said to Agree to Invest in Airbnb
text: Updated April 5, 9:58 a.m. |

headline: Slain Photographer Had Covered Several War Zones
text: Some of the scenes captured by Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer who was killed by a police officer in Afghanistan on Friday.

headline: Why That Sharp Wit Stood Out on Late Night
text: Life as we know it is over, and late-night television will never be the same.

headline: In Colorado, Cannabis Cup Time
text: With Colorado’s recent legalization of the recreational use of marijuana, ticket sales for Denver’s fifth annual Cannabis Cup this month are expected to double, according to event organizers.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Dallas
text: DALLAS — We are looking at the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here.

headline: Lupita’s Lancôme Gig, the Army’s Hair-Raiser and Christy Turlington’s Comeback
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Affluent Wine Buyers in Asia Find Their Confidence
text: HONG KONG — Six bottles of 1990 Romanée-Conti Burgundy sold to an Asian buyer at a Christie’s auction in Hong Kong last month for 980,000 Hong Kong dollars ($126,345). A case of wine from the Cros Parantoux vineyard in Burgundy, France, fetched $82,333 in a sale held by the American auction house Acker Merrall & Condit at a restaurant overlooking Hong Kong’s harbor.

headline: ‘With Grandma’s Ring, I Thee Wed’
text: Nervous yet hopeful, Ian Ross knew what he wanted to ask, but he wasn’t sure just how to say it. He stared into her eyes, knowing that the whole proposal was riding on this moment.

headline: Hedge Fund Advertising Off to a Slow Start, Survey Finds
text: Hedge funds have not exactly rushed to take advantage of their new ability to advertise.

headline: Stand Up, They’re Rocking the Boat, Like 1950 Again
text: For most people, the term fugue evokes a very sober, complex form of contrapuntal instrumental music. But then there is the “Fugue for Tinhorns,” the song that opens the classic 1950 musical “Guys and Dolls,” in which three small-time gamblers in New York argue over their picks to win a big horse race. Here was the great composer and lyricist Frank Loesser wresting the fugue form from classical music and turning it into a charming, clever, but no less musically ingenious opener for a show about some lovable denizens of the New York underworld, as vivid as ever in the brilliant book by Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows. And what better setting for that song, and Loesser’s inspired score, than Carnegie Hall, which on Thursday night hosted an exhilarating, one-time-only, ready-for-Broadway performance of “Guys and Dolls,” with Rob Fisher conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, no less.

headline: A Petticoat as Spy Signal
text: “Turn” could mean a lot of things. The Turn is what survivors on “The Walking Dead” call their zombie apocalypse. Repeated three times, it’s the title of a folk song, and it’s the first half of turncoat, as in traitor, or turndown, as in turndown service in a fancy hotel, or maybe just turnip, the root vegetable.

headline: So Far Away. No, She’s in Row K.
text: It had become a confounding mystery of the Broadway season: Why hadn’t Carole King come to see the Carole King musical? Did it mean that she didn’t like the show and was trying to distance herself from it? Was she just a recluse holed up in Idaho who didn’t like crowds? Then why did she perform at the Grammys and make regular appearances on “Morning Joe”?

headline: What, Me Old?
text: Twenty-five years ago, when the twin daughters of a childhood friend were 7 and I was 41, I told them that someday, when they were grown, I’d babysit for their children.

headline: Carlotta Gall on Fear and Hope in Afghanistan
text: In 2006, while reporting in Quetta, Pakistan, about the possible connection between Pakistan and the Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan, Carlotta Gall was attacked in her hotel room by four plainclothes agents of the I.S.I., Pakistan’s main intelligence service. Gall was punched twice in the face and temple, and her computer, notebooks and cellphone were seized.

headline: A Con Artist, a Librarian, Love and 76 Trombones
text: Hope is a major theme of “The Music Man,” and the opening number of the show at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport raises hopes for a sterling production throughout. Meredith Willson’s heartwarming 1957 musical, which won the Tony Award for Best Musical over “West Side Story,” begins in a railway car filled with traveling salesmen who complain about a flimflam man in their trade named Harold Hill. Their fast-paced patter song, “Rock Island,” is set to the beat of their bouncy ride through the Iowa countryside. Tightly choreographed and precisely sung in this production, it is a delightful introduction to a clever musical that celebrates the joys of rhythm, rhyme and syncopation.

headline: Video: Nickolas Butler’s Wintry Place on Earth
text: EAU CLAIRE, Wis. — As Nickolas Butler explains it, he actually began “Shotgun Lovesongs,” his debut novel about the gravitational pull of a small Wisconsin town on a group of friends, in Iowa, with a fit of homesickness. He was in his first semester at the University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop, in a class with James Alan McPherson.

headline: Last Bohemian Turns Out the Lights
text: At the end of March, Clayton Patterson, the outlaw artist, was sitting in the window of his storefront home on Essex Street complaining about New York. It’s something Mr. Patterson does well. He is an accomplished ranter, whose disputes with the city are numerous and varied but tend to revolve around the ruination of the Lower East Side by luxury apartments, ugly corporate chain stores, overpriced parking meters, pretentious restaurants and college students who vomit on the street.

headline: Scrambling for a New Site
text: The moment Lisa Goldstein walked into the grand old former synagogue that is the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts on the Lower East Side, she was in love. Ms. Goldstein, 33, said, “I always joked I picked the venue before the groom.” She and her fiancé, Keith Helman, 34, had booked the space for April 5, 2014. Invitations were sent. A Monique Lhuillier dress was picked out. Peter Callahan, the celebrity caterer, was booked.

headline: For Letterman’s Job, Dueling 10-Best Lists
text: It is now officially the most coveted job in television: successor to David Letterman. Let the maneuvering begin.

headline: New York’s Police Department Has Been Watching
text: New York City’s Department of Records and Information Services released Friday thousands of newly digitized images, including ones collected in the ’30s and ’40s by the Bureau of Criminal Alien Investigation.

headline: The Few, the Brave: Men in Tights
text: Given the winter’s crazy cold, it was hardly surprising to see men layering black sports tights under shorts for their workouts and outdoor runs — sensible, even. What was more of a shock was to see some of those men take the look out of the gym, incorporating it into their daily street wear.

headline: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
text: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was killed in Eastern Afghanistan today when an Afghan policeman approached her vehicle at a security checkpoint and opened fire with a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The German native was 48 years old.

headline: Who Are You on Facebook Now?
text: On his driver’s license and passport, at his doctor’s office and insurance company, for online dating and social media, and on every application or document that requires checking a box for gender, 24-year-old Ryley Pogensky is a “male.” But to his friends on Facebook, he is now a “trans man.”

headline: Banking on My Future as a Father
text: “When are you going to have one of these?” a friend asked a few months ago, referring to the 10-month-old crying baby in her arms.

headline: Apple and Samsung Fight Over Who Was the Follower
text: Last year, a member of Apple’s sales team prepared a research document expressing concern about the growth in sales of smartphones with larger screens, while sales in the segment of phones including the iPhone were slowing down.

headline: Corrosion Risk Prompts Ford Recall, and Spiders Clog Mazdas
text: Ford is recalling nearly 386,000 Escape sport utility vehicles from the 2001-4 model years because a corrosion problem could result in a loss of steering. The company is also recalling 49,000 vehicles from the 2013-14 model years because the seat backs are not strong enough, the automaker said in a news release on Friday.

headline: A Power Lunch, Times Two
text: Talk about a high-concept lunch date: bring Nancy Pelosi, who from 2007 until 2011 was the first woman to serve as speaker of the House (she is now the minority leader), together with Julia Louis-Dreyfus, the actress who plays the vice president (and as-yet-unannounced presidential candidate) on the HBO comedy “Veep,” whose third season begins Sunday. Of course, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus has real-life rank, too, having won four Emmy Awards for her work on three television comedies: “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine” as well as “Veep.”

headline: Master Drawings as Springboard for Invention
text: It was only in the last century that drawing became a respectable, stand-alone medium. Before that, it was treated as an educational tool or as preparation for larger works. Drawings were often discarded and rarely signed, creating problems for curators and opportunities for enterprising forgers.

headline: Death of a Pied Piper
text: Frankie Knuckles, the veteran club D.J. who died Monday at the age of 59 of complications from diabetes, may have ruled the underground club scene, but his death was mourned very publicly.

headline: The ‘No More Tears’ Formula for Yoga Wear
text: The moment of tears in the clothing-store dressing room has started at least a million diets. But for Alissa Benishai, a real estate developer, it started a business.

headline: It’s My Birthday. I’d Like That Shirt in Blue.
text: When Jordan Weinstein turned 32, he did not send out invitations, host a party or even have a few friends over for cake. That all struck him as unnecessary and indulgent. What he did do, however, was register for gifts at REI, the sporting goods store, and then distribute the link to his mother, fiancée and brother to pass around.

headline: The Found Art of Thank-You Notes
text: When Jimmy Fallon sits down to write his weekly thank-you notes on “The Tonight Show,” he is both ribbing and breathing life into a custom many felt was headed the way of the dodo. “Thank you, cotton candy,” Mr. Fallon scribbles on a correspondence card, “for making my grandmother’s hair look delicious.” Thank you, “bowling, for giving me an excuse to drink with somebody else’s shoes on.”

headline: Under Cover: Taking On Wall Street
text: This week’s cover story tells how a small group of Royal Bank of Canada employees uncovered and then set out to counter the unfair advantages of high-frequency trading in the stock market. Brad Katsuyama, a former trader at the bank, is one of the main players in Michael Lewis’s story and is featured on this week’s cover.

headline: Nineties Nostalgia Propels Coogi Brand Resurgence
text: Ugly sweater party? Please. For another example of how ’90s nostalgia is propelling street wear and high-end fashion, consider Coogi knitwear, instantly recognizable for its rainbow of snarls and swirls.

headline: Student, Athlete and Employee?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Truth About Venezuela, as Marco Rubio Sees It
text: To the Editor:

headline: Starting Duda Pays Off as Mets Win Their First
text: In the midst of a miserable first week of the season, the Mets tried to eliminate at least one potential controversy by naming Lucas Duda as the starting first baseman on Friday. The protracted battle between Duda and Ike Davis threatened to be a distraction to a team fraught with bullpen, hitting and attendance issues.

headline: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth
text: Jeff Dworkin, a Dallas builder, was surprised to find someone he didn’t recognize inside a half-finished house this winter where crews were about to texture the home’s drywall.

headline: The Dieting Supremacist. Hate Her.
text: I’ve lost almost 20 pounds in the last year — you still reading? — and I cannot tell you the contempt I feel when I see lesser beings stuffing their mouths with French fries and T-bone steak and pain au chocolat. Pain au chocolat is my favorite thing on earth. If I am ever sentenced to death for, say, kicking a teenage boy on Rollerblades in front of a truck, I will be requesting it as my last meal.

headline: Money Wins, Peace Loses
text: This was a week for cynics to shrug their shoulders. In Washington, the conservative majority on the Supreme Court struck down aggregate limits on individual campaign contributions, arguing in effect that these denied the very rich their right to participate fully in the political process. And in the Middle East, John Kerry became the latest in a long line of secretaries of state to watch his or her “peace process” founder in the deep fog of Israeli-Palestinian recriminations and distrust.

headline: Airport Workers March on a Symbolic Day
text: Airport workers, elected officials and community leaders rallied for improved wages, benefits and a paid holiday.

headline: Iran: Border Guards Released by Pakistani Militants
text: Four of five Iranian border guards seized by Pakistani militants along the volatile Iran-Pakistan frontier two months ago have been released, Iran state media reported Friday. The captors claimed to have executed one of the border guards. Iran’s government-run Press TV website quoted Esmail Kosari, deputy chairman of a parliamentary committee on national security and foreign policy, as saying that the other four had been handed over to Iranian officials in Pakistan. It was not immediately clear why they had been released, and there was no confirmation from Pakistan’s government. The abductions on Feb. 6 caused deep strains in relations between Iran and Pakistan, and the Iranians had threatened to send troops into Pakistani territory to rescue the captives. The border area, in Sistan-Baluchistan Province in southeastern Iran, is a hotbed of Sunni militant resistance to Iran’s Shiite authorities. In October, Iran executed 16 Sunni insurgents in retaliation for an attack by armed men who crossed the border from Pakistan and killed 14 Iranian border guards near the city of Saravan.

headline: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
text: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But it can also be wearable art.

headline: Judge Loath to Permit TV Testimony on Islamist
text: The testimony of a key prosecution witness in the terrorism trial of a radical Islamic cleric has been thrown into doubt because a federal judge in Manhattan is balking at allowing him to testify from Britain via closed-circuit television.

headline: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
text: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But students (above) waiting to get into a show in Paris have yet to discover that it is not an art form, although some looks at the shows there resemble walking sculptures that perhaps should be shown at the Venice Biennale: Issey Miayke’s Tree Ring pleated dresses, Gareth Pugh, Rick Owens and Junya Watanabe. Comme des Garçons has completely abandoned wearable clothes for wearable sculptures. That label’s work resembles that of Chakaia Booker, an American artist. Around Paris, other examples of fashion as art include, bottom row, faces in color.

headline: Evening Hours | Bring On the Greenery
text: Protecting the oceans, animals and art.

headline: Lingering Hope vs. Onset of Grief Over Lost Flight
text: BEIJING — Steve Wang has not slept at his home in Beijing since Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished with his mother on board. His days are a blur of rooms at the Lido Hotel: his suite on the 13th floor; the capacious ballroom, where Malaysian officials hold briefings; quiet corners where he has anguished meetings with other passengers’ relatives also living at the hotel. There are meals in between, though he said he no longer felt hunger.

headline: Wheel of Fortune: A New Way to Play Ivy Roulette
text: To the Editor:

headline: Safety Labels on Generic Drugs
Beer Franchise Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Believe Boy, 16, Killed Deliveryman
text: A 16-year-old and two older teenagers were arrested on Friday on murder charges in the fatal shooting of a deliveryman on a desolate street on the north shore of Staten Island, the police said.

headline: Before Joining a Board, Size Up the Job and the Mission
text: IN the last five years, Keith T. Banks, the president of U.S. Trust, a private wealth management division of Bank of America, has done what many of the firm’s wealthy clients do: He has joined nonprofit boards. He’s up to four. Yet the boards he sits on are not only different in mission, but also in size and expectations for trustees.

headline: Viewing Video Games From Another Level
text: A benchmark for video games as cultural artifacts came in 2012 when the Museum of Modern Art in New York announced it had acquired 14 games for its collection. Depending on your perspective, the museum might be a little late in acknowledging the significance of video games — or early, compared with other art institutions. (The games were acquired by the museum’s department of architecture and design, putting them in the “design” category rather than alongside painting and sculpture.) Now, an ambitious survey of video games organized by the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and previously on view there, is at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

headline: A Resolution at Last for a Father’s Unsettling Legacy
text: DOBSON, N.C. — Sometime in late 2012, feeling his mortality after two heart attacks, Joseph Corsbie realized that the moment had come to tell the story of the ashes. He had first heard it nearly 30 years earlier from his father, Walter. And only in the face of imminent death had Walter finally spoken, keeping his promise to never forget.

headline: Second Maker of Car Seats Cites Buckle Flaw in Recall
text: The Evenflo Company is recalling almost 1.4 million child restraints because a balky buckle could make it hard to free the child in an emergency. But the manufacturer is refusing to recall rear-facing infant seats that use the same buckle, according to a report from Evenflo posted on Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: U.S. Eyes Afghan Vote, Seeking Amenable Ally
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has watched cautiously from the sidelines in the months leading up to Saturday’s elections in Afghanistan, focusing instead on new crises in the Middle East and Ukraine, and no longer on the country that was a foreign policy priority when President Obama first entered office.

headline: In Bid for Revote, Union Claims Tennessee Officials Frightened Workers
text: The United Automobile Workers has seized on leaked documents from Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee in its efforts to persuade the National Labor Relations Board to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga.

headline: Charter School Refugees
text: LAST week, the New York State Legislature struck a deal ensuring that charter schools in New York City would have access to space, either in already crowded public school buildings or in rented spaces largely paid for by the city. Over the next few years, charters are expected to serve an increasing proportion of city students — perhaps as much as 10 percent. Which brings up the question: Is there a point at which fostering charter schools undermines traditional public schools and the children they serve?

headline: Curtis Bill Pepper, Author, Reporter and Traveler, Is Dead at 96
text: Curtis Bill Pepper, an author and reporter who roamed Europe and the Middle East for more than 40 years writing about politics, film, art, the Vatican, Leonardo da Vinci and more, died on Friday at his home in Todi, Italy. He was 96.

headline: Michael Lewis’s Crusade
text: There is always something just a little frustrating about reading a Michael Lewis book. On the one hand, Lewis’s core point — whether it is that left tackle has become the second most important position in football (“The Blind Side”), or that the stock market has become rigged by high-frequency traders, as his new book, “Flash Boys,” claims — is almost always dead-on. His ability to find compelling characters and tell a great story through their eyes is unparalleled. He can untangle complex subjects like few others. His prose sparkles.

headline: Personality and Change Inflamed Mozilla Crisis
text: Mozilla is not your typical Silicon Valley company.

headline: All in the Family, Sort Of
text: Here’s the latest life lesson from the campaign trail: If you are, say, making a home movie about how great your family is, try to remember to use pictures of your actual relatives, and not random attractive strangers.

headline: Grandstanding on Prisons in Texas
text: Rick Perry, the Republican governor of Texas, is gearing up for the 2016 presidential elections by bellowing about imaginary overreach from Washington and refusing to comply with the Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003.

headline: Army Base Shooting Highlights Difficulty in Identifying At-Risk Soldiers
text: The case of the Army specialist who opened fire with a .45-caliber Smith & Wesson handgun at Fort Hood on Wednesday is casting light on the difficulties the military has had in identifying soldiers at high risk of violence and deciding whether to restrict their access to firearms.

headline: Brooklyn Tough
text: Heather Hardy, 5 feet 5 inches of determination, began boxing in 2010 and is on a roll, undefeated after nine professional fights..

headline: Judge Says Ohio Must Recognize Same-Sex Marriages Performed Out of State
text: A federal judge in Cincinnati declared Friday that he would require Ohio to recognize same-sex marriages performed legally in other states, the latest in a series of court decisions around the country overturning restrictive state marriage laws and amendments.

headline: Applications Fall and Admission Rate Rises as Cooper Union Charges Tuition
text: The results are in for the first big test of Cooper Union’s new era — the era in which students actually pay to attend — and the university appears to have scored about 80 percent.

headline: Polarizing Wildcats Find Their Way Together
text: RICHMOND, Tex. — On a cul-de-sac in a leafy residential subdivision in this booming oil town 30 miles west of Houston, Andrew and Aaron Harrison were raised to look out for each other, as perhaps only identical twins could.

headline: 3 Soldiers Identified as Victims of Shooting
text: The Army on Friday identified the three people killed in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood as decorated soldiers who had served multiple tours of duty overseas.

headline: Grand Jury Questions Christie Aide in an Inquiry
text: The chief spokesman for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared before a grand jury in Newark on Friday to answer questions in the federal inquiry into the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

headline: Hand-to-Hand Coordination
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve never had a crossword puzzle make me think of the actor Keanu Reeves right off the bat, but that’s exactly what Ashton Anderson’s and James Mulhern’s grid did for me. The WHOA at 1 Across, made even more Keanu-y by the “Bill and Ted’s Excellent Adventure” clue “That’s crazy, dude!” got Mr. Reeves stuck in my head while I tackled the northwest corner.

headline: Saturday’s Highlights: From 4 to 2
text: If top-seeded Florida is to win its third national title in nine seasons, it must first topple No. 7 Connecticut, which dealt the Gators their last loss, on Dec. 2, before defeating either No. 2 Wisconsin, the only other team to beat the Gators this season, or No. 8 Kentucky, which has lost all three matchups with Florida this season.

headline: French Push U.N. to Seek War Crimes Case in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — France has taken the first steps toward proposing a Security Council resolution that would refer Syria to the International Criminal Court for the prosecution of war crimes, diplomats said Friday, an action long sought by rights advocates.

headline: We Were Just Laughing: Days With Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon
text: It is heartbreaking to call friends and colleagues in Kabul on a day like this. The connection from the United States is bad and I can barely catch their words. I was just there with them all earlier this week, laughing and swapping stories with two veteran journalists, Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan.

headline: Waiting for the Markets to Blink
text: HEADING into the second quarter, investors seem to have little conviction about the direction of stock and bond markets. Both ended the first three months of 2014 barely changed, despite a big change in Federal Reserve policy.

headline: My Bitcoin Befuddlement
text: AM I the only person in the world who doesn’t have Bitcoin jangling in a cryptographic wallet? Sometimes it seems that way.

headline: Complaints Build as a Cathedral Project Begins Its Rise
text: Laurie Frey heard jackhammers one morning this week and raced down the block to find demolition workers preparing to cut down the tall trees on the lot next to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. She realized what the power saws meant: A project to build a second apartment complex on the cathedral grounds was finally beginning.

headline: Seeking Silver Linings in Emerging Markets
text: IN a quarter in which most stock funds eked out small gains, emerging-market equity portfolios couldn’t even manage that much.

headline: When Bond Funds Think Outside the Box
text: UNCONSTRAINED bond funds can own debt instruments of any type — long- or short-term, high- or low-quality, corporate or government or whatever, in any country and currency — to try to enhance returns. With interest rates near record lows and investors eager to bolster yields, enthusiasm for these portfolios, also known as nontraditional funds, seems boundless too.

headline: Technology That Transforms Life (and Mutual Funds’ Returns)
text: TECHNOLOGY that transforms industries or consumers’ lives is an important investing theme these days. The managers of three mutual funds — Fidelity OTC Portfolio, Lord Abbett Micro Cap Growth and Driehaus Micro Cap Growth — have all focused on it, and their approach put them among the performance leaders in the first quarter.

headline: How E.T.F.s Have Gained Momentum
text: MUTUAL funds in the United States held $15.2 trillion in February. Exchange-traded funds were tiny by comparison, with only $1.7 trillion.

headline: Retirement Advice, Without the Sugarcoating
text: THERE are two overwhelmingly appealing things about Carrie Schwab-Pomerantz’s new personal finance book, which is aimed at those 50 and over.

headline: The Biggest Dividends Aren’t Necessarily the Best
text: RISK-AVERSE investors seeking steady income have had little to cheer about in recent years.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 4, 2014
text: April 4, 2014

headline: Dreaming of a Maserati, but Staying the Course
text: I GAINED access to a windfall the other day. And after fantasizing briefly about all the things I could buy, I’ve decided not to touch the money.

headline: New Global Aids Chief for U.S. Assumes Post
text: Dr. Deborah Birx, a former chief for global AIDS for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, was sworn in on Friday as the nation’s global AIDS coordinator. The post puts Dr. Birx, a former Army colonel, in charge of the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief and American participation in the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. A vast majority of all funds spent on global health come from those two organizations. Dr. Birx is the fourth to hold the post, which was created under the George W. Bush administration. It is in the State Department and carries ambassadorial rank. Dr. Eric Goosby, the last coordinator, resigned in November. His predecessor, Dr. Mark Dybul, is now executive director of the Global Fund, which is based in Geneva.

headline: Lawmakers Deserve More Pay, Congressman Says
text: Representative James P. Moran says members of Congress cannot “live decently” in Washington on their $174,000 salary and deserve more money. Their pay has been frozen since 2010, and Mr. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who is not seeking re-election, told Roll Call that he would introduce a measure that would provide members with a per diem allowance. “The fact is that this is the board of directors for the largest economic entity in the world,” Mr. Moran said.

headline: Pro’s Example Keeps Connecticut’s Foul Shooting Sharp
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Whether Connecticut has better 3-point shooters than Florida, or better rebounders or ball handlers, is up for debate. This much about their matchup Saturday night, though, is unassailable: The Huskies are the superior free-throw shooting team.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Administration Officials Over Drone Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit against top Obama administration officials that was filed by the parents of three United States citizens whom the government killed without trial in drone strikes, including Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical Muslim cleric.

headline: Creatures Great, Small and Imagined
text: Nearly 700 pounds and 15 feet long, the blue marlin lay on the deck of a fishing boat off the coast of Cape Verde as James Prosek snapped photographs, made sketches and took measurements. Awe-struck and moved, he watched the giant fish’s colors fade from their living vibrancy to the muted tones of death.

headline: Mouse Infestation Closes Birthplace of the Cronut
text: New York City residents and tourists are apparently not alone in their love of Cronuts, those croissant-and-doughnut hybrids that have people lined up for blocks before dawn outside a SoHo bakery.

headline: Knicks Fall to Washington, and Drop Behind Atlanta
text: Carmelo Anthony was able to string together so many good days and nights for the Knicks that it almost came to be taken for granted. But when the Knicks desperately needed Anthony, facing a must-have game against the Washington Wizards with the schedule dwindling to a handful of dates, he struggled to play through an injury to his right shoulder and was ultimately unable to provide another big effort.

headline: Rocked at Start, Tanaka Finds Rhythm and Lifts Yankees to Win
text: TORONTO — Three pitches into Masahiro Tanaka’s major league career, one thing was clear on Friday. As good as he may be, and as much faith as the Yankees had in him to commit $175 million for his services, Tanaka is not unhittable.

headline: Fewer Pupils Qualify for Gifted Programs
text: The numbers of children qualifying for seats in gifted programs in New York City public schools declined this year, the Education Department said on Friday, though they were still far higher than when citywide admissions testing began a few years ago.

headline: As Critics Vent, Maple Leafs Take Deep Breaths
text: TORONTO — The fading playoff hopes of the Toronto Maple Leafs rest with the backup goaltender James Reimer, who was vilified by some frustrated, overzealous fans two weeks ago in a series of nasty messages sent to his wife’s Twitter account.

headline: James Benkard Dies at 76; Defended Inmates in Death Penalty Cases
text: James W. B. Benkard, a prominent New York corporate lawyer who was honored for his extensive pro bono work in cases involving the death penalty and prisoners with mental illness, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: Rough Start Aside, an Elite Debut
text: Masahiro Tanaka’s adjustment period to Major League Baseball appeared to last about three innings.

headline: Corrections: April 5, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) MAN OF STEEL (2013) The director Zack Snyder traces the path of Clark Kent, portrayed by a ripped Henry Cavill, above, from boy to man — and superhero status — in this newfangled origin story. Russell Crowe and Ayelet Zurer play Jor-El and Lara Lor-Van, the birth parents of Clark, who was born Kal-El on the doomed planet Krypton; Diane Lane and Kevin Costner are Martha and Jonathan Kent, the Kansas couple who adopt him after he’s rocketed to Earth; Amy Adams is his romantic interest, Lois Lane; and Michael Shannon is General Zod, his alien foe. “At once frantically overblown and beautifully filigreed, ‘Man of Steel’ will turn on everyone it doesn’t turn off,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “If you wave away all the computer-generated smoke and see past the pulverized buildings, it’s possible to remain hooked on the resonant origin story that wends through ‘Man of Steel’ — that of the immigrant.” And while Mr. Snyder isn’t capable of mythmaking, she added, “in his sometimes poetic, sometimes crude way, he has given Superman a new lease on franchise life by affirming that this most American hero is also an alien yearning to breathe free.”

headline: 4 Killed After Car Plunges Into Creek, Police Say
text: Four people died on Friday night after the car they were riding in veered off a rain-slicked road, hit a curb and flipped into a creek off the East River, authorities said.

headline: Afghan Turnout Is High as Voters Defy the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defying a campaign of Taliban violence that unleashed 39 suicide bombers in the two months before Election Day, Afghan voters on Saturday turned out in such high numbers to choose a new president and provincial councils that polling hours were extended nationwide, in a triumph of determination over intimidation.

headline: U.S. Response to Crimea Worries Japan’s Leaders
text: TOKYO — When President Bill Clinton signed a 1994 agreement promising to “respect” the territorial integrity of Ukraine if it gave up its nuclear weapons, there was little thought then of how that obscure diplomatic pact — called the Budapest Memorandum — might affect the long-running defense partnership between the United States and Japan.

headline: Minding the Minders of G.M.
text: There is a truism in Washington that was confirmed last week in Congress: Even less popular than government regulation is a regulator suspected of not doing its job.

headline: Analytics: Taking Sides
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 6 issue of the magazine.

headline: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Australian authorities coordinating the multinational search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane in the southern Indian Ocean said Sunday that they were investigating three reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.

headline: Detroit and Its Art Treasures
text: Detroit and Its Art Treasures

headline: The Frustrations of a Part-Timer
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Paid for Playing Games
text: David Hanson, 28, is a game app developer at Concrete Software in Eden Prairie, Minn.

headline: An Economic Gauge, Imperfect but Vital
text: In “G.D.P.: A Brief but Affectionate History,” Diane Coyle, a British economist, conveys a sophisticated understanding of an economic standby, the quarterly measure of gross domestic product. A vital gauge of any nation’s prosperity, the G.D.P. has its strengths and its limitations, which are well explained in Dr. Coyle’s rich and engaging little book.

headline: Automation Alone Isn’t Killing Jobs
text: Although the labor market report on Friday showed modest job growth, employment opportunities remain stubbornly low in the United States, giving new prominence to the old notion that automation throws people out of work.

headline: The Oracle of Omaha, Lately Looking a Bit Ordinary
text: Warren Buffett is probably the most famous investor of his generation, and for good reason: His track record over the long term is a thing of beauty.

headline: Kim Bowers of CST Brands, on Managing Up vs. Managing Down
text: This interview with  Kim Bowers, chief executive of CST Brands, a gas-station and convenience-store retailer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: I Had a Nice Time With You Tonight. On the App.
text: Last Sunday, I spent a lazy afternoon with my boyfriend. We chatted while I made brunch, discussed the books we were reading, laughed at some cat pictures and then settled down with dinner, before bidding each other good night.

headline: The Wallet as Ethics Enforcer
text: There is a lot we don’t yet know about the disastrous decisions made by General Motors after it became aware of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalts more than 10 years ago.

headline: Space Chips for the Common Man
text: Moore’s Law is taking over space.

headline: 2 Italian Priests and a Canadian Nun Are Abducted in Cameroon
text: ROME — Two Italian priests and a Canadian nun were abducted early Saturday from their mission in northern Cameroon, the Italian government and Vatican officials said.

headline: Journeyman on the PGA Tour Downsizes His Life and Upgrades His Game
text: Last Sunday in San Antonio, as Will MacKenzie played into contention at the Texas Open, he tried to keep thoughts of the Masters out of his head. He was tied for second after a final-round 70, and then waited for the leader, Steven Bowditch, to finish.

headline: For Soprano, From ‘Butterfly’ to ‘Bohème,’ in a Flash
text: Last-minute cast changes at opera houses are always full of drama, but the one that took place in Saturday afternoon’s performance of Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera promises to go down in the annals of day-of-the-performance substitutions.

headline: Variety: A Well-Furnished Acrostic
text: Administrivial New Acrostic Web Game Alert! Have you noticed that the New York Times Acrostic game has had a facelift? It’s not dependent on Java, and is really easy and fun to play! You can give it a try here.

headline: Vivendi Chooses to Sell Mobile Phone Unit to Altice, Ending Noisy Bidding War
text: After a bidding war, the French media conglomerate Vivendi said Saturday that it would sell its mobile phone unit, SFR, to Altice in a deal worth as much as 17 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion.

headline: As Their Numbers Fall, College Basketball’s Black Coaches Face a Conundrum
text: Sometime around 1989, a small group of black coaches and writers began a Final Four tradition. We would meet, at coffee houses, snack shops, dimly lit restaurants, and talk into the hours of the morning about issues affecting young black athletes.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 68
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Despite Support in Party, Democratic Governors Resist Legalizing Marijuana
text: LOS ANGELES — California voters strongly favor legalizing marijuana. The state Democratic Party adopted a platform last month urging California to follow Colorado and Washington in ending marijuana prohibition. The state’s lieutenant governor, Gavin Newsom, has called for legalizing the drug.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 6
text: “The recovery still feels like a recession to many Americans and it also looks that way in some economic statistics.”

headline: For Knicks, Mediocrity Is No Bar to Postseason
text: Carmelo Anthony and his teammates represent the 68th Knicks team. Surprisingly, they still have a chance to become the 43rd to make the playoffs. Of those 43, they would be the seventh to have a losing record. And of those with losing records, they almost certainly would be the worst of the bunch.

headline: First Reviews Confirm Replay as a Strategy, Not a Cure-All
text: The least shocking news of the first full week of the baseball season should be this: The new instant replay system did not reverse every missed call. That was not the intent.

headline: Family Connection Breaks Ground at Masters
text: For Craig Stadler and his firstborn, Kevin, golf is the multivitamin that renews their father-and-son relationship. Like countless others, the Stadlers will converge on a golf course this week from different states and different stages of their careers to play a few rounds and catch up on each other’s hectic lives.

headline: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety Inside Ft. Hood
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Pastor Randall Wallace of the First Baptist Church of Killeen has watched thousands of troops head off to war and then come home to Fort Hood, the mammoth military base that shares this patch of Central Texas with an unpretentious jumble of pawn shops, fast food joints and vinyl-sided bungalows.

headline: In Women’s Final Four, Jousting Before the First Jump Ball
text: NASHVILLE — Not long after Muffet McGraw won her first and only national championship in 2001, she was cold-called by Paul Gullifor, a Notre Dame loyalist, women’s basketball aficionado, college professor and author.

headline: O Caddie! My Caddie!
text: Tempo, rhythm and timing.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: For the Devils, Shootouts Become a No-Win Mind Game
text: The Devils have a case of the yips. Not your garden variety, as with a golfer losing his putting touch. This one runs through the whole team and has been going on all season.

headline: Encouraging Debut and Frustrating Loss for Yankees
text: TORONTO — The return of Michael Pineda after two years of rehabilitation was supposed to be the final sign that the Yankees had recovered their health and that the numerous injuries that plagued them in 2013 were a thing of the past.

headline: John Calipari’s Trip to the Final, Step by Agonizing Step
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — John Calipari descended five steps from the court at AT&T Stadium, passed a marching band, 14 rows of seats and a towering stanchion of stands before lurching into a tunnel. He banked right, shuffled down a long, curved corridor and then, only then, did he reach the door to the Kentucky Wildcats’ locker room.

headline: A Fairer Pay System?
text: Readers discuss the huge disparity in pay

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 6
text: Fort Hood, Tex., suffered a devastating blow this week when Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at the Army base, killing three and wounding 16 of his fellow soldiers, then taking his own life. Five years ago, another soldier went on a similar shooting rampage at Fort Hood, killing 13 people. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel struggled to explain why new security measures had not been effective.

headline: Her First, and Last, Book
text: TWO years ago, Marina Keegan’s life brimmed with promise. She was graduating with high honors from Yale University, already a precocious writer about to take up a job at The New Yorker.

headline: The Trauma of Being the Also-Ran
text: IT was March 1997. I unlocked my apartment door, petted the dog and hit “play” on my answering machine.

headline: Hypocritical Tax Cuts
text: On Thursday, a strong bipartisan majority in the Senate Finance Committee voted to reinstate dozens of temporary tax breaks that had expired at the end of 2013. The package, mainly tax cuts for businesses, included sensible items like tax credits for the production of wind energy and other alternative fuels, and for research and development. It also included special-interest giveaways and some silly stuff like bigger write-offs for racehorses. But what’s particularly outrageous is that the bill calls for the government to borrow the entire $85 billion cost of the two-year reinstatement.

headline: The Trick of Life
text: SEVEN years into writing a novel, I started to lose my mind. My thirty-seventh birthday had just come and gone, the end of 2008 was approaching, and I was constantly aware of how little I had managed to accomplish.

headline: Policing the Sport of Kings and Knaves
text: The abuse and doping of thoroughbred horses has become so pervasive at racetracks that the Jockey Club, the sport’s most influential voice, is endorsing federal legislation to put the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of cleaning up the industry.

headline: Note to Republicans: Channel Jack Kemp
text: WHEN Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, delivered a speech last month outlining proposals for economic growth, his sponsor was the Jack F. Kemp Foundation, a Beltway organization set up in memory of the Republican politician who died in 2009 and has recently been cited as a hero by some of the party’s most prominent figures.

headline: Sheldon: Iran’s Best Friend
text: IT occurred to me the other day that the zealously pro-Israel billionaire Sheldon Adelson and Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, actually have one big thing in common. They are both trying to destroy Israel. Adelson is doing it by loving Israel to death and Khamenei by hating Israel to death. And now even Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey inadvertently got drawn into this craziness.

headline: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy
text: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy is an Indian social reformer and founder of Barefoot College, an organization that trains the poor, particularly poor women, to become self-sufficient through education and training. He has trained grandmothers, from sub-Saharan Africa to the Himalayas, to be solar engineers so they can both literally and figuratively be the source of power in their remote villages.

headline: When Coziness With Sources Is a Conflict
text: IN theory, most serious journalists can agree on this principle: It’s a bad idea to get too close to your sources. Cordiality, yes; coziness, no.

headline: Health Care Without End
text: SO you think it’s finished? So you think now that enrollment has hit seven million, now that the president has declared the debate over repeal “over,” now that Republican predictions of a swift Obamacare unraveling look a bit like Republican predictions of a Romney landslide, we’re going to stop arguing about health care, stop having the issue dominate the conversation, and turn at last to some other debate instead?

headline: As Vermont Goes, So Goes the Nation?
text: WHEN most liberals hear the words “third party,” they have nasty flashbacks to Ralph Nader’s spoiler campaign in 2000. The history buffs among them might think of the populist Greenback Party’s feckless protests against the gold standard in the 19th century or the five presidential campaigns of the Socialist Eugene V. Debs — the last of which, in 1920, he ran from prison.

headline: Bring Me My Dragons!
text: WASHINGTON — I’D been hoping to get the flu.

headline: The New Gay Orthodoxy
text: TO appreciate how rapidly the ground has shifted, go back just two short years, to April 2012. President Obama didn’t support marriage equality, not formally. Neither did Hillary Clinton. And few people were denouncing them as bigots whose positions rendered them too divisive, offensive and regressive to lead.

headline: A Rationalist’s Mystical Moment
text: MY atheism is hard-core, rooted in family tradition rather than adolescent rebellion. According to family legend, one of my 19th-century ancestors, a dirt-poor Irish-American woman in Montana, expressed her disgust with the church by vehemently refusing last rites when she lay dying in childbirth. From then on, we were atheists and rationalists, a stance I perpetuated by opting, initially, for a career in science.

headline: What Life in the Real World Costs
text: I APPLIED to college sitting on the carpeted stairway of our apartment, yelling down questions to my mother. “Mom, am I anything?”

headline: Capitalize Workers!
text: Raising the minimum wage has justifiably captured policy makers’ attention, but if the goal is to materially raise living standards for every American worker, we should also be calling for a minimum pension. Done right, this would not only create real wealth for the middle and working classes, it would use the power of financial markets to reduce wealth disparity instead of widening it.

headline: Like, Degrading the Language? No Way
text: IF there is one thing that unites Americans of all stripes, it is the belief that, whatever progress our country might be making, we are moving backward on language. Just look at the crusty discourse level of comments sections and the recreational choppiness of text messages and hit pop songs.
