headline: One Afghan Woman’s Voice
text: Despite Taliban threats, Afghans turned out across the country Saturday to vote for a new president. Shukria Barakzai, one of the female members of the Afghan Parliament, prepared to vote.

headline: Yes He Can, on Immigration
text: If President Obama means what he says about wanting an immigration system that reflects American values, helps the economy and taps the yearnings of millions of Americans-in-waiting, he is going to have to do something about it — soon and on his own. It has been frustrating to watch his yes-we-can promises on immigration reform fade to protestations of impotence and the blaming of others. All Mr. Obama has been saying lately is: No, in fact, we can’t, because Republicans and the law won’t let me.

headline: In Europe, Echoes of America as Concussions Spur Debate
text: LONDON — The debate over how to respond to the growing research linking brain trauma to injuries sustained in sports has spread to Europe, with many of the same dynamics seen in recent years as the issue gained momentum in the United States.

headline: Points for Product Placement: N.C.A.A. Cashes In, but Not the Players
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The new champions of men’s college basketball, whoever they may be, will cut down a net here Monday night. And when they do, they will climb to the basket on a blue-and-yellow Werner ladder, and they will clip the cords with a pair of orange Fiskars scissors.

headline: Stanford Star Makes Campus Her Stage
text: STANFORD, Calif. — Chiney Ogwumike was not yet a year old, standing contentedly in a baby walker next to her father, who was eating pizza while they watched television. Except that Ogwumike was not watching television. She was watching the slice of pizza in her dad’s hand.

headline: Under Revised Quake Estimates, Dozens of Nuclear Reactors Face Costly Safety Analyses
text: WASHINGTON — Owners of at least two dozen nuclear reactors across the United States, including the operator of Indian Point 2, in Buchanan, N.Y., have told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they cannot show that their reactors would withstand the most severe earthquake that revised estimates say they might face, according to industry experts.

headline: U.N. Leader Urges Action in Central African Republic
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, arrived in the Central African Republic on Saturday in an effort to drum up world support for an effort to stanch the widening sectarian conflict there.

headline: If Tiger Woods Were Healthy, Oh, the Places He Could Go
text: When golfers win consistently or play well on a certain course, they like to say “it fits my eye,” meaning that the shape of the fairways and the nuances of the greens blend with their swings and their senses. And for Tiger Woods, stalled at 14 for six years in his passionate pursuit of Jack Nicklaus’s record 18 major victories, this was supposed to be the year when the stars were aligned for him to win another major or two, when the course for each of the four major tournaments fit his eye.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: April 4, 2014
text: General Motors says it has connected 13 deaths and dozens of accidents to a defective ignition switch. The company, led by a new C.E.O., is now recalling millions of Chevy Cobalts, despite reports that the problem has stretched back more than a decade.

headline: Even Small Medical Advances Can Mean Big Jumps in Bills
text: MEMPHIS — Catherine Hayley is saving up for an important purchase: an updated version of the tiny digital pump at her waist that delivers lifesaving insulin under her skin.

headline: Having Close to 50 Wins May Not Be Good Enough in West
text: LOS ANGELES — Brandan Wright says he remembers how good the Golden State Warriors felt about themselves when he was a rookie in the 2007-8 season. They were the N.B.A.’s top-scoring team. They had won 48 games — the franchise’s best record in 14 seasons and a six-game improvement over the previous one, when they had upset the top-seeded Dallas Mavericks in the Western Conference playoffs.

headline: Voices Emerging Against a Union
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — Northwestern’s football coach, Pat Fitzgerald, has urged players to vote no in a secret ballot union election scheduled for later this month, he said Saturday.

headline: To Strike at Kochs, Democrats Revive Tactic That Hurt Romney
text: WASHINGTON — After months of wincing in the face of negative ads funded by the industrialists David and Charles Koch, Democrats believe they have finally found a way to fight back: attacking the brothers’ sprawling business conglomerate as callous and indifferent to the lives of ordinary people while pursuing profit and power.

headline: When Money Talks, Game Is Drowned Out at Big Stadiums
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When Steve Anderson arrived at AT&T Stadium on Saturday for the Final Four, he entered on the ground floor, then went up and up and up — and up again — to his seat in the upper tier.

headline: Few Answers After 4 Die When Car Plunges Into Creek in Queens; Driver Survives
text: A car carrying five young friends returning from a birthday party plunged into a creek in Queens after the driver lost control on a rain-slicked road Friday night.

headline: Grand Slam by Davis Seals Mets’ Ninth-Inning Rally Over Reds
text: After Lucas Duda, Ike Davis’s competition to be the Mets’ first baseman, earned the starting job Friday, Davis watched him hit two home runs that night to stake a firm hold on the position.

headline: Apathy and Fear of Taliban Combine to Keep Rural Voters Away From the Polls
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — While polling centers across Kabul and other Afghan cities were celebrating record turnouts on Saturday, Tahir Khan, a tribal leader in rural Nangarhar Province, experienced a very different Election Day.

headline: A Posthumous Triumph
text: My Sunday column looks about the message–of seeking meaning and fulfillment in life–from a young woman who graduated from Yale two years ago, Marina Keegan. Marina’s first book will be published this coming week, and it’s a call to life life to the fullest, to be idealistic when you’re young and can be. It’s a spirit I see in a lot of young people, and I’m a big fan of this generation of young people. I think they have more idealism than many previous generations, but also more of a practical sense of how to actually get things done rather than engage in largely symbolic gestures–a very practical idealism, if you will. Marina embodied that. And I write of her in the past tense for reasons that become obvious in the column.

headline: Technology’s Man Problem
text: Elissa Shevinsky can pinpoint the moment when she felt that she no longer belonged.

headline: Blast Near Falluja Kills 17 Iraq Troops
text: BAGHDAD — An explosion in a house west of Baghdad on Saturday killed 17 Iraqi soldiers who had sought cover during a clash with militants, officials said.

headline: At Times
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sundays are the only day that The New York Times crossword puzzle runs with a title and, the title is there in part to punnily help us figure out what we’re in for when we solve. Today, the title of this puzzle by Patrick Berry is fairly literal.

headline: The Victims of Fort Hood
text: A gunman killed three people and wounded 16 others before killing himself at Fort Hood, the same sprawling Army base in Texas where in 2009 an officer went on a shooting rampage that left 13 people dead.

headline: Tasting Early Success, Only to Walk Away
text: A victory at the World Junior Chess Championships can open the door to a life on the elite competitive circuit, as a list of past winners shows: Boris Spassky, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Viswanathan Anand, Levon Aronian.

headline: Afraid It Was Missing the Boat, a City Tries to Catch the Bus
text: Arlington has long been among the largest American cities without public transportation. Since 1980, the city’s voters have rejected transit proposals three times, with opponents citing fears ranging from costs to worries about an increase in crime.

headline: Now in Driver’s Seat, Patrick Credits Grass Roots
text: Almost eight years ago, before he became a state senator, Dan Patrick was known around the Texas Capitol as the Houston talk radio host who had shouted down a powerful committee chairman in the middle of a legislative hearing.

headline: Civil Rights Sins, Curated by One of the Sinners
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — In the woods off Monroe Road, a truck is so rusted that it is melting into the earth. It was Vernon Dahmer’s truck, the one that he drove and that his family continued to use after his death, the circumstances of which can be inferred from the three penny-size holes in the back panel.

headline: A Military Town: Bonded to Fort Hood
text: The town of Killeen, Tex., is adjacent to the Fort Hood military post. The town’s economy and culture are closely connected to the base.

headline: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
text: WASHINGTON — In the skies above Yemen, the Pentagon’s armed drones have stopped flying, a result of the ban on American military drone strikes imposed by the government there after a number of botched operations in recent years killed Yemeni civilians. But the Central Intelligence Agency’s drone war in Yemen continues.

headline: Log Jams Create Problems for Searchers
text: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department discussed the search in Oso, Wash., and explained how log jams have delayed the effort.

headline: Finding Fellowship After Deadly Washington Mudslide
text: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The landslide on March 22 in the high slope above the community of Oso mowed down a forest. Trees great and small, splintered and tumbling, became part of the slide’s signature, in killing 30 people and leaving 13 others still missing.

headline: For Center, 20 Years of Creating Vegetables
text: In 1983, after more than 10 years of research, a Texas A&M University horticulturist named Leonard Pike created an onion that did not make people cry. This alone was revolutionary, but Dr. Pike also conferred another attribute upon his plant progeny: a single center.

headline: A Long Shot Nears Its Goal: UConn Topples Florida
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — During the singing of the national anthem Saturday, Connecticut’s players stood in silence, heads down, arms around one another, lost in their thoughts. They swayed from side to side, as if at a revival — their own. All wore the same white long-sleeve T-shirt. It read, “UConn Pride.”

headline: Sales-Tax Plan Would Redefine District Wealth
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Peter Matthiessen, Lyrical Writer and Naturalist, Is Dead at 86
text: Peter Matthiessen, a roving author and naturalist whose impassioned nonfiction explored the remote endangered wilds of the world and whose prizewinning fiction often placed his mysterious protagonists in the heart of them, died on Saturday at his home in Sagaponack, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: As Town Mourns an Educator, It Celebrates a Close-Knit Community
text: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The long procession of funerals for victims of the Oso landslide began here and in the neighboring town of Arlington on Saturday.

headline: A Change in Atmosphere in Central Syria
text: The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights.

headline: Relative Calm in Parts of Syria Is Deceptive
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The change of atmosphere here in the Syrian capital is unmistakable. The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights. Tensions over security are draining from the city like air from a balloon. Checkpoints remain ubiquitous but sentries are relaxed, even jocular, teasing strangers, “Any bombs?”

headline: Citizenship-for-Cash Program in Malta Stirs Security Concerns in European Union
text: PARIS — A program in Malta that offers citizenship for cash is raising concern among officials who fear it could open a back door into Europe and the United States for swindlers, criminals or terrorists who can afford the price tag of up to $1.57 million.

headline: Election in Hungary Tests Nation’s Tilt to the Right
text: BUDAPEST — While Europe was enmeshed in its years of euro crisis, Viktor Orban, Hungary’s popular but controversial prime minister, tilted his country’s politics rightward, to a chorus of foreign and domestic criticism but little censure from the European Union.

headline: With Upset at Wood Memorial, Wicked Strong Ensures Spot in Derby
text: Last fall, Jimmy Jerkens thought he had a horse that would take him to the Kentucky Derby, a colt by the name of Wicked Strong. This was the one that would make him forget about the last time he had circled the first Saturday of May at Churchill Downs — five years ago with a tender-footed runner named Quality Road.

headline: Lawyer Sees No Revenge in an Arrest in New Delhi
text: The lawyer for a New York police officer arrested in India last month for having rounds of ammunition in his luggage said Indian officials were following the law in detaining his client, and not retaliating for the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York last year.

headline: Tending Their Wounds, Vowing to Fight On
text: KOBLENZ, Germany — Shot twice at the bloody denouement of Ukraine’s revolution, Yuri Kravchuk spends his days in the most pristine of hospital wards, gazing out the window at this orderly German city, churning images of battle through his mind.

headline: Brazil Sends In Armed Forces to Assist in Policing Poor Area
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — About 2,700 members of Brazil’s security forces on Saturday occupied a slum complex that sits along two highways connecting Rio’s international airport to its main tourist zone.

headline: Richard Brick, Who Drew Films Back to New York, Dies at 68
text: Richard Brick, a filmmaker and teacher who as the film commissioner of New York City in the early 1990s helped repair the city’s strained relationship with Hollywood and bring film crews back from Toronto and other faux-New York locations, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: Barbara Gibbons, 79, Writer of ‘Slim Gourmet’ Cookbooks, Dies
text: Barbara Gibbons, the author of “The Slim Gourmet” syndicated column and cookbooks — and the original 208-pound customer for their low-calorie recipes — died on March 26 at her home in Dallas. She was 79.

headline: Jesus Lives, but Should He Live in My Front Yard?
text: As I drove home from church, I eyed the bright foam sign my 6-year-old daughter held. “Jesus is Alive” it read in kid scrawl. “We’re supposed to put them in our yards!” Noelle beamed, eyeing her creation proudly through pink-rimmed glasses.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 5, 2014
text: April 5, 2014

headline: With a Spirited Garnett Back, the Healthy Nets Edge the 76ers
text: PHILADELPHIA — Kevin Garnett’s coach and teammates were teasing him Saturday morning, calling him a rookie. It had been so long since Garnett, 37, had joined them on the court that he seemed like a new player on the Nets.

headline: Zuccarello Provides Spark, but Clinching Must Wait
text: Mats Zuccarello’s performance encapsulated a lot of what went right and what went wrong for the Rangers in their 3-2 loss to the Ottawa Senators on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. He scored twice, but he was also on the ice for all of the Senators’ goals.

headline: With Late 3-Pointer, Kentucky Edges Wisconsin to Advance to Final
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan had a player once who wanted to leave college early and go to the N.B.A. It was Devin Harris, in 2004, and he was a junior.

headline: Judith Orlando and John Tamagni
text: Judith Sapadin Orlando and John Searle Tamagni were married Saturday afternoon at the Heights Casino, a private squash, tennis and social club in Brooklyn. The ceremony was led by Arnold L. Lehman, a Universal Life minister and the director of the Brooklyn Museum, where the groom is the chairman of the board of trustees.

headline: Janna O’Shea and Michael Zagari
text: Janna Elizabeth O’Shea and Michael Richard Zagari are to be married Sunday at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan. Carissa Templeton, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, is to perform a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Aviva Berman and Ezra Billinkoff
text: Aviva Jaclyn Berman, a daughter of Gita Guttman Berman and Steve Berman of Atlanta, is to be married Sunday to Ezra Lewin Billinkoff, a son of Dr. Sharon Lewin and Donald Billinkoff of New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine is to officiate at Summerour Studio, an event space in Atlanta, where Rabbi Dr. Analia Bortz is to take part in the ceremony.

headline: Nancy Costello and Katherine Rodway
text: Nancy Jane Costello and Katherine Linda Rodway were married Saturday at St. Peter’s Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. John Magisano, a minister of the Metropolitan Community Church, officiated.

headline: Hilary Cloos and Jeffrey Feinsod
text: Hilary Robinson Cloos and Jeffrey Marc Feinsod were married Saturday evening at Helsinki Hudson, an event venue in Hudson, N.Y. Brian C. Fox, the bride’s brother-in-law, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Marjorie Galler and Steven Horn
text: Marjorie Fran Galler, a daughter of Roberta I. Galler and Marvin Galler of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Steven Jared Horn, a son of Carol S. Horn and Lawrence A. Horn of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi James Ponet will officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

headline: Julia Balduzzi, Ryan May
text: Julia Alexandra Balduzzi and Ryan Patrick May were married Friday evening at the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Eddie Rodriguez, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Aliza Balog, Scott Goodside
text: Aliza Jordana Balog and Scott Bradley Goodside were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated.

headline: Samantha Beinhacker, Scott Anderson
text: Samantha Langbaum Beinhacker and Scott Edward Anderson were married Saturday at the Green Building, an events space in Brooklyn. Lori Hanau, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Doreen Lee, Eric Kushins
text: Dr. Doreen Formosan Lee and Eric Ross Kushins were married Saturday at the Eliza Thompson House, a historic inn in Savannah, Ga. Adam F. Kushins, the groom’s brother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Richard Forde, David Foushée
text: Dr. Richard James Forde and David Russell Foushée were married Saturday at the couple’s home in Yountville, Calif. Jan Chapman Lanterman, a friend of the couple and a deputy marriage commissioner in the County of Napa, Calif., officiated.

headline: Seraphim Reycraft, Henry Hoffman
text: Seraphim Yoo Reycraft, a daughter of Seraphim D. Reycraft and Thomas C. Reycraft of Pelham, N.Y., was married Saturday to Henry Maxwell Hoffman, a son of Erika V. Hoffman and Dr. Byron Jay Hoffman Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Michael Greco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham.

headline: Whitney White, Peter Van Steemburg
text: Whitney Anne White and Peter Dixon Van Steemburg were married Saturday evening at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Margaret Grey Fairchild, a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony that was led by Rebecca Linder Blachly, a former divinity student.

headline: Mark Anderson, Keith Bucklew
text: Mark Chenoweth Anderson and Keith Elden Bucklew were married Thursday at the Cannon House Office Building in Washington. Susan C. Bucklew, a senior United States judge for the Middle District of Florida and the sister-in-law of Mr. Bucklew, officiated in the office of Representative Kathy Castor, Democrat of Florida.

headline: Jacqueline Waldman, Stephen Wax
text: Jacqueline Cheryl Waldman and Stephen Brian Wax were married Saturday evening at the New York Palace hotel in Manhattan. Cantor Neil Ben-Isvy officiated.

headline: Carly Lindauer, Cliff Hamilton
text: Carly Heather Lindauer and Dr. Cliff Scott Hamilton were married Saturday evening at Millesime, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi William I. Kuhn officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Ford, Christopher Keaney
text: Elizabeth Scott Ford and Christopher Patrick Keaney were married Saturday at the Stonehouse Villa, an event space in Driftwood, Tex. Spike Gillespie, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Rachel Wasserman, Lonnie Greenberg
text: Rachel Jana Wasserman and Lonnie Greenberg were married Saturday evening at the PGA National Resort and Spa in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Cantor Bruce Benson officiated.

headline: A Match Made in Kickball
text: Emily Samantha Schneider, a daughter of Susan E. Greenberg and Evan B. Schneider of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to William Alexander Scheer, a son of Carole A. Scheer and Alex W. Scheer of Bulls Head, Staten Island. Rabbi Janet Roberts is to officiate at Giando on the Water, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Inauguration Day, in More Than One Way
text: Tiffany Melen Hall and John Brandon Rhea were married Saturday at the Chevy Chase United Methodist Church in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Kirkland Reynolds, a Methodist minister and the church’s pastor, officiated. Bishop Gregory G. M. Ingram, who presides over the First Episcopal district of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, participated.

headline: Corrections: April 6, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that an Australian vessel had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight data and cockpit voice recorders, possibly from the missing jet.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Inflation or Deflation?
text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Israel Warns Palestinians but Stays Open to Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened Sunday that Israel would take its own “unilateral steps” in response to the Palestinians’ move last week to join international conventions and reiterated that a Palestinian state could be created “only through direct negotiations, not through empty statements and not by unilateral moves.”

headline: 1914: Sir Herbert Tree To Star in Bernard Shaw’s ‘Pygmalion’
text: LONDON — Mr. Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion,” to be produced by Sir Herbert Tree at His Majesty’s Theatre on Saturday, will be the feature of the week, which otherwise would be uneventful, especially as many managers are taking advantage of Holy Week to give their companies a rest.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (HBO) SILICON VALLEY In this new comedy created by Mike Judge, a group of socially stunted programmers shares the home — or, as they call it, the incubator — of a dot-com billionaire who lets them live rent-free in exchange for a 10 percent stake in their ventures. The show’s mockery of “obscene wealth and the grandiosity that comes with giving back” is badly needed, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “A new cultural revolution is at hand, and many of its leaders are even more smug and self-righteous than the counterculture activists who, back in the 1960s, also thought they could change the world.” She added, “ ‘Silicon Valley’ isn’t making the world a better place, it is putting the real Silicon Valley in its place, one Tesla at a time.” Above, from left, Kumail Nanjiani, Martin Starr, Thomas Middleditch, Zach Woods and T. J. Miller star in the show. The season opener of “Game of Thrones” leads in at 9; “Veep” follows at 10:30.

headline: Concert Versions of Broadway Musicals Appear Beyond Theaters
text: Rosie O’Donnell sat in a booth at the Broadway supper club 54 Below, sipping red wine and getting teary as she watched members of the original cast of “Taboo,” the flop she produced on Broadway a decade ago, power through the score.

headline: Qatar Museums Authority Leader to Leave Post
text: Edward Dolman is stepping down as the executive director and acting chief executive of the Qatar Museums Authority, a job he held for three years, the authority announced on Sunday. But he will remain a member of the authority’s international advisory board.

headline: Guarded Optimism After Breast Cancer Drug Shows Promising Results
text: SAN DIEGO — Researchers say that a new type of drug can help prevent advanced breast cancer from worsening, potentially providing an important new treatment option for women and a blockbuster product for Pfizer.

headline: The World’s Biggest Tetris Game
text: The Drexel University professor Frank Lee and his team hacked into the lighting system of a 29-story skyscraper in Philadelphia to play Tetris on the building’s facade.

headline: Making a Game Larger Than Life
text: After a 20-hour Tetris marathon on his Macintosh SE/30 desktop computer, Frank J. Lee drove across the Bay Bridge from Berkeley to San Francisco, his mind still stuck on the game. He was an undergraduate majoring in cognitive science, and the year was 1990.

headline: Apple’s Deep Pockets: What $159 Billion Could Do
text: Big technology companies have a problem anyone would love to have: They are sitting on vast amounts of cash.

headline: New York’s Paid Sick Leave Law Quietly Takes Effect
text: Shiv Puri gathered his employees together after the lunchtime rush last week to deliver the big news: This year, the cook and kitchen staff at the Bombay Sandwich Company on West 27th Street will receive paid sick leave for the very first time.

headline: In Our Pages: April 7
text: 1889: Fires on the Prairie

headline: In a Test of Wills With China, U.S. Sticks Up for Japan
text: TOKYO — On his first trip to China as the secretary of defense, Chuck Hagel is finding himself in the middle of a spat that would not be out of place in “Mean Girls,” a movie about social cliques in high school.

headline: ‘Captain America: The Winter Soldier’ Has a Huge Opening
text: The Marvel movie machine can even bring summer early. “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” broke industry records for an April opening by taking in about $96.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend, an astounding 48 percent increase over the three-day opening for its series predecessor in 2011. The movie has already taken in an additional $207 million overseas.

headline: Two Officers Critically Injured While Responding to Brooklyn Blaze
text: Two veteran police officers, partners out on patrol around lunchtime on Sunday, rushed to the 13th floor of a high-rise housing development in Coney Island, Brooklyn, after a report of a fire was called in.

headline: Oligarchy and Monetary Policy
text: I’ve been thinking about how we talk about — or don’t talk about — the desirability of low inflation targets. As I noted the other day, the lates IMF World Economic Outlook makes a compelling case for raising the target above 2 percent — but avoids saying so explicitly, resorting to coded euphemisms. Meanwhile, inflation paranoia is very much a partisan thing. In my class notes for tomorrow I list the signatories of the economists’ letter warning about dollar “debasement” from quantitative easing; it’s obvious that everyone on the list is a highly committed Republican, and some people with the right ideological credentials are on board even though they have no relevant professional credentials. (William Kristol and Dan Senor, monetary experts?)

headline: UConn’s Center Adds Fitness to Her Ebullience
text: NASHVILLE — It was yet another Connecticut-Stanford game, and as usual, something weighty in women’s basketball rested on the outcome.

headline: Young, Rich and Ruling Radio, Country Walks a Broader Line
text: NASHVILLE — On the radio, it has displaced Top 40 as America’s most popular musical format.

headline: Attuned to the Money
text: Was Bernard L. Madoff ever tempted to sing about his pyramid scheme? Did Martha Stewart contemplate an insider-trading tap dance? Their efforts might have enlivened “Greed: A Musical for Our Times,” a revue by Michael Roberts at New World Stages.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 2
text: Last year, Churchill Downs adopted a points system to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in designated Derby prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Wood Memorial and Santa Anita Derby can be found here.

headline: Cement Makers Holcim and Lafarge Are Said to Agree on Merger Plan
text: PARIS – The boards of Holcim and Lafarge, two of the world’s largest construction materials companies, have agreed to merge, a person close to the discussions said on Sunday.

headline: Jeb Bush Talks Approach If He Runs for President
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — With eyes increasingly on him, Jeb Bush signaled on Sunday the kind of campaign he would mount if he runs for president, one arguing against ideological purity tests while challenging party orthodoxy on issues like immigration and education.

headline: In His Return From Injury, Niese Feels Good, but Reds Feel Better
text: Jon Niese sat alone in a booth at a sports bar in Port St. Lucie, Fla., last Monday, ordered a turkey burger topped with a fried egg and watched the Mets’ season opener on television. He probably would have started that game if his spring training had not been derailed by shoulder discomfort and elbow inflammation.

headline: John
text: John

headline: Smith Tries but Cannot Carry the Knicks
text: MIAMI — Carmelo Anthony’s right arm, by his own description, felt dead by the second half Sunday afternoon. It was not an ideal situation for the Knicks, who were seeking to remain viable (or at least marginal) candidates for the postseason against the Miami Heat.

headline: French Film Goes Viral, but Not in France
text: PARIS — The main character is a harried parent just trying to slog through the routine of the day: dropping off the toddler at day care, picking up the mail, running errands.

headline: Unrest in Eastern Ukraine
text: In Donetsk and Lugansk, crowds bearing Russian flags clashed with the police and stormed government buildings on Sunday.

headline: My So-Called Opinions
text: I.

headline: Telling Victim From Villain at Duke
text: This again? We were blitzed with the Duke University lacrosse scandal in 2006. And, it seems, we’re still not done with it.

headline: Powerhouse Theater Summer Season
text: Among the highlights of the summer season for the Powerhouse Theater will be “In Your Arms,” a collection of wordless dance vignettes written by playwrights like Terrence McNally, Christopher Durang, Carrie Fisher, Douglas Carter Beane and Lynn Nottage, with music by Stephen Flaherty (“Ragtime”) and choreography by Christopher Gattelli (“Newsies”). Produced by New York Stage and Film and Vassar College, the season is also to include new plays by Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”) and John Patrick Shanley (“Doubt”) and is scheduled to begin on June 20 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

headline: Museum Director to Be Commissioner of Cultural Affairs
text: Tom Finkelpearl, the president and executive director of the Queens Museum, is scheduled to be named the cultural affairs commissioner by Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday, the mayor’s office confirmed, putting Mr. Finkelpearl in charge of a $156 million budget and making him the point person on the arts for a city widely considered the cultural capital of the world.

headline: An Unusual Family Legacy With Heavy Responsibility
text: In Ajmal Zaheer Ahmad’s “Jinn,” the supernatural beings of the title have good and evil versions. But there’s good and evil, and there’s just plain bad. Most of the time, this incoherent thriller resembles an overheated trailer for itself: a glaringly rough assembly of ill-staged computer-generated action sequences and portentous moments.

headline: For UConn, as Well as the Huskies, a Golden Opportunity to Impress
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Halfway through a private brunch Saturday, as Connecticut’s biggest donors finished their all-you-can-eat French toast and sausages, the university’s president, Susan Herbst, put down her glass and made her way to the center of the room.

headline: Good and Evil, Ritual and Nightmare, in Sight and Sound
text: “Concealed,” by the British electronic-music duo Demdike Stare and the filmmaker and animator Michael England, is an audiovisual project, no more or less aural than visual, about dread and dreams, what happens in the world when the conscious mind isn’t noticing.

headline: A Homely Nymph, Wooed by a God to Rouse His Wife’s Jealousy
text: The conductor William Christie appeared onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to apologize to the audience that had packed the place for a performance of Rameau’s comic opera masterpiece “Platée.” He explained that he was still recuperating from a recent surgical procedure and would not be able to conduct Les Arts Florissants, the vocal and instrumental ensemble he founded in France 35 years ago, a group that has set the standard for the performance of French Baroque opera. He also regretted, he said, that the audience would not be seeing the director Robert Carsen’s staged production, which had recently played to acclaim in Vienna and Paris. This would be just a concert performance, the “busker’s version,” Mr. Christie said.

headline: Proclaiming Joy, in Concert, on His 75th Birthday
text: When Hugh Masekela celebrated his 75th birthday on Friday night, with a Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater, he recalled pivotal advice from Harry Belafonte, who was in the audience. In 1960, Mr. Masekela left the brutal apartheid of his birthplace, South Africa, to become a trumpeter in New York. He recalled that Mr. Belafonte, an early supporter, urged him to “put some of that stuff from your home into what you do.”

headline: Full-Throttle Emotions and Blind Faith
text: The soprano Renata Scotto, a celebrated interpreter of the tragic teenage heroine of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly,” found that being too emotionally invested in the character was problematic because “you suffer and you can’t sing.” The soprano Kristine Opolais said in a recent interview on Latinos Post that because she doesn’t hold back emotionally, she finds the role so psychologically taxing that she might have to limit future performances.

headline: The Faces of Power, From the Portraitist in Chief
text: DALLAS — Former President George W. Bush is something of a natural when it comes to making oil paintings, a decent amateur. Although he picked up a brush only in 2012, this naturalness emerged as a definite possibility barely a year later. That’s when images of two strange, seemingly introspective paintings by Mr. Bush went viral, hacked from the email of a Bush relative, very discreetly showing the former president bathing.

headline: Bolshoi’s ‘Giselle,’ Geared to Virtuosity and a Vocal Audience
text: MOSCOW — Of all the surviving 19th-century ballets, “Giselle,” with its narrative nexus of love and dance and death, is the one that can most be relied upon not to disappoint. Unlike other ballet classics from that era, it seldom loses narrative tension; its technical and acting challenges keep stimulating individual casts. And yet the Bolshoi Ballet performance I saw on Wednesday was the dullest account in my entire experience of this war horse (nearly 40 years). While the one on Thursday was considerably better, both were drearily routine affairs.

headline: The ‘Superpredator’ Scare
text: After a surge of teen violence in the early 1990s, some social scientists predicted the future was going to be a whole lot worse. Reality proved otherwise.

headline: A Couple of Couples
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a Monday puzzle that goes above and beyond, in my opinion.

headline: When Youth Violence Spurred ‘Superpredator’ Fear
text: As the police and prosecutors in Brooklyn tell it, Kahton Anderson boarded a bus on March 20, a .357 revolver at his side. For whatever reason — some gang grudge, apparently — he pulled out the gun and fired at his intended target. Only his aim was rotten. The bullet struck and killed a passenger who was minding his own business several rows ahead: Angel Rojas, a working stiff holding down two jobs to feed his family of four.

headline: Pornography, Children and Parents
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s Root, Root, Root for the Umpires ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Guide for Employers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Job Skills Gap
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Accessible Subways
text: To the Editor:

headline: Election Time in Afghanistan
text: But the threat of disruption from the Taliban is always present.

headline: Vox Takes Melding of Journalism and Technology to a New Level
text: WASHINGTON — Ask Ezra Klein what prompted him to leave a high-profile position at The Washington Post to start a new website, and the answer is a little wonkish, even for the founder of the newspaper’s Wonkblog, a mix of politics, economics and domestic policy that had become must reading in the Beltway.

headline: Neither Female Nor Male
text: SYDNEY, Australia — PRETTY much the No. 1 question you are asked when you’re pregnant is: “Girl or boy?” If you choose not to find out, but to be deliciously surprised at birth, as I did, then you will be asked to guess: “What do you feel it is?” I used to scrunch up my eyes and try hard to draw on what people told me was an age-old female intuition: Which genitals were sprouting in my round belly? I could never tell, though.

headline: Final Round at the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams
text: DALLAS — March 30 was the final day of the Spring Nationals here. When the last round of the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams began that evening, Roy Welland of New York City, Sabine Auken and Christina Madsen from Denmark, and Josef Piekarek and Alex Smirnov from Germany were two victory points ahead of Martin Fleisher, Zia Mahmood and Chris Willenken of New York City; Steve Garner of Chicago; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.

headline: Senate Set to Pass Bill Extending Jobless Aid
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate is expected to easily approve legislation Monday restoring unemployment benefits to nearly three million people, throwing the bill to a divided House where Republicans favor starkly different approaches to the issue.

headline: Traveler Magazine Learns Luxury Service at Hotels
text: Like most of the staff at the opulent Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, Bill Wackermann was busy. He attended an early morning meeting to prepare for the day’s guests. He inspected a room under renovation. He answered phones at the concierge desk.

headline: Turning 40, But Infused With Youth And Vigor
text: As with so many dance companies, Ailey II, the junior ensemble of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, exhilarates and disappoints at the same time. The dancers are tremendous. The choreography, not so much.

headline: Look Up! All Signs Point to Art
text: Can the likes of Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper and Cindy Sherman help jump-start the struggling billboard business?

headline: Margalit Fox Answers the Question: ‘Why That Life?’
text: Margalit Fox has written more than 1,000 obituaries for The Times.

headline: India’s Next Prime Minister?
text: Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party could become India’s next prime minister. Here’s a look at his controversial past and his economic promises.

headline: Timeline of the Riots in Modi’s Gujarat
text: Explore key developments in the 2002 riots in Gujarat that shadowed Narendra Modi’s ascent to the prime minister’s office.

headline: Eight (No, Nine!) Problems With Big Data
text: BIG data is suddenly everywhere. Everyone seems to be collecting it, analyzing it, making money from it and celebrating (or fearing) its powers. Whether we’re talking about analyzing zillions of Google search queries to predict flu outbreaks, or zillions of phone records to detect signs of terrorist activity, or zillions of airline stats to find the best time to buy plane tickets, big data is on the case. By combining the power of modern computing with the plentiful data of the digital era, it promises to solve virtually any problem — crime, public health, the evolution of grammar, the perils of dating — just by crunching the numbers.

headline: Jeter, With His Final Home Opener Up Next, Climbs Career Hits List to No. 8
text: TORONTO — A year ago, when the Yankees opened their season in the Bronx against the Boston Red Sox, there was a noticeable void. It was felt during the pregame introductions when players like Kevin Youkilis and Travis Hafner were announced over the public-address system, but Derek Jeter was not.

headline: Discovery Blitz, Including a Daredevil and Oprah
text: WHAT began with a sales pitch, ended with Oprah Winfrey — and in between featured two hours and 20 minutes of attractions like reality television stars, Ron Howard, Roseanne Barr, a marching band and one of the Wallendas, the daredevil circus performers?

headline: Bronx Neighborhood Fights for Its Spot on the Map
text: Allerton residents know where they live. It is everyone else they have to worry about.

headline: The Capitalism of Catastrophe
text: TULSA, Okla. — Disasters happen. It is a fact as certain as income taxes. And when a solar flare erupts or a flu pandemic hits, there is only one question that will matter: Are you, or are you not, prepared?

headline: Atlanta Archbishop Says He’ll Sell Mansion
text: After an uproar over the cost of a $2.2 million residence, the archbishop of Atlanta said over the weekend that he would sell the mansion.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 67
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: BlackRock Elevates Executives in Succession Planning Move
text: BlackRock, the giant investment management firm, announced a series of executive shifts on Sunday aimed at grooming a number of potential successors to its founder and leader, Laurence D. Fink.

headline: SAC Capital Plea and JPMorgan Earnings
text: SAC CAPITAL FADES AWAY AS JUDGE CONSIDERS ITS PLEA

headline: Departing White House Counsel Held Powerful Sway
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama selected Kathryn Ruemmler to be White House counsel in June 2011, it was something of a surprise: As a younger, relatively obscure lawyer, and one with no personal ties to the president, she did not fit the mold of predecessors.

headline: State Visit of Ireland’s President to Britain, a First, Underlines Evolution of Relations
text: LONDON — In a sign of the warmth of relations between two countries with a troubled history, Ireland’s president, Michael D. Higgins, is to arrive here Monday for the first state visit to Britain by an Irish president.

headline: Questions for Comcast as It Looks to Grow
text: It is hard to say how rugged the questions will be when Comcast goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday to defend its proposed megamerger with Time Warner Cable.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion District Robberies Turn Heads, and Some Can’t Help Smirking
text: PARIS — Since the reign of France’s Sun King, the historic Place Vendôme has served as this city’s capital of luxury, home to high-end fashion boutiques and diamond shops, Coco Chanel’s mansion, and the palatial Hôtel Ritz Paris. Lately, though, this quarter snug in the heart of Paris has turned into the hub of a decidedly more low-rent form of plunder: smash-and-grab robberies.

headline: Toledo Blade Sues Over Detention of Journalists at Tank Plant
text: The Toledo Blade newspaper has filed a lawsuit against six government officials, including Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, claiming that two of its journalists were detained unlawfully while taking pictures outside a tank plant in Lima, Ohio.

headline: A Community Mourns Soldiers Killed in Fort Hood Rampage
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Even before a gunman killed three soldiers last week at Fort Hood, the homily for Sunday’s noon Mass at St. Joseph Catholic Church here was always going to be about death, a consequence of the year’s liturgical calendar two weeks before Easter.

headline: Oligarchs and Money
text: Econonerds eagerly await each new edition of the International Monetary Fund’s World Economic Outlook. Never mind the forecasts, what we’re waiting for are the analytical chapters, which are always interesting and even provocative. This latest report is no exception. In particular, Chapter 3 — although billed as an analysis of trends in real (inflation-adjusted) interest rates — in effect makes a compelling case for raising inflation targets above 2 percent, the current norm in advanced countries.

headline: Weil Hires Senior Goldman Bankruptcy Specialist for London Office
text: A month and a half ago, Barry Wolf sat down for dinner at Babbo in London’s upscale Mayfair district with two of his partners at the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges.

headline: Waiting, Fittingly, for a Catcher to Bloom
text: Six games into their season, the Mets have the fewest hits in the majors and the most strikeouts a game in the National League. They also just took two of three from the Cincinnati Reds — a playoff team last season — and came within an opening-day strike of a .500 homestand.

headline: A Rush to Overbuild Downtown
text: The developer Larry Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the World Trade Center site, feuded for years about how to rebuild the area after Sept. 11, 2001. Then, in 2010, they made a deal that gave Mr. Silverstein nearly $2 billion in financing and incentives to build two towers adjacent to the museum and memorial.

headline: Surgery Will Shelve Mets’ Parnell for Season
text: Closer Bobby Parnell will have Tommy John elbow surgery Tuesday, the Mets said after their 2-1 loss to Cincinnati on Sunday. Parnell, who learned last week that he had a partly torn ulnar collateral ligament, is expected to miss the rest of this season, and his availability for the start of the 2015 season could be in jeopardy.

headline: Expressway to Amazon in a Box
text: OSTENSIBLY, the new Amazon Fire TV is a streaming media set-top box — an Internet-connected device that lets you watch video from Amazon Instant Video, Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, Crackle or a few other outlets and play games with or without a controller, which is sold separately.

headline: Sun Pharmaceuticals of India to Buy Ranbaxy, a Smaller Rival
text: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, the Indian drug maker, said on Sunday that it would pay about $4 billion in stock for Ranbaxy Laboratories, a smaller Indian rival.

headline: Abusive and Frivolous Patent Suits
text: Abusive and frivolous lawsuits brought by holders of patents are costing the American economy billions of dollars. Fortunately, Congress is on the case. A large bipartisan majority in the House approved a bill last year that would reduce such litigation; the Senate, where a similar bill is being negotiated, may soon follow.

headline: Business Titans Too Rich to Bribe Seek to Ease Fears in East Ukraine
text: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — Two months ago, Hennadiy Korban, a millionaire businessman, fled to Israel to escape retribution for siding with opponents of Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. After Mr. Yanukovych’s ouster, he flew home in triumph aboard a private plane to begin a new life — as a harried civil servant.

headline: U.S. Tries Candor to Assure China on Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON — In the months before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s arrival in Beijing on Monday, the Obama administration quietly held an extraordinary briefing for the Chinese military leadership on a subject officials have rarely discussed in public: the Pentagon’s emerging doctrine for defending against cyberattacks against the United States — and for using its cybertechnology against adversaries, including the Chinese.

headline: Behavior Detection Isn’t Paying Off
text: A multiyear experiment in behavior detection is only worsening the Transportation Security Administration’s reputation for wastefulness. Since 2007, the T.S.A. has trained officers to identify high-risk passengers on the basis of mostly nonverbal signs, like fidgeting or sweating, which may indicate stress or fear. The total price tag: nearly $1 billion.

headline: The Mentally Ill, Behind Bars
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new correction commissioner, Joseph Ponte, have inherited a city jail system in which nearly 40 percent of the 12,000 inmates have mental illnesses — up from about a quarter just seven years ago. Yet despite the stark shift, the system has not been redesigned to serve the complex needs of inmates with mental illnesses.

headline: What It Means if the Death Penalty Is Dying
text: As executions become concentrated in fewer and fewer states and racial disparities continue, does the application of capital punishment make it unconstitutionally cruel and unusual?

headline: Even Missing Star, Irish Are Unstoppable
text: NASHVILLE — That other undefeated women’s college basketball team, the one apparently without the luck of the Irish, nonetheless steamrollered its way to the national championship game on Sunday night.

headline: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
text: With the Obama administration deporting illegal immigrants at a record pace, the president has said the government is going after “criminals, gang bangers, people who are hurting the community, not after students, not after folks who are here just because they’re trying to figure out how to feed their families.”

headline: Early Tallies Indicating Afghan Vote a Success
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After enduring months of Taliban attacks and days of security clampdowns, Afghans reveled Sunday in the apparent success of the weekend’s presidential election, as officials offered the first solid indications that the vote had far exceeded expectations.

headline: With a Holler, Homers Make N.C.A.A. Broadcasts Fun
text: Was that a devilish cackle from Rex Chapman when Aaron Harrison sank the 3-pointer that lifted Kentucky over Wisconsin on Saturday? Or was it the laugh of an announcer hired to be an unrepentant homer?

headline: France Curtails Role at Genocide Services After Rwanda Leader Casts Blame
text: PARIS — Stung by critical remarks from Rwanda’s president that laid some of the blame for that country’s 1994 genocide at the door of France, the French government has scaled back its planned participation in the 20th anniversary commemoration of the massacres.

headline: Glaxo Starts Investigating Possible Iraq Misconduct
text: The British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline said on Sunday that it was investigating claims of improper conduct related to its business in Iraq, less than a year after China accused Glaxo of engaging in a bribery scheme aimed at increasing drug sales there.

headline: Comptroller to Opt Out of Public Financing System
text: ALBANY — Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, is the first to admit that what he plans to do is hypocritical.

headline: Calipari Credits a Mysterious ‘Tweak’ With Turning Kentucky’s Season Around
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Kentucky Coach John Calipari was sitting at home one night in early March when an idea popped in his mind.

headline: A Star Candidate’s Support for Secession Undercuts Quebec’s Governing Party
text: BUCKINGHAM, Quebec — With his media holdings and celebrity, Pierre Karl Péladeau is a combination of Rupert Murdoch and Silvio Berlusconi, so his decision to run as a candidate in Quebec’s legislative elections has drastically altered the campaign. But the commotion he has caused was not what his party, the Parti Québécois, had hoped for when it introduced Mr. Péladeau as its star candidate last month.

headline: Costa Rica Set for Lopsided Victory
text: MEXICO CITY — With his opponent in the race for president of Costa Rica on the sidelines, a history professor seemed poised to win a lopsided victory on Sunday.

headline: Toughened by Hardship, Day Is Relishing His Challenges
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — The two-story grand foyer in the 5,462-square-foot home opened to a formal living room with toys strewn on its tile floor. The golfer Jason Day, bathed in sunlight streaming in from the French doors, was talking about rooting through a junkyard for his own toys, including his first club, as a child. He had to raise his voice at times to be heard above the thwacking sound made by his 22-month-old son, Dash, who was hitting a giant plastic golf ball across the room.

headline: Cities Advance Their Fight Against Rising Inequality

headline: Surge of Violence Across Syria Kills Over Two Dozen
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence flared across Syria on Sunday, as an explosion killed more than two dozen antigovernment fighters in the central city of Homs and shells struck areas of Damascus, the capital, killing at least two people. On Saturday, a man died after a riot broke out in the crowded Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan.

headline: Arts Prize to Betye Saar
text: The assemblage artist Betye Saar, above, will receive the 55th annual Edward MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement in the arts, which is given by the MacDowell Colony, an artists’ retreat in New Hampshire. The honor is to be presented to Ms. Saar, 87, by the author Michael Chabon and others at a ceremony on Aug. 10 in Peterborough, N.H. In a statement, Mr. Chabon praised Ms. Saar’s work for building “scale models of a world that is intensely personal and yet instantly, inescapably recognizable as our own broken world.” Previous winners include Robert Frost, I. M. Pei, Georgia O’Keeffe and Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Plugging Away at Living, Come What May
text: Plays as funny and moving, as wonderful and weird as “The Realistic Joneses,” by Will Eno, do not appear often on Broadway. Or ever, really. You’re as likely to see a tumbleweed lolloping across 42nd Street as you are to see something as daring as Mr. Eno’s meditation on the confounding business of being alive (or not) sprouting where only repurposed movies, plays by dead people and blaring musicals tend to thrive.

Not the shot, really, so much as Wisconsin’s defense on the play.

headline: The Hour of the Chronograph Watch
text: At last week’s Baselworld watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, the chronograph — an elaborate stopwatch of sorts, popular in aviation and sporting events — proved it’s here to stay. But unlike the crop we spotted at Geneva’s Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair earlier this year, this new set consistently favors a more classic aesthetic. With pared-down dials, uncomplicated indices and timeless rose gold or stainless-steel cases, these 10 vintage-inspired chronographs are functional for any racing event and handsome enough for more formal affairs.

headline: Colleges Increasing Spending on Sports Faster Than on Academics, Report Finds

headline: Thomas Polgar, C.I.A. Officer, Dies at 91; Helped Lead U.S. Evacuation of Saigon
text: Saigon was falling and the United States was fleeing, desperately evacuating the last of its embassy staff and C.I.A. officers in the final, chaotic hours of April 1975. With the airport under siege by the North Vietnamese, helicopters landed on rooftops to ferry away Americans and some South Vietnamese.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 9 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: WOMEN OF SOUL Tessanne Chin, Melissa Etheridge, Aretha Franklin, Ariana Grande, Patti LaBelle (above), Janelle Monáe and Jill Scott pay homage to the “foremothers” of music in this concert taped last month in the East Room and hosted by President Obama and his wife, Michelle. In “Brothers Hypnotic” (2014), presented by “Independent Lens” at 10, the director Reuben Atlas trails the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, founded by the Chicago jazz trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran. The ensemble grapples with Mr. Cohran’s ideals of black consciousness while performing on New York streets, at Lincoln Center and in recording studios. “The fearless streak displayed by the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble deserves its equivalent in a bolder movie technique,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Atlas delivers a rousing finale with a shiver-inducing studio session involving father and sons that’s at once a glimpse at deeply felt family dynamics and a moving bridge across generations.”

headline: Hunt for Malaysian Jet Tests Technical Limits
text: HONG KONG — The metronomic pings that may signal the flight data recorders from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 emanate from stygian depths in the eastern Indian Ocean, 2.8 miles below the waves, where the water pressure is more than three tons per square inch. The bottom is a quarter-mile deeper than even the sandy plain near the Mid-Atlantic Ridge where the black boxes of Air France Flight 447 were found off the coast of Brazil nearly three years ago.

headline: Apologetic and Sobbing, Pistorius Testifies He Killed His Girlfriend by Mistake

headline: Channels of Oligarchic Influence: An Example
text: I’ve been suggesting that inflation paranoia has a lot to do with the interests, or at any rate the perceived interests, of the 0.1 percent; the same goes for other policy arenas. But how does that influence work? Well, there are multiple channels. In some cases we have crude buying of influence through the promise of campaign contributions or the threat of backing someone else — hence the pilgrimage of GOP would-be presidents to Las Vegas to abase themselves before Sheldon Adelson. Some of it involves financing think tanks and media organizations. But an important channel, I believe, is personal: oligarchs quite literally wine and dine people who go along with their views and interests — and when billionaires are doing the wining and dining, well …

Chappelle Adds Radio City Shows
text: After staying away from scheduled performances on New York stages for a decade, the comedian Dave Chappelle announced on March 27 that he would make his return at Radio City Music Hall on June 19. By the time tickets went on sale, on Friday, the run had been extended to four shows (though June 22), and on Monday, with only premium tickets remaining (“official platinum seats” for up to $495, compared with the standard top price of $96.30), a fifth show has been added — on June 18. If Mr. Chappelle’s comeback is a test of show business proverbs – “the audience is fickle and will forget you if you’re not out there” versus “absence makes the heart grow fonder” – the absence one appears to be winning.

headline: Document | On a Lark
text: What began as a simple idea — taking portraits of caged birds against blank, colored backdrops — has turned into something of an obsession for the British photographer Luke Stephenson, whose images are compiled in a new self-published book. To access his feathered finds, he tapped into a network of quirky avian fanciers — from a vicar with an affinity for lovebirds to a hipster with an unironic collection of rare breeds — venturing into their homes with his miniature, portable studio. Save for a few dust specks, his images of budgerigars, conures, siskins and, yes, canaries aren’t retouched. He simply chooses complementary backgrounds, letting each subject get comfortable before taking its picture. Stephenson discovered that birds are generally well-behaved subjects. “Humans, on the other hand,” he says, “are a lot less predictable.” “An Incomplete Dictionary of Show Birds”; incompletedictionary.com.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Falls in the Cracks of Criminal Law

headline: Drug Sale Shows Risk in Japan’s M.&A. Adventures

headline: In a Nation of Muslims, Political Islam Is Struggling to Win Votes
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Last September, ultraconservative Islamic groups telegraphed their power, railing against an international beauty contest until the government ordered it to be staged entirely on the Hindu resort island of Bali. In 2012, radical Islamic groups known for their violent tactics and religious conservatives raised enough of a fuss that Lady Gaga canceled a concert here in the Indonesian capital. And hundreds of local governments in recent years have passed rules on morality and dress inspired by Shariah, or Islamic law, and instituted bans on alcohol.

The shot begins with a worker at the dam and pulls out to a wide hovering view of  the expansiveness of the dam.

headline: Raymond Pettibon’s Surf Paintings Ride Into Manhattan
text: Just in time for the winter thaw, the uptown gallery Venus Over Manhattan has opened “Are Your Motives Pure?,” a show of surfer paintings by the artist and cult punk-rock illustrator Raymond Pettibon. The gallerist Adam Lindemann has painstakingly amassed more than 40 greatest hits — from small works embellished with the artist’s usual comic-book-style riffs to bold, monumental paintings — from a rarefied group of collectors all over the world. “Having a Pettibon surfing painting is like having a Richard Prince car hood,” Lindemann says. They’re a slick and sunny slice of American pop culture. But while Pettibon examines the trappings of surf culture in the paintings, the artist — who despite living in Venice Beach, Calif., has never ridden the waves himself — is also dealing with universal truths. These works are about the solitary surfer against the vast ocean, man against nature. “You get a sense that nature is going to swallow him up,” Lindemann notes. “You could see them as disaster paintings.”

headline: Deal for Questcor May Create More Headaches for Acquirer
text: Assets are being given a shine in a $5.6 billion tax arbitrage deal. Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals, a specialty drugs company, is paying a 27 percent premium to buy Questcor Pharmaceuticals, a rival barraged by regulatory inquiries.

The collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have bought the room-size installation for the Broad, their new art museum, for an undisclosed price.

headline: Getting to Know Your Inner Fish

This time of year, just before the first of the Vidalias are pulled from the sandy soil, the green tops farmers call quills cover nearly every field.

headline: Long a Survivor in Syria, a Dutch Priest Is Slain
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Rev. Frans van der Lugt, a Dutch Jesuit priest who became a symbol of suffering and compassion in the war-ravaged Old City district of Homs, Syria, was shot to death Monday morning by a lone gunman, according to members of his order. The killing came amid growing disputes between Syrian insurgents blockaded in the Old City — those who want to accept an amnesty from the government in exchange for laying down their arms, and those who do not.

headline: Annenberg Fund Awards Fellowships to Seven Young Artists
text: The Leonore Annenberg Fellowship Fund for the Performing and Visual Arts, a 10-year program that is now in its seventh year, will award fellowships to seven young artists from diverse backgrounds, including a violinist who grew up in rural Kentucky and has won several important classical music prizes, but also doubles as a bluegrass fiddler, and a dancer with American Ballet Theater who began his career path when, as a 14-year-old in Florida, he auditioned for a performing arts high school on a whim.

headline: Inside the Mind of a Child With Autism
text: Therapists who specialize in autism often use a child’s own interests, toys or obsessions as a way to connect, and sometimes to reward effort and progress on social skills. The more eye contact a child makes, for example, the more play time he or she gets with those precious maps or stuffed animals.

headline: Answers to Tough Questions About Dying
text: Lots of people want to encourage you to have the Conversation with aging family members about their wishes at the end of life, and then to help you document those preferences in an advance directive.

headline: Egg Production
text: All of the immature egg cells (oocytes) a woman will ever produce are stored in the ovaries by the time she is born. The average age that girls begin to menstruate is 12 years old. Each menstrual cycle occurs approximately every 28 days. During each cycle, hormonal messages from the brain cause the ovaries to develop a single mature egg cell for potential fertilization, even as other hormones instruct the uterine lining to thicken in preparation for nourishing the fertilized egg cell.

headline: Artistic Director Named for Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet
text: It has been almost a year since Benoit-Swan Pouffer left the position of artistic director of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, and rumors have swirled about potential candidates for the enviable task of running a well-funded, New York-based operation with an extensive repertory of work by big-name choreographers.

headline: Comcast Shares Are Down, but Time Warner Cable Deal Is Still Safe
text: On Wednesday, lawmakers on Capitol Hill will ask Comcast to defend its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable, a deal that would merge the two largest cable operators in the country. The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to ask Comcast executives tough questions about competition and scrutinize how much choice consumers have when it comes to high-speed Internet.

headline: Greta Gerwig Replaces Maggie Gyllenhaal in ‘The Village Bike’
