headline: Salamanders, Nature’s Climate-Protecting Vacuum Cleaners
text: Small and slippery, these amphibians live humble lives in the forest. But salamanders may play an outsize role in slowing climate change.

headline: A Hungry Butterfly Is a Hurting Butterfly
text: Monarch butterflies that go without food may end up with smaller, paler wings, according to new research in the journal PLOS One. To study the effect of food on growth, researchers deprived monarch larvae of milkweed. They found that two days of food restriction had a small but clear effect on wing size and coloration.

headline: Salamander’s Hefty Role in the Forest
text: If someone asked you to name the top predator in North American forests, you might think of bears, or maybe great horned owls. But here’s another answer to think about: woodland salamanders.

headline: Before the Silk Road, the Grain Road
text: Nomadic shepherds in the high plains of Central Asia used grain imported from China and southwestern Asia more than 5,000 years ago, according to a new study — perhaps to sprinkle over bodies in funeral rituals.

headline: China’s Dominance in Cement Has Little Effect on European Suppliers
text: HONG KONG — In the cement industry, as with so much else in global commerce, China is a dominant force.

headline: Interest in a Property Grows With One Key Addition: An Architecture Prize
text: When he won the Pritzker Prize on March 24, the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban had a very busy day. As the 37th winner of architecture’s biggest prize — the profession’s Nobel — Mr. Ban made all the major papers, had appearances on CNN and NPR, and even sat down with Charlie Rose.

headline: Heroic Figures From the Bible, Writ Large and Sparely
text: Stravinsky could be prickly and selfish, but he also had a generous streak. When the Swiss playwright René Morax, who was looking for a composer to provide incidental music for his “King David,” asked for his opinion of Arthur Honegger, Stravinsky gave a warm recommendation, and Morax and Honegger joined forces.

headline: Minimalist Leather Goods from a Harvard-Trained Architect
text: The accessories designer Albert Chu likes to cite his grandfather — a mathematician who proved the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem in 1944 in just a few well-edited pages — as a formative influence. “After all, why do something in a zillion steps when you can do it in a sentence?” he says. “It may be harder, but to me, the end result is so much more satisfying and beautiful.” The same principle applies to Otaat, Chu’s L.A.-based line of mostly unisex leather bags and wallets. A rigorous thought process — Chu is a Harvard-trained architect and approaches designing bags as he does buildings — results in shapes that are easy, elegant problem-solvers. A sac called the “Ninja Pouch” flips and flops into multiple configurations; rectangular bags have dual handles that allow for horizontal or vertical orientation; softly structured “box” bags function as either. There’s a whiff of playful humor to the designs, underscored by the fact that Chu also sells conical party hats, made with the same premium leather and high-end stitching as the bags. As for the line’s name? It’s an acronym for One Thing at a Time, but it’s hard not to want all of it at once.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 4-6, 2014
text: A federal judge has blocked Florida from enforcing a new law that banned doctors from discussing gun ownership with their patients. U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said the legislation was so vague it violated physicians’ right to free speech.

headline: Colder Can Mean Older
text: Q. Does a lower body temperature mean a longer life?

headline: Crossing Borders With Allure
text: Making new music approachable without pandering has long been of keen interest to the American Composers Orchestra, especially in the eight years that Derek Bermel has been involved — first as a composer in residence, and now as its artistic director. “Border Vanguards,” presented at Zankel Hall on Friday night, showed how this ensemble has become unusually adept at assembling menus of complementary courses, mixing the savory with the sweet in a manner palatable to almost anyone.

headline: The 16th Century’s Line of Fire
text: Bertrand Russell once wrote that mathematics had a “beauty cold and austere.” In this new book, the historian Amir Alexander shows that mathematics can also become entangled in ugliness hot and messy.

headline: For Space Projects, Zero Gravity
text: Opportunity, NASA’s resilient rover, just keeps rolling across Mars even though it landed a decade ago. It has survived mechanical malfunctions, computer glitches, tricky sand traps, ferocious dust storms and long, frigid Martian winters.

headline: ‘If/Then’ Opens Well at the Box Office
text: Idina Menzel’s fans are following her to “If/Then,” the Broadway musical which drew lackluster reviews but earned a healthy $931,268 at the box office in its first full week of post-opening performances.

headline: Puerto Rico Hires Bankruptcy Lawyers
text: Puerto Rico’s fiscal agent has hired another well-known restructuring law firm, raising the specter that the financially troubled island is preparing to revamp its finances.

headline: Lawyers for a Guantánamo Detainee Cite Failing Health in Seeking His Release
text: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for the last former British resident imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a federal judge on Monday to order his release because he has post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments.

headline: Beaujolais, Freed From Clichés
text: Updated | May 5, 2014

headline: Derek Jeter’s Colleagues Figure Prominently in a Victory
text: As the ball flew off Derek Jeter’s bat and into the left-field corner, Brian Roberts and many of his teammates thought they were about to witness another signature Jeter moment. Here was his final home opener, and as the ball zoomed closer to the wall, it appeared Jeter would again put his indelible stamp on Yankee history, just as he had with his famous flip, his dive into the stands, his World Series home runs and his 3,000th hit.

headline: Smallpox and Murder Come to a Sweltering City
text: Emma Donoghue’s new novel is based on a very peculiar historical incident: a murder that took place in San Francisco in 1876 and was never conclusively solved. It does not speak well for Ms. Donoghue’s elaborately fictionalized narrative to say that her no-nonsense factual afterword is a more interesting telling of the story.

headline: Showtime Series Aims to Engage Sleepy Public on Global Warming With Celebrity Guides
text: Early in 2011, two longtime 60 Minutes producers, David Gelber and Joel Bach, met with me to describe their ambitious plan to create a television series on global warming that, they hoped, would break through the enduring public apathy and haze of disinformation surrounding the subject. I wished them luck, while warning that the scale and complexity of the problem would make it hard to be both engaging and accurate.

headline: Bach Is on the Spring Syllabus
text: Juilliard415, the orchestra of the historical performance program at the Juilliard School, has been enjoying quite a spring. Last month, it collaborated with the Choir of Trinity Wall Street in a performance of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion,” conducted by Gary Thor Wedow at Alice Tully Hall, that caught fire and magic.

headline: Bordeaux, Decanted
text: Bordeaux is not the kind of wine most people fall for instantly. It lacks the sweet come-on that can be so seductive initially, but soon grows tiring. Instead, it’s a little austere, a bit reticent, especially when it’s young. But with time, Bordeaux reveals its many wonderful attributes. It’s a wine you learn to love.

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Treating College Athletes Like Employees
text: The head of an institution with a vested interest in maintaining the current college sports business model is unhappy about recent attempts to change it. Who could have predicted such a thing?

headline: Asymmetric Stupidity
text: Ezra Klein’s new venture Vox is up, and so far, so OK — some fairly interesting pieces, and nothing like Nate Silver’s lamentable decision to make a professional concern troll his chief writer on climate. I am troubled by Ezra’s big inauguratory think piece, but that’s because I think the piece raises a genuine intellectual puzzle.

headline: Website Collects Online Information for Road Trips
text: The days of doing battle with folding state maps while driving across the country are fading, but even the latest route-finding technology can be cumbersome. Travel websites, smartphone apps and GPS units are great, but their specificity can lead to a technology pileup as each is put to its particular use.

headline: Studios File New Lawsuit Against Megaupload and Its Founder
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s major film studios on Monday added a new civil lawsuit on copyright infringement to the legal challenges facing the owners of the now-closed entertainment website Megaupload.com.

headline: Reactions
text: PSYCHOLOGY

headline: Email From Steve Jobs Hints at How Apple Ticks
text: .story-body-text strong { color: #444444; font-family: nyt-cheltenham, Georgia, serif;} .DC-note .DC-note-title { display: none !important; }

headline: Few Frills, but Free Wi-Fi
text: Forget the kale in the minibar and a turned-down bed. For many business travelers, a clean, affordable room without all the frills, and in the right location, will do just fine.

headline: Racking Up the Miles, But Still Chasing Elite Status
text: MICHAEL SOMMER and his friend Tom Mayo were on the ski slopes in Park City, Utah, on a sunny morning last Friday, passing a cellphone back and forth while they discussed with me how airline service for loyal fliers is going downhill fast.

headline: Panel Urges Low-Dose Aspirin to Reduce Pre-eclampsia Risk
text: Pregnant women should take low-dose aspirin daily to reduce their chance of developing pre-eclampsia if they are at high risk for the life-threatening disorder, an influential government panel said on Monday.

headline: Gauging the Intelligence of Infants
A Transformed Theater in a Transformed Land
text: MOSCOW — Thirty years ago, during my first trip to Russia, I bought a ticket for the Bolshoi Ballet. Though I paid an excessive amount by 1984 Soviet standards for a restricted-view seat all the way on the side of the sixth, uppermost ring, I didn’t care: I was in the Bolshoi Theater for the first time. It was the world premiere of Yuri Grigorovich’s new production of the three-act ballet “Raymonda” (1898). To see better, I switched to a slightly more central place. To steady myself, I sometimes placed my hand on the ceiling.

headline: Albums From Sohn, Oran Etkin and Pedro Luis Ferrer
text: SOHN

headline: Look for Cancer, and Find It
text: Mammography has become a fighting word in recent years, with some researchers questioning its value and others staunchly defending it.

headline: Highbridge Capital Hires a Trader in London
text: The hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, which recently hired away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen,  has picked off a portfolio manager in London from Claren Road Asset Management, a division of the Carlyle Group.

headline: In Ethiopia, the Children Call Her ‘Grape’
text: I AM the deputy director of the Center for Health Logistics at John Snow Inc., a public health consulting firm. We work in dozens of countries, and manage logistics for the Agency for International Development’s health supply chain. Basically, that means we work with governments to make sure that health products are available across health care systems in each country.

headline: Fearing Punishment for Bad Genes
text: About 700,000 Americans have had their DNA sequenced, in full or in part, and the number is rising rapidly as costs plummet — to $1,000 or less for a full genome, down from more than $1 million less than a decade ago.

headline: The Kills’ Alison Mosshart Reveals Her Artistic Side
text: Alison Mosshart has spent more than a decade pulling rock-star moves as the frontwoman for the blues-punk duo the Kills. But when she’s not onstage, she’s usually making art. Right now, the singer is exhibiting what she calls “an oddball mix of works on paper, canvas and fabric” from the last few years as part of “Push It,” a 21-person group show devoted to female artists, on view at ArtNowNY through April 26. It’s the first time Mosshart has ever shown her art in public, but she doesn’t plan on letting it be her last. She hopes to stage a solo show later this year in her hometown of Nashville, Tenn. — if she can steal enough time from recording the next Kills album in London, that is. Here, she reflects on her art-making and how it relates to her music.

headline: Early Stephen King Novels to Be Reissued in Special Editions
text: Six of Stephen King’s early novels, all originally published by Doubleday between 1974 and 1983, are being given the deluxe treatment by Cemetery Dance Publications, a publisher that specializes in horror and suspense, and has published lavish editions of several of Mr. King’s later books.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Rwanda and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Bosnia, South Africa and Ukraine.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Settles Into Hit Status
text: It’s now official: HBO has its biggest hit since “The Sopranos.”

headline: San Diego Couple Rescued in Ocean Defend Decision to Sail Across Pacific
text: A California couple, rescued from their 36-foot sailboat in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday after their infant daughter became ill, defended their decision to sail into open seas with two young children, as my colleague, Jennifer Medina reported.

headline: Germany Announces Deal on Art Looted by Nazis
text: BERLIN — The German government on Monday announced an agreement with Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a Nazi-era art dealer, that would pave the way for the possible restitution of art wrongfully taken from Jewish owners and held in his private collection for decades.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Prevails in Bahrain Thriller
text: Updated, 1:35 a.m.: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, drivers for the Mercedes Formula One team, waged an often side-by-side duel at Sunday’s event in Bahrain. Hamilton held on for victory by a margin of one second.

headline: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer
text: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil — an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.

headline: A Strad? Violinists Can’t Tell
text: It’s a foregone conclusion in the violin world: The best violins were made 300 years ago by Italian masters like Stradivari and Guarneri del Gesù.

headline: The Road to Hell and Back Is Paved With Surprises
text: WASHINGTON — The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen, whose 75th birthday is being celebrated with a weeklong festival at venues across the Washington area, has built a reputation for writing accessible music. And it is, with orchestration as colorful and bold as a Hawaiian shirt and with a knack for keeping listeners engaged through unexpected twists that might include a violinist singing, an electric guitar lurking near the woodwinds or a brass chorale morphing into a bebop band.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: UConn Beats Kentucky for Title
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Connecticut Huskies had seen this script before, but they decided on a different ending.

headline: Gay Marriage and Corporate America
‘Flash Boys’ Fuels More Calls for a Tax on Trading
text: It’s not every day that you find a fan club for new taxes, especially among economists and legal experts.

headline: Interview With William Rockefeller
text: A transcript of the National Transportation Safety Board’s interview with William Rockefeller, the Metro-North Railroad engineer at the controls last year during a fatal train derailment in the Bronx.

headline: In Performance: Emerson String Quartet
text: The Emerson String Quartet performs an excerpt from Beethoven’s Quartet No. 9 in C (Op. 59, No. 3).

headline: What Fish Teach Us About Us
text: To Neil H. Shubin’s long résumé — paleontologist, molecular biologist, dean and professor of anatomy at the University of Chicago School of Medicine, best-selling author — can now be added “television host.” Dr. Shubin, 53, who helped discover the 375-million-year-old fish called Tiktaalik, hailed as a missing link between sea and land animals, will preside over “Your Inner Fish,” a three-part series on evolution (based on his book of the same title) that makes its debut Wednesday on PBS.

headline: Masiello Will Keep Manhattan Job
text: The Manhattan men’s basketball coach, Steve Masiello, will be allowed to return after he finishes his bachelor’s degree, the university announced Monday.

headline: Medical Factual Report for William Rockefeller
text: A report from the National Transportation Safety Board on the medical history of William Rockefeller, the Metro-North Railroad engineer involved in the fatal train derailment in the Bronx last year.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Army Releases Detailed Account of Base Rampage
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — In a little more than eight minutes, Specialist Ivan. A. Lopez fired at least 35 rounds at his fellow troops at Fort Hood, unleashing panic and bloodshed over two blocks on foot and from inside his vehicle as he killed three unarmed soldiers and wounded 16 others while they were sitting at desks, driving in a car and standing outside buildings, an Army official said Monday.

text: Q. Can the Microsoft Surface tablet run iTunes?

headline: A 45-Second Test Flight
text: A test flight of a consumer aerial drone with a stabilized camera, the DJI Phantom 2 Vision Plus, ends when a moveable object meets an unyielding surface.

headline: Reaction to Jailing of Egypt Activists
text: The brother of the detained activist Ahmed Douma, Mohamed Douma, and a human rights activist spoke out after an Egyptian appeals court upheld the jailing of leaders in the 2011 pro-democracy uprising.

headline: Jimmy Van Bramer Is City Council’s Arts Champion
text: He played drums as a teenager for the St. Joseph’s Brigade, a Catholic fife, drum and bugle corps. He fondly recalls singing along to his mother’s 45s while he and his seven siblings cleaned their childhood home in Astoria, Queens. (“Top of the World,” by the Carpenters was a favorite.)

headline: Court Rejects Appeal by Imprisoned Leaders of Egyptian Revolt
text: CAIRO — The prison sentences of three liberal leaders of the 2011 uprising in Egypt were upheld by an appeals court on Monday as the families of two other detainees — an Egyptian journalist and an American citizen — released an exchange of letters about the hunger strike they were conducting.

headline: Where the Streets Have No Children
text: A chance mention of an Ecuadorean town with no children and a handful of old residents set Santiago Arcos on a mission to document its dwindling life.

headline: Trisha Brown Dance Attains Half of Fund-Raising Goal
text: As the Trisha Brown Dance Company nears the halfway point of a three-year farewell tour, it plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised half of the $5 million that it is seeking to preserve Ms. Brown’s legacy through educational initiatives and occasional performances.

headline: A Troupe, Now 10, Has Its Routines
text: The most unusual thing about New Chamber Ballet is its regularity, its systematic schedule of performances. What other company presents new work with such consistency, and under such consistent circumstances?

headline: After EMI Debacle, Guy Hands Finds Solace in Gardening
text: Guy Hands tried to make money from the likes of Katy Perry and Coldplay when he bought the music giant EMI in 2007. But he has had much more success selling resin garden animals and bedroom slippers to retirees in garden centers across Britain.

headline: Rein In Shady Tax Preparers
text: WHEN you hear the words “tax preparer,” you may imagine a calculator-clutching accountant, carefully scrutinizing receipts beneath a green eyeshade. But the reality is that in most states nearly anyone can be a tax preparer. There’s no test to pass or code of ethics to follow. Walk around a low-income community and you’ll notice that check cashers, payday lenders, pawnbrokers and even furniture retailers offer tax-preparation services.

headline: Billboard Names Tony Gervino as Editor
text: Billboard, the music industry’s premier trade publication for more than a century, named Tony Gervino as its editor on Monday, the latest in a series of changes to remake the magazine in a more general-interest direction.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: A poll by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College consisted of telephone interviews with 1,190 adult residents throughout New York City from March 29 to April 3.

headline: Are Court Stenographers Necessary?
text: After a New York court reporter left behind an incomplete record, some are asking whether it still makes sense to use stenographers in legal proceedings.

headline: Mixed Marks for the Mayor’s First 100 Days
text: The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College asked New York City residents to assess Mayor Bill de Blasio and how he has been dealing with issues that range from education to unemployment.

headline: 49 Percent of New Yorkers Approve of de Blasio’s Performance, Poll Says
text: Nearly half of New Yorkers approve of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s job performance so far in City Hall, and his high-profile effort to provide free prekindergarten has attracted wide support, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/NY1/Siena College Poll
text: Forty-nine percent of New Yorkers approved of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s job performance, according to the poll.

headline: Video Notebook: Brian McCann
text: The Yankees’ new catcher talked about his first home game with the team and being a part of Derek Jeter’s final opening day at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Country Music Awards Nod to Young and Old
text: The 49th annual Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday night split the difference between young and old: The show opened with a splashy, poppy performance by the Band Perry, and the 25-year-old Kacey Musgraves, left, won the album of the year award for “Same Trailer Different Park.” But some of the biggest shows of respect went to veterans like Merle Haggard, Garth Brooks and, especially, George Strait, who won for entertainer of the year, the top prize. The three-hour show, broadcast by CBS from two casinos in Las Vegas, also rewarded Miranda Lambert with single of the year, for “Mama’s Broken Heart,” and best female vocalist. Jason Aldean was male vocalist of the year; Florida Georgia Line took home best vocal duo; and the Band Perry was best vocal group. Jessi Alexander, Connie Harrington and Jimmy Yeary, the songwriters behind Lee Brice’s hit “I Drive Your Truck,” won song of the year, and Justin Moore was named new artist of the year.

headline: The Water Cooler Runs Dry
text: If you’re closing in on 50 but want to feel much, much older, teach a college course. I’m doing that now, at 49, and hardly a class goes by when I don’t make an allusion that prompts my students to stare at me as if I just dropped in from the Paleozoic era.

headline: What Suffering Does
text: Over the past few weeks, I’ve found myself in a bunch of conversations in which the unspoken assumption was that the main goal of life is to maximize happiness. That’s normal. When people plan for the future, they often talk about all the good times and good experiences they hope to have. We live in a culture awash in talk about happiness. In one three-month period last year, more than 1,000 books were released on Amazon on that subject.

headline: Equity Fund Buys Maker of Matzos
text: This year, Passover will be brought to you by private equity.

headline: Polio Spreads From Syria to Iraq, Causing Worries
text: Syria’s polio outbreak has now officially spread to Iraq, the first neighbor of the war-ravaged country to be hit by the crippling virus despite an ambitious Middle East inoculation effort, and global health officials warned Monday that dozens of vulnerable Iraqi children could potentially be infected.

headline: Student Deaths, One After the Other, Unsettle a Close-Knit Campus
text: WASHINGTON — Three deaths at a single dormitory this semester, two of them last week, have shaken the campus of George Washington University. The first death has been confirmed as a suicide. One last week is thought to have been a suicide, while the cause of the other is still unknown.

headline: Dangerous ‘Game’ for a Writer
text: In “The Writing Life,” Annie Dillard points out that “[a writer] is careful of what he reads, for that is what he will write.” I’ve encountered versions of this adage — along with the more extreme, don’t read anything while writing, lest you contaminate your voice — from a variety of sources and have often wondered how it could possibly be true. After all, I’ve spent my share of time with Dostoyevsky and Camus and I’m still waiting. Such admonishment always struck me as one more of those superstitions writers cultivate for the sake of it, like never discussing a work in progress or stopping only when you know what happens next.

headline: Sweep of Heat by Nets Would Be Striking, if Not Substantive
text: MIAMI — No team has beaten the Miami Heat four times during a single regular season since LeBron James arrived in 2010. The Nets have a chance to do just that on Tuesday night.

headline: Prisoner in Israel Is Linked to Talks
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — He is the single most popular Palestinian politician, and he is serving five consecutive life sentences plus 40 years in an Israeli prison for crimes including murder. He is an ardent supporter of both the two-state solution and what Palestinians call the resistance against Israeli occupation. He is considered the top contender to become the next Palestinian president, and perhaps the only figure who can reunite the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

headline: Operatic Drama Swells in Labor Talks at the Met
text: Labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera has been known to reverberate from the opera house to the White House. President John F. Kennedy helped salvage the 1961 opera season by asking his labor secretary to intervene in negotiations. President Jimmy Carter sent telegrams urging management and labor to keep talking in 1980, but a long lockout still truncated the season.

headline: Ten Cents a Bag? That’s About Right
text: There’s something ridiculous about the life of a two-handled plastic shopping bag. The 20 minutes it spends cradling your groceries home is bracketed by two vast gulfs of time. First, thousands of years beneath the earth, in a natural-gas deposit, and then, after its conversion to a disposable polyethylene product, a second eternity as all-but-indestructible trash.

headline: As Kayla McBride Boldly Goes, Notre Dame Follows Suit
text: NASHVILLE — It was not her numbers in the box score, though they were impressive enough. It was the look on Kayla McBride’s face, adamant, fearless, that described how thoroughly Notre Dame dominated Maryland, 87-61, on Sunday in the semifinals of the women’s Final Four.

headline: Afghanistan’s Vote
text: That an estimated 60 percent of 12 million eligible voters in Afghanistan faced down Taliban threats and cast ballots in Saturday’s presidential election is good news, suggesting civic resilience, a certain faith in democratic processes and a maturing political system in a war-torn country. It is a further sign that the time has come to end America’s combat role there after 13 years of conflict.

headline: As Obama Spotlights Gender Gap in Wages, His Own Payroll Draws Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday will call attention to what he has said is an “embarrassment” in America: the fact that women make, on average, only 77 cents for every dollar that a man earns.

headline: A Familiar Script in Ukraine
text: The events taking place in Donetsk and elsewhere in eastern Ukraine are very similar to those that led up to the Russian annexation of Crimea. In fact, the pro-Russian secessionists who seized the local administration building in Donetsk, the center of the industrial Donets Basin, are following the script laid down in Crimea to the letter. They have declared the region’s independence from Ukraine and called for a referendum by May 11 on joining Russia.

headline: NBC Expects to Strike Gold in a Late-Night Renaissance Led by Fallon
text: TOP executives of NBCUniversal took a victory lap of sorts on Monday, briefing a roomful of reporters on recent healthy ratings — practically round the clock — for their NBC television network and suggesting they would seek healthy increases in advertising rates when the upfront market for the 2014-15 season begins next month.

headline: G.M.’s Cobalt Crisis
text: The Chevrolet Cobalt is in many ways the perfect representation of the bad, old days of General Motors, when quality didn’t much matter, market share was more important than profitability, and financial decisions came before design and even safety decisions.

headline: Officials on Unrest in Ukraine
text: On Monday, officials from the United States, Russia and Britain discussed the growing unrest and violence in the Ukrainian cities of Donetsk, Kharkiv and Luhansk.

headline: School Funding Deal in Kansas Complicates Governor’s Campaign for Re-election
text: Kansas lawmakers agreed over the weekend to send more money to the state’s poor school districts, addressing a State Supreme Court ruling last month that school financing had to be equalized around the state.

headline: Mickey Rooney’s Quietest Role
text: Forget Andy Hardy. Set aside, for the moment, the rest of his MGM highlight reel, the hoofing and crooning with Judy Garland, in his double-breasted suit with his pomaded hair swooped back, or in Western get-up or (yuck) blackface. Forget, too, the turbulent personal life of the problem gambler who “went through the ladies like a hot knife through fudge,” as Ava Gardner (Wife No. 1 of 8) put it.

headline: Pacers’ Reliable Lineup Shows Signs of Overuse
text: Too much of a good thing can be bad, and the Indiana Pacers have found that their overused starting lineup is wearing down at the worst possible time.

headline: Pressing Obama’s Agenda, Maryland Lawmakers Raise Minimum Wage
text: Maryland embraced President Obama’s call to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour on Monday, the second state to do since Connecticut acted last month.

headline: Concession Offered, Taiwan Group to End Protest of China Trade Pact
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Yang Shih-wei admits he is an unlikely opponent of a trade deal with China. A 27-year-old Taiwanese banker who spent a year working at a trading company in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, he has seen firsthand how quickly Taiwan’s giant neighbor is growing. And he says that if Taiwan wants to compete economically, it cannot shun China.

headline: Tech Firms May Find No-Poaching Pacts Costly
text: It is the talk of the Valley.

headline: John Pinette, 50, Stand-Up Comic and Actor, Dies
text: John Pinette, a stand-up comic whose Falstaffian figure provided him with no shortage of subject matter, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 50.

headline: Iran’s Choice for U.N. Post Denied Entry Into the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted unanimously on Monday night to bar Iran’s newly named ambassador to the United Nations from entering the United States, charging that he was involved in the hostage-taking at the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979.

headline: Charlotte Names New Mayor Amid Scandal
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In a city left reeling after its mayor resigned in a federal corruption sting two weeks ago, the City Council on Monday chose a successor, Daniel G. Clodfelter, a state senator in his eighth term who is a former member of the Council.

headline: Hackers Lurking in Vents and Soda Machines
text: SAN FRANCISCO — They came in through the Chinese takeout menu.

headline: Drivers in New Jersey to Lose Link as Pulaski Skyway Route Closes
text: NEWARK — Here is the view of New Jersey transportation from an eight-acre tow yard on the edge of the city:

headline: U.S. Gas Tantalizes Europe, but It’s Not a Quick Fix
text: HOUSTON — As congressional pressure builds on the Obama administration to quicken gas exports to Europe to reduce its dependence on Russia, it may be tempting to gaze upon a marshy, alligator-infested Louisiana inlet of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Air National Guard on Baby Rescue
text: Maj. Mark Bomann, the flight doctor who treated a sick baby who was rescued from a family boat in the Pacific Ocean, said the 1-year-old girl was in stable condition.

headline: Chuck Stone, a Fiery, Trusted Columnist in Philadelphia, Dies at 89
text: Chuck Stone, whose columns for The Philadelphia Daily News denouncing racism, political corruption and police brutality inspired such trust that wanted criminals sometimes surrendered to him rather than to the police and the authorities called on him to mediate prison crises, died on Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 89.

headline: In Switch, Development Agency Welcomes Business and Technology to Poverty Fight
text: JOHANNESBURG — Civic leaders recently broke ground on a lush cricket field here for the Nelson Mandela Children’s Hospital, a nearly $100 million state-of-the-art pediatric facility that is to provide care for youth throughout Southern Africa. Donations are pouring in, but not enough.

headline: 2 Tots, a Sailboat and a Storm Over Parenting
text: LOS ANGELES — As her family began what was supposed to be a monthslong journey in a 36-foot sailboat from Mexico to New Zealand, Charlotte Kaufman wrote openly of her misgivings about taking her two daughters — ages 1 and 3 — to sail the South Pacific, with her husband as captain and herself as the crew.

headline: ‘Succeed and Proceed,’ to Instant Riches
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Throughout the course of an intriguing N.C.A.A. tournament, John Calipari spoke about the transformation that took his team of freshmen from midseason mediocrity to the N.C.A.A. championship game, where it lost to a veteran Connecticut team. But the most compelling change was how Calipari has transformed his pregame and postgame interview sessions into small revivals and prayer meetings, promoting and preaching the gospel of Kentucky basketball, defending and explaining a recruiting system praised and vilified as “one and done.”

headline: Wish for Change Animates Voters in India Election
text: NEW DELHI — Over the last several years, as the yearning for a strong leader began to deepen and swell in the Indian electorate, one politician was systematically preparing himself to be the answer to that demand.

headline: Two World War II Veterans Honor 19 Soldiers Who Disappeared 70 Years Ago
text: EAST FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — On Monday morning, two World War II veterans held bouquets of roses and boarded an old warplane at Republic Airport here. Both men — Frank Kittle, 90, and Jack McMullen, 91 — narrowly escaped death while serving on such planes over Europe during the war.

headline: Dogs and Scoundrels, Well Dressed
text: An English bulldog plays a minor role in the new production of “The Threepenny Opera” that opened at the Atlantic Theater Company on Monday. Romeo is his name, and he acts very naughty in the tableau that opens the show, slobbering away at the leg of a streetwalker who’s passed out flat on the ground. Still, Romeo is as cute as can be and looks as if he wouldn’t have a mean bite, even if, say, you slapped a tiara on his head and asked him to do his best impression of Queen Victoria.

headline: That’s Enough!
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We started off the week with a terrific debut by Douglas Taillon, and we continue the fun with a really nice puzzle by Ian Livengood. This one was another one that felt like it was over too soon.

headline: Sharpton Is Linked to Spying on the Mafia
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton was an F.B.I. informer who had extensive dealings with Mafia figures in New York in the 1980s and secretly recorded their conversations using a briefcase modified with hidden electronic equipment, a report said on Monday.

headline: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work

headline: Somalia: 2 U.N. Advisers Slain
text: A security guard in Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region shot to death two consultants working for the United Nations shortly after they had landed at the Galkayo airport on Monday, officials said. Nicholas Kay, the United Nations’ special representative for Somalia, said the two victims were advising the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. One victim was British and the other was French, The Associated Press reported, citing British and French officials. The president of the Puntland region, Abdiweli Mohamed Ali, confirmed that the gunman was a security guard and said that he had been arrested, along with an accomplice, another guard. Mr. Ali said an investigation was underway.

headline: Sleep Disorder and Schedule Change Cited as Possible Factors in Train Derailment

headline: Canada: Parti Québécois Seen Losing Power in the Province
text: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Québécois on Monday. Based on early returns, four television networks forecast a victory for the Liberal Party. The results are likely to be viewed as a severe rebuke of the movement for Quebec independence. Before the election, the Parti Québécois played down the likelihood that it would seek a third referendum on separation if re-elected. For years, polls have shown that a firm majority of Quebeckers oppose leaving Canada. Yet the party’s attempt to avoid the issue, which was the basis of its founding, fell apart last month when its star candidate, Pierre Karl Péladeau, a media magnate, immediately vowed to make Quebec a nation in a rousing speech that concluded with a raised fist.

headline: Another Injury Shelves David Robertson

He was a freshman on that team, as old as the five players in Kentucky blue joining him Monday for the opening tip-off in the national championship.

headline: A New Twist on the Iconic Maralunga Sofa
text: Cassina’s founder Cesare Cassina and the visionary furniture designer and architect Vico Magistretti crafted an enduring design legacy together, one to which even the most dedicated of couch potatoes are forever indebted. Legend has it that when Cassina first saw Magistretti’s prototype for the now-iconic 1974 Maralunga sofa, he disliked it so much that he punched it — hard. His frustration split the back of the model, which fell back over itself so that it resembled a headrest. This serendipitous series of events eventually resulted in the design for the Maralunga, the first upholstered sofa to incorporate movement — the back transforms into an actual headrest — for ultimate comfort. To mark the 40th anniversary of its bestseller, the company collaborated again with design visionaries to develop a new version of the sofa, this time tapping 20 students from the Swiss art and design school ECAL for the task. Just in time for Milan’s annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the results are on view at the Cassina showroom in the city beginning tomorrow.

headline: The Case of Brendan Eich
text: I’ve written a fair amount about pluralism lately, in the context of debates about what kind of accommodations might be made for religious institutions and communities in a public-policy landscape that’s likely to become increasingly hostile to some of their beliefs. That discussion offers an interesting background to the defenestration of Brendan Eich, briefly the CEO of Mozilla, for his past donation to the ballot initiative that (temporarily) re-established the conjugal/opposite-sex definition of marriage in California. I say “interesting” because while Eich’s ouster has been cited (by some liberals as well as conservatives) as a kind of left-wing escalation in the culture war, there are some ways in which his fate might be reasonably seen as less troubling, to principled pluralists and religious conservatives both, than some of the other cases and controversies currently in the news.

headline: Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam Names New Director
text: The Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, a mecca for modern and contemporary art fans, has named Beatrix Ruf to be its new director, The Art Newspaper reported Tuesday. headline: Dianne Feinstein Accused of ‘Deep Emotional Feeling’
text: If Michael Hayden, the former Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, wanted to say something ridiculous about a member of Congress, he succeeded. During an appearance on “Fox News Sunday,” where Republicans go to trash Democrats without fear of follow-up questions, he said that Senator Dianne Feinstein’s “deep emotional feeling” had tainted the Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the C.I.A.’s abuse of prisoners after the 9/11 attacks.

headline: Maazel Withdraws From Two Carnegie Hall Concerts
text: Lorin Maazel, who was to have led the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra on Friday and Saturday at Carnegie Hall, has withdrawn from the performances because of illness, the hall said. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Friday evening program, and Fabio Luisi will take over on Saturday. The programs Mr. Maazel, 84, was to conduct were both devoted fully to the works of Richard Strauss, and are unchanged.

headline: For Passover, Fried Artichokes
text: ROME — I have always loved artichokes fried in the Jewish style, or carciofi alla giudia, a traditional dish of the Roman Seder. So on a recent trip to Rome, I hunted for them. Every chef I queried had the same answer, delivered with the same slightly weary shrug: “You have to go to the ghetto for that.”

headline: Obama Signs Measures to Help Close Gender Gap in Pay

headline: Among Ukraine’s Jews, the Bigger Worry Is Putin, Not Pogroms
text: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — From his office atop the world’s biggest Jewish community center, Shmuel Kaminezki, the chief rabbi of this eastern Ukrainian city, has followed with dismay Russian claims that Ukraine is now in the hands of neo-Nazi extremists — and has struggled to calm his panicked 85-year-old mother in New York.

headline: Best, Brightest and Rejected: Elite Colleges Turn Away Up to 95%

headline: Imax Selling 20 Percent of Its China Business
text: LOS ANGELES — China Media Capital, a state-run entertainment investment fund that has already done business with Time Warner, DreamWorks Animation and 21st Century Fox, added Imax to its deal portfolio on Tuesday.

headline: The Stars Remain Aligned
text: Jean-Georges is still a four-star restaurant. That is all. Thank you for your time.

headline: Tech-Focused Hedge Fund to Return $2 Billion to Investors
text: As investors nurse steep losses from  technology stocks, one hedge fund has decided to return money to investors and turn its focus to companies not listed on the stock market.

headline: A New Line | Talon’s Boho-Chic, West Coast-Inspired Jewelry Collection
text: The Brooklyn designer Emily Hirsch creates jewelry with a talismanic quality. She began her line Talon in 2009 with glass and metal amulet necklaces that contained vials of blended essential oils that reminded her of her California childhood. Now, she is expanding to a full range of pieces steeped in the feeling of 1970s West Coast Americana, including rings, earrings, cuff bracelets etched with detailed feather and flower motifs and a pendant necklace in opal, carnelian, onyx or Indian garnet, each stone set in recycled silver or gold.

headline: Inquiry Implicating Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Offers Look at a 2012 Race
text: Last week he was holding forth as usual on hot-button topics like Benghazi and big government, and bantering with on-air guests who addressed him by his former title, “Governor.”

headline: New Ferry Service Between Maine and Nova Scotia
text: Beginning May 15, Nova Scotia-bound travelers have a new transit option from Maine: getting there by cruise-ship-style ferry.

headline: Three Legs Good, One Leg Bad
text: The good news for Obamacare just keeps coming in. Via Charles Gaba, the Rand Survey — which was the subject of a report in the LA Times, but which wasn’t publicly available — is now in. And it says that as of mid-March — that is, before the final enrollment surge — the Affordable Care Act had already produced a net gain of 9.3 million insured adults. Again, that’s a net gain; so much for claims that more people are losing insurance than gaining it.

headline: Banks Ordered to Add Capital to Limit Risks
text: Updated, 9:08 p.m. | Federal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis.

headline: Comcast Gives a Nod to a Future Apple Set-Top Box
text: Inside a document published by Comcast on Tuesday, the company gives a nod to a future Apple set-top box, even though Apple hasn’t introduced one yet.

headline: Share Your Favorite Travel Ritual in Europe
text: We invite you to send us photos of a place in Europe you’ve visited repeatedly that is meaningful to you.

headline: Germany Moves Forward on Renewable Energy Plan
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government approved legislation on Tuesday revamping Germany’s sweeping plan to generate more than 40 percent of its energy needs through renewable resources by 2025 by slowing the rapid expansion of solar and wind parks in an effort to hold down spiraling prices.

headline: Man Wrongfully Convicted in 1989 Brooklyn Murder Is Set Free
text: A timeworn phone bill from a Quality Inn in Orlando, Fla., turned out to be one of the most valuable pieces of paper Jonathan Fleming owns.

headline: Astier de Villatte’s Collaboration with a Countess
text: Ivan Pericoli and Benoit Astier de Villatte of Astier de Villate, known for their scents and ceramic accessories, are presenting two new ceramics collections created in collaboration with the Countess Setsuko Klossowska de Rola, a painter and the widow of Balthus (and the subject of some of his most famous paintings). The first collection is inspired by the architecture of the Grand Châlet of Rossinière, the home Klossowska de Rola shared with Balthus beginning in the the ’70s and where she still lives today. The second includes playful ceramics modelled by the countess herself, including a candlestick tree and an incense burner in the form of a cat.

headline: Bomb on Train in Pakistan Kills 14
text: LONDON — A bomb ripped through a stationary train in western Pakistan on Tuesday, killing 14 passengers and wounding at least 40, half of them seriously, in a new escalation of the long-running conflict in Baluchistan Province.

headline: Trying to Make a Character Move as Easily as You Do
text: Motion-controlled gaming has never worked as well as advertised.

headline: Family Disaster Preparedness
text: Eighty percent of the population would not survive the first 100 days of the apocalypse, Bob Gaskin, who served in the Marines and is the founder of the Black Dog Survival School, told an assembled crowd at the Third Annual National Preppers and Surivalist Expo in Tulsa, Okla. “If you don’t know now what you’re going to do then,” he said, “you aren’t going to make it.”

headline: Captain and Design Faulted in East River Ferry Crash
text: WASHINGTON — A ferry crash on the East River that injured 80 people last year was caused by captain’s error and a poor design on the ferry’s high-tech bridge, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

headline: Westerleigh, S.I., Built on Temperance
text: Followers of the temperance movement late in the 19th century created a place called National Prohibition Park, where they could escape the stresses and bad influences of the city. The community, on Staten Island’s North Shore, is now known as Westerleigh.

headline: In San Francisco, Staying True to an Area’s Roots
text: The newly coined Mission Creek neighborhood in San Francisco’s northeast Mission District has long been home to light industrial manufacturing. But lately Mission Creek has become a creative hub for local goods, and unlike in many fast-changing areas of the city, the new arrivals here have so far stayed true to the area’s roots: It’s a place where people make things.

headline: The Kentucky Derby as a ‘Rite of Passage’
text: Native Dancer, the thoroughbred that won race after race in the 1950s, was unlike the stocky draft horses Carl Myers knew as a boy growing up in Amish country in Lancaster County, Pa. The colt was lean and elegant and, with its gray coat, stood out among the other thoroughbreds on his family’s black-and-white television set.

text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Burnt Ends in Singapore
text: New restaurants are a dime a dozen in Singapore, but novel concepts are still a rarity — which probably explains why Burnt Ends, a gourmet barbecue joint, has been packed since it debuted last May.

headline: Improving the User Experience of Automated Integration Testing
text: The New York Times Test Infrastructure Development team has been working on a reporting system with a new front end to present results for our functional test suites. We’ve decided to open source our projects as we continue to work on them.

headline: 30 Seconds With Jim Palmer
text: Jim Palmer, the Hall of Fame pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, grew up a Yankees fan in New York. One of his fondest memories is of his father taking him to his first game at Yankee Stadium in 1954. The Indians were playing the Yankees. He was amazed at how the field glowed.

headline: Jeter’s No. 2 Is No. 1
text: At Monday’s home opener in the Bronx, Deter Jeter shirts were everywhere, welcoming back the Yankee captain as he begins his final season.

headline: A Few Notes to Hear All
text: At the risk of hyperbole, it seemed likely that fewer notes were played during a 110-minute performance of “Peckinpah Trios,” a 2004 piece by the Dutch composer Antoine Beuger, on Saturday night, than might have been contained in a single ringtone on an audience member’s smartphone. No one present could make the comparison the hard way, thanks to the standard cautionary announcement.

headline: Those Fish Fins You Call Hands and Other Evolutionary Quirks
text: The club of scholars named Neil who are good writers and also telegenic is fairly small, with Neil deGrasse Tyson (see “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey”) sometimes seeming to be its only member. But let’s not overlook Neil Shubin, a paleontologist who makes an appealing guide to our evolutionary history on “Your Inner Fish,” a three-part exploration, based on his books, that begins on Wednesday on PBS.

headline: Damien Hirst to Tell His Story
text: The British artist Damien Hirst has signed a deal to publish his autobiography with Viking Penguin, the publisher announced on Tuesday. The autobiography, due out in Britain in fall 2015, will be written with James Fox, who worked with Keith Richards on his 2010 memoir, “Life.” The book is to be published in the United States by Penguin Press, also in fall 2015. (Viking Penguin and Penguin Press are imprints of Penguin Random House.)

headline: Oxygen Shifts Focus to Millennial Viewers
text: In another sign of the growing influence of the millennial generation on Madison Avenue, the Oxygen cable channel will be revamped to appeal to a modern young woman, offering several new series with a multicultural focus.

headline: After ’09 Fraud, Afghanistan Reports a Cleaner Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan presidential election on Saturday appeared to be substantially cleaner than the widely discredited 2009 election, according to complaint figures released Tuesday by the authorities here.

headline: Underwater Search
text: Officials designated an underwater search area around the two locations where they have estimated the missing plane may have entered the water.

headline: A Little Pizza Homework
text: There is pizza dough in my refrigerator right now. I made it last night in about 20 minutes, 15 of which were spent reading a magazine while it rested. I’ll bake it tomorrow night under mozzarella, then put a small arugula salad on top, an homage to the Green and White pizza available at Roberta’s in Brooklyn.

headline: Obama Pushes Equal Pay for Women
text: Lilly M. Ledbetter, left, watched as President Obama signed two executive measures aimed at increasing transparency about women’s pay.

headline: Unearthing Lost Gems in Career of Lyricist
text: A fantasy that tantalizes many music theater aficionados is the dream of unearthing a lost masterpiece from the trove of shows that flopped on Broadway or were never produced. Tastes change, after all, and work considered too avant-garde back in the day may suddenly be rediscovered and retrospectively deemed “ahead of its time.”

headline: T’s Toast to Salone
text: To kick off Salone Internazionale del Mobile and celebrate T’s spring design issue, which is out this weekend, some of the world’s best-known architects and designers gathered at the Villa Necchi Campiglio last night in Milan. Video art by Derrick Adams set the scene for the fete, where T’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, and the Italian art curator Francesco Bonami hosted a range of design and fashion luminaries: Tom Dixon, Francesco Vezzoli, Daniel Libeskind, Ambra Medda, Joseph Dirand, Laura Sartori Rimini, T’s Tom Delavan and the house of Missoni’s leading ladies, from Rosita and Margherita to Angela and Teresa.

headline: You Can’t Always Get What You Want
text: Numbers suggest that the difference between need-blind and need-aware admissions is fuzzy.

headline: Weakness in Infield Leaves Yankees Vulnerable
text: The Yankees’ infield will undergo a drastic makeover after shortstop Derek Jeter retires at the end of the season. But even now, the four players who take the infield these days for the Yankees are hardly recognizable.

headline: Experts Find a Door Ajar in an Internet Security Method Thought Safe
text: Updated | A flaw has been discovered in one of the Internet’s key security methods, potentially forcing a wide swath of websites to make changes to protect the security of consumers.

headline: Iran’s Choice of Envoy ‘Not Viable,’ U.S. Says
text: The Obama administration intensified its objections on Tuesday to Iran’s nomination for United Nations ambassador, a former translator whose role in the 1979-81 Tehran hostage crisis has touched American political nerves, asserting that the choice was “not viable” in what seemed as close as possible to ruling it out.

headline: An Editorial Cartoon on Native American Mascots Comes to Life in Cleveland
text: Last week, a die-hard fan of the Cleveland Indians named Pedro Rodriguez expressed his love for the baseball club as he has each year for the past decade, by attending the first game of the new season dressed in homage to Chief Wahoo, the club’s Native American mascot, in a feathered headdress with his skin painted bright red.

headline: If the Devil Taps You, Pretend You Didn’t Feel It
text: When Stravinsky wrote “The Soldier’s Tale,” his 1918 dramatic work that combines spoken text with a seven-piece chamber ensemble, he had in mind the touring puppet shows and playing troupes he encountered in the Russia of his youth. Over the years, when “The Soldier’s Tale” has been presented as a staged drama or a ballet, it has often been updated or mythologized. It is probably best known as a concert work, without its spoken text.

headline: The Lives of Animals, Disabled and Otherwise
text: Fans of the PBS series “Nature” are used to having their breath taken away by the photography, but they’re less accustomed to having their heartstrings tugged. Wednesday’s installment, “My Bionic Pet,” about animals with disabilities, goes for the emotions. It’s one of three programs this week that prove that television about nonhuman creatures can be more than mere pretty pictures or idiotic turtle wrangling.

headline: Youth Movements, Glittering if Not Yet Totally Polished
text: Seeing back-to-back programs of the same company can reveal a lot about its dancers. Do they become more or less complex, the more you get to know them? Do you want to keep spending time with these people, or have you had enough?

headline: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
text: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israel’s ambiguities and contrasts.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 65
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

text: Some law school students send the Justice Department résumés and references. At the University of Virginia School of Law, one class is sending document requests and lawsuits.

headline: For Injured Bolshoi Director, a Time to Judge
text: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was partly blinded last year in a brutal acid attack that stunned the dance world, paused for some eye drops then put on his brown-tinted wraparound sunglasses before making his way to the theater.

text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: ARTnews Sold to Private Company
text: Talked-about sales in the art world usually involve a painting or sculpture. On Tuesday, the big item in the shopping basket was ARTnews, which describes itself as the world’s oldest and most widely circulated art magazine. Milton Esterow and Judith Esterow, the owners of the magazine since 1972, said in a statement that they sold the 112-year-old publication to Skate Capital, a private asset management firm owned by a Russian, Sergey Skaterschikov.

headline: Kerry and McCain on Foreign Policy
text: Secretary of State John Kerry and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, exchanged harsh words over the Ukraine crisis and foreign policy on Russia at a Senate hearing.

headline: The Art of Collaboration, in Action
Three’s a Trend | Concrete Sculpture at the SP-Arte fair in São Paulo
text: Last week, São Paulo played host to the 10th annual SP-Arte fair, held in the gargantuan Ciccillo Matarazzo pavilion in Ibirapuera Park, a sinuous structure of concrete, steel and glass designed by Oscar Niemeyer for the 1957 São Paulo Biennial. Perhaps the setting explains the preponderance of minimalist concrete sculpture trotted out by several hometown galleries at this year’s event, which closed on Sunday. At Galeria Jaqueline Martins, São Paulo-based Ana Mazzei’s “Et Nous, Nous Marchons Inconnus” (which translates to “And We, We Walk Unknown”) was a procession of gray geometric forms marching from wall to floor. David Batchelor, a Scotsman, placed a number of cement bricks on plinths at the booth of Galeria Leme, adorning them with shards of broken, colored glass. Meanwhile, at the upstart gallery Emma Thomas, a buffet of drinking glasses (water, Margarita, shot, Champagne) were spread across a table and filled to the brim with cement by the local artist Lucas Simões. Called “Bebado Samba” (or “Drunken Samba”), it’s a punning rejoinder to Brazil’s midcentury “Concrete” and “Neo-Concrete” art movements, which spiraled off into a plurality of aesthetics and “a scene impossible to read as a single movement,” according to the artist. “ The final view can be seen as a party where the drunken conversations happen.”

headline: Weather Channel Returns to DirecTV
text: The Weather Channel will return to DirecTV Wednesday after a nasty three-month dispute, with the cable network getting a small price increase but agreeing to substantial concessions, including an alteration of its daily national programming schedule to accommodate the demands of the satellite service.

headline: Legacy Evolving at a Presidential Library
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — There are few conferences that could have lured President Obama and three former presidents — Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush — as the Civil Rights Summit is doing this week at the LBJ Presidential Library here. This three-day gathering to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, which began on Tuesday, includes Mr. Obama as the keynote speaker on Thursday morning, with the former presidents speaking successively each night. Mr. Carter was to speak Tuesday night; Mr. Bush will conclude the summit on Thursday.

headline: McClatchy to Sell Anchorage Daily News to Alaska Dispatch Publishing
text: Business moguls continue to shake up the world of newspapers, this time to the far north.

headline: Investors’ Appetite for I.P.O.’s Seems to Ebb
text: Companies are rushing to the public markets on Wall Street to sell their shares, and this week is expected to be the busiest for initial public offerings in more than seven years.

headline: Over 50 and Underappreciated
text: Not long ago, the cosmetics industry veteran Andrea Robinson was in her Park Avenue apartment, showing off a newly built home office with white walls and a monochrome animal print rug. The sparse aesthetic contrasted with the lush textiles of the living room, where a fire was roaring.

headline: In Women’s Game, It’s Not Just Basketball, It’s Family
text: NASHVILLE — Until Connecticut left no doubt in its superiority in an unprecedented championship showdown of unbeaten teams with Notre Dame on Tuesday night, the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament was almost a rumor compared with its all-consuming men’s counterpart.

headline: Official’s Remarks Attacking S.E.C.’s Timidness Cause Stir
text: A textbook retirement speech blends beloved anecdotes with tired clichés. James Kidney, a trial lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission who recently departed the agency, offered a different style: an airing of grievances.

headline: Powerful, Disruptive Shareholders
text: THE season is starting for annual meetings, when shareholders have the chance to attend gatherings of companies in which they own stock to tell chief executives what’s on their mind.

headline: HBO Signs ‘Game of Thrones’ to Two More Seasons
text: A day after receiving news that “Game of Thrones” had shattered its previous ratings records, HBO announced that it had ordered two more seasons of the program, a fantasy drama.

headline: Global Warming Scare Tactics
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — IF you were looking for ways to increase public skepticism about global warming, you could hardly do better than the forthcoming nine-part series on climate change and natural disasters, starting this Sunday on Showtime. A trailer for “Years of Living Dangerously” is terrifying, replete with images of melting glaciers, raging wildfires and rampaging floods. “I don’t think scary is the right word,” intones one voice. “Dangerous, definitely.”

headline: Magazines Coordinate Their Content in Version of TV’s Crossover Episodes
text: Crossover episodes of television series are a popular method to stimulate ratings, as viewers are encouraged to watch cast members from one show turn up on another. Crossovers date to the early days of the medium and there was one as recently as March 26, when cast members from two TV Land series, “Hot in Cleveland” and “The Soul Man,” exchanged appearances on each other’s programs.

headline: European Court Rejects Data Retention Rules, Citing Privacy
text: BRUSSELS — A top court on Tuesday struck down a European Union law, adopted in response to deadly terrorist attacks, that required telecommunications companies to retain information about calls and emails for up to two years.

headline: A Cappuccino for Public Safety
text: In New York, many things are referred to as jokes. The Van Wyck “Expressway,” for example, a coarsely paved road that has been under repair for as long as anyone can remember, is a joke. Compared with those of other world capitals, our mass transit system is a joke. And every now and then we’re reminded that underground is a bewildering mess of pipes, wires and fibers, the stuff that keeps the whole semi-anarchic mess running. That’s a joke, too, one that The Times called “a glaring example of America’s crumbling infrastructure.”

headline: Search for Malaysian Jet to Be Costliest in History
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — As the intensive hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 entered its second month on Tuesday, the only certainty was that it would become the most expensive search and recovery effort in aviation history, with an international fleet of ships and planes scouring the Indian Ocean at a cost of millions of dollars a day.

headline: At Fort Hood, Wrestling With Label of Terrorism
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — In the hours and days after a deadly shooting at Fort Hood last week, Army officials have not shied away from talking about terrorism — to contrast it with the 2009 attack and to ease fears about the motive behind the second mass shooting on the base in nearly five years.

headline: Playing Hockey With Putin
text: Shortly before the Sochi Olympics, Russian President Vladimir Putin played in an exhibition hockey game there. In retrospect, he was clearly warming up for his takeover of Crimea. Putin doesn’t strike me as a chess player, in geopolitical terms. He prefers hockey, without a referee, so elbowing, tripping and cross-checking are all permitted. Never go to a hockey game with Putin and expect to play by the rules of touch football. The struggle over Ukraine is a hockey game, with no referee. If we’re going to play — we, the Europeans and the pro-Western Ukrainians need to be serious. If we’re not, we need to tell the Ukrainians now: Cut the best deal with Putin that you can.

headline: Details of Sharpton’s Time as Informer Shed Light on a Life With Many Chapters
text: It was the early 1980s, and the Rev. Al Sharpton was seeking a foothold in the music business. He called news conferences and said he would schedule demonstrations and boycotts if black promoters were not given a role in Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” tour.

headline: U.S. Fines General Motors $28,000 for Not Cooperating With Ignition Flaw Inquiry
text: Federal safety regulators fined General Motors $28,000 on Tuesday, saying it had not provided much of the information requested for an investigation into a recall of about 2.6 million cars with an ignition switch defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Keeping Track: Unemployment Insurance and a Financial Tax
text: Jobless Benefits, Withheld

headline: In Montana, Cutthroat Trout Are Hungry Trout
text: WEST GLACIER, Mont. — When “A River Runs Through It” was released 21 years ago, moviegoers who had never seen a fly rod descended upon tackle shops. Once outfitted, they made a beeline to Montana for a chance to cast to oversize brown and rainbows like those Brad Pitt seemed to land on every other cast. Those anglers probably did not realize that like themselves, the browns and rainbows were relatively recent arrivals, shouldering into the historical domain of Montana’s state fish.

headline: Closing Ports to Stolen Fish
text: The oceans are vast and humans are small — as the monthlong hunt for a vanished Malaysian jetliner demonstrates. Think of the challenge, then, for law enforcement and fisheries managers in going after fleets of shady boats that engage in illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. These criminals ply the seas and sell their catches with impunity, making off with an estimated 11 million to 26 million metric tons of stolen fish each year, a worldwide haul worth about $10 billion to $23.5 billion. Many use banned gear like floating gillnets, miles long, that indiscriminately slaughter countless unwanted fish along with seabirds, marine mammals, turtles and other creatures.

headline: Illinois Moves to Ease Chicago Pension Woes
text: CHICAGO — The Illinois legislature on Tuesday approved a plan to start easing Chicago’s crippling pension problems by requiring some city workers to pay more for their retirement benefits and by granting smaller increases in those benefits.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Drops the Ball
text: Less than two months ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced a plan to provide public financing for basic college-education programs in state prisons — a tried and true way to reduce recidivism at a fraction of the cost of keeping people behind bars.

headline: Number of Mothers in U.S. Who Stay at Home Rises
text: BOSTON — Likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics, the number of stay-at-home mothers in the United States has risen since 2000 after decades of decline, a report released Tuesday by the Pew Research Center shows.

headline: After Rwanda’s Genocide
text: On Monday, Rwanda commemorated the victims of a genocide unleashed 20 years ago by Hutu extremists in power then. More than 800,000 people, mostly Tutsi men, women and children, were systematically hunted down and brutally murdered over a period of just 100 days. The world stood by and let the blood bath happen.

headline: Democrats Use Pay Issue in Bid for Women’s Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats, trying to recast the midterm election focus away from health care, are reaching out to the constituency that has delivered them the last two presidential elections, the Virginia governor’s race and a bevy of close Senate contests: women.

headline: Arthur Smith, Musician Who Wrote ‘Dueling Banjos,’ Dies at 93

headline: China’s Embrace of Foreign Cars
text: CHONGQING, China — For more than a decade, Chinese automakers have been talking about starting large-scale exports to North America and Europe, prompting periodic worries in the West that companies like General Motors, Ford and Volkswagen might be crippled by Chinese competition the way they were by Japanese imports a generation ago.

text: BOSTON — Zeituni Onyango, President Obama’s Kenyan-born aunt, who received asylum in the United States in 2010 after years of living illegally in Boston, died on Tuesday in a rehabilitation home here. She was 61.

headline: Redwood Poaching in California
text: At Redwood National and State Parks, thieves have been stealing burls, protrusions on trees that are prized for their intricately patterned wood.

headline: Inspired by Countryman’s Victory, Australians Follow Adam Scott’s Lead to Augusta
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Adam Scott’s shout of “C’mon Aussie” after he drained a long putt that vaulted him into a playoff at the Masters last year echoed a late 1970s cricket jingle that became a country’s rallying cry. Little did Scott know then that his countrymen would treat it as an exhortation.

headline: Poachers Attack Beloved Elders of California, Its Redwoods
text: REDWOOD NATIONAL AND STATE PARKS, Calif. — It was an unlikely crime scene: a steep trail used by bears leading to a still, ancient redwood grove. There, a rare old-growth coast redwood had been brutally hacked about 15 times by poachers, a chain saw massacre that had exposed the tree’s deep red heartwood.

headline: Rounding Up Suspects, Pakistan Charges a Baby
text: LONDON — Pakistan’s troubled criminal judicial system has failed to prosecute several notorious figures living there over the years, including Hafiz Saeed, the militant leader with a $10 million American reward on his head, and Osama bin Laden.

headline: For Phil Mickelson, Emotions Don’t Fade, Even 10 Years and 3 Green Jackets Later
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Ten years ago, no one knew or cared how high Phil Mickelson could jump. Back then, Mickelson was considered the world’s best known golfer without a major championship. How he would react to his first major victory mattered not at all because it might never happen.

headline: For Obama Presidency, Lyndon Johnson Looms Large
text: WASHINGTON — Two days before joining other presidents in Texas to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, President Obama tackled enduring inequality himself on Tuesday, in this case economic disparity based on gender.

headline: Edwin F. Kagin Dies at 73; Battled Religious Displays
text: Edwin F. Kagin, the son of one minister and father of another, who saw religiosity creeping into the public domain and fought against it in a dual role as head lawyer and jester-provocateur for one of the country’s most militant atheist organizations, died on March 28 at his home in Union, Ky. He was 73.

headline: Masters Field Grappling With Void Left by Tiger Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — During Phil Mickelson’s news conference with reporters on Tuesday, Tiger Woods was mentioned indirectly. Mickelson launched into an unsolicited explanation of how Woods’s absence is affecting the 2014 Masters tournament.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s High-Tech Marketing Message
text: If Hillary Rodham Clinton doesn’t run for president, she could always get a job in marketing, particularly around testing messages and evangelizing new technology.

headline: Marine Shoots Fellow Guard at North Carolina Base
text: A guard at a Marine Corps base in North Carolina was in custody Tuesday night after he shot and killed another guard in an isolated incident, officials said.

text: What happened to the I.M.F.?

headline: Parti Québécois Failed to Renew Mandate, Analysts Say
text: OTTAWA — Two obituaries may be written in the  crushing defeat of the Parti Québécois in Monday’s election: for separatism as a political force in Quebec in the foreseeable future, and for the party itself, whose aging leaders were brought down by the very issue on which it was founded.

headline: Ken Forsse, Who Brought a Toy Bear to Life, Dies at 77
text: Talking toys have been around since Edison made a doll that recited nursery rhymes by means of a small hand-cranked phonograph. Now there are dolls that reply emotively to a child, by name.

headline: Gas Prices for Summer Projected to Hold Steady, Reflecting Sufficient Supply
text: HOUSTON — Just a few years ago, American families faced uncertainties when planning their summer vacations, fearing that rising gasoline prices would blow their budgets. Then came the 2008-9 economic downturn, sending fuel prices lower.

headline: Hidden Agendas Laid Bare in a Debate
text: A fight over an arts funding grant causes a kerfuffle the size of Kansas in “The Most Deserving,” a frisky but inconsequential new comedy by Catherine Trieschmann that opened at City Center on Tuesday night under the auspices of the Women’s Project Theater. Kansas is actually where the big set-to takes place, when a meeting of a county arts council turns testy, resulting in a series of events that leaves just about everyone’s feathers permanently ruffled.

headline: Like a Kid on Christmas
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have another debut today, and John E. Bennett poses a question for us: WHAT’S IN THE BOXES?

headline: Coffee and Tea Company to Start Selling Recyclable Single-Serving Pods
text: One concern expressed by consumers considering the adoption of a single-serve hot beverage system is whether the pods that contain coffee or tea can be recycled.

headline: Pre-K Victory Ad With Mayor de Blasio’s Family Aims to Help Him Regain His Footing
text: The commercial begins with a photograph of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s smiling children as toddlers. As a piano plays softly, his wife, Chirlane McCray, appears on the screen, extolling the education initiatives her husband has spearheaded in City Hall.

headline: New York City Settles Lawsuit by Detective Called a ‘Rat’
text: A former Brooklyn police detective who claimed his career was ruined after he was labeled a “rat” by other detectives in his squad will receive a $280,000 settlement from New York City.

headline: Aleksandra Scepanovic
text: Ms. Scepanovic, 44, is a founder and the managing director of the Ideal Properties Group, a brokerage firm based in Brooklyn that focuses on residential and commercial property in the borough. Ms. Scepanovic, a native of Serbia, started the company in 2007 with her partner, Erik Serras.

headline: Red Herrings and Overlooked Clues in Plane Search
text: More than a month after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, searchers pledged to scour the ocean for the plane’s black boxes. But as the batteries powering the data and voice recorders’ sonic beacons fade, so do the chances that the airliner’s wreckage and the 239 bodies of the passengers and crew on board will be found. Several missteps, red herrings and bureaucratic delays have thwarted the search.
