text: RECENT SALE

headline: De Blasio Picks Immigrants to Lead Two City Agencies
text: Jacques Jiha moved to East Flatbush, Brooklyn, from Haiti at age 21 and paid his way through college and graduate school working as a parking lot attendant. Feniosky Peña-Mora moved to Washington Heights at the same age from the Dominican Republic, with a degree in engineering but speaking no English.

headline: Updated Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
text: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has led to a multinational air and sea search across a vast area of the Indian Ocean. Recently, after weeks of debris sightings that turned out to be irrelevant, sounds have been heard that may be coming from the missing plane, but thus far there has been no confirmation. As the search narrows and the international inquiries into the disappearance continue, Matthew L. Wald, a correspondent for The New York Times, answers some basic questions.

headline: As a Hospital Rises, So Do Hopes for a Neighborhood
text: DALLAS — On the edge of downtown Dallas, the sleek, 17-story tower that is the new Parkland Hospital punctuates the pancake-flat Texas landscape like a gleaming exclamation point.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 8, 2014
text: April 8, 2014

headline: UConn Wins Women’s N.C.A.A. Title
text: NASHVILLE — His record ninth N.C.A.A. title secured, Geno Auriemma climbed a ladder Tuesday night, snipped the final strands of the net and pumped it in his fist, literally standing above everyone in women’s basketball.

headline: The Birth of the 13th Amendment
text: The climax of Steven Spielberg’s film “Lincoln” — the passage of the 13th Amendment in the House of Representatives — vividly captures the culmination of a dramatic yearlong legislative battle that mixed skillful behind-the-scenes maneuverings with high-minded constitutional debate, internecine party politics, personal animosities and the polarizing dynamics of a presidential election. Approval in the House on Jan. 31, 1865, trailed the amendment’s passage in the Senate on April 8, 1864, by almost 10 months. Its adoption by 27 states the following December introduced the word “slavery” into the Constitution for the first time.

headline: Drexel Works to Build Up Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — The northward view from John F. Kennedy Boulevard near 30th Street Station here features only a parking lot bordered by a sagging chain-link fence and overshadowed by the rusting trestles of an elevated freight railroad.

headline: Secret Service Employees Reassigned
text: The Secret Service has reassigned several employees in the wake of alcohol-related misbehavior in the Netherlands before President Obama arrived there for meetings last month, an agency spokesman said Tuesday. The spokesman, Ed Donovan, said the reassigned employees were part of the Special Operations Division, which provides emergency response should the president be attacked while traveling. The reassignments were first reported by The Washington Post. Mr. Donovan added, “Policies that would affect the entire work force are currently under review by leadership.” Three agents were sent home from the Netherlands for “disciplinary reasons” in connection with their drinking. One was found passed out in a hallway.

headline: Japan’s Foreign Minister Says Apologies to Wartime Victims Will Be Upheld
text: TOKYO — In one of the clearest signals that Japan is trying to allay fears that it is whitewashing wartime atrocities — and to repair somewhat frayed relations with the United States — the foreign minister said on Tuesday that his government would not try to push revisions of that history.

headline: A Weakening Currency Could Mean Strength For Turkish Exporters
text: ISTANBUL — In a country where the exchange rate is considered a key barometer of economic health, almost nobody is happy about the Turkish lira’s decline in the last year.

headline: Brandeis Cancels Plan to Give Honorary Degree to Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Critic of Islam
text: Facing growing criticism, Brandeis University said Tuesday that it had reversed course and would not award an honorary degree to Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a campaigner for women’s rights and a fierce critic of Islam, who has called the religion “a destructive, nihilistic cult of death.”

headline: Claims of French Complicity in Rwanda’s Genocide Rekindle Mutual Resentment
text: PARIS — Is it possible to commemorate a world tragedy without opening old wounds?

headline: Speaking at Rights Event, Carter Deplores Disparity
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Former President Jimmy Carter on Tuesday targeted the mistreatment of women for the next front in the civil rights movement, calling for a multifaceted attack against abuses from pay discrimination in the workplace to rape on college campuses and global sex-trafficking of women and girls.

headline: The High Cost of Free Speech
text: After the so-called Sheldon primary, when four potential candidates for the Republican presidential nomination went to Las Vegas over the last weekend in March to court the casino owner Sheldon Adelson, it took a heavy dose of audacity on the part of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. to claim on April 2 that “ingratiation and access . . . are not corruption.”

headline: José Mourinho Delivers a Victory for Chelsea in the Champions League
text: LONDON — He returned to Chelsea from Real Madrid last summer declaring himself to be no longer the Special One he had declared himself to be on arrival for his first spell as Chelsea’s manager in 2004.

headline: Muslim Shrine Stands as a Crossroads in Syria’s Unrest
text: SAYEDA ZEINAB, Syria — This cinder-block town near Damascus, once a hub of prayer and commerce open to the world, seems like a tightly guarded military zone.

headline: Government’s Abuses ‘Far Outweigh’ Syrian Rebels’, Rights Chief Says
text: The United Nations human rights chief said Tuesday that abuses by the Syrian government “far outweigh” the atrocities committed by opposition forces, prompting the Syrian envoy to refer to her actions as “lunatic.” The comments of the high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, were likely to fortify French efforts to push the Security Council to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court. Her office, as well as a commission of inquiry, have repeatedly cited rights violations on both sides. “But you cannot compare the two,” she said. “Clearly the actions of the forces of the government far outweigh. The violations, killings, cruelty, persons in detention, disappearances far outweigh, so you cannot compare the situation. It’s the government that’s mostly responsible for the violations.” The Syrian envoy, Bashar al-Jaafari, denounced Ms. Pillay for bias and said she was “acting irresponsibly.”

headline: Russia: Court Upholds Registration Law
text: The Constitutional Court said Tuesday that it had upheld a law requiring nongovernmental organizations that engage in political activity and receive funds from abroad to register as foreign agents. In a decision on Sunday, the court reduced fines associated with the law. Critics of the law, which was passed in 2012 with support from President Vladimir V. Putin, have said it was being used to clamp down on civil society groups, like the election-monitoring organization Golos, that had been critical of the Kremlin. Thousands of organizations have been investigated under the law since its introduction and four have been fined, Russia’s prosecutor general said last year.

headline: Britain: A Moment of Contrition Compounds Problems for a Minister
text: Ordered to repay about $9,600, Culture Secretary Maria Miller had a moment of contrition last week in Parliament, where she made a formal apology after over-claiming her expenses. That it was just a moment — she spoke for 32 seconds — has prompted an avalanche of criticism and a mini-crisis for Prime Minister David Cameron. Five days later, Ms. Miller’s expenses still dominated British newspaper headlines on Tuesday while organizers of an online petition, calling on her to repay more money or quit.

headline: China: Suicide Victim Linked to Official
text: A senior police official linked to the disgraced Communist Party official Bo Xilai hanged himself in a hotel room last week, the state news media reported Monday. The police official, Zhou Yu, whose body was discovered Friday, played a prominent role in the “strike black” campaign under Mr. Bo, the former Chongqing party chief. The campaign was portrayed as a crackdown on organized crime but also targeted lawyers and businesspeople considered to be enemies of Mr. Bo or his allies. Mr. Bo was removed from his post in 2012, convicted on corruption charges and sentenced to life in prison. It is unclear if Mr. Zhou’s suicide was related. The microblog of a district department in the Chongqing police force said Mr. Zhou had diabetes and had recently received a diagnosis of severe liver disease that led to depression.

headline: N.C.A.A. Women’s Title Game
text: Connecticut defeated Notre Dame in the first meeting of unbeatens in the women’s championship.

headline: Venezuela: President and Leaders of the Opposition Agree to Hold Talks
text: President Nicolás Maduro and the leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties agreed on Tuesday to take part in talks that could help defuse tensions that have arisen during two months of anti-government protests. The agreement was brokered by a group of South American foreign ministers meeting in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital, and the talks will be carried out with the participation of the foreign ministers of Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador, along with a representative of the Vatican. It was not clear when the talks would begin, but an opposition leader said the first meeting would occur in public. Venezuela is marked by a bitter political division, and the agreement to talk is a promising shift, although there appears to be little willingness on either side to give ground.

headline: Cuba Project Defended at Senate Hearing
text: The administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, Dr. Rajiv Shah, defended his agency’s social media project in Cuba to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.

headline: At the Milan Furniture Fair, Two British Designers Reinvent Passé Materials
text: At the Salone del Mobile in Milan this week, two of London’s biggest design talents have shacked up with each other to offer side-by-side takes on semi-outdated materials. Occupying one half of the gallery Project B, the furniture designer Max Lamb has lined an entire room — furniture included — in his new twist on terrazzo, the speckled composite material which will remind many Americans of airport flooring, but which for Lamb served as a reference to classic Italian vestibules. While the pattern is currently trending in design and fashion (see Carven’s recent terrazzo-print sweatshirts), Lamb says he’s been experimenting with it since 2011, after his frequent work with stone led him to visit an old-school terrazzo maker in Yorkshire, near where he grew up. He then “went a completely different route,” he says. His version — the first product in a new line of designer architectural surfaces called Dzek, launched by the former Phillips de Pury retail director Brent Dzekciorius — embeds chunks of marble in resin instead of cement, making the material much more durable. And unlike the terrazzo of yore, which was usually poured on-site, it’s pre-cast and sold by the square foot. “It has endless applications,” he says. “It can be used on walls, floors, ceilings. You can even C.N.C.-mill a bathtub out of it.”

headline: Times Minute | College Rejection Boom
text: Acceptance rates at top universities hit a record low. Also on the Minute, President Obama to pay his respects at Fort Hood, and Yankees fans on Jeter’s last season.

headline: As Braves Honor Hank Aaron, Mets Rain on the Parade
text: ATLANTA — It was a long night’s work, which was perhaps why, at the end of each inning, Bartolo Colon took his time walking from the mound to the dugout. He always seems at ease, which makes it appear all the more remarkable when he controls and suppresses an offense the way he did the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night.

headline: The Power of Sebelius
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Are You Programmed to Enjoy Exercise?
text: It’s possible that some of us are born not to run. According to an eye-opening new genetics study of lab rats, published in The Journal of Physiology, the motivation to exercise — or not — may be at least partly inherited.

headline: Study Finds Sicklier Enrollees in Earliest Stage of Health Law
text: People who signed up early for insurance through the new marketplaces were more likely to be prescribed drugs to treat pain, depression and H.I.V. and were less likely to need contraceptives, according to a new study that provides a much-anticipated look at the population that signed up for coverage under the new health care law.

headline: India Election Digest: April 9
text: What you need to know about India’s elections on Wednesday: Parts of Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya and Nagaland go to the polls, while the vote in a fifth northeastern state, Mizoram, was postponed to Friday.

headline: Sliver of Medicare Doctors Get Big Share of Payouts
text: A tiny fraction of the 880,000 doctors and other health care providers who take Medicare accounted for nearly a quarter of the roughly $77 billion paid out to them under the federal program, receiving millions of dollars each in some cases in a single year, according to the most detailed data ever released in Medicare’s nearly 50-year history.

headline: Nets Sweep Heat as Plumlee Blocks James’s Dunk in Final Seconds
text: MIAMI — The laughter and exaggerated shouting began, as if on cue, as soon as reporters encircled the rookie Mason Plumlee inside the visitors’ locker room at American Airlines Arena late Tuesday.

headline: Month Later, Trade Pays Off for the Rangers
text: The combination the Rangers were awaiting for more than a month finally clicked Tuesday. Martin St. Louis assisted on both of Brad Richards’s power-play goals and, for good measure, set up Derek Stepan for an even-strength goal, as the Rangers beat the Carolina Hurricanes, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., Outspoken Marine Corps Leader, Dies at 78
text: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., who as commandant of the Marine Corps was an outspoken opponent of allowing people who are openly gay to serve in the armed forces and joined other military leaders in shaping the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy as a compromise, died on April 2 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 78.

headline: How Much Medicare Pays For Your Doctor’s Care
text: Use the form below to find a doctor or other medical professional among the more than 800,000 health care providers that received payments in 2012 from Medicare Part B, which covers doctor visits, tests and other treatments. Payments may also cover overhead, such as staff salaries and drug costs. In some cases, when doctors work as salaried employees of group practices, the payments that show up under their names go to their institutions.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 2:45 P.M. (Starz) AMOUR (2012) An elderly French couple, portrayed by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, above, find their love tested when she has a stroke and he becomes her caretaker in this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, directed by Michael Haneke. Isabelle Huppert plays their self-centered daughter — like her parents, a musician — whose questions about what she can do to help as her mother becomes increasingly incapacitated ring hollow. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called this film “a masterpiece about life, death and everything in between.” And while some viewers may find the movie cold and even cruel, she added, “there’s another point to be made here, namely that all the violence in ‘Amour’ is crucial to Mr. Haneke’s rigorous, liberatingly unsentimental worldview, one that gazes on death with the same benevolent equanimity as life. All of which is to say: Bring hankies. This is a film that will make you weep not only because life ends but also because it blooms.”

headline: Political Ties of Top Billers for Medicare
text: MIAMI — Two Florida doctors who received the nation’s highest Medicare reimbursements in 2012 are both major contributors to Democratic Party causes, and they have turned to the political system in recent years to defend themselves against suspicions that they may have submitted fraudulent or excessive charges to the federal government.

headline: Deutsche Bank Economist to Join China’s Central Bank
text: HONG KONG — Deutsche Bank’s chief China economist is taking up a new role at China’s central bank.

headline: Early Count in Indonesia Favors Largest Opposition Party
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Out of power for 10 years, Indonesia’s largest opposition party was leading unofficial vote tallies from Wednesday’s national legislative elections, as the country’s focus now quickly turns to a presidential election in July.

headline: Toyota to Recall 6.4 Million Vehicles
text: Weeks after agreeing to pay the largest criminal penalty ever by an automaker for hiding safety defects from the public, Toyota on Wednesday announced a wide-ranging recall of nearly 6.4 million vehicles worldwide for problems with air bags that may not deploy or seats that could move in a crash.

headline: Deadly Blast at Fruit Market Shatters Calm in Pakistan’s Capital
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In the deadliest attack on the Pakistani capital in more than five years, a powerful explosion ripped through a crowded market in Islamabad on Wednesday, killing at least 22 people and suggesting that, after a long stretch of relative calm, the city was back in the firing line of the country’s militants.

headline: Leader Tightens Hold on Power in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, was re-elected as head of his country’s top governing agency as its rubber-stamp Parliament met in Pyongyang on Wednesday to help consolidate his power by filling top leadership posts vacated in recent purges.

headline: British Culture Secretary Quits Amid Uproar Over Expenses
text: LONDON — Politicians rarely like saying sorry, and generally try to put the unpleasant business behind them as quickly as possible. But 32 seconds, it seems, is a bit too quick.

headline: Nigeria’s Seplat Raises $500 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Seplat, an independent Nigerian oil and gas company, said Wednesday that it raised 300.9 million pounds, or about $500 million, in its initial public offering, a dual listing in London and in Nigeria.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Inventive College Courses
text: In “10 Courses With a Twist,” Laura Pappano writes about professors teaching in inventive new ways.

headline: Gasps in Court as Prosecution Prods Pistorius
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — The prosecutor in Oscar Pistorius’s murder trial, Gerrie Nel, had just begun his cross-examination, and he was doing everything he could to goad Mr. Pistorius into losing his composure and his temper.

headline: U.N. Ignores South Sudan Camp Crisis, Charity Says
text: The United Nations peacekeeping operation in South Sudan was severely criticized on Wednesday by Doctors Without Borders, the emergency medical charity, over what it called a shameful indifference to the squalid living conditions of 21,000 displaced people forced to shelter in a flooded portion of a peacekeeping base in the capital, Juba.

headline: A Taste of Spring
text: April is a transitional season, not only for weather but also for cooking. More produce begins to appear at farmers’ markets, and even supermarket asparagus begins to come from places closer than Peru. In most of the country, though, it’s not yet time for hot-weather eating; we still crave more than a light salad.

headline: How to Think Like the Dutch in a Post-Sandy World
text: In December 2012, Shaun Donovan, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was on vacation in Berlin when he decided to detour to the Netherlands. He wanted to get a firsthand sense of the famed Dutch approach to water management. Hurricane Sandy struck six weeks before, and in the aftermath, President Obama asked him to lead a task force, whose objective was not just to rebuild but also to radically rethink the region’s infrastructure in light of climate change.

headline: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
text: Frédéric Brenner has spent his adult life deciphering his own complex identity.

headline: To Whom, or What, Would You Like to Write a Thank-You Note?
text: A much-emailed Times article about the art of the thank-you note suggests that the handwritten note showing gratitude is making a comeback in the era of digital communication.

headline: Race for a Top Job in Europe Hits the Road
text: NIVELLES, Belgium — Jean-Claude Juncker, the former prime minister of Luxembourg who helped steer Europe through its currency crisis, sought to strengthen his bid to become the next president of the European Commission this week by taking to the road in an American-style campaign tour bus.

headline: Graft Inquiry Fells Another Ally of Former Security Chief
text: A former aide to Zhou Yongkang, until recently the head of China’s internal security forces and said to be the subject of a corruption investigation, has been expelled from the ruling Communist Party for accepting “huge” bribes and referred to the criminal justice system for prosecution.

headline: China Waits for an Apology
text: BEIJING — In 1970, when China was in the grip of the Cultural Revolution, Zhang Hongbing, a 16-year-old in Guzhen, a county in Anhui Province, made a fateful decision. During a family debate that year, his mother, Fang Zhongmou, had criticized Mao Zedong for his cult of personality. Her son and his father, believing her views to be counterrevolutionary, decided to inform on her. She was arrested that same day.

headline: New York Today: Cherries Bloom in Brooklyn
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Ebola Virus: A Grim, African Reality
text: There’s nothing like an outbreak of Ebola virus disease to bring a small, struggling African nation to international notice. One week we couldn’t place it on a map; the next week, after Ebola virus disease strikes, we know the body count and the name of the capital and whether its airport has closed.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Vienna Orchestra to Receive $1 Million Birgit Nilsson Prize
text: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra played on many of the most celebrated recordings of the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, including the classic set of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle conducted by Georg Solti that immortalized her Brünnhilde. Citing her “countless musical high points,” the orchestra voted unanimously to make her an honorary member in 1999.

headline: Beijing’s Neighbors Resist Transfer of Its Polluting Industries
text: Beijing’s latest effort to move energy-intensive, polluting businesses out of the Chinese capital has run into resistance from regional governments who are unenthusiastic about taking more industrial castoffs.

headline: How a Start-Up Can Compete With the Big Boys for Talent
text: Everything about running a tech start-up is tough. We know what we’re trying to achieve but don’t know how long it will take or how much it will cost. We do everything on the cheap because precious investor funding is hard to come by. At the same time, we have to compete with the big boys for everything, most critically talent. But we can’t afford big salaries and bonuses, in-house chefs, trips to inspiring conferences in exotic locations, or an office with floors connected by slides. How can we compete?

headline: Authorities Release German Art Trove
text: BERLIN — The private art collection that sparked an international debate  over Germany’s willingness to address restitution claims for Nazi-looted artworks will be returned to Cornelius Gurlitt, German prosecutors said Wednesday. The release will allow a team of international experts to begin a yearlong examination of the works in the collection in order to help determine their provenance.

headline: Once Around the Diamond With Tyler Kepner
text: Tyler Kepner, the national baseball correspondent, travels the country, hunting the sport’s best stories. Tyler gives us a glimpse of life as a baseball columnist, how he works and what he’s keeping an eye on this season. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: An Order for Banks to Hold More Capital
text: “Federal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis,” Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The rule increases to 5 percent, from roughly 3 percent, a threshold called the leverage ratio, which measures the amount of capital that a bank holds against its assets. The rule is scheduled to take effect at the start of 2018.

headline: Questions About Financial Aid?
text: With financial aid award letters in hand, families are struggling to make sense of it all by colleges’ May 1 deadline. To supplement his article “What You Don’t Know About Financial Aid (but Should),” Richard Pérez-Peña, a national correspondent covering higher education for The Times, and Mark Kantrowitz, a nationally recognized expert on financial aid and publisher of Edvisors, answered readers’ questions.

headline: What You Don’t Know About Financial Aid (but Should)

headline: Stagnation Without End, Amen (Wonkish)
text: In 1938 Alvin Hansen, who did more than anyone else to bring Keynesian economics to America, gave a landmark speech to the American Economic Association. (The speech is behind a paywall, but Tim Taylor has a good summary here.) In it, he made the case for “secular stagnation” — a persistently depressed economy. His arguments were pretty good, too: slow population growth and slow technological progress, he argued meant low investment demand — and even very low interest rates wouldn’t be enough to make up for the shortfall.

headline: Police Policy on Fires Is Questioned Amid Grief at Death of a New York Officer
text: From the outside, there were few signs of a serious high-rise fire. No smoke pouring from windows, no commotion outside the Brooklyn apartment building on Sunday as two New York City police officers rushed inside, grabbing an elevator for the 13th floor.

headline: Student Stabs 21 People at a High School Outside Pittsburgh
text: As classes began at a high school in suburban Pittsburgh on Wednesday morning, a 16-year-old student walked through the hallway stabbing and slashing students with two large knives, the authorities said.

headline: The Uphill Climate Challenge in ‘Years of Living Dangerously’
text: Joe Romm, the Center for American Progress climate blogger who’s also one of two chief science advisers for the forthcoming Showtime climate series, “Years of Living Dangerously,” sent a query last night after seeing a Twitter note I posted. My note was about an Op-Ed article in The Times by Michael Shellenberger and Ted Nordhaus of the Breakthrough Institute.

headline: Israel Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ by Kerry’s Remarks on Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — In an unusually pointed rebuke of an ally, Israel said on Wednesday that it was “deeply disappointed” by Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks a day earlier that appeared to lay primary blame on Israel for the crisis in the American-brokered Middle East peace talks.

headline: Question-and-Answer Site Quora Raises $80 Million
