headline: What Did Medicare Pay Your Doctor?
text: A small number of doctors, about 2 percent, accounted for nearly a quarter of Medicare spending in 2012, according to a new analysis by The Times. Just one-quarter of the doctors billing Medicare accounted for three-quarters of its payments that year. Read the full story, and search for your doctor’s billings with our online tool.

headline: Student Survey on Academic Advising
text: Statistics examine students’ experiences with academic advising.

headline: Greece Dives Back Into the Bond Market
text: ATHENS — Europe’s leaders have been preaching austerity for years, arguing that only deep budget cuts will revive the economy and inspire the necessary confidence among investors.

headline: Again, Obama Offers Comfort at Fort Hood After Soldiers Are Killed
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Five years later, President Obama was back Wednesday on the same field in front of the same building on the same Army post in the same state, with some of the same faces again grieving for soldiers killed in an act of senseless violence.

headline: Russia Plotting for Ukrainian Influence, Not Invasion, Analysts Say
text: MOSCOW — The separatist demonstrations again churning through eastern Ukraine have raised fears of a Crimean-style invasion by the 40,000 Russian troops coiled just over the Russian border. But Moscow’s goals are more subtle than that, focused on a long-range strategy of preventing Ukraine from escaping Russia’s economic and military orbit, according to political analysts, Kremlin allies and diplomats interviewed this week.

headline: Rash of Suicides Underlines Maharashtra Farmers’ Discontent
text: DHANORA, India — In this sleepy village in eastern Maharashtra, about 50 miles south of Nagpur, the sense of desperation is palpable. The dirt road that leads to the village passes through desolate fields, where the winter plantings of cotton, soybean and legumes have been ruined by unseasonal rains, harsh winds and an unusual hailstorm that hit this state and several others in February.

headline: To Slim Down, Procter & Gamble Sells Most of Its Pet Food Brands to Mars
text: Since A. G. Lafley returned last year for a second stint as chief executive of Procter & Gamble, investors have been waiting for him to make a big move. On Wednesday, they got a small but significant first step.

headline: More Mayhem? You Betcha
text: CALGARY, Alberta — The first question about “Fargo” the television series is: What is it?

headline: Mark Morris Bringing a Handel Work to Mostly Mozart Festival
text: Mark Morris’s new staging of Handel’s “Acis and Galatea” will have its New York premiere this summer as part of the 48th Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center.

headline: Parents Should Coach Academics as Seriously as They Do Sports
text: It sometimes seems that the American success ethic stops at the schoolhouse door. We encourage ambition in youth sports and entrepreneurial enterprise, but our families are often suspicious of the value of scholastic competition.

headline: Senate Panel Expresses Caution on Merger of Cable Giants
text: WASHINGTON — Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed concern on Wednesday that the proposed $45 billion merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would raise the prices consumers pay for cable television and high-speed Internet service while leaving them with fewer choices for video programming.

headline: Today in Small Business: Yelp Has Been Struggling
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Nikolai Solntsev, the self-declared commissar of the Eastern Front and a founding father of the newly proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic, has been waiting 22 years, three months and 14 days for this moment.

headline: Bunny Swap
text: As Easter approaches, it’s officially bunny season, and there are some endearing examples of the species out this year (one looks a little different from the others, but more about that later). Both “Found,” written and illustrated by Salina Yoon, and “Here Comes the Easter Cat,” by Deborah Underwood with illustrations by Claudia Rueda, would be sweet, sugar-free additions to a child’s Easter basket. There’s no reason, however, to restrict their consumption to springtime, because both books concern a perennial childhood issue: balancing the desire to do right with the impulse to do just what you want.

headline: Architecture | Striking a Balance
text: The fervently followed architects Karl Fournier and Olivier Marty of Studio KO imbue their rigorous modernism with a subtle blend of history and culture.

headline: La Quinta Shares Little Changed on Debut
text: Updated, 4:19 p.m. |

headline: No Comment Necessary: Replacing the A.C.A. With…the A.C.A.?
text: According to Talking Points Memo, there is “internal dissent” on whether the Republican Party should come up with an alternative to the Affordable Care Act. One congressional aide explained that it’s difficult to come up a replacement, because it would probably end up looking a lot like the A.C.A.:

headline: New Home for a Mural That Reads Like a Menu
text: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — Crisp and white as a chef’s toque, the newest artwork at the Culinary Institute of America made its debut last month as the perfect backdrop for commencement snapshots. Graduates and family members almost instinctively posed before the mural, a sculptural mélange of food-related words and objects.

headline: Low Inflation and Structural Illusions (Wonkish)
text: The suggestion that only the short-term unemployed matter for wage determination, that the long-term unemployed have been written off, is rapidly congealing into orthodoxy. And it might be true. But I’m with Mike Konczal here: it’s far from being a well-established fact. Mike argues that to the extent it was true at all, it was a temporary phenomenon, and that more recent data don’t support the claim. I’d make a different (although not necessarily conflicting) argument: a lot of the supposed evidence comes from applying Phillips curves estimated over periods of moderate to high inflation, and there are good reasons to believe that such estimates misbehave at low inflation.

headline: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
text: Also on the Minute, looking at Medicare reimbursement and the genetics of exercise.

headline: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
text: In the Video

headline: Senate Republicans Block Bill on Equal Pay
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked legislation meant to close the pay gap between men and women, framing an election-year fight between the parties over whose policies are friendlier to women.

headline: Prosecutor Cross-Examines Pistorius
text: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius was cross-examined by the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, in the third day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Nets’ Flexible Attack Baffles Heat, but Playoffs Pose a Stiffer Test
text: When the Nets lost Brook Lopez for the season in December, they found themselves without the best low-post scorer in the N.B.A. Or so they thought. This season, the league’s most efficient post scorer, according to the statistics company Synergy Sports, is actually Nets guard Shaun Livingston.

headline: Wheelies: The Focus Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Green Revolution, This Time for Africa
text: Last month was the 100th anniversary of the birth of Norman Borlaug, the father of the Green Revolution.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistan Market Blast
text: Survivors combed through the debris after an explosion at a vegetable market in the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan.

headline: When L.B.J. Came to Lunch
text: Today, The Times published two articles related to Lyndon B. Johnson. In one, Peter Baker sets up President Obama’s address on Thursday to the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex., to commemorate the 50th anniversary this year of the Civil Rights Act. In the other, Carl Hulse writes about the Washington politicians traveling to New York to see “All The Way,” the Broadway play portraying the first year of the Johnson presidency.

headline: Latin American E-Commerce Giant to Acquire 2 Real Estate Sites
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The Latin American e-commerce giant MercadoLibre has acquired VMK, a holding company that owns two major real estate websites, the companies are expected to announce on Wednesday.

headline: How to Study the Numinous
text: In an op-ed in the Sunday edition of this newspaper, Barbara Ehrenreich, card-carrying liberal rationalist, writes about her own mystical experiences (the subject of her new book), and argues that the numinous deserves more cutting-edge scientific study:

headline: Alibaba’s Deal-Making Raises a Red Flag
text: Powerful insiders are the norm at Internet companies. Alibaba’s tie-up with a digital-TV company adds an extra twist. The Chinese e-commerce group, which is planning a  listing in the United States, has signed a three-step deal with  Wasu Media of China that looks a little too clever for comfort.

headline: Detroit Creditor Shows Court Four Offers for City’s Art
text: DETROIT — With city and state officials pushing to keep Detroit’s bankruptcy moving quickly toward a resolution, a bond insurer threw an obstacle into the proceedings on Wednesday: four potential offers for the treasures in the city’s art museum, which Detroit does not want to sell.

headline: In Cape Town, Local Color Comes in Bright Shades
text: It’s perhaps the most recognizable of Cape Town’s neighborhoods: a warren of rainbow-bright houses at the foot of Signal Hill, their indigo, fuchsia and lavender facades brightening even the gloomiest days. Bo-Kaap has long been home to Cape Town’s vibrant Muslim community, the Cape Malays, but in recent years, others have been moving into this tight-knit enclave. Young professionals looking for affordable apartments in the city center and gay couples priced out of nearby De Waterkant have been slowly buying up Technicolor real estate.

headline: Michael Cera and Kieran Culkin to Star in ‘This Is Our Youth’ on Broadway
text: This will do nothing for Michael Cera’s on-screen reputation as a young slacker without peer: this summer, he will make his Broadway debut in a new production of Kenneth Lonergan’s “This Is Our Youth,” one that he and his co-star, Kieran Culkin, have been trying to bring to the stage for nearly five years.

headline: UMass Guard Joins List of Openly Gay Athletes
text: Derrick Gordon, a University of Massachusetts guard, revealed that he is gay, joining a fast-growing list of publicly gay male college and professional athletes.

headline: Do the Courts Have a Role to Play in Drone Strikes?
text: History will not look kindly on the succession of federal court rulings since the 9/11 attacks that have bowed to government claims of national security to deny meaningful judicial review for extraordinary acts, like rendition and torture.

headline: Two More Pings Detected in Plane Search
text: Australia’s chief search coordinator, Angus Houston, and the United States team commander, Capt. Mark Matthews, spoke about new signals detected in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Best-Laid Plans for Starry Revival
text: Many of us read John Steinbeck’s 1937 novella “Of Mice and Men” in high school, but it has been a lot harder to see it on Broadway, until now. The show, getting a starry revival at the Longacre Theater, was last on Broadway in 1975, and then for only two months. In the new production, James Franco, whose résumé includes jobs as an actor, poet, professor, filmmaker and more, makes his Broadway debut as George, and Chris O’Dowd (“Bridesmaids”), also on Broadway for the first time, is the simple-minded Lennie in Steinbeck’s Depression-era tale of struggling migrant workers.

headline: Jimmy Beans Wool Decides to Get Back to Knitting
text: Last week, we published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, a yarn and fabric retailer owned by Laura and Doug Zander. Hoping to transform Jimmy Beans into a $100-million company, the Zanders made several hires and introduced numerous costly marketing initiatives that pulled Ms. Zander, the chief executive, from her role guiding operations. The efforts backfired, however, and the company’s sales growth stopped.

headline: A Must-Have List Changes in Midstream
text: A few years after his arrival in New York in 2005, Nakul Chaturvedi bought a large alcove studio in Midtown East. He met Courtney Yates at a Halloween party, and they were married two years ago.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 64
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Sotheby’s Responds to Loeb, With Visual Aids
text: In his battle for control of the auction house Sotheby’s, the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb has focused much of his attention on what he calls the inadequacy of its board members.

headline: A First Look at a New Documentary About the Master Gardener Piet Oudolf
text: “I think it’s the journey in your life to find out what real beauty is, of course, but also discover beauty in things that are at first sight not beautiful,” says Piet Oudolf in this trailer for the forthcoming documentary “Piet Oudolf: Fall, Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall.” The Dutch garden designer from Hummelo, the Netherlands, has risen to international acclaim thanks to the many private and public parks he worked on, including the High Line in Manhattan, the Lurie Garden in Chicago’s Millennium Park and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London, which was home to the 2012 Olympic Games and just opened to the public last week. These projects bring the quality of home gardening to public spaces, creating organic environments that feel as though they’ve been growing there, on their own, for years. For his latest undertaking, Oudolf is designing the grounds of the new outpost of Hauser & Wirth gallery, a remodeled 18th-century farmhouse in the rolling hills of the English county of Somerset that is set to open in July. This film, produced by the filmmaker Thomas Piper and Checkerboard Film Foundation, will offer an intimate view of Oudolf’s process, from landscape blueprints to theories on beauty, when it hits the big screen toward the middle of next year.

headline: This Old House
text: A powerhouse gallery bucks the trend toward ‘important’ architecture in big cities and sets up an outpost in English farm country.

headline: Go Daddy Said to Pick Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan for I.P.O.
text: The Go Daddy Group, the Internet registrar best known for cheeky, controversial ads, is moving full speed ahead with plans for an initial public offering.

headline: Los Angeles Museum Grants to Promote Art and Technology
text: When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art unveiled the results of its original “art and technology” program in an exhibition in 1971, many visitors were struck by what was missing: women. Of the 46 artists and technology experts pictured on the catalog cover, all were men. Protests ensued.

headline: Impac Dublin Literary Award Narrows Field to 10
text: The International Impac Dublin Literary Award has winnowed its very long list of nominees for the 2014 prize to 10 finalists.

headline: Eat, Stay, Buy Locally: Treading Lightly on the Road
text: Between the intricate shrines of Angkor Wat, the diverse landscapes of the countryside and the kindness of its people — and despite the horrors of its recent history — Cambodia knocks a lot of people off their feet. It certainly had that effect on me when I first visited a few years ago and then again when I returned this winter. Yet it was impossible not to notice the school-age children begging barefoot at the major tourist sites, underage local women escorting Western men on sex tours, and the proliferation of seemingly unsustainable large-scale resorts being built on the pristine southern coast.

headline: A 10-Month Family Trip Around the World
text: “It’s much more impacting to learn about the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia than in class,” said Miles Maurer, 15, who instead of attending the ninth grade in Flagstaff, Ariz., this year is traveling around the world. It’s difficult to disagree.

headline: $772 Million Penalty for Bank of America Credit Card Practices
text: Bank of America has been ordered to pay roughly $772 million in refunds to customers and fines to federal regulators to settle allegations that the bank used deceptive marketing and billing practices involving credit card products.

headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran Need ‘Intensive Work,’ Envoys Say
text: Iran and the group of six major powers negotiating a permanent agreement to resolve the Iranian nuclear dispute concluded a two-day round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday, asserting that “a lot of intensive work” remained to complete a draft accord by their self-imposed deadline in three months.

headline: Pain Relievers Tied to Heart Rhythm Disorder
text: A new study found that the popular pain relievers known as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, may increase the risk for the most common type of irregular heartbeat, atrial fibrillation.

headline: Germans Loosen Their Purse Strings
text: FRANKFURT — When Europe seemed to be falling apart in 2010, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund annoyed Germans by suggesting they should stop hoarding so much of their wealth and instead buy more things from their ailing European neighbors.

headline: Britain Increasingly Invokes Power to Disown Its Citizens
text: LONDON — The letter informing Mohamed Sakr that he had been stripped of his British citizenship arrived at his family’s house in London in September 2010. Mr. Sakr, born and raised here by British-Egyptian parents, was in Somalia at the time and was suspected by Western intelligence agencies of being a senior figure in the Shabab, a terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: A New Album From Billy Corgan, but Only 250 Copies
text: Billy Corgan, the imaginative singer and lead guitarist for the Smashing Pumpkins, has undertaken some unusual side projects in recent times, including evenings devoted to synthesizer music inspired by Herman Hesse’s “Siddhartha” and the 13th-century poet Rumi, both at Madame Zuzu’s Teahouse, in Highland Park, Ill., which Mr. Corgan owns. At the moment, Mr. Corgan and his band are at work on two new Smashing Pumpkin albums, which are due to be released in 2015.

headline: When the Criticisms Never End
text: Five nights a week, Amanda H. and her husband drove to her parents’ upscale continuing care retirement community in suburban Boston. She could feel her anxiety build as they rode the elevator upstairs.

headline: Image of the Day: April 9
text: A member of an insurgent group, which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, at a polling booth in Manipur.

headline: G.O.P. Seeks Investigation of Ex-Official From I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Wednesday formally asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to begin a criminal investigation of Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official caught up in the scandal over political targeting of Tea Party groups.

headline: Fed Recognized Change in Unemployment Goal Could Be Misunderstood
text: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve changed the guidelines for its stimulus campaign last month, it did not change its commitment to supporting the economy, according to an account of the decision that the Fed published on Wednesday.

headline: Through a Lens Sharply
text: Recently, I unpacked a box that had been in storage for a long time. It was full of postcards. Hundreds of them. Postcards from every trip I had ever taken. Postcards of famous monuments, famous museums, famous mosques, famous mountains, famous red phone booths. I gazed at my stash — I must have saved them for good reason — and felt ... nothing. They weren’t my London, my Paris, my Istanbul. They were pictures of places that belonged to everyone.

headline: Classical Playlist: Jeffrey Mumford, Mozart, Brahms and More
text: MUMFORD: ‘Through a stillness brightening’Miranda Cuckson, violinist; Wendy Richman, violist; Julia Bruskin, cellist; Winston Choi, pianist; Argento Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Michel Galante; and others(Albany) Jeffrey Mumford, a distinguished American composer who studied with Elliott Carter and Bernard Rands, among others, has an unerring knack for fashioning rigorous works as changeable as cloudscapes, bursting with color, nuance and poetry. Those qualities are abundantly present in this generous Kickstarter-financed collection of chamber pieces spanning 30 years; sources and sonorities vary, but inspiration and expert advocacy are consistent. Two of the performers involved, the violinist Miranda Cuckson and the cellist Julia Bruskin, will perform works from the collection with the pianist Steve Beck on Sunday at Spectrum on the Lower East Side.(Steve Smith)

headline: Reader Idea | Using the ‘Who Made That?’ Column to Teach Reading Strategies
text: Occasionally we publish ideas from readers in lieu of our own lesson plans, and, as with the simple, versatile activity we feature below, they often make us wish we were still in the classroom ourselves so we could try them out “IRL,” as the kids say.

headline: Q. and A. on Heartbleed: A Flaw Missed by the Masses
text: This week, security researchers publicized a significant security flaw, named Heartbleed, which could expose the personal information that people plug into websites, like passwords and credit card numbers.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Latest Memoir to Be Released in June
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s much-anticipated memoir of her time as secretary of state will be released on June 10, her publisher said Wednesday.

headline: Here’s a Story ... of a Mashed-Up Family ...
text: The first shock is that Shirley Partridge has married Reuben Kincaid, the band’s seemingly undesirable manager. Young Danny is distraught, like Hamlet when his mother married his uncle. Then little Cindy Brady is hiding behind the arras when Danny unsheathes his dagger.

headline: App Smart: Off the Beaten Path
text: Many apps available for mobile devices can feel like tools on a Swiss Army knife, but there are also many weird and surprising apps that can captivate you.

headline: A Collection of Wonderful and Weird Amusements
text: MOBILE apps can seem a bit like the tools on a Swiss Army knife. Many of them are useful, but some are just fun.

headline: The Obama Deportation Debacle
text: President Obama has been spent the last five years deporting the wrong people. The evidence is pretty clear.

headline: Recipes for Kids:  Congee
text: Congee is a thick Chinese soup made with rice, which expands and breaks apart as it cooks. In China congee is eaten for breakfast, but it is delicious for lunch and dinner, too. It is also known as jook.

headline: The Gun Report: April 9, 2014
text: Last week, Nathan Trapuzzano, a 24-year-old software engineer and newlywed with a baby on the way, went out for an early morning walk in his Indianapolis neighborhood. He was approached by two people who attempted to rob him, surveillance video shows. One of the would-be thieves pulled out a handgun and shot him in the stomach, killing him.

headline: Video From Fort Hood Memorial Service
text: As our colleague, Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder report, President Obama returned on Wednesday to Fort Hood for a memorial service for three soldiers killed in a mass shooting at the base last week.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2014
text: Remembering Maya Angelou, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Shirley Temple Black, Nadine Gordimer, Ruby Dee, Howard Baker, Elaine Stritch, Mickey Rooney, Robin Williams and others who died this year.

headline: Knives, Not Guns, at a School Near Pittsburgh
text: As we hear and read more about the violence at Franklin Regional High School in Murrysville, Pa., where authorities say a 16-year-old student walked from classroom to classroom randomly stabbing and slashing 19 students as well as a security guard before being tackled and subdued by a principal and a police officer, the same words keep coming up again and again in different contexts.

headline: European Official Urges ‘Say on Pay’ Requirement for Boards
text: BRUSSELS — A European Union official renewed his efforts to curb excessive pay by introducing a plan on Wednesday that would require a shareholder vote on salaries for directors of publicly traded companies.

headline: Times Should Have Nodded to Wall Street Journal in Medicare Story
text: The New York Times led its print edition today with an extensive treatment of an important story: that a small fraction of doctors get a huge share of the billions of dollars paid out under Medicare.

headline: What You Get for ... $900,000
text: BOISE, IDAHO

headline: AT&T to Switch Its Advertising Message
text: Take a look at these three words: “Mobilizing your world.” They could soon become almost as familiar to you as your name or Social Security number.

headline: The Return of a Very Tall Roadside Attraction
text: A now-defunct roadside attraction in remote Baker, Calif., named the world’s tallest thermometer, may be restored. LaRae Harguess, a high school guidance counselor whose family owns the 134-foot-tall concrete tower, said in a telephone interview that the family was working to refurbish it.

headline: Executives Discuss Comcast Merger
text: An executive vice president of Comcast, David L. Cohen, and the chief executive of Public Knowledge, Gene Kimmelman, argued their cases before Congress on the proposed merger with Time Warner.

headline: Mac DeMarco’s Appetizing ‘Salad Days’
text: As a slacker-child of the 1980s, I heard Mac DeMarco’s brand-new album “Salad Days” for the first time and thought: Yes. I get this. The laid-back grooviness, the moments of introspection undermined by cheeky apathy and hints of l’enfant terrible.

headline: Photos: Baseball, Anyone? Anyone?
text: Attendance at ballparks can be pretty spotty this time of year, when it’s often cold and rainy in many big-league towns. But the first week and a half of the 2014 major league season has produced some especially bleak scenes.

headline: Thanks for the Flair, Mom
text: Whether you order Vietnamese noodles, Taiwanese bubble tea or Chinese pastries, one way to experience the diversity of Elmhurst is through the restaurants that line the streets. That’s precisely what drew Nora Li, who moved to New York from China three years ago, to the Queens neighborhood on a recent afternoon. She was buying groceries that included shrimp crackers and instant noodles. Ms. Li, an art student, was wearing an oversize coat with suede details, a beanie and cropped pants exposing her socks and loafers. She described her personal style as “saggy.”

headline: In Sicily, Greek History by Bike
text: Travelers can get a double hit of culture with a new biking trip from the Bristol, Vt.-based travel outfitter VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations, which focuses on Greek civilization in Sicily.

headline: New Dallas Festival Teams Symphony With Artists
text: Over the last three decades Dallas has invested billions in its arts district, a one-stop-shopping location for visual art, dance, classical music and theater. And beginning next year, the various creative disciplines will start trying to get together and experiment more often. The Dallas Symphony Orchestra is set to announce the founding of a new annual arts festival, to be called Soluna, that intends to recruit established visual artists to collaborate with the symphony and with other Dallas-based musical companies and ensembles.

headline: A Director Takes on a World of Nefarious People
text: Some directors make movies hoping for awards and accolades. Others for money. David Hare, who wrote and directed the new BBC spy thriller “Turks and Caicos,” had a different objective: to bring down the British government and, while he’s at it, Uncle Sam, too.

headline: Officials on Murrysville School Stabbing
text: The chief medical officer at Forbes Regional Hospital, Dr. Mark Rubino, and the Murrysville, Pa., police chief, Thomas Seefeld, provided updates after a student stabbed at least 20 at a high school.

headline: ‘Frozen’ and ‘Happy’ Reign, While Music Sales Continue to Plunge
text: There’s not much news at the top of the music charts this week. The “Frozen” soundtrack is the No. 1 album for a ninth time, with 149,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Pharrell Williams’s “Happy” is the top single yet again. That lineup has not changed for a month.

headline: House Hunting on ... the Costa del Sol, Spain
text: A VILLA IN A GATED COMMUNITY ON THE COSTA DEL SOL

headline: Leave Rochelle Out of It, a New Lower East Side Bar
text: As bar names goes, Leave Rochelle Out of It wins points for originality. Named after a mutual ex-girlfriend of two of the proprietors, Brett David and Stephen Yorsz, the bar is a celebration of bro-culture that would make Robert Bly proud. There are more than 150 types of whiskeys, deafening music and racy films.

headline: An Evening Full of Bach, the Father and the Sons
text: The final, agitated movement of Johann Christian Bach’s Symphony in G minor, written in 1770, does not so much end as kind of check out. A twisting melodic line in the strings spins delicately upward and trails off. On Tuesday night at Zankel Hall, when the acclaimed period-instrument chamber orchestra Akademie für Alte Musik Berlin finished its fleet, incisive performance of this work, there were gasps of delighted surprise from people in the audience, including one audible “Oh, gee!”

headline: Shift From Paper Complicates Giving Treasury Bonds as Gifts
text: Reginna Peckens, a child care provider in Marietta, Ohio, uses the federal government’s online TreasuryDirect system to buy digital savings bonds for herself. But she hasn’t been able to persuade her mother, who is not computer savvy, to use the system to buy savings bonds to give as gifts, something she used to do regularly. Now, “there are extra steps,” Ms. Peckens said.

headline: Fashion in the Age of Instagram
text: In the Dries Van Noten exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris is a video that stitches together sequences from 20 years of his runway shows — a “supercut,” in online argot. On a tour of the show not long ago, Mr. Van Noten nodded along as memorable moments flashed: male models pedaling bicycles, women stalking the length of an enormous dinner table. But what stood out most were the ghostly points of light illuminating the audience’s faces in the recent shows.

headline: A Reporter Analyzes the Driving Role of Pakistan in the Afghan War
text: On July 7, 2008, insurgents detonated a huge suicide car bomb outside the Indian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing 54 people, including an Indian defense attaché. The attack destroyed the embassy’s protective blast walls and front gates, and tore into civilians waiting outside for visas.

headline: He Sees Dead People, but Through a Stoned Haze
text: Tyler Labine first made an impression on television as the funny guy in a couple of underrated hourlong shows, the science-fiction drama “Invasion” and the ghostbusters comedy “Reaper.” But since then he has become a sitcom guy, one of those who show up about once a year — “Animal Practice” (NBC, 2012), “Mad Love” (CBS, 2011), “Sons of Tucson” (Fox, 2010) — and go away 9 or 13 episodes later, looking for the next pilot.

headline: Reconciliation Held Together With Bleeding Stitches
text: As Rwanda and the world note the 20th anniversary of the genocide in that country, much of the focus has been on reconciliations between the Hutu killers who slaughtered Tutsis and the victims’ family members and friends. “Coexist,” a documentary by Adam Mazo, at first seems as if it is merely going to be another effort to draw feel-good stories out of an impossibly ugly moment in history. But it ultimately proves itself much smarter than that, exploring whether forgiveness that is mandated by the government can be genuine.

headline: A New Line | Lou & Grey’s Soft, Laid-Back Staples Debut With a Dreamy Video
text: Loft, Ann Taylor’s spinoff brand, has hatched a cool little sister: Lou & Grey, featuring a range of soft, lounge-y layers designed to transition from the sofa to the streets. To commemorate the launch of the line, which will be sold online and at 500 Loft store-in-stores, the brand enlisted the model, illustrator and girl-about-town Langley Fox Hemingway as its muse. Here, T premieres a video, shot by the artist Mark Borthwick in his signature hazy style, of Hemingway cavorting along the coastline in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: A Young Star, Poised and Grounded
text: While audiences are taking their seats for “The Library,” a new play at the Public Theater written by Scott Z. Burns and directed by Steven Soderbergh, its lead actress, Chloë Grace Moretz, is already onstage.

headline: The Three-Seat Strollers
text: A few years ago, Brian Berger, the founder of Mack Weldon, an online purveyor of men’s socks and underwear, saw a close friend surrounded by three siblings at a birthday party. “It was just an amazing experience watching the four of them, and to have all those siblings to go through life together with,” recalled Mr. Berger, 40.

headline: There’s Brightness When the Fog Clears
text: Fog machines in dance performances are usually signs of bad taste. But the fog in Trisha Brown’s 1980 work “Opal Loop/Cloud Installation #72503” is something else. It rolls in as if from the sea, a floating and evanescent cloud of water molecules that is somehow under artistic control.

headline: Now Turning Heads: The Sales Staff
text: THE SCRUFFY YOUNG MAN in the Nike sweatpants is there to help you with that Greg Lauren one-of-a-kind $1,250 cape.

headline: As Comfortable as ...
text: On a recent morning, a friend sent me an email with the subject “Rod Lavers are back in stock.” A link inside the email opened to a page on the Adidas website that prominently featured, from five different angles, the familiar white-mesh and green-soled sneakers, or Lifestyle Shoes, as the company calls them. They cost $65. The question was not whether to buy a pair but how many to buy.

headline: The Many Alternative Computing Worlds of Linux
text: HAVE you ever wondered what happened to Linux? Linux is the free software created through the open source development process that many technology enthusiasts had predicted would revolutionize the world of computing.

headline: Artists Try to Prick Conscience of Drone Operators With Giant Portrait of Orphan in Pakistani Field
text: While a series of deadly bombings in Pakistan this week threatens to undermine peace talks between the government and the Taliban, a group of rights activists and artists have started a campaign to draw attention to the human cost of another sort of violence — American drone strikes aimed at militants, which have reportedly killed hundreds of civilians in recent years.

headline: What Awaits Banks After the Leverage Ratio
text: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art to Expand Photography Center
text: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has long been renowned for its photography collection. Now it will have galleries whose size and scope will match the ambitions of that collection.

headline: Can China Cast Off Despotism?
text: It’s no longer politically correct to use the word “Oriental” in the West. But nowhere has the word “despotism” fallen out of favor.

headline: In a Fight for Everything Brooklyn
text: Williamsburg is a middle-aged Italian couple with good scarf game buying coffee and strolling by the water in Bushwick Inlet Park. Williamsburg is a dude in head-to-toe Rick Owens thumbing through techno CDs at the new Rough Trade record shop. Williamsburg is a glass-and-steel tower housing a bunch of 30-something marketing executives proud they avoided buying in Dumbo.

headline: Coming Up Big at the Whitehead Women’s Pairs
text: DALLAS — Ran Jingrong and Wang Wenfei, a relatively new partnership from China, won the Whitehead Women’s Pairs here at the spring North American Bridge Championships on March 28. They finished more than three boards ahead of Kitty Cooper of Lakeside, Calif., and Lynne Feldman of San Diego. Third were Maritha Pottenger of San Diego and Prudence Saunders of Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Masters Spots Will Tell IBM’s Story in a New Way
text: AS a sponsor of the Masters last year, IBM did what most sponsors did and introduced a few new commercials that ran in heavy rotation during the golf tournament. But this year, in the advertising equivalent of a driving range, IBM is teeing up about 50 commercials that will run just once.

headline: With Declines Slowing, PC Sales Still Struggle
text: The personal computer market’s fever has broken, but the business is still sick.

headline: For an Hour, Dancing Like Beyoncé
text: With its hardwood floors, big windows and mirrored walls, Chelsea Studios looks like a typical dance rehearsal space. One recent night, about 35 people, mostly 20-something women in Lululemon athletic wear, were loosening up and waiting for the music to start.

headline: Volkswagen Halts Sales of Some Cars Over Transmission Leak
text: Volkswagen said on Wednesday that about 25,000 of its 2014 models may leak transmission fluid, and that it had told dealers to stop selling them while it discusses a possible recall with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Judge Allows Christie Aides to Withhold Bridge Emails
text: In a major setback to the legislative investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a New Jersey judge ruled on Wednesday that two of Gov. Chris Christie’s former aides do not have to comply with subpoenas seeking emails and other communications about the closings and attempts to cover them up.

headline: The Woman and the Giant (No Fable)
text: When Diane Arbus and Eddie Carmel met in 1960, each had embarked on a career that seemed willfully disreputable. Carmel, who in adolescence had a wild growth surge as a result of an inoperable pituitary-gland tumor, was exhibited as a giant in circuses and sideshows. For a young New Yorker who had attended City College, it was a louche way to make a living.

headline: The Pleasure Is in the Details
text: Schubert’s hourlong Octet in F for Winds and Strings can have a pleasantly narcotic effect on the listener, each one of its amply proportioned six movements warping sensations of time and purpose like a carefree summer afternoon. So I didn’t think too much of it at first when I found my mind wandering during Saturday evening’s performance of the work by Musicians From Marlboro, an ensemble from that Vermont-based festival, as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts.

headline: Shopping in Your Closet for Coachella Music Festival
text: Music festival season kicks off this weekend with the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. And even though the haters are huffing, and the hoopla around “festival fashion” is excessive, there are good reasons to be excited this year. For one, Outkast is headlining many of the festivals. For another, assembling your rock-fest look will be a piece of cake. Free-floating dresses, folky prints, fringe, tie-dye — a Coachella undercurrent so infected the spring collections that, come festival time, you’re already there. No need to head to the shops; just come as you are.

headline: Corporate Design: An Energizer Versus an Eyesore
text: The rivalry between the South Korean tech giants Samsung and LG isn’t just played out over sales of smartphones and curved television screens. Both companies are building new American headquarters, Samsung in north San Jose, Calif.; LG in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. And on this score, the contest isn’t close. Buildings are corporate symbols and advertisements, after all. Samsung comes across as a good citizen here; LG as a lousy neighbor.

headline: An Artist Demands Civility on the Street With Grit and Buckets of Paste
text: ATLANTA — With a lick of wheat paste, a roller and a stepladder, Tatyana Fazlalizadeh, a painter and illustrator from Brooklyn, introduced herself to the South, in an unusual way.

headline: Deadly Wave of Blasts Hits Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi capital, Baghdad, experienced a series of violent attacks on Wednesday when eight car bombs and two mortar shells killed as many as 25 people in episodes around the city, according to security personnel.

headline: Weathering a Technical Glitch With Puckish Spirit and Catchy Songs
text: Neil Finn’s concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall wasn’t the smoothest show of a long career. But technical glitches only underscored the strength of his songwriting and the puckishness of his spirit. His two-and-a-half-hour set included most of the songs from his new album, “Dizzy Heights,” along with a generous retrospective from his bands Split Enz and Crowded House in the 1980s and his other solo and collaborative projects since the 1990s.

headline: Hit and Run at Day Care in Florida Kills a Child
text: MIAMI — A hit-and-run crash sent a car barreling through the wooden wall of a crowded day care center on Wednesday in a suburb of Orlando, killing one girl and injuring 15 people, at least 12 of them children, some of them grievously, the authorities said. One adult was also hospitalized.

headline: Massaging Applicators
text: The latest gimmick in skin care? Products with massaging applicators. Like the vibrating mascara wand before them, they are fun to use, even if the result is indistinguishable from one achieved with your fingertips.

headline: Personalities Beyond Fists and Faces
text: Beyond the classic poses of boxers with fists at the ready, Holger Keifel found a spirit that lingered beyond the ring.

headline: A Big Job Might Ruin a Good Thing
text: It took one week to go from cancel Colbert to coronate him.

headline: As Ally Prepares for Offering, Government Cuts Stake
text: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | The federal government is close to shedding the last remnants of its crisis-era bailouts.

headline: New Kids on the Magazine Rack
text: Walk into any magazine store in New York City these days, and prepare to be flummoxed by a wall of unfamiliar fashion publications. Once-obscure titles like the Gentlewoman and 032C, which pioneered an indie print resurgence, now share shelf space with dozens of newer and even more obscure magazines, each offering its own niche perspective on fashion — from the irreverent to the fearless. Here’s a guide to seven fashion magazines on the cutting edge of print.

headline: Jamie Dimon Writes of ‘Nerve-Racking’ 2013
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has reflected in his annual shareholder letter on a year that was marked by the bank pulling out its checkbook to mend frayed relationships with the federal government — a reconciliation that has already cost around $20 billion.

headline: Despite Doubts, a Vote Worth Casting
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It would be easy for me to say I had no fear going into Election Day. But it wouldn’t be true.

headline: Taking on Art Looters on Twitter
text: Monica Hanna stood inside the Malawi National Museum in Minya, Egypt, last August, armed only with a cellphone and her Twitter account, as looters ran rampant. Nearly all the objects she had loved since childhood — mummies and amulets, scarabs and carved ibises — were gone. In their place lay shattered glass, shards of pottery, splintered wood and the charred remains of a royal sarcophagus.

headline: Hall of Fame Decides Who Rocks, Officially
text: In the beginning, it was obvious who should be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Ray Charles, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, Little Richard, James Brown, Bob Dylan: All were giants whose selection no one could quarrel with.

headline: What She Did for a Warm Towel
text: When designers need inspiration for a new product, some simply look around their own homes and consider what’s missing.

headline: Discounts from Sferra, Marimekko, Intérieurs and Rech!
text: Sferra’s sample sale runs through Sunday at Chelsea Market, with up to 70 percent off prices on bed, bath and table linens (a set of four Crest embroidered linen dinner napkins, originally $75, is about $22); 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), sferra.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Kenya, India and Central Africa Republic.

headline: The Name on the Digital Door
text: Sasha Lord has never met the residents of Hell or Namaste, Om shanti, but she has spent a lot of time thinking about them. For a while, every time Ms. Lord, a 32-year-old band promoter in Arlington, Va., posted a photograph on Instagram from her studio apartment, she was reminded of their existence.

headline: Add Seeds and Soil, Then Stir
text: “The Plant Recipe Book” (Artisan, $24.95), by Baylor Chapman, is a follow-up to “The Flower Recipe Book,” and like its successful predecessor offers an ingredient-by-ingredient approach to gardening — container gardening, in this case. The suggested chef’s pantry includes a small trowel, coated wire, a watering can, pruning shears and even actual kitchen tools like a skewer and a turkey baster.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: All That’s Missing Is a Necktie
text: The Oriole Mill was founded eight years ago by Bethanne Knudson, a textile artist, and Stephan Michelson, a statistical analyst and musician. The couple, who took over a 72,000-square-foot former food processing plant in Hendersonville, N.C., produce jacquard fabric and make most everything to dress a bed (they don’t do sheets). They recently introduced four collections. Two (Cape Cod and Colorado Plateau) are in what’s-not-to-like neutrals, and a third (Charleston) has a cheery blue-and-white pattern. The last, Brooklyn, is a dark departure. “It’s a masculine, urban bed that was inspired by a fabric we make that is reminiscent of men’s wear,” Ms. Knudson said. Prices are $150 for a 20-inch-square pillow to $1,350 for a king-size duvet. Information: 828-693-5500 or theoriolemill.com.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 10
text: Openings and Events

headline: Squirrels Are Reading This Now
text: Almost nothing can come between squirrels and the birdseed they gorge on, not even Led Zeppelin music and mild electrical shocks. For three decades, the humor writer Bill Adler Jr., 57, has collected tips for keeping the rodents away from avian meals. He has updated his 1988 volume, “Outwitting Squirrels: 101 Cunning Stratagems to Reduce Dramatically the Egregious Misappropriation of Seed From Your Birdfeeder by Squirrels” (Chicago Review Press, $16.95), for a new, third edition. (His other books include advice for coping with cranky toddlers, ravenous deer, litigious neighbors and incompetent home contractors.) The field has made some technological advances, he reports, but squirrels still have little else to do all day but strategize.

headline: A Gentleman Returns, With Art
text: The Lord Baltimore, yet another down-at-the-heels grand hotel, has been returned to its former elegance, thanks to a renovation that was completed in March.

headline: Should I Fix Those Little Hairline Cracks in My Walls?
text: Q. Should I fix those little hairline cracks in my walls before selling my home?

headline: It’s Mourning in America
text: Growing up in Uniontown, Pa., the Hurley twins, Tracy and Tonya, spent most weekends attending funerals with their grandmother. “In our hometown, Sundays were either for funerals or a Steelers game,” said Tracy, who is now Tracy Martin. “And our grandmother was a funeral fly.”

headline: Egg Cups for the Occasion
text: When you’re shopping for egg cups, it makes sense to bring some eggs along with you. How else would you try out the egg cups for size?

headline: Women’s Rights Activist Criticizes Brandeis’s Decision to Cancel Her Honorary Degree
text: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a women’s rights advocate and critic of Islam, said in a statement on Wednesday that Brandeis University had betrayed the principles of freedom of expression and religion by rescinding an invitation to her to receive an honorary degree.

headline: Photo Diary | Milan Design Week 2014: Boffi
text: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.

headline: Prepping the Mower
text: What to do before cutting the grass.

headline: Homeowners, Start Your Engines
text: Every November there comes a day when I race into the shed with my trusty lawn mower, fling it into a corner and let loose a fist pump that would give Tiger Woods chills. Is it the final cut of the year? Yup. But you never truly know, so it seems like a good idea not to drain the gas, change the oil or do whatever it is the read-the-manual folks do.

headline: I.M.F. Warns of Risk From Emerging-Market Corporate Debt
text: WASHINGTON — As fears mount about emerging markets, American mutual fund investors with significant exposure to bonds issued by indebted companies in fast-growing economies may be at risk, the International Monetary Fund warned in a report published on Wednesday.

headline: New York City Reducing Role of Tests in Advancing Students to Next Grade
text: New York City’s Education Department, in a break with the data-driven policies of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, moved on Wednesday to reduce the role of standardized exams in deciding which students to hold back each year.

headline: We Need to Talk About the Test
text: I’D like to tell you what was wrong with the tests my students took last week, but I can’t. Pearson’s $32 million contract with New York State to design the exams prohibits the state from making the tests public and imposes a gag order on educators who administer them. So teachers watched hundreds of thousands of children in grades 3 to 8 sit for between 70 and 180 minutes per day for three days taking a state English Language Arts exam that does a poor job of testing reading comprehension, and yet we’re not allowed to point out what the problems were.

headline: Former S.E.C. Official to Join K.K.R. as Compliance Chief
text: Bruce Karpati, a former Securities and Exchange Commission official, is joining the giant private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company as its chief compliance officer, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Weighing Life’s Risks, on Land and Sea
text: To the Editor:

headline: Refugee Crisis in Syria
Cooks Do It All on Snowboard Expeditions
text: During expeditions to Alaska, Jeremy Jones and Teton Gravity Research look for team members who are as versatile as they are dependable. No one embodies this better than the crew’s camp cook.

headline: Chiding an F.E.C. Colleague
text: To the Editor:

headline: Health Goal Met, White House Reviews Missteps
text: WASHINGTON — Days after hitting their target of signing up more than seven million people for health insurance, Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, and other top aides to President Obama gathered last week on the patio just outside Mr. McDonough’s West Wing office.

headline: Video: Cooks Do It All on Snowboard Expeditions
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.
