text: To the Editor:

headline: A Move to Adjust Pensions?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Massimo Tamburini, Sculptor of Shapely Motorcycles, Dies at 70
text: They were objects of unalloyed lust.

headline: Los Angeles’s Future at Risk
text: A report on the civic health of the city said that it was barely treading water while the rest of the world was moving forward.

headline: Ready for Frozen Four, Gophers’ Star Goalie Is Inviting the Pressure
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Like so many things involving hockey in Minnesota, Adam Wilcox’s story began with a couple of youngsters playing in a basement.

headline: Obama Mourns Victims at Fort Hood
text: President Obama delivered remarks at the base in Texas and mourned with the families and uniformed comrades of those killed in the shooting last week.

headline: Benefits of Fake Meats
text: To the Editor:

headline: College for Criminals
text: IN February, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced plans to underwrite college classes in 10 state prisons, building on the success of privately funded and widely praised programs like the Bard Prison Initiative. Mr. Cuomo pointed out that inmates who got an education had a much better chance of finding a job and were much less likely to menace their neighbors after release. He noted that the cost — $5,000 per inmate per year — would be a bargain compared with the $60,000 it costs to incarcerate a prisoner for a year.

headline: Even New York Drivers Wowed by a White, Winged Commuter
text: I had an extraordinary moment on the Palisades Parkway leaving New York City. In medium traffic moving about 50 miles per hour, with end-of-day sun slanting from the west, I could see something white and, seemingly, winged, flitting and darting within the flow of cars up ahead.

headline: M.L.B. Report Highlights Sobering Number of Black Players
text: Dave Dombrowski is the head of baseball’s on-field diversity task force, but he is also the president of the Detroit Tigers. In the last year, as he studied ways to give better opportunities to African-Americans, Dombrowski realized the challenge demanded more than a committee of experts with day jobs.

headline: Parenting the Non-Girlie Girl
text: There are many possible explanations for why my 5-year-old daughter has yet again asked if she can change her name to Sam. Sam can also be a girl’s name, I explain hopefully. No, she clarifies, sighing at the dullard she has been given for a mother. She wants to be Sam the boy’s name.

headline: Designing an Eco-Friendly Honeymoon
text: Cayuga Sustainable Hospitality, a Central American eco-lodge operator with eight properties, is looking for newlyweds to help perfect the “eco-honeymoon” experience.

headline: We Should Be in a Rage
text: Voter apathy is a civic abdication. There is no other way to describe it.

headline: Wayne Henderson, a Founder of the Jazz Crusaders, Dies at 74
text: Wayne Henderson, a trombonist and composer who was a founding member of the Jazz Crusaders, which played straight-ahead bebop beginning in the 1950s and then morphed into leading performers of jazz-funk, died on April 5 in Culver City, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Layers of Mystery for a Steinway Grand
text: This is a mystery story, but not a conventional whodunit. It has no dead bodies. No smoking guns. No hard-boiled detectives in trench coats and fedoras.

headline: Mary Cheever, a Central Figure in a Literary Family, Dies at 95
text: Mary Cheever, a central figure in a family of prominent American writers whose most notable member was her husband, John, with whom she had a relationship as complex as those he wrote about in his prizewinning short stories and novels, died on Monday at the home they had shared in Ossining, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: James Hellwig, Wrestling’s Ultimate Warrior, Dies at 54
text: James Hellwig, a professional wrestler known in the 1990s as the Ultimate Warrior — a frenzied mountain of muscle and face paint who was billed as the heir apparent to Hulk Hogan, but who then fell out of favor — died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 54.

headline: Russia Didn’t Share All Details on Boston Bombing Suspect, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Russian government declined to provide the F.B.I. with information about one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects that would most likely have led to more extensive scrutiny of him at least two years before the attack, according to an inspector general’s report.

headline: Northwestern Requests Review of Labor Ruling
text: CHICAGO — Northwestern on Wednesday formally requested a review of the ruling that its scholarship football players are employees and able to form a union.

headline: Where the G.O.P. Gets It Right
text: Republicans may seem like ultimate Scrooges. Many want to slash food stamps, unemployment benefits and just about any program that helps the needy.

headline: In a Land of On-Time Arrivals, a Tour of Anything But
text: BERLIN — In the early days of aviation, it was common for people to visit airports simply to stand on observation decks and watch the planes come and go. This city’s new airport is attracting tourists for the opposite reason: a conspicuous lack of passengers and planes after a series of delays and bungles that have driven its cost billions of dollars over budget and pushed its opening back indefinitely.

headline: Report Finds Los Angeles at Risk of Decline
text: LOS ANGELES — From the 73-story skyscraper that just broke ground downtown (the tallest in the West), to the blizzard of office, shopping and apartment complexes rising from there to the Pacific, construction is bustling in Los Angeles. Home prices are up, and the foreclosure rate is declining. Crime is down. There is a new mayor in City Hall. In many ways, Los Angeles, like many once-beleaguered cities across the nation, seems on the upswing.

headline: U.S. Pair Can’t Leave Qatar Amid Appeal
text: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple entangled in Qatar’s criminal justice system over the death of their adopted daughter, have been denied permission to fly home while the appeal of their three-year prison term is pending, and their lawyers said they might be incarcerated as early as Friday.

headline: Free-for-All in the Cafeteria
text: More than a million children attend public schools in New York City. About 780,000 of them are poor enough to qualify for a free or reduced-price lunch. Getting into the program requires some paperwork, which is a burden but not a terrible one; the application is just one page. So why do so many eligible children — about 250,000 — not participate?

headline: Banks Ease Hours for Junior Staff, but Workload Stays Same
text: The biggest investment banks recently signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules.

headline: Where Does the G.M. Recall Rank?
text: Automakers have a long history of trying to maintain their reputations in the face of major recalls.

headline: A Risk to India’s Nuclear Doctrine
text: With India’s national elections in full swing, the campaign promises of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, are drawing more scrutiny. Among the more troubling proposals in the party’s election manifesto is one to “revise and update” the country’s nuclear doctrine.

headline: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars
text: There was nothing but the car key on Jacob Hughes’s key ring.

headline: Missteps Aside, de Blasio Looks to Focus Anew on Activist Style
text: He regrets his public-relations headaches, saying he and his team could have done a better job speaking to the public.

headline: Capital in the Twenty-First Century
text: My NYRB review of Piketty is up.

headline: Mechanics of the Plane Search, Explained
text: How the multinational team off the coast of Australia is continuing the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Users’ Stark Reminder: As Web Grows, It Grows Less Secure
text: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi — an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot.

headline: An Easy Hole? Only for Those Who Play It Perfectly
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The 15th hole at Augusta National Golf Club is statistically one of the easiest in the Masters, a 530-yard par 5 whose green can be reached in two shots, with the field routinely averaging a better-than-par score.

headline: Amid ‘Exploding’ Houses and a Wave of Mud, a Maternal Instinct Flared
text: SEATTLE — What Amanda Skorjanc saw on the morning of the landslide in Oso, Wash., looking out her window with her 22-week-old baby in her arms, was the stuff of nightmares.

headline: Flaw Calls for Altering Passwords, Experts Say
text: A programming mistake from two years ago has forced countless websites to make fixes to protect the sensitive personal information of consumers.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for April 9, 2014
text: April 9, 2014

headline: After Optimism of More Pings, Reality of Long Jet Search Settles In
text: In the excitement of detecting four bursts of signals that might have originated from the flight recorders of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, missing for more than a month, Australian officials have waxed optimistic.

headline: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than Data Makes Them Look
text: Although consumers and health experts will be poring over the newly released Medicare data for months, maybe years to come, one startling piece of information has already emerged, demonstrating some of the complexity inherent in the long-fought-over information on 880,000 health care providers across the country.

headline: Syria: Deadly Car Bomb Blasts Hit Homs
text: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.

headline: Medicare’s Most Reimbursed Ophthalmologists
text: Nearly 3,000 ophthalmologists fell in the top 2 percent of Medicare Part B recipients, each receiving more than $470,000 in payments in 2012.

headline: The Medicare Data’s Pitfalls
text: The release on Wednesday of Medicare payment data is getting mixed reviews from doctors. Many say they favor sharing information but worry that the data presented by Medicare omits important details and may mislead the public and paint an unfairly negative picture of individual doctors.

headline: A Bagful of Memories of a Home in Augusta
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Before the Masters began, four caddies carved out a quiet moment to lift their bottles of beer in a toast to their favorite former nun, a Southern woman whose hospitality survived her death.

headline: Sharpton’s Group Seems Undaunted by His F.B.I. Role
text: As new details emerged about his four-year stint in the 1980s as a confidential informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Rev. Al Sharpton thought enough of the attention to hold a news conference to address what became front-page fodder for New York tabloids for two days this week.

headline: The Truth About the Pay Gap
text: Women are the primary or co-breadwinner in 6 out of 10 American families. That makes the economic imperative of addressing the wage gap between women and men important, as is every step President Obama can take in that direction.

headline: Last Criminal Trial Stemming From Occupy Wall Street Is Underway
text: By most accounts, Occupy Wall Street’s moment in the cultural spotlight has passed, and headlines about disaffected New York idealists protesting the wide gap between rich and poor have become scarce.

headline: In Houston, Bush 41 Greets Obama, Who Later Assails G.O.P.
text: HOUSTON — President Obama came to this Texas metropolis on Wednesday to raise money for Democrats, but the first person to welcome him to town was the city’s most prominent Republican, the first President George Bush.

headline: Playing 15 Can Play With Your Head
text: The 15th hole at Augusta often plays a crucial role in determining the Masters champion.

headline: Japan Pushes Plan to Stockpile Plutonium, Despite Proliferation Risks
text: TOKYO — Just weeks after Japan agreed to give up a cache of weapons-grade plutonium, the country is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of the material, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.

headline: He’s Old, Rich and Dying, and Wants His Nephew’s Girl
text: “This place is fun! A wondrous mess! I wish my every day knew such excess!”

headline: Day Trip Destination
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I thought this one was relatively easy for a Thursday puzzle and there wasn’t much of a trick to the theme, but I did enjoy all the FLAGS waving at me. The theme hangs together very well, and the cluing is tricky.

headline: De Blasio Is Urged to Alter Housing Plans at Brooklyn Park
text: Brooklyn Bridge Park, which stretches 1.3 miles along the East River waterfront, was a creation of the administration of Michael R. Bloomberg, with a novel — and contentious — financing mechanism in the form of luxury housing in the park.

headline: In Maryland, a Political Drama Befitting the Show at Its Center
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Where was Frank Underwood when he was really needed?

headline: U.S. Attorney Criticizes Cuomo’s Closing of Panel
text: Less than two weeks after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo abruptly shut down a commission he had formed to investigate political corruption in New York State, the United States attorney in Manhattan is sharply questioning the governor’s decision and is taking possession of all of the panel’s case files, according to letters sent to the commission’s members on April 3 and again on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: On Civil Rights Act Anniversary, Bill Clinton Challenges Lawmakers to Be Bold
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Bill Clinton’s political awakening came against the backdrop of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War. Fifty years later, Mr. Clinton observed the anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 with a strong reminder about the sacrifices lawmakers must make to advance sweeping and controversial legislation.

headline: Flight 370 Search Brings Satellite Company an Unaccustomed Bit of Fame
text: LONDON — On an enormous electronic map of the globe in the modernist headquarters of a satellite company here, two green hexagons the size of dinner plates hovered off the west coast of Australia, revealing signals from an armada of ships and planes converged in the hunt for any remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Injury and Math Dim Hopes for Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Another day as a member of the Knicks meant conditioning work and shooting drills, a focus on the immediate future (four remaining games) and a sad reassessment of the team’s playoff odds (slim to none).

headline: Energy Panel Faulted on Information Safeguards
text: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may not have adequate controls to protect information that could be used to sabotage the power grid, the Energy Department’s inspector general said on Wednesday. The inspector general, Gregory H. Friedman, issued a “management alert” that was a veiled slap at a former chairman of the commission, Jon Wellinghoff, who has been arguing that an attack last year on a California substation was an act of terrorism, a conclusion that the F.B.I. and local law enforcement officials have refused to endorse. Mr. Friedman said that the commission staff had created a presentation that “should have been classified and protected from release.” The commission generated a memo, later described by The Wall Street Journal, that said that simultaneous attacks on a handful of substations around the country could cripple the power grid. The inspector general said he was acting after a complaint from the Energy Department’s ethics officer and letters from the chairwoman and ranking minority member of the Senate Energy Committee. He recommended establishing a classification system, a step he said the current chairwoman of the commission had promised to implement promptly.

headline: Tanaka Has Highs and Lows, but the Yankees’ Bullpen Has Only the Latter
text: After a solid but unspectacular major league debut last week, Masahiro Tanaka examined video of his outing to determine what he might have done wrong. He found a slight mechanical flaw, which he declined to identify but aimed to correct.

headline: Profiling Rules Said to Give F.B.I. Tactical Leeway
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would allow the F.B.I. to continue many, if not all, of the tactics opposed by civil rights groups, such as mapping ethnic populations and using that data to recruit informants and open investigations.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Spy Games Are Exciting, Until They’re Deadly
text: Charles Duluth, the K.G.B. agent posing as a conservative journalist whom Philip calls upon for help from time to time, is a very strange character. He has a stiff, patrician voice but is a die-hard Marxist. One imagines him growing up among crusty WASP bankers and thus handily learning to despise capitalism. At any rate, he’s not a particularly great spy, and as Episode 7 begins, Philip can’t get a hold of him, and he desperately needs his help in placing a large bug — “the size of a rat,” Philip complains to the new handler, Kate — on a computing system to gather data from the Arpanet, an Internet prototype.

headline: Wheeler and Mets’ Offense Are No Match for Santana in His Braves Debut
text: ATLANTA — Eight games into the season, the Mets were already counting moral victories. They had been blanketed for eight innings, held to three hits by Ervin Santana in his Braves debut. But once Santana left the game, they rallied to score three runs in the ninth, before falling short, 4-3, at Turner Field on Wednesday night.

headline: De Blasio: ‘You Can’t Be Passive in a Role Like This’
text: Following are edited excerpts from an interview with Mayor Bill de Blasio conducted on Wednesday by The New York Times:

headline: Lost Season at Least Provides Seasoning for Islanders
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — With three games remaining in a disappointing season, the Islanders cannot be blamed for mulling what might have been.

headline: Already, Nets Rookie Has Signature Moment
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Mason Plumlee, the Nets’ 24-year-old rookie center, was reclining at his locker here Wednesday afternoon, shaking his head and laughing about the previous night.

headline: Different Sort of Dog Run: Beside Train, Between Boroughs
text: The urban dog has long lived a singular life. Apartment hallways double as exercise hubs. Sidewalks teem with potential snacks, discarded from bodegas on high.

headline: India Election Digest: April 10
text: What you need to know about India’s elections on Thursday: Voters in 11 states and three union territories go to the polls — Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Haryana, Jammu and Kashmir, Jharkhand, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Lakshadweep and Delhi.

headline: Chinese Exports and Imports Unexpectedly Fell in March
text: HONG KONG — China’s exports unexpectedly fell in March, and its imports dropped even more sharply, but the significance of the data for the Chinese economy was clouded by uncertainty over the extent to which exporters and importers were timing shipments to profit from currency market shifts.

headline: Putin Warns of Restricting Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials threatened on Wednesday to restrict supplies of natural gas to Ukraine, and they reiterated the Kremlin’s contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.

headline: The Importance of Being Nicky
text: The legendary Nicky Haslam’s exuberant interiors are the mark of an audaciously unparalleled man. When it came to decorating his own new home, he threw out all the rules of good taste and embraced the phoniest of fakes.

headline: Vintage Studio Portraits of Indian Women From the Peak of British Colonialism
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: In Milan, Martino Gamper’s Clever Scheme to Showcase Italian Craft Traditions
text: People have been talking about the London-based Italian designer Martino Gamper since the opening of his playful, shelving-focused exhibit “Design Is a State of Mind” at the Serpentine Gallery. This week he also brought his irreverent touch to Milan, where visitors to Salone di Mobile can find his latest work at Nilufar Gallery or admire his windows for the department store Rinascente. Gamper also presented a third project, the exhibition “FROM—TO,” in which he was involved less as a designer, and more as a curator.

headline: The Reinvention of Minimalism
text: In his elegantly spare Paris apartment, architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand introduces sensuous materials and classical elements to sublime effect.

headline: A ‘Code Death’ for Dying Patients
text: Sadly, but with conviction, I recently removed breathing tubes from three patients in intensive care.

headline: Heroes of Banking Reform
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | dross
text: dross•\ˈdräs, ˈdrȯs\• noun

headline: Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by Tanaka
text: Nelson Cruz smirked at the question, more irritated than amused by the suggestion that he might have been curious to see Masahiro Tanaka in person. The hype of a $155 million contract and another pinstriped sensation from Japan did not do much for Cruz, the Baltimore Orioles’ left fielder.

headline: Walmart to Sell Organic Food, Undercutting Big Brands
text: Walmart plans to announce on Thursday that it is putting its muscle behind Wild Oats organic products, offering the label at prices that will undercut brand-name organic competitors by at least 25 percent.

headline: Pro Bowl to Join Super Bowl in 2015
text: The N.F.L. Pro Bowl will be played in Glendale, Ariz., next year, a week before the Super Bowl is held there. It is the first time the Pro Bowl and Super Bowl will be played in the same city since 2010, when both games were held in Miami Gardens, Fla. The N.F.L. said the Pro Bowl would return to Hawaii in 2016, but the league did not say where the game would be after that.

headline: J & R Closes Manhattan Store for a Redesign
text: J & R Music and Computer World, a mainstay music and electronics store in Lower Manhattan for 43 years, closed its doors on Wednesday to redesign its space on Park Row.

headline: Times Minute | Why L.B.J. Still Matters
text: Today on the Minute, commemorating 50 years since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act.

headline: Golfers Hoping for Winning Introduction to Masters
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Twenty-four Masters rookies are in this year’s field, a modern-era record, increasing the chances that someone will become the fourth player to win in his inaugural Augusta National Golf Club appearance.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Sheldon (Jim Parsons, above) has a meltdown after deciding that he is wasting his time on string theory. In “The Millers,” at 8:30, Carol (Margo Martindale) adds her dentist to the Miller Family Blacklist for charging a late fee, so Nathan (Will Arnett) must take his personal relationship with her underground. In “Two and a Half Men,” at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) decides that Kate (Brooke D’Orsay) is the One — until he meets Vivian (Mila Kunis). And in “The Crazy Ones,” at 9:30, Simon (Robin Williams) thinks he may have found the One (Pam Dawber) as well, but he becomes disillusioned with love after Gordon (Brad Garrett) and his partner break up. David Copperfield appears as himself.

headline: In I.P.O., a Quest to Satisfy China’s Appetite for Pork
text: HONG KONG — There is a commodity creating ravenous demand among China’s growing consumer class, one whose pricing is so important that it influences the Chinese central bank’s monetary policy. The commerce ministry even maintains strategic reserves and has been piling them higher in recent weeks in an attempt to stabilize prices.

headline: Corrections: April 10, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: In French Premier’s Blend of Socialism, Conservative and Centrist Notes
text: PARIS — France’s new prime minister introduced the country this week to his particular brand of Socialist Party politics: more centrist on social issues, more conservative economically and more combative than the man who appointed him, President François Hollande.

headline: What’s Next in the Search for Flight 370
text: Investigators have narrowed down the search area for the missing Malaysian jetliner, but it could be weeks or months before they find any trace of the plane.

headline: Setting Up an Election in the World’s Largest Democracy
text: MEERUT, India — Raj Singh endured hot winds as he feverishly operated a sewing machine outdoors to repair tents that had ripped in a storm the night before.

headline: Dogged Prosecutor Seeks to Paint Pistorius as a Bully
text: Oscar Pistorius, the South African athlete accused of murdering his girlfriend, faced new questions on Thursday from a dogged prosecutor intent on depicting him as a narcissistic bully who routinely berated her and recklessly carried a loaded gun everywhere he went.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 10, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Students End Occupation of Taiwan’s Legislature
text: Updated, 8:20 a.m.ET | Hundreds of protesters who occupied Taiwan’s legislature for more than three weeks decamped Thursday evening, bringing to an end a standoff over the handling of a trade pact with China.

headline: Piramal to Sell Vodafone India Stake for $1.48 Billion
text: LONDON – Piramal Enterprises, the largest minority investor in Vodafone India, said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its entire stake in the business to the British telecommunications company Vodafone.

headline: In Mongolia, a Gift Horse for Hagel
text: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel knew even before he landed here that there was no way he could keep the horse.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Student Stabs 20 People at High School Near Pittsburgh
text: In “Student Stabs 20 People at High School Near Pittsburgh,” Timothy Williams and Emma G. Fitzsimmons report on a mass knife attack on Wednesday.

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside Greek Central Bank
text: ATHENS — A large car bomb exploded outside Greece’s central bank Thursday morning, shaking buildings for blocks around but causing no injuries.

headline: European Union Debates Initiative on Embryo Protection
text: BRUSSELS — A packed hearing on a petition calling for the protection of human embryos led to a rare outbreak of raucous exchanges in the European Parliament on Thursday — a sign that the battles over abortion and stem cell research that divide nations like Spain and the United States are making a serious incursion into European Union affairs.

headline: The Paramedic Murderer of Narrowsburg, N.Y.
text: In the hills around Narrowsburg, N.Y., where second-home owners tend gardens and the Lenape once roamed, people don’t forget a mysterious death. They still talk about the bar owner who shot his waitress in the chest late one night and served just six months in jail after saying it was an accident. Then there was the story about the man who arrived home one night only to notice that his wife, who had been in the back seat, was no longer in the car. Her body was found on the side of a road along the route he’d taken. Charges were never filed.

headline: Personalities Beyond Fists and Faces
text: Holger Keifel spent eight years as a shadow in the court of boxing royalty, making portraits of fighters, trainers and promoters in the corners of rooms where he did not belong. The best of three or four frames captured in the fleeting moments of a news conference, weigh-in or short breathers between sparring sessions — each was a jab.

headline: Drinking Milk Linked to Arthritis Relief
text: A large study has found evidence that milk consumption may slow the progression of knee arthritis.

headline: Do You Like to Exercise?
text: A recent genetics study of lab rats seems to suggest that the motivation to exercise — or not — may be partly inherited, at least for small rodents. Perhaps some of us are born to enjoy exercise, while others — not so much.

headline: Group Says It Has Raised Over $1.7 Million for Hillary Clinton
text: Ready for Hillary, the independent group devised to build support for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s potential 2016 presidential campaign, said Thursday that it had brought in 22,000 new donors and raised more than $1.7 million in the three-month period that ended March 31.

headline: New York Today: Take Out the Compost
text: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Free to Be Mean: Does This Student Satire Cross the Line?
text: On a recent cloudless afternoon, a group of young comedy writers — one in Ray-Bans and a floppy wizard hat, another in skateboard sneakers and funky jeans — descended upon San Diego State University’s palm-tree-dotted campus, brandishing copies of their latest creation: a 12-page broadsheet of lewd humor.

headline: Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is More Likely Ancient Than Fake, Scientists Say
text: A faded fragment of papyrus known as the “Gospel of Jesus’s Wife,” which caused an uproar when unveiled by a Harvard Divinity School historian in 2012, has been tested by scientists who conclude in a journal published on Thursday that the ink and papyrus are very likely ancient, and not a modern forgery.

headline: Tesla’s Lightweight Solution to Preventing Model S Fires
text: A cloud of doubt lingering over Tesla Motors parted on March 26, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed an investigation of the Model S begun in response to two cars that were destroyed by fires after striking objects on the highway.

headline: The Trouble With Too Much T
text: In 2009, the South African middle-distance runner Caster Semenya was barred from competition and obliged to undergo intrusive and humiliating “sex testing” after fellow athletes at the Berlin World Championships questioned her sex. Ms. Semenya was eventually allowed to compete again, but the incident opened the world’s eyes to the process of sex testing and the distress it could bring to an athlete who had lived her whole life as a girl. When an endocrinologist, a gynecologist and a psychologist were brought in to determine whether the teenager was really a woman, she simply asserted, “I know who I am.”

headline: Daily Report: As the Internet Grows, It Grows Less Secure
text: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi — an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot, Farhad Manjoo writes in his State of the Art column.

headline: China Sets Hong Kong-Shanghai Trading Deal
text: HONG KONG — It was a seven-year wait, but China on Thursday finally announced a plan to allow two-way investment between the Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges.

headline: Who Are Hit Men?
text: STORNOWAY, Scotland — Everyone starts as a novice, whatever your job. You bumble around, make mistakes, learn by doing. It applies in any walk of life, and the criminal industry isn’t any different. A team from Birmingham City University’s Center for Applied Criminology has carried out the first typological study of British hit men, and it starts, of course, with the novice.

headline: In Our Pages: April 11
text: 1914: Eavesdropping End Promised

headline: Photos: The Making of the Masters
text: When Augusta National Golf Club opened in 1933, there were few hints at the grandeur of its future. Bobby Jones, having retired from golf as an amateur at age 28, wanted a place to play golf in private. After winning 13 major titles, he was swarmed at any golf course he strolled on to, so he sought a course of his own, where he could invite his friends to join as members. Clifford Roberts, an investment banker and friend, helped him acquire the 385 acres that would become Augusta National and together they steered their little club into history.

headline: It’s Official: No Deductible Caps in Small-Business Health Plans
text: Tucked inside the so-called Medicare “doc fix” bill — must-pass legislation to forestall steep cuts in payments to doctors — that President Obama recently signed was a separate provision that removed restrictions on deductibles in small-business health plans. As a result, small-business owners may be able to shift some of their health care costs, especially as they increase, to their workers.

headline: Twitter and Facebook Wield Little Influence on TV Watching
text: Listen to executives at Twitter and Facebook talk about how we watch television and you might walk away thinking that Americans are chattering nonstop on the social networks while watching their favorite shows.

headline: The Oscar Pistorius I Knew
text: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer to The Times Magazine, wrote a cover article in 2012 on Oscar Pistorius, who is now being tried in the shooting death of his girlfriend.

headline: RLM Finsbury Names New President
text: RLM Finsbury, a strategic communications and advisory firm, said on Thursday that Stephen Labaton would become its United States president.

headline: Bank of England Holds Key Rate at 0.5%
text: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday left a key interest rate unchanged at a record low, as Britain’s economy continues to recover and inflation remains in decline.

headline: Times Minute | Why L.B.J. Still Matters
text: In the Video

headline: Tachyus, a Data Start-Up for Oil Industry, Raises $6 Million From Founders Fund
text: Since graduating from Stanford in 2011, Dakin Sloss has already co-founded two start-ups, including the government data analysis company OpenGov.

headline: Authorities Cast Doubt on Signal in Jet Search
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities searching for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane said Friday that the latest potential signal was probably not from the flight recorders, despite hopes raised the previous day.

headline: Coffee, Tea or Liberation?
text: So many momentous things happened in 1969.

headline: Watch Proteins Do the Jitterbug
text: If you could shrink down to the size of a molecule and fly into a cell, what would you see?

headline: Morning Agenda: Junior Banker Blues
text: JUNIOR BANKERS STILL WORK LONG HOURS  |  In the last six months, many of the biggest investment banks have signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules and take a few weekend days off. But like other practices on Wall Street, the more things change, the more they stay the same, William Alden and Sydney Ember write in DealBook.

headline: R.B.S. Agreement Opens Door for Future Dividends
text: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland has reached a deal with the British government that will pave the way for it to pay dividends in the future.

headline: All Eyes on Delhi As It Goes To Vote
text: NEW DELHI — The nation’s capital went to the polls on Thursday in a three-way race for Delhi’s seven parliamentary seats that could be a bellwether of the national elections.

headline: Ending Vitriol, Icahn and eBay Reach a Deal
text: Last month, Carl C. Icahn appeared ready to take no prisoners in his battle with eBay, calling the online commerce giant among the worst-run companies he had ever seen.

headline: Taking a Risk, Investors Snap Up Once-Shunned Greek Debt
text: ATHENS — Investors shunned Greek bonds at the height of the European economic crisis, fearful that the region’s sickest nation would collapse from its financial woes.

headline: Seeking More From Chinese Films
text: There was a sting to the China Film Directors’ Guild awards in Beijing this week, when the director Feng Xiaogang, the head of the jury, announced that the guild would not award the top prizes — film of the year and director of the year. The reason? No film in contention was good enough: Chinese films need to meet “a higher standard,” Mr. Feng said.

headline: Massacre in a Nairobi Mall
text: The Shabab, an Islamist militant group based in Somalia, took responsibility for the attack, saying it was revenge for Kenya’s military operations in Somalia.

headline: G.M. Places 2 Engineers on Leave in Inquiry
text: DETROIT — The ignition-switch scandal at General Motors widened on Thursday as the automaker suspended two engineers and added another repair to its recall of cars with a faulty ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths.

headline: The Woman Within
text: Reed Birney and Patrick Page, actors in Harvey Fierstein’s new Broadway play “Casa Valentina,” learn the art of cross-dressing.

headline: Clothes Make the Man
text: Before rehearsals began for the new Broadway play “Casa Valentina,” the seven men in the cast were asked to come to work a few days early. They arrived to find a huge table covered with ladies’ wigs in ’60s-era hairdos — flips, bobs, French twists. Nearby was a long rack of colorful house dresses and white slips and brassieres. Yet no one made a move. The actors shared small talk, sipped coffee, checked their smartphones and looked around as if the room were empty.

headline: Ruth Rathblott, of Harlem Educational Activities Fund, on Seeking Opportunities
text: This interview with Ruth Rathblott, chief executive of the nonprofit Harlem Educational Activities Fund, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: U.S. Court Seems Split on Utah Gay Marriage Ban
text: DENVER — The push for same-sex marriage, which has celebrated victory after victory in courtrooms across the country, entered an uncertain stage on Thursday as a federal appeals court appeared divided about whether the socially conservative state of Utah could limit marriage to a man and a woman.

headline: Fast-Growing Sectors Drive a Market Sell-Off
text: Investors dumped Internet, biotechnology and other fast-growing companies at a dizzying pace on Thursday, dragging down the rest of the stock market and stirring up painful memories of the dot-com bust in 2000.

headline: Michael Lewis: By the Book
text: The author of “Liar’s Poker,” “The Blind Side” and, most recently, “Flash Boys” says it’s hard to dramatize the quotidian in a way that makes it fresh for readers: “It’s like describing the air we breathe.”

headline: From Smallest of Clues, Flying Reptiles Reborn
text: About 220 million years ago, as we learn at a thoroughly entrancing new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, a fish caught a pterosaur, chewed it up and spit out the pieces. The expelled mass eventually fossilized, creating what is decorously called a “gastric pellet.” We see its cast here: a compact, egg-size mound of spindly, bent, broken and crushed sticks.

headline: Don’t Hoodwink the Help, Dear
text: In the first moments of our acquaintance with Johanna Parry — before the opening titles of “Hateship Loveship” appear on screen, and before the first notes of music have sounded — we know some important things about her. We note her kindness as she grants an old woman’s dying wish, and also her practicality and physical strength. Other people will perceive Johanna as drab, passive and unworldly, a person to be quietly mocked or carelessly ignored, but the first shots of Liza Johnson’s new film, adapted from a story by the Canadian Nobel laureate Alice Munro, provide important evidence to the contrary.

headline: Qatar Investment Executive Said to Start Hedge Fund
text: LONDON — A top investment executive at Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund is leaving to start a hedge fund, people briefed on the development said.

headline: Why Students Are Tested, and Why Some Parents Opt Out
text: Amid protests and debate, “unprecedented” numbers of students opted out of New York State’s English Language Arts testing this month. Some parents opted out as a way to voice their objections over the practice of administering federally mandated standardized tests, others because of concerns over how test results are used to evaluate schools and teachers. Many parents are simply confused about the origin and purpose of the standardized tests all children are required to take and what it means to opt out of them. Consequently, I thought I’d use this week’s column to explain the nuts and bolts of standardized testing and opt-outs.

headline: House Tour | Joseph Dirand
text: The architect takes T through his luxuriously minimal Paris apartment and discusses why he favors function over form in decoration.

headline: 36 Hours in Seville, Spain
text: You don’t have to spend long in Seville to see why so many operas have been set there. A sense of drama pervades the Andalusian capital, from its Moorish royal palaces and extravagant Catholic festivals to the way the strum of a guitar tends to send a whole room into syncopated clapping. Maybe it’s this penchant for pomp that keeps the city dynamic in lean times. At contemporary-minded shops, restaurants and arts spaces that continue to open among Seville’s tangle of narrow stone alleyways, a friendly localism seems to rule the day.

headline: How the Aam Aadmi Party Lost Its Way
text: NEW DELHI — One morning last December, I traveled from my house to Ramlila Maidan, a sprawling area in central Delhi, where Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, was to be inaugurated as the city’s new chief minister.

headline: Briton Named President of ABC News
text: ABC put in place the missing piece of its succession plans Thursday, naming James Goldston the president of ABC News, replacing Ben Sherwood.

headline: ScienceTake: Those Clever Crows
text: Scientists are trying to understand the limits to the well-established intelligence of crows.

headline: The Moral: Aesop Knew Something About Crows
text: Crows and their relatives, like jays and rooks, are definitely in the gifted class when it comes to the kinds of cognitive puzzles that scientists cook up.

headline: Shares in Ally Dip in Their Debut
text: Updated, 6:17 p.m. |

headline: Indian Candidate’s Biography Has an Asterisk: A Wife, of Sorts
text: NEW DELHI — At a campaign rally this year, Narendra Modi, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, offered this curious qualification for the post of India’s prime minister: He could not possibly be corrupt because he is a bachelor.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘A Poem of Changgan’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “A Poem of Changgan” by Li Po and the Sunday Review article “Romance at Arm’s Length” by Daniel Jones.

headline: Day 2 of Pistorius Cross-Examination
text: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius returned to the stand to face new questions from the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, on the fourth day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Does the Rock Hall of Fame Matter?
text: Amid the usual debate about who belongs in the Hall of Fame and who gets to decide, why should music lovers care?

headline: Will ‘House of Cards’ Deal Elsewhere?
text: House of Cards, the Netflix depiction of a Machiavellian America, has been tight with the government of Maryland. So tight, in fact, that it has enjoyed not just $26.7-million in show business tax credits for filming its award-winning production there, but also use of the legislature’s debating floor as an occasional set.

headline: It’s Time for Africa’s Green Revolution, Focused on Corn
text: I hope you’ll read Tina Rosenberg’s latest Fixes post — “A Green Revolution, This Time for Africa.” The first Green Revolution, in Asia, was centered on rice and wheat. Rosenberg lays out the case for an African focus on corn (known as maize almost everywhere else in the world):

headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Albuquerque Police of Excessive Force
text: ALBUQUERQUE — At least 37 times in the last four years, police officers here have responded to threats with bullets, killing 23 people and wounding 14 others. On Thursday, the Justice Department weighed in with a scathing assessment, accusing the Albuquerque Police Department of a “pattern or practice of use of excessive force” that routinely violated people’s constitutional rights.

headline: Today in Small Business: Saving the Family Business
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Picture Becomes a Weapon in a Bank’s Proxy Battle
text: “Below is a picture taken at last year’s annual shareholder meeting of our bank’s chairman,” the two-sentence shareholder letter from the activist investor Joseph Stilwell began. “None of the other board members bothered to wake him up.”

headline: U.N. to Send Peacekeepers to Central African Republic
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Thursday voted unanimously to send 12,000 peacekeepers authorized to do whatever necessary to protect civilians in the Central African Republic, where a vicious sectarian conflict has effectively partitioned the country into Christian and Muslim swaths and left a trail of gruesome killings.

headline: Quebec City Festival Offers Music Fans a Summer Bargain
text: The Festival d’été de Québec, now in its 47th year, will offer more than 300 performances in Quebec City, from July 3 to 13, the festival announced on Thursday. The festival bills itself as Canada’s largest outdoor music event (although it presents shows at indoor venues as well). It is also one of the bargains of the festival circuit: a festival pass, which allows access to all shows, is priced at 78 Canadian dollars (about $72); the first 60,000 passes will sell for 68 Canadian dollars (about $62). A spokesman said that 300,000 people attended the festival last summer.

headline: Times Minute | Jesus’ Wife?
text: Also on the Minute, federal courts review same-sex marriage and a voyage into a neuron.

headline: Times Minute | Did Jesus Have a Wife?
text: In the Video

headline: Fire Death Leads Police to Codify Protocols
text: The New York Police Department has issued mandatory protocols for officers entering buildings in response to fires, after an officer responding to a blaze in a Brooklyn high-rise died.

headline: Colbert Will Host ‘Late Show,’ Playing Himself for a Change
text: CBS made its choice, quickly and definitively: Stephen Colbert will succeed David Letterman as the host of its late-night franchise, which Mr. Letterman created when he came to the network in 1993.

headline: In Villages Torn by Violence, Traditional Loyalties at Risk
text: FUGANA, India — Sakur Ahmed, an ironsmith, is a member of the only Muslim family left in the village of Fugana, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, where violence between Muslims and Hindu Jats erupted in September. When Muslims fled the village, Mr. Ahmed, protected by a Hindu neighbor, chose to stay.

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside Bank of Greece
text: The deputy prime minister of Greece, Evangelos Venizelos, spoke after a large car bomb exploded outside Greece’s central bank on Thursday morning.

headline: Cuomo Caught Up in Rare Conflict With Prosecutor
text: IRONDEQUOIT, N.Y. — An unusually public confrontation between two of the state’s most powerful officials escalated on Thursday. Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, not known for engaging in on-air rebukes of elected officeholders, took aim at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over his decision to dissolve an anticorruption panel.

headline: Judge Approves SAC Plea, Closing a Painful Chapter
text: Updated, 9:40 p.m. | In the span of a week, Steven A. Cohen’s investment firm changed its name, hired a former federal prosecutor and became a felon.

headline: Look Again, With Love and Liebling
text: Jerome Liebling’s career was devoted to the idea that every person has value and dignity. A new exhibit shows that sentiment with lyric beauty.

headline: Wheelies: The BMW X6-Fighter Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Greenish Shootlets in Southern Europe (Implicitly Wonkish)
text: There are hints of recovery in some of Europe’s austerity-stricken economies. Even Greece is finally showing some signs of an uptick. And you know one thing is going to happen: some people will say, “See — growth despite austerity! Krugman and the Keynesians were wrong!”

headline: Microsoft Touts Data Protection Approval in Europe; Eager for New Customers
text: LONDON – Online privacy is heating up as a selling point, at least in Europe.

headline: House-Passed Budget Shows Parties’ Divergence
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Rodney Davis won his House seat in 2012 by barely a thousand votes, making him a leading candidate as Target No. 1 for Democrats who are eager to make his support for the latest House Republican budget a centerpiece of the fall campaign.

headline: CNN to Show Documentaries in 9 P.M. Time Slot
text: CNN is getting out of the host business in its 9 p.m. time slot, at least for now.

headline: Segal Awards Go to JACK Quartet and Melissa Aldana
text: A quartet and a saxophonist won this year’s Martin E. Segal Awards, given to emerging artists who are associated with Lincoln Center.

headline: Evidence Comes Up Short as Egypt Tries 3 Journalists
text: CAIRO — Prosecutors on Thursday were unable to produce video footage that they say is the basis of their case against three journalists accused of conspiring to broadcast false reports about civil strife in Egypt. Instead, they showed a Cairo courtroom footage of family photographs, trotting horses and Somali refugees in Kenya.

headline: Oversight Committee Censures Ex-I.R.S. Official for Refusal to Take Questions
text: WASHINGTON — A House committee voted on Thursday to hold a former Internal Revenue Service official in contempt for refusing to answer its questions about her role in holding up applications for tax exemption from conservative political groups before the last election.

headline: Live Nation to Open Outdoor Concert Venue at Manhattan Pier
text: Roseland is no more, but another new space for concerts is opening in Manhattan.

headline: Videos Dismissed in Al Jazeera Case
text: Mike Greste, the brother of a detained Al Jazeera journalist, Peter Greste, commented after an Egyptian judge dismissed videos presented by the prosecution. The image above is from March 31.

headline: Plaintiffs on Utah’s Ban on Gay Marriage
text: Two of the plaintiffs in a case challenging Utah’s ban on gay marriage, Moudi Sbeity and Derek Kitchen, discussed why they were pursuing the lawsuit.

headline: ‘A Night With Janis Joplin’ Cancels Off Broadway Run
text: Just a day before “A Night With Janis Joplin” was to have started its second New York run, producers announced on late Wednesday they were canceling the show.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Joe’
text: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from his film featuring Nicolas Cage and Tye Sheridan.

headline: How Many Minutes Does It Take?
text: Ben Werschkul is the senior producer for news in the video department at The Times.

headline: Sacrificing Sense for Speed in Markets
text: Rube Goldberg: A comically involved, complicated invention, laboriously contrived to perform a seemingly simple operation.

headline: Image of the Day: April 10
text: Rahul Gandhi, leader of the Congress party’s election campaign, cast his vote in New Delhi.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Of Mice and Men’ and ‘Friendship in an Age of Economics’
text: As John Steinbeck’s novel “The Grapes of Wrath” prepares to celebrate its 75th birthday, its oft-taught brother, “Of Mice and Men,” is in previews on Broadway.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Sydney Women’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: 50 Years Later, Obama Salutes Effects of Civil Rights Act
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — For three days, the veterans of a long-ago movement reunited and drew together their spiritual heirs to explore the legacy of the Civil Rights Act a half-century after it transformed America. And then the legacy walked onstage.

headline: No Handouts From These Rabbits
text: TIMOTHY HASKELL, he of the slightly twisted imagination who regularly scares people as the creator and director of the “Nightmare“ haunted houses in New York around Halloween, has something new and a bit less diabolical planned for Easter weekend: Full Bunny Contact, a carnival more focused on fun than on fright.

headline: A Series of ‘Cataclysmic Events,’ at Good Prices
text: As a freshman in college, the Miser naïvely chose to fulfill his science requirement with an introductory course in astronomy. He dug space as much as the next guy. A semester of looking at the stars? Compared with balancing equations, calculating vectors or dissecting dead animals, how hard could it be?

headline: Why Liberalism Needs Pluralism
text: Just to ride a little further on my recent hobbyhorse, pluralism, I thought this Andrew Sullivan analysis of the divide between same-sex marriage supporters over the treatment of Brendan Eich was useful in thinking through some wider political issues as well.

headline: BMW Recalls 156,000 Vehicles With 6-Cylinder Engines
text: BMW is recalling about 156,000 vehicles equipped with 6-cylinder engines because a defect could cause stalling or engine damage, the automaker said in a news release Thursday. The action comes almost two years after the automaker began fixing the same models in China, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: David Gordon Green Narrates a Scene From ‘Joe’
text: Nicolas Cage has an intimate moment with a venomous snake in this scene from “Joe,” narrated by the director David Gordon Green and also featuring Tye Sheridan. Mr. Green discusses how the scene was shot using a handful of non-traditional actors and a real cottonmouth snake.

headline: Mike Flanagan on ‘Oculus’
text: The director discusses his horror film about a haunted mirror.

headline: Tax Revenue Rockets Up, Helping Lessen the Deficit, Treasury Department Says
text: The economy may be plodding along. But business is booming for Uncle Sam.

headline: Upgrades for Historic Luxury Hotels
text: After restoring some of its most historic hotels last year, including the Gritti Palace in Venice and the Hotel Maria Cristina in San Sebastian, Spain, the Luxury Collection from Starwood Hotels & Resorts announced a second round of upgrades, this time to two more historic properties, the Hotel Imperial in Vienna and the Excelsior Hotel Gallia in Milan, and two more-modern ones including Santa Marina Resort in Mykonos, Greece, and Grand Hills in Broumana, Lebanon.

headline: The Treasure Rests at the Bottom
text: How is the English language so impoverished that we do not have a word for the glory of rice brought nearly to a scorch at the bottom of a pot? The Spanish call it socarrat; the Chinese, guo ba. It is graten in Haiti, nurungji in Korea, pegao in Puerto Rico, khao tang in Thailand, xoon in Senegal.

headline: Next Guessing Game: Who Will Replace Colbert?
text: “Stephen Colbert” is dead. Long live Stephen Colbert. One day after I wrote of the downside of replacing David Letterman with Stephen Colbert, CBS went ahead and did exactly that.

headline: N.H.L. Promoted Violence Regardless of Health Risk, Players’ Suit Says
text: Nine former professional hockey players have filed a lawsuit against the N.H.L. that says the league “intentionally created, fostered and promoted a culture of extreme violence.”

headline: Icahn May Someday Win, and eBay Will Spin Off PayPal
text: Carl C. Icahn has lost the battle of bluster at eBay. The activist investor is quitting his proxy fight now that the company is appointing one new director and agreeing to talk to him. Considering that Mr. Icahn had “never seen worse governance” and was broadly right about the benefits of eBay separating its PayPal unit, that’s a retreat. But he may yet win the war.

headline: Common Core Gets Strong Defense From State Education Chief
text: Under sustained attack over new standardized tests and learning standards, the New York State education commissioner told an audience on Thursday that “we’re not retreating” and that the constant criticism was damaging an overdue effort to raise student achievement.

headline: Officials Approve U.N. Peacekeeping Unit
text: The French and American ambassadors to the United Nations, Gérard Araud and Samantha Power, and the Central African Republic’s foreign minister discussed the United Nations peacekeeping operation.

headline: Living With Cancer: Bedtime Issues
text: Like the other women in my cancer support group, I have been trying to salvage aspects of the person I had been before the diagnosis.

headline: Border Capture, Seen From Above
text: On a helicopter with its pilot and a Border Patrol chief, a reporter and photographer for The New York Times watched migrants crossing the Rio Grande and turning themselves in.

headline: The Early Years of Stockholm’s Mega Home-Design Store
text: The only way to really understand how much the Stockholm design emporium Svenskt Tenn stands for Swedish style is to go and visit the store. What Hermès and Fortnum & Mason are to Paris and London, respectively — beacons that help foreigners better grasp the culture of the town they’re in — Svenskt Tenn is to their northern and more mysterious sister. At the 90-year-old department store, you can buy almost anything for the home, from one of the deepest production sofas in the world to a doorstop shaped like an acorn — anything, that is, but something boring. It’s fitting that the ground floor of the store includes an art gallery with a rotating schedule of shows.

headline: Obama Pays Tribute to Civil Rights Act
text: President Obama delivered remarks on the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act at the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex.

headline: Icahn’s Feud With eBay Generated Noise, but Slight Bump for Shares
text: Updated, 5:47 p.m. | In his monthslong battle with eBay, Carl C. Icahn accused the online commerce site of failing to generate bigger returns for shareholders.

headline: Eli Manning Has Surgery on Ankle He Injured in Season Finale
text: Giants quarterback Eli Manning had arthroscopic surgery on his left ankle Thursday to relieve pain associated with a sprain he sustained in the last game of the season.

headline: Hoping for Asylum, Migrants Strain U.S. Border
text: HIDALGO, Tex. — Border Patrol agents in olive uniforms stood in broad daylight on the banks of the Rio Grande, while on the Mexican side smugglers pulled up in vans and unloaded illegal migrants.

headline: A Journey North, From Farther South
text: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.

headline: The Gun Report: April 10, 2014
text: More than 300 people banned from owning guns—including felons, fugitives and people with histories of mental illness—were able to buy them in Maryland last year because state police were flooded with background check requests, The Baltimore Sun reported yesterday. And because of a loophole that allows gun dealers to release firearms after waiting a week, regardless of whether a check is done, 51,812 guns were handed out prematurely.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: exercise enjoyment, Medicare dollars and pregnancy risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Centuries of Judaica From Life and Rites in Muslim Lands
text: Artifacts from Sephardic Jews who fled Muslim countries, typically with few possessions in hand, are re-emerging and being reunited in virtual and tangible forms.

headline: Benghazi: ‘The Administration Has Won’
text: Remember Karl Rove wandering around the Fox News set on election night 2012, trying to convince his colleagues that Mitt Romney, and not Barack Obama, had won the state of Ohio?

headline: A Journey North, From Farther South
text: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.

headline: In Search of ‘Wild’ Costa Rica
text: By the end of our fourth day on the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica, we had seen, according to the tally kept by my 9-year-old, Sasha, dozens of species of animals. We had peered at leafcutter ants, army ants and zombie ants. We had been deafened by howler monkeys, beguiled by squirrel monkeys and strangely stirred by capuchin monkeys, whose feet bear an eerie resemblance to human hands. That afternoon, in the national park that covers a third of the peninsula, we had even spied two tapirs, endangered mammals that look like hornless rhinoceroses with long snouts.

headline: An Auctioneer Comes Back to the Business
text: The rumors started Sunday, when the Qatar Museums Authority said that Edward Dolman, its executive director and acting chief executive, was stepping down after three years.

headline: De Blasio, Marking 100 Days on Job, Says ‘Grass Roots’ Will Drive Agenda
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to recapture the energy that propelled him to victory last November, marked his 100th day in office on Thursday with a rhetoric-heavy speech that called on his supporters to help him create a “people-powered government” in New York.

headline: Reverse Mortgage Realities
text: Adult children have reason to be wary when their parents start talking about reverse mortgages. The loans make sense only for those who plan to stay in their homes for the rest of their lives and can afford to pay property taxes and insurance for that long.

headline: Abusing Both Medicare and Politics
text: Campaign finance reformers have long warned that the growing power of big money in politics would produce a giant scandal. But those scandals happen every day, and the trading of campaign donations for political favors has steadily eroded public trust in Washington. The latest illustration of that can be seen in the connection between Medicare fraud and “super PAC” abuse.

headline: Minimalist Show, Minimally Revised
text: Museum art exhibitions are painfully ephemeral. Once they close, they are gone, except for their catalogs and documentary photographs. This has understandably spurred visions of time travel among curators and curators in training.

headline: The Battle for Late Night Viewers on Screens of All Sizes
text: Congratulations, Stephen Colbert! You’ve been crowned one of the kings of late night television, succeeding David Letterman as host of the “Late Show,” CBS’s flagship late-night franchise.

headline: Exploring the Amazon in ‘Rio 2’
text: Images from “Rio 2” of sequences set in the Amazon rain forest.

headline: A Protégé of James Turrell Makes His New York Debut (With Lasers and Holograms, Naturally)
text: As a child growing up in Ohio, the artist Matthew Schreiber was fascinated by the lasers he saw in “Star Wars” and at the theme park Ontario Place in Toronto, which he visited with his family. Years later, he began incorporating them into his art practice, and today he will unveil those efforts, including a mesmerizing room filled with darting red beams of light, in his first New York solo show, “Sideshow,” on view through May 10 at Johannes Vogt.

headline: Yee I-Lann: ‘Picturing Power’
text: Tyler Rollins Fine Art

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Indonesia, Israel and Russia.

headline: Kristen Morgin: ‘The Super Can Man and Other Illustrated Classics’
text: Zach Feuer

headline: Peter Buggenhout: ‘Caterpillar Logic II’
text: Gladstone Gallery

headline: Paris-Roubaix’s Quaint Course Is Viciously Bumpy
text: WALLERS, France — On one side, the rock was as flinty and jagged as a chipped tooth. On the other, its edge was caved in, so the surface sheared away sharply. Squatting in the dirt, Clement Huchez examined the stone, rolling it in his hands for a few moments. Then he slid it into the rubble puzzle in front of him and exclaimed, “It’s perfect!”

headline: Greece Returns to the Bond Markets
text: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Joaquín Almunia, and the Greek finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, said Greece’s return to the bond markets was good news for the whole euro zone.

headline: Joe Sola: ‘American Sex Room and other Works’
text: Blackston

headline: Letters: Canon Fire
text: Canon Fire

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 63
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Iván Navarro: ‘This Land is Your Land’
text: Madison Square Park

headline: The Cubs of Wall Street
text: Imagine you’re a scientist in some sci-fi alternate universe, and you’ve been charged with creating a boot camp that will reliably turn normal but ambitious people into broken sociopaths more or less willing to do anything.

headline: The Justice Gap
text: “Low-class people do low-class things.” What’s notable in this reflexive dismissal of those with modest means are not the words themselves. Rather, please turn your attention to the person whom Matt Taibbi, in his ambitious new book documenting America’s unequal administration of justice to rich and poor, quotes saying them: a private attorney hired by New York State to defend low-income people in criminal court. We never learn his name, but Taibbi calls him Waldorf because he resembles the grouchy old balcony heckler on “The Muppet Show.”

headline: Demolished Club Casts a Long Shadow
text: The developer HFZ Capital is proposing a new building for the empty lot at 20 West 40th Street, and the Historic Districts Council is not happy, protesting that the flat-topped 32-story tower is out of place on a street that has long had “a picturesque skyline.”

headline: At One With Their Dogs, Growling and Snapping
text: The most indelible scenes in David Gordon Green’s “Joe,” filmed in the backwoods of Texas, have the fierce clarity of illuminations glimpsed in a lightning flash. In one lingering afterimage, a team of mostly African-American laborers, toiling in a desiccated pine forest, methodically poison sickly trees with “juice hatchets” (small axes that squirt deadly herbicide) to kill them off and make room for the planting of hardier species. These woodsmen, played by nonprofessionals, share an easy, rough-hewn camaraderie. They are the least tormented characters in “Joe,” a punishing exercise in Southern miserablism.

headline: An Alfresco Fling Beats Selling Tractors
text: Before Alain Guiraudie made his justly lauded “Stranger by the Lake,” he directed “The King of Escape,” a fresh, antic comedy that’s powered just as much by libido. In this case, sex is comedy, and Mr. Guiraudie makes the most of the anarchic freedoms of the genre. Originally shown at Cannes in 2009, “The King of Escape” matter-of-factly sketches out a randy patch of the French countryside, where cruising thrives among butch, gray-haired rustics and where aphrodisiac roots grow in the woods.

headline: Heads or Tails
text: The life of a penny.

headline: No Cause for Shame
text: My husband and I will soon be reunited with a couple we spent a lot time with in the ’80s, but haven’t seen much of since. Our sons, now both 34, used to play together, so I know the subject of children will come up. But our son has suffered from addiction for years, and lives on the edge of poverty because of the unfortunate choices he’s made. How do we deal with their questions without infringing on his privacy?

headline: What the Sea Took Away, a Daughter Restores
text: Fourteen years ago, my husband vanished. A talented sculptor whose work was in major collections, he had been in a downward spiral for over a year, unable to finish a single piece of work, tumbling into alcoholism, paralyzed by depression.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Art and Style Are Their Lifeblood
text: With their finely chiseled clavicles and cheekbones, their nocturnal habits and exquisite taste, Adam and Eve are about the coolest couple you could imagine. (They are played by Tom Hiddleston and Tilda Swinton, which definitely helps.) Adam lives in a vast apartment in the picturesque ruins of Detroit, surrounded by vinyl records and vintage guitars acquired by an eager young gofer named Ian (Anton Yelchin). Eve haunts the alleys of Tangier, speed-reading old books in every known language and lingering in an all-night cafe with Christopher Marlowe, who still regrets, five centuries after the fact, not receiving proper credit for Shakespeare’s plays.

headline: A Week’s Vigil, Then Easter Hallelujahs
text: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted otherwise, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) An expanded listing is available at nytimes.com/arts.

headline: Missing Ingredient on Minimum Wage: A Motivated G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Each of the three previous presidents — two Republicans, one Democrat — signed an increase in the federal minimum wage.

headline: For New York City Doormen, Some Closed Doors
text: It has been more than two decades since the city faced a large-scale strike by the doormen’s union. But this could change when its contract expires on April 20.

headline: 2 Regulators Issue Guidelines on Sharing Cyber Security Information
text: WASHINGTON – Sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said Thursday.

headline: Tenor Receives Richard Tucker Award
text: Michael Fabiano, a 29-year-old whose burnished tenor has made him one of the opera world’s most closely watched young singers, has won the $50,000 Richard Tucker Award, the foundation that gives the award announced on Thursday.

headline: A Delaware Court Flexes a Never-Tested Muscle
text: The Delaware Court of Chancery, known as the nation’s business court,  has now done something it had apparently never done before in its 222 years — issue an arrest warrant.

headline: Banned Group’s Leader Given Pakistani Parliament Seat After Vote Dispute
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s electoral commission has granted a parliamentary seat to the leader of a banned sectarian group that has long been accused of inciting violence against minority Shiites.

headline: Jazz Singer, Meet Big Band
text: When a jazz singer performs with a large band, transcendence arrives only at the moment that the disparate musical ingredients suddenly click into place, and you feel propelled by the acceleration of a mighty engine whose components all mesh. Such moments were infrequent on Tuesday evening at Birdland, where the singer Jane Monheit appeared with the Manhattan School of Music Swing Band. But the few times the elements jelled, the aligned forces achieved the state of bliss I like to call musical liftoff.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of Time for a 30th Anniversary
text: Stephen Petronio’s staying power, especially in the financially precarious world of modern dance, is breathtaking. Whether his sinuous, slippery choreography appeals or not — more on that later — he is committed.

headline: Writing a Playbook That Ensures Glory
text: Kevin Costner is one of the great salesmen in American movies, a natural-born closer. He’ll look you in the eye, start in with the pitch, and the next thing you know, you almost believe that Donald Sutherland and Lyndon Johnson killed Kennedy; that if you build a ballpark in the middle of a cornfield, “they will come”; and that “Dances With Wolves” is a better picture than “Goodfellas.” Something about him — the baby blues, the slightly weak chin, the aw-shucks manner, at once aggressive and self-effacing — makes him hard to resist, even when you know you’re being conned. That’s part of the appeal.

headline: Navigating the Art of Japan From a Different Direction
text: No compass is needed for “Points of Departure: Treasures of Japan From the Brooklyn Museum,” a radically reorienting show at Japan Society Gallery. Organized around the four cardinal directions, the show gives you a new way to navigate Japanese art — one that emphasizes regional cultures, outside influences and indigenous populations.

headline: Passions, ‘Superstar’ and More
text: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including drama, readings and processions. Free, unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

headline: Whiffs of Choral Ambrosia
text: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York. Free, unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

headline: The Breakfast That Preceded ‘The Dinner Party’
text: Love it or hate it, Judy Chicago’s “The Dinner Party” remains a great, enduringly provocative monument of feminist art. Permanently enshrined in a triangular room taking up most of the space allotted to the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art at the Brooklyn Museum, it consists of a three-sided banquet table with 39 elaborate place settings. Each is dedicated to a famous woman who is represented by the work’s most controversial feature: a fancifully stylized image of a vagina rendered in two or three dimensions on a large dinner plate.

headline: Androgynous Betrayals
text: The breadth, nerve and intricacy of Francine Prose’s big new novel should surprise even her most regular readers. A bona fide page turner, “Lovers at the Chameleon Club, Paris 1932” unfolds over 20 years, across an increasingly ominous Europe, among thugs and artists and poseurs who share only the danger that threatens to cramp their partying style. The Chameleon Club is their unofficial Paris headquarters, a cross-dressers’ heaven specializing in innocently filthy humor. But as that “chameleon” in that title indicates, everything here, even the Chameleon Club itself, is subject to wartime change.

headline: Origins Story, Through a Modern Lens
text: The photography world has been ruled in recent years by a fascination with abstraction and experimental processes and techniques. You see this everywhere in the current Association of International Photography Art Dealers show at the Park Avenue Armory. Even Hans P. Kraus Jr., who deals in photographic old masters, is showing — alongside vintage prints by Charles Marville, now featured in a show at the Metropolitan Museum, and Eugène Atget — some 19th-century pencil drawings by John Herschel, an important contributor to early photography. The drawings here, of Stonehenge and sights on the European Grand Tour, were made with a camera lucida, an optical device that functions in a manner similar to that of the camera obscura but in full daylight rather than a dark room.

headline: Theater Listings for April 11-17
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Warily, Jordan Assists Rebels in Syrian War
text: IRBID, Jordan — When rebels want to return to Syria to fight, Jordan’s intelligence services give them specific times to cross its border. When the rebels need weapons, they make their request at an “operations room” in Amman staffed by agents from Jordan, Saudi Arabia and the United States.

headline: Federal Regulators Advise Banks to Protect Their Systems From Internet Security Flaw
text: Updated, 7:17 p.m. | Federal regulators are advising banks to take steps to protect their systems from the Heartbleed Internet security flaw that could put sensitive customer information at risk.

headline: Lifetime Anguish Is the High Cost of Courage
text: What place is there nowadays for a solid, old-fashioned movie about war, remembrance and reconciliation? That question occurred to me while watching “The Railway Man,” an unabashedly stodgy, high-minded film in the David Lean tradition (without the grandeur), starring Colin Firth as Eric Lomax, a British Army officer who served and suffered during World War II.

headline: Sebelius Resigns After Troubles Over Health Site
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, is resigning, ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Official on Report on Albuquerque Police
text: The acting assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s civil rights division, Jocelyn Samuels, discussed an investigation that concluded the Albuquerque police used excessive force.

headline: Photo Diary | Milan Design Week 2014: Salone and Paul Smith
text: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.

text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for April 11-17
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Worry About a Smelly Rental
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Domesticated Macaws Reclaiming Their Wild Side
text: The cinematic equivalent of attack by kaleidoscope, “Rio 2” sucks you in and whirls you around before spitting you out, exhausted. A tropical tornado of cadmium and cobalt, magenta and marigold, Carlos Saldanha’s frantic follow-up to his well-received 2011 animated feature, “Rio,” ups the ante on sound and movement but pays scant attention to story. Prioritizing a sellable soundtrack — and a veiled plug for this year’s World Cup soccer tournament — over an original and engaging narrative might not have been the intent, but it sure feels that way.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
