text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Seeking Favor Among Those You Regulate
text: The strangest things become commonplace in politics, like the ties that bind the oil and gas business and some of its regulators.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 11-17
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Budget Chief Is Obama’s Choice as New Health Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — Even when Sylvia Mathews Burwell was in her early 30s, friends speculated that she might return to her native Hinton, W.Va., and run for governor someday. After all, she had been a Rhodes scholar, and her mother — who later became mayor of Hinton, population 2,600 — had driven her daughter’s interest in politics.

headline: Dance Listings for April 11-17
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 11-17
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 11-17
text: ‘ISLAND OF LEMURS: MADAGASCAR’

headline: Gathering of Gods From Places Long Forgotten
text: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art gives its all to an exhibition in terms of space, money and scholarship, and the art involved is as rich as a massed chorale and as haunting as a single-voice chant, no institution on earth can produce more impressive results. Such is the case with “Lost Kingdoms: Hindu-Buddhist Sculpture of Early Southeast Asia, 5th to 8th Century,” which opens on Monday.

headline: Spare Times for April 11-17
text: OPENING OF LUNA PARK (Sunday) Veterans of the Cyclone roller coaster — and those who appreciate it best while standing on terra firma — will cheer as Luna Park kicks off another season in Coney Island, Brooklyn, starting at noon. An egg-cream splash on the venerable roller coaster, which turns 87 in June, will set it and the other attractions at the amusement park in motion once again.

headline: On the Wall, Who’s the Deadliest One of All?
text: Don’t try to outwit a haunted mirror: It can see you. That’s the moral of “Oculus,” a derivative but efficient chiller that cribs from “Solaris,” “The Shining” and “The Amityville Horror” yet also shows glimmers of imagination.

headline: Finding the Pleasure in the Details
text: Schubert’s hourlong Octet in F for Winds and Strings can have a pleasantly narcotic effect on the listener, each one of its amply proportioned six movements warping sensations of time and purpose like a carefree summer afternoon. So I didn’t think too much of it at first when I found my mind wandering during Saturday evening’s performance of the work by Musicians From Marlboro, an ensemble from that Vermont-based festival, as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts.

headline: A Light Touch on Ecstasy, Melancholy and Wonder
text: The English soprano Lucy Crowe, who made her New York recital debut on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, is a winsome presence, with long blond hair, a ready grin and bright eyes. They match her bright voice, which suits the early-music repertory for which she has begun to be known in this country.

headline: Digging Up Old Drilling Logs to Strike Not Oil, but Water
text: Daniel Ortuño pulled a small piece of Texas history from a shelf in a building at the University of Texas at Austin. The yellowing piece of paper said that on Dec. 19, 1951, John L. Boyd began drilling a 1,350-foot-deep oil well through 17 layers of shale and limestone in Crockett County in southwest Texas.

headline: On-Camera Dating
text: A rare sustained epistolary romance, “Hank and Asha” runs on video recordings instead of pen and paper. Though not very ambitious, this winsome, whisper-thin tale shimmers along with the charming urge to connect and reveal yourself that links its two correspondents.

headline: Breaking Silence on a Monk
text: “Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence” is a loving portrait of the titular Trappist monk and author, directed by Peter C. Jones, his nephew. The film covers Father Keating’s early days in an affluent family in New York City and on Long Island, then progresses through his passionate embracing of the monastic life.

headline: Doctors Shun Insurance, Offering Care for Cash
text: LAREDO, Tex. — For 12 hours a day, the waiting room at Dr. Gustavo Villarreal’s family practice is packed with patients who pay a flat $50 fee for the convenience — or necessity — of a walk-in, quick-turn doctor’s visit.

headline: U.S. Indicts Ex-Connecticut Governor Again
text: John G. Rowland, who resigned as governor of Connecticut 10 years ago in a corruption scandal, was indicted on Thursday on charges that he tried to hide his involvement in congressional campaigns in 2010 and 2012.

headline: Teenagers, Fed Up, Hatch a Deadly Plan
text: Several times, “Perfect Sisters” shifts its tone so jarringly that you’re left scratching your head. But eventually you realize that Stan Brooks, the director, might be making a point with the incongruity. If so, kudos to him for trying something different in a movie that otherwise could have seemed like an extended episode of any of the scheming-teenager shows that are all over television.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Kitchen Table Anarchists Under Siege
text: A stodgy banquet of idealistic speeches and weeping violins, “No God, No Master” presents a fascinating period in modern American history — the infamous 1919-20 raids on anarchist suspects by Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer — with more earnestness than artistry.

headline: Events in New Jersey for April 13-19, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Latin Rhythms, Exported to the Mideast
text: Pierre Dulaine, a teacher and former champion in ballroom dancing, is the founder of Dancing Classrooms, a nonprofit organization behind the events in Marilyn Agrelo’s 2005 documentary, “Mad Hot Ballroom.” That film concerned Dancing Classrooms’ work with New York students; in Hilla Medalia’s charming “Dancing in Jaffa,” Mr. Dulaine heads to Israel to try to instill mutual respect in 10- and 11-year-old Jewish and Palestinian Israelis through a 10-week course in the movements (and courtesies) of Latin dance.

headline: Rescinding an Honor for an Anti-Islam Activist
text: To the Editor:

headline: Finding Meaning in Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Philip Roth, Still Writing (Letters, at Least)
Students Reading E-Books Are Losing Out, Study Suggests
text: Could e-books actually get in the way of reading?

headline: Exploring the Blot on a Newspaper’s Record
text: At a media ethics talk excerpted toward the end of “A Fragile Trust,” an audience member asks the speaker, Jayson Blair, why anyone should ever believe him. That question isn’t satisfactorily addressed in Samantha Grant’s documentary, a decade-later excavation of the scandal involving Mr. Blair at The New York Times. It’s not as if this superficial accounting of his offenses offered evidence of renewed credibility.

headline: A Man of God, and of Contradictions
text: The title of Ilan Duran Cohen’s film “The Jewish Cardinal” may sound like a punch line. But it accurately describes a real man, Jean-Marie Lustiger, the Paris-born son of Jewish immigrants from Poland, who at 13, bar mitzvah age, converted to Catholicism in the fraught year of 1940.

headline: On Madison Avenue, the Word on ‘Mad Men’
text: FROM the filming of its pilot episode to the disclosure that its seventh — and last — season would be split in two, the AMC series “Mad Men” has intrigued, captivated and sometimes infuriated the real-life counterparts of the show’s fictional advertising men and women of the 1960s.

headline: A View From Hong Kong
Wooing the Boss With a Spicy Dance
text: Comedy, romantic and otherwise, has shuttled back and forth across the Atlantic over the years, picking up a band of horny buddies here, some mumbling self-deprecation there. “Cuban Fury” (which has both) stars the British comic Nick Frost as Bruce, a former child salsa-dancing champ. But despite the overblown title, the movie is milder than a Will Ferrell drag vehicle and more of an ordinary shy-guy-makes-good yarn punched up with some recurring bits.

headline: The Question Is Whodunit; the Answer Is Clear
text: “Unthinkable” is unwatchable, which is too bad, because there are certainly enough oddities in the incident it tries to dramatize to have made for a decent conspiracy theory film.

headline: Events on Long Island for April 13-19, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: California: Reward Offered to Solve Attack on Power Substation
text: With no apparent progress in determining who attacked an electric substation in Silicon Valley a year ago, Pacific Gas & Electric on Thursday offered a $250,000 reward for information. The utility said that it planned $100 million in security investments in the next three years. The attack did not shut off power but did substantial damage when someone shot out radiators on 17 transformers and clipped fiber-optic telephone lines. Also on Thursday, government and industry officials testified at a Senate committee hearing that they were making progress on improving both physical and cybersecurity on the grid, a subject of rising anxiety.

headline: Like, if You Can’t Beat ’Em, Join ’Em?
During Hagel Visit, China Showed Its Military Might, and Its Frustrations
text: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — When Robert M. Gates visited China in 2011 as the United States defense secretary, the military greeted him with an unexpected and, in the view of American military officials, provocative test of a Chinese stealth fighter jet, a bold show of force that stunned the visiting Americans and may even have surprised the Chinese president at the time, Hu Jintao.

headline: Don’t Stand There. The Dance Cartel Wants You to Shake It!
text: HOW do you start a dance craze? The members of the Dance Cartel think the next Nae Nae or Dougie could be the Space Bounce or maybe the Flickitty Poppitty.

headline: Polk Award for Snowden Coverage Draws 2 to U.S.
text: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras, two of the journalists who reported on documents about government surveillance leaked by Edward J. Snowden, plan to return to the United States on Friday to accept a Polk journalism award for national security reporting.

headline: The Tobacco Ties That Bind
text: I DON’T smoke, but if during the day I wanted to buy cigarettes, I could walk into the CVS pharmacy across the street from my office, or the Walgreens two blocks away, and get them. They’re kept right behind the cash register.

headline: Bush Urges Effort to Close Black and White Students’ Achievement Gap
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Former President George W. Bush called the achievement gap between white and black children “a national scandal” on Thursday and urged both parties to come together to address it as the central civil rights issue of the modern era.

headline: Events in Westchester for April 13-19, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Russia: Lawmakers Want to Investigate Gorbachev
text: Five members of the Russian Parliament have asked the prosecutor general to open a criminal case to investigate the breakup of the Soviet Union and the role played by the former leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They contend that he failed to heed a referendum in 1991 that showed that a majority of Soviet citizens wanted to retain the union, and that he illegally formed a committee to study granting sovereignty to the Baltic countries. Mr. Gorbachev, 83, responded that he would cooperate but blamed the leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Belarus for the breakup. This stirring up of history captures an official mood today in Moscow, where many are questioning the legitimacy of former Soviet borders, and President Vladimir V. Putin’s government has twice in five years crossed them with the Russian Army, in Georgia in 2008 and in Ukraine this year.

headline: How to Heal the Heartland
text: It’s tornado season, the springtime tempest, which means the Big Empty of the United States will get another cameo on the nation’s stage. Prepare for the annual montage of heartbreak and houses tossed to the wind, of schools scalped of their roofs and trailer parks reduced to rubble.

headline: The Grand Jury Indictment
text: The United States attorney’s office said John G. Rowland, a Republican who served as governor of Connecticut from 1995 to 2004 and as a congressman from 1985 to 1991, would be arraigned on Friday afternoon.

headline: Health Care Nightmares
text: When it comes to health reform, Republicans suffer from delusions of disaster. They know, just know, that the Affordable Care Act is doomed to utter failure, so failure is what they see, never mind the facts on the ground.

headline: Shoe Thrown at Hillary Clinton During Speech
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton was interrupted during a Las Vegas speech on Thursday, when a woman in the audience threw a shoe at her.

headline: The Moral Power of Curiosity
text: Most of us have at one time or another felt ourselves in the grip of the explanatory drive. You’re confronted by some puzzle, confusion or mystery. Your inability to come up with an answer gnaws at you. You’re up at night, turning the problem over in your mind. Then, suddenly: clarity. The pieces click into place. There’s a jolt of pure satisfaction.

headline: NYT Now: Sylvia Mathews Burwell
text: Michael D. Shear on President Obama’s new nominee for health secretary.

headline: Amazon Buys ComiXology
text: Amazon extended its domain over the world of words on Thursday by acquiring ComiXology, the giant digital comics platform. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: At Amen Corner, Masters Scores Turn for the Worse
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — When Adam Scott walked to the tee of the treacherous par-3 12th hole during the first round of the Masters, he was at the pivot of the exalted Amen Corner. The crowd awaiting him — among the largest on the grounds of the Augusta National Golf Club — rose in applause.

headline: For Greece, a Sign of Stability
text: After years of agonizing austerity and the biggest debt restructuring in history, Greece had some good news on Thursday when investors reacted enthusiastically to the country’s return to global capital markets with the sale of five-year bonds, raising 3 billion euros, or about $4.2 billion. The sale attracted more than €20 billion in orders, driving the interest rate down to 4.75 percent, well below expectations.

headline: Israel to Halt Tax Transfers to Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — Israel will halt the monthly transfer of tax revenues it collects on behalf of the Palestinian Authority and use the money to offset Palestinian debts to Israeli utility companies, a government official said late Thursday.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Gift to the Cynics
text: Nine months ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo looked New Yorkers in the eye and said, “Trust is everything to me.” Don’t believe it.

headline: Events in Connecticut for April 13-19, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Former Bell, Calif., Official Sentenced on Corruption Charge
text: LOS ANGELES — The former assistant city manager of Bell, Calif., was sentenced Thursday to more than 11 years in prison on corruption charges, and ordered to pay millions of dollars in restitution to the city she robbed.

headline: Satellites Show Russian Forces Poised Near Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — NATO released satellite photographs on Thursday showing Russian military equipment, including fighter jets and tanks, that it described as part of a deployment of as many as 40,000 troops near the border with Ukraine. The release came the same day that President Vladimir V. Putin reiterated a threat to curtail gas sales to Ukraine.

headline: Telling a U.N. Envoy to Stay Home
text: Should the United States deny a visa to Iran's next ambassador to the United Nations because he was involved with the 1979 Tehran embassy takeover?

headline: Anglican Leader, Under Fire for Remarks, Urges Caution on Same-Sex Marriage
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The archbishop of Canterbury, under fire for appearing to link expanded gay rights in the United States to violence against Christians in Africa, said on Thursday that he is advocating for a slow and deliberative response to same-sex marriage, mindful of the global implications.

headline: Former Massachusetts Senator Announces New Hampshire Run
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — From the Mount Cube Sugar Farm in Orford to the Moose Muck Coffee House in Colebrook, Scott Brown has been testing his message across New Hampshire and, to the surprise of almost no one, has decided that it works.

headline: In eBay Fight, Icahn Chooses Peace Over War
text: It’s not every day that you hear the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn utter the statement, “it’s better to have peace than war.”

headline: Lance Armstrong’s Positive, if Reluctant, Step in a Sport’s Purification
text: Last summer, Lance Armstrong sat a few feet from me and said he would never “rat out” his friends by publicly revealing who had helped him dope and who had known about his doping. Not a chance. No way. The last thing he would ever do.

headline: Minnesota Lawmakers Vote to Raise Base Wage
text: Minnesota lawmakers voted to raise the minimum wage on Thursday, making it the fifth state to raise base wages this year with midterm elections approaching.

headline: An App to Avoid the Unwelcome on Your List
text: Cloak is the antisocial-media app: It combs your Instagram and Foursquare feeds (and any day now, those of Twitter and Facebook) so you can avoid undesirable people. When someone you’re trying to elude checks in on Foursquare, say, the location shows up on a map within Cloak, alerting you to the whereabouts of your nemesis. You can set the app up so that it alerts you when specific people — a former girlfriend or boyfriend, for instance — are posting to social media, or you can have a broad alert set for when you really just want to be alone. Despite its name, Cloak doesn’t hide you; if you want to hide, don’t post to Instagram.

headline: A Private Equity Titan With a Narrow Focus and Broad Aims
text: One of the best-performing private equity firms of the last 15 years doesn’t have a big name like K.K.R., Blackstone or TPG.

headline: U.S. Agencies ‘Generally’ Acted Properly Before Boston Bombing, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies “generally shared information and followed procedures appropriately” in their investigation of Tamerlan Tsarnaev and his brother, Dzhokhar, in the years leading up to the Boston Marathon bombing, but they should have more closely scrutinized Tamerlan when he returned to the United States from Dagestan in 2012, according to a report by the inspector general for the intelligence community that was released on Thursday.

headline: Keeping Track: Drug Sentences and Crowdfunding
text: Shorter Drug Sentences

headline: Mexico: Convicted Trafficker Now Aiding U.S. Officials
text: The United States attorney in Chicago said Thursday that a top member of the Sinaloa gang had been cooperating with the authorities since he pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges a year ago. The man, Jesús Vicente Zambada Niebla, who was arrested in Mexico in 2009, is the son of Ismael Zambada García, believed to be one of the leaders of the Sinaloa gang. Under a plea deal, Mr. Zambada Niebla, 39, could receive a lighter sentence if he continues to cooperate. The agreement describes how he delivered tons of cocaine and heroin from South and Central America to distributors, who then smuggled the drugs to the United States. Also Thursday, the Treasury Department said that it was imposing sanctions on real estate companies in Guadalajara that laundered money for other top figures in the same gang.

headline: Northern Ireland: Man Charged in 1998 Bombing
text: A well-known Irish Republican was charged on Thursday with the murders of 29 people who were killed in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998. The bombing, which was carried out by the Real Irish Republican Army, a splinter group, was the worst single atrocity of the conflict known as the Troubles, and it wounded more than 220 people. But there has never been a criminal conviction in the case. The man charged Thursday, Seamus Daly, 43, was arrested on Monday. He was one of four men ordered to pay more than $2.5 million in damages to the victims’ families in a civil case five years ago. He has always denied involvement in the bombing.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 10, 2014
text: April 10, 2014

headline: Radio Clip Shows Different Side of Republican Senate Challenger in Mississippi
text: WASHINGTON — State Senator Chris McDaniel cuts a smooth-as-silk image as he crisscrosses Mississippi seeking to topple Senator Thad Cochran in the Republican primary.

headline: Lance Armstrong Reveals Names in Lawsuit
text: In documents released as part of a whistleblower lawsuit, Lance Armstrong reveals for the first time that several key members of his cycling team knew or aided him in doping.

headline: Gaza Runner, Israeli Hurdles
text: The Palestinian Olympic athlete Nader al-Masri has been denied permission by Israel to cross from Gaza to participate in this year’s Palestine Marathon in Bethlehem.

headline: Heartbleed Flaw Could Reach to Digital Devices, Experts Say
text: When the Heartbleed bug was disclosed on Monday, the attention focused on the fallout for major Internet companies like Yahoo and Amazon. But security experts said the potential for harm could extend much further, to the guts of the Internet and the many devices that connect to it.

headline: Two Gambles on Outfielders, but One Costs Millions More
text: Grady Sizemore played every game in 2007, from opening day through the seventh game of the American League Championship Series. He was on the winning side of the final postseason game at the old Yankee Stadium, but his Cleveland Indians fell short of the World Series. The Boston Red Sox stopped them.

headline: Mideast Tensions Sideline a Gazan Marathon Runner
text: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip — As a boy growing up in this town close to the border with Israel, Nader al-Masri was the neighborhood champion of Catch Me if You Can. “No one could catch me,” he recalled. After soccer matches, young Nader would do laps around the empty field.

headline: A Toast to the Ramps of Spring
text: The first wild onions of the season — or ramps, as they are called — are to die-hard food lovers what robins or baseball are to the rest of us: a harbinger of spring. One of the first restaurants in the city to be serving ramps this year is Tarallucci e Vino, an Italianesque wine bar at 15 East 18th Street. “I basically called everyone I knew trying to find them,” said Andrew Welch, the head chef, who eventually scored a batch of ramps from an unnamed forager in South Carolina. That cache, followed by a second from Virginia, caused the restaurant to issue an ecstatic Twitter post two weeks ago: “First ramps of the season!” (The message was concluded by the only-in-the-New-York-food-world hashtag of #omgramps.) So far, Mr. Welch has used his ramps in entrees like the hand-rolled garganelli pasta he was serving the other night with fiddlehead ferns, crushed red pepper and a ramp pesto ($19,) and in appetizers like the one a party of three was enjoying while waiting for a missing fourth person to arrive.

headline: Testimony Still Sought on Shut Lanes at George Washington Bridge
text: Legislative investigators in New Jersey say they will begin calling witnesses to testify about the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge last fall, proceeding even though a judge ruled that two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie did not have to comply with a subpoena seeking records related to the scandal.

headline: Answers to Questions About the Con Edison Clock Tower’s Lights and Bingo
text: Q. I am used to seeing the top of the Con Edison clock tower, off Union Square, lighted up. On April 1, the lights went out and stayed out for quite a while. Was that an April Fools’ joke?

headline: The Chanteuse and the Gun Are Loaded
text: Some things were never meant to be shouted through megaphones. On the basis of “Bullets Over Broadway: The Musical,” the occasionally funny but mostly just loud new show that opened at the St. James Theater on Thursday night, that would include the wit of Woody Allen.

headline: Things Worn at Home
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was challenging, as Friday puzzles tend to be, but wow, was it worth it. There is so much good stuff in today’s puzzle by Peter Wentz. I just had to work hard to establish a toehold in order to find it.

headline: Patrons of 2 Stores Ponder a Loss of Music and Color
text: It was where Vincent Moore went to buy Led Zeppelin, Jimi Hendrix and Donna Summer on LPs in the 1970s. It was where he went to buy the first “Die Hard” movie on VHS in the 1980s, and countless compact discs. Later still, it was where he bought his first digital camera.

headline: Partnerships Old, New and Stage-Managed
text: Pico Alexander, the 22-year-old actor playing George Gibbs in the production of “Our Town” opening at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick later this month, has sometimes had trouble focusing during rehearsals.

headline: Three Honorary Starters at the Masters, With 13 Green Jackets
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods is not playing in the Masters for the first time since 1994 because of a back injury, but he has not forgotten about the tournament, which he has won four times. Woods took to Twitter on Thursday after the honorary starters, Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, hit the first tee shots to open the 78th Masters.

headline: An Arkin Brother’s Standing Commitment
text: Bob Arkin had just arrived at the gig, and already the boss was starting in.

headline: Officials Rule Boy’s Death as Homicide
text: The death of a 4-year-old boy, who prosecutors say was tortured and starved to death by a family friend, has been ruled a homicide by the New York City medical examiner’s officer, paving the way for murder charges to be filed in the case.

headline: Three Aggressive Young Golf Stars Are More Old School Than Not
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The young and the restless grouping of Rory McIlroy, Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed arrived at the par-4 17th hole a combined four under par in the first round of the Masters. All three hit approaches that looked suitable for posing, but two of the balls rolled like tears off the green.

headline: Venezuelan Leader and Opposition Meet in Bid to Ease Tensions
text: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties held a dramatic televised meeting on Thursday in a first step aimed at defusing tensions that have escalated during more than two months of antigovernment protests.

headline: Culture Minute | A Weekend Jump-Start
text: Some ideas for your off hours. Last chance for the Trisha Brown Dance Company in New York, the final season of “Mad Men” begins, and a Woody Allen-inspired Broadway show.

headline: Culture Minute | A Weekend Jump-Start
text: In the Video

headline: Italian Court Weighs Community Service for Berlusconi
text: ROME — A court in Milan held a sentencing hearing on Thursday for former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who was convicted of tax fraud in 2012.

headline: In a Queens School, an Early Start on Preparing ‘Responsible Digital Citizens’
text: Janet Elias refers to her students as digital natives, children who have never known a world without computers. She teaches them to search the Internet and create slide-show presentations, and this year she has also added a theme on social media: its applications, its effect on real-world events and the importance of using it safely.

headline: Settlement Ends Dispute Over Rooney’s Remains
text: LOS ANGELES — Mickey Rooney can finally rest in peace, as a dispute over disposition of his remains was settled on Thursday, according to The Wrap. The settlement came shortly before a court hearing that was to have addressed the matter on Friday morning.

headline: Rangers, in Their Home Finale, Slip Past the Last-Place Sabres
text: The sign of a confident team, Rick Nash was saying in the Rangers’ locker room Thursday night, is winning the bad games.

headline: Yankees Win in Style, but Most of Focus Is on a Substance
text: After all the money spent, after the Yankees poached a star Boston outfielder and the Red Sox brought his World Series ring to Yankee Stadium, after all this, the story line in the first meeting of 2014 belonged to Michael Pineda’s right hand.

headline: Rangel and Challengers Meet in First Debate of Primary Campaign
text: The grizzled incumbent trumpeted his experience, pounding on the table for emphasis while insisting, to laughter, that he wouldn’t cling to his seat “till I drop dead.”

headline: House Votes to Deny Visa to Iranian Envoy Linked to ’79 Hostage Crisis
text: The House on Thursday unanimously passed legislation approved by the Senate aimed at denying a visa to Iran’s choice for United Nations ambassador. The vote sent what sponsors called a blunt rejoinder to the Iranian government for having selected a nominee who played a role, however minor, in the 1979 American hostage crisis in Tehran.

headline: Steven A. Shaw, 44, Founder of an Early Blog About Food, Dies
text: Steven A. Shaw, a founder of the influential online culinary discussion forum eGullet and one of the first writers to start his own food blog, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 44.

headline: Newcomer and Powerhouse Reach Final
text: PHILADELPHIA — Daniel Ciampini scored a hat trick to lift Union College over Boston College, 5-4, on Thursday at Wells Fargo Center. The Dutchmen (31-6-4) advanced to their first N.C.A.A. final, where on Saturday they will face Minnesota, the No. 1 seed.

headline: Times Minute | The New Stephen Colbert
text: Bill Carter on the news that Stephen Colbert will leave his satirical right-wing character behind for a fresh start at CBS’s “Late Show.”

headline: Times Minute | The New Stephen Colbert
text: In the Video

headline: Diamond in the Rough
text: From hawking his wares on the sidewalks of SoHo to showing them at the Whitney Biennial, the sculptor Alma Allen has taken the road less traveled to art world stardom.

headline: Three Storied Design Brands Venture Into New Territory
text: At this year’s Salone del Mobile in Milan, the Finnish tableware company Iittala expanded into housewares; the Italian housewares maker Kartell moved into tableware; and the German furniture line e15 got serious about lighting.

headline: Classic Rock
text: From monoliths to mosaics, marble has been a staple of regal artistry since the days of ancient Egypt. Now, a new group of designers are carving out their own models.

headline: Itinerary | Joshua Tree’s Artful Excursions
text: Whether or not you can score a personal invite to the sculptor and designer Alma Allen’s home and studio in Joshua Tree, Calif., the desert respite offers plenty of other sources of art, culture and inspiration (and makes for an ideal escape from the nearby madness that is the Coachella festival). Here, a few highlights.

text: Question:

headline: Congress and the Belief That Human Life Is Priceless
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Word of the Day | remunerative
text: remunerative•\ri-ˈmyü-nə-rə-tiv, -ˌra-\• adjective

headline: Corrections: April 11, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: 9 Dead and Dozens Injured in California Crash
text: A tour bus carrying high school students on a college visit collided with a FedEx 18-wheeler in a fiery crash on Thursday in Northern California that left nine people dead and dozens injured, according to the authorities.

headline: Showing Value at the Plate and on the Bases, Young Leads the Mets to a Win
text: ATLANTA — Just before the season, Eric Young Jr. seemed to be the odd man out in the Mets’ outfield, behind Curtis Granderson, Chris Young and Juan Lagares. His speed was his most notable trait, and he was the Mets’ only natural leadoff hitter, but to play, he had to show that the team could not thrive with just anyone leading off.

headline: India Election Digest: April 11
text: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Voter turnout was high during the first big phase of the elections, Narendra Modi’s estranged wife expresses hope that he will win, and candidates look for ways to exceed their legal campaign spending limit.

headline: N.B.A. to Play Abroad in Preseason
text: The N.B.A. on Thursday announced a slate of international preseason games to be played in October. There will be five games across four countries, including two Nets games in China. The Nets and the Sacramento Kings will play Oct. 12 in Shanghai and Oct. 15 in Beijing. The Nets previously visited China in 2010, playing exhibition games in Beijing and Guangzhou. The San Antonio Spurs will play exhibition games against local clubs in Berlin and Istanbul, and the Miami Heat and the Cleveland Cavaliers will face off in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Leee Black Childers, Portraitist of a Downtown Demimonde, Dies at 68
text: Leee Black Childers, whose photographs of Warholians, punk musicians, club kids, drag queens and other denizens of late-night downtown life told an inside story of a vibrant musical era in New York City and elsewhere, died on April 6 in Los Angeles, where he had gone to attend a retrospective of his work. He was 68 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Welcomes Its Newest Members
text: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducted its new members at a full-scale arena concert on Thursday night at Barclays Center, with its largest live audience by far. It would have been an ideal setting for the band that didn’t perform: Kiss, the hard-rock arena-spectacular showmen in makeup who, until this year, had been snubbed by the hall since becoming eligible in 1999. After Kiss was accepted, its members, past and present, had squabbled with the Hall of Fame and among themselves over which of its lineups, original or current, would perform; no one did.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 12:45 P.M. (HBO) GLORIA: IN HER OWN WORDS (2011) After making headlines as a journalist in the 1960s in New York City with an exposé on the working conditions of Playboy Bunnies, Gloria Steinem felt her political ideals expanding when she covered an abortion hearing for New York magazine in 1969 and learned of the horrifying experiences women had endured. (Ms. Steinem, above in 1969, kept secret the abortion she’d had at 22.) On Aug. 26, 1970, she helped lead the Women’s Strike for Equality on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the 19th Amendment, giving women the right to vote. In 1972 she helped found Ms. Magazine, beginning her ascent as a public face of feminism. This documentary from Peter W. Kunhardt chronicles the life of Ms. Steinem, who turned 80 last month, from her childhood in Toledo, Ohio, and the inspiration for her work, to her battle with breast cancer, her late-in-life marriage and subsequent widowhood. Barbara Walters, Helen Gurley Brown, Phil Donahue and Larry King weigh in.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 11, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics on “Joe,” “Draft Day” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”

headline: Beijing Court Upholds Legal Scholar’s Sentence
text: A Beijing court has upheld a four-year prison sentence for Xu Zhiyong, the legal scholar who inspired a campaign for civic participation and social justice in China. Mr. Xu was convicted in January of “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” in connection with a series of small protests in 2012 and 2013 calling for government officials to disclose their assets.

headline: Panda Transfer Falls Victim to Fallout Over Missing Plane
text: China is not shy about using “panda diplomacy” as a tool of soft power. It has a long tradition of bestowing nations with the bamboo-chomping mammals, most famously in the early 1970s, when Beijing sent two pandas to the National Zoo in Washington amid President Richard M. Nixon’s groundbreaking diplomatic opening to China.

headline: In London, Museum Adds Fashion Conservation Space
text: LONDON — Scientific advances and technological innovations continue to change textile conservation, but most specialists say the craft still depends on three things: agile hands, good sight — and space.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 11, 2014
text: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Colbert to Succeed Letterman on ‘Late Show’
text: In “Colbert to Succeed Letterman on ‘Late Show,’ ” Bill Carter reports on CBS’s announcement of the next host for its flagship late-night program.

headline: When You Are Old Enough to Vote, Will You?
text: Young people, ages 18 to 24, are significantly less likely to vote than those over age 35. People who make more than $75,000 a year are much more likely to vote than those making less than $50,000. That means older and wealthier Americans have a greater say in who is running our government — especially during midterm elections like the ones coming up this year. Do you think voting is important? Is it a civic duty?

headline: Look Again, With Love and Liebling
text: Jerome Liebling’s lyrical vision of everyday life permeates a body of work that combines passionate idealism with sometimes brutal realism. It is a style shaped by a destitute childhood in Depression-era Brooklyn and forged by horrific firsthand experiences during many of the most violent battles of World War II.

headline: New York Today: Their First 100 Days, Too
text: Good morning on this warm, cloudy Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Looking for America Beyond Its Borders
text: Academic politics are so vicious because the stakes are so small.

headline: Sony Warns Some New Laptop Batteries May Catch Fire
text: HONG KONG — Sony on Friday warned of the potential for batteries to burn or catch fire in some of its new Vaio laptop computers and asked owners of the units in question to stop using them immediately.

headline: Co-operative Bank Cancels Bonuses as It Posts Steep Loss
text: LONDON – The Co-operative Bank said on Friday that it would cancel 4.97 million pounds, or about $8.38 million, in bonuses for current and former executives and other employees as the British lender reported a £1.3 billion pretax annual loss.

headline: Why No One Goes to Naples
text: NAPLES, Italy — Spring is here. In southern Italy, the sun is shining, the sky is blue and the weather is balmy. Orange blossom fragrances mingle with wafts of jasmine. The food is good, the wine is inexpensive, the locals are friendly and beauty is all around. But where are the tourists?

headline: Daily Report: Security Flaw Could Extend to Digital Devices, Experts Say
text: When the Heartbleed bug was disclosed on Monday, the attention focused on the fallout for major Internet companies like Yahoo and Amazon. But security experts said the potential for harm could extend much further, to the guts of the Internet and the many devices that connect to it, Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy report.

headline: Prosecutor Targets Pistorius’s Claims of Safety Fears
text: Oscar Pistorius appeared flustered, agitated and tired at his murder trial on Friday, the third day of cross-examination by a relentless prosecutor who accused him of shooting his girlfriend in the head during an argument.

headline: What Limiting the Employer Mandate Would Mean for Small Businesses
text: The Save American Workers Act of 2014, which seeks to limit the reach of the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, has led a charmed life, for a bill. Most of its fellow legislation languishes in committee and never gets a public airing. But the Save American Workers Act was in and out of the House in a matter of months.

headline: Alessandra Stanley: Even the Snobs Say I’m Lucky
text: Alessandra Stanley, once a co-bureau chief for The Times in Moscow and a bureau chief in Rome, has been the chief television critic for The Times since 2003. In her columns, she interprets the latest prime-time obsessions, reality-TV guilty pleasures and major television news events, from debates to awards shows. She spoke with us about her approach to her work. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: Raising a Moral Child
text: What does it take to be a good parent? We know some of the tricks for teaching kids to become high achievers. For example, research suggests that when parents praise effort rather than ability, children develop a stronger work ethic and become more motivated.

headline: As Trading Hurts JPMorgan, Auto Loans Aid Wells Fargo
text: Updated, 9:11 p.m. | The contrasting fortunes of two of the nation’s biggest banks — JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.

headline: Are Iran and Israel Trading Places?
text: STANFORD, Calif. — Although the Israeli and Iranian governments have been virtually at war with each other for decades, the two countries have much in common.

headline: Ukraine on the Brink
text: With Moscow bearing down, Kiev seeks an economic rescue.

headline: U.S. Markets Quiet After Global Sell-Off
text: European stocks joined a global slide on Friday after a big drop in Tokyo that followed a sharp sell-off in Internet and biotechnology shares in the United States a day earlier.

headline: 10 Ways to Teach and Learn About Spring (While The Learning Network Is on Vacation)
text: Like many school districts around the country, we’re taking next week off to celebrate Passover, Easter and the return of weather that no longer requires outfits like this.

headline: In Our Pages: April 12
text: 1939: Service for Autograph Chasers

headline: A Miss for JPMorgan
text: JPMORGAN EARNINGS FALL 18.5%  |  JPMorgan Chase reported an 18.5 percent slump in first-quarter earnings on Friday, as the nation’s largest bank grappled with dual challenges: sluggish revenue from trading and lackluster mortgage lending, Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes in DealBook. Both issues, broadly buffeting the banking industry, damped profits at JPMorgan.

headline: Laemmle’s List: A Mogul’s Heroism
text: Among the pioneering moguls of Hollywood, Carl Laemmle, who commanded Universal Pictures for more than 20 years and who died 75 years ago, was not only less recognizable than the rest, he was also different from the rest. For one thing, he was older than the others and the first to emigrate from Europe to America. For another, he was less autocratic. Laemmle, an elfin man, was informal, unpretentious and cheery. Everyone, including his own son, called him Uncle Carl, and, according to one witness, he would roam the lot at Universal City with a pail in which he would urinate when he felt the urge. Most of the others made a point of declaiming their American-ness. Laemmle kept close ties to his native Germany — he visited Europe each year — and called the country his fatherland.

headline: Unlocking Android With a Glance
text: Q. Is the face-recognition feature on the Nexus tablet safer than using a password to unlock the tablet’s screen?

headline: Wells Fargo Posts Strong Earnings
text: Updated, 10:00 a.m. | Wells Fargo’s first-quarter results beat Wall Street expectations, as the bank posted stronger-than-expected profits, fueled by lower loan losses and decreasing expenses.

headline: Total Taxes on Wages Are Rising
text: AFTER the financial crisis, many countries cut taxes to stimulate their economies. But since 2010, with concerns about government debt rising, the trend has gone the other way.

headline: Italian Asset Manager Raises $961.5 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The Italian asset manager Anima said on Friday that it raised 692.5 million euros, or about $961.5 million, in an initial public offering.

headline: Google Glass Available to Anyone in U.S. — for One Day Only
text: Google Glass! On sale! One day only! Just $1,500! Get ’em while they’re hot!

headline: In an Instant, a Bus to College Was a Fiery Trap
text: LOS ANGELES — Harley Hoyt, an 18-year-old senior at Valhalla High School in San Diego County, was listening to his headphones to pass the time during the 12-hour bus ride up California’s Interstate 5 when he was catapulted forward, his face smashing against the seat in front of him.

headline: They Died With the Camera On
text: The Hollywood combat films produced during World War II were almost entirely heroic and celebratory. No American died in vain; a better world could be glimpsed beyond the storm clouds. The combat movies made during and soon after the Korean War were scarcely so optimistic.

headline: A Monstrous Wrong Undone in a Blaze of Pastoral Passion
text: LONDON — In the Bohemia scene in the Royal Ballet’s new full-length “The Winter’s Tale,” the very air feels abundantly fresh. The young lovers Perdita and Florizel, high on waves of mutual enchantment, dance both impetuously and experimentally, part of a community whose celebrations have an extraordinary folk vitality. Behind these two sweethearts is a vast greenwood tree laden with strange fruit harvested by the corps onstage, and the range of costumes suggests an eastern Mediterranean idyll, both contemporary and traditional. The music travels from a slow, exotic flute melody to tunes that trip with complex meters and orchestration of changing colors.

headline: The Return of Expansionary Austerity
text: Here we go again. There’s now a full-court press of the usual suspects claiming that the recovery in the UK proves that fiscal austerity isn’t contractionary after all, that the IMF had it all wrong, and so on.

headline: Bayern Munich and Real Madrid to Meet in Champions League Semis
text: The two favorites to win the UEFA Champions League, Bayern Munich and Real Madrid, were matched against one another in the semifinals in a draw held Friday in Nyon, Switzerland.

headline: Gone in 0.001 Seconds
text: For Brad Katsuyama, then a young equities trader at Royal Bank of Canada, a life-changing revelation about the stock market began in June 2007 with a mystery: Why, when he tried to buy stocks at the offered prices on his computer screen, did the offers instantly vanish and the prices pop higher?

headline: Adding Insult to Gun Injuries, Police Often Handcuff Victims
text: Two days after he was shot, Andre Daly woke in a haze with a police officer standing by his hospital bed in Brooklyn.

headline: One Baby, Five Nationalities
text: We opted not to find out our baby’s sex before he was born. The annoyance of not being able to shop for pink or blue clothes, leaving the baby room neutrally white and having have two separate naming discussions was far outweighed by what seemed to be the much more traditional way of doing things: We wanted, like virtually everyone in human history, to learn the gender at the same time we found out whether our baby was hairy and plump or gawky and bald, or whether it had its mother’s toes or its father’s weak chin.

headline: Big G.O.P. Donors Stir Senate Runs
text: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are rapidly burning through their campaign cash, whittling away their financial advantage over Republican opponents as they fend off attacks from conservative groups, according to figures released through Friday.

headline: View From the Top
text: THE HARD THING ABOUT HARD THINGS Building a Business When There Are No Easy AnswersBy Ben Horowitz Harper Business/HarperCollins, $29.99.

headline: The Bottom Line From Both Sides
text: The Wall Street-Main Street divide is not just for political slogans. It’s also useful for categorizing literature.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FAMILY LIFE,  by Akhil Sharma. (Norton, $23.95.) Sharma’s novel, deeply unnerving and tender at the core, charts a young man’s struggles to grow within a family shattered by tragedy and disoriented by its move from India.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SON OF A GUN: A Memoir,  by Justin St. Germain. (Random House, $16.) In late 2001, St. Germain’s mother — “a former Army paratrooper, the toughest woman I’ve ever known” — was shot and killed in Arizona, apparently by her fifth husband, a wrecked ex-cop. This tale of personal loss and grief drives St. Germain’s searing memoir, but its bigger story concerns the culture of guns, violence and manhood in the American West.

headline: Leaning In Without Falling Over
text: Joan C. Williams has been a longtime laborer in the trenches of women’s work. The founding director of the Center for WorkLife Law at the University of California’s Hastings College of the Law, she boldly attacked the male-dominated workplace in “Unbending Gender” and, with her co-author, Cynthia Thomas Calvert, provided a blueprint for increased labor flexibility in law firms in “Solving the Part-Time Puzzle.” Now, in collaboration with her daughter, Rachel Dempsey, Williams has turned to a different kind of book. Deftly combining sociological research with a more casual narrative style, “What Works for Women at Work” offers unabashedly straightforward advice in a how-to primer for ambitious women.

headline: For All It’s Worth
text: Most people are used to owing money to others, but few think about what money may owe us: an equitable society, a functioning political system, a peaceful economy that can stay off the exhausting roller coaster of financial booms and crashes.

headline: The Banker, the Visitor, His Wife and Her Lover
text: Another month, another bright young star in the firmament of Indian writing.

headline: Analyze That
text: The first half of Jean Hanff Korelitz’s novel about a New York therapist is less than revelatory, although that turns out to be for excellent reason. Grace Reinhart Sachs, an affluent Upper East Side mother with a thriving couples practice, frets almost generically about such privileged concerns as how much to push her son to continue with his violin lessons. She offers loving descriptions of an ideal husband — a pediatric oncologist — who somehow never gels into either a recognizable type or an intriguingly unique character. The absence of key friends and family members feels underexplained.

headline: Debt Trap
text: “We cannot mortgage the material assets of our grandchildren without asking the loss also of their political and spiritual heritage.” So said President Dwight Eisenhower in his 1961 farewell address.

headline: Home Improvement
text: When my family moved to Accra, Ghana, in 1990 just as I was about to start high school, we landed in a country whose G.D.P. was less than one-quarter the size of Delaware’s, despite its plentiful deposits of gold and other precious minerals. A military dictator had ruled it for almost a dozen years. Poverty, hunger and disease stalked the countryside. It felt like a place cut off from the rest of the world. If we wanted to call my grandparents in Wisconsin or Addis Ababa, all five of us would squeeze into a phone booth at the post office. We didn’t have a home phone, and the waiting list to get one was decades long.

headline: Kamikaze Strategy
text: The mountain of Purgatory haunts the cover of Peter Mountford’s arresting second novel, “The Dismal Science.” The image, which calls to mind the second volume of “The Divine Comedy,” leads the reader into the book, the stark path curling its way up toward Terrestrial Paradise, symbolized by one lonely but verdant tree.

headline: How Banks Fail
text: Five years after the drama that began in 2008 — the failure of one bank after another, the decline in the stock market and the freezing up of finance — we still cannot seem to agree about the causes of the crisis. There are some who like to pin all the blame on the corrupt business practices of Wall Street and the greed of bankers. Then there are those who think it was just one more example of the sort of irrational mass hysteria that gives rise to boom-and-bust cycles in financial markets. Still others focus on the inherent characteristics of banks that seem to make them especially vulnerable to investor panics — the fact, for example, that their loans and investments cannot be liquidated in a hurry, while depositors can withdraw their cash with the click of a mouse.

headline: Statistically Speaking
text: In the dark days of the Great Depression, the economist Simon Kuznets set about calculating the total national income of the United States. It was a case of a demand creating its supply, the demand by Congress and citizens to understand the scale of the economic calamity the nation was then experiencing. The same demand for understanding helps explain the public’s interest these days in what might otherwise seem to be dry, uninviting economic statistics. How secure is the recovery from the impact of the 2008 financial crisis? What good is a recovery that benefits only the wealthy minority? Do our children have any hope of seeing their living standards rise as ours did over the late 20th century — or is that dream of progress over?

headline: Inside the List
text: Wilderness Adventure: The crime novelist Nevada Barr is a write-what-you-know success story — when she began her Anna Pigeon series, about a National Park Service ranger who frequently stumbles across dead bodies, Barr was herself working as a law enforcement ranger in the park system. “I had a lot of time in the backcountry to think,” she told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans in 2008. “There were a couple of people in the park that needed killing, and I thought about how to get away with it.” (Perhaps unsurprisingly, Barr quit that job once her books started to catch on.) How did Park Service employees respond to the series? Guardedly at first, to judge from a 1995 profile in National Parks magazine that cited Barr’s perceived “disregard for both the agency and the people” who worked in the parks. “I enjoy the stories,” one employee acknowledged, “but some of the cynicism about the Park Service makes me feel like I’m at work.” Things have gotten better since then: In 2011, the National Parks Conservation Association presented Barr with an award for “enhancing public understanding of national parks” and drawing “attention to the invaluable work of National Park Service staff.” The 18th Anna Pigeon mystery, “Destroyer Angel,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Money Issue
text: This week, Chris Hayes talks about Kevin Roose’s “Young Money”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the book business; Timothy Noah on Matt Taibbi’s “The Divide”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Money Issue
text: This week, Chris Hayes and Timothy Noah.

headline: Highway Patrol on California Bus Crash
text: A California Highway Patrol spokeswoman, Lacey Heitman, gave updates following a deadly collision between a FedEx tractor-trailer and a chartered bus carrying high school students in Orland, Calif.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Money Issue
text: In The New York Times Book Review’s Money Issue, Chris Hayes reviews Kevin Roose’s “Young Money: Inside the Hidden World of Wall Street’s Post-Crash Recruits.” Mr. Hayes writes:

headline: Detroit Wins Judge’s Nod for Contract Settlement
text: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday approved this bankrupt city’s latest attempt to extricate itself from some long-term financial contracts that have been costing it tens of millions of dollars a year, holding up its settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.

headline: Inside Baseball
text: Most views of a major-league baseball game are as traditional as the game itself, the cameramen sidelined in pens next to the dugouts. To see the game from some new angles, Mike Escamilla, a photographer and an athlete, went to the Los Angeles Dodgers’ spring-training camp in Glendale, Ariz., and mounted cameras to players’ bats, umpires’ chests, catchers’ face masks and even remote-controlled drones. Some players, who tend to be skittish and superstitious even by the standards of professional athletes, were reluctant to take part. “Getting close to the players on the field was clearly not something photographers did, but after some slow introductions, a few players agreed to help us out,” Escamilla says. “Once we showed them the photos, they were like, ‘Wow, this is rad.’ ” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 3.30.14 Issue
text: THE CHEF AT 15

headline: What Kelis and Paul Newman Have in Common
text: In recent years, you studied to be a chef. You have a new show on the Cooking Channel called “Saucy & Sweet,” and your new album is called “Food.” How would you describe your philosophy on cooking? As much as my music is very much who I am, so is my cooking. Food has become such a way of life, sort of like what you listen to, who you’re with, what you’re wearing. My character comes through in my cooking.

headline: Can I Spy?
text: Is it unethical to infiltrate a group, through employment or other means, to learn more about them in order to expose what they do if you don’t agree with their stated aims? The F.B.I., for example, has undercover agents who pretend to be drug dealers. Recently, it has become illegal in some states for animal rights activists to pretend to be prospective employees at livestock farms and slaughterhouses because some were secretly videotaping the conditions. When is it ethical to pretend to be someone you’re not to learn information that could be beneficial to society? TIM DE VALROGER, HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Breakfast of Champions
text: Plus: Alicia Silverstone’s son is clueless about “Clueless,” and Judge John Hodgman rules on “Game of Thrones” spoilers.

headline: Spice of Life
text: Each time my husband, Ismail, returns from visiting relatives in Libya, his suitcase is lined with yellow powder in plastic baggies: the spice mix of his mother, Hajja. As a child, he watched her fill an iron pan with desiccated cloves, fenugreek seeds, withered black peppercorns, cinnamon bark, gnarled turmeric and ginger roots. Using a palm brush over an open fire, she swept the pan with one hand and drew the aroma in with the other. Her nose told her when her spices were ready. She once ground them herself, but now she takes her roasted spices to the mill.

headline: Who Made That Contact Lens?
text: In 1887, a German doctor named Theodor­ Samisch saw a patient whose lower eyelid had been destroyed by carcinoma, leaving his cornea exposed and desiccated and his lashes curling inward. To preserve the patient’s vision, Samisch contracted with two brothers who specialized in artificial eyes. They made a protective shell of handblown glass, transparent in the middle and opaque around the edge, with reddish threads for blood vessels. “I have worn the glass supplied by you continuously, day and night,” the patient wrote the brothers 21 years later, “and my eye has always felt very well with it.”

headline: Elementary School Concert Draws Billy Joel
text: It is not unheard of for composers to turn up at concerts of their music, at least in the classical music world. When the composer is a rock star, the likelihood of an appearance drops considerably, and when the concert is at 9:30 a.m., and the performers are kindergarten through second-grade students, well, the odds drop to near zero.

headline: French Bath and Beauty Goods With an Old-World Touch
text: In 1803, the perfumer Jean-Vincent Bully established a distillery on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris. His signature scented skincare vinegars went on to become the toast of 19th-century Europe, and he even inspired the character of César Birotteau, the titular hero of Balzac’s novel. Now, his legacy is being revisited by Ramdane Touhami, a former co-owner of Cire Trudon, the French luxury candle manufacturer. L’Officine Universelle Buly, as the line has been re-christened, embodies the original’s Old-World elegance and emphasis on natural ingredients. The range of exquisitely packaged, paraben-free products — perfumes, oils, creams, marble-encased candles, scented matches — can be found in the brand’s new Saint-Germain-des-Près apothecary alongside accouterments like sponges, combs and crystals sourced from Morocco.

headline: Above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade
text: A perfectly positioned and expertly renovated historic townhouse perched high above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade with idyllic views of the Manhattan skyline, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and beyond, is about to enter the market at $16 million.

headline: In France, a Move to Limit Off-the-Clock Work Emails
text: PARIS — Given France’s 35-hour workweek, generous vacations and persistent, if not altogether accurate, reputation for indolence, it may come as a surprise that the French are only now considering limits on the work emails and phone calls that come at all hours of the day and night.

headline: Incendiary Words in Campaigns Draw Ban on Rallies for Two Politicians
text: Updated, 12:50 a.m. | NEW DELHI — The Election Commission of India has banned two politicians, Amit Shah of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Azam Khan of the Samajwadi Party, from holding rallies in the state of Uttar Pradesh for their “highly inflammatory speeches,” the news channel NDTV reported late Friday.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paying Employees to Quit
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Obama Names Health Pick, Veteran of Fiscal Battles
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he was nominating his budget director, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, as the administration tries to move beyond its early stumbles in carrying out Mr. Obama’s health law.

headline: They Thought Their Son Was Bipolar. They Were Wrong.
text: Desperate parents search for a doctor who can explain why their son goes out of control.

headline: New York Boomers on Hipster Turf
text: Lenore Berner, born at the very tail end of the baby boom generation, turned 50 in February. (Her husband, Dan, had hit the half-century mark the previous year.) A few weeks later, the Berners moved from a two-bedroom apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which they were renting for $4,500 a month, to a 39th-floor waterfront rental in Long Island City, Queens — the price tag a more modest $3,850.

headline: Class Action Complaint Against the N.H.L.
text: The complaint by nine retired players said the N.H.L. failed to take adequate steps to warn the players of the dangers of the sport and deliberately promoted violence for profit.

headline: A Chance for a Market’s Wallflowers to Bloom
text: In January, Seth Klarman, a billionaire who runs the Boston-based Baupost Group investment partnership, warned in his annual letter to clients that “a skeptic would have to be blind not to see bubbles inflating” and cited the “nosebleed stock market valuations” of companies like Netflix and Tesla Motors.

headline: The Aesthetes | Expats in Tangier
text: A group of eccentric expats living in Tangier open their extraordinary homes and share what lured them to the city and kept them hooked.

headline: A Dutchman’s Opinion: Henk Ovink Weighs in on Post-Sandy Proposals
text: Following my profile of Henk Ovink and his work to bring Dutch water-management ideas to bear in the Northeastern United States, I asked Henk to briefly describe each of the 10 proposals that the Hurricane Sandy Rebuilding Task Force has highlighted for possible implementation. Each was spearheaded by a multidisciplinary team in conjunction with local community groups. The next step in the process will see Shaun Donovan, the H.U.D. secretary and chairman of the task force, make a final selection from these visionary approaches.

headline: A Creative Approach to Adjusting to Life in China
text: My company, iPai, doesn’t offer bonuses for being stationed overseas to any of our executives.

headline: Your Street Style: Dressed for Spring in Winter
text: Readers showed us how they stylishly tried to usher in spring weather through their clothes.

headline: Customers Can Lose When Banks Shuffle Payments
text: THE proverbial $35 cup of coffee that can result from overspending a bank account hasn’t disappeared yet.

headline: Turkish Court Overturns Part of Law on Judiciary, Loosening Government’s Grip
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s highest court on Friday overturned the provision of a new law that gave the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan greater control over the judiciary, a law that critics said harmed the country’s separation of powers and was part of a broader effort on the part of Mr. Erdogan to push back against a corruption investigation.

headline: Floyd Cardoz Exits North End Grill
text: Floyd Cardoz, the executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, said Friday that he was leaving the restaurant and its parent company, the Union Square Hospitality Group, where he has worked for nearly 17 years for the restaurateur Danny Meyer.

headline: Muslim, Gay, and Making No Apologies
text: PARIS — HE was born inside the public library of Rabat in Morocco where his dad worked as a janitor and where his family lived until he was 2. For most of his childhood, he hid his sexuality as best he could, but his effeminate demeanor brought mockery and abuse, even as it would later become a source of artistic inspiration.

headline: Witchcraft on the West Side
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Facts & Figures: The Death of the Mall
text: Malls have been closing their doors, and teenagers are to blame.

headline: Times Minute | Next Steps After Sebelius
text: The White House correspondent Michael D. Shear on what’s next for the Obama administration with Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, ending her five-year tenure.

headline: Times Minute | Next Steps After Sebelius
text: In the Video

headline: In Las Vegas, Shopping Souk-Style
text: Grand Bazaar Shops, a collection of more than a 150 stores, is scheduled to open this fall in Las Vegas.

headline: Ukrainian Prime Minister Visits Donetsk
text: Ukraine’s acting prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, said if protesters occupying a government building leave peacefully that they won’t be arrested.

headline: Pro-Russia Ukrainians Are Promised More Power, but Remain Dubious
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s acting prime minister on Friday abandoned threats to forcibly evict pro-Russian demonstrators from government buildings, and assured political and business leaders in the country’s rebellious east that they would get more power to run their own affairs.

headline: Wheelies: The Moab Jeeps Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Childhood Dreams Can Inspire Rewarding Second Careers
text: EVER since Sandra Colony was a child, when she was spellbound by the glossy photographs of exotic places in the pages of National Geographic, she has been driven by the desire to explore the world.

headline: News Alert: The News Alert Is Changing
text: Ian Fisher is an assistant managing editor at The Times. Since coming to the paper in 1990, he has served as bureau chief in Rome, deputy editor on the foreign desk and the day editor on the home page.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Ryan McDonagh, Rising Star for Rangers, Sweeps Team Honors
text: Defenseman Ryan McDonagh’s breakthrough season was capped with two laurels Friday, as his teammates and reporters covering the Rangers awarded him the team’s top honors.

headline: ‘I’m 5’2, but I Identify as Heidi Klum’
text: I cannot tell you how delighted I was to read that Facebook is now offering a greatly increased range of user ID labels.

headline: ‘An Addict With Friends’
text: The night the police came for Robert Aaron, he was at home in the Mott Street apartment where he has lived for the last quarter century, making a coconut pudding called tembleque. Mr. Aaron, whose legal name is Robert Aaron Vineberg, is a 57-year-old musician who has played with David Bowie, Wyclef Jean, Mick Jagger and Amy Winehouse, among others, a genial man with a pencil-thin mustache and a grasp of half a dozen languages. He is also a heroin addict who has sometimes sold the drug. On this night, Mr. Aaron said, his visitors did not ring the bell.

headline: Mike Daisey Will Present ‘Dreaming of Rob Ford’ Onstage in Toronto Festival
text: When the directors of Crow’s Theater in Toronto invited the monologist Mike Daisey to create a show for the East End Performance CRAWL, the company’s new festival of site-specific solo shows, he settled on an idea quickly and perhaps inevitably, given the festival’s nature and location, and his own passion for topicality. The world premiere of “Dreaming of Rob Ford,” Mr. Daisey’s meditation on the exploits of Toronto’s mayor, will open the festival, which runs from May 21 to June 1.

headline: Great Grain Salads
text: For the next few weeks you’ll be hearing a lot from me about a conference I attended in March at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. Called “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives,” this conference, presented by the Culinary Institute of America, the Harvard School of Public Health and the Samueli Institute, brings together medical professionals with chefs and nutrition researchers to explore food and its relationship to health. Now in its 10th year, the conference has inspired hospitals to install teaching kitchens. Surgeons whose knowledge of knives had been limited to the scalpel have learned to wield a chef’s knife as they participate in kitchen workshops run by chefs from the Culinary Institute and chefs presenting at the conference.

headline: Irish Republican Ordered Held Without Bail in 1998 Bombing Case
text: DUBLIN — A dissident Irish Republican charged with 29 counts of murder in the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, was ordered held without bail on Friday.

headline: The Aesthetes
text: For the legendary expats of Tangier, a life devoted to beauty reaches full flower in this North African hothouse of history and hedonism.

headline: For Afghan Journalists, Election Brings a Sense of National Duty
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the raucous news outlets of Afghanistan — and there are hundreds of them — have come into their own in recent years, they have taken to criticizing government officials and institutions with an enthusiasm that borders on glee. And despite attempts by the powerful to rein in reporters, much of the news media has thrived with an occasionally adversarial approach.

headline: Kentucky Students Catch Breath to Cheer a Derby Hopeful
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The University of Kentucky is renowned for its eight men’s basketball national championships and its three Final Four appearances in the last four years. But the university now finds itself in the unfamiliar, and unlikely, position of having fostered a Kentucky Derby prospect.

headline: Alibaba to Acquire Chinese Mapping Firm as Buying Spree Continues
text: The Alibaba Group, a Chinese e-commerce juggernaut, will buy the portion of the mapping and navigation company AutoNavi Holdings that it does not already own, the latest move in an acquisition spree before Alibaba’s expected stock listing in the United States.

headline: Image of the Day: April 11
text: A mustard field on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Pope’s Request for Abuse Victims to Forgive Church Draws Calls for Action
text: Pope Francis said in remarks broadcast on Friday that he was “personally” asking for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done in the sexual abuse of children.

headline: In Sydney, Lively Culture Amid Natural Beauty
text: The late, great Australian art critic Robert Hughes once complained that “Crocodile Dundee” is still regarded by many Americans as a work of social realism. A rhetorical exaggeration, of course, but he had a point. As an Australian living in New York, I’ve long been puzzled at the dominance of charming clichés about the country as a sun-dappled frontier. Advertising campaigns still promote the “ocker” image — Australian for redneck — depicting beer-swilling, happy-go-lucky folk barbecuing steak at the beach.

headline: Wounded by the Language of War
text: When did the language we use to talk about death start to resemble a Pentagon briefing, full of military references and combat analogies?

headline: Pink Dolphins and Sunsets Along the Amazon
text: Sitting on the deck of a small cruise ship called the Aqua, I listened to the never-ending sounds of the Amazonian rain forest. Beside me was a retired executive, a fellow passenger whom I had just met the day before. As the sinking sun bled into the darkening sky and the riverbanks along this tributary of the Peruvian Amazon turned from green to black, he told me of his days in Lagos in the ’70s and Dubai in the ’90s, then lapsed into silence. The moment was all the sweeter because we were playing hooky from an outing to view nocturnal birds, opting for perfectly chilled white wine over mosquitoes.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Joe,’ ‘Draft Day’ and ‘Only Lovers Left Alive’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the Texas thriller “Joe,” the sports film “Draft Day” and the vampire drama “Only Lovers Left Alive.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Israeli Military Takes Over Seminary in West Bank Settlement
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military on Friday took over a seminary known for extremism in the Jewish settlement of Yitzhar in the West Bank, moving in a company of border police troops after radical settlers clashed with soldiers and destroyed army property there over the last week.

headline: Obama Nominates Chairman for Humanities Endowment
text: William Adams has led liberal arts programs and institutions for most of his career, slowly training for an opportunity that finally came on Thursday, when President Obama nominated him to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

headline: Rizzoli Bookstore May Be Better Off Elsewhere
text: On Wednesday afternoon, two days before its scheduled closing, Rizzoli Bookstore was crowded with the sort of people who, never especially populous in Midtown Manhattan, appear even more like icicles in the desert: gray-haired women with Mohawks or turbans, students, men with indifferent facial grooming, older citizens. Some of them did not know that the building, which has housed the bookstore on West 57th Street for the past 29 years, was slated to be demolished, along with two adjoining buildings. When they were told by a salesperson they expressed the requisite shock and lament.

headline: The Fading Honor Code
text: The campus tour for prospective Middlebury students stops in a corridor outside a much-frequented eatery at the student center. Here, the guide directs their attention to a glass case exhibiting signatures of every freshman who has signed the honor code, a pledge made during orientation. To high school students fresh out of the SAT and A.P. grind, these signatures suggest that the competition for high scores is over; learning would now be fuller and more meaningful. Lowering their gaze, however, they might notice three trash bins lined up under the display. This juxtaposition looks to be a fitting metaphor for Middlebury’s attitude toward its honor code.

headline: Fast Cash: Work a Reunion
text: One sign of spring: older folks whizzing around campus in golf carts. Reunion season kicks in on the heels of commencement (and again at homecoming), and somebody has to drive those carts, give directions and tend bar — with an assist from a laminated sheet of cocktail recipes.

headline: Pomp From the Past
text: It’s almost over. The first spring graduates will be walking next week. We share inspiration from commencements of the last half-century.

headline: Steven Pinker’s Mind Games
text: The Harvard professor culled exam questions from his course “Psychological Science.” Test your knowledge.

headline: What Makes a Positive College Experience?
text: After a decade of research, Daniel F. Chambliss, an organizational sociologist at Hamilton College, believes he knows what most determines how students feel about their time at college. It comes down to factors like dorm design, friends and extracurricular involvement more than what happens in the classroom. In their new book, “How College Works,” Dr. Chambliss and Christopher G. Takacs describe the findings from an ambitious study of Hamilton students and alumni, using interviews, surveys and even an analysis of academic writing samples to tease out how college has affected them. Although Hamilton, a small, selective, expensive liberal arts college in upstate New York, has little in common with the large state universities and community colleges that most students attend, Dr. Chambliss said the lessons learned could apply everywhere.

headline: Ivy League Ups and (Yes) Downs
text: It’s not really a popularity contest, but among the Ivies, is anything not competitive? Applications to the University of Pennsylvania rose by more than 14 percent this year and fell by as much at Dartmouth.

headline: Because Ze Said So
text: Gender-neutral terms are catching on at more liberal campuses. Here, an essential glossary:

headline: Models With Doctorates
text: The old joke about the value of higher education — What do you call a Ph.D. in philosophy? Oh, waitress! — is getting a new punch line courtesy of Betabrand, based in San Francisco. The clothier has asked women who are Ph.D.s or doctoral candidates to model “smart new spring fashions” (get it?). So far, 120 have applied and 30 are being featured, said Chris Lindland, the chief executive.

headline: Who Advises Best, Pros or Profs?
text: Academic advising has always been one of those intractable problems on college campuses. Students rarely think about it until that frantic moment when they need someone to sign the registration form for next semester’s classes.

headline: The Power Broker of N.Y.U.
