text: Martin Lipton, chairman of the board of New York University, recently took a trustee to lunch at San Pietro, a pricey Manhattan restaurant frequented by the city’s C.E.O.s. Over a meal that lasted several hours, they discussed Mr. Lipton’s plans to step down next year, after 16 years at the helm. “Marty wants his own replacement there a year in advance,” recalled Evan R. Chesler, chairman of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a leading New York law firm. The reason, he said: “The new chairman would be responsible for the process that selects the president who will replace John Sexton.”

headline: Who Am I?
text: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.

headline: Happenings | A New York Pirate Radio Station for the Art Underground Takes Texas
text: Since 2012, the artist, gallerist and publisher Aaron Bondaroff (known to some as the Downtown Don) and Al Moran, his partner in the Los Angeles gallery Ohwow, have been broadcasting Know-Wave, an online radio station that provides a platform for the members of the downtown and L.A. art communities to express themselves, promote their work and interact with each other. It’s a free-form affair: hosts go on-air whenever they want and play whatever they like, be it French gangster rap, underground hip-hop or noise-rock bands you’ve never heard of. Occasionally, they bring in art world personalities for interviews. (Past guests have included Chan Marshall, Rodarte, Dan Colen, Glenn O’Brien and Mykki Blanco.)

headline: Movie Review: ‘Only Lovers Left Alive’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Only Lovers Left Alive.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Joe’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Joe.”

headline: An Uproar Over a Diabetes Article, With a Back Story
text: Many Times readers, some of whom have Type 1 diabetes, are upset over an article last Sunday in which Elisabeth Rosenthal explored the often extraordinary expense of treating the disease. It was an installment in her series, “Paying Till It Hurts,” about the high cost of medical care in America.

headline: Can a Pop-Up Service Fix It? Probably
text: Last Sunday, Adam Sobel approached the Pop Up Repair table at the Greenmarket next to Columbia University, cradling his black espresso machine. A couple of months ago, the steamer wand had started leaking slightly, and Mr. Sobel, a Columbia professor who teaches applied math and earth science, decided to take matters into his own hands. He consulted online instructions and ordered new parts, but found it difficult to properly screw them into the appliance’s hard-to-reach interior nooks and crannies. After his efforts, the machine leaked everywhere.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Draft Day’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Draft Day.”

headline: Tough Tests Looming in 2016 Raise Stakes for G.O.P. in Midterm Elections
text: WASHINGTON — To understand the Republican imperative to capture the Senate in the midterm elections, look toward 2016, when a narrow victory this year could well be swept away.

headline: Round and Round They Go
text: Gifts for bicyclists.

headline: Diplomat Who Led Secret Talks With Iran Plans to Retire
text: WASHINGTON — William J. Burns, a career diplomat who led the Obama administration’s back-channel negotiations with Iran, plans to step down as the State Department’s second-ranking official in October, administration officials said on Friday.

headline: The Gender Wage Gap, by State
text: On Wednesday Senate Republicans blocked consideration of the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would help narrow the persistent wage gap between men and women. A dissection of that vote reveals an even bigger betrayal of women’s economic interests than immediately apparent.

headline: There Goes Tokyo, Stomp by Stomp
text: Sad and stately are probably not the words that come to mind when you think of “Godzilla.” But the Japanese original, restored for its 60th anniversary and playing at Film Forum beginning Friday, should make you think again. The American version, “Godzilla: King of the Monsters!,” released in 1956, was chopped up (40 minutes were cut), rearranged, dubbed and fitted out with new footage with Raymond Burr. The original, a disaster movie and cautionary tale, feels like a different animal, or monster, altogether.

headline: The Great Moderation Is Back
text: Perhaps you remember the Great Moderation, the comforting term economists pinned on the period of relatively steady growth that began in the early 1980s.

headline: After the Squall, Chop Remains for JPMorgan Chase
text: JPMorgan Chase’s clean sheet already looks off-white. For the first time in years, its quarterly earnings weren’t cluttered with special items like big trading losses or legal costs. The bank’s $5.3 billion profit in the three months ended in March fell short of expectations anyway.

headline: Sebelius and Burwell on New Health Roles
text: President Obama, the secretary of Health and Human Services, Kathleen Sebelius, right, and the nominee to succeed her, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, discussed the new administration changes.

headline: For Falcone, No Joy in the Sale of Manischewitz
text: At Seder tables next week, many Passover celebrants will nosh on matzo and gefilte fish made by the Manischewitz Company.

headline: Marcelo Gomes as Romeo
text: American Ballet Theatre’s production of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Video courtesy of American Ballet Theater

headline: Brooklyn Dance Parties Coming to Waterfront Park
text: As a prelude to Celebrate Brooklyn!, the free summer performing arts festival at Prospect Park, the festival’s producer, BRIC, is presenting three dance parties, also free, at Brooklyn Bridge Park. The parties, at Pier 1 on consecutive Thursday evenings (May 8, 15 and 22, at 7 p.m.), will include performances by bands that draw on popular and folk styles from around the globe, as well as D.J. sets and dance lessons.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of AT&T Hacker Known as ‘Weev’
text: A federal appeals court on Friday reversed the conviction of Andrew “Weev” Auernheimer, a hacker and self-described Internet troll, who was accused of stealing the personal data of 114,000 Apple iPad users in 2010.

headline: Iran Secretly Convicted Former Marine, Lawyer Says
text: TEHRAN — Amir Hekmati, a former Marine incarcerated here in August 2011 and sentenced to death on espionage charges that were overturned, was secretly retried by a revolutionary court in December, convicted of “practical collaboration with the American government” and given a 10-year prison term, his new lawyer said this week.

headline: Stars of Their Own Screenplay
text: Four years ago, Daniel Grossman was convinced that his fellow New Yorkers Sofia Alvarez, a playwright and screenwriter, and Adam Squires, a graphic designer, would hit it off. They just needed a nudge, or two or three, that he would be only too happy to provide.

headline: Asparagus, Spanish-Style
text: Once, while traveling in Andalusia, I experienced asparagus Spanish-style.

headline: Marcelo Gomes, the Dancer at Home in Hell’s Kitchen
text: Not long after Marcelo Gomes moved with his dachshund, Lua, into a subcompact (475 square feet) condo in Hell’s Kitchen two and a half years ago, he gave a housewarming party. And as he had done on other break-out-the-champagne occasions, such as his 30th birthday, the Brazilian-born Mr. Gomes, 34, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, gave the guests a gift-buying directive. In this particular instance they were asked to show up with a blue or white vase.

headline: Sweet Tale of Friendship (Sex, Too)
text: Ask John Turturro about his newest project, “Fading Gigolo,” and he will excitedly tell you about the streetwalker films, like “The Life of Oharu” or “Midnight Cowboy,” that helped inspire the idea; the Isaac Bashevis Singer short stories that helped him settle on a tone for the script; and the filmmakers, like Michael Cimino, Spike Lee and the Coen brothers, who helped him develop his own directorial style.

headline: A Filmmaker’s ‘Progressive Pathway’
text: For nearly 50 years, Marco Bellocchio has been one of the cinema’s great poets of rebellion and escape — from family, from the Italian bourgeoisie and from the conformism and hypocrisy they represent. His most recent film, “Dormant Beauty,” plays a variation on this theme: Opportunistic politicians try to keep an accident victim from being taken off life support, preventing her from escaping a 17-year coma.

headline: Big Ticket | A Home in the Sky for $30.5 Million
text: A three-bedroom unit on the 60th floor of One57, the Extell Development Company’s 90-story spike of bluish glass that does not scrape the Midtown sky as much as puncture it, sold for $30,551,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Pay the Babysitter Over $1,900 This Year? You Owe It to Her to Put Her On the Books
text: If you pay a babysitter more than $1,900 in a calendar year, you’re classified as a household employer. That means you have the responsibility to administer the payroll and tax process for your babysitter. We don’t have a full-time babysitter, but it doesn’t take anything close to a full time schedule to hit $1,900. At $20 an hour, a parent owes taxes at 95 hours, or less than 2 hours a week.

headline: A Freewheeling Pursuit of Spontaneity on Film
text: Many a director has stumbled while chasing after a sense of spontaneity through improvisation. But in a few short years, the Brooklyn filmmaker Nathan Silver, 30, has already made lively attempts at capturing the flickering, uncertain energies among people in a room — pushing boundaries or just sharing space — with his freely made yet nuanced movies. Stumbles and messes along the way are only part of the action, and part of what make up his garrulous, willful characters.

headline: A Mayor of Sorts Meets His Public
text: Harvey Fierstein had just finished watching a preview on Wednesday night of his new play, “Casa Valentina,” when he tried, without much success, to make his way to the exit.

headline: Hasidim See Things Through a New Lens
text: FailedMessiah.com, the muckraking blog written by the once-Hasidic Jew Shmarya Rosenberg, is best known (and, in some quarters, loathed) for posts exposing crimes suspected of being perpetrated by Hasidic and other highly observant Jews.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Other Michael Lewis Backlash
text: When Michael Lewis rolled out his new book with an appearance on the CBS show “60 Minutes” and an excerpt in The New York Times magazine, the author was praised by literary critics and panned by high-frequency traders.

headline: Last Night to Bend the Rules
text: Dina Litovsky has been photographing bachelorette parties, where brides-to-be confront the tricky rituals of the last night of single life.

headline: Corvette Number Eight Pulled From National Corvette Museum Sinkhole
text: The chasm that opened beneath the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., in February — swallowing eight of its prized cars – has at last been emptied of all of its valuable contents. A few of the cars pulled from the sinkhole were in decent condition and others were in worse, albeit salvageable shape.

headline: The Gun Report: April 11, 2014
text: On the morning of January 30, Shawn Harrington, a 38-year-old assistant basketball coach at a high school in Chicago, was stopped at a red light in the Humboldt Park neighborhood when two men opened fire on his car. Harrington shielded his 15-year-old daughter, whom he was driving to school, and was hit by two bullets, one of which passed through his upper back and cracked his vertebrae, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. Another bullet lodged in the headrest of the seat in which his daughter was sitting.

headline: Syria’s Lost Generation
text: SOMETHING about the boy was not right. He seemed disoriented, detached from his surroundings. He barely spoke, and when he did, it was in flat monosyllables, his eyes unfocused and downcast, as if too heavy to roll up from the weight of all they had seen. He was the picture of quiet devastation, of a childhood forever splintered.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 62
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Quinoa Salad for a Crowd
text: Melissa Clark makes a quinoa salad with soft roasted carrots and crunchy fried leeks that can serve as a side course or a main dish.

headline: Give Your Heart to Quinoa
text: It took me a while to give my heart to quinoa.

headline: Kathleen Sebelius Was Too Cool and Too Patient
text: Kathleen Sebelius was known for her patience and cool under savage attack by Republicans, who treated her as a stand-in for the health law. She sat through hearings calmly reciting talking points while they fumed and fulminated for their audience.

headline: Police Clash With Squatters in Rio de Janeiro Slum
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Violent clashes broke out on Friday between police officers and squatters here when the authorities dislodged thousands of families from a newly formed favela, or slum, in a complex of abandoned commercial buildings, focusing attention on the rising tension over surging rents and housing shortages.

headline: Review: 2014 Nissan Rogue SV
text: Nissan brings a new Rogue to the compact crossover wars.

headline: G.M. Documents Reveal Years of Talks on Defect
text: Last month, Mary T. Barra, the new chief executive of General Motors, told a panel of stern and dubious House members that she first became aware of a serious safety issue with the Chevrolet Cobalt in December, two months before the company announced a recall that would eventually cover 2.6 million cars.

headline: When Cars Ruled the World’s Fair
text: From its humble origins as a Queens garbage dump — inspiration for the valley of ashes in “The Great Gatsby” — Flushing Meadows Corona Park emerged as the site of two world’s fairs, in 1939-40 and 1964-65.

headline: 1964 World’s Fair’s View of the Future
text: The World’s Fair in New York promised visitors a glance into the future of automobiles. Automakers like General Motors, Ford and Chrysler put on elaborate displays of their predictions.

headline: Adapting to a New Environment
text: For those of the mammalian persuasion, evolution has tended to be a leisurely process. This has not been the case among compact crossover utility vehicles, which in the last half-dozen years have made leaps in sophistication while adapting to a changing high-tech environment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, India, Spain and Italy.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: The Sixth Stage of Grief: Buying a Puppy
text: Last fall, I received a puppy for my birthday. The gift, from my wife, Cynthia, was welcome, even if it came around 50 years too late.

headline: Texas Monthly Sues Times Co. Over New Hire
text: The publisher of Texas Monthly filed a lawsuit on Friday against The New York Times Company related to The Times’s hiring of the magazine’s departing editor in chief, Jake Silverstein.

headline: California School Officials on Bus Crash
text: Earl Perkins and Tom Waldman of the Los Angeles Unified School District discussed the steps the district will take following the bus crash.

headline: He Tells the Clintons How to Lose a Little
text: Nine years ago, on their 30th wedding anniversary, Hillary Rodham Clinton gave her husband a gift she hoped would ensure many more years together: Dr. Mark Hyman.

headline: The Mellon Lifestyle as a Brand
text: “It’s a good story. Do you want me to start, love?” Nicole Hanley Mellon asked her husband, Matthew Mellon, on a recent Friday. The couple were seated in the living room of their apartment in the Pierre hotel, telling how they met in 2006 at a wedding in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: He Walked by Night
text: New York at night is a Rorschach blot: What you see depends on your state of mind. Maybe that street scene in front of you looks like “La Dolce Vita”; maybe it’s “Taxi Driver.”

headline: U.S. Says Iran’s Pick for U.N. Envoy Won’t Get a Visa
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday said it would bar an Iranian diplomat nominated as United Nations ambassador from entering the country, in a rebuke to Iran at a time when the United States is engaged in delicate negotiations with Tehran over its nuclear program.

headline: Kanye Teams Up With Adidas, John Galliano and Oscar De la Renta Break Up and The Met Announces Its Gala Theme
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: A Caribbean Resort Goes Solar
text: Blessed by year-round tropical sunshine, the Caribbean seems like a natural candidate for solar power.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
text: Bill Cunningham reporting on the first truly spring week in New York City.

headline: Belafonte Settles Dispute Over Martin Luther King Documents
text: Harry Belafonte and the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have settled their differences over the ownership of documents that Mr. Belafonte said had been given to him by Dr. King; his widow, Coretta Scott King; and a close aide, Stanley Levison. According to a joint statement by Jonathan S. Abady, Mr. Belafonte’s lawyer, and Michael W. Tyler, the lawyer for Dr. King’s estate, “the parties have reached a compromise, the terms of which are confidential and have resulted in Mr. Belafonte retaining possession of the documents.”

headline: Tips to Manage Spending in Retirement
text: ADVISERS put a considerable amount of effort into talking to clients about accumulating a life savings. But advisers and their clients tend to devote less thought to how to spend that money when it’s time.

headline: Offshore and Underground
text: I had lunch with Gabriel Zucman today, co-author of the startling new paper (pdf) showing that the concentration of wealth at the very top — the 0.1% — is fully back to Gilded Age levels.And he pointed me to another paper that flew under my, and I suspect other peoples’, radar: his demonstration that a lot of wealth at the top is held in offshore tax havens (pdf).

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
text: Hunt and Gather Finally, spring arrived, in a galvanized bucket of tulips at Union Square and planters full of tulips, daffodils and hyacinth. People stripped off coats for a first peek at spring fashion. And Saturday’s Tartan Day Parade, the city’s shortest (10 blocks, 20 minutes), was alive with tartans, bagpipes and Scotties. Fabergé held an egg hunt: 250 artist-designed eggs placed across the city to be auctioned on April 22 as a benefit for Studio in a School, an arts education group, and the Elephant Family, a global conservation organization.

headline: Tap Universe Shrugs Off Any Notion of Borders
text: If you had to define tap dancing, “Rhythm in Motion” would be a difficult place to start. This celebration of (mostly) new tap choreography, presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation, shows that despite the common denominator of percussive feet, tap today defies easy categorization. Program B, seen on Thursday at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, exhibited the many functions of the form: tap as pure music, as political statement, as nonverbal narrative.

headline: Comedians in Two Realms
text: These days, TV stars routinely do making-of videos while their hit shows are still on the air. Their predecessors didn’t have that luxury, but their recollections are being captured by programs like PBS’s “Pioneers of Television,” which begins a new season on Tuesday (check local listings) with a particularly entertaining episode, “Standup to Sitcom.” The episode includes Jerry Seinfeld, Roseanne Barr, Tim Allen and Bob Newhart, who describe how their sitcoms came about and how they made the transition from doing stand-up to acting on TV. These stars made it look easy, but it’s a challenge. “The difference between the stand-up and the sitcom is you’re going from the least collaborative medium there is to the most collaborative,” Mr. Seinfeld says. “The reason you become a comedian is you’re not a good collaborator, you’re not good with people, you’re not good in social situations or professional situations.”

headline: Global Groove and a Throwback
text: Born in the Democratic Republic of Congo and raised in Belgium, the rapper and singer Baloji makes chameleonic African music. His most recent album, “Kinshasa Succursale,” revisited Congolese music past and present. But he also draws on grooves worldwide. His songs and rhymes (largely in French) address political and cultural matters with multilayered wordplay and unmistakable conviction, even as the party continues. (7:30 p.m. Thursday, Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715.)

headline: Madness and Movement
text: Having a theater to call your own — on the Upper West Side, no less — is practically unheard-of for a choreographer in New York. The rare exception is David Parker, whose company, the Bang Group, has been at the West End Theater for more than a decade. Mr. Parker is generous with the real estate, opening the space to Soaking WET, an eclectic dance series.

headline: Enticing Choices in One Afternoon
text: The brilliant British pianist Stephen Hough plays an adventurous program on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. Liszt’s visionary Piano Sonata and Brahms’s Fantasies (Op. 116) are the best-known works he will play. But how often do you get to hear piano pieces by Wagner and Bruckner? (5 p.m., Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org.)

headline: 3,200 Crabs, 1 Unstoppable Man
text: Despite being prevented from leaving China, Ai Weiwei manages to maintain a healthy international career. If one were to judge by news media attention alone, one might think him the only Chinese contemporary artist in existence. His most innovative work has been through various forms of social media, in what might be called a continuing digital version of performance art. (A book of his blog posts, published in 2011, remains his magnum opus.)

headline: ‘I Like to Be Crazy on the Stage’
text: If you’re a certain kind of soprano, you end up learning a lot about going insane. Young, agile voices like Olga Peretyatko’s earn mad scene after mad scene.

headline: Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams
text: DALLAS — The winners of the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams on the final day of the Spring Nationals here last month were Gan Ling, Huang Yan, Hu Wen, Wang Hanyong, Li Lixuan and Li Yiting, all from China. They finished 0.75 victory points ahead of their countrywomen Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Shen Qi and Zhou Lihua.

headline: A Climate of Complexity
text: All this angst about climate change, and the answer’s been there all the time: Indiana Jones.

headline: A Venerable Tapestry, Woven Anew
text: The stringent harmonies of Shostakovich’s broody String Quartet No. 12 filled the living room of Eugene Drucker’s Upper West Side apartment on a recent morning as the Emerson String Quartet rehearsed. Mr. Drucker and Philip Setzer, the quartet’s founding violinists, sat on one side of the room opposite the violist Lawrence Dutton. With his back to the window, the cellist Paul Watkins had a view of a bookcase lined with nine Grammy Awards and side tables bristling with framed photographs of musicians paying handwritten tributes to the quartet’s reign in the chamber music pantheon: Bernstein, Levine, Rostropovich.

headline: In Poignant Paeans, Lost Players Live On
text: An eerie tapping sound accompanies parts of Shostakovich’s String Quartet No. 13, which the Emerson String Quartet will perform on April 23 at Alice Tully Hall. Players take turns striking the body of their instruments with the wooden tips of their bows, with the steady, precise motion of someone hammering a small nail. The spooky effect is part of Shostakovich’s bleakly beautiful tribute to Vadim Borisovsky, the longstanding violist of the Beethoven Quartet, who retired from the ensemble in 1964 because of ill health.

headline: Ex-Connecticut Governor Pleads Not Guilty to Campaign-Related Charges
text: NEW HAVEN — Ten years after he resigned in disgrace from Connecticut’s highest office, former Gov. John G. Rowland pleaded not guilty on Friday to an indictment on campaign-related charges that could send him back to prison.

headline: Health Reform and Affinity Fraud
text: Over at Talking Points Memo, they seem bemused by the violent reaction on the right to any suggestion that Obamacare is working as well as all the evidence suggests it is. Josh Marshall and Ezra Klein both made a fairly obvious point: Kathleen Sebelius’s resignation was almost surely timed to follow good news, so that her departure wouldn’t be easy to spin as part of a narrative about failed reform. The right, however, went ballistic — not so much expressing skepticism over the good enrollment numbers and the encouraging survey data as expressing total outrage and bewilderment that anyone believes the good news. On the right they know, just know, that it’s a total disaster.

headline: In the Air | Classic Rock
text: Marble emerges as the material of choice in contemporary design.

headline: Wet Spring Weather Requires More Attentive Driving
text: The rain that tends to arrive in April often makes roads slick and dangerous. Mark Cox, director of the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs, Colo., said in a telephone interview that with snow and ice absent from roads, motorists can be lulled into a false sense of security when it is raining.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
text: Saw them last night at Brooklyn Academy of Music. Totally amazing. Every time you thought they couldn’t surprise you any more with their range, they pulled something else out — and not just by singing in Gaelic. When Rhiannon Giddens kicked off her shoes and starting dancing, the whole audience lost it.

headline: Key to Tougher Teslas: Titanium
text: A cloud of doubt lingering over Tesla Motors parted on March 26, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed an investigation of the Model S begun in response to two cars that were destroyed by fires after striking objects on the highway.

headline: Formula One’s New-Age Hybrids Find Their Footing
text: Lewis Hamilton, the 29-year-old Englishman who won it, called it “a racer’s race,” perhaps the best ever of his 24 victories, and by the measure of how many others in the sport described it, that was no boast.

headline: Highlighting the Classical, Hitting the Mystical, Flirting With the Demonic
text: Almost every season at the New York Philharmonic, gifted artists in their 20s, sometimes even younger, are soloists in concertos. So it was surprising that it took until Thursday night for the superb British pianist Paul Lewis, 41, to make his Philharmonic debut at Avery Fisher Hall. He played a majestic and insightful performance of Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor with the revered maestro Christoph von Dohnanyi conducting.

headline: Obama, Citing New Laws, Says the G.O.P. Is Moving to Restrict Voting Rights
text: President Obama deplored on Friday what he called a Republican campaign to deny voting rights to millions of Americans as he stepped up efforts to rally his political base heading into a competitive midterm campaign season.

headline: Capitalizing on Her Leap to Stardom
text: It goes without saying that when you’re handed the part of a lifetime, you play it to the hilt. In the case of Lupita Nyong’o, the 31-year old Oscar winner — born in Mexico, raised in Kenya, educated at Yale and vaulted to what seemed like overnight fame — the part of the slave Patsey in “12 Years a Slave” was just a preamble for a far larger role.

headline: The Body as Helix in an Infinite Cosmos
text: “Open your joints,” the choreographer Shen Wei quietly exhorted his troupe recently in a large, airy studio at the Mark Morris Dance Center. “Drop your weight, stretch and go down even deeper, so your body is completely free.” Mr. Shen was preparing the dancers for a run of performances of his 2005 work “Map,” opening on April 29 at Judson Memorial Church, a stately neo-Romanesque pile on Washington Square

headline: Amid Flames and Flowers, She Dashes Through Time
text: In “Orlando,” a monologue presented by Peak Performances at Montclair State University, the Scottish actress Judith Williams plays a boy, a young man, a male ambassador and several women, too. Of course, they’re all the same person.

headline: 2 Kenyans Kidnapped in Somalia in 2011 Are Found Alive
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Two Kenyan aid workers who were abducted by the Shabab militant group in 2011 were rescued on Thursday evening by Kenyan troops who are part of a peacekeeping mission in Somalia, officials said Friday.

headline: A Lucky Strike, Indeed
text: “Mad Men” made its debut on AMC in the summer of 2007, the creation of a former writer of “The Sopranos” whose pilot script was rejected by HBO, starring an unknown leading man and residing on a network best known as a second-tier movie channel, one that didn’t cost extra.

headline: East Meets West, Over Cocktails
text: LOS ANGELES — During its heyday in the 1940s, the Forbidden City in San Francisco billed itself as “the world’s most famous Chinese nightclub.” A jacketed doorman greeted visitors outside, drawing them into the club’s grand interior, with its rich tapestries and Mandarin-collared bartenders. On the bandstand sat a large gold Buddha looking down on the audience, which often included celebrities like Bob Hope, Rita Hayworth and Lauren Bacall. Tourists from the Midwest were there, too, lured by articles in Life and Look magazines, and by promises of the club’s “exotic splendor” and “all-star Chinese floor show.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman: Learning to Dispense With the Negative
text: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman hardly seem like victims of self-doubt. Between them, they have covered the Clinton White House and the fall of the Soviet Union (Ms. Shipman), anchors BBC World News America (Ms. Kay) and learned to kiteboard at nearly 40 (Ms. Kay again). And yet both say they have had to work to overcome fears of inadequacy, tendencies to defer to male colleagues and “tortured cycles of useless self-recrimination.” In “The Confidence Code,” to be published on Tuesday, they lay out a path for women to become more self-assured. In phone conversations and at a lunch date (served by Sidra Forman, a Washington chef), Ms. Kay and Ms. Shipman discussed how to swat away creeping negative thoughts and what they are really thinking when they’re on television. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Introducing Corporate to Cool
text: On a chilly night not long ago, Katie Longmyer sat behind the D.J. in the Living Room Bar at the W New York Downtown hotel and surveyed her creation: fashion-industry denizens, purveyors of high art and Lower East Side hipsters, all dancing with gleeful abandon.

headline: A Niche No Longer
text: There’s a lot to appreciate about the new Nissan Rogue: more room, good fuel economy, impressive crash protection and a zestful approach to a mountain road.

headline: Al Jazeera Series Depicts U.S. Problem
text: It turns out that there is a reason to watch Al Jazeera America.

headline: You’ll Go Far, My Pet
text: Not to brag, but we may have a little genius on our hands. Our 6-month-old is up before dawn playing brain games. She knows her way around an iPad and practically devours puzzles, and I’m teaching her to read. Just recently, she mastered an advanced chess toy.

headline: An Eye on the Ball, Even in Tax Season
text: All you people who haven’t filed your taxes yet, John R. Lieberman’s got your number. A certified public accountant and personal financial specialist who has talked about tax issues on “The Daily Show” and on CNN, he likens April 15 to Christmas Day: There are people who shop early in September, and there are people who show up on Dec. 24. Mr. Lieberman, 55, who is managing director at Perelson Weiner in New York and does a lot of international work, lives on the Upper East Side with Dr. Andrea P. Thau, 54, an optometrist. The couple has two sons, Evan, 24, in his third year at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv, and Richard, 21, graduating from Binghamton University this year. Sunday is typically a work day for Mr. Lieberman, especially this time of year, but he tries to get in some tennis; he once aspired to the pro circuit.

headline: Killing Inmates the Old-Fashioned Way
text: On Wednesday, the Tennessee state senate voted 23-3 to allow execution by electrocution if drugs for lethal injection — the method of choice around the country — are unavailable.

headline: A Perfect Place to Hunt the Living Dead in Queens
text: As the inhuman shrieks drew near, six survivors of the zombie apocalypse huddled together, scanned the blacklit maze of the asylum and gripped their assault rifles. When a severed arm flew out from around the corner, they screamed and unloaded their weapons into the darkness.

headline: Herbalife Shares Decline on Criminal Inquiry News
text: Herbalife shares plunged late Friday afternoon after a news report linked the diet supplements company to a criminal investigation.

headline: Vienna Philharmonic Finds Owners of a Nazi Gift
text: It is a simple oil painting, showing a sailing ship moored in a harbor, an early work by the French artist Paul Signac, made in 1883. For decades it lay hidden away in a storage space of the august Vienna Philharmonic, a 172-year-old institution that is one of the cultural pillars of Europe.

headline: April Is the Cruelest Month
text: Brooklyn Ballet, which includes classical and street dancers, is an ambitious enterprise. That’s a gentle way of saying it’s all over the map. For “Vectors, Marys, and Snow,” the company’s spring program, seen last weekend at the Actors Fund Arts Center, Brooklyn Ballet unveiled a handful of works, including excerpts from its forthcoming “Brooklyn Nutcracker.” It’s true that there was a bracing chill in the air, but Tchaikovsky in April is just cruel.

headline: Help for the Big Guys
text: Even those among us who are doing the best can use a little help now and then.

headline: Trying to Regain Childhood’s Magic
text: NEW HAVEN — “I’m sick of my rational existence in the ‘real world,’ ” the elderly man grumbles to his grandson. “I want to live once again in one full of mystery and magic and shadows I can play with.”

headline: Whose Picture Is It, Anyway?
text: Last fall, while on a family bike ride around Central Park, I took a photo of my 9-year-old son. His cheeks were flushed, his big brown eyes were lit with happiness and the golden sun made his light-olive skin appear to glow. It was a great picture and one I wanted to share with my friends online.

headline: Mentally Ill, in Prison and Outside
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeing Asian Cultures, Through an Indigo Lens
text: A 57-foot-tall blank wall under a skylight beckoned to Jinyoung Jin last fall, when she became associate director of cultural programs at the Charles B. Wang Center at Stony Brook University. “I felt I had to show something on it,” said Ms. Jin, who had a similar impulse about other vast expanses in the Wang Center, the 120,000-square-foot center for Asian and Asian-American arts and culture that she now oversees. “My purpose is to fill up the whole space,” she said recently as she stood on a second-floor bridge that offers a panoramic view of the sunlit white wall, which is no longer empty.

headline: Deciding Where to Set the Limits on Surveillance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Persons of Interest
text: This issue is about style and rooms that are intensely personal. Yet the term “personal style” (like the term “lifestyle”) is now so overused in the decorating and design sphere as to be essentially meaningless. The homes, studios and work featured in this issue are personal in the sense that they are intimate — each seems like an organic extension, expressed through space and objects, of their makers. They don’t aim to be expressions of “personal style”; rather they just possess great style, which is always sui generis and, at least in the case of all the places we feature here, from the heart.

headline: Auto Nirvana
text: The 1964 New York World’s Fair reflected a world where the automobile had reached the pinnacle of its power and prestige.

headline: Screening Air Passengers
Tax-Preparer Licensing
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 11
text: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Moments From Pistorius’s Testimony
text: A look back at the most dramatic moments from Oscar Pistorius’s testimony as he took the stand in his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: House G.M. Hearing Documents
text: Reference documents compiled as part of an investigation by the House Energy and Commerce Committee into why it took General Motors more than a decade to publicly disclose a dangerous flaw in a small-car ignition switch and to order a recall of the vehicles with the defective switch.

headline: Cups With Hitler’s Image Are Investigated in Germany
text: BERLIN — Some people think they see statues of saints weeping or an image of Jesus in their toast. A woman in western Germany recently thought she saw Adolf Hitler on a cup, nestled between rose petals and gaudy English writing. It turns out she was not imagining the profile of the man with a toothbrush mustache.

headline: And Now, Kosher Cheeses
text: It’s tough for those obsessed with Époisses and other fine cheeses to understand. How is it that, for generations, many ancient, runny or stinky cheeses were not available to those orthodox Jews who adhere to strict kashrut dietary law? Perhaps because those laws forbid meat and milk from being served together and, as a result, dairy products often get short shrift. But now people like Brent Delman, who is known as the Cheese Guy, are letting observant Jews in on a wide world of cheeses.

headline: A Latin Heart Beats Anew
text: When I reviewed the Cuban Crocodile in Long Beach in 2012, it was the only Cuban restaurant I knew of on Long Island. It was damaged by Hurricane Sandy, and Corazon de Cuba opened in its former quarters less than four months ago.

headline: Jesse Winchester, Writer and Singer of Thoughtful Songs, Dies at 69
text: Jesse Winchester, a honey-voiced singer who wrote thoughtful songs with deep Southern roots, died on Friday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 69.

headline: Spring Design Issue
text: In our spring design issue, T celebrates risk takers. Leading the way is the architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand, whose elegantly spare Paris apartment, with its towering windows and generous slabs of marble, puts a new spin on minimalism. We travel to Tangier — long a refuge for adventurers and free-thinking outsiders — where a merry band of eccentric expats are letting their freak flags fly. We step into the homes of a pair of visionaries: the self-taught sculptor Alma Allen, whose journey as an art star has taken him from the streets of SoHo to the wild borderland of Joshua Tree, Calif., and the madcap designer Nicky Haslam, whose new London flat reflects his flair for the unconventional, and must be seen to be believed. Elsewhere, David Netto makes the case for personality and practicality in interior design; the international art gallery Hauser & Wirth bucks convention by opening an outpost in English farm country; the legendary French fabric house Le Manach gets a new lease on life; and the surrealist director Alejandro Jodorowsky as well as the surprisingly-nimble-in-the-kitchen pop star Kelis snack on gold popcorn while considering the future and blinged-out Louboutins. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Remember Fort Pillow!
text: On April 12, 1864 — the third anniversary of the firing on Fort Sumter — a Confederate force led by the brilliant and brutal Nathan Bedford Forrest attacked Union troops holding Fort Pillow, an obscure post in West Tennessee. What happened after Forrest’s men captured Fort Pillow remains one of the most notorious and controversial incidents of the Civil War.

headline: U.S. Denies It Knew of Heartbleed Bug on the Web
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration denied Friday that the National Security Agency or other parts of the federal government had known about the Heartbleed security vulnerability that has created widespread fears that passwords and other sensitive information belonging to millions of Internet users may have been revealed over the past two years.

headline: Journalists Who Broke News on N.S.A. Surveillance Return to the U.S.
text: The journalists had been threatened, cajoled and condemned by the British and American governments. Their work together had set off a hunt for their source and a debate on both sides of the Atlantic about government surveillance.

headline: Local Views, Bucolic and Serene
text: Step into the new show at the Bruce Museum these days, and you are instantly transported to a soothing, bucolic world where water burbles, crickets chirp, and calm reigns. And that is before you even look at a single one of the 29 paintings in “Pasture to Pond: Connecticut Impressionism.”

headline: Financial Advice for People Who Aren’t Rich
text: For a couple of years now, a number of entrepreneurs have been racing to solve the same problem: the financial services industry’s persistent inability to provide personalized advice and appropriate investments at a reasonable price to customers who are not rich.

headline: Mystery Surrounds Death of Ukrainian Activist
text: BARMAKY, Ukraine — For more than 20 years, Oleksandr Muzychko battled and somehow survived Russian power, taking up arms against Moscow-backed rebels in Georgia and Moldova, against Russia’s army in Chechnya and finally against Ukraine’s pro-Russia president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Samsung Calls on Google Executive to Defend Innovation
text: In Apple’s latest patent fight with Samsung Electronics, lawyers on both sides are relying on the power of a good story to sway a jury. And Samsung is borrowing one from Google.

headline: Tax Returns Show Drop in Obamas’ Earnings
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, released their 2013 tax returns on Friday, showing a sharp decrease in their personal income since filing their 2012 returns.

headline: Former Ranger Traces Troubles to 2004 Fight
text: Dan LaCouture’s troubles began, he said, on Jan. 5, 2004, when one of his Rangers teammates got into trouble at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Cano’s Fresh Start
text: The baseball experience of my childhood led me to believe in the stability of the baseball family. Even though free agency was alive and well in those years, my favorite players were mainstays. Mike Schmidt, Steve Carlton and Garry Maddox were Philadelphia Phillies legends who showed me that once you are granted the golden ticket to play professional baseball, you can enjoy a long career and be identified mainly with one team.

headline: Idea of New Attention Disorder Spurs Research, and Debate
text: With more than six million American children having received a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, concern has been rising that the condition is being significantly misdiagnosed and overtreated with prescription medications.

headline: Pope Francis Asks for Forgiveness
text: The pope personally asked for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done “for having sexually abused children.”

headline: Pope Takes Responsibility in Priests’ Abuse Scandal
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis said on Friday that he took personal responsibility for the harm done by priests who sexually abused children, and he pledged that the Roman Catholic Church would confront the issue unflinchingly and impose sanctions when necessary.

headline: In an Excruciatingly Hip Neighborhood, a Bloody Encounter
text: The manager of a Mobil station in Manhattan’s meatpacking district shrugged and shook his head.

headline: Rules Violation at Augusta: Unauthorized Quesadilla
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bode Miller, a six-time Olympic medalist in ski racing, was just another face in the gallery at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday. He did, though, look slightly out of place initially, having arrived with a light ski parka to combat the morning chill and a baseball cap promoting not a golf entity but Sölden, an Austrian ski resort.

headline: Blast Survivor Thanks Her Rescuers
text: In the devastation that followed a gas explosion in East Harlem last month, firefighters found a woman through a break in the smoke: a flash of color amid the debris that was once 1644 Park Avenue.

headline: An Italian Menu to Feed Everyone
text: Some restaurants just feel great to walk into. Casual but stylish, Sorella occupies a big, high-ceilinged room decorated with sepia photos of the owners’ and employees’ ancestors from the old country and offers views of Hartford’s Old State House. The tripartite floor plan accommodates a lively bar scene, couples dining intimately, and families, in a cozy back space anchored by a colorfully tiled potbellied wood-burning pizza oven.

headline: Battle for the Bigger Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — On the surface it’s just an old-fashioned game of Hollywood tit for tat: Cinemark, the nation’s No. 3 theater chain, has been promoting the growth of its network of extra-large movie screens, and Imax, the standard-bearer in the format for decades, has reacted with popped claws.

headline: Bookstores in Seattle Soar, and Embrace an Old Nemesis: Amazon.com
text: SEATTLE — A love of books and bookstores runs deep in the sinews of this city, where gray skies and drizzle can drive a person to drink, or read, or both. A long-running annual survey ranks Seattle the country’s second-most literate big city, behind Washington, D.C., as measured by things like the number of bookstores, library resources, newspaper circulation and education.

headline: In Brazil, Usual Olympics Worry With Unusual Validity
text: The smash-hit London Olympics were nearing a close in August 2012, and I found myself in an elevator at the main news media center with a small delegation of observers from the next Summer Games, in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: The Apple Chronicles
text: So they’re at it again, Apple and Samsung, fighting over patents in a courtroom in San Jose, Calif. They had a similar fight in 2012, in the same courtroom, which Apple won. Samsung has also won its share of these legal battles, including in Australia.

headline: Stage Is Her Playground: Jump-Rope, Fuzzy Tube and Windup Toy
text: In her new solo “Forested,” the second piece in a trilogy exploring the ways an audience’s gaze can be guided and controlled, the dancer and choreographer Amanda Loulaki uses her body as a vessel. Her compact frame has been on trips like this before. Ms. Loulaki, a New York artist born in Crete, is enamored of the choreographic potential of stringing together fragments of movement, gestures and emotions to create an ambiguous whole.

headline: Tom Petri, G.O.P. Congressman From Wisconsin, Is Retiring
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, said Friday that he would not seek re-election after 35 years in Congress.

headline: Hoofing It Into the Future
text: Ask tap dancers what inspires them, and the conversation will probably turn to teachers, mentors, artistic ancestors. Perhaps more than any other, this is a dance form that knows where it came from, reveres its roots and doesn’t relegate its history to the past.

headline: Evoking Creation, Occasionally With a Big Bang
text: According to a line of Kabbalistic commentary, Genesis — Bereshit in Hebrew — begins not with the letter bet, the second of the alphabet, but with an invisible aleph, a letter that is inaudible on its own and here represents the sublime and translucent state that preceded the world’s creation. On Tuesday evening the German composer Matthias Pintscher conducted the formidable Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall in the New York premiere of his own “bereshit,” a mesmerizing and sophisticated work that grew out of a whispered harmonic played high on a double bass and the barely-there hum of a gong — sounds as amorphous as an aleph.

headline: Utopian Vision Born of a Harsh Truth
text: The exhibition “Aljira at 30: Dream and Reality,” at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton, starts with a video revisiting the 1967 Newark riots, titled “5 Days in July,” by Chuck Schultz and Esther Podemski. Made in 2007, it was shown that year at Aljira, an alternative exhibition space in Newark for emerging and underrepresented artists. The two-screen piece shows the city on fire and footage of the National Guard overrunning the rebellion of the African-American community after the arrest and beating of a cabdriver for a traffic infraction.

headline: Japan: New Energy Strategy Approved
text: Japan’s cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards. The new strategy, first proposed by the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe two months ago, scraps a promise made by a previous government after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster to phase out atomic energy. Under the new plan, Japan could start as early as August to restart at least some of its 48 operable commercial reactors, which were stopped after the Fukushima accident spread nuclear radiation across northern Japan.

headline: Murder Charge for Teenager in Fire That Killed an Officer
text: A teenager who the authorities say set a fire in the hallway of a Brooklyn high-rise last week was charged with second-degree murder on Friday, two days after the death of one of the two New York City police officers who were critically injured in the blaze.

headline: Sebelius’s Slow-Motion Resignation From the Cabinet
text: WASHINGTON — Everyone knew it was a disaster. After Kathleen Sebelius appeared on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” last October, she and her staff at the Department of Health and Human Services felt she had been sandbagged by Mr. Stewart. At the White House, President Obama’s top aides were aghast at her wooden performance.

headline: Chinese Fireball Mystery
text: China’s largest energy company has made the country’s first commercially viable shale gas discovery, but the path to energy independence is fraught with risks, as one town has seen first-hand.

headline: Derailed by Masters Win, Bubba Watson Seeks Another
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bubba Watson, the 2012 Masters champion, concedes his mind was not on golf last year.

headline: China Takes On Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
text: JIAOSHIZHEN, China — Residents of this isolated mountain valley of terraced cornfields were just going to sleep last April when they were jolted by an enormous roar, followed by a tower of flames. A shock wave rolled across the valley, rattling windows in farmhouses and village shops, and a mysterious, pungent gas swiftly pervaded homes.

headline: Doubly Disabled in Life
text: Americans with intellectual and developmental disabilities historically have been shuttled far from society’s mainstream into segregated lives and workplace serfdom, earning wages as low as pennies per hour for the most repetitive and menial jobs. The Supreme Court in 1999 pronounced this kind of treatment a civil rights violation under the Americans With Disabilities Act, but abuse and isolation from society have continued to this day.

headline: Inching Forward With Iran
text: There is no doubt that the negotiations between the major powers and Iran over its nuclear program have been productive. All the nations involved — the United States, Britain, France, China, Germany, Iran, even Russia — appear committed to reaching a deal that will go beyond November’s interim agreement and produce a permanent one. The chief negotiators completed a third round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday and plan to meet again on May 13, after which they expect to begin drafting actual text. They hope to wrap it all up by July 20.

headline: It’s Leaving 57th Street, but Rizzoli Bookstore Vows Sequel
text: Lea Noring of Acworth, Ga., had a destination in mind for her first trip to New York, and it was not one of those crowded places like Times Square or the Empire State Building that the locals disdain as tourist traps.

headline: At Phillips Exeter, a World of Religious Diversity
text: EXETER, N.H. — “Money, prestige, success — they have become slave masters,” Milton Syed, a slight 18-year-old from the Bronx, told his audience. He was wearing a necktie with his collared shirt, as required by the dress code here at Phillips Exeter Academy, alma mater of Daniel Webster and Franklin Pierce, of Gore Vidal and Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Mr. Syed, a senior, was preaching a khutbah, the Friday sermon after Muslim prayers, to a group of 10, including several fellow Muslim students, a Muslim math teacher and a blond girl who was not Muslim, just curious.

headline: The Self-Sort
text: This week, four presidents journeyed to Austin, Tex., to address the Civil Rights Summit and remark on President Lyndon B. Johnson’s legacy on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act.

headline: Torturing Children at School
text: Federal investigators have opened an inquiry into the tragic case of a high school student in Bastrop County, Tex., who suffered severe brain damage and nearly died last fall after a deputy sheriff shocked him with a Taser, a high voltage electronic weapon.

headline: A Tour of the Heavens Gets an Upgrade
text: The Hudson River Museum, in Yonkers, is already reaping the benefits of its eight-month, $1.5 million planetarium renovation, completed in February. Since the March 8 reopening, school group bookings are up, and so are weekend ticket sales.

headline: Canadian Bankruptcy Court Clears the Way for Furniture Executive to Buy Bike Share Company
text: OTTAWA — A businessman from Quebec has received a court’s approval to purchase the company that provides the bicycles and technology for several major bike-sharing systems, including Citi Bike in New York and Barclays Cycle Hire in London.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 11, 2014
text: April 11, 2014

headline: Lobby for Small Brewers, Concerned Over Rule, Finds Friends in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Susan Collins wanted to talk about beer.

headline: Alternative to Shoots
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — By my count, there were seven entries in this puzzle by Mel Rosen that I had to look up, but that’s O.K. I know I have to put in my time to get through a Saturday grid, and this was tough but doable. And the result was an enjoyable solve, so that makes it worthwhile in my book.

headline: Salvadoran General Accused in Killings Should Be Deported, Miami Judge Says
text: An immigration judge has found that a former defense minister in El Salvador, a close ally of the United States during a civil war there in the 1980s, should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations, including the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of more than 1,000 peasants.

headline: Franken’s Campaign Against Comcast Is No Joke
text: WASHINGTON — For Senator Al Franken, the political became personal at a “Saturday Night Live” cast party, of all places.

headline: Take In the Hudson View, Cosmo in Hand
text: Edgewater Harbor, the sprawling residential development across the Hudson River from the Upper West 90s of Manhattan, feels a bit like a place waiting to happen, with gleaming new high-rises cheek by jowl with construction sites, leasing signs in windows and new retail businesses popping up on the ground level.

headline: Student Crossing a Street is Hit by 2 Cabs and Killed
text: A college senior who was visiting New York City for job interviews was struck by two taxicabs and killed as she crossed a street on the Upper East Side, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Excitement Turns Into Exasperation, Even for Stars
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After signing his scorecard and speaking to the news media, the South African Branden Grace considered a quick stop in the pro shop Friday to buy six Masters folding chairs. He was going to need them for camping out during the weekend at one of the holes on the back nine at Augusta National.

headline: The Ruling on Gen. José Guillermo García
text: The decision by a Miami judge, issued on Feb. 26, said that the former Salvadoran defense minister should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations.

headline: Greenwald and Poitras Land in New York
text: The journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras spoke to reporters after arriving at Kennedy Airport.

headline: Hailing Farmers, Fishermen and Legends Past
text: On the website of Restaurant North, just beneath the headings for “Our Menu” and “Our Wine” is an unexpected category labeled “Loves,” which includes slide show shout-outs to the Mets catcher Gary Carter, the cookbook author James Beard, Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead, and the exterior of the Peter McManus Cafe, the enduring tavern in Manhattan.

headline: Amid Storm Over Slurs, Fire Chief Plans Exit
text: A fire chief in Westchester County whose firefighters disclosed that on several occasions he had used anti-Semitic slurs to deride a town supervisor has decided to retire at the end of the year.

headline: A Yankees Pitcher’s Hand Revives Arguments Over Pine Tar
text: It is used to heal horses’ hooves and to soothe skin ailments on farmyard hens. It has also been used to preserve the wood and rigging on boats in Scandinavia, for hundreds of years, no less. And for almost that long, it seems, it has been used by pitchers to get a grip on the baseball in cold weather.

headline: The World Goes to the Polls
text: If the first week of April was one that favored cynics, this past week was more attuned to optimists. There were the extraordinary images of Afghans defying Taliban threats and bombs to exercise their hard-won right to transfer power through the ballot. Then Indians embarked on what was billed as the biggest election ever held, followed by Indonesians in what must be the world’s most complicated election, with half a million polling places scattered among 17,000 islands.

headline: City Accused of Dragging Its Feet on Settling Suit in ’89 Jogger Rape Case
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has long said that his administration would swiftly settle the lawsuit by five men convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park. “We will settle the Central Park Five case because a huge injustice was done,” he said in December.

headline: With Hands Spotless and Pitches Filthy, Red Sox’ Lester Shines
text: A night after Yankees starter Michael Pineda’s dirty right hand overshadowed his effective outing against the Boston Red Sox, Jon Lester made certain the focus remained on his pitching and only his pitching. Lester held the Yankees to two runs and six hits in a 4-2 victory Friday at Yankee Stadium, continuing his recent success against them.

headline: Desperation and Two Stars Fuel Much-Needed Win for the Knicks
text: TORONTO — The Knicks may now only be delaying the inevitable. They can only keep trying to eke out victories and keep hoping that the Atlanta Hawks undergo some seismic collapse to cede the Eastern Conference’s final playoff spot.

headline: Coming Soon to MoMA, Lots of Knocking Next Door
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s controversial decision to demolish a neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum, is about to become reality.

headline: Terry Collins Shows Mets How to Compete, and to Endure
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Terry Collins used to have a bet every day with Barry Bonds. When he was the bullpen coach with the Pittsburgh Pirates, Collins would throw Bonds batting practice, and they wagered on the number of home runs Bonds could hit.

headline: City’s Doormen Reach New Labor Agreement
text: Averting what would have been their first strike in nearly 25 years, the union representing 30,000 building service employees said on Friday that they had reached a tentative labor deal with the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners.

headline: Hawks End Nets’ Home Streak and Move Closer to Playoff Berth
text: The Nets did the Knicks no favors Friday night. The Nets did themselves no favors, either.

headline: ‘Sweet’ Lou Hudson, Jump Shot Master With the Hawks, Dies at 69
text: Lou Hudson, a six-time N.B.A. All-Star who was one of the most reliable scorers in the league in a 13-year career, most of it with the Atlanta Hawks, died on Friday in Atlanta. He was 69.

headline: A Finish Rarely Seen on the Ice Is Followed by Elation and Disbelief
text: PHILADELPHIA — In a sport unaccustomed to buzzer-beaters, the reverberations from a game-winning, last-second goal late Thursday were still resounding hours later at Wells Fargo Center.

headline: A Roller-Coaster Season for the Devils Hits Another Low Point
text: NEWARK — Devils Coach Pete DeBoer could only laugh.

headline: Mobilizing Against a Common Core Test
text: Students and parents protested the E.L.A. exam at Public School 11 in Chelsea, Manhattan.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Showtime) DJANGO UNCHAINED (2012) Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz), a German bounty hunter, teams up with Django (Jamie Foxx, above right, with Mr. Waltz), a former slave turned gun for hire, to rescue his wife (Kerry Washington) from a plantation owner (Leonardo DiCaprio) in this action-adventure directed by Quentin Tarantino. Samuel L. Jackson plays a house slave who assists his master. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film, which also earned Mr. Tarantino an Oscar for best original screenplay, “crazily entertaining, brazenly irresponsible and also ethically serious in a way that is entirely consistent with its playfulness.” He added: “Mr. Tarantino is a virtuoso of bloodshed, that is for sure, and also more enamored of a particularly toxic racial slur than any decent white man should be. But decency in the conventional sense is not his concern, though in another sense it very much is. When you wipe away the blood and the anarchic humor, what you see in ‘Django Unchained’ is moral disgust with slavery, instinctive sympathy for the underdog and an affirmation (in the relationship between Django and Schultz) of what used to be called brotherhood.”

headline: Russian Conductor’s Carnegie Appearance Draws Protests
text: As long as the Russian conductor Valery Gergiev maintains his friendship with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, it appears, protesters will have reason to dog his steps.

headline: Corrections: April 12, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets Hit Batter in 11th, Sending Angels to Victory
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — By some quirk in the baseball schedule, the Mets had played a night game in Atlanta on Thursday. They had left as soon as they could and had arrived here, bleary-eyed, around 3 a.m. local time. Now, late Friday night, they were locked in an intense game with the Los Angeles Angels, and it was dragging on, into the 9th, the 10th and beyond.

headline: Police Drop Charges Against Baby in Pakistan
text: A 9-month-old Pakistani boy will not be going to prison on attempted murder charges.

headline: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
text: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

headline: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
text: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

headline: The Most Dangerous Word in Tech
text: The most important word in the technology industry is “innovation.” It is also the most dangerous.

headline: Outkast at Coachella
text: “I know it’s kind of weird,” said the rapper and singer Andre 3000 of Outkast, dressed in overalls and a hoodie and standing with his partner Big Boi. “But thank y’all for coming.”

headline: Coachella 2014 — day 1
text: The first day of this year’s Coachella festival featured performances by Ellie Goulding, Broken Bells and OutKast.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Talk With Simon Head, Author of ‘Mindless: Smarter Machines Are Making Dumber Humans’
text: Simon Head thinks the world has become good for computers, but bad for most humans.

headline: A Whole New Meaning for Food to Go
text: Top chefs have been known to open satellite restaurants worldwide. Now a few of the world’s most respected chefs are moving abroad for limited culinary residencies.

headline: Analytics: Housing Authority
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 13 issue of the magazine.

headline: Wall Street, The City, And Austerity
text: Noah Smith, Simon Wren-Lewis, and I have in effect been having an intermittent, long-distance conversation about the role of the finance industry in promoting a view of our economic problems — one that emphasizes the dangers of deficits and monetary expansion — that has had a seriously damaging effect on policy. The question is why so many people in finance gravitate toward that view, and cling to it despite what is at this point overwhelming evidence that it’s wrong.

headline: Thought Secure, Pooled Pensions Teeter and Fall
text: The pensions of millions of Americans are being threatened because of trouble in a part of the retirement world long considered so safe that no one gave it a second thought.

headline: 1939: Goldfish Aren’t Safe in Bowls As College Boys Gulp ‘Em Alive
text: NEW YORK — The silly season has arrived with the advent of a craze far outdoing flagpole-sitting, marathon dancing, chain letter-writing and non-stop beer guzzling for dizziness.

headline: Pay for Performance? It Depends on the Measuring Stick
text: Year after year, as executive pay continues its inexorable climb, it’s amusing to watch corporate directors try to justify the piles of shareholder money they throw at the hired help. Check out any proxy filing for these arguments, which usually center on how closely and carefully the executives’ incentive compensation is tied to the performance of company operations.

headline: How Badly Did the Knicks Lose This Season? Let Us Count the Ways
text: The Knicks needed two games to absorb their first loss of the season, and it was an excruciating finish as the Chicago Bulls’ Derrick Rose sank a baseline runner for the go-ahead basket in the waning moments. It was Oct. 31, back when the Knicks were still flush with optimism, but the result left them feeling disappointed. It fast became a theme, one that culminated Saturday with their elimination from playoff contention when the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Miami Heat.

headline: Armed Men Seize Police Station in Eastern Ukraine City
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian militants attacked police stations and other security facilities in the most populous part of eastern Ukraine on Saturday, in a brush fire of violent unrest that the government in Kiev immediately denounced as Russian “aggression.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have to remember not to drink any beverages when I’m solving one of Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams puzzles. Some of his PandAs are on the corny side, but today’s had a good amount of really clever stuff that almost made me spray my monitor from all the giggling.

headline: Brad Smith of Intuit: Follow the Fastest Beat of Your Heart
text: This interview with  Brad Smith, chief executive of Intuit, the software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Crack in the Laptop’s Screen (and in Customer Service)
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: In Their Hearts and Hopes
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — After the Rangers won the 1994 Stanley Cup, the team’s first championship in 54 years, they fulfilled the words of their coach, Mike Keenan: “Win this, and you’ll walk together forever.”

headline: How a Bicycle Maker Saw the Light, and Found Its Balance
text: Cyclists have more ways than ever to make themselves conspicuous when on the road: fluorescent-orange helmets, reflective trench coats, bike horns that mimic car horns, and lighting systems with red lasers that project downward to create a virtual bike lane. Until recently, however, there wasn’t an effective method of illuminating the entire bike frame.

headline: A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play
text: Chris Tillman pitches for the Baltimore Orioles, which means he can never assume the location of the infielders behind him.

headline: In the Workplace, Leaders Who Aren’t Always Followed
text: Who really makes the changes in an organization? It’s not always the people with the highest executive titles. A growing body of research has pointed to the importance of informal leaders known to researchers as “brokers,” who have the gift of connecting employees in productive new ways.

headline: For the Newest Yankee, Reaching the Majors Was a Family Affair
text: More than 20 years later, his aunts and uncles still talk about the way Yangervis Solarte cried the day he watched his uncle get on that plane.

headline: In Jordan Town, Syria War Inspires Jihadist Dreams
text: ZARQA, Jordan — Late one night, Abu Abdullah left his whole life behind.

text: Stephanie M. Heydt, 43, is the curator of American art at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta.
