text: “Is there anyone who’s not ready for me to sign this contract?”

headline: Better Insurance Against Inequality
text: Paying taxes is rarely pleasant, but as April 15 approaches it’s worth remembering that our tax system is a progressive one and serves a little-noticed but crucial purpose: It mitigates some of the worst consequences of income inequality.

headline: Still No. 1, and Doing What He Wants
text: It is good to be the king. It is even better to be Larry Ellison.

headline: Executive Pay: Invasion of the Supersalaries
text: Corporate America’s well-oiled compensation machine is running like a dream.

headline: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
text: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: The Pay at the Top
text: The list of 100 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business from the Equilar 100 C.E.O. Pay Study for 2013.

headline: A Vote Against Congress in India?
text: Times correspondents report on the incumbent Congress party and the key players in the fight to lead the world’s largest democracy.

headline: In 3-Hour Show on Palmer, Golf Channel Joins His Army
text: The opening words of “Arnie,” a three-part testimonial to Arnold Palmer on Golf Channel, set the direction of this extravaganza.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 61
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Coalition-Building Season in India
text: COIMBATORE, India — As a potential political partner, the chief minister of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu has some drawbacks.

headline: 25 Years After Stadium Disaster, Liverpool Still Mourns
text: LIVERPOOL, England — In the middle of the bustling city center last week, not far from the merriment of the famed Albert Dock, a man set up a makeshift kiosk to peddle Liverpool F.C. scarves. Over the course of a lunch hour it seemed he always had a customer or two, and to understand the emotions that drive most fans here, one needed to look only at the three scarves displayed prominently across the top of the man’s tent.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 12
text: “Heartbleed is further evidence that we don’t have our house in order when it comes to Internet security.”

headline: Anaheim Ducks and Their Coach Grow Together
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — His label as hockey’s Everyman has worn a bit thin, but Anaheim Ducks Coach Bruce Boudreau continues to produce results that are anything but ordinary.

headline: In California, Saving a Language That Predates Spanish and English
text: EUREKA, Calif. — Sitting in a circle in a classroom at Eureka High School here, Tenayah Norris and a half-dozen other students were learning how to express direction in Yurok, a Native American language that nearly became extinct a few years ago. Growing up on the Yurok reservation about 90 minutes north of here, she sometimes heard her grandfather speak it to his contemporaries, and she studied it, on and off, in the community.

headline: Buyers Find Tax Break on Art: Let It Hang Awhile in Oregon
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, tucked into a quiet corner of a college campus here in the hills of the Pacific Northwest, is hardly the epicenter of the art world. Yet major collectors, fresh from buying a Warhol or a Basquiat or another masterpiece in New York, routinely choose this small, elegant redbrick building at the University of Oregon to first exhibit their latest trophy.

headline: Durant Adds Steady to Spectacular
text: To say that Kevin Durant has had a breakout season for Oklahoma City would seem ridiculous, given that he led the league in scoring in three of the last four seasons and is a perennial All-Star. But offered less help than he had in the past, he proved up to the task of being a one-man team. His consistently high production has him entering a new stratosphere as a player.

headline: Doing China’s Bidding in Nepal
text: A Human Rights Watch report released this month shows how far Nepal has gone in capitulating to Chinese pressure in cracking down on Tibetan residents and refugees. It details a long list of shameful actions against Tibetans in Nepal, including restrictions on their activities and movements, surveillance and intimidation, arbitrary detention and forcible return to China.

headline: Bankruptcy Beyond the Potholes
text: Congress is lurching toward its standard emergency, edge-of-the-cliff deal for the federal Highway Trust Fund, which could run short of money as early as August. The fund pays for the nation’s vitally needed road and transit projects and has operated on an 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal gasoline tax that hasn’t been raised since 1993. Now it is running on fumes, raising about $39 billion a year but facing shortfalls of close to $20 billion annually as more efficient cars pay less into the fund while infrastructure repair costs rise.

headline: My Mother’s Keepers
text: WEST SHOKAN, N.Y. — IF my mother had been aware enough to know what we were spending on her care, she would have been aghast. She’d always been frugal. I once noticed the remains of the Easter ham in the refrigerator two months later. “Don’t you think it’s time to throw that out?” I asked. “Ham doesn’t go bad,” she explained. She could make a piece of tinfoil last clear into the next decade. She once made an old corduroy jumper of mine into a seat cover for the rocking chair — perfectly good material, not to be wasted.

headline: Reclaiming the Words That Smear
text: AMES, Iowa — “UNBECOMING.” “Miss Congeniality.” Not sufficiently “ladylike.” In politics, these words and phrases have long been used to belittle female candidates. But now, female politicians are increasingly trying to rethink — and reclaim — how language shapes how they are perceived.

headline: Mark My Words. Maybe.
text: MY tattoo kept getting delayed by other people’s weddings: a bachelorette party in Vegas, cliff-top vows in Zion, a ceremony in Westchester. I wasn’t just attending the ceremony in Westchester, I was officiating at the ceremony in Westchester. I couldn’t picture giving my blessing in front of 200 people while my left arm glistened under Saran Wrap. I felt the slightest twinge of resentment. My life seemed perpetually tucked into the pockets of time created between the milestones of other lives.

headline: Diversity and Dishonesty
text: EARLIER this year, a column by a Harvard undergraduate named Sandra Y. L. Korn briefly achieved escape velocity from the Ivy League bubble, thanks to its daring view of how universities should approach academic freedom.

headline: Women’s Unequal Lot
text: I DROPPED in on my sister last week. As usual, I was amazed.

headline: Max Levchin
text: Max Levchin is a Ukrainian-born computer scientist and serial entrepreneur who co-founded PayPal and Yelp. He is currently president of HVF (Hard Valuable Fun), which is a hybrid think tank/venture capital firm that focuses exclusively on data-driven projects.

headline: Jazz and Real Estate
text: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio — I WISH my father, a landlord, were alive to read the news about the rental boom. He always liked numbers, particularly when they went up.

headline: The Killers Underfoot
text: SAN FRANCISCO — IN just over a month, life-giving rains will soak India during the annual monsoons. As welcome as these rains are, they also bring with them injury and death from snakebite. As they do each year, venomous snakes seeking dry ground will slide into people’s homes, gardens and fields; they will curl up in woodpiles, latrines and play areas. Hundreds of thousands of snakebites will cause an estimated 40,000 deaths over the course of the monsoon season.

headline: A Wit for All Seasons
text: WASHINGTON — I DON’T remember much about being on Stephen Colbert’s show.

headline: High-Priced Treatments
text: Readers discuss how to weigh the costs and benefits of medical innovations.

headline: Providing the Balm of Truth
text: “What if we gave her some aloe vera gel?”

headline: Parental Involvement Is Overrated
text: Most people, asked whether parental involvement benefits children academically, would say, “of course it does.” But evidence from our research suggests otherwise. In fact, most forms of parental involvement, like observing a child’s class, contacting a school about a child’s behavior, helping to decide a child’s high school courses, or helping a child with homework, do not improve student achievement. In some cases, they actually hinder it.

headline: Recovery for Whom?
text: The Federal Reserve, increasingly optimistic about the economy, is dialing back its stimulus efforts. The International Monetary Fund has raised its forecast for growth in the United States. Congress has long since reduced aid to the economy, with many lawmakers, mostly Republicans, adamant that the economy is better off with less government involvement.

headline: Accusation in Montana of Treating Rape Lightly Stirs Unlikely Public Fight
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — For nearly three years, this college town in the hills of western Montana has lived under the shadow of stories of rapes gone unpunished and complaints that officials minimized or ignored reports of sexual assaults — especially if the suspects played for the University of Montana Grizzlies, the wildly popular football team.

headline: The Coat Speaks for Itself, Clearly
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters green coat that came into vogue in the late 1930s has become what amounts to the world’s most recognizable reversible jacket. Augusta National Golf Club members wear theirs on the grounds to make themselves visible to tournament patrons seeking guidance on the course. And the reigning Masters champion wears it to make himself visible outside the club’s gates to anyone in search of a connection.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 13
text: Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary who faced criticism for the flawed rollout of the new health care law, resigned this week. Earlier this month, President Obama announced that more than seven million Americans enrolled in the new health care exchanges. Sylvia Mathews Burwell, currently the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, is Mr. Obama’s choice to take over the job.

headline: Growing Up at Sea
text: ONE of my earliest memories is of looking down from the bow of my family’s sailboat and seeing dolphins gliding alongside us through the bright water. That spot at the tip of the bow, called the bow pulpit, was my favorite place when I was a child. It can be difficult to find somewhere to be alone when living with your parents and younger brother on 81 feet of wood and aluminum, but the bow pulpit was always there when I wanted time to myself. My brother preferred to climb the masts.

headline: A Loyal Soldier Doesn’t Deserve This
text: THE only reason he is alive, says Mike Yurchison, is his girlfriend, Leigh Anna Landsberger. She sits with him through endless waits at Veterans Affairs, whispering that he’s smarter than she is even if his brain is damaged. She helps him through his seizures, and she nags him to overcome drug addiction.

headline: Go Ahead, Vladimir, Make My Day
text: SO the latest news is that President Vladimir Putin of Russia has threatened to turn off gas supplies to Ukraine if Kiev doesn’t pay its overdue bill, and, by the way, Ukraine’s pipelines are the transit route for 15 percent of gas consumption for Europe. If I’m actually rooting for Putin to go ahead and shut off the gas, does that make me a bad guy?

headline: Saving Young People From Themselves
text: RETIREMENT is a financial obligation that today’s younger generations are not handling well. That may be through no fault of their own — they suffer from lower incomes, after being adjusted for inflation, and student debt that makes it a struggle to save. But regardless of the reason, the failure to save for retirement is setting up Americans in their 20s and early 30s for financially stressed golden years.

headline: Standing by our Veterans
text: My Sunday column looks again at the mental health crisis facing veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. I was against the Iraq war, but I still think we owe far better after-care to those troops who went and fought there. I tell the story this time through Mike Yurchison, who I mentioned tangentially in a column two years ago after his younger brother (also an Iraq veteran) committed suicide. Now it’s Mike who is in trouble.

headline: Shanahan Made the N.H.L. a Safer Place
text: Brendan Shanahan’s tenure as the N.H.L.’s chief disciplinarian was brief but epic, with the league turning an important corner. He “helped to change the culture of the game,” as Commissioner Gary Bettman said.

headline: Finance Officials Push for Bold Action to Sustain Economic Growth
text: WASHINGTON — At the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual spring meetings, concerns about crisis have given way to concerns about complacency.

headline: At 40, Colon Continues to Defy Time and Weight
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At some point as Bartolo Colon dominated the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night, he walked through the dugout, looked down at his bulging belly, grabbed it firmly with his hands and shook it three times. Then, clearly pleased with himself, Colon smiled. He seemed proud of his size, or at least proud that he was talented enough to shut out the Braves for seven innings in spite of it.

headline: Rangers, Primed for Flyers in Playoffs, Rest Top Players
text: MONTREAL — Now the real hockey season begins, the Rangers were saying after Saturday night’s regular-season finale, a hard-fought, entertaining but ultimately meaningless 1-0 overtime loss to the Montreal Canadiens.

headline: Arsenal and Wenger Avoid Nightmare and Advance to F.A. Cup Final
text: LONDON — Arsène Wenger paced. He fidgeted. He squatted then rose then squatted. When he finally stood still, he pulled at the belt loops of his natty suit. For more than two hours Saturday at Wembley Stadium, Wenger looked altogether uncomfortable.

headline: New Hampshire Republicans Get a Preview of 2016
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Here in a state where presidential politics are never far from anyone’s mind, three Republicans who are considering a run for the White House — Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Rand Paul of Kentucky, and Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor — pitched their views on Saturday for how conservatives can retake power in Washington.

headline: Police Kill Gunman, 86, Who Fatally Shot His Daughter
text: An 86-year-old man shot and killed his daughter on Saturday at the home they shared in Queens, and was then shot and killed by a police officer, officials said.

headline: New Faces in Middle of Order Power Yanks to a Win
text: The sun shone brightly, and a faint wind began to blow from behind home plate. It was the first such wind of the season, the so-called jet stream at the new Yankee Stadium that favors left-handed hitters. To this point, it had not meant much to Brian McCann, the new Yankees catcher. But he got a good idea of what it could mean to him this season.

headline: Another Prosecutor Is Said to Investigate Port Authority
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has subpoenaed documents from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey concerning a range of the troubled agency’s major construction projects, including several that have come under scrutiny as a result of the politically charged George Washington Bridge lane closings, a person with knowledge of the matter said Saturday.

headline: A World Is Reshaped, and Printers Adapt or Die
text: The survivors of the printing industry are increasingly high tech and automated. Many are holding on by moving beyond media publishing and into packaging and labeling.

headline: Leaner and More Efficient, British Printers Push Forward in Digital Age
text: PETERBOROUGH, England — At a media conference a few years ago, the editor of The Guardian newspaper, contemplating the future of print, recalled his paper’s installation of its newest presses in 2005.

headline: Brazil Tracks From Boom to Rust
text: Brazil’s economic boom bore big construction projects to empower its impoverished interior. But as the economy cools, many are unfinished, leaving a legacy of division and dislocation.

headline: Pro-Russian Protesters Build Barricades
text: After seizing a police station in Slovyansk, Ukraine, pro-Russian protesters raised the banner of the People’s Republic of Donetsk and constructed barricades around the station.

headline: Grand Visions Fizzle in Brazil
text: Projects conceived in boom times stand abandoned, visible symbols of waste and the country’s crippling bureaucracy.

headline: From Boom to Rust, Lavish Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
text: PAULISTANA, Brazil — Brazil plowed billions of dollars into building a railroad across arid backlands, only for the long-delayed project to fall prey to metal scavengers. Curvaceous new public buildings designed by the famed architect Oscar Niemeyer were abandoned right after being constructed. There was even an ill-fated U.F.O. museum built with federal funds. Its skeletal remains now sit like a lost ship among the weeds.

headline: It’s Taxing
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — As if we needed a reminder, today’s puzzle by Dan Schoenholz provides us with a timely countdown to the April 15 deadline for filing our taxes. Fortunately it’s a funny reminder, which may help make the medicine go down a bit easier for some of us.

headline: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — Stepping into a heated debate within the nation’s intelligence agencies, President Obama has decided that when the National Security Agency discovers major flaws in Internet security, it should — in most circumstances — reveal them to assure that they will be fixed, rather than keep mum so that the flaws can be used in espionage or cyberattacks, senior administration officials said Saturday.

headline: How to Save $68,469 in Taxes
text: In some cases, collectors can avoid paying taxes on art they buy if they display it out of state before bringing it home. Here is how one collector navigated the system.

headline: Tsunami Warning After Earthquake Strikes Near Solomon Islands
text: A strong earthquake struck offshore near the Solomon Islands in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday morning, causing officials to issue a tsunami warning for the area. There were no immediate reports of damage.

headline: Conservatives Clash With G.O.P. Leaders on Hood County Water Needs
text: Since the beginning of the Tea Party movement in Texas in 2009, state Republicans have harnessed its appeal to voters who are demanding less government spending and more local control. But when it comes to water policy, a hotly debated issue given the state’s severe drought and growing needs, conservatives worry that establishment Republicans have not stuck to those principles.

headline: Rivka Haut, Dies at 71; Championed Rights of Orthodox Jewish Women
text: Rivka Haut, a prominent champion of Orthodox Jewish women fighting for divorce in rabbinical courts and seeking to pray together as a group, died on March 30 in the Bronx. She was 71.

headline: Rail Transport of Crude Oil Increases as Pipeline Falls Short
text: In December, a new terminal in the Port of Beaumont welcomed its first customer: a train carrying 43,000 barrels of crude oil from Colorado. Workers at the terminal, the Jefferson Transload Railport, transferred the crude to a barge, which traveled down the Neches River to a nearby refinery.

headline: Augusta’s Designated Fill-In Bests Rory McIlroy
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Miguel Ángel Jiménez, whose six-under-par 66 Saturday was the low round of the week, is one of seven players 50 or older who teed off Saturday at the Masters. There were six touring professionals and Jeff Knox, the tournament representative and course record-holder, who played as the marker for the two-time major champion Rory McIlroy, the 51st competitor to make the cut.

headline: North Carolina Shows Strains Within G.O.P.
text: DURHAM, N.C. — There is a Tea Party candidate who talks about the Constitution and has the backing of Senator Rand Paul. There is a Baptist pastor, endorsed by Mike Huckabee, who wears a “Jesus First” lapel pin and has led the fight against same-sex marriage. And there is a Republican state lawmaker — supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and $1 million from Karl Rove’s American Crossroads group — standing up for the party establishment.

headline: Lingering Power of Hostage Crisis Short-Circuits Iranian Nominee
text: PARIS — When Iranian militants seized the United States Embassy and took dozens of Americans hostage on an overcast Sunday morning in November 1979, I assumed it was just a brief anti-American sit-in. My main concern, I told my editors at Newsweek, was not how dangerous Tehran would be. It was whether it would still be a story by the time I arrived there from Paris the next day.

headline: Carol Grimaldi, Co-Founder of Lauded Brooklyn Pizzeria, Dies at 76
text: Carol Grimaldi, the co-owner with her husband, Pasquale, of the original Grimaldi’s Pizzeria in Brooklyn, which for many years was hailed as one of the best pizza restaurants in a city of pizza connoisseurs, died on Thursday in Queens. She was 76.

headline: Revived Soriano Remains Consistently Streaky Force for Yankees
text: Alfonso Soriano was so successful in anticipating the start of his hot streak this season that he wondered whether he should apply those predictive skills to the lottery.

headline: Schools Chancellor Details Initiatives for Schools
text: Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña on Saturday called for a “back-to-basics approach” to educating New York City’s 1.1 million public school students, and said she would work to reduce class sizes, curb the use of suspensions and pair more local universities and cultural institutions with public schools.

headline: A Nightclub Reflecting ’80s Dallas Is Revisited
text: Among Dallas residents of a certain age, the Starck Club is often recalled with a mix of nostalgia and wonder: How did such a thing ever exist?

headline: Bubba Watson Falters, and a 20-Year-Old Ties for the Lead
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Experience is worth a couple of strokes at Augusta National Golf Club. Everybody says so, and sure enough, the top-10 leader board after 54 holes of the Masters includes two players past their 50th birthdays, Miguel Ángel Jiménez and Fred Couples, as well as the 2012 champion, Bubba Watson.

headline: Aid to Schools Is Goal of Push to Raise Taxes
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Thailand’s Political Tensions Are Rekindling Ethnic and Regional Divisions
text: LAMPHUN, Thailand — Each time Muean Chimoon leaves his wooden house in northern Thailand, he pays homage to a portrait of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, a father figure and long a symbol of national unity.

headline: Search for Tiger Woods’s Successor Skips a Generation
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods is missing from this year’s Masters, and so are all the people we once expected to replace him.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 12, 2014
text: April 12, 2014

headline: Blue Grass Stakes Winner Isn’t Likely to Run in Kentucky Derby
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Officials at Keeneland Race Course have been criticized for their decision to return to a dirt surface after their eight-year use of Polytrack led to a significant reduction in deaths. But the result of the Blue Grass Stakes on Saturday pointed to at least one reason for the change, which will occur at the end of the spring meet.

headline: Damascus and Rebels Trade Blame in Gas Attack
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian state television and antigovernment activists reported Saturday that poison gas had been used in a rebel-held village in the central province of Hama, with each side blaming its enemies for an attack they both said sickened more than 100 people.

headline: Knicks’ Playoff Hopes End as Hawks Cruise Past Heat
text: The end for the Knicks came in unlikely fashion on Saturday night, with the Atlanta Hawks beating the Miami Heat, of all teams, to nail down the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Xenophobic Chill Descends on Moscow
text: MOSCOW — The huge banner was unfurled on Friday morning outside one of Moscow’s biggest bookstores, Dom Knigi, a grand emporium of the written word on Novii Arbat Street across from a Citibank, a Baskin-Robbins and a Dunkin’ Donuts, and down the block from a big movie theater where the main feature at the moment is “Captain America: The Winter Soldier.”

headline: Vows: The Perfect Fire
text: Susan Levin lost her life’s work of art and all her possessions when her house burned down in a wildfire. She ordered new things online — and fell in love with the FedEx delivery woman.

headline: Fred Ho: The Music Lives On
text: The baritone saxophonist Fred Ho died on April 12th after a years-long battle with cancer. Mr. Ho’s music is known for straddling the line between classical and jazz.

headline: Fred Ho, Composer and Musician in ‘Popular Avant-Gard,’ Dies at 56
text: Fred Ho, a composer, saxophonist, writer and radical activist who composed politically charged operas, suites, oratorios and ballets that mixed jazz with popular and traditional elements of what he called Afro-Asian culture, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 56.

headline: Flurry of Goals Gives Union First Title
text: PHILADELPHIA — Union College toppled the five-time champion Minnesota, 7-4, on Saturday at Wells Fargo Center to win its first N.C.A.A. men’s hockey title.

headline: My TEDx Talk: We Are Perfect, With a Hefty Asterisk
text: I just gave a talk at TEDx Portland — a daylong event focused on various interpretations of the word “perfect.”

headline: The Triumph of Personal Style
text: The pressure to stick to one particular style in interior decorating can yield a space that looks good in photographs but isn’t necessarily a particularly pleasant place to call home. Using his own Hamptons getaway as an example, the author makes the case for the considerations of real life.

headline: Fawn Jiang, Brendan McGinty
text: Fawn Vera Jiang and Brendan John McGinty were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Sarah J. Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Rina Parmeshwar, Prabhu Balasubramanian
text: Dr. Rina Parmeshwar and Prabhu Shankar Balasubramanian are to be married Sunday morning at the Santa Clara Marriott in Santa Clara, Calif. Pandit Agoram Sivaramakrishnan will lead the ceremony with Krishnan Ganapathy Sastrigal participating; they are both Hindu priests.

headline: John Gordon, Justin Zaremby
text: John Stuart Gordon and Justin Scott Zaremby were married Saturday at the Elizabethan Club, a private literary club in New Haven. Judge José A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom Dr. Zaremby served as a law clerk in 2010 and 2011, officiated.

headline: Sarah Stein, Alex Koppelman
text: Sarah Jenny Stein and Alex Ritter Koppelman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Lee Friedlander at Skylight One Hanson in Brooklyn.

headline: Mary Allison, Louis Ferrara
text: Mary Patricia Allison and Louis Michael Ferrara were married Saturday at the home of Alfredo and Jennifer Dreyfus, a sister of the bride, in Gilbert, Ariz. John T. Johnson, a bishop of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony.

headline: Erica Fink, Arel Lidow
text: Erica Blair Fink, the daughter of Nancy F. Fink and Jonathan J. Fink of New York, was married Saturday evening to Arel Ives Lidow, a son of Diana D. Lidow and Derek B. Lidow of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated at the Essex House in New York.

headline: Kim Carlson, Jeanne Graham
text: Kim Elizabeth Carlson and Jeanne Jo Graham were married Saturday evening at the 112 Eatery Restaurant in Minneapolis. Kathryn L. Quaintance, a Hennepin County District Court judge in Minneapolis, officiated.

headline: Candice Chiu, Alex Wong
text: Candice Chiu and Alex Nelson Wong were married Saturday evening at the DAR Memorial Continental Hall in Washington. The officiant was Sandra Day O’Connor, the retired United States Supreme Court justice, for whom the bride was a clerk from July 2011 to July 2012. The couple met at Harvard, from which the bride graduated and each received a law degree.

headline: Erin Muckey, Alexander Cavin
text: Erin Joy Muckey and Alexander William Cavin were married Saturday at the Beach Club at Sea Ranch Lakes in Sea Ranch Lakes, Fla. Joseph E. Falit, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Mock Trials Lead to Real Romance
text: Jessica Lynne Miller and Joshua Herbert Frost were married Saturday evening at the Bourne Mansion, an event space in Oakdale, N.Y. Justice Milton A. Tingling Jr., of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated.

headline: Sandra Sanchez, Jacob Angel
text: Sandra Sanchez, a daughter of Sandra L. Sanchez and Alejandro Sanchez of Chula Vista, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Jacob Daniel Angel, a son of Gail A. Angel and the Rev. Stephan E. Angel of Chicago. The groom’s father, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Kimberly Resnick, Adam Thaler
text: Dr. Kimberly Sue Resnick, the daughter of Lanie Resnick and Gerald A. Resnick of New York, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Adam Michael Thaler, the son of Sharon Kitain Thaler and Dr. Bruce J. Thaler of Philadelphia. Rabbi Howard K. Cove officiated at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J.

headline: Christie Wilson, John Bonasera
text: Christie Michelle Wilson and John James Bonasera were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Hyon, Aaron Rubin
text: Elizabeth Susan Hyon and Aaron Grant R Rubin were married Saturday evening at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse in New York. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated.

headline: Olivier Cassegrain, Troy Miller
text: Olivier Philippe Cassegrain and Robert Troy Miller were married Saturday in Paris at the city hall for the Seventh Arrondissement. The arrondissement’s mayor, Rachida Dati, officiated.

headline: The Complete Package
text: Margie Ellen Ashley and Susan Barbara Levin are to be married Sunday at the Marin Art and Garden Center in Ross, Calif. Marsha R. Angus, a Universal Life minister, will officiate.

headline: Kathleen Milazzo, Travis Johnson
text: Kathleen Marie Milazzo and Jay Travis Johnson were married Saturday evening at the Holy Family Catholic Church in Chicago. The Rev. Jeremiah M. Boland, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Webster University Clings to Its Title at Final Four
text: Chess had its own version of the Final Four last week, with Webster University of St. Louis taking the title, known as the President’s Cup, for the second year in a row.

headline: The Toddler Who Survived, and the Cop Who Became Her Mom
text: The bodies were discovered throughout the first-floor railroad flat in Brooklyn, a bizarre still-life of death. Many of the victims remained seated in chairs or couches; one woman’s hands still held a spoon and a small can of pudding.

headline: Corrections: April 13, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets Absorb a Staggering Blow but Deliver the Final One
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Jose Valverde was crouched over, his hands on his knees, as he watched Raul Ibanez’s three-run homer sail into the night. The shot, which tied the score at 6-6 in the bottom of the ninth, spoiled a solid start by Jon Niese and forced the weary Mets to play on. They had flown here from Atlanta two nights before, had battled the Los Angeles Angels for 11 innings and lost the previous night, and now this.

headline: Climate Efforts Falling Short, U.N. Panel Says
text: BERLIN — Delivering the latest stark news about climate change on Sunday, a United Nations panel warned that governments are not doing enough to avert profound risks in coming decades. But the experts found a silver lining: Not only is there still time to head off the worst, but the political will to do so seems to be rising around the world.

headline: In Our Pages: April 14
text: 1914: England Crushes France in Annual Rugby Match

headline: Ukraine Forces Storm a Town, Defying Russia
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants in the country’s east, defying warnings from Russia. Commandos engaged in gunfights with men who had set up roadblocks and stormed a Ukrainian police station in Slovyansk, and at least one officer was killed, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: Partial Afghan Results Portend a Runoff as Fraud Is Cited
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the first official report of partial results from the Afghan presidential election, the candidates Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani appeared to be leading a race in which a runoff election was increasingly certain, according to data released by the Independent Election Commission on Sunday.

headline: I Have No Idea How Many Calories Are in My Grandmother’s Gefilte Fish
text: Passover is coming, and so is my Nanna. At 98, an age when most of her contemporaries (I’d say “many” of her contemporaries, except the truth is, Nanna has outlived most of her generation) are in bed or assisted living, my Nanna, Faye Frumin, will board a plane from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Philadelphia, where she will supervise the ritual making of the gefilte fish, one of the centerpieces of the Seder feast.

headline: Nations’ Handling of New Climate Report Presages Divisions in Treaty Effort
text: Justin Gillis’s news story from Berlin on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change — the one on the world’s options for limiting global warming — tells you all you need to know about the familiar contents. The chart of trending news in the United States above tells you all you need to know about how much people are tuning in. (Click to learn more about how Newsmap works.)

headline: Bend It, Charge It, Dunk It: Graphene, the Material of Tomorrow
text: I just want to say one word to you. Just one word.

headline: Coachella 2014: Day 2
text: The second day of this year’s music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2014 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Conan O’Brien, above, hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater at L.A. Live, which bestows Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in “best” categories like kiss, villain, fight and shirtless performance. Andrew Garfield, Emma Stone and Jamie Foxx will unveil a sneak peek of “The Amazing Spider-Man 2”; Ellen Page will introduce a clip from “X-Men Days of Future Past.” Presenters include Lupita Nyong’o, Jessica Alba, Chris Pratt, Seth Rogen, Seth MacFarlane, Mila Kunis, Shailene Woodley, Cameron Diaz, Leslie Mann, Kate Upton and Nicki Minaj. Mark Wahlberg will be honored with the annual MTV Generation Award. Eminem, Rihanna, Ellie Goulding, Zedd and Twenty One Pilots are scheduled to perform.

headline: Monday Rush Will Test Pulaski Skyway Shutdown
text: The planned two-year shutdown of the northbound lanes on the Pulaski Skyway faces its first major test on Monday morning as thousands of drivers in New Jersey turn to alternative routes or public transportation for travel between Newark and Jersey City.

headline: An Artist Takes His Pay in Coffee and Community
text: David Ellis is painting what could be his biggest commission ever — assuming he lives long enough, since he’s being paid in coffee and tobacco.

headline: A Letdown in London for a British Olympic Champion
text: LONDON — If it had gone in the storybook fashion that much of Britain willed, Mo Farah, a hero for winning the 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the 2012 London Olympics and the 2013 world championships, would have won on his marathon debut here Sunday.

headline: Slide Show: Scenes From Coachella
text: Photographs from the second day of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Cartoon Birds Can’t Stop Captain America
text: “Rio 2” got its wings a bit clipped at the weekend box office by a still-speeding superhero, while Kevin Costner was humiliated by a micro-budgeted horror flick. “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” (Walt Disney Studios) was the No. 1 movie in North America for the second weekend in a row, taking in an estimated $41.4 million, for a two-week domestic total of $159 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles ticketing data. “Rio 2” (20th Century Fox), an animated avian musical, was close behind with a solid $39 million, on par with the opening-weekend total for its series predecessor. But analysts and Fox, which backed “Rio 2” with a sizzling social media marketing campaign, had been predicting slightly higher totals. “Excellent weather across the middle of the country and the Northeast suppressed grosses in general yesterday and especially for matinees,” Chris Aronson, Fox’s president of domestic distribution, wrote in an email on Sunday morning. “Rio 2” has unusually light animated competition in the weeks ahead, Mr. Aronson noted.

headline: Liverpool Closes In on Championship That It Last Won 24 Years Ago
text: LIVERPOOL, England — They sang “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and “We Shall Not Be Moved” and, over and over, “Liiiiiverpool.” The fans at Anfield seemed never to go quiet once the game began on Sunday, and soon, perhaps, they will sing about being champions.

headline: Pistorius Versus the Pit Bull: Fierce Prosecutor Shares Stage
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — It was a corruption trial that had transfixed South Africa, and the prosecutor was in no mood for mercy. The defendant was the nation’s top police official, a figure of such international stature that he had once led Interpol. But when he took the stand, his testimony — his wife, he said, had accidentally shredded evidence — was rejected outright by his inquisitor.

headline: Fire Races Through Hills of Chilean Port City
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A voracious fire that spread through the hills of the port city of Valparaíso left at least 12 people dead and more than 500 families homeless on Sunday, a day after it forced the evacuation of thousands of others.

headline: Diving Into the Strange, Retrieving Its Beauty
text: The pianist Jeremy Denk recently picked up the prestigious Avery Fisher Prize to go along with the MacArthur Foundation fellowship that he received last year. This is what you call being on a roll. These honors were in recognition not just of his excellence as a pianist but also of his adventurousness as an artist. Both qualities were on display on Saturday night, when Mr. Denk played a recital at Washington Irving High School, part of the very affordable Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series.

headline: Somber Army in Blue Gathers in Queens to Mourn a Fallen Officer
text: They slipped hands into white gloves and shed blue caps, smoothed gold-buttoned uniforms and fell into a hush, one by one, as they joined the long line of police officers filing into the funeral home. Passing the flowers and the children dressed in black, they paused at the open coffin of their fellow officer, whose shield number — 5711 — glittered in gold from a badge-shaped wreath of white flowers.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Unemployment, Structural or Cyclical?
text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
text: Update: Constitution, the undefeated winner of the Florida Derby, will miss the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races because of a shin fracture, said Elliott Walden, president and chief executive of WinStar Farm. Also, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin withdrew Cairo Prince from consideration because of an injury to his left front ankle.

headline: Ellsbury Batting Third for Yankees Without Fitting Profile
text: Paul O’Neill. Don Mattingly. Mickey Mantle.

headline: Deadly Flames in Chile
text: A fire that swept through the hills of Valparaíso in Chile left at least 11 dead and charred homes and cars in its wake. President Michelle Bachelet called in troops to maintain order.

headline: Surge in Narcotic Prescriptions for Pregnant Women
text: Doctors are prescribing opioid painkillers to pregnant women in astonishing numbers, new research shows, even though risks to the developing fetus are largely unknown.

headline: Visiting Another Country, No Longer Heard From
text: A quarter-century has passed since the Berlin Wall came down and the German Democratic Republic disappeared. That’s more than half the life span of the East German state, a smoke-and-mirrors contraption conjured from the rubble of World War II that has become, for those who lived there, an increasingly distant and improbable memory.

headline: What a Foul Mouth You Have, Grandma
text: The nervous young man has almost escaped from the funeral reception when the genteel widow thanks him for coming. It’s only decent to offer a kind word about her husband.

headline: A Showcase Highlights Newcomers’ Evolution
text: For artists known as “emerging,” what determines when they’ve emerged? Experience? Recognition? Number of grant applications completed?

headline: Man Kills 3 at Jewish Centers in Kansas City Suburb
text: A man opened fire outside a Jewish Community Center and a nearby retirement community in a suburb of Kansas City, Mo., on Sunday afternoon, killing three people before he was taken into custody.

headline: Investigative Reporter Leaves NBC News
text: Michael Isikoff, an investigative reporter who has broken numerous national news stories, has left NBC News. His last day was Friday.

headline: Fouéttes and Pirouettes to the Southern Banjo and Fiddle
text: “Tradition is a guide, not a jailer.” That quotation from W. Somerset Maugham is the motto of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, an African-American string band.

headline: A Feast With Some Unusual Pairings
text: In the parlance of Youth America Grand Prix, a ballet convention and competition now in its 15th year, one purpose of its gala shows is for its young participants, the “stars of tomorrow,” to be inspired by “the stars of today,” the ballet luminaries who perform. The young dancers watching the closing night celebration at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday, an affair more than three hours long, could be inspired without being dispirited by flawlessness.

headline: Mussing Up a White-Linen-Tablecloth Vibe With Jazz Provocation
text: The standout tune in the early set at Minton’s in Harlem on Wednesday night was a new one, “Brainlifter,” composed by the drummer Jeff (Tain) Watts and briskly demolished by his four-piece band. Built over a gear-shifting groove, it was a maze full of trapdoors through which Mr. Watts and his crew barreled with aplomb. Only during a forcefully swinging tenor-saxophone solo by Troy Roberts did the action on the bandstand begin to feel like a developing story rather than an unassailably sturdy truth.

headline: On Shaky Ground
text: The 1989 earthquake that shook San Francisco sent out a wake-up call that continues to echo across the country.

headline: Leading the Honor at the Imp Pairs in Dallas
text: DALLAS — Scott Levine and Aaron Silverstein of New York City entered the last session of the Lebhar Imp Pairs on March 22 in the lead at the Spring North American Championships here. In that session, though, their opponents held most of the cards and made few mistakes. Levine and Silverstein slipped to sixth.

headline: Awards for Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear
text: Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear were among those honored at the 25th annual Glaad Media Awards presented on Saturday in Los Angeles by the group formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Ms. Lopez was given the Vanguard Award in recognition of her efforts to increase the visibility and understanding of gays, lesbians, bisexuals and the transgendered. She is also an executive producer on the ABC Family series “The Fosters,” which focuses on a lesbian couple and their children and was named outstanding drama series. Mr. Lear, who produced television series like “All in the Family” and “The Jeffersons” was the recipient of the Pioneer Award. The actress and transgender activist Laverne Cox received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award for her work in the Netflix series “Orange Is the New Black.” Other honorees included the Canadian pop duo Tegan and Sara for their album “Heartthrob”; the comic book series Young Avengers, by Kieron Gillen, Jamie McKelvie and Mike Norton from Marvel Comics; and Fuse’s reality series “Big Freedia: Queen of Bounce.” More awards are to be presented on May 3 at a ceremony in New York City.

headline: Choreographer Named to Montclair State Project
text: The choreographer Heidi Latsky has been selected as the first participant in a new short film series focusing on dance and choreography. The project, Dance for Film on Location at Montclair State University, in New Jersey, will be underwritten by a $450,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and is to include three films by three different choreographers. The other two participants will be named later. Each work will be shown along with a live repertory that will become part of Peak Performances at Montclair State. In a statement, Jedediah Wheeler, the executive director of Peak Performances, said that the project is designed so that “the camera will not be used as a tool to document a performance, but rather as a collaborator to create a dance especially for film.”

headline: Another Vote for Colbert
text: Conan O’Brien has joined the choir of late night television hosts who have praised CBS’s decision to name Stephen Colbert as the successor to David Letterman on “Late Show.” Mr. O’Brien told The Associated Press on Friday while backstage at a rehearsal for the MTV Movie Awards that Mr. Colbert is “fantastic,” and that he was looking forward to his work on “Late Show.” “I’m glad that it’s the right person getting it,” he said. Jimmy Fallon, the host of “The Tonight Show” on NBC, and Jimmy Kimmel, the host of his own show on ABC, had already voiced their approval of Mr. Colbert’s appointment. Mr. O’Brien, who hosted “The Tonight Show” for seven months before he was replaced by Jay Leno in 2010, denied any speculation that he had been a candidate for the “Late Show” appointment. “I wasn’t up for it,” Mr. O’Brien said and added that he was happy with his show, “Conan,” on TBS, which was renewed last year through November 2015. “I get to do what I want,” he said.

headline: Poised on the Cusp of Womanhood
text: Hyerin Lee, a dancer with LeeSaar the Company, is the first to appear onstage at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Sitting on the floor with a knee bent in front of her torso, she gazes soulfully into a high corner of the space like a model whose motivation is to ponder the Dalai Lama. A spotlight, aimed at her, grows to fill the entire stage. While Stravinsky’s “Apollo” plays, she alternates between dreamy, beatific poses — touching her head, she angles her chin with razor precision — and self-inflicted thrashing. She smacks her ribs with her elbows.

headline: Promises of Preparedness Followed Devastating Earthquakes. And Yet.
text: It is hard to imagine any people, collectively, being better prepared for earthquakes than the Japanese. Their country is one long seismic zone, which at any moment could, literally, rock and roll. Every Sept. 1, across the archipelago, Japanese engage in exercises devoted to disaster awareness: what to do should the worst happen. The occasion resonates with history. On that date in 1923, the Great Kanto earthquake devastated Tokyo and nearby Yokohama, unleashing fire and fury that left more than 100,000 people dead. After that, Japan resolved that it would prepare for whatever cataclysm nature might throw at it.

headline: Two Works That Challenge a Pianist to Go the Distance
text: “It’s not a very good piece,” the gentleman sitting behind me at Carnegie Hall pronounced on Wednesday evening after Mitsuko Uchida had performed Schubert’s Piano Sonata in G (D. 894). From the same source, after Ms. Uchida had played the other work on the program, Beethoven’s 33 Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli (Op. 120), came the verdict, “That’s a great piece.”

headline: Bringing Shostakovich Off the Bench
text: When David Samuel, the violist of the Ensemble MidtVest, took ill just a few hours before the group’s performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, his colleagues scrambled to replace him. They found a willing musician, Gregory Luce, but they simply didn’t have time to rehearse with a newbie the two planned works with viola.

headline: Death Knell for Opera in San Diego After 49 Years
text: SAN DIEGO — Molly Whittaker is a chorus member with the San Diego Opera, where she has performed for almost 10 years. But the other evening she could be found outside the opera hall, wearing a bright red T-shirt reading “Fight for San Diego Opera,” and thrusting pamphlets and stickers at patrons as they arrived for a performance of Massenet’s “Don Quixote.”

headline: Maestro Stands In, Despite Protests
text: The two programs of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall over the weekend, in their ambition, their grandiosity and their striving for effect, spoke eloquently of the musical personality of their planner, Lorin Maazel, the ensemble’s music director since 2012. It was Munich’s favorite son, Richard Strauss, all the way, on the 150th anniversary of his birth, with a grandiloquent work on each program: “Also Sprach Zarathustra” on Friday evening and “Ein Heldenleben” on Saturday.

headline: A Playwright Seeks Healing With His Work
text: Marcus Gardley had been rewriting through the night. The next morning, it was time for a pep talk to the five actors in a scruffy rehearsal space who were clutching Draft 18 of “The Box: A Black Comedy,” his satire about black men and prisons both literal and metaphorical.

headline: Pacers Can Still Be No. 1, Even After Floundering
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Sunday was Fan Appreciation Day at Bankers Life Fieldhouse, and before the Pacers took on the Oklahoma City Thunder, several Indiana players addressed the crowd, thanking fans for their support this season and imploring them to be loud during the game.

headline: Famous Debate Words
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I believe I could safely wager that crossword puzzle solvers are probably the most pedantic when it comes to spelling errors. I know this because all I have to do is make a typo in this space, and there are many sharp-eyed readers who are, shall we say, willing to help me find it. And that’s totally fine, really. If ever there should be a place where words are spelled correctly, it should be a blog about the crossword puzzle.

headline: The Precarious Foundation of a Dream House
text: Richard Maxwell looks at the world with X-ray eyes. Watching the plays of this rigorously inventive auteur, we are encouraged to see the plasterboard behind the wallpaper, the skin under the greasepaint and the skulls beneath the skin. Or in the case of “Isolde,” his smashing new work at the Abrons Arts Center, the beams and blueprints — and light and air — that go into the imagining of something as substantial and transitory as a dream house. Or, come to think of it, a play.

headline: More Higher-Priced Deals
text: Companies are staying private longer and investors are eager to write big checks. As a result, enormous venture capital rounds are becoming common.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 60
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 14
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday and an auction of five-year inflation-protected securities on Thursday.

headline: Suicide Prevention Sheds a Longstanding Taboo: Talking About Attempts
text: The relationship had become intolerably abusive, and after a stinging phone call one night, it seemed there was only one way to end the pain. Enough wine and pills should do the job — and would have, except that paramedics barged through the door, alerted by her lover.

headline: For Grown-Up Watson, the Jacket Still Fits
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — A few hours before he went out to try to win a second green jacket, Bubba Watson conducted a Masters trivia contest Sunday for his million-plus Twitter followers. The game helped unclutter Watson’s mind and clarify his purpose. One of the questions asked how many of the last 23 champions had come from the final pairing.

headline: Shots Fired in Kramatorsk
text: Men dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles fired on the Police Headquarters in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday.

headline: An Institution Exploring the Political Left Is Closing
text: For nearly 40 years the Brecht Forum has held classes, lectures, symposiums, musical performances and art exhibitions, all organized around the aim of examining the role of the political left in American society.

text: But many of the faces remain the same.

headline: My Ideas, My Boss’s Property
text: SAN DIEGO — THE big story in Silicon Valley these days is a class-action lawsuit alleging that several major tech companies, including Google and Apple, agreed not to try to hire away one another’s employees — thereby hindering workers from seeking out better-paying jobs.

headline: Secret Drugs, Agonizing Deaths
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — FACING a critical shortage of lethal injection drugs, prison officials in a number of states have recently engaged in an unseemly scramble to obtain new execution drugs, often from unreliable and even illegal sources. Not only does this trend raise serious questions about the constitutionality of executions, it also undermines the foundations of our democratic process. In the name of security, states are now withholding vital information about their death penalty procedures — from death row prisoners’ lawyers and from judges, whose stamp of approval they need to impose the ultimate sanction, as well as from the public, in whose name the sentence is carried out.

headline: Surviving the Finish Line
text: Runners, spectators and volunteers who were at the finish line of the Boston Marathon when the bombs exploded reflect on how their lives have been affected. Here are their stories of transformation.

headline: Series of Bombings Kills More Than 20 Across Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Militants with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria gained control of the main road that links Baghdad with the northern provinces for a short time on Sunday, while a series of explosions around Iraq left up to 25 dead, according to security forces.

headline: Local News, Off College Presses
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — In January, residents here learned the news that the senior place-kicker for the University of Michigan’s football team had been permanently “separated” from the college for violating its student sexual misconduct policy. In addition, the violation, what the authorities said was a sexual assault, occurred in 2009, when the kicker was a freshman, and his punishment was not determined until his athletic career had ended this past winter.

headline: Bruins Coach Eschews Negativity and Builds Winners
text: BOSTON — On the first Monday of April 2007, the Devils had a 47-24-8 record. They were in first place in the Atlantic Division with the second-best record in the Eastern Conference. They had won four of their past five games and appeared well positioned for a deep playoff run.

headline: In New York, Hard Choices on Health Exchange Spell Success
text: In contrast with the early stumbles in most of the country, New York State, almost from the start, has provided a textbook lesson in how to make the Affordable Care Act work. But it has done so by making some tough decisions.

headline: Sanctions Are Eased; Iran Sees Little Relief
text: Halfway through a six-month nuclear deal between Iran and major world powers that was meant to allow time to reach a comprehensive agreement, the Iranians have seen little in the way of a boost from the sanctions relief they had been expecting, trade lawyers and diplomatic analysts say.

headline: 3 Straight Homers Set Off Angels’ Rout
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Mets starter Bartolo Colon adjusted his cap, fiddled with his belt and kicked the dirt as the Los Angeles Angels’ Raul Ibanez rounded the bases. The fans at Angel Stadium were on their feet, cheering. In a stretch of seven pitches in the bottom of the first inning on Sunday, three Angels connected for solo home runs: Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Ibanez.

headline: Obama Effect Inspiring Few to Seek Office
text: LUDLOW, Mass. — Eric Lesser was shaking hands with diners in a Portuguese restaurant last week when he spotted the owner of Manny’s TV & Appliances. “Oh, I’ve got to get a picture,” Mr. Lesser eagerly said, draping his arm over Manny Rovithis, whose low-budget commercials have run for decades in Western Massachusetts. Mr. Lesser’s giddiness about meeting the local celebrity had not faded when he sat down for lunch.

headline: The Poetry of the Trading Floor, Going Beyond Bears and Bulls
text: LONDON — Finance is such a picturesque business, but nobody seems to notice.

headline: Three Expensive Milliseconds
text: Four years ago Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, abruptly canceled America’s biggest and arguably most important infrastructure project, a desperately needed new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. Count me among those who blame his presidential ambitions, and believe that he was trying to curry favor with the government- and public-transit-hating Republican base.

headline: Tightness in Jeter’s Leg Keeps Him Out for Second Game in a Row
text: Derek Jeter was held out of Sunday’s lineup for a second straight day after Manager Joe Girardi revealed that Jeter experienced tightness in his right quadriceps during the Yankees’ 4-2 loss to the Red Sox on Friday.

headline: Yahoo Rolls the Dice on TV
text: Yahoo, a company that seems like a permanent adolescent in search of an identity, is about to try a new persona: high-quality television programmer.

headline: Win No. 688 May Be Brodeur’s Last as a Devil
text: NEWARK — Amid a sea of fans wearing red and black plus a smattering of old-school Devils green, goaltender Martin Brodeur played perhaps his final game for the franchise, a 3-2 victory Sunday against the Bruins.

headline: Beaming Good Cheer to a Norwegian Town’s Dark Days
text: RJUKAN, Norway — Yearning for sunlight has been a part of life in this quaint old factory town in central Norway for as long as anyone can remember. Here, the sun disappears behind a mountain for six months of the year.

headline: The College Faculty Crisis
text: The public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of this country’s students were burdened by rising costs and dwindling state revenues long before the recession. They reacted by raising tuition, slashing course offerings and, sometimes, by cutting enrollment.

headline: Rich Start-Ups Go Back for Another Helping
text: Quora, a question-and-answer website, didn’t need to raise money. It had barely touched $60 million in venture capital that it accepted just two years ago.

headline: A Gossipy Newsletter Aims Higher
text: LONDON — Every Thursday the Popbitch newsletter, written in a typewriter font redolent of the early Internet, lands in the inboxes of hundreds of thousands people in Britain and around the world.

headline: Seeking a Plan to Rein In the Floodwaters Through the South Mountain Reservation
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — Striding through the South Mountain Reservation, a patch of wilderness in an otherwise highly developed corner of New Jersey, Fred R. Profeta Jr. does not see the stands of oaks and maples or the shimmering streams so much as their absence.

headline: Keep the Carriage Horses
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio noted his 100th day in office last week with a big speech and a proud recitation of campaign promises kept: universal prekindergarten, an end to unconstitutional policing, paid sick leave, among other things. There is one prominent pledge he would do better to break.

headline: A Year After the Boston Marathon Bombings, Injured Brothers Endure
text: STONEHAM, Mass. — When two bombs transformed last year’s Boston Marathon into a war zone, the Norden family absorbed a double dose of grief. J. P., 34, and his brother Paul, 32, both strapping construction workers in their prime who were there to cheer on a friend, each lost a leg in the carnage.

headline: Echoes of the Superpredator
text: Remember “superpredators”? Nearly 20 years ago, they prowled into the American consciousness — a menacing new breed of children, born of crack-addled mothers and absent fathers, and programmed solely for murder and mayhem.

text: ALGIERS — With a presidential election on Thursday, most Algerians see a fourth term for the incumbent, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, as a foregone conclusion.

headline: Saying Farewell to a Business That Turned Into an Identity
text: On his last day as a company man, Marty Singer braced himself for the final drive to the office. It was Friday morning. The clock was ticking. But he couldn’t bear to go.

text: A new post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, about how 45 percent of the popular vote turned into a two-thirds supermajority for Fidesz.

headline: Seeking Bargains, Red Sox Secure Bullpen Insurance

headline: American’s Wish for Iranian Burial Riles Hard-Liners
text: TEHRAN — Richard Nelson Frye, a renowned American scholar of Iran who died last month in Boston at 94, wanted to be buried at a spot in this country where songbirds sing and dry desert breezes cool the slow afternoons.

headline: Amid Charges of Hypocrisy, Louisiana Lawmaker Faces Calls to Step Down
text: WEST MONROE, La. — As she handed out garbage bags on Saturday as part of an anti-litter drive, Patsy Edmondson drew a parallel to Louisiana’s history of tawdry politics.

headline: Stepping Into the Shoes of a Ravaged Singer
text: When Billie Holiday sang, history attests, her audiences tended to clam up. Even in the bustling nightclubs where she mostly performed, Holiday often insisted on total quiet before she would open her mouth. The quiet usually held, as one of the great singers of the last century turned jazz songs and standards into searching, and searing, portraits of life and love gone wrong that cast a shimmering spell.

text: Here be spoilers, and analysis that probably qualifies as obsessive, in a clinical sense.

headline: Ron Pundak, a Key Israeli in Oslo Accords, Dies at 59
text: JERUSALEM — Ron Pundak, an Israeli academic who took part in secret talks with Palestinian officials that led to the Oslo peace accords of the 1990s and who remained an ardent advocate for peace even after relations between the sides unraveled, died on Friday in Tel Aviv. He was 59.

headline: Concussion Cases Inspire New Course at George Washington’s Law School
text: WASHINGTON — The revelations that hits to the head may lead to long-term brain damage have rocked the football world at all levels, alarming coaches, players and their parents and forcing the N.F.L. and the N.C.A.A. to tighten safety standards.

headline: The Art of ‘Something From Nothing’
text: SEATTLE — Entrepreneurs are lucky to have one big score. Richard Barton has had a string of them, by repeatedly asking the same simple question: What piece of marketplace information do people crave and don’t have?

headline: Maxwell House, Aiming to Reclaim Coffee Crown, Starts Makeover

headline: Popular Demand
text: Viewers watched on-demand television programming an average of 8.7 hours a month in 2013, according to Rentrak. Free broadcast and cable TV shows accounted for 6.4 of those hours. Most viewers, 66 percent, watched a show at least four days after it was originally broadcast.

headline: Photo Replay: April 6-12
text: Whether in the heat of battle or the exuberance of celebration, having a leg up on the competition can be an advantageous position.

headline: In Monte Carlo, the First All-Organic Restaurant to Receive a Michelin Star
text: In Monaco, carrots just might be the new caviar. “For me, luxury is eating baby peas that were picked an hour earlier or maybe a carrot that was just pulled out of the ground,” says the chef Paolo Sari, whose cooking at Elsa — a sunny restaurant at the suavely bohemian, India Mahdavi-designed Monte Carlo Beach Hotel — recently won him the first Michelin star ever awarded to a 100 percent organic establishment.

headline: Opportunity for All and Social Innovation: Obama’s Policy Agenda
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Bill Clinton. Jonathan Greenblatt is a special assistant to President Obama and director of the Office of Social Innovation and Civic Participation at the White House.

headline: A Number That May Not Add Up
text: In July 1998, the National Institutes of Health changed what it means to be overweight, defining it as a body mass index of 25 or greater for adults. The cutoff had been 28 for men and 27 for women, so suddenly about 29 million Americans who had been considered normal became overweight even though they hadn’t gained an ounce.

headline: A Chance for Retro Reinvention
text: For the “Mad Men” protagonist, Don Draper, the melancholy if alluring young widow he met on a plane ride in Sunday’s season premiere could be just a passing flirtation or perhaps a new flame who will share in his extramarital escapades.

headline: Yankees Find Another First Baseman in a Pinch, Then Beat Boston
text: The Yankees signed Carlos Beltran this off-season to help bolster their offense. On Sunday night, the Yankees also needed Beltran to help save their infield defense. Beltran made his career debut at first base after several injuries had left Manager Joe Girardi with a ravaged roster.

headline: India Election Digest: April 14
text: What you need to know on Monday about India’s elections: The chief minister of West Bengal asks voters not to back the Bharatiya Janata Party, a study shows economic activity tends to slow before national elections, and a candidate in Rajasthan has generated a buzz with his campaign promise.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) THE TRIALS OF MUHAMMAD ALI (2013) In 1967 — after changing his name from Cassius Clay, joining the Nation of Islam and refusing to be inducted into the United States military because of his religious opposition to the Vietnam War — Muhammad Ali, above, was convicted of draft evasion. Stripped of his world heavyweight championship and banned from boxing, he spent the next four years fighting legal battles. In 1971, his case for being a conscientious objector reached the United States Supreme Court. In this “Independent Lens” presentation, the director Bill Siegel combines interviews with Louis Farrakhan; Mr. Ali’s second wife, Khalilah Camacho-Ali; the journalist Robert Lipsyte; Mr. Ali’s loyal brother, Rahman; and a clerk from the Supreme Court proceedings to address Mr. Ali’s challenges then and now, including his battle with Parkinson’s. “The film falls short of explaining Mr. Ali, who, like many outspoken individuals, can stubbornly repel scrutiny, nor will it pacify the many who opposed his conscientious objections,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But it also underlines one enduring quality: namely, that he probably couldn’t care less what people think.”

headline: Despite Frustrating Week, McIlroy Meets His Diminished Goal
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At the start of the week, nothing short of a Masters victory would do for Rory McIlroy, the former world No. 1 from Northern Ireland. After a five-over-par 77 in the second round, he revised his goals, lowering the bar to try to clear the top 15. That would beat his career best here, a tie for 15th in 2011, when McIlroy entered the final round with the lead.

headline: Searchers to Deploy Submersible in Hunt for Missing Jet

headline: Saab in Talks to Buy ThyssenKrupp Shipyard Operations
text: LONDON – The Swedish military contractor Saab said on Monday that it was in talks to buy ThyssenKrupp’s shipbuilding operations in Sweden.

headline: Last Night to Bend the Rules
text: Welcome to the secret world of the bachelorette party. For you first-timers, please, don’t be alarmed. There is a set of rituals that transpire throughout the evening, starting with ensuring that you have relinquished any responsibilities that may distract you from having fun: check. Getting yourself pampered and dressed up more provocatively than for the average night out: check. And most important, figuring out how to get the bride-to-be to enjoy her final moments of being an unmarried woman.

headline: After Delays, Syria Completes Another Shipment of Chemical Arms
text: GENEVA — After lengthy delays in loading its chemical weapons for destruction abroad, Syria has completed delivery of another shipment that brings the total to almost two-thirds of its arsenal, the international watchdog overseeing the process reported on Monday.

headline: Ardian to Sell Food Ingredients Maker to Symrise for $1.8 Billion
text: LONDON – Symrise of Germany has offered to buy the Diana Group, a maker of food ingredients, from the private equity firm Ardian for 1.3 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion.

headline: Arrest Order for Fugitive Hong Kong Tycoon Reaffirmed

headline: Ukraine Falters in Drive to Curb Unrest in East
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal on Monday to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev, where political leaders and security forces have few reliable ways to confront Russian-backed separatists in the restive east.

headline: Huge New York Development Project Becomes a Data Science Lab
text: Hudson Yards is a huge estate development project, the largest in New York since Rockefeller Center. It is to include office towers, apartments, shops, a luxury hotel, a public school and acres of public space. Construction began at the end of 2012, and has picked up recently.

headline: What I Learned About Business as a South Georgia Bottom Fisher
text: When I tell people the first business lesson I ever learned was with Louisiana Pinks, they often think I was in the nail polish or lipstick businesses, or maybe rose bushes. Sorry, not at the age of 15 living in rural southern Georgia. I was in none of those businesses. I was selling worms.

headline: Looking Back at the Publishing Beat With Julie Bosman
text: Julie Bosman recently wrote about the declining number of bookstores in New York City. Before she decamps to Chicago to become one of our Midwest correspondents, we asked her to reflect on the state of the publishing industry and share some of her reading habits.

headline: City Says Water Meets Safety Standards, But Residents Remain Cautious
text: Officials in the northwestern Chinese city of Lanzhou have declared that a faulty pipeline was repaired and that the water supply now meets safety standards, days after tests showed levels of a cancer-causing chemical more than 20 times national safety limits.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Funding Feast
text: There can never be too much money in the bank. Such appears to be the thinking behind a new dynamic that is reshaping Silicon Valley. Start-ups, already flush with cash, are piling on investment dollars, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Of the 100 largest venture capital fund-raising rounds on record, 88 were issued within the last five years, according to CrunchBase, which tracks venture funding. Each delivered more than $50 million to the companies.

headline: Lessons for the Largest Democracy From a Much Smaller One

In fluent if ungrammatical English he told us he was taking us somewhere that would tell us more about his country, one of the longest-running democracies in Central America.
