text: The Blackstone Group and the merchant banking arm of Goldman Sachs said on Monday that they had agreed to buy Ipreo Holdings from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in the latest instance of private equity firms buying holdings from one another.

headline: Coachella 2014: Day 2
text: The second day of this year’s music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.

headline: Coachella 2014: Day 3
text: The final day of this year’s music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Blood Orange, Beck and Arcade Fire

headline: Under Cover: In Pursuit of an Unearthly Record
text: What inspires a music collector to search high and low and pay large sums of money to acquire one record? Obsessiveness, says Chris King, who owns the record “Last Kind Word Blues,” by Geeshie Wiley, that appears on this week’s cover.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: John Jeremiah Sullivan on the Search for Geeshie and Elvie
text: John Jeremiah Sullivan, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about searching for the two women behind a legendary 1930s blues record. He is the author of “Pulphead.”

headline: Endurance Bids $3.2 Billion for Aspen Insurance
text: Updated, 2:31 p.m. |

headline: Suvir Saran’s Guacamole With Toasted Cumin
text: The chef Suvir Saran says that “avocados make people happy,” and he’s right. He adds toasted cumin seeds, which he refers to as “Indian bacon bits,” to his chunky guacamole. This guacamole has all the flavors of a Mexican guacamole – illustrating yet again how Indian, Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Mexican cuisines overlap. In fact, the ingredients here are identical to those that I have always used in my guacamole; but this recipe has the added delight of texture, as the ingredients aren’t mashed up.

headline: Chilean Cabbage and Avocado Slaw
text: Coleslaw meets guacamole here in this utterly simple mix of shredded cabbage, salt, lemon, and puréed avocado. The chef Iliana de la Vega, who was born in Oaxaca, Mexico, served it at a delicious Latin-themed lunch she prepared at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference this year at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. I couldn’t get enough of it. I sat with Iliana at the lunch and asked her about the salad. “Just salt the cabbage, let it sit for a while, then add lots of lemon juice and the mashed avocado,” she said. That really is all there is to it. Shred the cabbage thin and for best results let it sit, after salting generously, for an hour or more, to tenderize it and draw out strong-tasting juices.

headline: Roasted Tomatillo-Poblano-Avocado Salsa
text: One of my favorite new cookbooks of this season is “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel), by Kim Sunée. The book is a memoir, travelogue and cookbook all rolled into one, written by an author who earlier published another compelling memoir with recipes,“Trail of Crumbs.” Kim is a poetic world traveler who loves many cuisines. She is a big fan of taco trucks and loves salsa, the spicier the better. This salsa is based on her recipe for roasted tomatillo-poblano salsa. I love its balance of char, heat, acid and creamy. I’m a moderate when it comes to heat, but you can make this hotter by adding more chiles.

headline: Chunky Avocado-Papaya Salsa
text: This is based on a recipe in Kim Sunée’s wonderful new book, “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel). Her recipe is more of a salad, a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors. I loved the idea of combining avocado and papaya, two subtle, creamy fruits, with crunchy, bright-tasting Asian pears and spicy chiles. The first time I saw the recipe I wanted to test it right away, but I didn’t have Asian pears. So I used an apple, and loved it. It’s the sweet, crunchy fruit that does the trick, and apples and Asian pears both work. There are onions in the original recipe but I’ve made them optional.

headline: Avocado and Roasted Tomatillo Salsa
text: I have been making tomatillo and avocado salsa for years, but I usually simmer the tomatillos rather than roasting them. Roasting the tomatillos, chiles and garlic – toasting really, as I use a skillet for this, on top of the flame – produces a salsa with a delicious charred flavor. I learned something recently from the chef Iliana de la Vega, who demonstrated the recipe at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference in Napa Valley in March: she says, in no uncertain terms, that you should not add water to tomatillo salsas. Without the water, this is a more intense salsa with pleasing density. You can use it as a sauce to serve with chicken or fish, or as a dip with chips or other vegetables.

headline: U.N. Leaders Discuss Ukraine Crisis
text: The American, Russian and Ukrainian ambassadors to the United Nations discussed the escalating crisis in Ukraine at a Security Council emergency meeting on Sunday night.

headline: Nigeria Blast Kills Dozens as Militants Hit Capital
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — Militants struck near the heart of the Nigerian state early Monday, bombing a bus station in the capital, Abuja, just miles from the seat of government in one of the worst attacks in years in the country’s struggle with insurgents.

headline: Investors Trying to Beat the System Invariably Are Disappointed
text: Let’s start with a parable.

headline: For the Auto Industry, a Showcase for Change
text: The 2014 New York International Auto Show is billed, rightly so, as a showcase for dozens of new and significantly changed automobiles. But more than that, it is also a showcase for the quickening pace of change in the auto industry.

headline: Moving Water to Birds, Painkillers During Pregnancy, To Love and Hate Bugs
text:
A new program is using crowdsourced data to select rice fields for bird rest stops; the numbers of women who take opioid drugs for pain during pregnancy is rising, but what are the risks?; a new book looks into the philias and phobias surrounding insects.
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: ‘Book of Mormon’ Wins Big at Olivier Awards
text: The Broadway hit “The Book of Mormon” dominated the Tony Awards in 2011, winning nine (including for best musical), and on Sunday night the show was a powerhouse at the Olivier Awards, London’s equivalent of the Tonys. The West End production of “Mormon,” which opened there last year, won for best new musical, best actor (Gavin Creel as Elder Price), best supporting actor (Stephen Ashfield as Elder McKinley), and best choreography (Casey Nicholaw).

headline: Twitter’s Biggest Shareholders Say They Won’t Sell Stock
text: Updated | Added comment from JP Morgan Asset Management and updated the total amount of stock owned by shareholders that say they won’t sell.

headline: In China, a Big Jet Becomes a Status Symbol
text: IN the United States, public reaction to the corporate use of business jets can be scathing when instances of obvious excess become publicized, such as the day in 2008 when the top executives of the Detroit automakers each used a private jet to fly to Washington to argue for $25 billion in taxpayer bailouts.

headline: Seeing Double | The Versatility of a Cardigan
text: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways.

headline: Food Curated: La Vara’s Churros
text: The perfect churro is eaten fresh from the fryer, says Alex Raij, co-owner of La Vara in Brooklyn. She created a brunch churro that balances a sweet, crunchy exterior with a moist eggy interior.

headline: Video: La Vara’s Churros
text: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: When Boating With Young Children
text: Still want to take your children out onto the open sea? You’ve got company.

headline: Today in Small Business: Mobile Yoga
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: Mizuno Campaign Asks What Makes Sammy — and Everybody Else — Run
text: A running shoe firm is seeking to attract new customers and encourage current ones with a campaign that promotes the positive changes that could occur if only more people were to put one foot in front of the other.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Scott Christie joined the Toronto office of ClarkHuot, part of the CHR Group, in a new post, creative director. He had been creative director at the Toronto office of Interbrand, part of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Times Minute | Afghan Uncertainty
text: On the Minute, the chief of The Times’s Kabul Bureau, Rod Nordland, discusses the first results from Afghanistan’s presidential elections.

headline: Tax Preparers’ New Role: Health-Coverage Advisers
text: WASHINGTON — Iris I. Burnell, an adviser at Jackson Hewitt Tax Service, has prepared scores of returns in the last few months, as she does every year ahead of the April 15 filing deadline. But many of her consultations this year have also included educating clients about the tax implications of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Barton on ‘Power to the People’
text: Richard Barton describes the philosophy behind many of his businesses, which are meant to empower people in new ways.

headline: Times Minute | Afghan Uncertainty

headline: When Not to Speak Your Second Language to Your Children
text: I never thought of myself as having much in common with Spanish-speaking immigrants to the United States. I was born in Iowa, to parents of Western European ancestry, and I am a classic example of the monolingual American whose only exposure to another language came from a brief high school foreign-language class.

headline: Sol Golomb’s Rectangle Puzzle
text: This week’s puzzle is based on an original by Solomon Golomb, a major figure in communication theory and a legendary professor at the University of Southern California. Dr. Golomb is also a prolific puzzle creator; I was introduced to his precise and insightful challenges by the physicist, electrical engineer and mathematician Nelson Blachman, who consumed puzzles of all types and particularly enjoyed those by Dr. Golomb.

headline: Asian Cultural Council Divides the Prize for Rockefeller Awards
text: The Asian Cultural Council, which was founded in 1963 to encourage cultural exchanges between the United States and Asian countries, normally gives its $50,000 John D. Rockefeller 3rd Award to a single artist every year. This year the council is splitting the award for the first time, the council announced on Monday. The winners are the composer Chinary Ung, the choreographer and dancer Pichet Klunchun, and an arts administrator in Indonesia, Amna Kusumo. They will each receive $50,000.

headline: Beans and Peas Lower Cholesterol
text: Eating modest amounts of legumes — peas, chickpeas, beans and lentils — appears to reduce levels of LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol.

headline: Aftermath of Nigeria Bus Bombing
text: Nigerian officials and witnesses described the morning rush hour blast at a crowded bus station that killed at least 70 people on the outskirts of Abuja.

headline: Paying Farmers to Welcome Birds
text: WHEATLAND, Calif. — The Central Valley was once one of North America’s most productive wildlife habitats, a 450-mile-long expanse marbled with meandering streams and lush wetlands that provided an ideal stop for migratory shorebirds on their annual journeys from South America and Mexico to the Arctic and back.

headline: JWT to Bring Back the Classic J. Walter Thompson Name
text: A funny thing happened on Monday morning to carefully laid plans by the giant JWT advertising agency to announce later in the year that it would bring back its longtime name, the J. Walter Thompson Company: The chief executive of the JWT parent, Martin Sorrell of WPP, let the cat out of the bag.

headline: Day 4 of Pistorius Cross-Examination
text: Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympian accused of murdering his girlfriend, sobbed during a fourth day of grueling cross-examination in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Beyond the Finish Line
text: Jeff Bauman was waiting to see his girlfriend when the bombs went off. Then his Boston marathon began.

headline: As Cubs Wander Into the Bronx, They’ve Never Been Worse
text: The Cubs were a juggernaut: 322 victories over three seasons, winning the pennant in each of those years and going on to take the World Series twice in a row. The team was built to endure, too, with future Hall of Famers at first base, second base and shortstop, and another Hall of Famer on the mound.

headline: Who Am I?
text: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.

headline: Creativity Trumps Perfection at the Masters
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bubba Watson is old enough to be Jordan Spieth’s uncle, but that is not why their final-round duel at the Masters remained compelling long after the outcome was no longer in doubt.

headline: U.N. Official Condemns Use of Torture in Syrian War
text: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, condemned the rampant and routine use of torture by the Syrian authorities in a paper released by her office on Monday, which also records torture by some armed opposition groups and serious allegations of torture and the ill-treatment of children.

headline: No Comment Necessary: New Hampshire’s Senator From Massachusetts
text: Scott Brown announced last week that he would run to unseat Jeanne Shaheen as senator from New Hampshire. Which of the two deserve the label “third senator from Massachusetts”?

headline: Wildfire Rages in Chile
text: Firefighters struggle to contain a massive wildfire in Valparaíso, Chile, that has destroyed thousands of homes since Saturday.

headline: New Dave Eggers Novel Coming in June
text: Dave Eggers’s latest novel will be published on June 17, just eight months after the appearance of his last, the social-media cautionary tale “The Circle.” The new book’s title is a two-sentence mouthful: “Your Fathers, Where Are They? And the Prophets, Do They Live Forever?”

headline: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
text: The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography.

headline: New Collection of Shirley Jackson Works to Be Published
text: In the competition to bring previously unpublished works of Shirley Jackson to readers, Random House has prevailed, in a far less bloody manner than her classic short story “The Lottery” would suggest. Random House said on Monday that it had acquired a new collection of works by Ms. Jackson, the National Book Award-nominated author of “The Haunting of Hill House,” compiled primarily from her papers at the Library of Congress.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Lady Day’
text: Audra McDonald sings “What a Little Moonlight Can Do” from “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar and Grill,” about the life of the singer Billie Holiday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 14
text: The Golden temple at dawn on the occasion of Baisakhi festival in Amritsar, Punjab..

headline: Imagining Charles (Finally) in Charge
text: LONDON — The Queen is dead. Charles, paranoid and power obsessed, dissolves Parliament and parks a tank outside Buckingham Palace. While Prince William dithers, his steely and pragmatic wife, Kate, orchestrates a palace coup to save the monarchy and prevent Britain from sliding into civil war.

headline: Michael Phelps Plans Return to Competitive Swimming
text: There is no Olympic design behind Michael Phelps’s comeback, if you can call it that. At this stage, Phelps’s coach, Bob Bowman, would prefer that people not read too much into his return to competition next week at the Arena Grand Prix in Mesa, Ariz.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 11-13, 2014
text: For the last month, a serial shooter has been wreaking havoc on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area. Three people have been wounded in as many as 20 shootings, calling to mind the terror that paralyzed the Washington, D.C., area in 2002, when a pair of snipers killed 10 people.

headline: Too Much Family Love
text: For 15 years Anna was a solitary figure sitting at the far end of our waiting room for her annual checkups, having shaved a half-hour off her workday so she could hustle over before we locked our doors.

headline: Alexa Ray Joel Recovering After Collapsing at Café Carlyle Show
text: Alexa Ray Joel, the 28-year old daughter of the singer Billy Joel and the model Christie Brinkley, and a singer, pianist and songwriter in her own right, was two songs into her set at the Café Carlyle on Saturday evening  – the final performance in a two-week run that opened on April 1 – when she suddenly collapsed. She was taken to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital.

headline: White House Pressed to Protect Ailing Monarch Butterflies
text: All too often, species that humans care about only get attention when they are in crisis. Such is the case with monarch butterflies. The insect, famed for its remarkable annual migrations, faced declines in habitat on both the Mexican and American ends of its range for decades, but now is the focus of an urgent push for a rescue. The latest step is a letter sent on Monday to President Obama and relevant cabinet members by a group of scientists, educators, farmers, and other concerned citizens organized by the Xerces Society and other conservation groups focused on these butterflies. The letter (read it here) describes policies the administration could pursue on both public and private land along the butterfly’s migratory path.  In February, after about 20 naturalists, poets and other monarch defenders pressed for international action in an open letter, the plight of the butterfly was addressed by President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts at a summit. The leaders agreed to create a working group to study ways to protect the butterfly at both ends of its range. A recent article by Richard Conniff in Yale Environment 360 describes what farmers can do to help monarchs. I also recommend a recent feature in The Times by Michael Wines describing efforts by various groups to restore habitat:

headline: A Son’s Deafness Prompts a Scientific Journey
text: Like almost all newborns in this country, Alex Justh was given a hearing test at birth. He failed, but his parents were told not to worry: He was a month premature and there was mucus in his ears. A month later, an otoacoustic emission test, which measures the response of hair cells in the inner ear, came back normal.

headline: India Won’t Use Nuclear Weapons First
text: India’s Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, has clarified its stated plan to “revise and update” the country’s nuclear weapons doctrine.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
text: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.” (Last month’s ranking: 1.)

headline: Citi’s Stock Seems Priced for More Mediocrity
text: Citigroup’s stock looks perfectly priced – for more mediocrity.

headline: Long in the Tooth
text: Q. Why, after 5,000 or so years under ice, would the teeth of the so-called Iceman of the Alps still look pretty good? How long do teeth last?

headline: Hunt for Missing Plane to Go Underwater
text: Angus Houston, who is coordinating the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, announced that teams plan to use a submersible vehicle to hunt under the ocean.

headline: A Sea of Blue and Mourning at an Officer’s Funeral
text: The police sharpshooters stood atop an apartment tower on Beach 84th Street in Far Rockaway on Monday morning. They were there by way of protocol, but the view must have been striking. It was a fitting vantage point for the funeral of an officer who died in a high-rise building fire.

headline: Next Residents of a Luxury Building: Police Horses
text: The newest residences at Mercedes House, a ziggurat of luxury rentals on Manhattan’s Far West Side, provide tenants with creature comforts found nowhere else in the city.

headline: N.H.L. Teams Suffer Post-Olympic Blues
text: The so-called Olympic effect seems to have struck N.H.L. teams again.

headline: How Fruit Flies Are Like Helicopters
text: Apparently it is not just speed that makes a fly so hard to swat. In the face of danger, fruit flies execute surprisingly nimble maneuvers to pitch and roll out of harm’s way, researchers say.

headline: In Many Cities, Rent Is Rising Out of Reach of Middle Class
text: MIAMI — For rent and utilities to be considered affordable, they are supposed to take up no more than 30 percent of a household’s income. But that goal is increasingly unattainable for middle-income families as a tightening market pushes up rents ever faster, outrunning modest rises in pay.

headline: An Acidic Wine Calls for Duck and Rhubarb
text: Rhubarb, like the lean Napa cabernet sauvignons, is defined by bright acidity and modest fruit flavors. And happily, the first rhubarb of the season is showing up in the market. The rhubarb plays off rosy, meaty duck magret rimmed with creamy fat. A touch of blood orange in the sauce contributes more fruit and acid.

headline: Bullets, Blood and Then Cry of ‘Heil Hitler’
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — After the Sunday afternoon mayhem, the handcuffed suspect was led to a gun-gray police car, his beard salt and pepper, his T-shirt a striking white. He looked like who he was, in part: a retiree who was said to have just spent part of his weekend at a casino. Then, from the back seat, he shouted a hoary phrase tinged with a Southern inflection:

headline: The Bulls May Have a Role Model for Anthony
text: After reporters covering the Chicago Bulls had finished interviewing Coach Tom Thibodeau on Sunday night, they headed to the team’s locker room at Madison Square Garden and went en masse to one player, Joakim Noah, who was finishing dressing with his back to them.

headline: Maazel Withdraws From Boston Symphony Concerts
text: April should have been a banner month for Lorin Maazel, the 84-year-old former director of the New York Philharmonic. He was to have brought the ensemble he currently directs, the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, to Carnegie Hall over the weekend, but had to withdraw from the performances because he was ill. (Valery Gergiev and Fabio Luisi filled in for him.) Now the Boston Symphony Orchestra has announced that he has had to bow out of concerts in Boston, from Thursday through April 26. He was also to have taken the orchestra on an Asian tour, with concerts in China, which the orchestra last visited in 1979 (it was the first American orchestra to perform there after the normalization of relations), and Japan, which the Bostonians last visited in 1999.

headline: Obama Speaks About Kansas Shootings
text: The president honored those killed in shootings at two Jewish centers in Kansas, saying no one should have to worry about their security while praying with their fellow believers.

headline: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
text: The New York Times has swept the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes for photography. The staff photographer Tyler Hicks won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for his coverage of a terrorist attack at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya, that left more than 60 people dead. Josh Haner was awarded the Pulitzer in feature photography for his images of the slow and painful recovery process for a survivor of the Boston Marathon bombing.

headline: GrafTech Drama Headed for Proxy Fight
text: The war of words between GrafTech International, a small steel company, and its largest independent shareholder, Nathan Milikowsky, is heating up, and a proxy fight is on the horizon.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Wins Another Nascar Crown Jewel
text: `Kevin Harvick passed Dale Earnhardt Jr. with one lap to go to win the Southern 500 Nascar Sprint Cup race at Darlington, S.C., Saturday. Harvick has now won all of Nascar’s most prestigious races, including the Daytona 500, the Brickyard 400 and the Coca-Cola 600.

headline: Pulitzer Prizes Awarded for Coverage of N.S.A. Secrets and Boston Bombing
text: The Washington Post and Guardian U.S. on Monday won the Pulitzer Prize for public service, among the most prestigious awards in journalism, for their articles based on National Security Agency documents leaked by the former government contractor Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Two Photography Pulitzers
text: Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored in feature photography for his images of the recovery of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor.

headline: Mozilla Names Interim Chief
text: Mozilla, the maker of the popular Firefox web browser, announced Monday that it had appointed Chris Beard the interim chief executive of the company.

headline: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design
text: T’s design editor Tom Delavan interviews the Italian designer, who discusses her show at Salone del Mobile.

headline: A Tiny Discovery in Australia’s Swamps
text: Researchers have discovered a tiny new species of crayfish in Australia. Weighing just over seven grams, the Gramastacus lacus is one of the world’s smallest freshwater crayfishes, and is distinguished by a large male genital papilla and raised ridges above the eyes. Described in the open-access journal ZooKeys, it resides in swampy areas on the eastern coast of Australia from Wamberal Lagoon to Wallis Lake, where it periodically burrows into the water table to survive dry periods, effectively hiding from scientists seeking to study it.

headline: The 2015 Nissan Murano: Dialing Back From a Striking Design
text: What is it? The 2015 Nissan Murano is the third generation of the company’s midsized crossover.

headline: VW Golf SportWagen: A Station Wagon Concept
text: What is it? According to Volkswagen, the Golf SportWagen Concept previews a bigger, more spacious and more fuel-efficient replacement for the Jetta SportWagen.

headline: Total to Proceed With Angola Ultra-Deepwater Project
text: LONDON — After more than a year’s delay, the French oil company Total said on Monday that it had found the cost savings needed to move ahead with the giant ultra-deepwater Kaombo project off the coast of Angola, setting a start date of 2017.

headline: Still Nothing on the I.R.S.
text: Some readers objected last week when I wrote that “Fox News Sunday” is the place where Republican politicians go to make empty accusations without fear of follow-up questions. So I wanted to note that the show’s host, Chris Wallace not only asked follow-ups, but tough ones, in an interview on Sunday with Representative Charles Boustany, Republican of Louisiana.

headline: Napa Cabernets From a Cold, Wet Year
text: Outside of a few pockets of fog, California is the land of warmth and sunshine. This has led some to conclude that California wines must always show evidence of this privileged climate through plush textures and opulent fruit.

headline: With Purchase of Drone Maker, Google Sees a Fleet of Satellites
text: Google is reaching for the sky.

headline: Michael Kaiser to Become Co-Chairman of IMG Artists
text: Michael M. Kaiser is adding another position to his résumé.

headline: Budget Office Lowers Estimate for the Cost of Expanding Health Coverage
text: WASHINGTON — The insurance expansion under the Affordable Care Act will cost $1.383 trillion over the next decade, more than $100 billion less than previous forecasts, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.

headline: E-Cigarettes Are Targeted at Youths, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — An investigation by Democratic members of Congress into the marketing practices of electronic cigarette companies has found that major producers are targeting young people by giving away free samples at music and sporting events and running radio and television advertisements during youth-oriented programs.

headline: MTV Movie Awards Red Carpet
text: At the MTV Movie Awards, guests like Lupita Nyong’o in a colorful Chanel dress and Rita Ora in a plunging neckline Barbara Casasola dress, shined on the red carpet.

headline: It Pays to Pay Addicts to Get Vaccinations
text: Paying heroin addicts the equivalent of $50 each to have a series of three injections in a month was very effective in getting them fully vaccinated against hepatitis B, a new British study has found.

headline: Learning From What Lincoln Had to Say
text: Ken Burns, the documentarian who gave us “The Civil War,” knows quite a lot about the Gettysburg Address, but in his latest film, he turns his attention to a group of boys who are just learning about it. The result is “The Address,” a documentary Tuesday night on PBS that has little to do with the war but is quietly revelatory, just as that earlier work was.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 59
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design, on Her Salone Exhibition
text: Last Thursday, in the middle of Salone del Mobile, Rossana Orlandi hosted a cocktail party at the Bagatti Valsecchi Museum. Champagne flowed as the see-and-be-seen crowd piled in to admire the “Untold” exhibition she curated there, which she explains in the above video interview with our design editor, Tom Delavan. Displaying contemporary pieces in the historic 19th-century house allowed Orlandi to “show how modern pieces are perfect and can have a fabulous dialogue with an old palace,” she says. The video opens with the light installation that she and Vionnet’s creative director, Goga Ashkenazi, commissioned from the artist Jacopo Foggini for the show. Orlandi, who was once a fashion designer and loathes the “trendsetter” label often tacked onto her globally-recognized name, is now famous for championing the careers of designers on the rise, a category Foggini fell into not long ago. “When I find a designer, first of all I want to be sure that this designer — he will grow up,” she explains. Cast in the fashion house’s signature shade of blue, Foggini’s installation set the tone for the queen of design’s fête — a high point during an action-packed week.

headline: Flavors of the South From One of Its Own
text: I met Donald Link for the first time three weeks after Hurricane Katrina drowned New Orleans. He was mucking out the walk-in at Herbsaint, his sophisticated restaurant in the city’s central business district. Hauling rotted pig heads to the curb in a city that had just lost hundreds of people was awful work. But it had to be done, and he was one of the first chefs to do it.

headline: The Making of Pulitzer Prize-Winning Photos
text: Today, two Times journalists, Tyler Hicks and Josh Haner, were awarded Pulitzer Prizes for photography in 2013.

headline: 2014 Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, Letters, Drama and Music
text: FICTION

headline: They Crawl Right Into Your Head
text: Trained as an entomologist, Jeffrey A. Lockwood discovered 12 years into his career that he was phobic about the very subject he had chosen as his life’s work.

headline: When a Game Turned Into a Disaster
text: “Hillsborough,” Tuesday night on ESPN, is a soccer movie with very little soccer in it. It’s about a match played 25 years ago at the Hillsborough stadium in Sheffield, England, that ended after just six minutes — when the realization set in that amid the festive atmosphere of an F.A. Cup semifinal, fans were being crushed to death a few yards behind the west goal.

headline: Zombies in the Garden, Killing Themselves Slowly
text: Scientists say they have identified a protein that causes zombielike behavior in plants.

headline: Obesity Studies Tell Two Stories, Both Right
text: WASHINGTON — Researchers at the University of North Carolina published a paper last week that introduced another wrinkle into the debate about childhood obesity. They disputed recent findings that obesity among young children had fallen since 2004, arguing that a longer view — using data all the way back to 1999 — showed that these youngsters were not really getting any thinner.

headline: Bikini (and Hoop Skirt) Season Is Here, and Not a Moment Too Soon
text: Say you decide to make a dance about the isolation of grief: How would you represent the boredom of solitude without boring a spectator? That’s one of the challenges that Rebecca Brooks and her collaborators have set themselves in “Still Left on This Rock.” And at Danspace Project in the East Village this weekend, on a double bill with Anna Azrieli’s “third skirt scrum,” much of the 45 minutes of “Still Left” slipped from languor into longueurs.

headline: In Performance: Adrian Lester
text: Adrian Lester performs a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s play “Red Velvet,” a drama about the 19th-century black actor Ira Aldridge. The show runs through April 20 at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: Chia-Seed Pudding for Breakfast: Tart, Sweet and Good for You

headline: Spying on a Grown-Up World
text: Family is the North Star for Mona Simpson’s characters: It defines who they are, chaperones their choices, shapes their views of the world. Her dazzling debut novel, “Anywhere But Here” (1986), gave us an indelible portrait of a girl’s emotionally fraught relationship with her impossible, narcissistic mother. “The Lost Father” (1992) followed that same heroine’s obsessive search for the father who abandoned her. And “A Regular Guy” (1996) depicted another abandoned daughter trying to come to terms with her father — in this case, a rich, eccentric entrepreneur (who bore more than a passing resemblance to Ms. Simpson’s real-life brother, Steve Jobs).

headline: Pulitzer-Winning Play ‘The Flick’ to Reopen in New York
text: Annie Baker’s play “The Flick,” which ran Off Broadway last year and won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday, will be remounted at Barrow Street Theater in the near future, according to a spokesman for its producer, Scott Rudin.

headline: Etsy Artisans Reach Retailers
text: Etsy is giving small business owners, like the woodworkers Shelli and Seth Worley of South Carolina, the opportunity to sell to retailers through a wholesale website.

headline: Etsy, Home of the Handmade, Takes On a Wholesaler’s Role
text: Amy Hamley of Redraven Studios makes jewelry and delicate home décor items out of porcelain, like hanging planter sets and necklaces in the shape of arrow heads. For three years, she worked out of her basement and tried to break into the wholesale market.

headline: Still Sensing the Presence of a Departed Composer
text: I wasn’t ready for Robert Ashley to be gone. Associates and intimates had shared news, quietly, of the deteriorating health that would lead to his death on March 3 at 83. Still, I’d thought, no way would karma, destiny or what have you allow Ashley to be taken before the conclusion of his three-opera series underway at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Quinoa

text: “Original adaptation,” like “instant classic” and “jumbo shrimp,” is an oxymoron that makes sense.

headline: A Christmas Day Flight, With a Reindeer for a Captain

I was always involved in the hotel industry, and now I’m a senior vice president at Virtuoso, a luxury travel network, so I’m doing long-haul flights all the time.

headline: Refusals Cut Options After C-Sections
text: CASPER, Wyo. — When Marie Scott, a child-care worker turned stay-at-home mother, found out she was pregnant again last year, she knew she wanted a traditional birth.

headline: Not Merely Dead, Most Sincerely Dead
text: A single death is not a tragedy in most video games. Instead, it’s something closer to an irritant — not even a paper cut, more like a chipped nail. Death is so cheap that a new word — “permadeath” — has been coined to describe games that turn your demise into something more than a speed bump on the road to victory.

headline: Artists and Spectators, Not So Far Apart
text: INDIO, Calif. — The age of the pop performer being somehow distinct from or greater than the audience is almost over; the audience has grown much more powerful, mostly through the forces of the Internet and social media. Nowhere is this more apparent perhaps than at last weekend’s Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, whose audience — cultivated over 15 editions in 15 years — has all that soft power and money, too: Tickets cost at least $375. The audience members have been called tastemakers, but let’s see that generalization and raise it. Let’s call them artists.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

text: A glimpse at what gals wore to the Milan Furniture Fair.

headline: Samsung Executive Says Marketing Drove Phone Sales to No. 1
text: SAN JOSE, Calif — Becoming the world leader in the mobile handset market was no easy task. Or at least that was the point Samsung tried to make Monday in its patent trial against Apple.

headline: Finding Fresh Poetry in the Familiar
text: Setting out to attend a prominent concert by a performer of documented substance and renown, you might assume that everything you will hear is similarly significant. But should this necessarily be the case? On Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, Stephen Hough, a pianist consistently thoughtful about the works he presents, offered an alternate notion. His recital included three pieces that might fairly be termed trivial, yet, in context, those works held valid interest.

headline: Interest Rates and the Budget Outlook
text: The CBO has issued its latest budget update, and as always it’s a very careful piece of work. But there is one thing really worth drawing attention to — not that the CBO is necessarily wrong, but it might be, and at any rate people should be aware of what’s driving the conclusions.

headline: A Pulitzer Today,  and  in May, a New York Premiere
text: John Luther Adams, who was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for music on Monday for his work “Become Ocean,” has a special reason to look forward to its New York premiere next month at Carnegie Hall: he has yet to hear it performed live.

text: Ambassadors from the United States, Britain and France all told the United Nations Security Council on Sunday night that video evidence posted online — showing well-armed insurgents seizing police stations in eastern Ukraine — contradicts Russian claims that peaceful protesters in the region are under threat from government forces.

text: For Elizabeth Williams, who has spent more than three decades depicting famous criminals through her drawings, the job of courtroom illustrator is a study of character.
