text: New York City F.C., a team that will enter Major League Soccer next year, will play its first three seasons at Yankee Stadium, according to two people familiar with the team’s plans.

headline: Storefront, Airbnb for Retail Spaces, Raises $7.3 Million
text: Sometimes copying the concept of a start-up and changing the idea slightly can lead to astoundingly unoriginal companies.

headline: Carriages Belong in Central Park
text: DURING his run for mayor, Bill de Blasio pledged to eradicate the Central Park horse-drawn carriage business. He called the industry inhumane, and proposed to replace the retired horses with electric-powered replicas of vintage cabs. Since taking office, he has not agreed to meet with the operators or hear their views. In a Google Hangout on Friday, the mayor affirmed his commitment to a ban: “We expect action on it this year.”

headline: After Fire, Picturesque Hills of Chilean Port City Are Left in Ruin
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Two days after wind-borne flames ravaged the steep hills surrounding Valparaíso, many slopes of colorful houses that gave the slender port city a picture-postcard landscape have been reduced to rings of ruins.

headline: The Oldest Hatred, Forever Young
text: Most of the hate crimes in the United States don’t take the fatal form that the shootings in Kansas over the weekend did, and most aren’t perpetrated by villains as bloated with rage and blinded by conspiracy theories as the person accused in this case, Frazier Glenn Miller. He’s an extreme, not an emblem.

headline: Voice of Soccer Calls the Action Well Off the Field
text: THE World Cup in Brazil was eight months away when a small group of ESPN marketers gathered last October to decide how to promote Ian Darke, the media giant’s lead announcer for the event.

headline: China’s Actions in Hunt for Jet Are Seen as Hurting as Much as Helping
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — When a Chinese government vessel took the world by surprise this month with its announcement that it had detected underwater signals that might have come from the missing Malaysia Airlines plane, China suddenly looked like the hero of the multinational search effort.

headline: The Book That Didn’t Exist
text: Seventeen years ago I wrote a book, which you can find on Amazon and Google and elsewhere online. This is unusual only because my book was never published. It’s called “Goths,” fitting for a title that has left its traces on the Internet but does not exist. The traces themselves are ghostly. Other than the title, Amazon lists only the publisher (Random House Trade), language (English) and ISBNs (one with 10 digits, the other with 13). Google goes further by giving the publication date (March 1, 1998) and promising a cover image — but it turns out to be a placeholder. And unlike Amazon, Google neglects to mention that the book is a hardcover. Google admits, “We haven’t found any reviews in the usual places,” which in this case would be the planet Earth. “Be the first to review this item,” Amazon encourages, but has as yet found no takers.

headline: Immigrants Stir New Life Into São Paulo’s Gritty Old Center
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For obvious reasons, many Paulistanos still consider this megacity’s decrepit old center a no-go zone.

headline: The Deadly Cost of Fashion
text: A photojournalist who covered last year’s deadly collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh draws connections to New York from clothing labels he found in the rubble.

headline: Israeli Officer Killed on Way to Seder in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli police officer was fatally shot and his wife and young son were wounded Monday evening as they drove to a Passover Seder near the West Bank city of Hebron, according to a spokeswoman for the Israeli military.

headline: ‘The Deadly Cost of Fashion’
text: Last April 24, Ismail Ferdous, my co-director on this Op-Doc video, photographed the deadliest disaster in garment industry history: the collapse of Rana Plaza in Bangladesh, which killed more than 1,100 workers and injured around 2,500.

headline: Family of Shooting Victims Speaks Out
text: Mindy Corporon and Will Corporon spoke after their family members were killed on Sunday at the Jewish Community Center in Kansas.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe Remains a Draw on Broadway
text: Daniel Radcliffe’s star power on Broadway remains intact. After helping generate million-dollar weekly grosses as the leading man in the 2011 revival “How to Succeed In Business Without Really Trying,” Mr. Radcliffe – best known as the eponymous boy wizard in the “Harry Potter” movies – returned to Broadway last week as the title character in Martin McDonagh’s 1996 dark comedy, “The Cripple of Inishmaan.” For its first two preview performances, “Inishmaan” grossed $155,234 – or 95 percent of the maximum possible amount, with nearly every seat sold.

headline: Phyllis Frelich, Tony-Winning Actress and Deaf Activist, Dies at 70
text: Phyllis Frelich, the actress who made a groundbreaking and Tony-winning Broadway star turn in 1980 in “Children of a Lesser God,” Mark Medoff’s play — written with her and her husband’s help — about the courtship and marriage of a deaf woman and a man who can hear, died on Thursday at her home in Temple City, Calif., near Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: 2 Pakistanis Suspected of Cannibalism After Head Is Found
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — In a macabre case that has transfixed and horrified Pakistanis, the police on Monday arrested a man suspected of cannibalism after they found an infant’s head at his home.

headline: Utah Garage Cleaning Turns Up Boxes of Suffocated Infants
text: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah — The infants were found in cardboard boxes, each one rolled up in a shirt or towel and tucked into a plastic bag. One had been stillborn, their mother, Megan Huntsman, told the police. The other six, she said, she had strangled or smothered immediately after giving birth, and interred them in the garage of her family’s brick home here.

headline: Canada’s Lonely Standard-Bearers in the N.H.L. Playoffs
text: MONTREAL — Perhaps it is just a random quirk of probability, but the numbers are eye-opening nonetheless. For the first time since 1973, only one Canadian team — the Montreal Canadiens, fittingly — qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs, which begin Wednesday. Six of the seven Canadian teams will not play in the postseason, while 15 of the 23 teams based in the United States will.

headline: U.S. Halts Effort to Collect Old Social Security Debts
text: WASHINGTON — The Social Security Administration said Monday that it would stop trying to collect taxpayers’ debts that were more than 10 years old.

headline: Appeal to Return 4 to Death Row Is Heard
text: The North Carolina Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments about whether it should reinstate death sentences for four inmates whose punishments were reduced under a law that allowed certain criminal defendants to challenge their sentences by raising claims of racial bias in their prosecutions.

headline: 2 Executives Leave G.M. After Wide-Ranging Recall
text: DETROIT — In the first major shake-up of General Motors’ senior management since the company announced a wide-ranging recall in February, its chief spokesman and head Washington adviser, and its top human resources executive have left the company.

headline: Iran: U.N. Is Asked to Resolve Envoy’s Visa Dispute
text: Iran on Monday said it had complained to the United Nations over the refusal by the United States to grant a visa to its choice for ambassador, Hamid Aboutalebi, a career diplomat who once worked as an interpreter for the revolutionary group that seized the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979. The deputy foreign minister for European-American affairs, Majid Takht-e Ravanchi, was quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency as saying that Iran had asked the Committee on Relations with the Host Country to examine the issue and that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon should intervene if necessary. But United Nations officials said that neither Mr. Ban’s office nor the committee had yet received any written complaint from Tehran or its United Nations mission. An official at the mission of Cyprus, which currently leads the committee, said that after it received a written complaint it could take up the issue at its next, yet-to-be-scheduled quarterly meeting. The committee can only make recommendations.

headline: Mexico: Homicides Decline Near Border, Report Says
text: Murders in Mexico declined in 2013, and they decreased significantly in several cities near the border with the United States, according to a new report from the Justice in Mexico Project at the University of San Diego to be released Tuesday. Using preliminary police data, researchers identified a homicide decrease of about 16 percent, with some of the biggest drops in murders in Ciudad Juárez and Monterrey, notoriously dangerous cities that have recently calmed down as the war between criminal gangs and the government has declined in intensity. Still, experts warn, it is not clear whether the decline is attributable to an overall weakening of organized crime: The number of gun-related murders has held steady as other kinds of killing have declined, and homicides have sharply risen in states farther south. Extortion and kidnapping have also increased nationwide. But with overall murder rates down for the second year in a row from their 2011 peak, some parts of Mexico appear to be on the mend, said David A. Shirk, an author of the report. “The decrease in violence that the government in Mexico is trying to convince people of is in fact real,” he said.

headline: Specialists Join Call for Veto of Drug Bill
text: Women’s rights and medical groups have called on Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee to veto legislation that would allow criminal assault charges to be filed against women who use illegal drugs during pregnancy. Critics say the measure will harm babies because pregnant women will be afraid to seek medical care.

headline: With Ukraine Tensions Mounting, U.S. Weighs New Sanctions Against Russia
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday against further disruption of eastern Ukraine even as the United States and Europe prepared to expand sanctions against leading Russian figures in the next few days.

headline: Looking at Some Corporate Tax Loopholes Ordinary Citizens May Envy
text: It’s Tax Day.

headline: Phelps Is Back, and at His Age, Why Not?
text: Despite vows to the contrary, Michael Phelps, the most prolific medal winner in Olympic history, will return to competitive swimming after all.

headline: C.E.O. Pay Goes Up, Up and Away!
text: At 79, Graef “Bud” Crystal is the grand old man of executive compensation critics. Once a top compensation consultant, he switched sides in the 1980s, becoming a fierce critic of many of the practices he helped institutionalize, and analyzing executive pay for other media like Fortune and, most recently, Bloomberg News. He’s been known to call his second career “atoning for my sins.”

headline: Zander Hollander, Sports Trivia Shepherd, Dies at 91
text: Zander Hollander, a journeyman journalist who rebounded from the merger of his newspaper in the mid-1960s by becoming what Sports Illustrated called “the unofficial king of sports paperbacks” — particularly a once wildly popular series of encyclopedic yearbooks — died on Friday in a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Marathon Bombing Suspect Waits in Isolation
text: He cannot mingle, speak or pray with other prisoners. His only visitors are his legal team, a mental health consultant and his immediate family, who apparently have seen him only rarely.

headline: A Long Obedience
text: Monday night was the start of Passover, the period when Jews celebrate the liberation of the Israelites from slavery into freedom.

headline: In the Middle East, Time to Move On
text: The pointless arguing over who brought Israeli-Palestinian peace talks to the brink of collapse is in full swing. The United States is still working to salvage the negotiations, but there is scant sign of serious purpose. It is time for the administration to lay down the principles it believes must undergird a two-state solution, should Israelis and Palestinians ever decide to make peace. Then President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry should move on and devote their attention to other major international challenges like Ukraine.

headline: Red-Hot Brewers Win by Swinging Freely, Always
text: MILWAUKEE — No team in the major leagues swings as aggressively as the Milwaukee Brewers. No team in the major leagues has as many victories, either. The Brewers believe these facts are related.

headline: Political Rifts Slow U.S. Effort on Climate Laws
text: WASHINGTON — The United States needs to enact a major climate change law, such as a tax on carbon pollution, by the end of this decade to stave off the most catastrophic impacts of global warming, according to the authors of a report released this week by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

headline: In Ukraine’s East, Russians Are Blending Right In
text: HORLIVKA, Ukraine — In a video posted online Monday, a man wearing an unmarked green uniform calls to attention a squad of Ukrainian policemen who have just switched over to the pro-Russian side in this eastern Ukrainian town.

headline: Gefilte Fish Is Scarce This Passover. Taste Buds Are Ambivalent.
text: Erik Antes spent most of Sunday, the day before the start of Passover, on the phone behind the counter at BenZ’s Gourmet in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, fielding frantic phone calls.

headline: Batter’s Reward
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Batter up! Gary Cee is back, and he, like many sports fans, is dreaming about baseball. Today, Mr. Cee is going to make sure that we get on base by any means necessary, even if it means walking us.

headline: Unmet Promise on Discrimination
text: President Obama has made repeated use of executive orders to advance the administration’s goals when Republicans in Congress refused to act. Last week, he signed two orders requiring modest but important steps by federal contractors to narrow the wage gap between female and male employees.

headline: Apparent Hate Crime Aimed at Jews Instead Strikes Christians
text: William L. Corporon was a longtime family doctor, but to his family, he was Popeye, a nickname bestowed by a grandson, Reat Underwood.

headline: A Deadline for Grandfathered Weapons
text: Weeks after a demented gunman killed 20 children and six adults in a Newtown, Conn., school, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York legislators passed the SAFE Act, a strong gun-control law that included a broad ban on semiautomatic assault weapons. Those who already owned such weapons could keep them if they agreed to register the guns with State Police by midnight Tuesday.

headline: Preventing Painkiller Overdoses
text: The Food and Drug Administration earlier this month approved a hand-held device that can quickly reverse the effects of an overdose and prevent deaths from opioid painkillers and heroin. The easy-to-use injector delivers a dose of the drug naloxone, a treatment that is typically delivered in hospitals but can now be used by family members or emergency responders at the scene of an overdose.

headline: Schimmel Brings Flair and Pride in Heritage to W.N.B.A.
text: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — On Monday afternoon, Shoni Schimmel, a member of the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla in eastern Oregon, sat inside the lobby of the Mohegan Sun hotel, surrounded by Native American-inspired décor and steps away from a souvenir shop selling dream catchers.

headline: DNA and Insurance, Fate and Risk
text: Should insurers be barred from seeing genetic tests for life, disability and long-term care coverage, so people can be tested without fear that the results would be used against them?

headline: Florida Lawmakers Proposing a Salve for Ailing Springs
text: CHIEFLAND, Fla. — To the untrained eye, Manatee Springs is an idyllic refuge in Central Florida: The cool water is so clear in parts that the sand glistens like polished aluminum. A vast series of underwater caves beckons thousands of divers. Deer wander by as do manatees, turtles, owls. Eagles soar overhead.

headline: Yankees’ McCann Cleared by X-Ray
text: The Yankees reported mixed results from the medical tests performed on two players  Monday.

headline: Testimony From Britain May Be Used in Terror Trial
text: A key government witness in the terrorism trial of a radical Islamic cleric may testify from Britain via a closed circuit television connection, a federal judge in Manhattan said in a ruling released on Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 15, 2014
text: “It’s the Jewish madeleine. It’s that food that has the ability to transport you in time and connect you to your lineage.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 14, 2014
text: April 14, 2014

headline: Maple Leafs Turn to Shanahan to Give Team Identity
text: TORONTO — Brendan Shanahan won three Stanley Cups and an Olympic gold medal during his playing days, and the Maple Leafs hope that winning culture will transcend to a club that collapsed late in the season.

headline: Don’t Skimp on Legal Training
In the Bronx, Supporters Go Against Rep. Rangel
text: State Senator Adriano Espaillat picked up a number of important endorsements on Monday in his second attempt to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel, the 22-term Harlem Democrat, gaining the support of the Bronx borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr., and several other members of the Bronx Democratic establishment.

headline: Publicizing of Veterinary Files Is Urged for Triple Crown Events
text: The chairman of the Jockey Club, one of horse racing’s most influential groups, called Monday for the veterinary records of every horse competing in this year’s Triple Crown races to be made public immediately. He said the goal was to ensure that the horses were sound and not under the influence of unnecessary drugs and that the races were run safely and fairly.

headline: Fourth of July Fireworks Show Will Move Back to East River
text: In the half-hour on the Fourth of July when the electrifying palette of fireworks dances and dazzles across the night sky, Lisa Ricca said that the familiar mantra of real estate — location, location, location — applied to her apartment complex in Weehawken, N.J., and not because she is a sales agent who has brokered deals for at least 50 units there.

headline: Corrections: April 15, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets’ Record Is Better Than Play Has Been
text: PHOENIX — The schedule was not kind to the Mets over the first two weeks of the season. They faced the Washington Nationals, the Cincinnati Reds, the Atlanta Braves and the Los Angeles Angels, four teams that are considered contenders. Four teams with more star power than the Mets had, all with higher payrolls. These were teams built to win now, unlike the Mets.

headline: Bystander, 13, Shot in Brooklyn
text: A 13-year-old boy was shot twice in the head on Monday in Brooklyn, apparently a bystander in a dispute between two men, the police said.

headline: Worker Dies After Falling From Building
text: A construction worker died on Monday after he fell onto scaffolding at an office building near Pennsylvania Station in Midtown Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Landlords to Repay Over $1 Million in Fees
text: Ben Warren, a retired theatrical prop designer, had lived in his Bronx tenement for more than 30 years when the building changed owners in 2007. Soon, heat and hot water became sporadic, repairs went undone and tenants started being harassed.

headline: Pulling Tricks From Everyone’s Sleeves
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio can swell with enthusiasm for people and movements and moments progressive.

headline: Officer Testifies About Encounter With Occupy Wall Street Protester
text: It was St. Patrick’s Day 2012, and after spending his afternoon looking for intoxicated people at Pennsylvania Station, Officer Grantley Bovell was deployed to Lower Manhattan to help clear Zuccotti Park of scores of protesters who had gathered to mark the six-month anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: Inmate Gets Life in Prison for Plotting to Behead a Judge and a Prosecutor
text: Joseph Romano seemed like just another post-recession white-collar criminal when he went to jail for fraud two years ago — a Long Island man with a wife and three children, a volunteer at his children’s school, a Navy veteran who liked vintage cars and had gotten too greedy.

headline: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find
text: Even as the cost of prescription drugs has plummeted for many Americans, a small slice of the population is being asked to shoulder more and more of the cost of expensive treatments for diseases like cancer and hepatitis C, according to a report to be released on Tuesday by a major drug research firm.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) CELEBRITY WIFE SWAP  Isabella Hofmann, the former girlfriend of the actor Daniel Baldwin, trades places with Halima Rashid, the wife of the musician Jermaine Jackson (above right with Ms. Rashid) in this Season 3 opener. After struggling with drug addiction for a decade, Mr. Baldwin is sober and trying to rebuild his relationship with Ms. Hofmann, who lives in a modest home in the Hollywood Hills area of Los Angeles with their autistic son, Atticus (above left with Mr. Baldwin and Ms. Hofmann). Ms. Rashid, meanwhile, lives in a grand estate with plenty of room for her racks of clothing and shoes, as well as the couple’s show dog, Fiji. Despite the differences in their lifestyles, the women seem to welcome the change. The men? Not so much.

headline: India Election Digest: April 15
text: What you need to know on Tuesday about India’s elections: A group dedicated to stamping out superstition challenges fortune tellers to predict the outcome of the elections, the daughter of Prime Minister Manmohan Singh expresses anger at the publication of a memoir by a former aide to the prime minister, and a former Coal Ministry official writes a memoir about his time in the government.

headline: Adding Design to His Business Duties
text: Cali, Colombia’s third largest city, has overcome much of its reputation as a violent place overrun with crime and drug cartels. But it still surprises many to learn it is the home of a luxury accessories brand with a new men’s line.

headline: Mets’ Win Does Not Come Without Its Costs
text: PHOENIX — Juan Lagares and Curtis Granderson had started the season on opposite paths. Lagares was the young, exciting center fielder who was finally hitting enough to make a case to play every day. Granderson was the newly acquired, highly paid veteran who was in a slump.

headline: Times Minute | Boston Bombing Tribute
text: The national correspondent Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston ahead of events to commemorate the anniversary of the marathon bombing.

headline: Times Minute | Boston Bombing Tribute
text: In the Video

headline: The Death That Kindled the Uprising at Tiananmen Square
text: Updated, 3:57 a.m.ET| Rarely has the timing of an ousted leader’s death been so consequential. In 1989, Hu Yaobang, a former general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, was attending a meeting of the Politburo when he became pale and shaky, asked to be excused and crumpled with a heart attack. Twenty-five years ago, on April 15, he died after a week in the hospital, an event that unleashed a cascade of demonstrations centered on Tiananmen Square, which culminated in the armed crackdown of June 3-4.

headline: Expatriate Indians Return Home to Have Their Say
text: Sajid Aboobacker, 35, flew to Kozhikode, in the southern state of Kerala, from Dubai on a chartered flight on April 7 with 145 other Indians, desperate for their voices to be heard in a historic Indian parliamentary election that could see the triumph of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its prime ministerial candidate, Narendra Modi.

headline: Submersible’s First Scan for Jet Wreckage Is Cut Short
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has moved to the dark depths of the Indian Ocean with the first deployment of an unmanned submersible to scan the seabed for signs of wreckage, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Reading Valentine’s Card, Pistorius Leaves the Stand
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — It took just nine minutes on Tuesday for Oscar Pistorius’s defense lawyer to release him from anguished days and hours on the stand, and he did so with a last, loving message from the woman he is accused of murdering.

headline: Hong Kong I.P.O. Structure Is Fine as Is, Investor Survey Finds
text: HONG KONG — Hong Kong may have lost Alibaba’s giant initial public offering to the United States, but for some large investors in this Asian financial hub, that’s just fine.

headline: From Ordinary Life, Extraordinary Images
text: Chang Chao-Tang was a high school student in 1959 when he borrowed his older brother’s Aires Automat 120 twin-lens reflex camera without much thought. He liked going for long walks with the camera after school; it eased the burden of his homework. Eventually, he found himself taking photos with the camera every day, photos of common people and places in Taiwan, like youngsters poking out of street corners or at beaches, farm animals, and dolls.

headline: Tracy Morgan: ‘You Got to Watch What You Say’
text: The comedian Tracy Morgan talks to Dave Itzkoff about his return to stand-up, reflects on the limits of free speech and offers some advice to his former “30 Rock” colleague Alec Baldwin.

headline: Chinese Military Newspaper Likens Lost Jet to Pearl Harbor
text: Throughout the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, commentators have groped for analogies to convey the enigma of how a Boeing 777-200 could disappear without a trace. China’s official military newspaper, the Liberation Army Daily, may well be the first to liken the aircraft’s loss to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

headline: Tribute and Mourning Year After Boston Bombings
text: BOSTON — It may be one of the biggest cities in the country, but Boston was a small town on Tuesday as it mourned the losses it suffered in carnage a year ago and honored the sense of community that emerged from the ashes.

headline: Norway Returns a Rare Silent Film to China
text: Updated, 5:55 a.m.ET | In a gesture that could help ease relations between Norway and China, strained since the awarding of the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize to the imprisoned democracy advocate Liu Xiaobo, the National Library of Norway has returned a long-lost Chinese silent film.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Recognizes 3rd Gender
text: Updated, 10:29 p.m. | NEW DELHI — In a landmark ruling on Tuesday, the Supreme Court of India allowed transgender people to identify as a third gender and directed the central and state governments to give full legal recognition to them.

headline: New York Today: Tax Day Ritual Recedes
text: Good soggy Tuesday to you.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: The Mazda Miata Turns 25
text: Tom Voelk, who produces the Times’s video reviews, reveals what’s in his garage: a first edition Mazda Miata. Here’s his personal take on how the car was received when it hit the market 25 years ago.

headline: A 25-Year Affair With a Mazda Miata, Still Going Strong
text: A lot of now-significant pop culture appeared in 1989: Nintendo gave the world the Game Boy; “The Seinfeld Chronicles” were first broadcast on NBC (and yes, they quickly renamed it); Mazda rolled out what has become, for many, the most popular sports car ever produced, the 1990 MX-5 Miata.

headline: Animal Rights Group to Turn Bear-Bile Farm Into Sanctuary
text: A state-owned company that raises bears to extract bile for use in traditional Chinese medicine says it will hand over 130 bears to an animal rights group, and the farm where they were raised will be turned into a rehab center. The move marks a major success in the campaign to end the practice of bear-bile farming, which animal rights campaigners call cruel and abusive.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Makes Lonely Defense of G.M.
text: Updated, 5:42 p.m. |

headline: In Annual Letter, BlackRock Chief Says Firm Will Keep Speaking Out
text: Over the last 26 years, BlackRock has become one of the biggest investment managers around, with more than $4 trillion under management.

headline: A Non-Techie Tries to Build a Tech Company
text: As a non-techie, I was daunted by the task of starting a technology company, Posse. I had an ambitious idea to build a social network that connects customers and retailers but I didn’t know what a line of code looked like, let alone what language we should use or how to tell a good engineer from a bad one. Like many entrepreneurs, I had a vision but no clue how to execute it.

headline: Motorola Solutions to Sell Enterprise Business for $3.5 Billion
text: Updated, 10:14 a.m. |

headline: F.B.I. Video Warns of Efforts to Recruit American Students as Spies
text: The United States government has released a 28-minute video about the case of Glenn Duffie Shriver, an American who took money from Chinese intelligence officers while living in Shanghai and was convicted of trying to acquire United States defense secrets for them.

headline: European Parliament Approves Laws on Banking Overhaul
text: BRUSSELS — After countless late-night meetings and political skirmishes, the European Union on Tuesday put in place the final pieces of a landmark plan for managing a banking system whose troubles have done so much to dent the bloc’s economy.

headline: Daily Report: Etsy Seeks Wholesaler’s Role in Handicraft Sales
text: Etsy, the popular e-commerce site for handmade, vintage and other artisan items, now has over a million sellers of goods, and the company says it generated $1.35 billion in sales last year. Still, although Internet retailing is a growing market, more than 90 percent of retail commerce still takes place in physical stores, and like many retailers that started online, Etsy wants a piece of that action. Instead of opening locations, Elizabeth A. Harris reports, Etsy wants its sellers to take wholesale orders, so that through them, Etsy can be in thousands of stores at once without ever cutting a rent check.

headline: Ukraine Sends Force to Stem Unrest in East
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military landed airborne troops at an airport about 25 miles south of here on Tuesday, raising tensions with Russia in the opening phase of what the government in Kiev called a wider military operation to confront pro-Russian militants in the eastern part of the country.

headline: In Performance: Adrian Lester of ‘Red Velvet’
text: This week’s video features Adrian Lester in a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s “Red Velvet,” a drama about the 19th-century African-American actor Ira Aldridge. In this scene Mr. Lester, who plays Aldridge, reflects on a painful incident that happened during his days as a young actor. The show, directed by Indhu Rubasingham, continues through April 20 at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: Save the Subjunctive!
text: Here’s the latest in my series of quixotic pleas on behalf of a dying verb mood.

headline: Fast Home Wireless: A Content Weapon?
text: Consumers will ultimately choose the winners in the competition among cable companies, television networks, tech giants and others to supply our digital entertainment. We may do it, however, in a way we don’t expect: by the speed of our home networks.

headline: Adding a Religious Holidays Calendar
text: Q. Is there any add-on or overlay to add a comprehensive Jewish calendar to my Macintosh Calendar app on OS X 10.9 Mavericks? The current calendar offers a few religious holidays, but by no means all.

headline: Dreaming of Corporate Tax Breaks
text: A LOOK AT CORPORATE TAX LOOPHOLES  |  Individuals have long sought to take advantage of dozens of tax deductions and loopholes, but corporations have excelled at this game, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: 3 Former ICAP Brokers Appear in British Court in Libor Manipulation Case
text: Updated, 9:13 a.m. | LONDON – Three former brokers at the British financial firm ICAP appeared in court on Tuesday on charges that they conspired to manipulate a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: Desalination Plant Said to Be Planned for Thirsty Beijing
text: BEIJING — A coastal desalination plant planned for east of Beijing could provide a large portion of the drinking water for the parched Chinese capital by 2019, the state news media quoted officials as saying on Tuesday. The reports indicated that the government and state enterprises were investing heavily in desalination projects to alleviate a dire water shortage in northern China.

headline: Believe It or Not, a Skeptic’s Journey
text: There are many writers who I wish would declare, as Barbara Ehrenreich does at the start of her new book, “I will never write an autobiography.” But she is not among them.

headline: City University of New York Announces Dance Initiative
text: It won’t come as a shock to New York-based choreographers to learn that a 2010 report from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation cited “a critical need for affordable dance rehearsal space” in the city. But it might be a surprise to learn that the City University of New York has responded to that report with a new residency program, announced on Tuesday, that will provide rehearsal and performance space at the university’s campuses across the five boroughs.

headline: Troubled Italian Bank May Seek Larger Share Sale
text: PARIS — Shares of Monte dei Paschi di Siena fell sharply on Tuesday after a report that the troubled Italian bank was seeking to raise substantially more cash than investors had been expecting.

headline: President of Algeria Seeks Fourth Term
text: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, president of Algeria for 15 years, is running for another term despite his apparent frail health.

headline: The Decision: One Child, One School
text: Jon and I binge-read the emails. We had applied to nine preschools for our daughter, and the decisions rolled in: We were in, off earlier wait lists, on new wait lists, we got into the synagogue. (Phew!) One lottery school that rejected us right away invited us to start the entire process from the top. Not happening.

headline: Census Survey Revisions Mask Health Law Effects
text: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau, the authoritative source of health insurance data for more than three decades, is changing its annual survey so thoroughly that it will be difficult to measure the effects of President Obama’s health care law in the next report, due this fall, census officials said.

headline: Now Screening | Tribeca Premieres Documentary About Raf Simons’s Dior Debut
text: “With Raf, we had what you could call a reluctant protagonist,” says the director Frédéric Tcheng of Christian Dior’s artistic director of two years, Raf Simons. “He had always purposefully stayed away from the public eye.” In “Dior & I,” which premieres this week at the Tribeca Film Festival, Tcheng documents the creation of Simons’s first couture collection for the house in spring 2012. Having previously worked on fashion films like “Valentino: The Last Emperor” and “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel,” Tcheng was able to gain access to Simons’s famously cloistered world, documenting him as he studied Dior’s s archives, worked in his atelier and visited his childhood home.

headline: In Our Pages: April 16
text: 1939: Roosevelt Presses for Peace

headline: Diageo Makes New Bid for Controlling Stake in United Spirits of India
text: LONDON – Diageo said on Tuesday that it had made an offer of 1.13 billion pounds, or about $1.9 billion, to take a controlling stake in United Spirits of India.

headline: Which Books From Your Past Do You Read Now With Ambivalence?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Chang-rae Lee has said that rereading D. H. Lawrence feels “artistically inspiring,” but also “cringe-inducing.” This week, Adam Kirsch and Zoë Heller discuss the books from their past that they now read with ambivalence.

headline: Barclays Picks Former Bain & Co. Executive to Lead Compensation Committee
text: LONDON – Barclays said on Tuesday that it had chosen a former Bain & Company managing director to serve as the head of its compensation committee.

headline: The Read Around: Robert Coover
text: Robert Coover, whose latest novel is “The Brunist Day of Wrath,” says he feels most like a writer when working late into the night.

headline: Today in Small Business: Etsy Goes Wholesale
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments at Milan Design Week
text: Salone del Mobile, Milan’s annual design week, concluded Sunday. As is custom, the official Salone event — where the biggest furniture companies introduce their latest designs all under one roof, in one of the largest convention centers in the world — was punctuated with a series of special exhibitions called Fourisalone (meaning “outside salone”), put on by local showrooms, shops and museums. And this year, a few underlying themes unified the whole experience. For starters, everyone, it seems, played up the contrast between new and current designs against the historic backdrop of the city. At the center of it all was Rossana Orlandi’s much-talked-about exhibition of contemporary works at the Museo Bagatti Valsecchi, a 19th-century palazzo. “I wanted to create a dialogue between the new and the old,” Orlandi said about the show, “Untold.”

headline: U.N. Cites Abuses in Crimea Before Russia Annexation Vote
text: GENEVA — Amid fears of escalating violence in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations called on Tuesday for action to counter misinformation and hate speech used as propaganda and urged the authorities in Crimea to account for killings, torture and arbitrary arrests in the buildup to the March referendum that led to its annexation by Russia.

headline: Reopening of Picasso Museum in Paris Delayed Again
text: PARIS – The reopening of the Musée Picasso – closed for more than four years during a renovation and expansion – has been delayed yet again, a museum spokeswoman said Tuesday. Andréa Longrais, the spokeswoman, said no date had been set for its opening and declined to give an explanation for the delay. Since the Picasso museum is under the stewardship of the French government, the official date has to be determined by the Culture Ministry. The building site is all but ready, the lights for the art works are in place and except for a few minor technical items, everything is done, Ms. Longrais added.

headline: Video: Robert Coover Talks About ‘The Brunist Day of Wrath’
text: In “The Read Around,” authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Robert Coover discusses “The Brunist Day of Wrath,” a sequel to his 1966 novel “The Origin of the Brunists,” which introduced the fictional religious cult of the title.

headline: Rising Sun
text: Joe Romm draws our attention to the third slice of the latest IPCC report on climate change, on the costs of mitigation; the panel finds that these costs aren’t that big — a few percent of GDP even by the end of the century, which means only a trivial hit to the growth rate.

headline: How Working Women Help the Economy
text: If someone asked you to name the most important economic trends of the last 30 years, you would probably respond with rising inequality, increasing globalization and fast-paced technological change.

headline: Facebook Requires Users to Install Separate Messaging App
text: You’ve heard of shotgun weddings? Well, Facebook is imposing a shotgun upgrade on everyone who uses its mobile apps. But the company swears you’ll live happier ever after.

headline: Video and Social Media Posts on the Anniversary of the Boston Marathon Bombings
text: Updated, 3:13 p.m. On the first anniversary of the Boston Marathon bombings, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was among the officials speaking on Tuesday at a tribute for the victims and survivors, as my colleague Katharine Q. Seelye reports.

headline: Supply, Demand, and Unemployment Benefits
text: Ben Casselman points out that we’ve had a sort of natural experiment in the alleged effects of unemployment benefits in reducing employment. Extended benefits were cancelled at the beginning of this year; have the long-term unemployed shown any tendency to find jobs faster? And the answer is no.

headline: Italy Nominates Veteran as Chief of Eni
text: LONDON — Claudio Descalzi has served as a hard-working lieutenant to Paolo Scaroni, the chief executive of the Italian oil giant Eni, for years. Now the Italian government, which has a controlling stake in the company, has chosen Mr. Descalzi to succeed Mr. Scaroni.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 58
text: After celebrating his 28th birthday April 10, Fernando Gago’s world — make that his World Cup — crumbled.

headline: The Young: Lost and Alienated
text: Flailing youth befuddled and intimidated by a forbiddingly complex world is a theme that seeps into the bloodstream of this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, which begins its 13th edition on Wednesday in Lower Manhattan theaters.

headline: Times Minute | Kiev’s Military Operation

headline: Facts & Figures: A Cheaper ‘Obamacare’

headline: Finnish Stamps to Honor Noted Erotic Illustrator
text: In the fall, the Finnish postal service will release a new set of stamps, including evocative photos of Finnish bridges, pastel-hued garden scenes and – oh, yes – sleek sado-masochistic drawings with abundant amounts of beefy male nudity.

headline: Peter Baker on U.S. Strategy With Russia
text: Peter Baker, The Times’s chief White House correspondent, discusses the Obama administration’s use of diplomacy with Russia in trying to resolve the crisis in Ukraine.

headline: Taking No-Kill Approach With Feral Cat Population
text: It was nearly 3 a.m. and her target still had not fallen for the trap. Stephanie Seiler was sitting in a 22-year-old pickup truck on a Brooklyn street. She knew he would be back, so she opened a bottle of wine and settled in to the 12th hour of her stakeout.

headline: Afghanistan Says NATO Airstrike in East Killed Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials said that a NATO airstrike in eastern Afghanistan killed a woman and two children on Tuesday, again raising the issue of civilian casualties at a time when both the presidential election and the future of the Western troop presence are unresolved.

headline: Moments From Pistorius’s Time on Stand
text: Dramatic moments from Oscar Pistorius’s seven days of testimony in his murder trial.

headline: Obama Commutes a Prisoner’s Sentence, Lengthened More Than 3 Years by a Typo
text: WASHINGTON — Ceasar Huerta Cantu did not discover the mistake until he had already spent six years behind bars. His lawyer had missed it. The judge did not notice. But studying a report he was not supposed to have, the federal inmate noticed something was wrong.

headline: Joan Jonas to Represent United States at 2015 Venice Biennale
text: Joan Jonas, a pioneering figure in performance and video art, has been chosen to represent the United States at the 2015 Venice Biennale.

headline: Finishing One Race and Starting Another
text: A year ago, John Eligon, a Midwest correspondent, ran the Boston Marathon and then covered the aftermath of the bombings at the race’s finish line. He plans to run again this year.

headline: Wheelies: The Molto Bello Bonus Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Case Against Higher Taxes
text: Because it’s tax day, because he mentions me and because I’m easily provoked, below the quote you’ll find three rejoinders to Jonathan Cohn’s admirably forthright argument that American society would be much better off if most of us were writing larger considerably larger checks to Uncle Sam:

headline: Gallery | Inside the Homes and Studios of the World’s Finest Designers
text: The photographer Leslie Williamson’s new book, “Modern Originals: At Home With Midcentury European Designers,” out from Rizzoli today, offers an intimate look at the homes and studios of some of Europe’s best known designers, including Le Corbusier, Alvar Aalto, Carlo Mollino, Gae Aulenti and Finn Juhl, alongside lesser known names like Roland Rainer, Joseph Nemec and Renaat Braem. It follows Williamson’s first book, “Handcrafted Modern: At Home With Midcentury Designers” (Rizzoli, 2010). Both titles are part of a larger project Williamson began almost 10 years ago. “I made a dream list of the homes of all the architects and designers I wanted to visit in my lifetime,” she explains. “I’ve always been a fan of design, and I was curious to see how these people — whose work I love and am inspired by — lived themselves.”

headline: Image of the Day: April 15
text: An artist from Bangalore, Karnataka urges people to vote in the ongoing parliamentary elections in India.

headline: Linklater’s ‘Boyhood’ to Open BAMcinemaFest
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced Tuesday that its sixth annual BAMcinemaFest, which will run from June 18-29, will open with Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood,” a film that has been receiving considerable praise on the festival circuit.

headline: Chevrolet Corvette Z06 Convertible: A New V8 Engine Roars Inside
text: What is it? The droptop version of Chevrolet’s extremely powerful Corvette Z06.

headline: Twitter Acquires Gnip, Bringing a Valuable Data Service In-House
text: Updated | Added the announcement of Twitter’s new vice president of consumer product.

headline: ABC’s Nightly News Scores a Rare Ratings Win Over NBC’s
text: ABC News broke a winning streak for NBC News last week, though not an exorbitantly long one, as it once did in morning television.

headline: Intersection: Doha’s Souq Style
text: At the bustling Souq Waqif in Doha, Qatar, Fahad Al Obaidly, a fashion designer, likes to wear traditional garments then add a modern twist.

headline: Editor With a String of Hits Is Joining Little, Brown
text: Little, Brown and Company announced Tuesday that Lee Boudreaux, a widely admired editor and the editorial director of Ecco, a division of HarperCollins, for the last nine years, has been named vice president and editorial director of her own imprint, which will bear her name and publish 8 to 10 titles a year.

headline: Iraq Shuts Down the Abu Ghraib Prison, Citing Security Concerns
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi government said Tuesday that it had closed the Abu Ghraib prison, the site of a notorious prisoner abuse scandal during the American occupation of Iraq, because of fears that it could be overrun by Sunni insurgents who have gained strength over the last year.

headline: Capital Murder Among Charges for Suspect in Kansas Shooting
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — State prosecutors on Tuesday charged a 73-year-old white supremacist with murder in the killing of three people outside two Jewish community facilities on Sunday.

headline: What’s the Point of the Pulitzers?
text: Do the Pulitzer Prizes still matter? Do they stand for anything except journalistic self-congratulation? The question comes up every year around this time.

headline: Suspect Charged in Kansas Shootings
text: Steve Howe, the district attorney for Johnson County, Kan., announced that prosecutors had filed murder charges against the white supremacist accused of fatally shooting three people.

headline: Not All Investigations Are Alike
text: Say a company finds out that it is under investigation for possible criminal violations. Its challenge is to figure out the chances that the investigation will result in charges and the possible impact of those charges on its business. Not all investigations are alike, and there are telltale signs about how serious a threat one may present.

headline: Where Peter Chang Cooks, They Will Follow
text: SHORT PUMP, VA. — Peter Chang was in the house.

headline: One Person, One Vote? Maybe One Day
text: President Obama said on Friday that he would make voting rights a priority. But given that Congress can barely get around to naming post offices anymore, D.C.-led progress seems unlikely.

headline: On Tax Day: What’s Fair?
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: HotelTonight Goes Beyond the Last Minute
text: HotelTonight, the popular mobile application for booking last-minute hotel rooms, is now helping travelers to plan further in advance.

headline: Derick Brassard Leaves Rangers Practice With Back Injury
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Center Derick Brassard left practice clutching his lower back Tuesday as the Rangers began preparations for their first-round playoff series against the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: After Rainout, Doubleheader for Yankees
text: The Yankees have high hopes that their two youngest starting pitchers, Masahiro Tanaka and Michael Pineda, will lead their rotation into the future, and both will be on display Wednesday in what could be a captivating day-night doubleheader.

headline: Land Rover Discovery Vision Concept: An Intrepid Rollout
text: With New York preparing for its annual auto show, Land Rover chose a grand stage Monday night – the deck of the Intrepid museum in the Hudson River in Manhattan – to unveil its Discovery Vision Concept S.U.V.

headline: Listen Up | Coachella Newcomer Courtney Barnett on Playing ‘Slacker Rock’ and Life in the Fast Lane
text: Speaking before last weekend’s edition of Coachella, Courtney Barnett sounded wiped out. The 26-year-old Australian songwriter, who specializes in a lackadaisical style of slide-guitar music which she has described as “slacker-rock,” had just disembarked in Los Angeles after a 16-hour flight from Melbourne, her hometown, en route to Coachella, her first-ever major festival date. “It’s kind of terrifying, but I haven’t processed it,” she said of her appearance in Indio, which she’ll reprise next Sunday during the festival’s second weekend.

headline: South Williamsburg: Catching Up to the North Side
text: New Yorkers love to debate about which is better. The Nets or the Knicks? This restaurant or that one? Subways or cabs?

headline: Iran Escalates Dispute Over U.N. Envoy
text: UNITED NATIONS — Iran’s increasingly angry protests over the American decision to not grant a visa to its new United Nations ambassador, and the uncertainty over how far the dispute will go, have not only rubbed feelings on both sides raw. They have laid bare the limits of global law when its provisions clash with the interests of the host country, the United States.

headline: Pension Deal Edges Detroit a Step Closer to Recovery
text: Detroit’s pension boards and a retirees’ group say they have reached tentative agreements with the city that could serve as a breakthrough in its quest to settle with its major creditors and propel itself out of bankruptcy before the end of the year.

headline: After Prank by Dutch Girl on Twitter, Real Trouble
text: PARIS — Youthful pranks in the age of Twitter are no laughing matter, especially if you are a 14-year-old Dutch girl impersonating a terrorist.

headline: The Gun Report: April 15, 2014
text: Last week, the Florida House passed a bill that would allow people to carry concealed guns without permits during natural disasters and emergency evacuations. The bill was pushed by the N.R.A., whose lobbyist, Marion Hammer, came down hard on the governor’s office for failing to carry water for the organization.

headline: Blaming the Messengers, Euro Edition

headline: Neil Young’s Digital Music Project Raises $6.2 Million Online
text: PonoMusic, the high-definition digital audio business from Neil Young, has raised $6.2 million on Kickstarter, making it that crowdfunding platform’s third-most successful project.

headline: In Boston, Hope and Reflection
text: Officials and survivors of the Boston bombings gathered for a memorial service to commemorate the first anniversary of the attack at the marathon that killed three people and injured hundreds.

headline: Italian Premier Appoints Women to Lead 3 Major Company Boards
text: ROME — Underscoring his stated ambition to shake up Italy and enact social and economic reforms, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi proposed this week that women lead the boards of three of Italy’s largest state-controlled companies: an oil giant, the largest public utility and the postal service.

headline: A Green Group Sees Hope in ‘The End of China’s Coal Boom’
text: Through much of its history, Greenpeace has been big on what I call “woe is me, shame on you” messaging on the environment. As I explained at a TEDx event in Portland, Ore., over the weekend, fingerpointing (including Greenpeace’s) is appropriate in many instances, but doesn’t work well with human-driven global warming. The blame game too often ends up resembling a circular firing squad.

headline: Yahoo Earnings Offer a Peek at Alibaba’s Big Growth Ahead of Its I.P.O.
text: For some time, Yahoo earnings have been more than a report card for the company. They have also been a window into the earnings of its partner, the Chinese online commerce giant Alibaba Group.

headline: A Spicier N.H.L. Playoff Recipe
text: Under a new format this season, the N.H.L. playoffs are arranged by division, with no reseeding after each round, resembling an N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. Even though some teams face more difficult matchups than they would have under the previous format, the league got exactly what it wanted: matchups with plenty of spice and the renewal of some good rivalries.
