text: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.

headline: Bloomberg’s $50 Million Investment in Fear
text: Fourteen years ago, hundreds of thousands of women and their families rallied along the National Mall in the Million Mom March, demanding greater gun safety for their children and touching off a grass-roots political challenge to the National Rifle Association’s grip on Congress. Yet their campaign has only grown more difficult since then despite the steady, grisly flow of carnage.

headline: Korean Coast Guard Video of Ferry Rescue
text: As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, more than 280 passengers, most of them students, were still unaccounted for Wednesday night as coast guard and navy divers searched a ferry that sank hours earlier off the southwestern tip of South Korea.

headline: Terry Riley Music Among Highlights of River to River Festival
text: Music created and inspired by Terry Riley, the minimalist master, will be played at Federal Hall. The Trisha Brown Dance Company will perform on the East River waterfront.  The Haitian songwriter Bélo, who calls his music “Ragganga,” will play at the South Street Seaport.

headline: ‘Happy’ and ‘Frozen’ in Place at No. 1
text: Disney’s “Frozen” soundtrack is once again the No. 1 album in the country, with sales of 133,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Organize Photos on Your Phone
text: Molly Wood tests three apps, including the new Carousel by Dropbox, that help you sort and share the overwhelming number of photos on your mobile device.

headline: For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips
text: With sneakers slung around their shoulders and pockets full of cash, young boys huddle in hotel ballrooms and high school gyms, shouting and bartering as if they belong on a trading room floor.

headline: The Best Photo Organizing App? I’m Still Looking
text: I HAVE about 2,500 photos stored on my smartphone, and who knows how many more on previous phones and other devices I use. I need an organizing principle, stat.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: New York Via Park City or Berlin
text: The 13th edition of the Tribeca Film Festival gets under way on Wednesday with some 100 offerings to choose from. How is a film fan to decide?

headline: British Government Seeks Lift From Economic Data
text: LONDON — Britain crossed an important economic and psychological threshold on Wednesday when growth in paychecks caught up with inflation after years of financial crisis, austerity and an accompanying dip in living standards.

headline: Scene City: A Public Display of Affection
text: Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Chloë Grace Moretz attend opening of “The Library” at the Public Theater.

headline: BMW X4
text: A look at BMW’s new “Sports Activity Coupe,” the X4

headline: Cohen Gets to Trade for 90 Days Before Paying SAC Penalty
text: Even when he loses, the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen manages to find a way to win.

headline: The X4 Is Another Utility Player From BMW
text: Introduced on Wednesday: 2015 BMW X4

headline: A Scottish Trail Will Celebrate John Muir
text: To celebrate the spirit, work and legacy of the  conservationist John Muir, Scotland will officially unveil the John Muir Way on April 21.

headline: Taliban End a Cease-Fire With Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban said Wednesday that they were ending a six-week-old cease-fire but would continue peace talks with the Pakistani government.

headline: In Germany, Strong Words Over Google's Power
text: BERLIN — A trans-Atlantic war of words — and profits — over the future of the Internet heated up on Wednesday when the head of Germany’s largest publisher admitted that “we are afraid of Google” and suggested that European authorities were colluding with the American Internet giant to develop a “business model that in less honorable circles would be called extortion.”

headline: Court Deportations Drop 43 Percent in Past Five Years
text: New deportation cases brought by the Obama administration in the nation’s immigration courts have been declining steadily since 2009, and judges have increasingly ruled against deportations, leading to a 43 percent drop in the number of deportations through the courts in the last five years, according to Justice Department statistics released on Wednesday.

headline: Tanaka Lets Neither Cubs Nor the Cold Get to Him
text: Joe Girardi has been careful about how he handles Masahiro Tanaka. Nothing is trifling in this, Tanaka’s debut month in the major leagues, and Girardi, an obsessive planner, seemed to have Tanaka’s initial starts lined up at the ideal times.

headline: Seeking Young Viewers, Pivot Bolsters Its Original Programming
text: A small, somewhat new cable channel is wooing additional viewers and advertisers by beefing up its original programming, including what would be its first original scripted series.

headline: Jasmin Shokrian Dives Into the Burgeoning Dallas Art Scene
text: The Los Angeles-based designer Jasmin Shokrian makes quietly striking, sculptural clothes beloved by women in the art world. During last week’s Dallas Art Fair, the owners of Tenoversix — the L.A. boutique that last year opened an outpost in (and served as a design consultancy for) Dallas’s art-filled Joule Hotel — invited Shokrian to hold a trunk show in their space. The event offered an ideal excuse for Shokrian to explore the metropolis and its booming cultural scene over the weekend. “It felt like kind of a magical city,” she says. Yes, she’s talking about Dallas. Here, she shares some highlights, including a joint exhibition by Julian Schnabel and Richard Phillips at Dallas Contemporary and an accompanying dinner, a spin through the fair, a gallery opening co-hosted by the model and Dallas native Erin Wasson and a party called the Eye Ball.

headline: Yellen Discusses Fed’s Coming Decision
text: Speaking at the Economic Club of New York, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed’s coming decision on interest rates would depend on employment and inflation thresholds.

headline: The Birth of a Conspiracy Theory
text: If you spend enough time on the Internet you’ll eventually encounter a conspiracy theory. If you watch closely enough, sometimes you can actually see one being born.

headline: ‘Fargo’ on FX Debuts to an Audience of More Than 4 Million
text: The new FX drama “Fargo” got off to a promising start on Tuesday, with ratings across several broadcasts that added up to more than four million viewers.

headline: Clip: ‘Proxy’
text: A scene from the film “Proxy,” directed by Zack Parker.

headline: Cut the Clutter in Your Social Media Accounts
text: BEING active on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook is kind of like having a basement in the suburbs. These accounts can quickly become so cluttered that you might as well shut the door and say goodbye — you’re never finding anything you need again.

headline: ‘In the Garden of Souls’ and Gardens of Childhood
text: One worthy mission of Ballet NY, a chamber troupe founded in 1997 and still hanging on, is to offer chances, and trained dancers, to budding choreographers. So it might have been disappointing that the company’s program at Ailey Citigroup Theater on Tuesday featured no new works. Three out of the four pieces had been made for other groups. Yet this, too, was part of a worthy mission: allowing the creations of lesser-known choreographers to be seen again, embodied and interpreted by different dancers, giving those works a chance at an extended life.

headline: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander the Great is said to have wept because he ran out of kingdoms to conquer. Google is eager to avoid such a miserable fate.

headline: Acura TLX: All-Wheel Steering Tries for Another Comeback
text: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Acura TLX

headline: One-Man Hollywood in the Midwest
text: The concepts are high. The budgets are low. The themes are unnerving. That’s the best way to describe the films made by Zack Parker, a native of the Midwest who takes a more-than-meets-the-eye approach to his moviemaking. Mr. Parker is based in Richmond, Ind., a small town on the eastern side of the state that wouldn’t exactly be the first location choice for many directors. But he has shot four disturbing features in that area.

headline: Conquering Displacement With Words
text: BARCELONA, Spain — When he was just 22, the Spanish-Argentine writer Andrés Neuman was anointed by no less a luminary than the Chilean writer Roberto Bolaño, who had a discriminating eye for talent and wasn’t lukewarm when he found it. “The literature of the 21st century,” Bolaño proclaimed, “will belong to Neuman and a few of his blood brothers.” Bolaño said he felt like weeping when he discovered such a young, gifted writer; Mr. Neuman’s first novel, “Bariloche” (1999), Bolaño wrote, had “enthralled” and “hypnotized” him for the uncanny ease of its writing.

headline: Profit and Revenue Slip at IBM as Hardware Sales Fall and Layoff Costs Rise
text: IBM is investing heavily in the future. It has placed multibillion-dollar bets on businesses to deliver computing remotely over the Internet cloud, on sophisticated data-analysis software and on its Watson artificial-intelligence technology.

headline: Incubator Arts Project to Close
text: The Incubator Arts Project, a well-regarded experimental performance company, announced on Wednesday that it would close in July after deciding not to renew its lease at St. Mark’s Church in the East Village. In a statement, Incubator’s leaders were vague about the reasons for the decision but others involved with the company said the closing was due to the difficulty of raising money and generating revenue – a challenge faced by many theaters of all budget sizes.

headline: Credit Sought by ABC News for Pulitzer, but Rejected
text: It was a moment of triumph for accountability journalism. An investigation on sick Appalachian miners being denied medical care and benefits by the coal industry was honored on Monday with one of the highest awards in journalism: the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting.

headline: Leaping Off the Screen: Nelson George Talks About ‘Soul Train’
text: Nelson George’s new book, “The Hippest Trip in America,” documents the history of “Soul Train,” the landmark television dance show that had its premiere in 1971. “Soul Train,” which was created in Chicago then moved to Los Angeles, showcased and deeply influenced African-American music, dance and fashion, hosting artists like Stevie Wonder and James Brown and starting the careers of dancers like Rosie Perez and Jody Watley. In a recent email interview, Mr. George discussed his earliest memories of “Soul Train,” why certain stars wouldn’t appear on the program, the show’s possible return and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: For Diabetics, Health Risks Fall Sharply
text: Federal researchers on Wednesday reported the first broad national picture of progress against some of the most devastating complications of diabetes, which affects millions of Americans, finding that rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations fell sharply over the past two decades.

headline: A Filmmaker Relishes His Next Act(s)
text: Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones were sitting in the mezzanine of the Public Theater on Tuesday night, discussing whether Steven Soderbergh would make good on his promise of retirement. The director has said that he is finished directing movies.

headline: A Cultural Bazaar in Doha, Qatar
text: The Souk Waqif (“standing market”) in Doha, Qatar, has been rebuilt within the last decade into a shopping hub that includes architectural elements of the original century-old souk. At the Qatari market, you can shop for spices, traditional garments and kitchenware, or just enjoy a sip of Arabic coffee or a smoke from a hookah. The area’s blend of traditional and modern elements also manifests itself in the ways people dress to go shopping, ranging from women wearing a niqab to a colorful head scarf, to saris to jeans. Fahad al-Obaidly, a fashion designer, was in the area on a recent afternoon wearing a traditional floor-length coat with a black pair of jeans. Speaking through an interpreter, he credited the cultural mix of the area as a source of fashion inspiration. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Combative Director, Even in Letters
text: Elia Kazan’s 1988 “A Life”  arguably remains the most raw, soul-searching memoir ever written about a career in show business. And his story remains polarizing, whether for his naming names to the House Un-American Activities Committee or for his candor about the pain he inflicted on those who loved him.

headline: Beauty Bars That Offer Quick Touch-Ups
text: The actress Stephanie March, who plays the assistant district attorney Alexandra Cabot on “Law & Order: SVU,” was talking on a recent afternoon about a perk of her job: getting her makeup done professionally. “My lawyer makeup was like me only better, which was a revelation to people who saw me after work,” said Ms. March, 39.

headline: In a Choreographer’s Imagination, a Kiss Is Never Just a Kiss
text: When Eduardo Vilaro took the job of the artistic director of Ballet Hispanico in 2009, he left the company he had founded in Chicago, the Luna Negra Dance Theater, in the hands of the Spanish choreographer Gustavo Ramírez Sansano. Five years later, with Luna Negra having folded, Mr. Vilaro and Mr. Sansano have crossed paths again. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Ballet Hispanico unveiled its first commission for Mr. Sansano, “El Beso,” which was also his New York debut as a choreographer.

headline: Songs of the Dead (and Others), Alive and Kicking
text: Combinations and recombinations, the familiar and the strange, the chance to find something new within old songs, the camaraderie among musicians onstage and between longtime performers and loyal fans — all the jam-band elements were in place when Phil Lesh and Friends played the last of 10 area shows, the second of two concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night.

headline: A Little Zaniness and a Little Cabaret
text: As Lucie Arnaz, her eyes aflame, swiveled onto the stage of Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening and spat out the lyrics to the sizzling Lena Horne hit “Love,” she emulated the attitude of combative challenge that was a Horne signature. No matter that Ms. Arnaz, 62, is not as glamorous as Horne was even in her 80s, or that her voice isn’t as full-bodied or her manner as insinuating. The Horne tribute was still a smart, effective opening salvo in her show “Spring Is Here.”

headline: True King of Late Night? He Might Raise Eyebrows
text: After the latest upheavals in late-night television, with Stephen Colbert being picked to replace David Letterman, Jimmy Fallon establishing an early lead on Jimmy Kimmel, and the futures of Chelsea Handler and Craig Ferguson suddenly up in the air, the new king of comedy might be the star making the fewest headlines.

headline: After Years of Writing, an Author’s Own Epic Fantasy Comes True
text: The fantasy writer Brandon Sanderson’s reputation is finally as big as his novels — and that’s saying a lot.

headline: Despite Hurdles, House Democrats Hold Edge in Small Donations
text: WASHINGTON — House Democrats are winning the early battle for small donors, raising nearly $20 million more than Republicans so far this election cycle among so-called small-dollar donations.

headline: Jordanian Jets Strike Vehicles Trying to Enter From Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Jordanian warplanes on Wednesday destroyed three vehicles trying to enter the country from neighboring Syria in an unusual strike that underscored Jordan’s intensive efforts to maintain control over a border crisscrossed by smugglers, Syrian insurgents and refugees.

headline: Sky Ferreira: A Rebel, When Time Permits
text: Around 3 in the morning after the last Met Ball, the singer Sky Ferreira met one of her idols, Madonna. “By ‘met,’ I mean ‘attacked,’ ” said Ms. Ferreira, 21, over iced tea at a Cuban restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where she lives. “I think I sat in her lap at one point.” She showed a photo of the two of them on her phone.

headline: Rating Men in New York
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Silodor Open Pairs at the Spring Nationals
text: DALLAS — At the Spring Nationals here last month, the Silodor Open Pairs was won by John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas. They finished more than four boards ahead of Richard Budd of Portland, Me., and Zach Grossack of Newton, Mass. Third were Jill Levin of Henderson, Nev., and Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Bookshelf | Homes Inspired by the Creative Lives of their Owners
text: In the new book “The Inspired Home: Nests of Creatives” (Rizzoli, $55), Kim Ficaro and Todd Nickey prove that the most inspiring homes are not always the ones dreamed up by architects, designers or the incredibly wealthy. And they should know: Ficaro has styled props and interiors for Bon Appétit, Town & Country, Elle, Harper’s Bazaar and Domino, while Nickey co-owns a successful design company in L.A. Rather than choosing homes simply because they struck their fancy, the co-authors first rounded up a trove of creative types — artists, writers, musicians, stylists, art directors — who had interesting personal style, and then hoped their homes would follow suit. Their instincts proved correct, and the 17 nests featured in this beautiful coffee-table book, shot by the Danish photographer Ditte Isager, reveal the inspiring combination of natural light and accidental, lived-in beauty. And despite the authors’ professions, Ficaro and Nickey opted not to style or decorate any of the interiors before they were photographed. “We wanted to let the places breathe on their own,” explains Ficaro.

headline: BMW 4 Series Gran Coupe: Playing by the Numbers
text: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 BMW 4 Series Gran Coupe

headline: Deals by the Incoming La Scala Chief Cause a Stir
text: ROME — Alexander Pereira hasn’t even begun his first season as general manager of La Scala and his stewardship is already generating controversy. Mr. Pereira, who is scheduled to take over the Milan opera house on Oct. 1, signed an agreement to buy four productions for La Scala from the Salzburg Festival, where he is the director, without the approval of the Italian authorities, according to La Scala and the mayor of Milan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, India and Bosnia.

headline: In All the Spring Fashion Looks, a Balance
text: It takes a steady compass to navigate the sea of contradictory impulses defining fashion now. Go big, the merchants, designers and trend forecasters will tell you as they tout the charms of outsize pants, crop tops and calf-grazing dresses, while in the same breath trumpeting the sexiness of tiny shapes.

headline: Spring Fashion: Hand Yourself Bouquets
text: There was nothing temperate about Stephanie Solomon’s spring fashion forecast. “Your tights, throw them out,” she urged. “Get rid of your hats, your scarves, but most of all those hose. You never want to see them again.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Rose Is a Rose Is a Song Is a Song
text: What do Gertrude Stein and Prince have in common? “They’re both androgynous,” said the songwriter-musician Heather Christian playfully, after rehearsals for the new theater piece, “The World is Round,” based on Stein’s children’s book of the same name. They also have a tendency to repeat themselves. Particularly Stein, whose famed circular line “rose is a rose is a rose is a rose” comes from that 1938 book.

headline: 2 Hedge Fund Titans Agree to Buy the Milwaukee Bucks
text: Two Wall Street bigwigs, Marc Lasry and Wesley Edens, have a taste for distressed assets.

headline: A Homecoming of Sorts for Mark Fields of Ford
text: The opening keynote address at the New York International Auto Show by Mark Fields, chief operating officer of Ford Motor, unsurprisingly promoted innovation and technology, but it sidestepped any discussion of rumors that the company would soon take a new direction with one of its most visible technologies.

headline: From Madonna to Hedwig, Dressing the Divas of Rock
text: ARIANNE PHILLIPS KNOWS from fashion-savvy divas. A veteran fashion stylist and costume designer with a score of films and two Oscar nominations to her name (for Walk the Line and W.E.), she is still best known for styling Madonna, working on her music videos, films and last five world tours.

headline: An Easier Way to Delay Cutting the Cord
text: Doctors in the delivery room are increasingly urged to hold off cutting the umbilical cord of a newborn. Delayed clamping, as it’s called, allows blood to continue flowing from the placenta, improving iron stores in the baby.

headline: Aston Martin Vantage GT: A Blue Light Special, Comparatively
text: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Aston Martin Vantage GT

headline: Sights and Sounds From the Furniture Fair
text: The 53rd International Milan Furniture Fair had more than 350,000 visitors from some 160 countries.

headline: Square Feet: 84. Possessions: 305.
text: From time to time, Dee Williams does a possession count. The last tally was 305.

headline: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler and Lightology
text: Holiday cooking essentials are up to 65 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through Sunday or while supplies last (a Wusthof five-inch Santoku knife, originally $135, is about $50; a Le Creuset round skillet grill, regularly $220, is about $120); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), 212-966-3434 or broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Should We Remove Wall-to-Wall Carpeting?
text: Q. We have worn carpet in our bedrooms and hardwood floors in the rest of the house. Should we replace the carpet, change it to hardwood or leave it as is?

headline: Your Trainer Saw That
text: Angela Harrigan, a personal trainer at Life Time Fitness, sees each client maybe two hours per week, but she knows exactly how much of the other 166 hours they’ve spent furthering — or undoing — their efforts.

headline: Gather Round the Fire, Wherever You Want It
text: Behold the Dude: the first truly portable fire pit and grill from the Salt Lake City-based Cowboy Cauldron Company. This 45-pound vessel, the smallest of the company’s four hemispherical braziers, was designed with migratory outdoor entertaining in mind.

headline: A Cold One Wrapped in Plastic
text: Govino, a company known for making plastic wineglasses you wouldn’t be embarrassed to use in public, recently introduced something similar for beer. “Craft brew is huge right now,” said Joseph Perrulli, the creative director. “We saw an opening, went back and forth on designs and settled on a classic pilsner shape.”

headline: Study Finds No Evidence of Heartbleed Attacks Before the Bug Was Exposed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Ever since the Heartbleed bug was exposed last week, the question everyone has been asking is: Did anyone exploit it before a Google researcher first discovered it?

headline: Symbolism Meets Modern Life
text: Amy Reichert, an architect and exhibitions designer in Chicago, devotes part of her time to creating custom-made limited-edition Judaica, a challenge that requires adapting ancient synagogue fittings to modern clients’ needs, and then explaining them to craft artists who may never have attended a Seder. She has turned floating brass flowers into menorahs, has decorated silver Sabbath goblets with pearls and has had elm Seder plates carved to resemble desert dunes.

headline: Their Game, Now Ours
text: What, you didn’t catch Liverpool storm back against Manchester City last week? You missed Wayne Rooney’s 58-yard wonder goal against West Ham United?

headline: When Our Maids Lived In
text: If you’re a real estate hound, “Manhattan Classic: New York’s Finest Prewar Apartments” (Princeton Architectural Press, $50) is either a twist of the knife or a handy resource, depending on your point of view and your bank account. A total of 85 apartment houses built from the 1880s to the 1930s, the city’s first building boom, are collected here, along with floor plans and some interior photos. An index organizes buildings by architect or developer.

headline: Bentley Flying Spur V8: A Smaller Engine Arrives for North America
text: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16 The Bentley Flying Spur V8

headline: It’s All 1810 to Them
text: John and Judy Hobday live in what could almost be considered a museum: an 1810 stone house that they have painstakingly restored to its (nearly) original state.

headline: A Need to Go Public With Test Data
text: To the Editor:

headline: Occasional Tables: Holding Their Liquor
text: Lauren Rottet has designed her share of hotels and bars, the Loews Regency and the Surrey hotels on the Upper East Side and bars at the Hudson hotel near Columbus Circle among others. And she has produced a collection of furniture for Decca. So she knows how essential an occasional table is when you’re entertaining.

headline: Political Roadblocks to Action on Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cancer Society and Tobacco
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gilded Lily | Chelsea
text: Hedge-funders and scions may keep the extravagant bar tabs afloat, but the bottle-service universe always expands toward downtown for cool points. The latest alignment occurs on Wednesdays at Gilded Lily, a club on West 15th Street that opened in February.

headline: College Acceptance Rates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Better Pay for the Disabled
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Milan, Putting a Pretty Face on It
text: MILAN — At the 53rd International Furniture Fair here, which ended on Sunday, the German designer Konstantin Grcic introduced a chair for the Finnish company Artek. Running into him midweek, I congratulated him on the piece. “You’ve gotten in touch with your inner girl,” I said.

headline: Luxury Oral-Care
text: When celebrities are asked about their personal grooming habits, they often cite Marvis as their preferred toothpaste. But this beloved Italian brand is facing competition in the luxury mouth-freshening department.

headline: Dutch Design, Up for Bid
text: The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas, a glass slab of casino halls and 3,000 hotel rooms, once had an avant-garde attraction as well: a street-level showroom devoted to the Dutch design company Droog, whose signature witticisms (dresser drawers roped together, rags stacked to form chairs, milk bottles clustered into chandeliers) were shown on a translucent white floor.

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
text: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.

headline: An Indecent Burial
text: Twenty-five years ago this month, with the Supreme Court’s support for the right to abortion shrinking rapidly, the justices heard a case from Missouri that invited them to disavow Roe v. Wade, the precedent that 16 years earlier had given women the constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy. A month after the argument, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist circulated to his colleagues a proposed majority opinion that would have overturned Roe in all but name, upholding the challenged regulations under such a relaxed standard of judicial review that states in the future would have been able to impose nearly any obstacle to abortion that they might think of.

headline: Gee, Perfect Through Four Innings, Sparkles as Mets Sweep Diamondbacks
text: PHOENIX — For four innings, Dillon Gee was perfect, and through six innings, he was still cruising. In the seventh, however, he began to look human, and soon his day was done.

headline: The Deepwater Horizon Threat
text: FOUR years ago this Sunday, BP’s Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out, destroying the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig, killing 11 workers and setting off an uncontrolled oil gusher lasting 87 days. By the time the flow was stopped, an estimated 200 million gallons of oil had entered the ocean.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 17
text: Openings and Events

headline: America’s Urban Future
text: FOR all of the attention showered on hipster enclaves like Williamsburg, Brooklyn and Portland, Ore., America is only in the beginning stages of a historic urban reordering. After over a half-century of depopulation, cities have been filling up — and not just with young millennials, but with families and even older workers and retirees.

headline: Minimum Wage, Maximum Outrage
text: No one should ever endure the kind of economic humiliation that comes with working a full-time job and making a less-than-living wage.

headline: James Murdoch Joins Board of Advertising Start-Up
text: James Murdoch, the co-chief operating officer of 21st Century Fox, has joined the board of True[X] Media, an advertising company based in New York.

headline: My Father’s Strength
text: On the afternoon before my college graduation in 1999, there was a ceremony for graduates who were getting department prizes. My father was a New York City tunnel worker (a “sandhog”) and at that time he was working on Roosevelt Island, a 20-minute drive from Barnard’s campus. He always showered before leaving the job site, and on that day he’d brought khakis, a freshly pressed shirt and tie and the new jacket my mother had gotten him for his 55th birthday. I remember what he was wearing because it was the first time I noticed him holding a handkerchief, which he used throughout the ceremony to dab the corners of his mouth. After, when we were discussing where to have dinner, I spotted a narrow river of saliva traveling down the side of his chin.

headline: Obama Speaks on Jobs in Pennsylvania
text: President Obama spoke about job training at the Community College of Allegheny County in Oakdale, Pa.

headline: Obama Looks for Midterm Advantage on Job Training and Immigration
text: OAKDALE, Pa. — President Obama, seeking to shore up support for midterm elections that threaten to cost his party control of the Senate, vowed Wednesday to improve federal job training programs and chastised Republicans for blocking an overhaul of immigration law.

headline: Former Senator Is Selling the Bucks After Three Decades
text: Herb Kohl, who retired last year as a United States senator from Wisconsin after four terms, announced Wednesday that he was set to end his long run as the owner of the Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: Living in the Grip of Vigilance
text: Has fear come to play too big a role in government policy and the level of protection Americans seek?

headline: Precision to Meet Brute Force
text: When the first-round playoff series between the Rangers and the Flyers begins Thursday at Madison Square Garden, the assumption is that Philadelphia will try to thump, crash and physically intimidate the Rangers. The evidence? First, the Flyers accumulated the most penalty minutes in the N.H.L. this season, while the Rangers finished 22nd. And then there is the whole Broad Street Bullies tradition.

headline: Alfa Romeo 4C
text: Alfa Romeo attempts a comeback in the United States.

headline: Boston Police to Bolster Presence Before Marathon
text: BOSTON — Police officials pledged Wednesday to step up their presence near the finish line before next week’s Boston Marathon, after Tuesday’s day of tribute to the victims of last year’s attack was marred by a bomb scare that shut down the area for hours.

headline: Suburbs Try to Prevent an Exodus as Young Adults Move to Cities and Stay
text: It is a well-trod trail: Suburban youngsters enter their early 20s, leave their parents’ comfortable Tudors or colonials for the pizazz of the city, dawdle a few years until they find mates and begin having children and then, seeking more space and good public schools, move back to the suburbs and into their own Tudors or colonials.

headline: A Quick, Satisfying Drive in the 2015 Honda Fit
text: True to its name, the 2015 Honda Fit just fits. It’s a small car, and accordingly, weaves through tight urban spaces with ease. But for something so tiny, it has a lot of space inside – not just the kind that looks good in brochures, but the sort that makes drivers feel at ease, like they have finally escaped the womblike experience so many automakers offer, even on much larger cars.

headline: A Settlement on Soured Mortgages May Raise Questions on What Is Enough
text: One of the unsettled questions from the financial crisis is whether the big banks have paid enough to cover the mortgage abuses they committed before the market collapsed.

headline: What the Huracán and the Honeycomb Have in Common
text: One of the most stunning cars in New York for this year’s auto show was not to be found on the show floor of the Javits Center. Lamborghini’s Huracán LP 610-4 was shown Tuesday at Bathhouse Studios, a former site of public baths on the Lower East Side that has been turned into a photo studio and event space.

headline: It’s Official: Yahoo’s Former No. 2 Made a Lot More Than His Boss
text: Henrique de Castro, who was fired in January as Yahoo’s chief operating officer, was paid handsomely for his largely unsuccessful efforts to turn around the company’s flailing advertising business.

headline: 2015 Chevrolet Trax
text: A look at the “miniutility vehicle” from the 2014 New York auto show.

headline: Nissan Offers Owners of the Leaf E.V. Free Electricity
text: Nissan has sold more than 110,000 Leaf battery electric cars around the world and almost 50,000 in the United States, but it obviously wants to increase that. Americans respond to “free gas” promotions, so the company is trying something similar with electricity. Fred Diaz, senior vice president in Nissan’s sales and marketing after-sales operation, said Wednesday at the New York show that charging is going to be free for two years to new Leaf customers, first in 10 top markets, and later in 25.

headline: Russia Economy Worsens Even Before Sanctions Hit
text: MOSCOW — Margarita R. Zobnina, a professor of marketing here, has been watching the Russian economy’s gathering woes with mounting alarm: friends who have moved abroad with no plans to return; others who put off new business ventures because of rising uncertainty. Meanwhile, Ms. Zobnina and her husband, Alexander, also a professor, have rented a safe deposit box to hold foreign cash as a hedge against the declining ruble.

headline: In Ukraine, Russia Plays a Weighted Word Game
text: KIEV, Ukraine — If one ignores the images of masked men armed to the teeth and just listens to Russian television, the drama in eastern Ukraine can sometimes seem little more than a quarrel among constitutional scholars. The gunmen, denounced by the Ukrainian government as violent separatists, are invariably referred to by Russian officials and their state-controlled news media simply as “supporters of federalization.”

headline: After 2 Years, M.T.A. and Union Close In on a New Contract
text: More than two years after its contract expired, the union representing New York City’s subway and bus workers is involved in intense negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and appears on the cusp of reaching a new contract, union and government officials said Wednesday.

headline: Central African Republic: Aid Sought for Those Fleeing Unrest
text: The United Nations refugee agency said Wednesday that it was working with 14 other humanitarian relief groups to seek $274 million in emergency donations to support the swelling population of refugees fleeing violence in the Central African Republic, one of Africa’s most dysfunctional countries. The refugee agency said nearly 200,000 residents had escaped to neighboring countries over the last four months. More than 600,000 people were displaced inside the Central African Republic because of communal violence that has effectively partitioned the country into Christian and Muslim sectors. António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a statement that all relief agencies working in the region were “dramatically underfunded” and that his own agency was far outspending what it had expected. “This cannot be sustained,” he said.

headline: Gaza: Blasts Kill Hamas Militants
text: Three militants were killed Wednesday and five people were wounded when several explosions ripped through a Hamas facility in the southern Gaza Strip. The cause of the explosions was under investigation, but officials of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that controls Gaza, said they were the result of a “jihad mission,” a term that refers to militants felled in work accidents or during training. The dead were identified as members of Hamas’s armed wing. Four of the wounded were firefighters or others who rushed to the scene.

headline: India Election Digest: April 17
text: What you need to know about India’s election on Thursday: The fifth and biggest round of India’s national elections gets underway, with 121 constituencies across 12 states and union territories going to vote. What’s at stake: 28 seats in Karnataka, followed by Rajasthan (20), Maharashtra (19), Uttar Pradesh and Odisha (11 each), Madhya Pradesh (10), Bihar (seven), Jharkhand (six), West Bengal (four), Chhattisgarh (three), Manipur and the state of Jammu and Kashmir (one each).

headline: Alan Davie, Painter With a Global Bent, Dies at 93
text: Alan Davie, a Scottish-born painter whose audacious and colorful abstractions put a personal stamp on Pollock-like expressionism and seized on mythical and mystical imagery from cultures around the globe, died on April 5 at his home in Hertfordshire, north of London. He was 93.

headline: F. Reid Buckley, Novelist and Columnist, Dies at 83
text: F. Reid Buckley, a novelist, columnist, founder of a school of public speaking and, in family lore, the most literary of Aloise and William F. Buckley Sr.’s 10 children, including former Senator James L. Buckley and the conservative commentator William F. Buckley Jr., died on Monday in hospice care in Columbia, S.C. He was 83.

headline: Spring Shape-Up Secrets From the Fashion Crowd’s Favorite New Gym
text: Rare is the gym that can be described as aesthetically pleasing. Yet that’s just what the trainer Stephen Cheuk has assembled at S10 Training, his recently opened fitness center in the TriBeCa neighborhood in New York. Designed by Samuel Amoia Associates, which has previously undertaken projects for André Balazs and Ian Schrager, it features mirrored changing-room cubes, brick walls with a lime-wash finish and a prominently placed photograph by Jim Mangan. The stylish look suits Cheuk’s roster of clients, which includes the Alexander Wang design team, the actor-slash-designer Waris Ahluwalia and a host of other downtown fashion types. “It’s a visually beautiful gym, which doesn’t hurt when you’re working out,” notes Ahluwalia, who has trained with Cheuk for years.

headline: The Antidepressant Generation
text: “I think our experiment failed,” the young graduate student told me, referring to our attempt to take her off the antidepressant she’d been on for seven years. She was back in my campus office after a difficult summer break, and as she talked about feeling unsettled and upset, I wondered about the broader experiment playing out on college campuses across the country.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Fuse) PIRATE RADIO (2009) The time: Britain in the mid-1960s, when the BBC, aided by the government, kept official radio channels mostly free of rock ’n’ roll. The place: a tanker off the British coast, where rebel broadcasters (Philip Seymour Hoffman, Bill Nighy and Rhys Ifans, above at microphone) blasted the Stones, the Kinks, Jimi Hendrix and the Who over the airwaves. This angers a government minister (Kenneth Branagh) who wants to keep listeners safe with high culture and educational programming. The director of this movie, Richard Curtis, “isn’t concerned with exploring why gatekeepers might want to maintain the divide between high and popular culture,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “He wants to party. So he piles on the comic high jinks, lobs the jokes and cranks the splendid tunes.” Mr. Nighy can also be seen as a financially distressed British retiree lured to Jaipur, India, in John Madden’s “Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” (2012), at 4:45 on MoreMax, and as the washed-up rock star Billy Mack, angling for a comeback, in Mr. Curtis’s “Love Actually” (2003), at 8 on Showtime.

headline: It’s the End of the World as We Know It . . . and He Feels Fine
text: Late one night last August, on the chalk downlands of southern England, Paul Kingsnorth stood in a field beside an old-growth forest, two yurts and a composting toilet. Kingsnorth is 41, tall, slim and energetic, with sweeping brown hair and a sparse beard. He wears rimless glasses and a silver stud in his ear, and he talks with great ardor, often apologizing for having said too much or for having said it too strongly.

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
text: David Turnley photographed the Rwanda genocide and its aftermath in 1994 while working for The Detroit Free Press. He won the Pulitzer Prize in 1990, for his coverage of political upheaval in the Eastern bloc and China, including the fall of the Berlin Wall and Tiananmen Square. He has won the World Press Picture of the Year award twice, and the Robert Capa Award for Courage.

headline: Running Against Republicans, and the Environment
text: How far should Democrats be prepared to go to keep control of the Senate in November’s election? If they win because one of their members repudiates everything they stand for, is it worth the victory? That’s the troubling question raised by a new re-election campaign ad for Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana. Her victory is crucial to preventing a Republican takeover of the Senate, but the environmental positions she takes in the ad sound far more Republican than Democratic.

headline: Bibi van der Velden’s Whimsical Fine Jewelry Collection
text: “Fine jewelry,” says the designer and sculptor Bibi van der Velden, “should be taken with a dose of humor.” A thread of whimsy runs through the work of the New York-born, Amsterdam-based designer, whose handcrafted pieces have been collected by the likes of Kanye West and Sienna Miller. Though she started her line in 2006, her work is gaining new attention this season; it recently debuted at Bergdorf Goodman and Dover Street Market in New York and will launch on Net-a-Porter on June 9th. Her spring collection, carved from 40,000-year-old mammoth tusks that emerged from the Russian tundra thanks to global warming, includes such designs as a pendant depicting a cloud raining thunderbolts, a necklace strung with dodo egg-shaped “pearls” and a wraparound dragon ring that features a tiny man clutching a diamond emerging from the jaws of the beast. The natural world is a leitmotif for van der Velden, who likes to tell the story of how an owl once soared through the room at one of her runway shows. For fall, her pieces will incorporate actual scarab wings. “I am fascinated by nature and its beauty,” she says. “I hate to see such beauty go to waste.”

headline: Sometimes a Bad Birthday Gift Has Its Uses
text: THE deeper an artist gets into her career, the harder it can be for her to find inspiration, as Jill Sobule can tell you.

headline: Chief of British Conglomerate Calls 2013 Results ‘Disastrous’

headline: The Party Decides, Unless It Can’t
text: Right now, the most striking thing about the public polling on the 2016 Republican nomination isn’t just the absence of a clear frontrunner: It’s the absence of a clear pair or trio or even a quartet of frontrunners. The latest Iowa poll has Mike Huckabee in the pole position with eleven percent, and then eight (!) others — all of whom are more serious figures than some of the characters who briefly polled well last time around — bunched between six and ten percent; the national polling average isn’t quite that compressed, but it’s close. This can’t last, but everyone recognizes that the situation is historically unusual (as, on the other side, is Hillary Clinton’s extraordinary advantage); the question is, how unusual, and what does it mean for the normal way that these things shake out?

headline: Pregnancy Weight Gain Predicts Child’s Obesity

headline: Basil A. Paterson, 87, a Power in Harlem With Statewide Reach, Dies

Paterson, one of the old-guard Democratic leaders who for decades dominated politics in Harlem and influenced black political power in New York City and the state into the 21st century, when he saw his son David A. headline: De Blasio’s 2013 Promise to Muslims

headline: Oil Slick in Indian Ocean Not From Missing Jet, Tests Find

headline: Political Ads, Often Negative, Try Instead to Accentuate the Positive
text: WASHINGTON — Outside political groups, long known for their negative advertisements featuring ominous music and foreboding narration, are trying something new this campaign season: a pivot to the positive.

headline: Mac DeMarco on Wearing Women’s Clothing and the Elements of No-Fuss Style
text: Last Tuesday, in the bathroom of his dressing room (the only place he was permitted to smoke), before playing a set at the Williamsburg music venue Baby’s All Right, the rising musician Mac DeMarco imparted insight into his no-fuss style. The key to his look, he confessed, is to avoid overthinking — in other words, to stock up on white Hanes T-shirts and floppy brimmed hats. Effortlessness is central to the 23-year-old Canadian’s approach to pretty much everything. “Take my advice,” he sings on the song “Brother,” from his album “Salad Days,” “to take it slowly, brother.” If that’s your plan this summer, read on to dress the part.

headline: N.B.A. Players Reset Union Search With Kevin Johnson as Point Man

headline: Arab-Israeli Activist Is Moved to House Arrest

He was being held on suspicion of conducting an unauthorized visit to an enemy state and contact with a foreign agent, according to his lawyers and Israeli security officials.

I could feel his breath on my face” and “I knew what was going to happen before he told me what was going to happen.”

headline: Lawsuit Aims to Derail New York Library Plan

headline: Back Onstage, With Fewer Secrets
text: Michael C. Hall has made a career of playing men with something to hide, the sort who manage their anxieties by pouring themselves into their work, which in the case of his two best-known television roles happened to include embalming and burying the dead (on “Six Feet Under”) and violently avenging the dead (on “Dexter”). Onstage now in the playwright Will Eno’s gnomic, desperate comedy “The Realistic Joneses,” Mr. Hall plays John, a man with plenty to hide but no real trade to busy his hands and thus to take his mind off a mortal secret he carries.

headline: A Bid to Park Recalled G.M. Cars Is Denied

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity

headline: F.D.A. Discourages Procedure in Uterine Surgery
text: Doctors should stop using a procedure performed on tens of thousands of American women a year in the course of uterine surgery, because it poses a risk of spreading cancerous tissue, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

headline: Today in Small Business: Smart Soda Cans?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Jabari Parker of Duke Declares for N.B.A. Draft

headline: 36 Hours in Prague
text: For people who haven’t traveled to Prague recently, the Czech capital might seem like a known quantity: a city with a thousand years of architecture, cheap beer and often boring restaurants where the most unusual ingredients are the doughy dumplings. But Prague is developing so quickly that many locals still haven’t heard of all the next big things: flashy new art galleries, dynamically developing old neighborhoods, great bars — beyond and including beer — and new restaurants with flavorful offerings from classic steaks and chops to Asian spice. In fact, so many new developments have appeared in Prague that you could spend an entire weekend visiting only those places that have opened in the past couple of years. See Prague Castle, Charles Bridge and all the other classic attractions. But finish out your stay with some of the vibrant newcomers.

headline: In Lecce, Making Magic With Humble Ingredients
text: La cucina povera. Often translated as “the food of the poor,” the term seems unlikely to make mouths water or inspire serious foodies to blow their vacation budget on a cooking course.

headline: Portraits on the Page of Paris, London and Venice
text: Paris, London, Venice: hardly the most mysterious places on the planet. Yet beyond Notre Dame, Big Ben and the Basilica di San Marco lie hidden iterations of these well-trodden cities: obscure corners, faded histories and the daily pleasures and aggravations of those who live there. A 19th-century Parisian photographer, a former musician in London and a novelist in Venice are among those who offer unexpected insights in six recently published or about-to-be-published books. Some urge you to visit, others beg you to stay away, all are likely to trigger the wanderlust of those eager to get closer to the authentic heart of a place.

headline: The Personification of Legends
text: Louis Armstrong, who always knew how to make an entrance, gets a doozy of an opening scene in “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show now playing at the Westside Theater. It’s March 1971 and dark as night in the trumpeter and singer’s dressing room at the Waldorf-Astoria, except for a Hopperesque shaft of light streaming through the door. A muffled ovation rises and falls in the distance, and then in he comes, lurching wheezily toward an oxygen tank across the room.

headline: BlackRock Profit Rises as It Attracts More Money From Investors

headline: Vision of Home
text: AIDONE, Sicily — The ruins of the ancient Greek city of Morgantina sit high on a hill in eastern Sicily. There are cherry trees, wildflowers and total stillness, save for the sound of bird song. The area has long been sacred to Persephone; legend has it that Hades pulled that goddess into the underworld by a nearby lake.

headline: Suit Accuses Director of New ‘X-Men’ Film of Sexual Assault

She said she had been at the stadium for four days. Her refugee document had expired, she said, and she feared that she would be sent back to war-torn Somalia.

headline: Obamacare, Deficits and Empirics
text: In my post yesterday on potential metrics for assessing Obamacare’s claim to be a policy success, I didn’t directly address the law’s eventual impact on the deficit. So I’m grateful to Jonathan Chait for raising the issue, in the course of a post explaining why the Obamacare debate proves (yet again, he would say) that liberals are more empirical and data-driven than conservatives. Noting that many Republicans had alleged that the law’s promise of deficit reduction was based (in Paul Ryan’s words) on “gimmicks and smoke and mirrors,” Chait cites a new C.B.O. estimate on the cost of the law’s coverage expansion and announces that reality has spoken, and the case is closed:

The investigation is part of a broad national crackdown on businesses seeking to turn a quick profit by exporting luxury cars from the United States to China.

headline: Is God Just Not That Into Me?
text: I never thought much about God, certainly never wondered whether God was thinking about me, until I fell in love with a Zen Buddhist priest. I met him on an online dating site, an environment of tactical omission. I just knew he was a Buddhist, as he knew I was a writer.

headline: My Daughter, Profoundly Disabled, Needs a School for Children Like Her
text: A Civil War historian, I never thought I’d use the word “segregationist” to describe myself, but my daughter’s public school has changed all that. I’m not talking about racial segregation — her school is one of the most economically and ethnically diverse in our town. I’m talking about self-contained education for children with disabilities, which, in the United States, is increasingly rare.

headline: Creation in Personal Utopias
text: The “insider-outsider” exhibition has been a major trend of the past few years, with works by folk and self-taught artists turning up at the 55th Venice Biennale and in galleries that normally showcase young, brazenly careerist people with M.F.A.s. In theory, everyone benefits; long-marginalized or forgotten artists get exposed to a wide audience, and contemporary artists receive a kind of authenticity by osmosis. But it doesn’t always work out that way.

headline: Morgan Stanley Gets Most Relief From First-Quarter Earnings
text: Few banks have reported much to crow about in their first-quarter earnings. But Morgan Stanley can claim relief, at least, from the $1.45 billion in net income it reported on Thursday.

headline: Colm Toibin Named Chairman of PEN World Voices Festival
text: The PEN American Center has announced that Colm Toibin will serve as the chairman of the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature beginning in 2015. Salman Rushdie has been the chairman since founding the festival in 2005.

headline: New Banksy Work Goes From Wall to Boys’ Club to Museum
text: Another day, another Banksy work – and, naturally, another ownership dispute. On Tuesday a large Banksy piece, this one showing a couple embracing while also checking their cellphones behind each other’s back, appeared on a wall near the Broad Plain Boys’ Club in Bristol, England, the artist’s hometown. The piece, which also appears on the artist’s website, was apparently on plywood and screwed to the wall – not Banksy’s usual approach, which is to paint directly onto the surface.

headline: Enrollments Exceed Obama’s Target for Health Care Act

headline: One-Fifth of China’s Farmland Is Polluted, State Study Finds
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government released a report on Thursday that said nearly one-fifth of its arable land was polluted, a finding certain to raise questions about the toxic results of China’s rapid industrialization, its lack of regulations over commercial interests and the consequences for the national food chain.

headline: Divine Decadence
text: It’s a daring thing to write about an evil person, especially in this day of autobiographical fiction, when readers assume most characters are thinly veiled self-portraits. And yet evil characters are usually dynamic and fascinating, upstaging all the goody-goodies. Think of Milton’s blazing, sexy Satan; Balzac’s scheming, driven master criminal, Vautrin; or Shakespeare’s Iago. Despite the allure of such characters, writers today usually avoid them, maybe because the whole category of Evil seems too theological or because modern psychology assumes that every bad act can be traced to childhood neglect or abuse and thus be explained away. I have to give my students an assignment to write about bad guys in order to get them to do it. But when they do write about them, it’s such a release!

headline: Updike at Rest
text: At first, he wanted to be a graphic artist. In 1954, John Updike — age 22, newly married and fresh out of Harvard, where he’d studied English literature and taken art courses — was awarded a fellowship to study abroad, and decided to apply to the Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Arts in Oxford, England. Asked to explain this decision, Updike replied, “It’s always been my ambition to be the next Walt Disney.” During his childhood in Shillington, Pa., where he lived until the age of 13 and which his readers know through his Olinger stories, his mother, Linda, arranged for her prodigiously talented son to take lessons from a local artist. Later, when they moved to Plowville, 11 miles from Shillington, to a farmhouse he would describe in his novel “Of the Farm,” Updike — now 14 or 15 — began sending his drawings and cartoons to The New Yorker and other publications. For Updike, who was interested in drawing but also, like his mother, in writing, to be published in The New Yorker had been an ambition, if not an obsession, from the moment the magazine first entered the household when he was 12.

headline: Sea Change
text: This is the latest in a series of insightful books, like “The Revenge of Geography” and “The Coming Anarchy,” in which Robert D. Kaplan, the chief geopolitical analyst at the global intelligence company Stratfor, tries to explain how geography determines destiny — and what we should be doing about it. “Asia’s Cauldron” is a short book with a powerful thesis, and it stands out for its clarity and good sense from the great mass of Western writing on what Chinese politicians have taken to calling their “peaceful development.” If you are doing business in China, traveling in Southeast Asia or just obsessing about geopolitics, you will want to read it.

headline: Live and Love for Today
text: I fell in love with a girl in high school. Nothing happened romantically between us, but we did hang out a few times. Eight years later, walking through a grocery store with my partner, I saw her again. She didn’t acknowledge me; she may not have seen me. But I felt a torrent of emotions. We are different people now, and I am with someone I care for deeply. But something about seeing her unsettled me. Whatever I felt for her, I’ve never felt again. And several times a year, I imagine my life with her in it. What should I do?

headline: Jets’ Newly Signed Running Back Denies Report That His Injured Knee Is Arthritic
text: Chris Johnson, signed by the Jets to be the breakaway runner they lacked, on Thursday disputed an ESPN report that he had developed arthritis in his surgically repaired right knee.

headline: A Provocateur’s Medium: Outrage
text: The 2012 survey of the courageous Chinese artist Ai Weiwei seen at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington has finally arrived in New York, and is much improved. The show, “Ai Weiwei: According to What?,” which opens Friday at the Brooklyn Museum, has been beefed up throughout, but most notably by two installation pieces completed in 2013. One, “S.A.C.R.E.D.,” is perhaps the best work of art Mr. Ai has yet made.

headline: MoMA Plans a Robert Gober Retrospective
text: It seems almost inconceivable that there has never been a Robert Gober retrospective in an American museum. This 59-year-old artist, who rose to prominence in the mid-1980s, is perhaps best known for his creepy sculptures of body parts — a cast wax leg or torso with individually applied hairs on them — as well as his signature sinks fashioned from plaster painted with enamel.
