headline: Adjusting for Price Inflation Isn’t Enough
text: In recent blog posts I have explained why the Democrats’ proposed increase in the minimum wage — to $10.10 an hour by 2016 — is too low. Even the much-lauded provision to annually adjust the minimum wage upward for price inflation is less than meets the eye.

headline: Sign on the Digital Dotted Line
text: In an electronic age, mortgage closings stand out as particularly cumbersome transactions. Come closing day, hundreds of pages of paper land in a thump before the borrower, who must then physically sign and initial them in dozens of places.

headline: What Eight Million Means
text: Sorry about blog silence — real life intruded, plus I did have to write a column. But I shouldn’t let the day pass without mentioning the latest big Obamacare news. Final enrollment for 2014, we now know, will be more than 8 million. The age mix has also improved, with more young people signing up at the end; as Jonathan Cohn points out in the linked article, the age mix in Obamacare’s first year is now just about identical to the age mix in Romneycare’s first year. Goodbye, death spiral.

headline: A Cozy Foursome, United in Rough-Hewed Harmony
text: In her 2011 book “Alone Together,” the social scientist Sherry Turkle describes our world as one in which technology has rendered us increasingly isolated when it comes to substantive interactions. We “friend” instead of making friends.

headline: Virtu Financial Said to Shelve I.P.O. Plans
text: The high-frequency trading firm Virtu Financial, which had expected to go public this month, has decided to postpone those plans indefinitely, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Shattering in a Space of Healing
text: In her works that bridge dance and visual art, Taisha Paggett has deconstructed the fitness craze Zumba, blindfolded herself while drawing on the walls of a room and performed as Fila Buster, a character inspired by the filibuster of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. For her latest piece, “Underwaters (we is ready, we is ready),” Ms. Paggett, shifting among four personas, holds the floor — for hours on end — as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Health Law Bellwether, UnitedHealth Posts Lower Profit
text: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, reported lower earnings on Thursday, attributing its weak results in part to the federal health care law.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Korea, India, Greece and Israel.

headline: John Turturro Narrates a Scene From ‘Fading Gigolo’
text: In this video, the actor, writer and director John Turturro discusses a sequence from his film “Fading Gigolo,” where he plays the gigolo of the title who is meeting a new client (Sofia Vergara).

headline: 2015 Rolls-Royce Ghost Series II: An Entry-Level Rolls
text: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Rolls-Royce Ghost Series II

headline: The Separate Kitchen Makes a Comeback
text: When Ashley Mabbitt was growing up in a four-bedroom house outside Chicago, her grandmother gave her this advice: “When I have people over, I like to feel I’m coming to a party. I like to take off my apron, put on lipstick, and step into a separate space.”

headline: Clinging to Minimalism, in Shadows and Whispers
text: Tahliah Barnett sings with clear voice, and she sings with her body, but on Wednesday night at Glasslands Gallery, she began her show with a whisper.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert’s New Chapter Begins
text: An Italianate Victorian mini-estate built in 1869 on a hilltop above the Delaware River by a descendant of John Reading — Colonial New Jersey’s first native-born governor — is about to enter the market at $999,000. The house has been owned for the last six years by the author Elizabeth Gilbert, whose best-selling memoir, “Eat, Pray, Love,” revolutionized the concept of self-actualization for its fans. The annual property tax is $13,688.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Clip: ‘Transcendence’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: I Am My Own Monster (Technology Rules!)
text: Johnny Depp, who’s built a brilliant career despite many of his lamentable film choices, may not be the first actor you think of to play a genius — much less humanity’s destroyer or savior. But he’s weirdly perfect in “Transcendence,” an inelegant, no doubt implausible (maybe not) science-fiction film about a futurist whose consciousness is uploaded onto the Internet. There, he (or a mysterious vestige of his being) expands like the universe, growing larger and mutating into a being who is godlike and yet far from divine, sort of like a star at the apex of his popularity.

headline: His Win Obscured, Runner Left Mark Off the Course
text: BOSTON — It was October, six months after Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia won the stricken 2013 Boston Marathon. He had returned for another race. On his way to dinner with friends, he had a request. He wanted to cross the finish line again on Boylston Street to reclaim in a private moment a triumph made irrelevant by tragedy.

headline: Remembering the Life and Work of Gabriel García Márquez
text: Gabriel García Márquez died on Thursday at 87. Over the years, as his work was reviewed in The New York Times, numerous luminaries took the opportunity to consider the great author and his work, including William Kennedy, Robert Stone and Thomas Pynchon.

headline: Even Vampires Pass the Velvet Rope
text: It wouldn’t be fair to call “Zombeavers” a “Sharknado” rip-off: The zombie-beavers film wrapped production in March 2013, four months before the shark-tornado film created a vogue for over-the-top-cheesy B movies with compound titles. But it would be fair to guess that the Tribeca Film Festival, where “Zombeavers” has its world premiere on Saturday night, wouldn’t mind if a little of that “Sharknado” magic rubbed off.

headline: Big Labels Take Aim at Pandora on Royalties
text: The music industry has opened a new front in its war against Pandora Media: royalties for songs made before 1972.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: A Win to Calm Some Nerves
text: The Red Bulls do not make things easy, but they do make them interesting.

headline: Obama Announces New Health Care Numbers
text: President Obama announced that eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: My Little Rifle
text: A Dutch photographer enters the world of real guns for real kids.

headline: In an Uneven Economy, an Opening in the Service Sector Beckons
text: The title character in “Fading Gigolo,” a low-key, low-energy comedy about New York haves and have-nots, is Fioravante, a melancholic bookstore employee played by the film’s director, John Turturro. When you first meet Fioravante, he’s packing up boxes, on the verge of becoming an ex-bookstore employee. His boss, Murray (Woody Allen), has been forced to shutter his charming shop, a painful and all-too-frequent occurrence in the real New York. In a moment of inspiration, or really creative contrivance, Murray suggests — ta-da — that Fioravante take up hooking.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Announces Her Pregnancy
text: Ms. Clinton said that she and her husband were expecting their first child this year.

headline: Mazda Commemorates the Miata’s Birthday With a Gathering of Its Classics
text: Anniversary celebrations are a recurring theme at this year’s New York auto show, and Mazda joined the party on Wednesday. Mazda’s birthday child was the Miata, the nimble two-seat sports car that set a new tone for the brand when it had its premiere at the Chicago auto show a quarter century ago. The Mazda festivities showcased a lot of what is old, with some classic and race-veteran Miatas, a bit of what is genuinely new with a chassis-only preview of the next-generation Miata and some of what is just a wee bit new in the MX-5 Miata 25th Anniversary Edition.

headline: Found Everything, Tried Everything, All His Own Way
text: Get confused is the first and last message of “Alibis: Sigmar Polke 1963-2010” at the Museum of Modern Art. And if you think, as I do, that some degree of continuing bafflement is a healthy reaction to art, this disorienting contact high of a show is for you.

headline: A Labor Leader’s Devotion to His Cause
text: “I think I know what my mission is,” says the labor leader Cesar Chavez in “Cesar’s Last Fast.” “Righting the wrongs that were committed against workers for 100 years.” Chavez  (1927-1993), a founder of what became the United Farm Workers union, faced brutal odds, as this compelling documentary demonstrates.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 18-24
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for April 18-24
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for April 18-24
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 18-24
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 18-24
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for April 18-24
text: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol
text: Sigurdur Hjartarson has a preoccupation with phalluses. It started in 1974, when he was given a bull penis as a joke, popped it in formaldehyde and decided it needed companions.

headline: SpongeBob, the Carnivore
text: The oceans are full of predators, but nobody thought sponges were among them until 1995, when scientists first realized that not all of these sedentary animals spent their days just filtering out bacteria and other micro-organisms from seawater.

headline: Dance Listings for April 18-24
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 18-24
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Waiting for ‘Waiting for Guffman,’ Sort Of
text: One day, someone will make a brilliant mockumentary about a team of filmmakers struggling to make their own Christopher Guest mockumentary. Until then, there is “Authors Anonymous,” directed by Ellie Kanner from a screenplay by David Congalton, but entirely in the vein of Mr. Guest’s “Waiting for Guffman.” The sendup’s target is a group of Los Angeles writers who meet weekly, waiting to be published.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 18-24
text: ‘MR. CHICKEE’S FUNNY MONEY’

headline: Spare Times for April 18-24
text: EASTER PARADE AND EASTER BONNET FESTIVAL (Sunday) Pedestrians will be able to step off the curb into the throng of strollers, street performers and photographers filling Fifth Avenue, from 49th to 57th Streets, for this annual event.

headline: In the City, a Fresh, Crisp Breath of Summer From the Mountains
text: The title of the program at SubCulture on Wednesday night was playfully ambiguous: “The Complete Aspen Music Festival and School (abridged).” Sounds like fun, right?

headline: In Europe, Auto Sales Are Still Low, But They Are Rising
text: European auto sales figures for March, reported today, show that slightly more new cars were sold in the euro zone during the most recent 12 months than had been sold a year earlier. The increase was a tiny one, just 0.4 percent.

headline: A Bear, Her Cubs and the Wilderness
text: Disney’s experience in the animal documentary business (as opposed to the business of talking animated animals) stretches back over half a century. Before there was today’s “Bears” there was “Bear Country,” an Academy Award winner in 1954. The newer ursine chronicle looks at one hungry year in the life of an Alaska mother and her two cubs, with typically simple storytelling and the drumbeat of the hunt for enough food to survive the winter.

headline: Global Sounds, Woven Together
text: If there is one thing that sets the MATA Festival apart from many of the other contemporary-classical bounties New York regularly produces, it might be a robust international representation, which seems to have grown sharply since Yotam Haber — a Dutch-born global citizen and the festival’s artistic director from 2009 until this year — has been at the helm. This year’s series, the 16th since MATA began in 1996, includes composers from 17 countries.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 18, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.”

headline: Once Again, Fires Burn and Caldrons Bubble
text: Well, there’s nothing halfway about WGN America’s entry into the scripted-series world. The witch-infested “Salem,” its initial offering, which has its premiere on Sunday, is brash and well executed and expensive-looking. And if you strip away the various questions and back stories involving the station’s strategy and just look at “Salem” as a television show, you’ve got to admit that it’s perversely entertaining.

headline: Deadbeat on the Range
text: Imagine a vendor on the National Mall, selling burgers and dogs, who hasn’t paid his rent in 20 years. He refuses to recognize his landlord, the National Park Service, as a legitimate authority. Every court has ruled against him, and fines have piled up. What’s more, the effluents from his food cart are having a detrimental effect on the spring grass in the capital.

headline: From Andreessen, a Lesson in Corporate Finance
text: The valuations of highflying technology companies can seem baffling to those not initiated in the ways of Silicon Valley.

headline: Capitalism and the Dalai Lama
text: WHAT can Washington, D.C., learn from a Buddhist monk?

headline: Horse Owners and Trainers Say They’ll Release Veterinary Records
text: In an effort to restore integrity and transparency to a sport battered by scandal, some of horse racing’s most prominent owners and trainers pledged Thursday to make public the veterinary records of their horses competing in high-level stakes races, including the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Abolish Horse-Drawn Carriages?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Benefits of Hospice Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Politics, a Cold Streak Can Make Loyalty Vanish
text: The standard for good old-fashioned treachery in politics is pretty low — in fact, many people think politics is a synonym for treachery. Even with that, the latest move by one of the state’s biggest business groups against the sitting lieutenant governor was breathtaking.

headline: More Senseless Gun Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unlikely Superstar Swap Could Aid Knicks
text: The Knicks completed another disappointing season Wednesday night, beating the playoff-bound Toronto Raptors before a Madison Square Garden crowd that snacked on complimentary boxes of popcorn — a thank you from the organization to fans for enduring a 41st consecutive season without a championship.

headline: ESPN Sees Continued Profitability Despite Competition
text: Aiming to squelch smoldering concerns about ESPN’s continued profitability amid rising sports rights costs, the Walt Disney Company on Thursday said profits at its ESPN-dominated cable networks unit would grow in the “high single digits” on a compounded annual basis for the next three years.

headline: Mock Gefilte Fish
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pope’s Comments on Abuse
text: To the Editor:

headline: Extend the Mideast Talks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Soaring Trips to a Temple in Nepal
text: The faces in “Manakamana,” a transporting ethnographic film set in a green sliver of Nepal, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond. The faces are sometimes creased and weathered, sometimes smooth as pebbles. A few look etched with worry, as if they were weighed down by a heavy burden, although they may also be seized with fear. That’s because for 10 or so minutes at a time, these faces are floating hundreds of feet above a lush Nepali forest in a cable car that takes pilgrims to and from the temple that gives this film its rhythmic title.

headline: Iran Gets an Unlikely Visitor, an American Plane, but No One Seems to Know Why
text: President Obama has warned that Iran is not open for business, even as the United States has loosened some of its punishing economic sanctions as part of an interim nuclear pact.

headline: Time Is Short for High-Risk Rescue Effort
text: With rising waves and swift currents off the southern coast of South Korea having largely stymied search operations around a capsized ferry late Thursday night, the fate of 271 people still missing was unknown. It was unclear even how many might still be aboard the vessel — which was underwater save for a small section of its keel — and if so whether any were in areas with pockets of air.

headline: Dierdorf, Ex-Wolverine, Joins Michigan Radio
text: When Dan Dierdorf called his final N.F.L. game for CBS Sports in January, he expected to retire from full-time work. He had two artificial hips, two artificial knees and a back in dire need of surgery.

headline: A Plea for Equal Pay for Equal Pedaling
text: You can’t exactly call “Half the Road” an infomercial for women’s cycling. It’s more like a political campaign ad disguised as a public service announcement, and the message is: Get rid of the U.C.I.’s current leaders. That’s the Union Cycliste Internationale, the organization that its detractors can’t just walk away from, because it has the power to award Olympic qualification points.

headline: Demands That Jews Register in Eastern Ukraine Are Denounced, and Denied
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Worshipers at the Bet Menakhem-Mendl synagogue in this eastern Ukrainian city confronted a horrifying scene as they left a Passover service this week: masked men on a sidewalk handing out leaflets demanding that Jews register and pay a fine or leave the area, witnesses said.

headline: Blood Ties Between Cop and Killer
text: Pulp done with passion can be its own reward, as the veteran Hong Kong filmmaker Dante Lam shows with his feverish cop thriller “That Demon Within.” Full of blood, tears and fire — from guns and gas explosions — this corpse-ridden movie wrenches us through an overheated plot involving a demon-mask-wearing gang of robbers and a mentally fragile cop. It’s none too subtle in either its sickly-green color schemes or its melodramatic logic, as timid it’s not.

headline: Merely Rich and Superrich: The Tax Gap Is Narrowing
text: Will this be the year that the superrich finally pay higher taxes than the very rich?

headline: Virginia Law Phasing Out ‘Fox Pens’ Vexes All Sides
text: STONY CREEK, Va. — Emerson Poarch Jr., 72, says his father went to his grave incredulous that hunters would pay a fee to run their hounds in a “fox pen.”

headline: When the Circus Descends
text: We are pretty familiar with this story: A perfectly sensible if slightly boring idea is walking down the street. Suddenly, the ideological circus descends, burying the sensible idea in hysterical claims and fevered accusations. The idea’s political backers beat a craven retreat. The idea dies.

headline: A Lost Soul’s Wanderings
text: Nathan Silver’s “Soft in the Head” opens in medias res, as Natalia (Sheila Etxeberría) explains to her abusive boyfriend (Nick Korbee) that she’s having a holiday dinner with her friend Hannah’s family. When this scene turns into a violent breakup, Mr. Silver disorientingly cuts to the opening titles, shown over an Orthodox Jewish candle-lighting ceremony. A sense of worlds colliding seems fundamental to the film.

headline: University of Chicago Economist Who Studies Media Receives Clark Medal
text: Matthew Gentzkow, an economics professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business who has done innovative work analyzing issues like bias in the press and the impact of the media on society, has been awarded the 2014 John Bates Clark Medal, the American Economic Association announced Thursday.

headline: Muslim Cleric ‘Was Committed to War,’ Prosecutor Says in Terrorism Trial
text: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, an Egyptian-born cleric who became prominent for his fiery sermons at a British mosque, was more than just a preacher, a federal prosecutor said on Thursday. “He was a trainer of terrorists, and he used the cover of religion so he could hide in plain sight in London.”

headline: Volvo XC90: The First of a New Breed
text: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: Volvo XC90

headline: After Tension, Lions Gate Consolidates Its Movie Marketing
text: LOS ANGELES — Lions Gate Entertainment on Thursday announced the resignation of one movie marketing chief and the promotion of another, ending one of Hollywood’s tensest working arrangements.

headline: Taxi Driver Charged in $28,000 Toll Fraud
text: Back and forth the driver went. A thousand times over the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge. Three thousand trips through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.

headline: Stranded by the Fight Over a Border’s Future
text: JERUSALEM — Abutting Israel’s separation wall, the blackened shell of a factory building known by local Palestinian residents as the station serves as a den for drug dealers and addicts. Out front, at a bend in the road, rotting trash smolders in an unofficial garbage dump as children pass on their way home from the nearby elementary school.

headline: Libraries Seek High-Speed Broadband
text: WASHINGTON — The federal E-Rate program has been a boon for schools and public libraries across the country, helping them acquire Internet access and telecommunications products at affordable or vastly discounted rates. But the sleek new computers, laptops and tablets do not mean much without high-quality broadband service to match.

headline: He Took the Dare to Change His Life
text: A study of desperation and the evil within, Daniel Stamm’s “13 Sins” is an empty, efficient thriller that leaves you as cold as most of its characters. Based on the 2006 Thai movie “13: Game of Death,” this disappointing remake is held together primarily by Mark Webber’s charged central performance as Elliot, a wimpy insurance salesman.

headline: In a Reunion, 2 Rangers and a Flyer Recall Glory
text: Ten years ago, Brad Richards, Martin St. Louis and Vincent Lecavalier were integral to the Tampa Bay Lightning’s Stanley Cup run.

headline: 2014 Soleil Anadi: Adding Some Elegance to the Corvette
text: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2014 Soleil Anadi

headline: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Adjust to New Banking Climate
text: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs had not reported earnings on the same day since the darkest phase of the financial crisis in 2008, but they did so again on Thursday.

headline: At 2014 New York Auto Show, Just Click to Kick the Tires
text: SOON after Google Street View, the Google Maps feature that provides pedestrian-level views of cities worldwide, was introduced in 2007, people who chanced to see the image-capturing cars with 360-degree cameras mounted on their roofs began to post pictures of the sightings online with the fervor of bird-watchers.

headline: Study Chides U.S. Over Loan Default by Solar Business
text: WASHINGTON — Long before the Energy Department lost $68 million on Abound Solar, a manufacturer that went bankrupt two years ago, it should have known that the company’s chance of repaying the loan it had guaranteed was deteriorating, according to a report by the department’s inspector general.

headline: Taking the Man Out of Oklahoma, Maybe
text: In “Home, James,” James is a photographer who makes most of his money as a driver for hire who transports the dissolute late-night souls of Tulsa, Okla., when they’ve had one or three too many. That’s how he first meets Cooper, a hard-drinking rich girl.

headline: The 42-Month Typo
text: No one disputes this fact: Ceasar Huerta Cantu was wrongly sentenced to three and a half extra years in federal prison because of a typo on a court document. Not his lawyer, not the prosecutor, not the judge. And yet it still took President Obama’s intervention to fix the error — two years after Mr. Cantu himself discovered it.

headline: In Scripted Surprise, Putin Answers Snowden on Spying
text: MOSCOW — The setup could not have been more perfect.

headline: Turkey’s Battle With Twitter
text: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the combative prime minister of Turkey, has called Twitter “the worst menace to society,” and he seems intent on intimidating its users.

headline: Mayor Details New Hurricane Sandy Aid Reforms
text: For thousands of New Yorkers whose homes were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, the rebuilding process has been a slog of navigating the federal bureaucracy and an alphabet soup of municipal agencies, with residents of Staten Island and the Rockaways accusing the city of paralysis and, in some cases, neglect.

headline: No Spring Break for the Unemployed
text: As members of Congress enjoy their extended spring break, 2.3 million unemployed Americans have been left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever get around to renewing federal unemployment benefits, which expired at the end of 2013. Every week that Congress fails to act, another 70,000 jobless workers will find there is no longer a federal program to turn to.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 17, 2014
text: April 17, 2014

headline: Women’s Soccer League Tries to Connect and Survive
text: GERMANTOWN, Md. — Natalie Lennartsson, a perky fourth grader who is 10 going on 17, said she didn’t learn “a ton” of new things Wednesday at a soccer clinic hosted by the Washington Spirit, the local women’s professional team.

headline: Automakers Let the Good Times Roll
text: It’s a banner time in the car industry. The products are flowing and sales numbers are high. That flush feeling coincides with the New York International Auto Show, and has prompted automakers to stage many outside events spilling over from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center into museums, restaurants and landmarks across the city.

headline: Hollywood Begs for a Tax Break in Some States, Including California
text: LOS ANGELES — The San Fernando Valley has served as home to award-winning movies like “E.T.,” “Boogie Nights” and “Crash.” But Raul Bocanegra, a state lawmaker representing a large swath of the valley, worries about the collapse of film and television production in his district and across Hollywood’s home state.

headline: Sandy Recovery Still Lagging
text: The hardest test of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s vision and competence might end up being something quite different from expanding prekindergarten or affordable housing. It might just be his ability to restore normality to the lives of tens of thousands of New Yorkers in the Hurricane Sandy zone, from the Rockaways to Staten Island, whose homes and businesses were washed away or ruined a year and a half ago. And, once that job is done, preparing the city to weather the inevitable and potentially disastrous storms to come.

headline: Salvation Gets Cheap
text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which pools the efforts of scientists around the globe, has begun releasing draft chapters from its latest assessment, and, for the most part, the reading is as grim as you might expect. We are still on the road to catastrophe without major policy changes.

headline: Passover in the Confederacy
text: For at least one night each spring during the Civil War, in places like Louisiana and South Carolina and Georgia and Virginia, Confederate Jews commemorated how God freed the children of Israel from slavery. They retold the story of when God is said to have sent down 10 plagues to help free the Hebrews from their bondage, the last of which was the slaying of all Egyptians’ firstborn children, and how the Jews marked their door posts with the blood of a slaughtered lamb so the Angel of Death would know to “pass over” them. Thus, they celebrated their liberation more than 3,000 years ago from slavery in ancient Egypt, and their exodus.

headline: Don’t Just Pass the Joint, Sell It
text: Selling or using marijuana remains illegal in plenty of states, but on screen, the underground marijuana business is already being treated with a “Happy Days” glow of nostalgia. That’s the tone of “Kid Cannabis,” a rollicking tale of border-running teenage pot entrepreneurs based on the real-life story of Nate Norman.

headline: Toe to Toe With the N.R.A.
text: What will Michael Bloomberg's planned $50-million campaign for gun control need to do to succeed?

headline: Live, and Online: Poison
text: Millions of Chinese are watching live interactive web entertainment, like the popular karaoke performer seen in this clip, who goes by the stage name Poison.

headline: Lucrative Stardom in China, Using a Webcam and a Voice
text: ZIGONG, China — Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke.

headline: Measure to Repeal Death Penalty Fails by a Single Vote in New Hampshire Senate
text: CONCORD, N.H. — In a tie vote, the New Hampshire Senate deadlocked Thursday on whether to repeal the death penalty, leaving the current law intact and New Hampshire as the lone state in New England that allows the execution of anyone convicted of a capital crime.

headline: Nigeria Fears Captive Girls Will Be Held as Sex Slaves
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — Dozens of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants in northeastern Nigeria this week remained missing on Thursday amid fears that they would be turned into “sex slaves and cooks” if they were not rescued, a top official in the region said.

headline: After the Violence, the Real Pain Begins
text: A bizarre puzzle box of twisted passions and psychological sickness, Zack Parker’s “Proxy” presents us almost immediately with a scene of such repulsive brutality that the film seems to be daring us to keep watching. If you accept, you’ll find yourself wading waist-deep into the swampy center of an original if overlong story about manufactured grief and disturbingly bad mothering.

headline: Entwining Tales of Time, Memory and Love
text: The Magus of magical realism, Gabriel García Márquez — who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87 — used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction: plagues of insomnia and forgetfulness, a cluster of magical grapes containing the secret of death, an all-night rain of yellow blossoms, a swamp of lilies oozing blood, a Spanish galleon marooned in a Latin American jungle, cattle born bearing the brand of their owner.

headline: Tip Well: It’s Your Waiter’s Last Night
text: “Tasting Menu” cites as inspirations the 2011 closing of El Bulli, the acclaimed Catalan restaurant that showcased its visionary chef, Ferran Adrià, as well as culinary cinema like “Big Night” and “Babette’s Feast.” Unfortunately, Roger Gual’s half-baked film hopes to split the difference between romantic comedy and foodie delight but fails at both.

headline: Gotta Dance (Together)
text: O.K., it’s not Montagues and Capulets, it’s rival Brooklyn dance clubs: the gritty, underground Static and the more upper-crust Oto. The star-crossed lovers are Donny (Derek Hough), a street dancer and parolee from New Orleans, and Aya (the South Korean pop star BoA), a Korean dancer-drummer raised in Japan. Static’s owner is Donny’s foster brother, Nick (Wesley Jonathan), who had a falling-out with his partner, Kaz (Will Yun Lee of “Hawaii Five-O”), Aya’s overprotective brother. Kaz went to work at Oto, which is owned by the Wall Street knave Michael (Jefferson Brown), who has designs on Aya and wants her at his beck and call.

headline: Mummy Dearest, Back for More
text: As soon as a playhouse announces a Charles Ludlam comedy, how sellers of Velcro and cheap wigs must rejoice. When Ludlam died in 1987, he left behind a flamboyant, genre-defying oeuvre that depends on outrageous, easily doffed costumes. In “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful,” revived by Red Bull Theater at the Lucille Lortel Theater, two stalwart actors (Arnie Burton and Robert Sella) shift gowns, trousers, fezzes and the occasional wooden leg faster than laws of space and time would seem to permit.

headline: In the Spotlight, Finding His Religion
text: If only the Tony Awards nominating committee would see fit to expand its categories, I could confidently predict at least two eminently deserving winners. For best performance by two actors in the same role ... (hold your breath, nibble your nails) ...sorry, no suspense here, folks.

headline: Fame-Hating Lewis Carroll Letter Lands in Los Angeles
text: A letter by Lewis Carroll declaring his hatred for fame and sometime wish that he had never written “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” has now found a home in the epicenter of the global celebrity hellscape: Los Angeles.

headline: Learn to Teach
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I just barely got a toehold in James Mulhern’s puzzle today. The clues seemed unusually cryptic for my money (not cryptic crossword style, just out of my reach). That’s not a bad thing. Most solvers like to wrap their brains around some difficult cluing and new, crunchy words, and this puzzle delivers.

headline: A Chip Off the Old Engine Block
text: In the deadly voice-over that begins Joel Surnow’s “Small Time,” a man declares: “This is the story about my father and the summer we spent together many years ago. It was the summer that changed my life.”

headline: Obama on Ukraine Pact
text: After a diplomatic agreement to ease tensions in Ukraine was reached, the president expressed skepticism about Russia’s promise to de-escalate the volatile situation.

headline: Deal is Reached to Ease Tension in East Ukraine
text: GENEVA — The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday evening that called for armed pro-Russian bands in eastern Ukraine to surrender the government buildings they have seized and that outlined other steps to defuse a crisis that has rattled the international community.

headline: That Thing He Had for the Boss’s Wife
text: An unconsummated long-distance passion that resists the erosion of time and memory is the subject of the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig’s posthumously published novella, “Journey Into the Past.” When addressed in the movies, this kind of longing is usually diluted into soap opera and its darker psychological implications suffocated by a gauzy romanticism. The French director Patrice Leconte’s film, “A Promise,” adapted from the novella, is no exception.

headline: Unmoved, Anthony Is Still on Fence Over Future
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Not so long ago, Carmelo Anthony made a public appearance in which he expressed his desire to test free agency. He wanted to explore his options, he said, although he emphasized that his preference was to remain with the Knicks.

headline: Rancher Says Utility Put Power Line in Wrong Place
text: RHOME, Tex. — Johnny Vinson is not your typical underdog. At 82, he is a rancher who has sold more land than most rural Texans could imagine owning. And he has plenty left to stand on, including more than 3,500 acres in Wise County that have ample room for dozens of gas wells, grazing cattle, a ranch house and staff living quarters.

headline: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
text: As the fourth anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill approaches, on April 20, arguments will rage about who should have done what and when. The advocacy documentary “Vanishing Pearls,” which opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles and will have one-night engagements in cities across the country over the next three months, makes an impassioned case that the spill’s effects still linger.

headline: Christie Appoints an Ombudsman
text: Continuing his efforts to move past the scandal surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closings, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Thursday named an ombudsman to strengthen ethics policies in his office, and eliminated the department that an internal investigation found had rewarded and punished mayors across the state depending on whether they supported the governor’s re-election.

headline: Clinton Backer Pleads Guilty in a Straw Donor Scheme
text: As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ran for president in 2008, one of her most enthusiastic financial supporters was Sant Singh Chatwal, an Indian-American hotel and restaurant owner, whose relationship with the Clintons dated back years.

headline: U.N. Council Takes Up Question of Rights in North Korea
text: The United Nations appeared to move a step closer on Thursday to holding North Korea’s government accountable for what an investigative panel has called a history of crimes against humanity and egregious human rights abuses, as the Security Council convened a special session to hear the panel’s views on what should be done.

headline: A Couple of Heirs of Travis Bickle
text: A 34-year-old messenger still living at home, Rupert Pupkin (Robert De Niro) dreams of becoming a stand-up comedy star. To force fate’s hand, he stalks and kidnaps his idol, the TV talk show host Jerry Langford (Jerry Lewis). Martin Scorsese’s 1983 movie “The King of Comedy” not only told a story but identified a malaise. Call it Pupkinitis.

headline: Turkey: Intelligence Bill Approved
text: Turkey’s Parliament on Thursday passed a bill that increases the powers of the national spy agency and strengthens its immunity, a move that critics said would allow Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan to bolster his control over state institutions. The measure, which requires presidential approval before it becomes a law, would give the National Intelligence Organization, known by the initials of its Turkish name M.I.T., access to information collected by public and private institutions without a court order and would expand its ability to carry out covert operations. Government officials said the changes would make the agency more efficient and provide protections for its personnel. Mr. Erdogan has been tightening his grip on state agencies as his government deals with accusations of corruption and has tried to block or control access to the Internet, Twitter and YouTube. “With this legislation, the M.I.T. is no longer a national intelligence agency but has become the prime minister’s intelligence agency,” said an opposition lawmaker, Sezgin Tanrikulu.

headline: Congo: Park Director Survives Shooting
text: Emmanuel de Merode, an internationally recognized Belgian conservationist who has been working to protect rare mountain gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is recovering from gunshot wounds after being attacked Tuesday by unknown assailants, officials said Thursday. Mr. de Merode, 43, the director of the Virunga National Park, Africa’s oldest national park, was attacked by the gunmen as he drove near Goma, not far from the border with Rwanda. He was taken to a hospital in Goma, where he underwent surgery. Mr. de Merode, above, is a Belgian prince and is married to Louise Leakey, a Kenyan paleontologist and the granddaughter of the archaeologist Louis Leakey, known for his studies on human evolution in Africa. Virunga National Park was established in 1925 by Belgium, which then governed Congo.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Sabathia Overcomes an Ace and a Dome, With Help From a Triple Play
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Yangervis Solarte has had many firsts since joining the Yankees this year, including his first major league game and his first hit. On Thursday, he added to his collection with his first major league home run and his first triple play at any level.

headline: Senate Seat That Davis Leaves Behind Looks Crucial
text: The two Republicans campaigning to replace State Senator Wendy Davis, the Fort Worth Democrat who is running for governor, are locked in a tight primary runoff battle.

headline: Cost of Treatment May Influence Doctors
text: Saying they can no longer ignore the rising prices of health care, some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care.

headline: After Hit to Mouth, Rangers Draw First Blood
text: The Rangers took full advantage of a rookie’s mistake and a teammate’s bloodied mouth to break open their Stanley Cup opener Thursday night.

headline: South Korea Ferry Updates
text: Officials discussed the latest developments in the search for passengers trapped inside the ferry that sank in the waters off southwestern South Korea.

headline: Rangers-Flyers Playoff Series
text: Action from the Rangers’ 4-1 victory over Philadelphia in the opener of their Eastern Conference series.

headline: Sebelius Says She’s Not Interested in Senate Run
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the soon-to-be former secretary of the Health and Human Services Department, said through a spokeswoman on Thursday that she was not interested in running for the Senate in Kansas, despite recent entreaties from Democrats.

headline: Messages From Students on South Korean Ferry
text: As a South Korean ferry began sinking with 475 people believed to be aboard — 325 of them students from Danwon High School — passengers reached for their cellphones and began sending messages to their loved ones. The following are transcripts of those exchanges.

headline: García Márquez, Magical Realism Master
text: Gabriel García Márquez, the Nobel laureate Colombian author whose “One Hundred Years of Solitude” established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City.

headline: Alternative to Carriage Has Little Horsepower
text: The horse of the future could be an electric car with an “ah-ooga horn” and seating for eight.

headline: Three Pitches, Nine Outs
text: The Yankees’ last three triple plays have come with C. C. Sabathia on the mound.

headline: Another Charge in Navy Bribe Case
text: A Navy enlisted man was charged in a complaint unsealed Thursday with accepting $1,000-a-month in cash, trips and consumer electronics for supplying a Malaysian contractor with sensitive Navy ship schedules. The petty officer, Dan Layug, 27, was the fourth Navy employee arrested in the case, which has also led to charges against the contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, for conspiring to bribe officials to inflate his billings. Prosecutors say Mr. Layug, who was released on a $100,000 bond, deposited payments from Mr. Francis’s company, Glenn Defense Marine Asia, in a bank account in the name of his infant daughter.

headline: Officials in Rhythmic Gymnastics Judging Scandal Are Said to Be Exonerated
text: Citing a lack of evidence, the Court of Arbitration for Sport has exonerated six officials who were implicated in a judging scandal, annulling a decision by the governing body for rhythmic gymnastics.

headline: A New, Cowboy-Inspired Fashion Frontier
text: Then and now, the rugged on-screen apparel of the cinematic heroes Clint Eastwood and John Wayne serves as an iconic expression of American style. This season, their characters’ Wild West legacy lives on in fashion’s frontier as the influence for spring collections by the likes of Junya Watanabe, Paco Rabanne, Creatures of the Wind and Valentino. Designers took visual cues from the cowboy uniform — distressed denim, fringe, turquoise, embroidery and, of course, boots — to create separates that come together for a fully transportive look. But if a head-to-toe Annie Oakley-influenced ensemble isn’t your modus operandi, pairing any of these individual items with monochromatic basics — a white tee with Junya Watanabe jeans or a black dress with a cashmere Elder Statesman bandana — will keep things relevant and fresh.

headline: Police Capture and Question Suspect in Shooting of Brooklyn Teenager
text: New York City detectives on Thursday night were questioning a suspect in a daytime shooting in Brooklyn that severely wounded a 13-year-old bystander this week, the police said.

headline: Events in New Jersey for April 20-26, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Ask Well: Are Exercise Cool-Downs Necessary?

headline: 2 Men Get $18 Million Each in Wrongful Conviction Case
text: Thirty years ago, a 16-year-old girl, Theresa Fusco, was found raped and strangled near the roller skating rink on Long Island where she worked. Not long afterward, prosecutors charged three men, who were convicted and went on to spend 18 years in prison.

headline: Nina Cassian, Romanian Poet Exiled for Skewering Regime, Dies at 89
text: Nina Cassian, an exiled Romanian poet who sought refuge in the United States after her poems satirizing the regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu fell into the hands of his secret police, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: With Cuomo’s Help, M.T.A. and Union Reach a Deal
text: When the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved its budget in December, agency documents warned that any increases in labor costs could have devastating consequences.

headline: Man Critically Injured in Hit-and-Run
text: A restaurant deliveryman was clinging to life Thursday night after he was struck by a vehicle in East Harlem, the police said.

headline: India Election Digest: April 18
text: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Voter turnout rose in most districts in the fifth phase of the elections compared with 2009, the Indian National Congress appears to be missing its youth unit, and voters at the world’s highest polling station remain optimistic that someday a politician will visit them.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Nat Geo Wild) CESAR MILLAN: LOVE MY PIT BULL Once upon a time, the pit bull was a popular family pet beloved by President Theodore Roosevelt, Gen. George S. Patton and Helen Keller. Today, these dogs are more closely associated with gangs and dogfighting, and have been responsible for a large percentage of fatal dog attacks on humans. Pit bulls are often abused or abandoned, and are euthanized at a higher rate than other dogs, with an estimated one million put down each year in the United States. In this special, Mr. Millan chronicles the history of the pit bull as a herder and companion — in Britain, the Staffordshire bull terrier was nicknamed “the nanny dog” for its sweet disposition with children — and with his own pit bull, Junior (above, with Mr. Millan), makes the case for the dogs as loyal and loving, given the right training for both animals and humans. “All dogs are great companions,” he says. “Communication creates a partnership, and dogs have the simplest communication on the planet. For them, everything is about trust, respect and love.”

text: Also on the Minute, an uncertain outcome after talks on Ukraine and Gabriel García Márquez departs, leaving behind his seminal literature.

headline: Scandal Downs Chairman of a Top Chinese State Company
text: For a year, the chairman of one of China’s biggest state corporations, China Resources, seemed immune to allegations that he had embroiled the company in corruption. That was until a reporter went public with the additional accusation that the chairman, Song Lin, kept a mistress who laundered his money.

headline: A Fractured Vote in Old Delhi Market
text: NEW DELHI — On a hot afternoon in the first week of April, as the ancient wholesale market of Chandni Chowk buzzed with frenetic activity, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, the Bharatiya Janata Party candidate from the neighborhood, appeared in the middle of the market.

headline: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
text: JINDO, South Korea — The captain and two crew members of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 270 people — most of them students — missing, were arrested early Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Prominent Scientist Welcomes Soil Pollution Report
text: Updated, 1:43 p.m. |

headline: Nationalist Leader in Scotland Wagers Career on Independence Vote
text: EDINBURGH — ALEX SALMOND means to lead Scotland into independence and, after 307 years of union with England, Scots have little more than five months to decide whether to follow him.

headline: Chinese Court Sentences 4 Activists to Jail
text: Amid intense security, a court in Beijing sentenced four more men to prison on Friday for their roles in the New Citizens Movement, a loose group of activists who called on government officials to disclose their financial assets.
