text: Good Friday morning on this Good Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Built on Brotherhood, Club Lives Up to Name
text: BUCHAREST — Aime Lema arrived first. It was earlier than Lema — the coach of A.S.F. Fratia Bucharest, a middle-of-the-pack team in the Romanian fifth division — would normally arrive for a game. But this day was different; it was his first day in charge.

headline: The Season of the Zipper
text: I’m so glad it’s spring because I won’t get stuck in my down coat anymore. Several times I had to put my hands over my head and get peeled out of it — once at a restaurant.

headline: Assad Campaigns for Re-election in Syria
text: Officials in Damascus have declared that a presidential vote will be held within months. President Bashar al-Assad is expected to win.

headline: Facebook’s Existential Crisis
text: Lately, I have found myself on Facebook, mindlessly scrolling through links to listicles, clicking through bizarre photo albums of cute snail portraits and halfheartedly skimming updates from people whose names I no longer recognize with little to no recollection about how I ended up on the site or why.

headline: Mortgage Reform Is Worth the Small Extra Cost to Borrowers
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: April 18, 1923: Yankee Stadium Opens to Public
text: It took 11 months and cost $2.5 million to build the original Yankee Stadium. And when it opened 91 years ago, the team announced that 99,200 fans showed up, with 25,000 turned away. Babe Ruth hit a home run, driving in three runs in the Yankees’ 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Here is how The Times covered the game.

headline: Daily Report: Stardom in China Takes a Webcam and a Voice
text: Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke, David Barboza reports.

headline: ‘Ai Weiwei: According to What?’
text: A look at the Ai Weiwei survey at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: ScienceTake: Killer Sponges
text: Sedentary sponges have evolved some fearsome weapons for trapping and devouring small prey.

headline: The Works of Cornelia Gurlitt
text: An exhibition in Germany is dedicated to the little-known artworks of the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was seized in Munich.

headline: Jacques Servier, 92, Dies; Accused of Hiding the Risks of Drugs
text: PARIS — Jacques Servier, who created one of the biggest pharmaceutical companies in France but whose life’s work was overshadowed by allegations that he concealed the dangers of drugs that he helped develop, died on Wednesday at his home in a suburb of Paris. He was 92.

headline: New Batch of Clinton Documents Is Released
text: WASHINGTON — The National Archives on Friday released its largest batch yet of previously withheld documents from the Clinton administration, with topics including the conflicts in Somalia and Rwanda, Middle East peace negotiations, the Oklahoma City bombing and public figures as varied as Richard M. Nixon and Oprah Winfrey.

headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
text: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

headline: Gag Order From Israeli Court Raises Questions
text: Updated, 10:42 a.m.

headline: Sympathy for a Rat
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Listen Up | Oh Land, the Pop Star Who Can’t Forget Her Moment as a Ballerina
text: Before she came to public attention as the ethereal electro-pop siren Oh Land, the Danish musician Nanna Fabricius was a small-town girl who dreamed of becoming a ballerina. She left home for Stockholm at age 15 to pursue those ambitions until a back injury ended her career. Still, she often dreams about her first creative pursuit. An actual dream, in fact, inspired her new music video for “Cherry on Top,” a twinkling ballad on her 2013 album “Wish Bone,” produced by TV on the Radio’s Dave Sitek. In it, she went into a dance studio — only to discover that she wasn’t a dancer, she was a piano player. The dream seemed an apt expression for the song, which, she explains, is about “taking off the blinders and seeing the world all around you.”

headline: Obama in Asia
text: The pivot to Asia is yet again weighed down with baggage.

headline: A Hidden Art Trove and a Lost Relative
text: HOCHSTADT, Germany — Last November, Hubert Portz was at his home in Hochstadt, southwest of Mannheim, reading a story in the morning newspaper when he came across a familiar name, causing his heart to skip a beat.

headline: Clinton Publisher Settles on Title for New Memoir
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s coming memoir about her tenure as Secretary of State will be titled “Hard Choices,” her publisher said early Friday.

headline: Most G-7 Nations Still Trying to Recoup Lost Jobs
text: MORE than six years after the Great Recession began, people in most industrialized countries are still less likely to be employed than they were before the downturn.

headline: Study of Moon’s Atmosphere Ends With Planned Crash
text: NASA’s Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer spacecraft slammed into the moon early Friday morning, as planned, but a few days earlier than NASA officials expected.

headline: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — An American-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat on Friday as pro-Russian militants vowed to stay in occupied government buildings, dashing hopes of a swift end to an insurgency that the authorities in Kiev portray as a Kremlin-orchestrated effort to put Ukraine’s industrial heartland under Russian control.

headline: Coachella 2014: Selfies (and Outkast) in the Desert
text: Now that the Coachella dust has been washed down 90,000 shower drains by the disappearing California water supply, it’s time to apply some music criticism and lifestyle journalism in this week’s Popcast.

headline: On Geeshie Wiley’s Trail
text: When I first started doing research for John Jeremiah Sullivan for his article about Geeshie Wiley and Elvie Thomas, two women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace, I kept Wiley’s song “Last Kind Words Blues” on repeat for days. I hadn’t listened closely to her songs before this project, but I was aware of the mythology around them. Now, I found myself hearing something new: a haunting, a mystery.

headline: Slopestyle Asks, When Is a Risky Sport Too Dangerous?
text: No sports discipline — not even boxing — has been dropped from the modern Olympics because it was too dangerous, and it would still be quite a surprise if slopestyle became the first.

headline: Who Made That Relief Pitcher?
text: In April 1903, a writer for Sporting Life described what might have been a baseball first: “Manager McGraw has originated a new plan,” the paper said, referring to John McGraw, the successful skipper of the New York Giants. “He will use two pitchers in every game, one being in the points five innings and the other four. No manager but one who has originality and nerve would attempt any such innovation, but McGraw has both.”

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Transcendence,’ ‘Fading Gigolo’ and ‘Manakamana’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: How Payday Lenders Prey Upon the Poor — and the Courts Don’t Help
text: In 2003, Tonya Burke was living in North Carolina with her two children when she got into financial trouble. She had fallen $500 behind on her rent and utilities, and neither of her boys’ fathers was able to chip in. Then she needed to take time off from work when her younger son, who was only 8 months old, had to have emergency intestinal surgery. After his recovery, she started working for $11 an hour as a secretary, “but my paychecks weren’t enough to cover the back bills and the new ones too,” she says. “I was at a point in my life where I didn’t want to ask anyone else for help.” There was a payday lender across the street from her office. “It seemed like a good solution.”

headline: The Million-Dollar Manhattan Apartment
text: With a budget of about $1 million, Patricia Marx began looking for a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in Manhattan last fall. She soon realized just how limited her options were.

headline: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour
text: The French-Canadian head chef of M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse reflects on his fondness for his wife, the borough of Queens and cooking veal brains for customers.

headline: From Fan Letter to Pen Pal
text: In 2003, the poet Laura Sims wrote a gushing fan letter to the experimental-fiction writer David Markson. (“ ‘Perfect’ is the one word I would choose to describe your work as a whole,” she wrote.) “Fare Forward,” a new book, collects Markson’s side of their ensuing correspondence, which continued until 2010, when he died at 82.

headline: Lives of the Poets
text: HOLDING ON UPSIDE DOWN  The Life and Work of Marianne Moore  By Linda Leavell  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHO OWNS THE FUTURE?,  by Jaron Lanier. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Lanier follows up the boldly predictive “You Are Not a Gadget” (2010) with a jeremiad against the concentration of money and power in our digital networks. Chief among his targets are “Siren Servers” — social media, financial institutions, intelligence agencies — that depend on accumulating and evaluating consumer data without acknowledging a monetary debt to the people mined for all this “free” information.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MONEY: The Unauthorized Biography,  by Felix ­Martin. (Knopf, $27.95.) Examining the nature and history of money, as well as its politicization, an economist and former World Bank official argues that it is a “social technology.”

headline: At Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball, Some Words From Ai Weiwei and Unusual Doughnuts
text: Ai Weiwei, Jenny Holzer and Kehinde Wiley were among the honorees at the Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball, an annual benefit gala that draws a mix of the cultural and civic establishment and young up-and-coming artists. The real estate leaders and philanthropists Jane and David Walentas, developers of Dumbo and Jane’s Carousel, were also honored at the Wednesday event; the fountain in front of the museum was named in their behalf.

headline: Dream Girls
text: What to do with the teenage girl as subject? She has been much maligned in the pages of our literature — Shirley Jackson’s homicidal Merricat in “We Have Always Lived in the Castle,” or Jeffrey Eugenides’s suiciding sisters. Even in less lethal incarnations, young girls in novels take advantage or are taken advantage of. The question of innocence is central — there is always virginity, literal and metaphorical, to be considered — and virtue is prized above all else.

headline: Innocence Project
text: Hindsight is a wonderful thing. But in fiction it can take on a whole new power — blunderingly obvious or brightly illuminating, depending on how imaginatively it’s applied. Rare is the contemporary novel that doesn’t set out, at least in part, to examine the effects of past behavior on present outcomes. While this can lead to pungent and suspenseful storytelling, it requires a delicate balance, keeping the reader engaged in the narrative momentum of an unknown future that’s already in the past. In her perceptive, empathetic and often emotionally gripping new novel, Leah Hager Cohen — author of the acclaimed “The Grief of Others” — has managed the trick very deftly.

headline: Three Siblings and a Murder
text: Peter Ackroyd’s new book begins like a fairy tale: “In the London borough of Camden, in the middle of the last century, there lived three brothers.” And a wondrous set of boys they are, having been born at precisely midday on May 8 of three successive years. This coincidence — only the first of many in Ackroyd’s breezy contrivance of a novel — signals an “invisible communion” among the brothers that will link their fates even as they set out on radically different paths through life. In the end, true to the Grimm Brothers template, only one will endure his personal ordeal and emerge relatively unscathed; the other two wind up succumbing to the wiles of the true hero of the piece — the city of London itself, the only character in the book the author actually seems to care about.

headline: Predator and Prey
text: Nevada Barr has been brooding about the primal bonds between man and nature ever since her first mystery, “Track of the Cat,” came out more than 20 years ago. While respectfully acknowledging the forces of nature (the rampaging forest fire in “Firestorm” comes to mind, as does the harsh terrain of “Winter Study”), she has always found humans to be the more savage. In DESTROYER ANGEL (Minotaur, $26.99), Barr takes this insight to a disturbing new level by allowing her series detective, the National Park Service ranger Anna Pigeon, to test her belief that “animals were better people than people.” In order to survive, can she revert to her own animal nature, hunting and killing other human beings?

headline: Let’s Have a Dialogue
text: Plato has begun to appear in some unexpected places. On the first track of Jay-Z and Kanye West’s hip-hop album, “Watch the Throne” (2011), you can pick out the line, “Is Pious pious cause God loves pious?” This, as classicists will instantly recognize, is an allusion to a dilemma posed in Plato’s dialogue “Euthyphro,” in which Socrates asks, “Is the pious loved by the gods because it is pious, or is it pious because it is loved by the gods?” In Rebecca Newberger Goldstein’s new book, “Plato at the Googleplex: Why Philosophy Won’t Go Away,” Plato turns up not only at the search engine’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., but also with the obstreperous host of a cable news talk show, as a consultant to an advice columnist, and in several other places a long way from ancient Athens. In Goldstein’s neat finale, the pupil of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle eagerly disappears into the magnetic bowels of an fM.R.I. scanner to have his brain probed.

headline: Missing Links
text: In the summer of 1981, a Swedish graduate student named Svante Paabo filled a laboratory at the University of Uppsala with the stench of rotting liver. Paabo was supposed to be studying viruses, but he had become secretly obsessed with a more exotic line of research: extracting DNA from Egyptian mummies. No one at the time had any idea if the desiccated flesh of pharaohs still contained any genetic material, so Paabo decided to run an experiment. He bought a piece of calf’s liver and put it in a lab oven at about 120 degrees for a few days to approximate mummification. In the dried, blackened lump of meat, he succeeded in finding scattered fragments of DNA.

headline: Taken for a Ride
text: Last year, after admitting he had used performance-enhancing drugs during his professional cycling career, Lance Armstrong sat down with the New York Times reporter Juliet Macur to defend his legacy. He reminded her that many riders had used such drugs. What distinguished Armstrong, in his view, was his competitive will. “I definitely wanted to win at all costs,” he told Macur.

headline: Spare the Advice
text: Almost from the birth of “development” as a concept in modern political economy, poverty has been regarded as a problem in search of technical solutions. The key, we’re told, is finding the correct mixture of policies to promote agriculture, reform financial markets or improve health. With the right mix of prescriptions, results come down mostly to ­implementation.

headline: The Women Behind the Bomb
text: Curious about the strange happenings on New Mexico’s Pajarito Plateau in the early 1940s, some of us might have read Robert Jungk’s “Brighter Than a Thousand Suns.” Or Richard Rhodes’s “The Making of the Atomic Bomb.” Perhaps, wishing for a more personal touch, we picked up Peggy Pond Church’s beautiful remembrance, “The House at Otowi Bridge,” learning about the enigmatic Edith Warner and her teahouse, which counted among its customers J. Robert Oppenheimer and Niels Bohr. Maybe, turning to Jennet Conant’s “109 East Palace,” we relived the Los Alamos story through the eyes of Dorothy McKibben, the widow who met the arriving scientists at a storefront one block from the Santa Fe Plaza, the first stop on what would be a long, strange ride.

headline: Language Without a Country
text: Like many admired writers from small countries, Josep Pla is largely unknown outside his native Catalonia. Not that Catalonia is a country as such, but the Catalan language has long been a proud symbol of the region’s separate identity from the rest of Spain. And Pla, who died in 1981 at the age of 84, is a recognized master of this language. Yet only now is any of his immense body of work being translated into English.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Best Years of Our Lives: New on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11 is “The Opposite of Loneliness,” by Marina Keegan, the 22-year-old writer who died in a car accident two years ago. A precocious poet, playwright and fiction writer who had graduated from Yale just days before, Keegan was on her way to her father’s 55th-birthday party when her boyfriend lost control of the car they were riding in. The car hit a guardrail and flipped over twice. He escaped unharmed, but she died at the scene.

headline: Japan Plans to Resume Whaling Program, With Changes to Address Court Concerns
text: TOKYO — In a move likely to bring renewed international criticism, Japan said Friday that it wants to resume its research whaling in the Southern Ocean next year under a redesigned program that would address objections raised by an international court.

headline: Today in Small Business: Bacon-Filled Chocolate Bunnies
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Italian Bank Increases Planned Share Sale to $6.9 Billion
text: ROME – Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italy’s third-largest bank, plans to offer investors as much as 5 billion euros, or $6.9 billion, in new stock as it fights to avoid nationalization and braces for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators, the lender announced on Friday.

headline: A Formal Setting
text: A few weeks ago, when I was tidying my apartment, my vacuum bumped against something under the bed. Curious, I moved the bed and discovered two wooden chests of silverware, and within them, funny, long-winded notes from my mother, detailing how many knives, forks and baby spoons each one held.

headline: How Hollywood Killed Death
text: Death in the blockbusters of 2013 played out something like this:

headline: Don’t Get Too Cute With Your Bloody Mary
text: I didn’t always like bloody marys. I blame an early childhood incident in which we coated our collie with tomato juice after a run-in with a skunk. (The juice was supposed to make the stench go away.) But my mother, who considered the viscous vermilion swill a tonic for nearly any affliction, loved them. So I was more than happy to make them for her now and then: All it took was a good slug of Smirnoff (the only vodka we had in the house, and one I still like), a can of tomato juice (or, as my mother sometimes preferred, Clamato), a shake of Lea & Perrins Worcestershire sauce, a heaping teaspoon of grated horseradish, a few shakes of black pepper, a good stir with ice, a lemon wedge for garnish, and that was that.

headline: Reply All: The 4.6.14 Issue
text: THE WOLF HUNTERS OF WALL STREET

headline: I Can’t Sue the Rain
text: Jazz for tots; Kate Upton vs. Upton Sinclair.

headline: Does Everyone Have the Right to Conjugal Visits?
text: Earlier this year, the Mississippi Department of Corrections decided to stop offering hourlong conjugal visits, depriving about 155 inmates (out of more than 22,000 statewide) the opportunity to cozy up with their husbands or wives. Officials cited budgetary constraints and prison pregnancies as the reasons for ending conjugal visits. Is it ethical to suddenly deny prisoners conjugal visits when they’ve been offered them before? Relatedly, is it ethical for taxpayers to carry the costs associated with the incarcerated mother’s pregnancy and delivery? Would it be ethical to allow only conjugal visits for those who agreed to use birth control? R.J.W., WYNNEWOOD, PA.

headline: Isle of No Man
text: North Brother Island is New York’s miniature Detroit, without the industry — a 20-acre, un-High Line-ed wilderness of trees and vines and abandoned, crumbling buildings in the treacherous tidal strait where the waters of New York Harbor trade places with those of Long Island Sound. It has been uninhabited for 50 years and off limits to all but biologists for more than a decade; the city manages it as a nature preserve. While it has always felt secret-filled, it now has a new one, which can be glimpsed in the photographer Christopher Payne’s new book, “North Brother Island: The Last Unknown Place in New York City”: When a vast swath of trees was recently cut down in the Bronx for development, the island’s forest, created by neglect, became the largest in the South Bronx. ﻿Robert Sullivan

headline: Sia Furler, the Socially Phobic Pop Star
text: Sia Furler walked into the Silver Lake studio 10 minutes late, ignoring the 22 keyboards and six guitars and giant speakers on her way to the blue velour sofa in the back. There she pulled a MacBook Air from her white Goyard bag and called up “Living Out Loud,” a song she had just started writing. As the music played, Furler began scat-singing: “Ha-ha-ha-ha!”

headline: On the Liberal Bias of Facts
text: “The facts have a well-known liberal bias,” declared Rob Corddry way back in 2004 — and experience keeps vindicating his joke. But why?

headline: 2015 Subaru Outback: Some Pizazz for a Redesigned Wagon
text: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Subaru Outback.

headline: Think Back: New York World’s Fair, 1964
text: The organizers of the New York World’s Fair billed the event as one for the ages, but it failed to leave a lasting mark on the culture. The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains why.

headline: Ferry Inquiry Focuses on Captain
text: As the search for victims entered its third day, Park Jae-Uk, the senior investigator, said the ship’s captain was not at the steering house when the ferry started sinking.

headline: The King Can No Longer Afford Queens
text: Far too often, over the past few years we have read about Brooklyn as a marketable commodity — its aesthetic, lifestyle and twee products coveted and exportable. But the 50th anniversary of the 1964 World’s Fair in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park would seem an appropriate time to reflect on Queens: The Brand.

headline: The Fair to End All Fairs
text: When you drive by on the Van Wyck Expressway or the Grand Central Parkway, the space-age towers of the New York State Pavilion, among the few remaining traces of the 1964 New York World’s Fair, rise up from the trees like a relic of some vanished, Jetsonian civilization, and the people who built them seem much more than 50 years distant from us. They were people apparently inspired by the idea of progress, and by a now quaint-seeming faith in the future, who actually believed in things like world’s fairs. Who would think of organizing such an event now? Who would pay for it? Who would bother to go?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Asia’s Cauldron’
text: This week, Robert D. Kaplan discusses “Asia’s Cauldron”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss this year’s Pulitzer Prizes; William Easterly talks about “The Tyranny of Experts”; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: 50 Years After the New York World’s Fair, Recalling a Vision of the Future
text: Fairgoers share memories of family outings and moments of inspiration at the 1964 New York World’s Fair.

headline: Under Cover: The President and the Bouquet
text: Daan Brand, an Amsterdam-based photographer, draws inspiration from the vivid imagery of cartoons to create his photo illustrations. So when the magazine’s photo department asked Brand to illustrate Jo Becker’s cover story chronicling the Obama administration’s shift on same-sex marriage, Brand imagined a series of photo illustrations that would maintain the reader’s focus on the key players in Becker’s narrative, especially President Obama and Vice President Biden.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Asia’s Cauldron’
text: This week, Robert D. Kaplan and William Easterly.

headline: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour, Head Chef at M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse
text: “Cooking for people doesn’t necessarily mean cooking what they want,” says Hugue Dufour. “They need to be told what they want, so they can enjoy better than they thought they would.” The French Canadian chef has taken the borough of Queens by storm in recent years with his idiosyncratic, unfussy, meat-loving M. Wells restaurants — the original, which closed in 2011, M. Wells Dinette in MoMA PS1 and the recently opened M. Wells Steakhouse. In the latest installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Dufour talks about the influence of his wife and co-conspirator Sarah Obraitis, getting kicked out of culinary school in Quebec and the pleasures of cooking veal brains in a diner.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: And Then It Came to an End
text: One day, the New York World’s Fair, with its architecture flavored by the Space Age, was the future. Then the next day, it was history. After the debt-plagued fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the destruction began. Over the course of a year, as these striking images from 1965 and ’66 attest, the fair was carefully and willfully dismantled: Cranes were brought in to remove the exhibitions, buildings were demolished, and even before the official closing, people picked over the grounds, yanking plants from their beds as souvenirs.

headline: O Youth and Beauty (and After That)!
text: Over the years, the boundary-blurring choreographer Miguel Gutierrez has created a number of evening-length works that reveal the angst of a generation through movement, music and text. Now 42, he’s suffering from a little burnout. “Age & Beauty Part 1: Mid-Career Artist/Suicide Note or &:-/,” presented as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first in a series of dances that focus on the challenges of being in midcareer.

headline: Hip-Hop Bête Noire Changes Again
text: Just five years ago, a rapper like Riff Raff would have been unthinkable. Known for gleaming non sequitur verse, Oscar-worthy Vine videos and a magical capacity for physical transformation, he is a hip-hop changeling for the Tumblr age, an appealing nuisance.

headline: Humans Fighting for Earth’s Health
text: In the beginning, it was about the dams. The naturalist John Muir and the forester Gifford Pinchot waged war in the early 1900s over the flooding of the magnificent Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park. Decades later, the proposed damming of the Colorado River prompted public outrage, and the environmental movement was born. Today some two million organizations worldwide work on behalf of social justice and the environment.

headline: Every Number Tells a Story
text: In a series called Collected Stories, the composer David Lang curates an alluring set of programs that explore the idea of storytelling in music. Six multigenre, wide-ranging concerts feature works from the medieval age to the present, including Irish folk music and Tuvan throat singing.

headline: A Family Reunion, Thanks to Goya
text: The public knows him best as “Red Boy,” Francisco de Goya’s portrait of the beguiling 5-year-old Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuñiga, dressed in red from head to toe, with his pet magpie. The painting, which has been in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s collection since 1949, is one of its most popular images. But few visitors are aware that the child is the son of the Count Altamira, governor of what was the Banco de San Carlos (now the Banco de España) and that between 1786 and 1788 the count commissioned Goya to paint that portrait, along with three others.

headline: Eternal Life, Thanks to Angels and Abs
text: SURREY, British Columbia — The first episode of the scary-monster show “Supernatural,” in which a college student came home and found his girlfriend on the ceiling, roasting like a blond marshmallow, was shown by the WB network on Sept. 13, 2005.

headline: Drawing on Their Home Turfs for New Work
text: Ratking

headline: At Bolshoi, the Battle for Ballet Still Rages
text: The Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow is emerging from the worst ballet scandal in recent history. Its artistic director, Sergei Filin, is still undergoing operations to restore his eyesight after the severe injuries he suffered in a shocking acid attack in January 2013. Since he became director in 2011, the list of Bolshoi dancers has changed considerably: New stars have been imported, while existing ones have left in a wide range of circumstances — some for other companies (claiming the Bolshoi repertory held them back) and others as part of the fallout from the scandal.

headline: Around the Unisphere at the World’s Fair, Lives Changed
text: All paths once led to the Unisphere, a magnet for the masses.

headline: In Our Pages: April 19
text: 1914: King Edward’s Dog Is Dead

headline: La MaMa Dance Festival With a French Accent
text: The ninth La Mama Moves! Dance Festival will bring together experimental dancers, ensembles and choreographers from around the world in programs that will include nine world premieres and four United States premieres. The festival runs from May 2 to 25 at all three of La Mama’s theaters – the Ellen Stewart Theater (66 East Fourth Street), the Club and the First Floor Theater (74A East Fourth Street).

headline: Image of the Day: April 18
text: A procession in Kolkata, West Bengal, to mark the occasion of Good Friday.

headline: After Stellar Season, a Seasoned Foe Awaits
text: The Nets sat all five starters in their final game of the regular season, content to drop to the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs to rest their aging roster. They will need all the energy they can muster against the young, feisty Toronto Raptors.

headline: Goldman, Citi, UBS ... and a Guy in an Office
text: Anyone looking at the mergers and acquisitions “league tables” — the Wall Street equivalent of Major League Baseball’s standings — during this hot year for merger activity would find the usual suspects: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs vying for the top spot, with other big brand-name firms jockeying to fill the coveted top 10.

headline: Stirring the Automotive Melting Pot
text: For decades, Italy’s role in any American auto show was clearly understood: to weaken the knees of enthusiasts with largely unattainable Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Maseratis. But new and unexpected forms of Italian exotica took starring roles this year at press previews of the New York International Auto Show.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Lou Howe
text: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.For his first feature film, the writer and director Lou Howe charged into dark and complex emotional waters. He paints a portrait of mental illness from an intimate perspective in “Gabriel,” which stars Rory Culkin in the title role of a young man returning home to his family after spending time in a mental health facility. Battling personal demons, he is also in search of a lost love.

headline: In the Bronx, a Tribute to a Salsa Singer
text: Muralists in the Bronx are honoring the salsa singer Cheo Feliciano, who died Thursday in a car accident in Puerto Rico.

headline: Paying Till It Hurts
text: A series of articles by the New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Rosenthal examines the price of medical care in the United States. In each installment, readers were invited to share their perspectives on managing costs and treatment.

headline: Pro-Russia Militant Rejects Ukraine Pact
text: The leader of a group of pro-Russia separatists, Denis Pushilin, said he would ignore the diplomatic pact between Russia and Ukraine to de-escalate the crisis.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Linda Lavin, by Day and by Night
text: Linda Lavin’s life on Central Park South resembles a sitcom.

headline: Big Ticket | Light-Grabbing Penthouse for $42 Million
text: A 12-room penthouse with panoramic Central Park views and more than 2,500 square feet of terraces atop the venerable Prasada at 50 Central Park West sold for $42 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Under Hoof, Foot and Tire
text: How about a real “Streetscapes” — not about buildings, but the streets themselves? The roadways of New York have long been the subject of turf battles among cars, horses, bikes and pedestrians. But the history of what they’re fighting over is multilayered — literally.

headline: The Pretend Complexity of the Nevada Cattle-Grazing Dispute
text: The Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy owes the government over $1 million in unpaid fines, incurred for grazing his cattle on protected public land. When the Bureau of Land Management tried to confiscate his cattle in early April, he resisted, attracting armed supporters clearly itching for a violent confrontation. “We were actually strategizing to put all the women up front,” said one of his backers, the Tea Party leader Richard Mack. “If they were going to start shooting, it’s going to be women that are going to be televised all across the world getting shot.” Not nearly as histrionic or rash as Mr. Bundy and Mr. Mack, the B.L.M. backed down and said it would “work to resolve the matter administratively and judicially.”

headline: Sheraton Expands Its Club Level Service
text: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts is planning to appoint more than 350 V.I.P. club managers to its club level lounges over the next few months.

headline: Applause for Avocados
text: Lately I’ve been reveling in Hass avocados, and now I understand why, having just discovered an article that David Karp, fruit expert extraordinaire, wrote in The Los Angeles Times a few years ago about the optimal time for ripeness in avocados. The California Avocado Commission sets Nov. 28 as the start of the Hass avocado harvest, meaning that the oil content in the fruit is high enough for picking.

headline: In Uruguay, Team and Country Are Unified Behind Coach
text: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — It was a telling gesture when Greg Dyke, the chairman of the English Football Association, slid his forefinger slowly across his throat moments after England was drawn in Group D of the World Cup.

headline: As Data About Drivers Proliferates, Auto Insurers Look to Adjust Rates
text: IT’S no surprise that car accidents, speeding tickets and where you live all affect how much you pay for automobile insurance. But consumer groups say that other, apparently unrelated, factors are unfairly being used to set rates.

headline: Fixing a Broken Smartphone
text: Q. Is it possible to replace the broken glass on a smartphone or do you have to buy a new one?

headline: Mazda Recalls Older Tributes; VW Cites Fire Hazard in Some 2014 Models
text: Mazda is recalling 109,000 of its 2001-4 Tribute sport utility vehicles because of a steering problem, and Volkswagen is recalling about 26,000 of its 2014 cars for a fire hazard, according to reports the automakers filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: At Coachella, It’s a Guy Thing
text: Thermal, Calif. — “People are getting more brave, which I love, just embracing it,” said Kelson Berkus, 30, a marketing executive in Los Angeles, nodding approvingly as he surveyed the Lacoste party, clad in aqua giraffe-print swim trunks (source: “probably Fred Segal”).

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: a new Passover food, painkillers during pregnancy and exercise cool-downs. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Taking a Job Out of the Financial Equation
text: No pensions. Roller-coaster retirement accounts. Longer lives and higher health care costs. Aging parents. Children in college. A will to work but fewer jobs to be had.

headline: Heartbleed Internet Security Flaw Used in Attack
text: Within 24 hours of the Heartbleed bug’s disclosure last week, an attacker used it to break into a major corporation, security experts said Friday.

headline: Russian Opposition Figure Faces Accusations of Libel
text: MOSCOW — Criminal libel proceedings against Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, extended into their second day on Friday, concluding without resolution.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Manakamana’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Manakamana.”

headline: Lois Wallace, a Respected Agent of Prominent Authors, Dies at 73
text: Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor who moonlighted as a screenwriter, had written a screenplay about two star-crossed lovers. His literary agent, Lois Wallace, thought it could also work as a novel and suggested that he turn it into one before the movie was made.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Fading Gigolo’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Fading Gigolo.”

headline: Free Samples Influence Doctors’ Prescriptions
text: One method pharmaceutical companies use to promote new medicines is to give free samples to doctors. A new study confirms that the technique is highly effective.

headline: My European Ritual
text: What compels people to return to the same place or experience repeatedly? Answers from nine writers take you to Athens and Berlin, Paris and Granada — and beyond.

headline: Your European Rituals
text: From England to Iceland, Barcelona to Warsaw, here are special spots Times readers like to visit more than once.

headline: Pasta With Garlicky Bread Crumbs
text: Melissa Clark makes pasta with toasted garlicky bread crumbs, anchovies and fresh parsley.

headline: Chinese Official Urges Russia and Central Asian Allies to Control Internet
text: BEIJING — Guo Shengkun, China’s minister of public security, said at a six-nation security conference in Tajikistan that Russia and Central Asian countries must strictly control the Internet and prevent “external forces” from trying to overthrow governments and “provoke a new wave of color revolutions,” according to news agency reports on Friday.

headline: Spilling Blood as if They Were Kids
text: For decades, sociologists have struggled to pinpoint the exact impact of childhood exposure to violent movies, but one fact is clear. In extreme cases, the cycle of violence repeats itself. Sometimes, kids steeped in extreme cinematic mayhem grow up to become hyperviolent filmmakers themselves.

headline: Biking Hercules’ Way in France
text: The Gauls, a Celtic tribe that inhabited what is now France, were a boorish bunch before Julius Caesar arrived in 58 B.C. and ushered in civilization. At least, that is the historical explanation Graham Robb, a literary historian best known for the books “The Discovery of France” and “Parisians,” had accepted along with most French people.

headline: Stone Lifting as Sport in the Basque Country
text: It was 10 o’clock on a bright Thursday morning when I washed up in a cafe in Leitza, a Basque village in a rugged, green valley south of San Sebastián, in search of directions. The barista and both of her customers, two elderly men wearing traditional Basque berets, knew whom I was looking for before I asked. Iñaki Perurena is the Michael Jordan of harrijasotzaile, or stone lifting, considered a herri kirolak, or rural Basque sport that has been an integral part of the Basque culture for 100 years, and I had come to Leitza in search of his hilltop museum and sculpture garden dedicated to this unusual athletic pursuit.

headline: Selected Documents Released From the Clinton Archives
text: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon another trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clinton’s White House.

headline: Left With the Crumbs? Lucky You
text: Bread crumbs are easy to take for granted. In most recipes, they barely register. They’re a crunch-intensifier or a garlic-and-cheese holder (ah, stuffed mushrooms), but never the main ingredient. They may not seem like something that demands to be homemade.

headline: Poison Pill’s Relevance in the Age of Shareholder Activism
text: When we look back 20 years from now, the lawsuit by Daniel S. Loeb and his Third Point hedge fund against Sotheby’s may well be the tipping point in how far companies can go to defend themselves against shareholder activists.

headline: Can We Get a ‘No Standing’ Sign?
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 55
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Trove of Old Film Footage, Now Online
text: In days of yore – or at any rate, from the dawn of cinema into the 1960s or so – going to the movies was more than just settling into a plush seat with nearly a gallon of soda and a truckload of popcorn, and then getting blasted against the wall with insanely overamplified sound. You’d get a cartoon or a short feature, and a few decades back you’d also get a newsreel. Sometimes it was actual news, although the growth of television rendered such films beside the point. Often it was a soft feature – footage of a celebrity wedding, a daredevil stunt, an exotic sports event or perhaps an interview with a music or film star.

headline: Faces of Ukraine, on the Eve of Tumult
text: In July 2010, young, lighthearted Ukrainians packed Kiev’s Independence Square for a concert by a drag queen singing frothy pop songs over techno beats.

headline: Yet Another Pretty Face
text: By what metric are we to determine whether a model is “super”? If it is name recognition, Forbes list position, magazines covered, campaigns fronted or some algorithm of them all, Kate Upton probably qualifies. In 2013 Ms. Upton, a 21-year-old from Melbourne, Fla., was named model of the year and appeared on the cover of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue for the second straight year. This year she was demoted to the inside cover, pictured wearing a bikini in zero gravity.

headline: Horseless, Not to Mention Senseless
text: Give the folks at NYClass, the advocacy group that wants to eliminate horse carriages from New York City, credit for recognizing the consequences of their campaign, and for having a plan.

headline: How Do You Say “Nobody Could Have Predicted” In Swedish?
text: A correspondent points me to the news from Sweden, which has stopped flirting with deflation and moved right in. Here’s inflation excluding food, energy, tobacco, and alcohol:

headline: 40th Anniversary Special for ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: “Saturday Night Live,” among the most influential of television shows, will get a full dose of NBC’s gratitude next February, when the network celebrates the show’s 40th anniversary with a three-hour special — live from New York, of course.

headline: 30 Seconds With Mike Fratello
text: Mike Fratello coached the Atlanta Hawks, the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Memphis Grizzlies in the N.B.A. With a 667-548 record, he is 18th on the N.B.A. career wins list and 19th in games coached. His teams qualified for the playoffs in 11 of his 15 seasons.

headline: Love and the Stick-On Nipple
text: I am not big on accessories: I wear the same ring, watch, bracelet and earrings day after day. Still, there is one special item I was thrilled to find and really thought I would wear daily: my fabulous, lifelike, press-on nipples. They were not something I had ever planned on needing, but then I never planned on having breast cancer and a double reconstruction, or as it is known these days, the Angelina Jolie surgery.

headline: Together With Songs in Their Hearts
text: When Shanta Thake, now the director of Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater in NoHo, was in her 20s, her work in the performing arts scene in the city left her constantly entertained during the day and frequently alone at night.

headline: Sherpa’s Family on Avalanche
text: Even as rescue teams attempted to reach victims of the Mount Everest avalanche, Dawa Yanju, the sister-in-law of a survivor, Dawa Tashi, described what happened.

headline: For Stone Phillips, a Focus on the Home Front
text: Originally, Stone Phillips told me, he intended to shoot a kind of home movie.

headline: Prisoner Whose 1988 Conviction Is Under Review Is Granted Parole
text: A Brooklyn man whose 1988 murder conviction is under review because of questions about the lead detective in the case will be released on parole next month, his lawyer said.

headline: Learning to Set a Goal for the Long Run
text: It was early winter and my son and I were taking the dogs on their nightly stroll. Something was clearly on his mind. “Anything you want to talk about?” I asked.

headline: Wheelies: The Welcome Back Maybach Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: In NoHo: Squeezing In, With Some Creativity
text: The housing market in New York seems to bring out the fearlessness in some developers.

headline: An Obituary or an Appraisal? Thursday Night’s Debate.
text: Dean Baquet, the managing editor of The Times, talks about the debate in the newsroom Thursday night over how to treat the death of Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist.

headline: In the Works of García Márquez, Finding a Link to Home
text: Under the fluorescent lights of a check-cashing store in Jackson Heights, Queens, a man recited the opening lines of “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” in Spanish, on Thursday night.

headline: Robin Leach Rolls on in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — Robin Leach, 72, wobbled up to Citizens Kitchen and Bar here looking neither rich nor famous.

headline: U.S. Delays Final Call on Keystone XL Pipeline
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department will delay its decision on construction of the Keystone XL pipeline until it has a clearer idea of how legal challenges to the pipeline’s route through Nebraska will be settled, State Department officials said Friday.

headline: Thunder’s Lofty Hopes Rest on a Fragile Hinge
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — It was nearly 12 months and 3 surgeries ago that guard Russell Westbrook hurt his right knee in the N.B.A. playoffs, ending the championship expectations of the top-seeded Oklahoma City Thunder. It was a fluky play, a sideswiping collision after a timeout, hardly anything that looked serious.

headline: Female in Gaza
text: I have been photographing in Gaza for several years, initially to cover the conflict with Israel, but over time returning because I am mesmerized by the women, and their strength.

headline: Years After a Bitter Fight, Prince and Warner Bros. Make a New Deal
text: More than 20 years after Prince protested against Warner Bros. Records by writing “slave” on his face and changing his name to an unpronounceable glyph, he has reconciled with that label through a new deal that gives him ownership of his old recordings and will include a major reissue campaign.

headline: How to Run on Health Reform
text: The Republican attack machine, fueled by millions of dollars from the Koch brothers, has Democrats so rattled about the health reform law that many don’t want to talk about it. They’re happy to run on equal pay for women, or a higher minimum wage, or immigration reform — all of which provide important contrasts with a do-nothing Republican Party — but they haven’t said much about the biggest social accomplishment of the Obama administration.

headline: Will and Kate (and Uncle Sam) Studied Here
text: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND — It was hardly your typical college party. Set under a heated white tent the size of a football field (tables covered in chilled bottles of Nicolas Feuillatte Champagne and goody bags stuffed with vouchers from Hackett and Jack Wills), it seemed more like a New York gala than a student event in a college town on the North Sea. But when the University of St. Andrews 2014 charity fashion show began, so did the party.

headline: Protests Continue Against Dropbox After Appointment of Condoleezza Rice to Board
text: The decision by Dropbox this month to appoint Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, to the company’s board of directors sparked a heated online debate about her views on Internet surveillance and the role of the National Security Agency.

headline: The Gun Report: April 18, 2014
text: Earlier this year, a legislator in Iowa floated a bill to lower the age at which children can legally shoot handguns. While anyone 20 or younger must be under the direct supervision of a parent or instructor to practice with a pistol or revolver, current state law prohibits children younger than 14 from handgun use, even with a parent around. Rep. Joe Riding, a Democrat from Altoona, wanted to lower that to 12.

headline: Program to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons Is 75% Complete, Group Says
text: GENEVA — As the deadline looms for the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons, the international organization overseeing the process reported Friday that the country had delivered another shipment of toxic agents for destruction abroad, bringing the program three-quarters of the way to completion.

headline: When Bravo Came to Charleston
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — For the last few years Charleston has been getting the sort of high praise it has not seen since before Reconstruction.

headline: In the Battle for Best Smartphone, Apple Still Beats Samsung
text: Over the last couple weeks, many of my colleagues in the tech press have published reviews of the Galaxy S5, Samsung’s newest top-of-the-line smartphone. They all arrived at more or less the same conclusion: The S5 is a very nice device.

headline: What to Expect When a Clinton Is Expecting
text: In some alternate universe, a distant political galaxy unlike our own, Chelsea Clinton might be able to have her first child quietly. No one would care about the size of her baby bump. If and when Hillary Rodham Clinton announces a presidential run, her status as a grandparent would receive exactly the same scrutiny as her male predecessors who were grandfathers.

headline: 13 Quit Board of San Diego Opera
text: LOS ANGELES – Less than a week after the board of the San Diego Opera reaffirmed its decision to shut it down, the embattled company was hit with a new wave of turmoil on Thursday as Karen Cohn, the president of the board, led a contingent of 13 board members in resigning.

headline: A Mustang Option: Matching Nail Polish
text: The Ford Motor Company is using a distinct new palette to market the Mustang to women at the New York International Auto Show: a line of nail polish colors. The Ford Mustang by OPI Collection features six colors inspired by the 50th anniversary of the car.

headline: What $5 Can Get at a Film Festival
text: Clara Mamet’s table at Barbuto wasn’t ready. It was 8 p.m. Wednesday, and Ms. Mamet, the 19-year-old daughter of the playwright David Mamet and the half-sister of the actress Zosia Mamet, was in New York for the Tribeca Film Festival, where her debut film, “Two-Bit Waltz,” would be shown later in the week.

headline: First You Spend, Then You Save
text: The psychology of saving fuel can get complicated, especially when it involves splurging to go from Point A to Point B.

headline: Premium Fuel Efficiency, and a Price to Match
text: The BMW 535d can exceed 40 miles per gallon on the highway, and the performance is impressive for a diesel. But do the fuel savings make up for the higher sticker price?

headline: Rules of Style | Sleigh Bells’ Alexis Krauss on Dressing for Coachella, Melt-Proof Makeup and the Virtues of Normcore
text: In 90-degree heat among a crowd of 90,000, it’s tough for anyone — even a bona fide rock star — to keep their look together. But Alexis Krauss, the inky-tressed frontwoman of the Brooklyn indie noise-pop band Sleigh Bells, has a way of always staying cool, even during her frenetic stage shows. Here, the singer — who plays Coachella this weekend and will be touring the U.S. and Europe all summer long — shares her secrets to braving warm-weather festivals in style.

headline: Amorality à Deux, Circa 1932
text: “Steal, swindle, rob, O.K.” pleads the pickpocket Lily (Miriam Hopkins) to her paramour, the thief Gaston (Herbert Marshall), in Ernst Lubitsch’s “Trouble in Paradise,” “but don’t become one of those useless, good-for-nothing gigolos!” Lily has reason to fear: the debonair Gaston has insinuated himself into a job with a perfume heiress (Kay Francis), and though he and Lily have designs on her riches, Gaston may be falling for his boss.

headline: From Rags to Riches to Rags
text: ST. LOUIS — BY now most of us know the basic facts of America’s rising income inequality: Since the early 1970s, the gap between the top and bottom of the income distribution has expanded significantly; what’s more, the only group to have experienced real economic gains during this period has been those in the top 20 percent, with gains heavily concentrated in the top 10, 5 and — most famously — 1 percent.

headline: The Trouble With Rice
text: For the past few years, Mary Lou Guerinot has been keeping watch over experimental fields in southeast Texas, monitoring rice plants as they suck metals and other troublesome elements from the soil.

headline: Snowden Defends His Part in Putin Forum
text: One day after he took part in a stage-managed forum with President Vladimir V. Putin on Russian state television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden defended his participation, in an essay published by The Guardian.

headline: Giving Snapshots the Gonzo Treatment
text: “I really thought what I would do, if I ever learned to draw properly, was I would try to change the world,” the British artist Ralph Steadman explains in “For No Good Reason,” Charlie Paul’s documentary about him, opening Friday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Bar and Bathroom Lines, Molto Adagio
text: When the curtain went down on Act II of Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera on a recent evening, close to 100 stagehands sprang into action. To the sound of beeping machinery, hammer strokes and intermittent warning shouts, they carried props, bundled drops, unfurled scrims, navigated the enormous wagon rolling the next set into place and secured escape stairs to the floor in what looked like brisk, efficient choreography.

headline: A Beer Vacation Is On Tap in Chicago
text: Lagunitas Brewing Company, the Northern California beer maker with a penchant for live music, has expanded its operations to Chicago, where it will open a  300,000-square-foot facility early next month.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 18
text: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: New York Bridal Fashion Week | Spring 2015
text: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2015 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of photos.

headline: Delayed Viewing Plumps Up ‘Mad Men’ Audience
text: Fans of “Mad Men” alarmed by the surprising ratings falloff for this season’s premiere may take some comfort in the first results of delayed viewing for the episode.

headline: The Re-education of a Brash Young Stock Picker
text: Nine years ago, Randy Kurtz made an extraordinary bet on himself, the stock market and his ability to pick a few winners.

headline: Lace Shows Its Strength
text: “It’s very important to me that these not be viewed just as wedding gowns,” said Vera Wang, the pre-eminent wedding-gown designer for a generation. She was on the phone discussing her decision not to hold a live show during the recent presentations of bridal collections in New York, a kinder, gentler and briefer version of Fashion Week, with profusions of curling-ironed hair, platform pumps and champagne flutes twinkling in broad daylight.

headline: An Indian From India Photographs Both
text: After encountering confusion over her roots, an Indian photographer created a set of diptychs in which she recreated classic poses of Native Americans.

headline: How to Make a Perfect Piece of Toast
text: There may be more pressing issues in the food world, or more ambitious projects to tackle, but I am here to talk about perfecting the simplest of kitchen basics.

headline: What Is Putin’s ‘New Russia’?
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, appearing cool and confident on national television during a four-hour question-and-answer show on Thursday, referred repeatedly to southeastern Ukraine as “New Russia,” a historical term for the area north of the Black Sea that the Russian empire conquered in the 1700s. “God knows” why the region became part of Ukraine in the 1920s, he said in response to a questioner, a strong signal that he would gladly correct that error.

headline: Eric Korsh to Run the Kitchen at North End Grill
text: Eric Korsh left Calliope, the French bistro in the East Village, where he was the chef and a partner, in late January, but he did not spend a great deal of time in the wilderness. He will be the new executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, replacing Floyd Cardoz, who is departing on April 30.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Korea, Central Africa Republic, India and Germany.

headline: Allowing a Puritan to Marry for Love
text: If you are going to savor the Metropolitan Opera’s welcome revival of Bellini’s “I Puritani,” it is best to put out of mind that this 1976 production was mounted for Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Sherrill Milnes and James Morris. Such an astounding four-star cast is not likely to come along again anytime soon.

headline: Pharrell’s Next Collaboration, Karl Lagerfeld’s Destination Fashion Show and Alexander Wang’s First Instagram
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Economist Receives Rock Star Treatment
text: French economists who boldly question the dominance of capital over labor — and call for a progressive global tax on wealth — visit the American halls of power about as often as French rock stars headline Madison Square Garden.

headline: Music From ‘Madama Butterfly’
text: A clip from Act 1 of “Madama Butterfly” from the Metropolitan Opera. The clip features Kristine Opolais, the soloist, as the character of Cio-Cio-San. She is accompanied by members of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus, including Jean Braham.

headline: When Gabriel García Márquez Went Back to Aracataca
text: The novelist and maestro Gabriel García Márquez died Thursday , mourned by the world at the ample enough age of 87. But for a time during his youth in Colombia — when he was inhaling three packs a day — he was sure that he would die young, dissolute “and in the street,” as he put it in his 2003 memoir “Living to Tell The Tale.” At that point, his mother, Luisa Santiaga Márquez, appeared unexpectedly in the city of Barranquilla, determined to rescue her law-school dropout son from a wasteful life as a mere writer. She convinced him to travel with her to the desolate, hellishly hot Caribbean town of Aracataca, where he was born in 1927.

headline: Lost in Literary History: A Tale of Courage in the South
text: Nineteen seventy-four was a good year for nonfiction writing in America. Robert A. Caro’s monumental biography of Robert Moses, “The Power Broker,” came out. So did Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein’s “All the President’s Men.” So did “Working,” by Studs Terkel, and Robert M. Pirsig’s “Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance.”

headline: Including the Young and the Rich
text: On a crisp morning in late March, an elite group of 100 young philanthropists and heirs to billionaire family fortunes filed into a cozy auditorium at the White House.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Frenzy
text: Runners wearing colorful tutus, a bulldog skating and a wall of forsythia in Central Park: New York comes to life with whimsical touches of color.

headline: On Its Return, Band Goes Right Back to the Basics
text: Loop’s concert on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge started, of course, with a drone: a guitar note looped for continuous sustain, almost meditative. But not for long. Soon the clobbering began: The repeating two-chord riff of “Soundhead,” basic and primal, blasted in unison on guitar, bass and drums. “I hear that sound! I hear that sound!,” Robert Hampson sang.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Two-Tone Spring
text: The contrasts of spring in New York and Paris: It looked like a basket of jelly beans at the women’s half-marathon in New York last Sunday, with many runners in tutus. Shop windows were filled with chicks, rabbits and decorated eggs. Big Bird sat on a bench near a wall of forsythia. Magnolias blossomed at the Frick, and a dog went skateboarding in a park. In Paris, where fashion still rules, black-and-white made a big sophisticated statement.

headline: Love Those Royal Family Photos? It All Started With Victoria.
text: LOS ANGELES — Today, as the formal boundaries between the British royal family and the public narrow, pictures of 9-month-old Prince George are posted daily on the Facebook pages of Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton. But, in fact, photography has been promoting the royal brand since its inception in the 19th century, as an exhibition on view at the Getty Center here shows. Fame may seem a 20th-century phenomenon, but Queen Victoria was the first public figure to exploit its promotional potential and the earliest — and least likely — international celebrity of the photographed world.

headline: A TV Opera, Live. Olé!
text: The relationship of language to music, and plot to text, is an intriguing element of Robert Ashley’s “Perfect Lives,” a complex and meditative sequence featuring a hypnotic, sung-spoken narrative that unfolds with myriad cadences.

headline: Evening Hours | April, Come What May
text: From opera and ballet to children and birds.

headline: Auto Show in the Round
text: The Automobiles team, working with the photographer Benjamin Norman, selected some of the new models at the New York International Auto Show for 360-degree interactive views.

headline: Versatility Is a Virtue in Fantasy of Identity
text: If you pay more attention than you should to television critics or the pop-culture gossip mills, you may have heard that you should be watching “Orphan Black” on BBC America, which returns for a second season on Saturday night.

headline: A Silver Anniversary for Mazda’s Blue-Ribbon Sports Car
text: British automakers like Austin-Healey, Lotus and MG may have originated the tidy, nimble roadster, but it was Mazda, a Japanese company, that mastered the formula decades later.

headline: Honing the Hybrids and Diesels
text: BMW has long promoted diesel engines as an important element of its plan to reduce carbon dioxide output. The automaker is still a champion of diesel power, but now it is embracing electric drive, too.

headline: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
text: Updated, Saturday, 1:52 p.m. | Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.

headline: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
text: Run in fright. Marlon Wayans’s comedy “A Haunted House” unaccountably made $40 million at the domestic box office, so we have “A Haunted House 2,” which, like its predecessor, pays parodic tribute to horror films including “Dark Skies” and the “Last Exorcism” movies, among countless others. Already the franchise displays a sputtering exhaustion.

headline: The Secrets and the Magic Are in the Details
text: In the program note for the current installment of Soaking Wet, the dance series that David Parker directs at the West End Theater on the Upper West Side, he speaks of presenting the work of Vicky Shick as a longtime dream come true. It seemed to him that her “exacting, poetic work” would be a perfect match for the “funky, mysterious space” on the second floor of a church. The debut on Thursday of Ms. Shick’s “Pathétique/Miniatures in Detail” proved him right.

headline: Added Attractions Through the Years
text: Special editions of the Mazda Miata that are nothing more than color and trim packages may not improve the driving experience, but their low production numbers can make them more attractive to collectors.

headline: Watch Out, iTunes. Vinyl Still Lives.
text: The story usually told about record stores is a sad one that just keeps getting sadder.

headline: Jordan Chodorow and Karen Allison Play at Bridge Base Online
text: Online bridge has certainly made it easier and cheaper for everyone to play. The diagramed deal was played during a pair game at Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com). North was Jordan Chodorow of Los Angeles and South was Karen Allison of Las Vegas, who has won five national championships.

headline: Woman Is Sought After Attempt to Kidnap an 8-Month-Old
text: The authorities were searching on Friday for a woman with a history of trying to abduct young children, saying she had tried to kidnap an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

headline: A Polish Painter Reconsiders His Calling
text: On April 27, the Vatican will live-stream a ceremony elevating Karol Wojtyla, later known as Pope John Paul II, to sainthood. Storm Theater and Blackfriars Repertory Theater have devised an alternative way to celebrate the pope, reviving his 1949 play, “Our God’s Brother,” translated by Boleslaw Taborksi, at the Theater of the Church of Notre Dame.

headline: The Faces May Be Familiar, but the Sounds Are Original
text: With its new-music series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offers its patrons a change of perspective. Held in the Kaplan Penthouse, with its floor-to-ceiling windows that afford sweeping views of the city against a darkening evening sky, the concerts present familiar artists from the society’s ranks engaging with new works by living composers — and, often, with instruments rarely seen in traditional chamber music settings.

headline: Two Schemers, Crossing All Kinds of Boundaries
text: Fair warning: If feeling a stranger’s bare buttocks pressed into your upper back is more than you’re willing to risk for an evening of theater — if, perhaps, this is exactly the sort of personal-boundary crossing that creeps you out about immersive performance — then you may want to think carefully before deciding to see “Ubu Sings Ubu” at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Airbnb Said to Close Fund-Raising Deal With Group Led by TPG
text: Airbnb has closed a new round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Don’t Know Much About History, Rand Paul Edition
text: I can easily understand it when people don’t know the facts about economic statistics; you need a fair bit of background knowledge even to know how to look these things up. It’s more surprising when people don’t know what they don’t know — when they make confident assertions that can be proved false in a few seconds by anyone who does know these things.

headline: Friday Not Music: Back to Black
text: For some reason, not feeling very musical today. Instead I’m waiting eagerly for the season 2 premiere of one of the few shows I watch regularly. I think what I love about it is the chemistry of the cast — they interact with each other so well it’s as if they’re all one person. Oh, wait …

headline: Italian Dishes With a Creative Twist
text: Verde Wine Bar and Ristorante in Deer Park is the new incarnation of a restaurant called Papa Joe’s, which got its start in 1984 as an 11-seat pizzeria owned by Niel and Catherine Carcaterra.

headline: Florida State Rape Inquiry
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
