text: To the Editor:

headline: The World’s Fairgrounds, Then and Now
text: What was once an ash heap in Corona, Queens, became the site of the 1939 World’s Fair. Its avenues, in turn, provided the layout for the 1964 World’s Fair. Despite Robert Moses’ intention of making Flushing Meadows-Corona Park a jewel of the city after the event, its evolution has been fitful. A few structures from the fair stand in good condition; others have fallen into disrepair; and still others have been reinvented.

headline: Scones, Finger Sandwiches and Tea
text: Raising one’s pinkie finger may be a faux pas — “Nobody does that,” according to Susan Peterson, co-owner of Teaberry’s Tea Room in downtown Flemington.

headline: Twin Shocks Shake Foundation of German Power
text: BERLIN — If there are two qualities prized by modern Germans, they surely are Ruhe (peace and quiet) and Ordnung (order).

headline: Davis Is Traded to Pirates
text: After months of speculation, the Mets traded first baseman Ike Davis to the Pittsburgh Pirates on Friday night, jettisoning a homegrown prospect they once viewed as a potential cornerstone of their lineup for years to come.

headline: ‘2 Milk Hollow’? That’s Code for Bunnies at Aigner Chocolates
text: If Beatrix Potter ran a chocolate shop, it would look like Aigner Chocolates, a little confectioner on the corner of Metropolitan Avenue and 71st Road in the middle of Queens.

headline: For Pizza, 800 Degrees of Separation
text: If pizza is the ultimate comfort food, then Connecticut must be a very comfortable state. With pizzerias in virtually every town across the state, and many towns possessing several, it can be difficult to decide where to dine. The three parlors listed below set themselves apart by burning wood in their ovens, and also by offering choices that go well beyond the norm.

headline: A Timely Gift of Hot Truffled Chickpeas
text: Nothing makes me grumpier than getting stuck with the worst table at a restaurant. Such was the case at the Twisted Oak in Tarrytown on a recent night: We were led through the bustling front room to a gloomy rumpus room better suited for darts or air hockey or a low-stakes poker game.

headline: A Way of Tracking Deer Helps the Police Follow Their Prey in the Subway
text: Bushnell, the maker of optical equipment for hunters, sells a “trophy camera” that tracks deer after dark. Mounted to a tree and armed with a motion detector, the camera silently snaps infrared pictures of passing animals that don’t see a thing.

headline: Ukraine Seeks Inquiry Into Killings
text: Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to investigate the deaths of civilians on its territory that occurred from Nov. 21, 2013, to Feb. 22, covering the period when more than 100 people were killed during antigovernment protests. It excludes the period shortly afterward when Russia annexed Crimea. It was not immediately clear whom Ukraine was accusing of the deaths. Initially, Parliament sought to single out the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, but other groups may also be included. Because Ukraine is not a member of the court, it has formally given it jurisdiction with respect to the period in question. That step, which was apparently taken in early April, was announced in a court statement issued late Thursday. Ukraine’s application said it expected “that the court shall duly study the case.” But a court spokesman emphasized that it would be up to a prosecutor to decide whether to proceed, and then the court’s judges would be asked to approve the decision. An investigation is not expected any time soon.

headline: Swim to Sea? These Salmon Are Catching a Lift
text: RIO VISTA, Calif. — As the Merva W puttered down the Sacramento River, it looked like any other dowdy fishing vessel headed toward the Golden Gate Bridge. But no other boat had as surprising a cargo or as unusual a mission: The Merva W was giving 100,000 young salmon a lift to the Pacific in the hope of keeping them alive.

headline: Michaels Stores’ Breach Involved 3 Million Customers
text: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer, estimates that data on three million of its customers’ payment cards may have been stolen in a breach over several months.

headline: Obama Signs Bill That Bars Iran’s Envoy
text: President Obama signed a bill into law on Friday that would prohibit anyone who has engaged in espionage or terrorism against the United States from obtaining a visa to enter the country as a representative to the United Nations. Congress passed the bill last week after Iran named Hamid Aboutalebi as its ambassador to the United Nations; Mr. Aboutalebi was an interpreter for the militant student group that stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and held Americans hostage for 444 days. Iran has insisted that the United States has no right to dictate whom it may choose to represent it. Mr. Obama said the Constitution gave him exclusive discretion to receive or reject ambassadors, and if a case arose where the law would interfere with his exercising that discretion, he would treat it as advisory.

headline: Sheriffs Limit Detention of Immigrants
text: Sheriffs in nine Oregon counties announced this week that they would no longer hold people in jail based on requests from federal immigration authorities after a United States magistrate judge in Portland ruled that an immigrant’s rights had been violated when she was held in a county jail on such a request.

headline: Readers Share Their Memories of 50 Years Ago in Queens
text: For the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 New York World’s Fair, we asked readers to share their memories and photographs from their visits to the fair. Here is an edited sampling of memories and photographs submitted by readers.

headline: Live Longer and Heirs Will Prosper in New York
text: DYING is going to have lower tax consequences in New York — if you can wait five to eight years. But in the meantime, the new estate and gift tax law that went into effect on April 1 is going to create enormously complex financial planning problems for all sorts of people.

headline: Ex-Marine Held in Iran Asks Official for Help
text: Amir Hekmati, an American incarcerated in Iran since August 2011, recently wrote to its foreign minister seeking help in gaining his release, after Mr. Hekmati learned from his new lawyer that he had been secretly tried and sentenced to 10 years imprisonment on a charge of collaborating with the United States government, family members reported Friday.

headline: Heartbleed Highlights a Contradiction in the Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Heartbleed bug that made news last week drew attention to one of the least understood elements of the Internet: Much of the invisible backbone of websites from Google to Amazon to the Federal Bureau of Investigation was built by volunteer programmers in what is known as the open-source community.

headline: Saving Minds Along With Souls
text: EASTER is a time of new beginnings. It is the answer, the pastor Rick Warren remarks, to loss and despair. A few weeks ago, one year after his son took his life while struggling with depression, Mr. Warren, the founding pastor of Saddleback Church, one of the nation’s largest evangelical churches, teamed up with his local Roman Catholic Diocese and the National Alliance on Mental Illness for an event that announced a new initiative to involve the church in the care of serious mental illness.

headline: New York Police Department Tells Officers to Avoid Elevators in Burning Buildings
text: Tightening guidelines it had issued after the death of an officer in a Brooklyn high-rise fire this month, the New York Police Department has barred officers from using elevators in burning buildings and recommended they not enter smoke-filled hallways.

headline: OpenSSL and Linux: A Tale of Two Open-Source Projects
text: The Heartbleed bug has cast a bright and not entirely flattering light on the open-source movement’s incentive model.

headline: Learning From Korea’s Disaster
text: PLAINSBORO, N.J. — With hope fading for the rescue of 271 passengers, most of them high school students, who remain missing after the South Korean ferry Sewol capsized and sank Wednesday, it is not too early to draw lessons from the disaster. South Korea’s early response was to point to “human error” and seek the arrest of the ferry’s captain, first mate and another crew member. But it’s worth keeping three points in mind as investigations proceed.

headline: In Detroit, Judge Takes Offbeat Tack in Hiring Help
text: DETROIT — It was not your standard job interview.

headline: And the Race Is Off
text: Maybe Kathleen Sebelius should reconsider that Senate thing.

headline: Greed and the Wright Brothers
text: Lawrence Goldstone’s new book, “Birdmen,” is about the origins of the airplane, from the early experiments with gliders in the 1890s, to the famous first powered flight by the Wright brothers in December 1903, to the wild next decade — a decade of daring by the early pilots eager to show off both their airplanes and their skill. A good part of the story Goldstone tells is about the rise of airshow exhibitions that swept America — exhibitions in which flamboyant pilots performed death-defying stunts before tens of thousands of spectators. Although, as the author points out, many of those pilots did not, in the end, defy death. On the contrary, death is a constant theme of the early years of flight.

headline: Snowden Defends Query to Putin on Surveillance
text: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose exposure of a vast trove of his government’s secrets made him a hero and even a celebrity in certain circles, suddenly found himself on the defensive a day after he took part in a televised and carefully orchestrated question-and-answer session with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: In Queens, Chickens Clash With the Rules
text: Sylvia Saye held a basket of multicolored eggs.

headline: Turning Up the Intensity
text: In the N.B.A. playoffs, everyone is looking to win it all, and no one, thankfully, is thinking about the lottery. So after all the talk during the regular season about which teams were tanking in hopes of landing top draft picks, it will be refreshing to watch game after game in which the only objective is to score the most points.

headline: Obamacare Bashing or Bust
text: Thursday, President Obama delivered a compendium of positive news about the Affordable Care Act:

headline: Slow Start Spurs Shift for Towers Near Arena
text: The first residential tower at the sprawling Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn rises only five of its intended 32 floors nearly a year and a half after construction started, making it one of the slowest-moving projects in a city with an unquenchable thirst for housing.

headline: Health Care Spending’s Recent Surge Stirs Unease
text: WASHINGTON — It’s back.

headline: In a Hole, Golf Considers Digging a Wider One
text: GREENSBORO, Ga. — Golf holes the size of pizzas. Soccer balls on the back nine. A mulligan on every hole.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 18, 2014
text: April 18, 2014

headline: A Generational Divide Worn on Their Heads
text: When Lydia Calviness died two years ago at the age of 93, she bequeathed her church hats to her grandniece Monica Moss. Genealogically speaking, Ms. Moss did not qualify as the closest female relative. Ms. Calviness had arranged the inheritance because Ms. Moss, like her, was what the lexicon of black Christianity calls a “first lady” — the pastor’s wife.

headline: Paper Shows U.S.-Flagged Plane in Iran Has Ties to Ghana
text: New details emerged on Friday about an American plane, owned by a small community bank in Utah and mysteriously parked this week at Tehran’s airport, showing that it had been leased by a Ghanaian mining company owned by a brother of Ghana’s president.

headline: Terror Watch Lists Run Amok
text: After eight years of confounding litigation and coordinated intransigence, the Justice Department this week grudgingly informed Rahinah Ibrahim, a Malaysian architecture professor, that she was no longer on the federal government’s vastly overbroad no-fly list.

headline: Finding Open Space and Fresh Air
text: Before participating in the Fresh Air Fund camping program, Edgar Saavedra and his two brothers spent summer days inside their home in the Bronx or in the library. Their neighborhood park was too crowded for playing soccer, so once or twice a week their parents put the boys on a bus for a 45-minute ride to a safer, greener park. “In the city, you can’t do much,” Edgar said. “There are only buildings. There’s no grass.”

headline: Awesome Con Fans Try to Break Record
text: As part of the convention kickoff in Washington, attendees tried to break the world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as comic book characters but fell short of the record, 1,530.

headline: Two Ministers Forge Friendship Across a Church Divide
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — The two ministers were foes before they ever met, partisans in a war they did not start, but partisans nonetheless.

headline: Putting One’s Cards on the Table
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we saw Stu Ockman over a year ago, he was calling out to us, but this time he has seen fit to twist our brains with a difficult Saturday puzzle.

headline: Viral Disease Spreads to Southeast Asia
text: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines. The Malaysian Health Ministry said a 54-year-old man recently back from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, died of it on Sunday, and a Filipino nurse was quarantined, along with his family, after a positive blood test. The nurse appeared healthy but, before returning to Manila on Tuesday, had been in contact with a Filipino paramedic in the United Arab Emirates who died of MERS. On Wednesday, the Emirates reported 10 new cases, all among health workers who treated a MERS patient who died April 10. Since the disease was discovered in 2012, there have been 243 confirmed cases with 93 deaths, the World Health Organization said. The coronavirus that causes MERS appears to originate in bats and is widespread in Middle Eastern camel herds. It occasionally infects humans and can spread among them, usually only after close contact.

headline: Tips Lead to Arrest in Series of Roadway Shootings Around Kansas City
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Weeks went by last month and the only evidence that victims of a spate of roadway shootings here could offer the police were the loud pops they had heard and the bullet holes in their cars. Someone was shooting vehicles as they drove on the southern edge of this city and in neighboring suburbs, and this metropolitan area of more than two million people was on edge.

headline: Richards Shows Rangers That Confidence Is Contagious
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers achieved only one victory against the Philadelphia Flyers on Thursday, but it is impossible to measure the value of a rejuvenated Brad Richards to the Rangers’ confidence.

headline: A Day of Chants, Bells, a Bike
text: Bora Yoon writes and performs music that combines ancient and modern elements, including 12th-century liturgical chants and abstract electronic “sound architecture.” On Sundays she gets paid to sing at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. Her new album, “Sunken Cathedral,” explores the structural parallels between the vaulted construction of a church and its organ and that of a human chest, with both producing sound by moving air through pipes. She will perform much of the album at the Asia Society on Wednesday. Ms. Yoon, 33, lives in Astoria, Queens, with “a great friend that I found through Craigslist,” she said.

headline: An Orange Jumpsuit for Lent
text: Kent McKeever has been summoned for jury duty twice. The second time was on March 17, more than a week into Lent, so he had no choice but to wear his orange prison jumpsuit. As he entered the McLennan County courthouse in Waco, Tex., two sheriff’s officers stopped him.

headline: Can Paradise Be Planned?
text: When the architect Robert A. M. Stern was a kid in the ‘40s, he used to spend his Sundays perusing The New York Times real estate section. In those days, recalls the self-described “modern traditionalist” best known for buildings like 15 Central Park West and the George W. Bush Presidential Library, “It was all about new houses that were being built in suburbia. I would look at them and redraw the plans. At the basic level I thought they were so damn bad and I thought I could do better.”

headline: Health Officials to Propose Tighter Monitoring of Water Tanks
text: In a reversal, New York City health officials are proposing stronger oversight of rooftop water tanks, which supply drinking water to millions of residents and workers each day but are often neglected by their owners.

headline: Algerian President Wins a Fourth Term
text: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algeria’s leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday. Opposition leaders who boycotted the election immediately cast doubt on the results, accusing Mr. Bouteflika, left, and his supporters of widespread fraud and of inflating the turnout, which was officially 51.7 percent. His strongest challenger, former Prime Minister Ali Benflis, won only 12 percent of the vote. Mr. Bouteflika, 77, has been largely incapacitated since suffering a stroke last year, but he has managed to retain a strong grip on power and has avoided the democratic changes prompted by the Arab Spring uprisings elsewhere in North Africa. He cast his ballot in the presidential election on Thursday from a wheelchair.

headline: Dressed to Lead the Pack
text: “Come on, we got the light, kids,” said the wolf pack leader, as traffic stopped and he guided five well-groomed dogs across Riverside Drive.

headline: Go Forth and Conquer, but Postpone the Selfie
text: Sign of the times: Bryant University in Rhode Island has told its graduating seniors not to take selfies when they come onstage for their diplomas next month.

headline: In Pistorius Trial, Critics See a Justice System Favoring the Rich and Famous
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Before the murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius opened, a judge who ruled that most of it could be broadcast said his decision would counter the notion that South African justice treated the rich and famous “with kid gloves” while it was “harsh on the poor and vulnerable.”

headline: 5 Episodes in a Pivotal Year in New York
text: A half-century ago, a progressive municipal administration took office with an ambitious agenda. Through the prism of five seminal events, in “New York City 1964: A Cultural History” (McFarland), Lawrence R. Samuel, an author and business consultant, explores the seething city that the administration of John V. Lindsay inherited after the election of 1965.

headline: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, a pair of F.B.I. agents appeared unannounced at the door of a member of the defense team for one of the men accused of plotting the 9/11 terrorist attacks. As a contractor working with the defense team at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the man was bound by the same confidentiality rules as a lawyer. But the agents wanted to talk.

headline: Nets Enter Playoffs With Toughness Spawned by Last Year’s Exit
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The genesis of this Nets team can be traced to last May. Forty-nine regular-season victories were quickly rendered meaningless by an inglorious first-round playoff elimination.

headline: Senseless Deaths on a Ferry, and by a Gunman’s Hand
text: The struggle for Ukraine continued to generate the most tension and passion over the past week. Though Russian, Ukrainian, American and European Union foreign ministers were meeting in Geneva to agree on steps to de-escalate the tensions, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to take little heed, provocatively noting on television that in czarist times, southeastern Ukraine was a Russian province called “Novorossiya,” literally “New Russia.” The possibility that he would annex it, as he had annexed Crimea, remained very real.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Journeyman Seems at Home, Nearly No-Hitting the Mets
text: Aaron Harang was known as a low-ball pitcher and a strike thrower when the Mets had him for four starts last September. He was like duct tape for a faltering rotation at the end of a disappointing season, but he was a veteran with enough reason to prove he could still pitch. After the season, the Mets let him leave.

headline: U.S. Plans Military Drills in Eastern Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The United States plans to carry out small ground-force exercises in Poland and Estonia in an attempt to reassure NATO’s Eastern European members worried about Russia’s military operations in and near Ukraine, Western officials said Friday.

headline: Documentary Producer to Lead City’s Film Office
text: Filling a post much discussed from Burbank, Calif., to Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday named Cynthia López, a co-executive producer of the award-winning documentary series “POV,” the new commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment.

headline: A Brownsville Sanctuary, 100 Years and Counting
text: Hundreds of children gathered outside the Brownsville Children’s Library the night it opened its doors in September 1914. Designed to look like a fairy tale castle, the branch, which was financed by Andrew Carnegie, was among the first free-standing children’s libraries in the nation.

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Comes Undone Along With Their Lead
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Concerns surrounding the Yankees’ bullpen entering this season appeared to have been erased through the first 16 games.

headline: N.B.A. Playoff Predictions
text: With the playoffs getting underway, The New York Times’ staff predicts who will emerge from each conference to meet in the N.B.A. Finals.

headline: Corrections: April 19, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) BILLY CRYSTAL: 700 SUNDAYS (2014) In this adaptation of his Broadway show, taped in January, Mr. Crystal, right, pays tribute to his father, Jack, who ran a record store in Times Square, produced concerts for jazz greats like Billie Holiday and died when Mr. Crystal was 15. The set evokes his childhood home in Long Beach, N.Y.; home movies are projected onstage; and an animated family fight, in which Mr. Crystal portrays all the characters, is done in mime. “ ‘700 Sundays’ is itself a love letter to the past,” Jason Zinoman wrote in a review of the production in The New York Times. Still, “all the reverent stories don’t add up to a flesh-and-blood character. Jack Crystal remains remote, larger than life, which may be where Mr. Crystal wants to keep him. It’s the kind of show that you wish your son made about you.”

headline: Cheo Feliciano, Debonair Salsa Singer, Dies at 78
text: Cheo Feliciano, a leading salsa singer renowned for both his love songs and his upbeat improvisations, died in an automobile accident on Thursday in San Juan, P.R. He was 78.

headline: Michael Janeway, Former Editor of The Boston Globe, Dies at 73
text: Michael C. Janeway, a former editor of The Boston Globe and executive editor of The Atlantic Monthly who wrote two books chronicling what he saw as the intertwined decline of democracy and journalism in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 73.

headline: Four Men Are Arrested in New Jersey Gunfight
text: Four men robbed an auto salvage shop in northern New Jersey on Friday and exchanged gunfire with police officers who foiled their attempt to get away in a U-Haul truck, the police said. The four were quickly arrested, though a fifth man involved in the robbery remained at large Friday night.

headline: The Stations of the Cross in Red Hook
text: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 19, 2014
text: “The day-to-day life is very tense. We never know what will happen.”

headline: Deadly Clash Reported on Border of China and Vietnam
text: BEIJING — Five Chinese civilians and two Vietnamese border guards died Friday during a clash between Vietnamese border guards and Chinese citizens who were trying to enter Vietnam illegally, according to official Vietnamese news reports on Friday and Saturday.

headline: Analytics: Is Unfair Trading Fair Game?
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 20 issue of the magazine.

headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
text: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

headline: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
text: JINDO, South Korea — The captain and two crew members of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 270 people — most of them students — missing, were arrested early Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: How Urban Anonymity Disappears When All Data Is Tracked
text: Cities are our paradises of anonymity, a place for both self-erasure and self-reinvention. But soon, cities may fall first in the disappearance, or at least a radical remaking, of privacy.

headline: Divers Begin Bringing Bodies Out of Capsized Ferry
text: JINDO, South Korea — After days of rescue efforts stymied by strong currents and poor visibility, divers made their way into a capsized South Korean ferry on Sunday and began bringing out bodies, starting what officials said would probably be weeks of grim recovery operations.

headline: A Swarm of Ant-Sized Robots, at Your Service
text: While the robots imagined in science fiction novels have often looked like humans, today’s robotic armies are emerging in all shapes and sizes.

headline: European Debt Deflation
text: As I noted yesterday, Sweden is now experiencing deflation, which is bad for a number of reasons — including the fact that household debt is very high, and deflation (or even low inflation) increases the burden of that debt. (This makes it even more ironic that the Riksbank’s justification for ignoring Econ 101 and raising rates in a depressed economy was concern about excessive household debt and financial stability.) Lars Svensson, who has been a prophet without honor throughout, offers more.

headline: Leveled by Landslide, Towns Mull How to Rebuild
text: OSO, Wash. — A sometimes awkward, invariably agonized conversation about the future has begun here at the site of last month’s devastating landslide, about what might be rebuilt and what was perhaps forever lost that day.

headline: When Delight Turns to Reality, It’s Goodbye, Easter Bunny
text: RICHMOND, Calif. — Back in 1988, when the seven founders of the House Rabbit Society first came together at a dining table in Alameda, Calif., just south of here, the idea of keeping a rabbit as an indoor pet was considered fairly smirk-worthy.

headline: Dorsett Is Feisty Key to Rangers’ Fourth Line
text: It was November on the Prairies, and the Medicine Hat Tigers’ team bus was rolling down the cold highway out of Alberta, headed for Saskatoon to play the Blades. But it took an unfamiliar turn, and the players asked Coach Willie Desjardins, “Where are we going?”

headline: Michelle Peluso of Gilt Groupe: I Don’t Need an Ivory Tower (or an Office)
text: This interview with  Michelle Peluso, chief executive of Gilt Groupe, the online shopping site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Banks Cling to Bundles Holding Risk
text: The Volcker Rule doesn’t go into effect until 2015, but that hasn’t stopped big bankers and their supporters in Washington from trying to undermine it.

headline: One Lousy Seat, a Fitting Tribute
text: MILWAUKEE — The corner of a baseball dugout, where the tunnel to the clubhouse intersects with the bat rack, ought to have a friendly greeter. At Miller Park, the home of the Milwaukee Brewers, his name is Bob Uecker. Everyone stops to say hi to him, and Uecker greets all with gusto.

headline: Inspired by an Eclipse
text: Rubina Isaac, 26, works with educational programs and tours for children at Adler Planetarium in Chicago.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic That Leaves
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — To borrow from Joyce Kilmer, I think that I shall never see a puzzle lovely as a tree. Oh, there are some that come close, especially those by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

headline: In Slovakia, Real Lottery Prize Goes to Tax Man
text: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — When Jozef Lazarcik, a 35-year-old factory worker, heard his number called on national television here recently, he pumped his fists, hardly believing his luck.

headline: Weeding Out the Bad Reference
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Democrats Confront Vexing Politics Over the Health Care Law
text: ATLANTA — When Franklin D. Roosevelt established Social Security, he created generations of loyal Democrats. When Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare into law, he built on that legacy, particularly with older Americans. And when George W. Bush instituted a new prescription drug benefit for Medicare, it helped reclaim elderly voters for Republicans.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: House Calls Are Making a Comeback
text: A relic from the medical past — the house call — is returning to favor as part of some hospitals’ palliative care programs, which are sending teams of physicians, nurses, social workers, chaplains and other workers to patients’ homes after they are discharged. The goal is twofold: to provide better treatment and to cut costs.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 19
text: “You’ll see us exploring new areas that we felt we didn’t have the room to do before.” Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, who has been working on revamping the way the company creates and distributes new services, focusing on apps.

headline: My Head Talks Piketty With Bill Moyers
text: By the way, the man himself pronounces it pick a TEA.

headline: When Diamonds Are Dirt Cheap, Will They Still Dazzle?
text: As a seventh grader, I was lucky to land the job of ball boy for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their annual late-March exhibition games in Miami. The experience left me with fond memories — of Roy Campanella smoking a cigar as he stroked line drives in the batting cage, of a young Sandy Koufax throwing harder than seemed humanly possible and of an aging Jackie Robinson struggling to remain in the lineup.

headline: An Overdue Haircut
text: It’s sheep-shearing season across much of the United States, and recently a team of five shearers descended on Lehfeldt Land & Livestock near Lavina, Mont., to remove a year’s worth of growth from about 3,000 ewes and bucks. The work took just over three days; the shearers have an incentive to work quickly because they are paid per sheep. After the wool is removed, it is placed in nylon bales weighing around 500 pounds each and shipped to a warehouse in Billings. Eventually a clothing maker or a mill will bid on it.

headline: From the Fishbowl to the Garden
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Pressure — what pressure? That is what Coach Alain Vigneault was saying last week before the Rangers started their opening-round series against the Philadelphia Flyers. Leading the Rangers is a pressure-filled job, he said, but not as much as coaching an N.H.L. team in Canada.

headline: Shearing Season
text: The springtime business of removing wool from sheep in the United States.

headline: Obamacare Versus The Wusses
text: One of the odd rituals of American punditry — the most famous example is Karl Rove’s tantrum in 2012, but it happens all the time — is the way pundits and operatives keep spinning after the polls have closed. Never mind the vote totals, and let’s dispute the network projections; my guy is still winning!

headline: When Swastikas on Uniforms Meant Luck
text: Why were the Boston Braves wearing a swastika on their caps when they opened the 1914 season against the Brooklyn Dodgers?

headline: Comcast’s Real Repairman
text: One morning late last month, David L. Cohen took a seat in a conference room atop Comcast’s corporate headquarters in Philadelphia, the tallest building in the city, and was handed a binder of architectural drawings. The plans were for a second Comcast skyscraper, taller than the first, because the growing company needs more space.

headline: Taking On Adam Smith (and Karl Marx)
text: PARIS — Thomas Piketty turned 18 in 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell, so he was spared the tortured, decades-long French intellectual debate about the virtues and vices of communism. Even more telling, he remembers, was a trip he took with a close friend to Romania in early 1990, after the collapse of the Soviet empire.

headline: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
text: Ever since the Titanic sank on its maiden voyage, carrying its captain and many of the passengers with it, the notion that the captain goes down with his ship has been ingrained in popular culture.

headline: Familiar Face Shines With a Mets Affiliate
text: RENO, Nev. — Bobby Abreu leaned against the concrete wall outside the modest visitors’ clubhouse last Thursday at Aces Ballpark, discussing how he had landed at this point in his baseball career with the Las Vegas 51s, the Mets’ Class AAA affiliate. When his teammates walked past, he smiled and joked and offered fist bumps.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 54
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: French Journalists Are Freed in Syria
text: PARIS — Four French journalists who were held captive for 10 months in Syria were released on the Turkish-Syrian border late Friday and were on their way home to France, President François Hollande said Saturday.

headline: Fright Nights in the N.B.A.
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The roster of the Oklahoma City Thunder has championship-caliber talent, but the team’s playoff hopes may rest — though not in peace — with one bit player who remains largely unseen.

headline: A 12-Year-Old’s Trek of Despair Ends in a Noose at the Border
text: Noemi Álvarez Quillay took the first steps of the 6,500-mile journey to New York City from the southern highlands of Ecuador on Tuesday, Feb. 4, after darkness fell.

headline: Marx Rises Again
text: IN the season of resurrection, it’s fitting that he’s with us once again — bearded, prophetic, moralistic, promising to exalt the humble and cast down the mighty from their thrones.

headline: Being ‘Good’ Isn’t the Only Way to Go
text: LAST September, the networking site LinkedIn added a feature that allowed its members to say whether they wanted to volunteer or serve on the board of a nonprofit. In just eight months, one million members raised their virtual hands.

headline: Torment on the Stand, but Is It an Act?
text: AGAIN and again over days of brutal cross-examination in a Pretoria courtroom, Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, broke down on the witness stand. He retched. He cried, then sobbed, then grew hysterical. It got so bad that at times the judge, Thokozile Matilda Masipa, had to adjourn the court while Mr. Pistorius regained his equilibrium.

headline: Reader Complaints, Behind the Scenes
text: JACKIE McCaffrey, a Times reader, sounded frustrated.

headline: Still Getting Wolf Whistles at 50
text: WASHINGTON — IT’S weird to be jealous of your car.

headline: The Risks of Everest Are Deadlier for Some
text: ON a bright afternoon in June of 1922, the Mount Everest pioneer George Mallory was leading a group of 17 men tied together in three separate rope teams toward the North Col of the mountain when he heard an ominous sound, and turned to see an avalanche fracturing the steep slope above them.

headline: Tolstoy and Miss Daisy
text: IF you were on I-85 near Atlanta on Wednesday morning or I-95 near Baltimore on Thursday afternoon, there’s a chance you spotted them. You’d remember, especially if she was driving when they lumbered by. It’s not often that you see an 18-year-old girl behind the wheel of a gold-colored Cadillac so enormous, so archaic. And it’s not usually a 79-year-old man you find beside her, her lone companion on the long road.

headline: Randall Copeland
text: Randall Copeland, a Southern Baptist married to a Catholic, is the vice president of operations at the Manischewitz Company, the nation’s largest manufacturer of kosher foods including such Passover staples as matzo and gefilte fish.

headline: The Part-Time Faculty
text: Readers discuss an editorial about the quality and pay of adjunct professors.

headline: How to Get a Job at Google, Part 2
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — HOW’S my kid going to get a job? There are few questions I hear more often than that one. In February, I interviewed Laszlo Bock, who is in charge of all hiring at Google — about 100 new hires a week — to try to understand what an employer like Google was looking for and why it was increasingly ready to hire people with no college degrees. Bock’s remarks generated a lot of reader response, particularly his point that prospective bosses today care less about what you know or where you learned it — the Google machine knows everything now — than what value you can create with what you know. With graduations approaching, I went back to Google to ask Bock to share his best advice for job-seekers anywhere, not just at Google. Here is a condensed version of our conversations:

headline: They Hook You When You’re Young
text: HOW do events from our childhood shape our adult preferences?

headline: Abandon (Nearly) All Hope
text: With Easter upon us, powerful narratives of rebirth and resurrection are in the air and on the breeze. However, winter’s stubborn reluctance to leave to make way for the pleasing and hopeful season leads me to think not of cherry blossoms and Easter Bunnies but of Prometheus, Nietzsche, Barack Obama and the very roots of hope. Is hope always such a wonderful thing? Is it not rather a form of moral cowardice that allows us to escape from reality and prolong human suffering?

headline: A Way for Artists to Live
text: THE bedroom was no wider than a subway car, painted Q-train yellow, and had a window facing a construction site that jackhammered at all hours. But I couldn’t wait to move in. I’d answered a Craigslist ad to join a new communal home, and though I wasn’t sure I was the communal-home type, I was also in a phase of reconsidering what type of person I might be. My six housemates planned to open a collectively owned and operated bed-and-breakfast in our building. If our projected costs and occupancy rates were correct (and if the jackhammering would let up), each partner would work 10 to 15 hours a week at the co-op to cover our rent, utilities and shared groceries, freeing up time to pursue the low-to-zero-pay projects we all had in music, art, education and writing.

headline: In Dad’s Hometown, European Souls
text: KARAPCHIV, Ukraine — TO understand why Ukrainians are risking war with Russia to try to pluck themselves from Moscow’s grip, I came to this village where my father grew up.

headline: Let Them Drink Chocolate
text: I AM a vegetarian, and it’s Passover. So until Tuesday night I am abstaining not only from all kinds of meat — beef, chicken, fish — but also from my usual low-fat alternatives, like bread, cereal and pasta. The holiday strictures laid out by Leviticus, added to my usual ethics, leave me this week with a heart-hostile diet of eggs, cheese, buttered matzo and my wife’s flourless chocolate cake.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 20
text: The Boston Marathon kicks off Monday morning,  one year after a bomb exploded near the finish line of the race, killing three people and wounding hundreds. Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts will discuss security at the marathon on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Hockey Players’ Concussion Suits Follow Path Charted in N.F.L. Cases
text: Someone once said that three makes a trend, and now that three concussion-related lawsuits have been filed by nearly two dozen former hockey players against the N.H.L., a trend has emerged.

headline: Republicans See Political Wedge in Common Core
text: WASHINGTON — The health care law may be Republicans’ favorite weapon against Democrats this year, but there is another issue roiling their party and shaping the establishment-versus-grass-roots divide ahead of the 2016 presidential primaries: the Common Core.

headline: This Time, Get Global Trade Right
text: Many Americans have watched their neighbors lose good-paying jobs as their employers sent their livelihoods to China. Over the last 20 years, the United States has lost nearly five million manufacturing jobs. In that same time, however, the prices that Americans pay for basic goods like T-shirts and televisions have fallen. The cost of clothing is down 8.2 percent since 1993, as “made in China” and “made in Bangladesh” labels have crowded out “made in U.S.A.” on the shelves of the local mall.

headline: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
text: WASHINGTON — Even as the crisis in Ukraine continues to defy easy resolution, President Obama and his national security team are looking beyond the immediate conflict to forge a new long-term approach to Russia that applies an updated version of the Cold War strategy of containment.

headline: So These Professors Walk Into a Comedy Club ...
text: NOT long after the physicist Werner Heisenberg (not the guy from “Breaking Bad”) identified the uncertainty principle in the early 20th century, E. B. White — in a somewhat similar vein — warned against meddling with what defines funny.

headline: Jokes From the Top 10 Cities
text: Researchers from the Humor Research Lab and Peter McGraw and Joel Warner, the authors of “The Humor Code: A Global Search for What Makes Things Funny,” asked more than 900 residents of the top 10 funniest cities to recount their favorite joke. Their responses revealed unique “humor profiles” for each city. Below is a sampling of representative jokes from each place.

headline: Pro-Russian Forces Work on Consolidating Power
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Just before the most important religious holiday of the year for both Ukrainians and Russians, the Orthodox Christian Easter celebration on Sunday, pro-Russian militant groups have paused what had been the daily expansion of their territory in eastern Ukraine.

headline: White Sox, Furthering Legacy, Provide Warm Home for Cubans Amid Chill
text: CHICAGO — Alexei Ramirez wore a winter cap, the kind with a fuzzy pompom on top, in the Chicago White Sox clubhouse last Wednesday. It was warm enough in there, but Ramirez took no chances. Stiff wind and icy air would await him on the field.

headline: Blowing the Dust Off a Century-Old Woe
text: In 23 pitches Friday night against Tampa Bay, Yankees reliever Cesar Cabral pieced together an unsightly outing, one that also has a place in the record books.

headline: Looking at the Ukraine-Russia Crisis from my Ancestral Village
text: For my Sunday column, I returned to the village near Chernivtsi, Ukraine, where my father grew up. What struck me there was the deep yearning for connections to the West, for a future tied not with Russia but with Western Europe. Obviously, one encounters somewhat different sentiments in eastern Ukraine, but overall this popular yearning for a future in Europe runs both deep and broad.

headline: Taunts Fly in Toronto, but Nets Get Last Word
text: TORONTO — It was only halfway through the first game of the N.B.A. playoffs, and Masai Ujiri, the general manager of the Toronto Raptors, was already apologizing to children.

headline: Flyers’ Mason Will Miss Game 2 Against Rangers
text: Philadelphia goalie Steve Mason confirmed after practice Saturday that he was not ready to return to play for Game 2 of the Flyers’ first-round playoff series against the Rangers on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Coach’s Return Is Fraught With Complications
text: MANKATO, Minn. — Todd Hoffner did no coaching at the Minnesota State football practice on Friday, three days after he was reinstated as the team’s coach. Dressed in a purple Mavericks top and black pants, he stood on the periphery, talking to friends and boosters while assistants ran the 1-hour-40-minute session on a windswept afternoon. With the team three weeks into spring drills, Hoffner did not want to disrupt the routine.

headline: Battle Rages in Homs, Hub of Revolt Against Assad Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Deadly battles are raging in Homs, the central Syrian city that was long a hub and a symbol of the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, with both soldiers and insurgents saying they have lost many fighters in recent days as the government presses an all-out assault on the last few rebel-held areas in the Old City of Homs.

headline: Critic of Pakistani Military Wounded in Karachi Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Hamid Mir, a prominent Pakistani journalist and a critic of the nation’s powerful military, was wounded by gunmen in the southern port city of Karachi on Saturday evening, according to police officials and local news media reports.

headline: Woman Arrested in Attempted Kidnapping of 8-Month-Old
text: A 46-year-old woman with a history of trying to abduct young children has been arrested in connection with the attempted kidnapping of an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, the police said on Saturday.

headline: A Tennis Player Learns to Be Aggressive for Health’s Sake
text: MONTE CARLO — Combining unconventional shotmaking and graceful, almost balletic footwork, Alexandr Dolgopolov is one of the most watchable players on the ATP Tour and the best Ukrainian player in a generation.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. A friend of mine told me that Wyatt Earp’s wife was a Jewish girl from New York. True?

headline: Ferry Captain and Crew Questioned
text: The captain of the Sewol has been charged with abandoning passengers, among other counts, after the ferry carrying more than 400 people sank off South Korea. Two crew members were also arrested.

headline: Zhou Family Ties
text: Several members of Zhou Yongkang’s family have made investments in companies with ties to the China National Petroleum Corp., the state oil company formerly run by Mr. Zhou.

headline: In a Mansion’s Interior, a Study in Contrasts
text: Elsie de Wolfe favored flowery painting on walls and furniture, mirrored surfaces to reflect light and an overall brightness for the rooms she designed. Charles Duveen’s trademarks included wood-paneled walls, furniture upholstered in deep red damask or velvet and rooms brimming with dark-hued antiques. Both designers helped create the look of different parts of Coe Hall, the mansion at the heart of the 409-acre Planting Fields Arboretum State Historic Park in Oyster Bay. And now both are the subjects of a new exhibition, “Fabulous Interiors by Elsie de Wolfe and Charles Duveen, 1915-1945,” which traces their careers and the impact they had on the home owned in the early 20th century by William Robertson Coe, an insurance magnate, and his second wife, Mai Rogers Coe, a Standard Oil heiress.

headline: On Wheels
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Another triumph from the Queen of Visual puzzles, Elizabeth C. Gorski. One thing Ms. Gorsi forgot to mention in her comments below is that New Yorkers will go to extreme lengths to find parking for their cars, even if it means pulling your fender right up against the car in front of you. Or sometimes on top.

headline: Investigating Family’s Wealth, China’s Leader Signals a Change
text: HONG KONG — His son landed contracts to sell equipment to state oil fields and thousands of filling stations across China. His son’s mother-in-law held stakes in pipelines and natural gas pumps from Sichuan Province in the west to the southern isle of Hainan. And his sister-in-law, working from one of Beijing’s most prestigious office buildings, invested in mines, property and energy projects.

headline: Suburban Jazz Club Attracts Star Lineups
text: The drummers Eliot Zigmund and Richie Morales are known for their performances on the world’s big stages — Mr. Zigmund with cool-jazz innovators like the pianist Bill Evans and the trumpeter Chet Baker; Mr. Morales with fusion pioneers like the guitarist Al Di Meola and the group Spyro Gyra.

headline: Legal Twist in Bid to Reclaim Nazi-Looted Hospital
text: PARIS — Stephan Templ was hoping to right a historic wrong when he fought to reclaim part of an imposing Victorian hospital that was looted from his family by the Nazis in 1938, he says. Instead, he now faces three years behind bars.

headline: Submersible Seeking Jetliner May Soon Finish First Sweep
text: HONG KONG — An unmanned submersible vehicle searching the ocean floor off Western Australia for signs of the missing Malaysia Airlines plane could finish an initial sweep of the area within five to seven days, search organizers said on Saturday.

headline: Adrianne Wadewitz, 37, Wikipedia Editor, Dies in Rock Climbing Fall
text: Adrianne Wadewitz, a scholar of 18th-century British literature who became one of the most prolific and influential editors of the online encyclopedia Wikipedia, died on April 8 in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 37.

headline: A Play About a Play Reveals Racial Tensions
text: “Trouble in Mind,” originally produced Off Broadway in 1955, has been rediscovered by major regional companies in recent years — and rightly so. Currently staged by Two River Theater in Red Bank, Alice Childress’s play is a semisatirical study of racism in the theater world that proves fascinating on several levels. It is a sometimes acrid backstage comedy, a frank look at mid-1950s social attitudes and also a commentary on the discomfort between blacks and whites that remains relevant to some degree today.

headline: Gene Estess, Who Left Wall Street to Aid the Poor, Dies at 78
text: Gene Estess worked on Wall Street for two decades and came to feel that he never had really good days. “I didn’t come home with stories to tell or satisfaction or a feeling I’d done anything to help anybody except myself and my family,” he said in an interview with The New York Times in 2003.

text: Salsa music fills the air. Clotheslines strung with laundry crisscross the space overhead. When you take your seat at Matthew Lopez’s “Somewhere” at Hartford Stage, all that’s missing from the old San Juan Hill neighborhood of Manhattan is the scent of frying sofrito.

text: Being good is not always enough. It helps to be lucky. That was the case for Romain Edouard, a French grandmaster, who won the Dubai Open Chess Championship last week.

headline: Jacob Birnbaum, Civil Rights Champion of Soviet Jews, Dies at 88
text: Just as the civil rights movement began with students challenging segregation at lunch counters, the movement to free Soviet Jews began with students demonstrating at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

text: LUBBOCK, Tex. — In the back of the Cotton Exchange building in Lubbock’s dusty downtown, the Innocence Project of Texas keeps more than 10,000 files from state prisoners in dozens of blue, purple, and white plastic boxes.

text: CHAPOTEAU, Haiti — For three years, the United Nations has refused to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of cholera to Haiti, insisting instead that it was more important to help the country stanch the disease once and for all.

headline: General Mills Reverses Itself on Consumers’ Right to Sue

headline: 1914: Easter Scenes In Paris
text: Two distinct streams of people could have been noticed outside the various Paris railway termini yesterday, the first consisting of Parisians about to quit the city for the Easter vacation, and the second, composed of English, German and other tourists, who had just arrived bent upon passing the same gay period in exploring the French capital. The result of the ingress of tourists was that the boulevards and main streets of Paris presented an even more cosmopolitan appearance than usual. Fortunately fine weather favored the sightseers and the guides reaped a rich silver harvest. Groups of energetic Teutons made an almost military inspection of the Louvre and decided with unanimity that the Mona Lisa’s smile is as over-rated as it is ambiguous.The char-à-bancs were all crowded, the majority of the passengers wearing caps. At dusk a group of English tourists, who had probably crossed the Channel for the sake of higher mental culture, marched contentedly up the avenue de l’Opéra to the immortal strains of “You made me love you,” supplied by the youngest visitor’s richly toned mouth-organ. The Frenchmen who had remained in Paris gazed upon their progress with unspeakable admiration and drank a thoughtful aperitif to the eternal durability of the “Entente Cordiale.” — The New York Herald, European edition, April 12, 1914.

headline: Clues to Family’s Business Ties Found in Public Paper Trail

The five tablets dedicated to the Zhou family in the hamlet of Xiqiantou list the nation’s former security chief, Zhou Yongkang, by his childhood name, Zhou Yuangen. They also record the names of his first and second wives, his two sons and his two brothers, their wives and their two sons.

headline: Hamilton Grabs 3rd Straight Win in Formula One
text: SHANGHAI — There is an easy way to measure just how much the Mercedes team is dominating the new Formula One season: At the Chinese Grand Prix outside Shanghai on Sunday, for the fourth race in a row, Mercedes beat its nearest rival by nearly half a minute.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (WGN America) SALEM The network’s first original scripted series explores the happenings that incited the infamous witch trials in 17th-century Massachusetts through the characters of Mary Sibley (Janet Montgomery, above), Salem’s unexpectedly pregnant head witch; her beau, John Alden (Shane West), who disappeared for seven years to fight Indians; her mysterious accomplice, Tituba (Ashley Madekwe); and Cotton Mather (Seth Gabel), the town’s spiritual leader. “You’ve got to admit that it’s perversely entertaining,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Though witchery is a favorite theme of shows aimed at teenagers, this series aspires to a grown-up audience. You can tell that from the sex and nudity (the somewhat demure basic-cable variety, but still, there’s a lot of flesh here). More important, you can tell it from the writing. When ‘Salem’ isn’t being deliberately outrageous, it’s cultivating a dynamic that could be fruitful as things move along. Here in the 21st century, science and reason rule, but in a world of sorcery, clinging to rationality just makes you stupid.”

headline: Asking How Much Opera Singers’ Work Is Worth
text: It was Monday morning and somewhere along the Henry Hudson Parkway, Jean Braham was already singing. She was gliding up and down the octaves as she headed down the highway in her Honda Accord.

headline: Another Faithful Hit for Hollywood: ‘Heaven Is for Real’
text: “Heaven Is for Real” became Hollywood’s fourth overtly faith-based hit of the year over the Easter weekend, taking in an estimated $21.5 million — double the dismal ticket sales that Johnny Depp mustered for his latest big-budget effort. But God still could not beat a superhero: The No. 1 movie at North American theaters was again “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” (Disney), which sold about $26.6 million in tickets, for a three-week domestic total of $201.5 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

headline: A Gimlet-Eyed Grunt, Soldiering Balefully Through a War’s Horrors
text: A century after the guns of August first boomed, World War I has lost none of its power to boggle the mind. The numbers are simply too big: 65 million men under arms, 37 million casualties, 12,000 miles of trenches on the Western Front, 1.45 billion shells fired. Rather than a human event, it often seems like an immeasurable abstraction, like negative infinity.

headline: Back to ‘The Boondocks,’ Minus Its Creator’s Touch
text: “The Boondocks” is back, and the less said about it the better, really. Aaron McGruder painstakingly produced three seasons of the sharply satirical animated show over the course of five years, from 2005 to 2010. He wasn’t involved in the long-delayed fourth and final season, which begins Monday night on Adult Swim, and it shows. Is a mediocre “Boondocks” better than no “Boondocks” at all? Maybe. As the show’s moral center, the 10-year-old black-militant ninja Huey Freeman, told the sad striver Tom DuBois when Usher stole his wife in Season 2: “Could be worse. Could be Omarion.”

headline: An Evolutionary Family Drama

headline: From Private Ordeal to National Fight: The Case of Terri Schiavo
text: Her surname in Italian means “slave,” and is pronounced skee-AH-vo. Grim as it may be, the word could apply to Theresa Marie Schiavo, even with its Americanized pronunciation: SHY-vo. For 15 years, Terri Schiavo was effectively a slave — slave to an atrophied brain that made her a prisoner in her body, slave to bitter fighting between factions of her family, slave to seemingly endless rounds of court hearings, slave to politicians who injected themselves into her tragedy and turned her ordeal into a national morality play.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 21
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: To Reduce Inequality, Start With Families
text: The French economist Thomas Piketty swept across the United States last week with a dire warning: Income inequality isn’t going to go away, and it probably will get worse. Only policies that directly address the problem — in particular, progressive taxation — can help us change course.

headline: The Public Health Crisis Hiding in Our Food
text: IF you have high blood pressure, you’re in good company. Hypertension afflicts 67 million Americans, including nearly two-thirds of people over age 60. But it isn’t an inevitable part of the aging process. It’s better to think of it as chronic sodium intoxication. And, as an important new study from Britain shows, there’s a way to prevent the problem — and to save many, many lives.

headline: Granderson Finally Puts an End to His Otherwise Forgettable Day
text: The home crowd seemed anxious as Curtis Granderson came to bat in the bottom of the 14th, with one out and the winning run on second.

headline: Bankrupt City Fighting to Open a Crack in California’s Pension Agency
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — When this bankrupt, working-class city took the unprecedented step in 2012 of stopping its required pension contributions — arguing that it could not otherwise make payroll — other financially stressed California cities took notice: Could San Bernardino defy Calpers, the powerful agency that administers the state’s huge pension system?

headline: Many Auto Show Visitors Unfazed by G.M. Recalls
text: Louis Monetti pulled a tape measure from his back pocket and stretched it across the Chevrolet Cruze’s trunk to make sure his bicycle would fit. Then he crouched for a good look at the car’s rear suspension. It all seemed fine, he said on Saturday at the New York International Auto Show, adding that he probably would buy the Cruze over the Ford Fusion.

headline: Surviving the Mount Everest Avalanche
text: Kaji Sherpa is a climber who survived the avalanche Friday on Mount Everest. From a hospital bed in Katmandu, he recounted the disaster that killed at least 13 Sherpas.

headline: New Mayor and a New Agenda, but Little Change Within the Ranks
text: Four months into his first term, Mayor Bill de Blasio continues to stock the top echelons of his administration with senior aides and commissioners who share his desire to break sharply from the policies and tone set by Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: After Everest Disaster, Sherpas Contemplate Strike
text: NEW DELHI — The 22 Sherpas who set out together toward Mount Everest’s Camp 2 on Friday morning were “full of joy and excitement,” but Kaji Sherpa was apprehensive: They were crossing a notoriously dangerous ice field, and they were moving too slowly.

headline: Sweden Turns Japanese
text: Three years ago Sweden was widely regarded as a role model in how to deal with a global crisis. The nation’s exports were hit hard by slumping world trade but snapped back; its well-regulated banks rode out the financial storm; its strong social insurance programs supported consumer demand; and unlike much of Europe, it still had its own currency, giving it much-needed flexibility. By mid-2010 output was surging, and unemployment was falling fast. Sweden, declared The Washington Post, was “the rock star of the recovery.”

headline: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down.

headline: Starting in June, ‘Today’ Will Simulcast on SiriusXM

headline: From Behind the Plate, a Dutiful Master Orchestrates the Cardinals
text: Baseball on television is nothing like basketball and football. In those sports, the primary camera angle shows most, if not all, of the participants. In baseball, you mostly see just two of the defensive players on every pitch.

headline: Sexual Abuse Lawsuits Are Expected to Expand
text: LOS ANGELES — The next round in a widening legal fight over sexual abuse accusations in Hollywood is now set for 2 p.m. on Monday. At that time, the lawyer who in a lawsuit last week accused the filmmaker Bryan Singer of drugging and raping his client in 1999 expects to announce additional lawsuits at a news conference in Beverly Hills.

headline: When Wrigley Opened, Yanks Were Different. Well, Not Totally.
text: This week, as Chicago’s Wrigley Field marks its 100th anniversary, Yankees fans may be wondering what their own team was like in 1914, before it become a powerhouse franchise, nine years away from its first World Series championship.

headline: Errors Mounted as Chaos Ruled Capsizing Ferry
text: JINDO, South Korea — Of all the images from the loss of a ferry in the cold waters off the southwest coast of South Korea last week, perhaps none have angered South Koreans more than those of the captain and his key crew members awkwardly and quickly fleeing their half-submerged vessel to the safety of a rescue boat, even as hundreds of their passengers remained trapped inside.

headline: Aereo Case Will Shape TV’s Future

headline: The Next Juvenile Justice Reform
text: Research has long shown that locking up young people puts them at greater risk of dropping out of school, joining the unemployment line and becoming permanently entangled in the criminal justice system. States and municipalities have thus been sending fewer young offenders to juvenile institutions and more of them to community-based programs that keep them connected to their families and reduce the risk that they will engage in further crime. The number of children held in custody plummeted from about 107,000 in 1995 to less than 71,000 in 2010 and is still falling.

headline: A Rare G.O.P. Battle Forces an Incumbent to Look Left
text: AUBURN, Calif. — A moderate Republican trying to unseat a conservative congressman from his own party, Art Moore sat a little stiffly at a Sizzler restaurant here during the monthly meeting of the Auburn Area Republican Women Federated. Appearing after the meeting’s agenda was already set, Mr. Moore was not invited to speak before the group — not that it would have made much of a difference.

headline: Running Out of Time
text: Next year, in December, delegates from more than 190 nations will gather in Paris to take another shot at completing a new global treaty on climate change. This will be the 21st Conference of the Parties under United Nations auspices since the first summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.

This is very deep dish — layered with malice and kindness, truth and conjecture, and all the mixed motives that make human beings such endlessly intriguing subjects of speculation.

headline: Longing for a Facial Scar to Simply Vanish
text: When Sutton Foster appears on Broadway, she’s usually boasting a sunbeam smile, flapping away in tap shoes, clowning around amiably and generally behaving like a girl determined to nail the talent competition in a beauty pageant, and maybe take home the Miss Congeniality award, too. But pep-allergic people will not need to steel themselves to see the terrific, heart-stirring revival of “Violet,” the musical by Jeanine Tesori and Brian Crawley that opened at the American Airlines Theater on Sunday night, starring Ms. Foster in a career-redefining performance.

Strenuous denials from the Kremlin have closely followed each accusation by Ukrainian officials that the world was witnessing a stealthy invasion by Russian forces.

headline: 50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back
text: TWIN BRANCH, W.Va. — When people visit with friends and neighbors in southern West Virginia, where paved roads give way to dirt before winding steeply up wooded hollows, the talk is often of lives that never got off the ground.

headline: John Shirley-Quirk, a Bass-Baritone and Specialist in Britten, Is Dead at 82
text: John Shirley-Quirk, a British chemistry teacher who almost by accident became a world-renowned bass-baritone, performing at the Metropolitan Opera and becoming known as an interpreter of Benjamin Britten, died on April 7, in Bath, England. He was 82.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Rush to Make Money May Be Hurdle

headline: U.S. Promotes Network to Foil Digital Spying

headline: Doris Pilkington Garimara, Aboriginal Novelist, Dies at 76
text: In the 1930s, Australian authorities undertook a campaign to force the native Aborigines into white culture, with the hope that intermarriage would eventually eliminate their race. Mixed-race aboriginal children were taken from their families and forbidden to speak their native language.

Facebook, with a 59.65 percent share in March, dominated traffic from computer users, followed by You Tube (23.02 percent), Twitter (2.29), Google Plus (1.71) and Yahoo Answers (1.07).

headline: Harris Goldsmith, Critic and Classical Pianist, Dies at 78
text: Harris Goldsmith, a rarity in classical music for his simultaneous careers as a professional pianist and a music critic, died on April 2 in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Wizards Beat Bulls at Their Own Gritty Game
text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Bulls are best known for their grit. A scrappy team short on household names, the Bulls can make opponents uncomfortable with hard-nosed defense and relentless energy. Stacey King, an announcer for the team, fondly calls the Bulls a collection of “heart, hustle and muscle.”

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Joss Whedon Fans Get a Surprise
text: Fans who lined up for the Tribeca Film Festival premiere of the paranormal romance “In Your Eyes,” written by Joss Whedon and directed by Brin Hill, on Sunday night were in for a surprise after the credits rolled: They needn’t have gone at all.

headline: India Election Digest: April 21
text: What you need to know on Monday about India’s elections: Residents of Punjab city see a connection between drugs and politics, the Bharatiya Janata Party backs off its campaign song, and analysts warn that it’s too early to count out the Indian National Congress.

headline: Brooklyn’s Most Beloved Ice Cream Shop Creates a Special Flavor for T
text: Spring’s arrival in Brooklyn means longer days, cherry blossoms flowering in the Botanic Garden — and blockbuster, out-the-door lines at Ample Hills Creamery, Brian Smith and Jackie Cuscuna’s three-year-old artisanal ice cream shop. Warmer weather drives crowds to the Prospect Heights storefront, which may explain why the couple are debuting another, bigger location later this spring in Gowanus — complete with a party space, a roof deck and an industrial-size kitchen that will let them produce pints for retail sale. They have also just published “Ample Hills Creamery: Secrets and Stories from Brooklyn’s Favorite Ice Cream Shop” ($24.95, Stewart, Tabori & Chang) with the writer and illustrator Lauren Kaelin, a longtime employee and creator of the smart Benjameme blog.

headline: Summerstage Plans Are Announced
text: SummerStage, the annual festival of free, live shows presented by the City Parks Foundation all over New York City, will offer performances of nearly every style of music – opera, hip-hop, R&B and jazz, for starters – as well as theater, film, dance and even a couple of circuses. The festival opens on June 3, with a performance by Ty Dolla Sign at Red Hook Park, in Brooklyn, and ends on Aug. 24, with a concert in Central Park by the Fania All-Stars (tickets are required for this one), part of a celebration of the 50th anniversary of Fania Records, the Latin music label, that will run through the festival.

headline: Low Vitamin D in Mothers Tied to Cavities in Babies
text: Low levels of vitamin D in pregnancy are associated with the development of cavities in babies, researchers report.

headline: Afghan Newlyweds, Facing Threats, Find Brief Respite in Mountains
text: HINDU KUSH RANGE, Afghanistan — They eloped from their village in the Bamian Valley on the first day of spring, but their month on the run has taken them back into winter as they fled higher into these rugged mountains in central Afghanistan. They stayed in the homes of friends when they could, and they slept rough in caves when they could not.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after people die by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco, George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, chooses a life of obscurity instead of exploiting his gift. In London, a solemn boy named Marcus feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left him adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris, Marie Lelay (Cécile de France), who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the world is determined to ignore. “Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan. He added: “What does seem new — newly strange, newly beautiful — is what ‘Hereafter’ makes of the here and now. It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that it’s wonderful.”

headline: Times Minute | Boston Marathon Takes Off
text: Also on the Minute, a tribute to the boxing champion Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and the story of a modern-day Romeo and Juliet from Afghanistan.

headline: MoMA’s Expansion and Director Draw Critics
text: Glenn D. Lowry, who will soon begin his 20th year running the Museum of Modern Art, has a longstanding practice of taking time each week to visit artists’ studios. Which is why he could be found one recent morning along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, watching the glass-blowing sculptor Josiah McElheny and assistants fashion a vessel from molten lumps, a process almost Elizabethan in its rituals.

headline: Parking Rules

headline: Tailoring Success
text: The luxury clothing company Kiton, based outside Naples, Italy, has made its name synonymous with craftsmanship and attention to its clients.

headline: Naples, a Haven of Hand Work
text: NAPLES, Italy — In a basement room on a street where motor bikes and honking horns drown out even the insistent church bells, Davide Tofani is working on a typical Neapolitan soft jacket. “When I make a suit, it is like shaping a second skin of my customer,” the tailor says. “I cannot imagine making a suit without knowing the body that will use it.”

headline: Arrests of 4 More Crew Members Sought in Korean Ferry Sinking
text: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors sought to arrest four more crew members on Monday from the South Korean ferry that sank last week as they raced to unravel the mysteries surrounding the sinking, which left more than 300 people dead or missing in one of the country’s worst peacetime disasters.

headline: China Southern Pays U.S. Fine Over Monkey Cargo
text: China Southern Airlines, a major state-owned carrier that in March announced it would no longer transport monkeys to laboratories in the United States, has agreed to pay a fine for violating an American animal welfare law, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

headline: Assault by City Management Officers Triggers Clash
text: Urban enforcement officers clashed with residents in a town in eastern China, the latest in a long series of violent interactions between the officers, known as chengguan, and the street peddlers they are tasked with regulating and bystanders who can be caught up in the disputes.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Look Back at the World’s Fair of 1964
text: In “Around the Unisphere at the World’s Fair, Lives Changed,” Liz Robbins writes about the World’s Fair of 1964 that took place in New York City.

headline: An Indian From India Photographs Both
text: It gets complicated when people ask Annu Palakunnathu Matthew where she’s from. Born in London, raised in India and now living in the United States, her journey is twisty, her accent a hard-to-place blend.

headline: Activist for Getting More Saudi Women Into the Work Force Plans Book
text: When Reem Asaad started what would become a successful campaign to require Saudi lingerie shops to hire female workers, she had no idea how it would turn out.

headline: Should Society Support Artists and Others Pursuing Creative Works?
text: Artists need time to do their creative work, but they also have to earn money to live.

headline: Bankers in Hong Kong Join Fight Against Mainland Influence
text: HONG KONG — In this city awash with money from mainland China, a former hedge fund manager hopes to incite a political awakening among the bankers, stockbrokers and financial traders whose livelihoods have become increasingly enmeshed in the mainland’s cash and influence.

text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: The Mayor’s Bumpy Ride
text: Good morning on this cool but warming Monday.

headline: China to Allow the Blind to Take College Entrance Exams
text: China’s Education Ministry has told its staff to provide more “humane” service in this year’s university entrance examinations, or “gaokao,” and allow disabled people, particularly the blind, to take part. Advocates said this was the first time that the state had clearly spelled out that the blind could take the regular university examination, and how.

headline: A Ray of Literary Hope on Italian TV
text: MILAN — Last November, I found myself in a glass elevator speeding to the top of the  Mole Antonelliana tower in Turin. I wasn’t there for the view: I had exactly 59 seconds to persuade Antonio Pennacchi, one of Italy’s most important writers, to read my novel. Even more nerve-racking: My elevator pitch was live on camera.

headline: For Boston, a New Beginning After a Safe Ending to Its Marathon
text: BOSTON — When the digital clocks along Boylston Street flashed 2:49 on Marathon Monday, nothing out of the ordinary happened. And that was reason for joyous celebration.

headline: Analysts Share High Expectations for Bigger iPhones
