headline: Editorials, From Start to Finish
text: Before I started working at The New York Times, I hadn’t spent much time pondering the question of how editorials came into the world. For all I knew they were delivered by stork. Roughly two years ago I was hired to start a blog for the editorial page, called Taking Note, and more recently I’ve started writing editorials as well. So I can now demystify the process. Storks have no involvement and, contrary to what some people on Twitter believe, neither does the Democratic National Committee.Editorials represent the opinion of The Times (unlike Op-Ed essays, which are written by outside contributors who represent their own opinions, and not that of the paper).

headline: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Giants Seek to Resolve Suit on Hiring Practices
text: After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: 1904: The Easter supplement
text: Between 1898 and 1904, the New York Herald published Easter supplements. The supplements included short stories by famous writers, colorful illustrations, culture guides, and advertisements for luxury hotels or the latest fashion boutiques. Here is the cover of the 1904 Easter supplement.

headline: Airbnb’s Huge Valuation
text: Airbnb is said to have closed a $475 million round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. At the value assigned by the investment, Airbnb — a website and app where homeowners and apartment dwellers rent their homes, spare rooms or couches to travelers — would be worth more than some established hotel chains like Wyndham Worldwide or Hyatt.

headline: Russia Accuses Kiev of Flouting Ukraine Accord
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Russia’s foreign minister accused the interim authorities in Kiev on Monday of flagrantly violating the international accord reached last week aimed at defusing the crisis in eastern Ukraine, in remarks that suggested Russia may be further preparing the groundwork for a military intervention.

headline: Class, Oligarchy, and the Limits of Cynicism
text: A recent paper (pdf) by Martin Gilens and Benjamin Page is getting a lot of attention, and deservedly so. Gilens and Page look at a number of issues over the past 30+ years where polling data let us identify public policy preferences, which can be compared with elite and interest-group preferences. And what they find is that politicians don’t seem to care very much about what the public thinks: when elite preferences and popular preferences are different, the elite almost always wins.

headline: In ‘Dutch Doubles,’ 4 Choreographers, Inspired by 4 Artists
text: AMSTERDAM — Like most big ballet companies today, the Dutch National Ballet has to carefully tiptoe between conservation and innovation — presenting works that signal “classical ballet” to audiences (“Swan Lake”!), and commissioning new pieces that say “we are relevant to contemporary culture.” Ted Brandsen, who has been directing the company since 2003, has been particularly proactive about new work, with a keen eye for talented dance makers. In a new program, “Dutch Doubles,” which opened last week at the Het Muziektheater, he adroitly combines tutus, Mozart and Beethoven, as well as high-profile collaborations with modern artists and designers.

headline: Rotating a Smartphone Video
text: Q. My son sends me videos of my grandson taken with a cellphone, but the ones he films in portrait mode play back in landscape mode in Windows Media Player on my Windows 7 computer. Is there a way to rotate them?

headline: Barclays Said to Join Commodity Exodus
text: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.

headline: Bookshelf | In Architecture, Small is Big
text: In architecture as in so much of life, bigger often seems better. Yet these days, contemporary architects — and their clients — are under stricter than ever budgetary, environmental and aesthetic constraints. As the editor and critic Philip Jodidio writes in his introduction to Taschen’s new book, “Small Architecture Now!” ($60), “small buildings often provide a degree of freedom to architects that cannot be obtained in gigantic public or corporate projects.”

headline: U.A.W. Drops Appeal of VW Vote in Tennessee
text: The United Automobile Workers union unexpectedly announced on Monday that it was dropping its effort to have a new unionization vote ordered at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline: Mumbai’s Business Community Tries New Enterprise: Politics
text: MUMBAI — At Priyadarshini Park in the Malabar Hill neighborhood of south Mumbai, under the shade of neatly aligned coconut trees, a platoon of middle-aged stock brokers discussed the volatility of the Indian stock markets as they went on their regular power walk along the frothy shoreline of the Arabian Sea.

headline: Chinese Court Orders Seizure of Japanese Vessel
text: A court in Shanghai has ordered the seizure of a Japanese ship over legal claims dating to before World War II, adding a point of contention to the sometimes rancorous relationship between Japan and China.

headline: Assessing the Impact of a Profit-Sharing Plan
text: In August, I wrote a series of posts about the design and implementation of a profit-sharing plan for my business. I decided to try this because my company has a long history of producing poor (or no) profits.

headline: Oh, the Stories Wrigley Field Could Tell
text: When the ballpark that became Wrigley Field opened in Chicago in 1914, it soon hinted at the checkered baseball history made there in the next 100 years.

headline: Wrigley Field Turns 100
text: Despite the team’s disappointing record, the century-old home of the Chicago Cubs continues to draw fans.

headline: Justice Stevens Suggests Solution for ‘Giant Step in the Wrong Direction’
text: WASHINGTON — Justice John Paul Stevens, who turned 94 on Sunday, is a mild man with an even temperament. He has a reverence for the Supreme Court, on which he served for almost 35 years until his retirement in 2010, and he is fond of his former colleagues.

headline: Manchester United’s Moyes Is Out, According to Reports
text: David Moyes was supposed to be the long-term successor to Alex Ferguson at Manchester United, one veteran Scottish manager passing control to his handpicked heir last May. But after a calamitous season that sees United heading toward its worst finish in the Premier League, it now appears that Moyes will not even last until this summer.

headline: Knicks Fire Mike Woodson as Coach
text: Mike Woodson was 109-79 in his two-plus seasons as the Knicks’ coach. His regular-season winning percentage of .580 is the third highest in franchise history. Still, it was no surprise Monday when the Knicks announced that he had been dismissed, less than a week after he and the team finished the 2013-14 season with a hugely disappointing 37-45 record that left them out of the playoffs.

headline: K.K.R.’s Acquisition of an Affiliate Encounters Opposition
text: A plan by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to acquire an affiliate has encountered opposition from a group that advises investors.

headline: U.S. Ordered to Release Memo in Awlaki Killing
text: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan ordered the release on Monday of key portions of a classified Justice Department memorandum that provided the legal justification for the targeted killing of a United States citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, who intelligence officials contend had joined Al Qaeda and died in a 2011 drone strike in Yemen.

text: 1889: American Art to Show in Paris

headline: Another Coach Spun Out the Garden’s Revolving Door
text: The Knicks have fired another coach, and to this we may all shrug and say, What else is new?

headline: Rockets Fired From Gaza Draw Airstrikes From Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Seven rockets fired from the Gaza Strip landed in southern Israel on Monday morning, prompting Israeli airstrikes that hit at least one training site of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that rules Gaza.

headline: Quiche With Red Peppers and Spinach
text: The real spring vegetable here is the spinach, lush and beautiful at this time of year. You can always get red peppers in a supermarket, and when you cook them for a while, as you do here, even the dullest will taste sweet. I make the pepper mixture first, then wilt the spinach in the same pan and line the tart shell with the savory mix. If you can, make the pepper and spinach filling a day ahead. It dries out a little if it sits overnight in the refrigerator and is less likely to dilute the custard.

headline: Roasted Asparagus and Scallion Quiche
text: I’ve made many a spring quiche filled with asparagus and herbs, yet I’d never thought about roasting the asparagus instead of steaming it. But lately I’ve been buying thick stalks of asparagus, and all I want to do is roast it; roasting intensifies the flavor and the stalks become incredibly succulent, more so than when the asparagus is steamed. This quality isn’t lost even when the sliced stalks are hidden inside a quiche.

headline: Cabbage and Spring Onion Quiche With Caraway
text: Spring onions found their way into several of this week’s quiches. For this one, I cooked the onions with cabbage – even a half a head of cabbage that has been lingering in your refrigerator will work here – until both vegetables were soft, lightly colored and sweet. I added caraway seeds to the mix because I love the flavor of caraway with cabbage. I used 1/2 teaspoon, just enough so that people noticed; they couldn’t recognize what it was (“Cumin?” they asked) right away, but they liked it. I made the filling a day ahead and let it sit uncovered overnight in the refrigerator.

headline: Scallion and Celery Quiche
text: I’ve written before that I consider celery an underrated vegetable, capable of contributing nuance and texture to a dish. But it would have never occurred to me to have it as one of the main vegetables in a quiche if I hadn’t heard the restaurant critic Jonathan Gold discussing a tarte au céleri that he’d had at Church & State in downtown Los Angeles, a sort of tarte flambée in which celery, celery root and apples stood in for the traditional onions and bacon. I figured if it worked so well in that dish, it could also in a quiche. It does.

headline: Whole-Wheat Pie Dough
text: Most of the vegetable tarts that I post on Recipes for Health call for a yeasted olive oil crust that I love to work with. With French quiches, however, I prefer a crust that resembles classic French pastry. However, I always use at least half whole-wheat flour – which is not so French – not only for its nutritional superiority, but also because it gives the resulting shell a nuttier, richer flavor that is particularly welcome in a savory tart. This dough, adapted from Jacquy Pfeiffer’s recipe for pâte brisée in “The Art of French Pastry,” involves more butter than you’re used to seeing in my recipes, but an occasional butter-based crust, especially when it’s made with whole-wheat flour and contains a filling that is all about vegetables, is not going to kill us. Instead, it’s a vehicle for the foods that we want to move toward the center of our plates.

headline: Justices Take Case on Status of Jerusalem in Passports
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Congress may require the State Department to treat Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in American passports, in a case that touches on generations of conflict in the Middle East, as well as the dueling roles of Congress and the president in the conduct of foreign affairs.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap:  The (Madison Avenue) Gods Must Be Crazy
text: Season 7, Episode 2

headline: No Time For Sargent
text: I’m a little late to this, but there’s lately been some buzz about the unearthing of Tom Sargent’s 2007 graduation speech, in which he briefly laid out 12 principles of economics. For the most part the speech is getting favorable attention. So let me be a spoilsport. It’s not so much that what Sargent said is wrong, although some of his principles are by no means universally agreed upon, even in normal times. What’s so striking about Sargent’s points is that it’s hard to think of a worse time to cite them. And the people citing that old speech clearly have ulterior motives.

headline: Food Curated: Brooklyn Bouillon
text: Rachael Mamane thought she could generate extra income for farmers who raise animals by creating a line of stocks from discarded bones. Brooklyn Bouillon was born from the idea.

headline: Video: Brooklyn Bouillon
text: A few years ago, when Rachael Mamane was working for the greenmarkets in New York City, she noticed that none of the farm stands offered high-quality stock to home cooks on a consistent basis. She had the idea to help farmers who raise animals to generate extra income by creating a line of stocks from their “waste,” like discarded bones. It was an opportunity no one else had seized.

headline: Listen Up | Newcomer King Avriel Makes Neo-Soul That Doesn’t Shy Away From Big Ideas
text: “I have a really short attention span,” says Avriel Epps. “I’m always trying to get to the next thing, and that’s how I feel about music, too. The only thing that’s going to stay consistent … is the depth of my message.” The singer, who goes by the gender-bending moniker King Avriel, has only released a few songs so far, all for free via her Soundcloud account. But she has already garnered attention for her use of sultry electro production to explore big themes like gender inequality and consumerism.

headline: A New Zealand Trail Is Open for Cyclists
text: New Zealand’s Heaphy Track, the longest of the country’s nine famed Great Walks, is now open to cyclists.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival:  Students Get a Starring Role in Times Square
text: At 11:57 each night this month, 40 electronic billboards in Times Square simultaneously spring to life with what, at first glance, might be mistaken for a shoe commercial. Six teenagers pull on Nikes, Uggs, lace-up boots and brogues in neighborhoods from Bushwick to Tribeca, then set off on the subway — destination: Washington Square Park — eventually converging with friends in a group hug.

headline: Toronto Gets an Art Fair With a Name Change
text: The newest offshoot of the Affordable Art Fair, a franchise that originated in London in 1999 and has generated multiple offspring around the world, is coming to Toronto in May. After opening with a private preview on May 7, at the Direct Energy Center, it runs for the next four days.

headline: Brain, Teen: Brain, Child Magazine Devotes an Issue to Parents of Teenagers
text: The single, No. 1 request from readers of this blog is “more about teenagers, please.” That vexing subset of children is also the most challenging for parents to write about, from a personal perspective: that toddler who was quite cheery about having her foibles unmasked for readers can quickly become a teenager highly protective of even the smallest of online mentions. Advice and more distant commentary is far easier to come by than essays from parents truly “in the trenches.”

headline: Tricky Dice
text: Our puzzle this week is about a tricky kind of relationship — one that’s a bit counterintuitive. Normally, when we compare several things, we expect something like the following: your friend Agnes weighs more than Beatrice, and Beatrice weighs more than Clarissa, then we’d expect Agnes to outweigh Clarissa. This makes sense. This kind of relationship would also work for heights, ages, and other single-dimension measures. This also works for containers: a dime is in a small pouch in Clarissa’s purse, so the dime is in the purse.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jo Becker on Reporting the Fight for Marriage Equality
text: Jo Becker, a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter for The Times, discusses her new book, “Forcing the Spring: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality,” to be published this month by Penguin Press.

headline: Tributes to Avalanche Victims in Nepal
text: Family, friends and climbers gathered in Katmandu, Nepal, to pay respect to the Sherpas killed in an avalanche on Mount Everest.

headline: Boston Marathon Day
text: Scenes from the Boston Marathon on Monday, a year after two bombs exploded near the finish line.

headline: Elizabeth Spencer Wins Rea Award
text: Elizabeth Spencer, whose body of work includes “The Light in the Piazza” (1960), has been awarded the 2013 Rea Award for short fiction.

headline: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
text: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will issue quarterly reports this week. Also on the Minute, the effect of California’s water crisis and celebrating 100 years of Wrigley Field.

headline: Counting Death in the Movies
text: In last week’s Riff, Alexander Huls bemoans the death of death in Hollywood films. “Of course action films have saccharine subplots that exist only to lend meaning to their staggering body counts,” he writes. “But in recent years, killing a major character in your average blockbuster has become inert thanks to the increasing use of formulas to create stakes.”

headline: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
text: In the Video

headline: A Year Later, It’s Old Glory in Boston Marathon
text: BOSTON — Something unusual happened when Meb Keflezighi, far ahead of his competitors, began passing some of the elite women who had started before the men on Monday in the Boston Marathon. As he charged by, many of the women — exhausted and in pain — cheered him on.

headline: Lawmakers Broadening Their Focus to Fight Against an Array of Sex Crimes
text: WASHINGTON — As the high-profile congressional fight over military sexual assault recedes, lawmakers are broadening their focus to an array of sex crimes like college campus assaults, preying on child and human trafficking.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Allscope Direct was opened by Allscope Media, New York, and Joe Shain, a longtime direct response marketing executive, who will be chief executive of Allscope Direct.

headline: Interpublic Group Joins Ranks of Publishers With Report in Magazine Form
text: Who says print is dead? Not the Interpublic Group of Companies, one of the world’s largest agency holding groups, which is publishing its corporate citizenship report, called Stronger, in magazine form in addition to a digital version available online.

headline: Image of the Day: April 21
text: HTC, a company based in Taiwan, unveiled new smartphones at a function in New Delhi.

headline: Today in Small Business: What Start-Up Founders Pay Themselves
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Waiting, Hoping and Coming Unraveled
text: “Do you want to do a retrieval?” my doctor asked.

headline: A Controlling Light Inside the Brain, Diet Doesn’t Matter to Cancer
text:
Optogenetics allows the use of light to switch specific brain activity on and off — so what does that tell us? A new look at the effect of nutrition on cancer suggests there’s not much effect at all.
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: Syrian Election Announced; Rebels Report New Weapons
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Although more than a third of Syria’s population has been displaced by war, the government said Monday that it would conduct a presidential election on June 3, an announcement denounced by the opposition as absurd and criticized by the United Nations as a new subversion of peace efforts.

headline: Spurning Merger Approaches, AstraZeneca Pursues Own Path
text: The British drug company AstraZeneca said no to a tie-up with Pfizer, turning down the possibility of one of the biggest drug mergers in recent history.

headline: InBloom Student Data Repository to Close
text: In a setback for the nearly $8 billion prekindergarten through 12th-grade education technology software market, inBloom, a non-profit corporation offering to warehouse and manage student data for public school districts across the country, announced on Monday morning that it planned to shut its doors.

headline: Brain Control in a Flash of Light
text: SAN DIEGO — Dr. Karl Deisseroth is having a very early breakfast before the day gets going at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience. Thirty thousand people who study the brain are here at the Convention Center, a small city’s worth of badge-wearing, networking, lecture-attending scientists.

headline: Group Led by TPG to Buy Health Care Company for $461 Million
text: A United States health care company that does business in China has agreed to be sold to a group of investors for $461 million after the investors raised their bid in the face of a rival offer.

headline: Birth Control at 7-Eleven
text: There was something illuminating about Cardinal Timothy Dolan’s obtuse remarks on the so-called birth-control mandate.

headline: Washington Company Cancels Russian Theater Festival
text: Citing a rise of anti-American sentiment and a yanking of Russian funds, the Woolly Mammoth Theater Company of Washington has canceled a festival of experimental plays from Moscow that were set to run this fall as part of the company’s 35th anniversary season.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Gidion’s Knot’
text: The suicide of a young boy named Gidion pits mother against teacher in Johnna Adams’s dark drama “Gidion’s Knot.” Set inside a primary school classroom, the play unfolds in real-time as the two women discuss the boy’s suspension and other events in the hours before he shot himself to death. The conversation turns into an emotionally fraught confrontation that tackles the issues of parental responsibility, youth violence and schoolyard bullying, with a strange detour into the world of medieval poetry.

headline: ‘Fortress of Solitude’ Musical Among Highlights of New Public Theater Lineup
text: A new musical based on Jonathan Lethem’s acclaimed novel “The Fortress of Solitude,” as well as another new musical by the creators of the Tony Award-winning show “Passing Strange,” are among the productions in the Public Theater’s 2014-15 season line-up that the theater announced on Monday.

headline: 2 Executions in Oklahoma Are Stayed, Ending Tussle
text: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers late Monday, ending a Kafkaesque legal showdown in which courts argued over jurisdiction even though the prisoners had successfully challenged the legality of the state’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.

headline: How a Song Written by Sia Furler Becomes a Hit
text: Last weekend’s magazine featured Steve Knopper’s profile of Sia Furler, who has written songs for artists like Beyoncé, Christina Aguilera and Flo Rida. Below, Knopper shares some of Furler’s stories about her experiences writing what would become hits for some boldface names in pop music.

headline: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: April 18-20, 2014
text: • On Friday, 27-year-old Mohammed Whitaker was charged with 18 felony counts in connection with a dozen shootings that wounded three people on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area in the past month. Police said more than 100 tips from victims and witnesses poured in, and the suspect had been under surveillance since April 11. They did not reveal a motive.

headline: Ivan Orkin’s Ramen Restaurant to Open on the Lower East Side
text: Occasionally a chef will do a pop-up in a borrowed kitchen to preview a new restaurant. But Ivan Orkin, the first American chef to open his own ramen shop in Tokyo, has had months of trial runs with his more casual Slurp Shop in the Gotham West Market. “It wasn’t supposed to happen like that,” he said as he was showing off his nearly finished Lower East Side restaurant, called Ivan Ramen. “This place was supposed to come first and the Slurp Shop would be the spinoff.”

headline: Russian Says Ukraine Violated Accord
text: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, accused Ukraine of violating the Geneva agreement and said pro-Russian civilians were asking to be saved.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Picks Up a Prize, Prematurely
text: Lewis Hamilton, driving for Mercedes AMG, held on to beat his teammate, Nico Rosberg, in Sunday’s Chinese Grand Prix. The win came despite an error by the flagman, who waved the checkered flag a lap early.

headline: Obama Names White House Counsel
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that he was naming W. Neil Eggleston, a veteran lawyer with extensive experience representing government officials in congressional and criminal investigations, as his next White House counsel.

headline: Magic in Service of Truth
text: Gabo lives. The extraordinary worldwide attention paid to the death of Gabriel García Márquez, and the genuine sorrow felt by readers everywhere at his passing, tells us that the books are still very much alive. Somewhere a dictatorial “patriarch” is still having his rival cooked and served up to his dinner guests on a great dish; an old colonel is waiting for a letter that never comes; a beautiful young girl is being prostituted by her heartless grandmother; and a kindlier patriarch, José Arcadio Buendía, one of the founders of the new settlement of Macondo, a man interested in science and alchemy, is declaring to his horrified wife that “the earth is round, like an orange.”

headline: A Wine Critic’s Realm Isn’t a Democracy
text: Heady discussions about the role of the wine critic may strike many people as navel gazing. Yet one issue has bubbled up on social media and blogs repeatedly in the last few months: Should wine critics allow their personal preferences to color their critical views? Or should they remain neutral on questions regarding a wine’s style, regardless of how they feel about it?

headline: Interview: Chris Messina on ‘Alex of Venice’
text: This was one of a series of posts on debuts that originally ran during the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Should Supreme Court Justices Play Politics With Retirement?
text: Former Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens’ new book — Six Amendments: How and Why We Should Change the Constitution — comes out tomorrow, and has been getting as much attention as you might expect for a book by a former justice calling for multiple controversial constitutional fixes.

headline: White House Easter Egg Roll Kicks Off
text: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, hosted the annual Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House.

headline: Planning a Trip That’s Socially Acceptable
text: Two new travel apps are harnessing the power of Facebook to help friends spend some time together.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 52
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ambulances Were Dispatched Late to Fatal Fire in Queens, Official Says
text: The New York City fire commissioner said on Monday that ambulances were dispatched later than they should have been to a Queens fire that killed two 4-year-old children and injured three other people late Saturday night.

headline: Cap’n Crunch Is Looking at You
Weekly News Quiz | April 8-21, 2014
text: An avalanche disaster, a novelist’s death, an Internet bug and a late-night successor: How many of our questions about the news of the last two weeks can you answer correctly?

headline: Banking Troubles, but Not a Word About Fraud Claims
text: Reading The Times’s coverage of Bank of America’s quarterly loss last week, I almost felt sorry for the financial behemoth. It has mortgage troubles, you see. It has onerous legal costs.

headline: Be Wary of a Big Mining Merger
text: Barrick Gold’s interest in a $33 billion merger with Newmont Mining deserves a skeptical eye.

headline: With Planning Out of the Way, Time to Enjoy the Moment
text: When we think of financial planning, we naturally focus on the future. We start by getting really clear about where we are today, then we spend time thinking about where we want to be 10, 20 or even 30 years from now. Part of the process includes deciding how much we’ll want to spend, when we’ll want to spend it and how much we can save. Someone has to decide when the plan will end, too, and estimate a year of death, perhaps for two people.

headline: Attackers Said to Single Out South Sudanese by Background
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Hundreds of civilians were killed when South Sudanese rebels took control of a strategic oil-producing town last week, the United Nations confirmed on Monday.

headline: Bucket List Item: White House Easter Egg Roll
text: WASHINGTON — Everly Deml could barely sit still atop her father’s shoulders, her tiny pink shoes bouncing against his chest. President Obama and Michelle Obama had just arrived for the 136th annual White House Easter Egg Roll, but Everly, 2, was angling for a better view of a six-foot-tall Easter bunny on the South Lawn.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Unequal Schooling
text: To the Editor:

headline: For These Females, No Such Thing as Penis Envy
text: A Brazilian cave insect has done a most unusual sex-role reversal, a new study finds: Females have penises, and males have vaginas.

headline: Chimps Are Particular About Where They Rest
text: Chimpanzees select firm, resilient wood to make their daily beds in trees, according to a new study in PLOS One. The researchers found that wild chimps at the Toro-Semliki Wildlife Reserve in Uganda used Cynometra alexandri, or Ugandan ironwood, in 73.6 percent of their nests, even though it constituted only 9.6 percent of trees in the study area. Weaving a bed from high-quality wood allows the chimps to safely rest in a prone position. Above, an adult chimp in a C. alexandri tree.

headline: Reactions
text: Conservation

headline: Guidance on Cleaning Mushrooms
text: Q. It is often hard to wash off the growing medium from store-bought mushrooms. Is it safe to eat? Should the stems be further trimmed?

headline: Indie Fashion Icons Jennifer Mankins and Jane Mayle on the Evolution of N.Y.C. Style
text: “Have I made your life crazy?” the retailer Jennifer Mankins asks the British-born fashion designer Jane Mayle as she greets her in the lounge of New York’s Marlton Hotel. The two have come together on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of Mankins’s Bird, the chain of Brooklyn boutiques that helped popularize a style of easygoing bohemian chic now worn by women in every cool neighborhood in America.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Korea, Nepal, Kent and the Netherlands.

headline: New Painkiller Rekindles Addiction Concerns
text: The abuse of prescription painkillers has reached epidemic proportions in America.

headline: The Trail of Tears, and of Damaged Skulls
text: Evicted from their Southeastern homeland by the federal government in the 1830s, Native Americans were sent on forced marches to eastern Oklahoma that became known as the Trail of Tears, an ordeal of disease, starvation and death. Now a study of Cherokee remains suggests that the stress interfered with the normal growth of their skulls.

headline: Running the Marathon
text: John Eligon of The Times at the starting line of the Boston Marathon on Monday morning.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: The Economy is Not Like a Household
text: I dashed off my Sargent comment in the few minutes before class, which meant that it was longer and more complicated than it should have been. So I want to come back to what I think is the most important point. In his speech, Sargent went right away to this:

headline: Growing Sales for ‘Beautiful’ and ‘Rocky’ on Broadway
text: The new Broadway musicals “Beautiful” and “Rocky” grossed more than $1 million for the first time last week, with the producers of “Beautiful” even sending out a news release on Monday to crow about the box office tally – at a time when “Beautiful” and other shows are trying to show signs of momentum heading into this year’s Tony Awards races. The competition for the best musical Tony is wide open for the first time in years, and four or five nominations for the award will be announced on April 29.

headline: In Performance: Julia Bullock
text: Julia Bullock, a rising soprano from Juilliard, sings “Canción de Cuna Para Dormir a un Negrito.” She is accompanied by the pianist Renate Rohlfing.

headline: An Abridged Version of an Age-Old Story, With a Supper (but Gluten-Free)
text: If Ed Sylvanus Iskandar had found himself in the Garden of Eden, he would surely have eaten the forbidden fruit — then made pies from the rest of the apples and served them to all comers. Having distilled the complete works of Sophocles into a single evening of theater (“These Seven Sicknesses”), this ambitious, savvy young director has now commissioned more than 40 playwrights to condense the Old and New Testaments into “The Mysteries,” a five-and-a-half-hour event at the Flea Theater that is both gratifying and grueling.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Prepare Unusual Hostile Bid for Maker of Botox
text: Updated, 9:12 p.m. | Activist investors are exerting ever more influence on corporate America, pressing companies to cut costs, replace executives and strike deals. On Monday, William A. Ackman, among the brashest men on Wall Street, made perhaps the boldest move yet for an activist.

headline: HBO Renews ‘Silicon Valley’ and ‘Veep’
text: HBO continues to celebrate a potent Sunday night, using another week of solid ratings to lock in, for at least another season, the three-show lineup that has become among the best received in that network’s history.

headline: The Lure of Forbidden Food
text: How hard will your child work for food?

headline: Claudia Rankine Wins $50,000 Poetry Prize
text: Claudia Rankine has been named the eighth winner of the $50,000 Jackson Poetry Prize. The award, run by the nonprofit organization Poets & Writers, is “given annually to an American poet of exceptional talent who deserves wider recognition.”

headline: Media Previews in Beijing Feature Many Debuts From Global Automakers
text: Auto China, held every two years in Beijing to showcase new models directed at the growing Chinese market, opened Sunday in Beijing with a media preview that featured a surprisingly robust display of debutantes from Chinese, European and American automakers.

headline: There Goes the Sun
text: Like just about everyone who has looked at the numbers on renewable energy, solar power in particular, I was wowed by the progress. Something really good is in reach.

headline: For Square, Making Money Remains a Challenge
text: The payments start-up Square has been considered one of the hottest young companies in Silicon Valley, with a multibillion-dollar valuation. But it now appears to be facing some growing pains.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Long-Run Fiscal Prospects
text: Slides here (pdf). I thought it would be unfair to the students not to give them a bit of color at the end.

headline: If It’s Possible, It Happened
text: Zooming through a Stockholm intersection on his bicycle one morning, 18-year-old Max Tegmark never saw the truck that hit him. The blast of a horn, the screech of tires and a sickening thud followed in quick succession, extinguishing a young life filled with promise.

headline: An Apple a Day, and Other Myths
text: SAN DIEGO — A trip to almost any bookstore or a cruise around the Internet might leave the impression that avoiding cancer is mostly a matter of watching what you eat. One source after another promotes the protective powers of “superfoods,” rich in antioxidants and other phytochemicals, or advises readers to emulate the diets of Chinese peasants or Paleolithic cave dwellers.

headline: Brain-Mapping Milestones
text: As the Brain Initiative announced by President Obama a year ago continues to set priorities and gear up for what researchers hope will be a decade-long program to understand how the brain works, two projects independent of that effort reached milestones in their brain mapping work.

headline: For Audiences as Varied as an Ark Full of Animals
text: LOS ANGELES — As you push on metal bars, a towering 16-foot giraffe with a mosaic body stretches its head. Flamingos with fly-swatter feet and pink-purse bodies promenade past, guided by puppeteers. A child turning a crank sets off sparks of lightning, signaling an approaching storm. And a moving rubber ramp lifts small animals, two by two, into an enormous ark made of unpainted fir.

headline: Not Just Playing Around Anymore
text: This year, a United Nations program devoted to urban planning in countries affected by poverty or natural disasters began developing a sports field in the slums of Kibera, Kenya, designing it in the popular sandbox video game Minecraft. The game, which allows players to build entire worlds out of cubes in a 3-D environment, helped the project leaders create a visual representation of the field that could be easily understood by the neighborhood’s residents.

headline: Cancer Vaccine Proves Effective in H.I.V. Patients
text: Vaccines against cervical cancer work well even in sexually active women with H.I.V., a new study has found. It also found that women who already have one or two strains of the cancer-causing virus can be protected against others.

headline: Literary Lives Laid Bare by the Nanny
text: I do judge books by their covers, sometimes, and the one on “Love, Nina” made me place it in the “probably not” pile. Its bright watercolor artwork (kids, bicycle, vaguely European street scene) suggests a book that’s trying too hard, in the Peter Mayle vein, to be adorable. The subtitle, “A Nanny Writes Home,” doesn’t dispel this impression.

headline: Finding Lyricism in the Contemporary Canon
text: The scores for “Refrain,” Stockhausen’s 1959 work for three musicians, provoked some titters when they were carried onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening. Each of the players was allotted sprawling sheets, a few feet long by a few feet wide, secured on cardboard by binder clips, and half of each sheet was given over to oddly curved musical staves.

headline: Portuguese Drone Program Off to Nonflying Start
text: As the Lisbon daily Público reported, the Portuguese Navy’s fledgling drone program attracted international attention last week because of footage of the failed maiden voyage of a new reconnaissance craft that was quickly viewed hundreds of thousands of times online.

headline: Their Surprise Route to Popularity
text: In sitcoms, it’s been the season of the embarrassing dad. Michael J. Fox, Robin Williams, Christopher Meloni, J. K. Simmons, Beau Bridges, Martin Mull and Peter Riegert have all played lovably messed-up fathers in new shows. (That could be the cast of a pretty good production of “Glengarry Glen Ross.”)

headline: Science Tools Anyone Can Afford
text: STANFORD, CALIF. — Manu Prakash keeps a map on his bedroom wall that imagines what the world would look like if it were configured according to the scientific research that each region produces.

headline: Felix Salmon to Leave Reuters
text: Felix Salmon, a prominent writer at Reuters on finance and the news media, said on Monday that he was leaving the news agency.

headline: Old World, New Tech
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The streets here offer a glimpse of what the future may have to offer.

headline: Maybe an A for Effort?
text: Student: Amethyst Amelia Kelly, a.k.a. Iggy Azalea.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Your Mother’s Copy...’
text: Chris Stack and Zoë Sophia Garcia in a scene from Kirk Lynn’s play “Your Mother’s Copy of the Kama Sutra,” at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Alone in a Prison Cell With a Tiny Window
text: “Solitary Nation” is about as hopeless an hour of television as you can imagine, which is exactly the reason to watch it. Whatever picture you might have in your mind of the nature of solitary confinement will be changed by this “Frontline” documentary (Tuesday night on PBS stations), and any notions you might have that it could be eliminated will be dimmed.

headline: Mets’ Ron Darling Pitches ‘That Should Be a Word’ Submission
text: Several months ago, a lot of people around here were absolutely giddy when The New York Times Magazine became a plot device on “House of Cards,” with actual cameos by Matt Bai, our chief political correspondent back then. But for my money, our little publication didn’t really hit the pop-culture big time until last Friday night, when Ron Darling dropped a One-Page Magazine reference during the Mets’ broadcast.

headline: Architect Helps Shape Future of a Building He Had to Leave
text: One of the happiest moments of the architect Steven Harris’s career arrived as he was being evicted in 2011 from his TriBeCa loft, his home of 34 years.

headline: ‘Saudi America’: Mirage?
text: At a time when Russia is saber-rattling and the Middle East is in turmoil, a welcome geopolitical trifecta could be in the making. The United States is poised to surpass Saudi Arabia and Russia as the world’s top oil producer. Canada’s oil sands have vaulted the country to energy superpower status. Mexico is embarking on a historic constitutional energy overhaul that its president promises will propel the country’s economy.

headline: Valeant’s History of Deal-Making
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which said on Monday that it was teaming up with the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman to bid for the maker of Botox, is no stranger to deal-making.

headline: Spotlight Illuminated Some Knicks Coaches but Singed Others
text: Red Holzman and his two N.B.A. titles cast a long shadow over the roster of coaches who tried, and failed, to lift the Knicks to the top.

headline: Insider Expected to Succeed Mulally at Ford
text: DETROIT — Ford Motor has picked Mark Fields, its chief operating officer, to succeed Alan R. Mulally as the next chief executive of the company, according to a person with knowledge of the move.

headline: How Green Was Thy Norman Conquest?
text: LONDON — WHEN William the Conqueror invaded England in 1066, he could not have imagined what would happen to the land he seized from the Anglo Saxons.

headline: ‘Nothing Racist’ in Blackface Dancers, English Candidate Insists
text: Updated, Tuesday, 12:56 p.m. | To the ever-growing catalog of behaviors that are not racist according to European politicians — like comparing a black minister to an orangutan in Italy and sharing a fabricated image of President Obama staring at a banana in Russia — we can now add performing in blackface, thanks to a candidate for Parliament in rural England.

headline: In Defense of Chocolate Milk
text: On the topic of chocolate milk, in schools in particular, I’m with Mark Oppenheimer. Writing about a recent article in PLOS One describing what happened when 11 schools, serving kindergarten through fifth grade, eliminated chocolate milk from their cafeterias (the students drank less milk, threw more milk away and bought fewer school lunches over all), he says:

headline: Tomorrow’s America, in Queens
text: WHEN the New York World’s Fair opened 50 years ago today in Flushing Meadow Park, in Queens, its president, Robert Moses, hailed it as an immediate success. And while it failed to turn a profit, more than 51 million people visited it over its two six-month seasons, drawn to its shiny corporate pavilions and space age optimism as a welcome distraction for a nation still mourning the death of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: GitHub Founder Resigns After Investigation
text: [ Updated to include Twitter commentary from Marc Andreessen, the venture capitalist whose firm financed GitHub. ]

headline: With Defiant Spirit, Boston Marathoners Run Again
text: More than 30,000 racers took park in the Boston Marathon, a year after an attack shattered a joyous tradition more than a century old

headline: Focus Turns to Samsung’s Patents at Trial
text: Before Monday, the focus of the latest Apple and Samsung patent trial was whether Samsung copied Apple. But on Monday, Samsung said Apple has done some copying of its own — including a method for transmitting video over wireless devices.

headline: Cameron’s Description of Britain as ‘Christian Country’ Draws an Angry Response
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron’s effort to describe his own Christian faith at Easter has backfired, with some critics accusing him of fostering “alienation and division” by characterizing Britain as a “Christian country.”

headline: World Carbon Emissions
text: In billions of metric tons, 2011. The worldwide total was about 32.6 billion metric tons.

headline: Keystone Pipeline May Be Big, but This Is Bigger
text: WASHINGTON — THE Keystone XL pipeline is a great political symbol. The proposed 1,700-mile pipeline, which would carry 830,000 barrels daily of carbon-heavy crude from Canada’s Alberta oil sands to Gulf Coast refineries, has galvanized environmental activists, who call it a litmus test for President Obama’s commitment to fighting climate change. It is a political weapon against Mr. Obama for Republicans, who call it a symbol of job creation and energy security. It has motivated liberal donors, led by the California billionaire Tom Steyer, who has personally urged Mr. Obama to reject the pipeline.

headline: Autism and the Agitator
text: What do you call someone who sows misinformation, stokes fear, abets behavior that endangers people’s health, extracts enormous visibility from doing so and then says the equivalent of “Who? Me?”

headline: Defendant Killed by Court Officer at Utah Trial
text: SALT LAKE CITY — With stunned jurors looking on, a defendant in a long-running gang prosecution was shot and killed by a deputy United States marshal in the federal courthouse here on Monday morning after he lunged to attack a witness testifying in his trial, federal authorities said.

headline: Drones Are Becoming Energy’s New Roustabouts
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — THE egg white drone lifted off from its ground station at a hospital construction site here, hovered for an instant, then zoomed off, sounding like a five-pound bee as it buzzed around the cranes towering over the six-acre project.

headline: Ice or Molten Salt, Not Batteries, to Store Energy
text: WASHINGTON — ENERGY storage is crucial to transforming the electric grid into a clean, sustainable, low-emissions system, the experts say. And it’s happening already, just not the way most consumers would expect.

headline: Skeptical Justice Scolds Coca-Cola on Juice Label
text: WASHINGTON — Not long after a lawyer for Coca-Cola started to defend its label for a blended fruit juice at a Supreme Court argument on Monday, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy subjected her to a series of unusually harsh questions.

headline: We Could See You in the Gas Tank Later, Alligator
text: PRODUCTION of biodiesel as an alternative to fossil fuels is on the rise in the United States, and one reason, proponents say, is that it can be made from a long list of raw materials.

headline: When Lending a Player Can Be Self-Defeating
text: MADRID — Imagine that you own an unusually large number of sand buckets. You have so many, in fact, that when you go to the beach one morning, someone immediately asks if they can borrow one, and you happily agree. It is one fewer to carry, after all, and you probably would not have used it anyway.

headline: The End, or Something
text: My new editor and I were sharing a celebratory drink at a swanky Lower Manhattan bar, like a pair of characters in my first novel, which she would publish in less than a year. She said that everyone loved it, there was only one concern: It did not have an ending. I explained that it did have an ending, it was just an ambiguous one.

headline: Shunning Gas Hogs, Athletes Green Their Rides
text: JEREMY GUTHRIE considers himself easygoing and comfortable with his beliefs, including how he feels about the environment.

headline: Boy Scout Troop Loses Charter Over Gay Leader
text: SEATTLE — The Boy Scouts of America, which voted last year to allow gay scouts but not openly gay scout leaders, has revoked the charter of a church-sponsored troop here for refusing to fire its adult gay scoutmaster.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Aid to Holders of Argentine Debt
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday seemed inclined to offer at least modest help to Argentina’s creditors.

headline: Iran Disputes Reports of Violent Crackdown in Prison’s Political Detainee Block
text: Iran’s penal authorities sought on Monday to discredit reports of a violent clash last week inside the political detainee block in Tehran’s Evin Prison, calling them fabrications fomented by enemies of the government.

headline: Vietnam Returns Migrants to China After Deadly Border Clash
text: BEIJING — The Vietnamese authorities have returned to the Chinese government 11 Chinese migrants and the bodies of five others after members of the group were involved in a deadly clash with Vietnamese border guards last Friday, according to a Vietnamese news report.

headline: Linking the Los Angeles Airport
text: LOS ANGELES — The two concrete nubs, dotted with rusted sticks of rebar, that protrude from the elevated rail tracks near Aviation Boulevard are reminders of the unfulfilled promise that came nearly 25 years ago with the restart of a rail system here.

headline: Answering an Emergency Call: Yes, There Is a Doctor on Board
text: WHEN I travel, I try to remember a quotation often attributed to William Butler Yeats that there are no strangers, only friends you have not yet met.

headline: Pakistan: Unicef Workers Freed
text: Two Unicef staff members who were abducted last week in Pakistan’s southern port city of Karachi have been released, a spokesman for the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Monday. The spokesman, Stéphane Dujarric, said the two were safe and well, but he had no other details. It was not clear who had abducted them or why they had been freed. Foreign aid workers in Pakistan have been increasingly singled out by jihadist insurgents for kidnappings and attacks. At least 12 United Nations staff members have been killed in Pakistan since January 2009. Some of the assaults have been tied to Taliban retributions for efforts by Unicef and other international aid groups to vaccinate children against polio, which has been spreading in Pakistan, particularly in the northwest tribal areas. Some Taliban leaders have said vaccine workers are Western spies using the guise of humanitarian aid to gather intelligence information.

headline: The Value of Unused Tickets? Airlines Won’t Say
text: HERE is the explanation for why I booked two one-way trips for the same day, from two different cities 2,500 miles apart. It involves parrots and construction workers.

headline: The Tyranny of the Glass Boxes
text: One57, the luxury condominium skyscraper under development just south of Central Park, lists several neighborhood attractions on its website. Among them is the Rizzoli Bookstore, which for decades operated out of a roughly 100-year-old neo-French Classical townhouse at 31 West 57th Street.

headline: Yes, Tanaka Can Still Remember How It Feels to Lose
text: BOSTON — The feeling Masahiro Tanaka had Aug. 19, 2012, must have been so bad that he resolved not to feel it again for a long, long time. That was the date of Tanaka’s last loss in a regular-season game.

headline: Netflix Says It Opposes Comcast’s Merger Bid
text: Netflix on Monday voiced strong opposition to Comcast’s planned $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable, even while confirming that it was raising subscription prices.

headline: The Leadership Emotions
text: Throughout American history, most presidents had small personal staffs. They steered through political waters as amateurs, relying on experience, instinct and conversations with friends.

headline: No Corrections: April 21, 2014
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Wage Theft Across the Board
text: When labor advocates and law enforcement officials talk about wage theft, they are usually referring to situations in which low-wage service-sector employees are forced to work off the clock, paid subminimum wages, cheated out of overtime pay or denied their tips. It is a huge and underpoliced problem. It is also, it turns out, not confined to low-wage workers.

headline: For a New Burt’s Bees Line, Check Your Calendar
text: WHILE it may seem that advertising is everywhere, one place marketers have not infiltrated is the popular calendar software on computers, smartphones and tablets. But now, in what Burt’s Bees says is a marketing first, the natural personal care brand is introducing promotional messages that will appear as appointments in electronic calendars like those by Microsoft, Apple, Google and Yahoo.

headline: Investigated by China’s Leaders, Powerful Family Has a Defender: Its Hometown
text: XIQIANTOU, China — Older villagers knew the eel fisherman’s boy who would become one of China’s most fearsome men. Until recently, his two younger brothers were their neighbors. “All three brothers were good people,” said a 69-year-old woman who lived next door. “They would not do bad things.”

headline: Transparency on Targeted Killings
text: For years now, the Obama administration has been playing a self-serving and duplicitous game over its power to kill people away from any battlefield and without judicial oversight or accountability. It has trotted out successive officials and doled out tidbits of information attesting to the legality of President Obama’s claim to unilateral authority to carry out such killings, while withholding information essential to evaluating that aggressive claim of executive power.

headline: The Real Port Authority Scandal
text: This is a column about the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, but you won’t read a word in here about the lane-closing scandal in Fort Lee, N.J. This is about another scandal, one that has been going for on so long that people don’t even think of it as scandalous. Indeed, it involves no illegality whatsoever. But that doesn’t mean it isn’t a scandal.

headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Ruling to Stay Executions
text: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers who had successfully challenged the legality of the state’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.

headline: Hamish Maxwell, Philip Morris Empire Builder, Dies at 87
text: Hamish Maxwell, whose acquisitions of food companies in the 1980s turned Philip Morris into a consumer products colossus, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87.

headline: The Lives of Emma Edmonds
text: In 1864, with huge casualties from battles in Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley, the Union enlisted thousands of volunteer nurses from the North, among them a reclusive 23-year-old woman named Sarah Emma Edmonds. But this wasn’t the first time Edmonds had volunteered for service. Nor was there any indication that this shy woman nursing soldiers in West Virginia had spent years behind enemy lines as a spy

headline: Battling for a Safer Bangladesh
text: After the Spectrum sweater factory collapsed in 2005, killing 64 workers, hardly anything changed to improve factory safety in Bangladesh.

headline: Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Steve Huber, an affable salesman who is still paying off an unexpected medical bill, was not among the millions of Americans who signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act during the enrollment period that ended March 31.

headline: Panel Tells Port Authority to Lessen Governors’ Sway
text: For an agency that has conducted most of its business behind closed doors for decades, the meeting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey held on Monday morning was indisputably extraordinary.

text: BOSTON — The white T-shirts said 4.15 Strong on the front and Survivor on the back.

headline: Companies Built on Sharing Balk When It Comes to Regulators
text: In the newfangled sharing economy, questions about safety, taxes and regulation have tended to be an afterthought. That has helped propel companies like Uber, Airbnb and Lyft into the stratosphere.

headline: Under Russia, Life in Crimea Grows Chaotic
text: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea — After Russia annexed Crimea practically overnight, the Russian bureaucrats handling passports and residence permits inhabited the building of their Ukrainian predecessors, where Roman Nikolayev now waits daily with a seemingly mundane question.

headline: Indictment Details How to Forge a Masterpiece
text: The painting caught Pei-Shen Qian’s eye, but it was the price that affected him deeply.

headline: Dancing Gertrude Stein, Surrounded by Wonders
text: In her 1934 lecture “Plays,” Gertrude Stein wondered, “What is the use of telling a story since there are so many and everybody knows so many.” You might ask the same question, gently, of Ripe Time’s “The World Is Round,” a tender and sassy adaptation of Stein’s opaque children’s book at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Fisher Theater.

headline: A Journey to Intimacy That’s Nobody’s Business but Their Own
text: If the title “Your Mother’s Copy of the Kama Sutra” doesn’t give you the heebie-jeebies (isn’t your mother’s copy of “Fifty Shades of Grey” mortifying enough?), rest assured that something in this new play by Kirk Lynn certainly will.

headline: Watch Out: The Ex-Wife Has Arrived, and She’s Got Lots of Baggage
text: Plays with just two characters usually move in one of two directions: from animosity to comity, or vice versa. “Annapurna,” a new play by Sharr White starring Megan Mullally and Nick Offerman, is definitely the kind that begins in full battle.

headline: Talking Mom Out of Bombing the Brownstone
text: Estelle Parsons, the great actor who stars as an embattled but indomitable Brooklyn painter in “The Velocity of Autumn,” a new play by Eric Coble, seems to be living an eternal springtime. Now 86, Ms. Parsons has lost little, if any, of her energy, and absolutely none of her ability to bring sustained, animated life to a well-drawn character. She never leaves the stage during this 90-minute, two-character play, which opened on Monday night at the Booth Theater, and yet she seems daisy-fresh at the curtain call, as if ready to run a half-marathon as an encore.

headline: It May Be Read to a Miscreant
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You are getting sleepy … keep your eyes on the circled/shaded squares in Ed Sessa’s puzzle and when you are feeling really, really relaxed, make the check out to me and send it to … never mind. Just kidding.

headline: U.S. Drones and Yemeni Forces Kill Qaeda-Linked Fighters, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — American drones and Yemeni counterterrorism forces killed more than three dozen militants linked to Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen over the weekend in one of the largest such attacks there in months, officials from both countries said Monday.

headline: Do the Rich Call the Shots?
text: Has the United States become more of an oligarchy than a democracy, with the economic elite holding more influence than the public on policy?

headline: Waiting Lists for Kindergarten Drop by Half, New York City Says
text: The number of students placed on waiting lists for kindergarten dropped by half this year as New York City’s Education Department used a new strategy for matching students with schools, officials said on Monday.

headline: As Jets Start Workouts, They Hope to Build on a Positive Ending
text: The Jets had last assembled the day after their season ended at Miami, where they toasted the present and the future — the victory that evened their record at 8-8 and the news that their beloved coach, Rex Ryan, had been retained. They filed into their New Jersey practice complex on Monday, nearly four months later, with a comparable level of excitement, to hear what could be construed as a continuation of Ryan’s post-mortem speech from December.

headline: Mexico Honors a Colombian Writer Whom Many Considered One of Their Own
text: MEXICO CITY — Every March, often with a yellow flower pinned to his lapel, Gabriel García Márquez stood on the stoop of his home here to greet well-wishers on his birthday.

headline: Analysis of Airbnb Listings
text: In an affidavit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the director of research for the state attorney general noted that of the more than 19,500 listings on Airbnb in New York at the end of January, the majority were for an entire apartment.

headline: Mayoral First Couple Talk About Love and Hard Times
text: In his first few months as mayor of New York, Bill de Blasio has rarely passed up a chance to dote on his wife, Chirlane McCray, from behind a lectern. On Monday he took his wife and his mushy, gushy expressiveness to the couch — and the nationwide audience — of ABC’s daytime talk show “The View.”

headline: Ukrainian Roma Face Threats and Violence
text: Roma in Ukraine said that the homes of seven of the 150 Roma families in Slovyansk were robbed by masked, armed men over the weekend.

headline: When It Comes to Fatherhood, It Seems Christie Knows Best

headline: A Driver’s Bloody Run-In With an Angry Detroit
text: DETROIT — Steve Utash had driven the same streets through this city for years on the way to his tree trimming jobs or his home in the suburbs. But one afternoon this month, along this familiar route, he found a side of Detroit he had never encountered, a Detroit where racial tension, churning just below the surface, can break into lawlessness in broad daylight. He found a side where people sometimes talk about meting out justice on their own, mostly because they say they cannot be sure when, or if, the police will show up.

headline: Boy Who Hid in Plane’s Wheel Well Beat Long Odds in Surviving 5 ½-Hour Flight
text: Jumping a deteriorating airport fence, running across the airport unobserved in the darkness and climbing into the wheel well of a parked Boeing 767, as a California teenager did on Sunday, is not all that difficult, according to experts, but surviving the trip — in this case, a five-and-a-half-hour flight from San Jose, Calif., to Maui, Hawaii — is extraordinary.

headline: Nets’ Anderson Has World of Experience in Pressure Situations
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Alan Anderson is one of five players on the Nets’ roster making his N.B.A. postseason debut during the first-round series against the Toronto Raptors. But to lump him with the other playoff initiates would be a mistake.

headline: Nepalese Government to Set Up Relief Fund for Sherpas
text: NEW DELHI — The government of Nepal has agreed to create a relief fund for Sherpa mountain climbers who are injured or killed in accidents and to make other concessions to the Sherpas, according to an official at the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation. The official, Sushil Ghimire, said some of the revenue the government gets from expeditions to Mount Everest would be set aside for the fund.

headline: Seeking a Museum With a Funny Bone, Starting From Scratch
text: Gabrovo, Bulgaria, is the home of the celebrated House of Humor and Satire. Odessa in Ukraine plays host to the famed Humorina festival. A Museum of Comedy is being planned for a church crypt in London.

headline: Intelligence Chief Issues Limits on Press Contacts
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has barred officials at 17 agencies from speaking to journalists about unclassified intelligence-related topics without permission, according to a newly disclosed directive.

headline: Mejia Shows Why Mets Can Rely on the Rotation
text: The home fans stood and applauded Jenrry Mejia as he walked off the field during the seventh inning Monday night. He had held the Cardinals scoreless, at times baffling them, and seemed to have grown up a little. This was perhaps his best start this season. He crossed his heart, kissed his hand and pointed to the sky.

headline: Voices From Donetsk
text: In Donetsk, Ukraine, pro-Russian residents spoke out about Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit and America’s role in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

headline: Beleaguered Albuquerque Department Reports Another Fatal Shooting by Police
text: ALBUQUERQUE — An Albuquerque police officer fatally shot a suspected car thief on Monday during a foot chase in which, officials said, the suspect pointed a gun at the officer as he closed in on her. The shooting occurred 11 days after the Justice Department rebuked the Police Department for engaging in a “pattern or practice of unconstitutional use of deadly force.”

headline: Russia Displays a New Military Prowess in Ukraine’s East
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry has accused Russia of behaving in a “19th-century fashion” because of its annexation of Crimea.

headline: Decades in Prison Sought for CityTime Scheme
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a judge to impose sentences of 105 years, 80 years and up to 40 years on three men who the government has said became “unbelievably rich” in connection with New York City’s scandal-marred payroll modernization project known as CityTime.

headline: Rangers Calmly Disagree With Two Diving Penalties
text: Any small advantage, gained or lost, can deeply affect a series as close as the first-round playoff matchup between the Rangers and the Flyers, which continues Tuesday with Game 3 in Philadelphia.

headline: Obama’s Strategic Shift to Asia Is Hobbled by Pressure at Home and Crises Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to announce an agreement with the Philippines next Monday that would give American ships and planes the most extensive access to bases there since the United States relinquished its vast naval installation at Subic Bay in 1992.

headline: Even With Dying Boxer’s Appeal, a Tough Road Ahead for Convicted Man
text: It was the dying wish of the former prizefighter Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a man whose life had come to symbolize how the justice system can go terribly awry: to see David McCallum, a Brooklyn man who had written to him from prison and asked for his help in overturning his murder conviction, go free.

headline: Official Denies F.B.I. Was Investigating Manifesto Leak
text: A Justice Department official denied Monday that the F.B.I. had investigated how a manifesto by Khalid Shaikh Mohammed ended up at The Huffington Post. It came to light last week that agents had approached a member of the defense team for a detainee facing trial before a military commission over the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He was asked to sign a confidentiality agreement, something the defense lawyers said improperly made him an informant. The disclosure derailed a week of pretrial hearings, and the special trial counsel, Fernando Campoamor-Sanchez, an assistant United States attorney, is leading an investigation into the matter. It was widely speculated that the subject of the F.B.I. inquiry was how the 36-page manuscript by Mr. Mohammed — the self-described architect of the attacks — had been leaked. But in a public court filing on Monday, Mr. Campoamor-Sanchez said that was not true. He did not identify the investigation’s actual subject, although he apparently offered greater details to the judge in an accompanying classified filing.

headline: Two Wounded in National Zoo Shooting
text: Two people were wounded in a shooting Monday evening that shut down the National Zoo on an unusually busy day. At least one suspect — initial reports said there were two — was being sought in the shooting, which occurred at the zoo’s entrance just before 6 p.m., the Washington police said. The police said the victims’ injuries were not life-threatening, but both were taken to a hospital for treatment. Police officials said they did not know what led to the shooting.

headline: Student Loans Can Suddenly Come Due When Co-Signers Die, a Report Finds
text: For students who borrow on the private market to pay for school, the death of a parent can come with an unexpected, added blow, a federal watchdog warns. Even borrowers who have good payment records can face sudden demands for full, early repayment of those loans, and can be forced into default.

headline: Word of the Day | suffragist
text: suffragist• \ˈsəf-ri-jist\• noun

headline: Utility Poles Generate Heat From Long Island Residents
text: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y. — Rich Bentley first noticed them in Manhasset Valley Park, and thought they were for coming field lights. Other homeowners on the North Shore of Long Island began spotting them, too: towering wooden poles with big round pulleys that resemble dream catchers, outside their windows in the thick of newly amputated trees.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) A FIERCE GREEN FIRE (2013) At one time, it was about the dams. The naturalist John Muir and the forester Gifford Pinchot waged war in the early 1900s over the flooding of the magnificent Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park. Decades later, the proposed damming of the Colorado River prompted public outrage, and the environmental movement was born. Today some two million organizations worldwide work on behalf of social justice and the environment. In this Earth Day tribute, “American Masters” chronicles issues (pollution, whaling, conservation of the Amazon rain forest, climate change) within the fight and the players who made a difference (Lois Gibbs, who rallied on behalf of Love Canal; David Brower, above, the first executive director of the Sierra Club; and Paul Watson and Rex Weyler, the founders of Greenpeace). “The environmental movement is about nature versus humanity,” says Robert Redford, who with Meryl Streep, Ashley Judd, Van Jones and Isabel Allende narrates this documentary, directed by Mark Kitchell. “It arose at a time when our industrial civilization has grown so powerful it threatens the natural world on which we depend for survival. It has become the battle for a living planet.”

headline: India Election Digest: April 22
text: What you need to know on Tuesday about India’s elections: The Election Commission takes action against alleged hate speech in Gujarat, the next Parliament is likely to be richer but less educated, and IT stocks are falling on investor anticipation of a Bharatiya Janata Party-led government.

headline: Students Are Graded as They Give a Voice to the South Bronx
text: Eight reporters for The Hunts Point Express went to work on Rafael Salamanca Jr., the district manager of Community Board 2 in the South Bronx.

headline: Bragging of Safety While Many Live in Fear
text: The twin holes resemble diamond studs, and a crack in the glass curls, as graceful as an eyelash along the lobby window.

headline: U Win Tin, Writer Jailed and Tortured in Myanmar for 19 Years, Dies
text: U Win Tin, a journalist, author and poet who became a leading opponent of the military rulers of Myanmar, where he was imprisoned and tortured for 19 years, died on Monday in Yangon, formerly Rangoon. Sources differ on whether he was 84 or 85.

headline: Increased Activity at North Korean Nuclear Site Raises Suspicions
text: JINDO, South Korea — Just days before President Obama is to arrive in South Korea, North Korea has increased activities at its main nuclear test site, raising suspicions in Seoul and Washington that the country may be preparing to conduct a new underground nuclear test, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Tuesday.

headline: Novartis and Glaxo Agree to Trade $20 Billion in Assets
text: Updated, 8:18 p.m. | The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis and its British rival GlaxoSmithKline announced on Tuesday that they would swap more than $20 billion in assets as they seek to sharpen the focus of their businesses.

headline: Nepal Mourns Everest Avalanche Victims
text: Three days after an avalanche killed 13 Sherpas on Mount Everest, a funeral procession was held for six of them in Kathmandu.

headline: For British Biographer, Modi Was Only a Phone Call Away
text: How does one get Narendra Modi, the front-runner in the race for India’s prime minister, to sit down for an interview? According to Andy Marino, the British author of a recent biography of Mr. Modi, the answer is simple: “Just call him,” he said by telephone from London.

headline: Manchester United Fires David Moyes as Manager
text: The very first sign that David Moyes was not going to continue Alex Ferguson’s standard at Manchester United may have come before Moyes ever coached a single meaningful game.

headline: From China, a Video Tribute to Its Aircraft Carrier
text: China’s sole aircraft carrier has seized the national spotlight again, with a stirring “Top Gun”-style music video by the state-owned arms manufacturer Aviation Industry Corporation of China.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Boston Runs Again
text: In “With Defiant Spirit, Boston Marathoners Run Again,” Katharine Q. Seelye writes about the running of the Boston Marathon on Monday.

headline: Free Education Comes at a Cost for Marginalized Students
text: SONBHADRA, India — On Sunday, Umesh, a soft-spoken second grader, and a dozen of his classmates clamored to tell a visitor why no children in the village of Raup had returned to their local government school in this remote southeast corner of Uttar Pradesh since March 26.

headline: Biden Offers Strong Support to Ukraine and Issues a Sharp Rebuke to Russia
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Vowing that the United States would never recognize Russia’s “illegal occupation” of Crimea, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday reiterated America’s support of Ukraine, declared that “no nation has the right to simply grab land from another” and called on Russia to stop supporting masked gunmen who have seized government buildings across the east of the country.

headline: If a Bubble Bursts in Palo Alto, Does It Make a Sound?
text: This year, Facebook purchased the mobile-messaging application WhatsApp for $19 billion, or about $350 million per employee and $40 per user, only some of whom even pay the $1 annual fee for the advertisement-free platform. But what was perhaps most remarkable about Facebook’s acquisition of WhatsApp was that the start-up was making any money in the first place. In recent years, Facebook has shelled out 10-figure sums for Instagram and the virtual-reality headset maker Oculus V.R., both of which had scant or no revenue. Ditto for the safe-sexting-enabler Snapchat, which reportedly turned down a $3 billion offer from Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: Winning With Compassion and Respect
text: Daniel Berehulak, a freelance photographer who often works for The New York Times, has won the 2014 Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award.  Preston Gannaway, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer based in Oakland, Calif., was selected as the award finalist.

headline: What Are Your Longtime Interests or Passions?
text: Do you root for a certain team? Is there a movie you constantly watch, a book you read over and over, a band you love more than all others?

headline: Search of Suspected Malaysian Jet Crash Site Is Nearly Done
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The unmanned submersible scouring the ocean floor for wreckage from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is nearing the end of its underwater search, having covered 80 percent of an area authorities believe to be the most likely resting place of the plane and its 239 passengers.

headline: Cinderella and Her Prince, With Palpable Longing
text: “La Cenerentola,” Rossini’s version of the Cinderella fairy tale, is Cinderella’s show. The Metropolitan Opera has a dazzling, plucky and endearingly poignant Cinderella in the superb American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, who triumphed Monday night when the company’s 1997 production, which gives this 1817 classic a 1930s look, returned to the repertory.

headline: Voters Disapprove of Cuomo’s Shutdown of Anticorruption Panel, Poll Shows
text: Voters across New York overwhelmingly disagree with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s decision to disband a commission that he had appointed to investigate corruption in state government, according to a poll released on Tuesday by Siena College.

text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: A Proud Tree’s Second Life
text: Good morning on this mild Tuesday.
