text: 1914: The Situation in Mexico

headline: So Tell Me a Story: How the Sports Narrative Works
text: Last year, John Branch won a Pulitzer Prize for his harrowing account of a deadly avalanche in the Pacific Northwest. John was the first New York Times sportswriter to win the prize for feature writing.

headline: No Matter What I Do, There Is Always a 27-Year-Old Doing It Better
text: When I hear stories of other people who are doing well, my first question is, “How old are they?”

headline: Americans Predict a Future Like Science Fiction
text: Given the fast-paced changes that happen in technology, predicting the future has become more fun than guessing who will win the Super Bowl or “Dancing With the Stars.”

headline: Economix Meets the Gales of Change
text: Creative destruction, an economic theory credited to Joseph Schumpeter, posits that institutions are destroyed so that new institutions can grow and flourish.

headline: Daily Report: Companies Built on Sharing Balk at Regulators
text: In the newfangled sharing economy, questions about safety, taxes and regulation have tended to be an afterthought. That has helped propel companies like Uber, Airbnb and Lyft into the stratosphere, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Intersection: Oakland’s Style
text: “People are antinormal,” Sarah Barnekow said of the style in Oakland, Calif.

headline: Bain Goes Off Script for Its Latest Deal
text: Bain Capital recently raised a fresh $7.3 billion fund for buyouts, but the second deal in that fund departs from the buyout playbook.

headline: Top Italian Banks Tap Private Equity for Help With Troubled Loans
text: American investment firms have found numerous opportunities to capitalize on the turmoil in Europe’s banking sector by buying distressed assets. But one major private equity firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is taking a novel approach.

headline: Navigate News With The Upshot
text: You have no shortage of excellent news sources — sources that expertly report and analyze news as it happens. Like you, those of us at The Upshot rely on those sources every day. So why are we starting a new site to help people understand the news?

headline: What Good Marathons and Bad Investments Have in Common
text: My sister-in-law, Jane Richards, ran last year’s Berlin Marathon. Throughout the course, she retched repeatedly. She collapsed only a few steps after finishing. Her body was a wreck, and she said the race was more painful than childbirth. Yet she scores it as one of the best experiences of her life.

headline: The Myth of Swing Voters in Midterm Elections
text: If you want to understand the 2014 midterm elections, remember this simple fact about American politics: There just aren’t that many swing voters.

headline: Incumbent Southern Democrats Are Less Vulnerable Than You Might Think
text: Democrats’ hopes of keeping their Senate majority this November may well hinge on the ability of three of their incumbents to hold onto their seats deep in enemy territory: the South. To take the Senate and consolidate their control of Congress, Republicans need only extend their stranglehold on Dixie to Arkansas, Louisiana and North Carolina, all of which voted for Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential election.

headline: Meet Leo, Our Senate Model.
text: LEO was the first computer for ordinary businesses. We’ve named our Senate forecasting model after it. Our model combines polls with other information to predict how many Senate races Democrats and Republicans will win this year. To read about the machinery behind our model — how it combines polls, analyzes other information and deals with uncertainty — we have put together an FAQ.

headline: Who Likes Web Censorship? (Ask Putin.)
text: If you want to explore how Russians’ attitudes toward an authoritarian government may be different from attitudes elsewhere, one place to look is how they think about censorship and freedom on the web.

headline: How Underpaid German Workers Helped Cause Europe’s Debt Crisis
text: To understand a crucial reason for the European financial crisis that nearly caused a global financial collapse and threatened to undo a six-decade push toward a united Europe, you could look at a bunch of charts of bond markets and current account deficits and fiscal imbalances.

headline: The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest
text: The American middle class, long the most affluent in the world, has lost that distinction.

headline: Back Story: How We Found the Income Data
text: Late last year, while reading a new book by the economist Angus Deaton, I came across a sentence that hinted at a solution to one of my biggest frustrations as an economics journalist.

headline: Charles Rangel, the veteran New York Democrat, wants you to know that he’s the tops.
text: His official site, using the less-than-subtle URL of rangel.house.gov/NumberOne, proclaims that Mr. Rangel ranks first in productivity among members of Congress, according to a list generated by TrackBill, a legislative research service. But there’s a significant catch: The rankings are based on a single metric — the percentage of bills sponsored that have passed. So the list is dominated by lawmakers holding committee and subcommittee chairs, which are the gatekeepers for most bills. Of Mr. Rangel’s 41 pieces of legislation that have passed since 2003, when TrackBill started counting, only one was passed in the past three years. Most occurred while he was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which has jurisdiction over tax issues.

headline: Ways to Think About the Model
text: We realize that many people will interpret our Senate model as predicting that the Democrats will retain control of the Senate this year, because the model shows their odds of doing so to be 51 percent. We think the better way to describe the race is as a toss-up, and we suggest keeping two things in mind:

headline: Seeking the Right Chemistry, Drug Makers Hunt for Mergers
text: Updated, 9:12 p.m. | The pharmaceutical industry is regaining its swagger, as companies turn to big and sometimes daring deals to expand and reshape their operations.

headline: Inequality 1992
text: I happened to notice Greg Mankiw citing some bogus claims that the one percent is an ever-changing group, not a persistent elite, and I thought “Wait — didn’t we deal with that one long ago?” And that brought to mind the piece I wrote for the American Prospect 22 years ago, “The rich, the right, and the facts.” (It doesn’t say this on the Prospect site, but it was indeed published in 1992). See the section on income mobility.

headline: In Performance: Julia Bullock
text: Julia Bullock, a rising soprano from Juilliard, sings Xavier Montsalvatge’s “Canción de Cuna Para Dormir a un Negrito.” She is accompanied by the pianist Renate Rohlfing.

headline: Close but Not Quite
text: [Please note: After Deadline will not appear on Tuesday, April 29, and will return on May 6.]

headline: Class-Ridden America
text: Via Mark Thoma, Larry Bartels produces the ultimate anti-Santorum argument. Santorum, you may recall, declared that we have no classes in America — even the term middle class, he says, is “Marxism talk“. The usual response is to point to the data and say that objectively we are indeed a class society.

headline: Ackman’s Botox Ambitions
text: William A. Ackman, one of the brashest men on Wall Street, has come up with perhaps the boldest move yet for an activist: He has teamed up with the health care company Valeant to bid roughly $50 billion for Allergan, the maker of Botox, David Gelles, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The offer by Valeant is expected to be announced Tuesday morning.

headline: This simple table summarizes our story on American living standards.
text: In 1980, the American rich and middle class and most of the poor had higher incomes than their counterparts almost anywhere in the world. But incomes for the middle class and poor in the United States have since been growing more slowly than elsewhere. Why? Among the reasons: This country has lost its once-wide lead in educational attainment. Other countries have increased their workers’ skill levels more quickly, helping create well-paying jobs. The United States also tolerates more inequality: The minimum wage is lower here. Executives make more money. The government redistributes less of it. By 2010, the poor in several other countries had pulled ahead. And Canada’s median income had reached a virtual tie with that of the United States. Since 2010, other data suggest Canada has moved ahead.

headline: About the Data
text: The data in today’s article on income comes from LIS, a group that maintains the Luxembourg Income Study Database. Staff members at LIS — based in Luxembourg and at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York — gather data on household income from around the world and harmonize the statistics, so that numbers from different countries can be compared. Government agencies typically conduct the underlying income surveys.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Drum Up Stealth Activism
text: Remember the dawn raid, when a would-be acquirer built up a stake before the target realized it was under attack? The activist investor William A. Ackman has come up with a kind of drone strike version. His Pershing Square Capital Management hedge fund and Valeant Pharmaceuticals have teamed up to grab a potential 9.7 percent stake in Allergan, with a hostile takeover by Valeant ready for deployment.

headline: Permira to Acquire German Chemical Maker CABB International
text: LONDON – The European private equity firm Permira said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the specialty chemical company CABB International of Germany.

headline: Comcast Reports Strong Earnings as Cable TV Subscribers Hold Steady
text: Comcast, already the largest cable operator in the country, is trying to become even larger with a proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable. But even without that enormous planned acquisition, Comcast is growing.

headline: An Online Meeting Place for Creative Types
text: After graduating from New York University in 2013 with a degree in film and television, Dan Kim found himself in an entirely unexpected situation: a friend asked him to help shoot a music video, an incredible opportunity at the time, and Kim had to turn him down. “I was in film school, but I didn’t know anybody who could help,” he explains, referencing his then-nonexistent set of industry contacts. “I thought it was insane that there was no space for people like me to share their ideas. People still use Craigslist!” The realization drove Kim to create Unique Board, a website where artists working in seven different categories – cinematography, fashion, design, music, art, dance/performance and technology/programming – can find each other for different projects. “We’re digitizing the collaboration process, making it simple but effective by cutting off all the extra steps of networking,” Kim explains about the site, which has amassed over 200 members — many based in New York, many others international — since going live in February.

headline: I Am Not a Thief
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Court Backs Michigan on Affirmative Action
text: WASHINGTON — In a fractured decision that revealed deep divisions over what role the judiciary should play in protecting racial and ethnic minorities, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a Michigan constitutional amendment that bans affirmative action in admissions to the state’s public universities.

headline: At Funeral, Expressions of Grief and Anger Toward Kiev Officials
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Hundreds of residents of this eastern Ukrainian city under the control of pro-Russian militants came to the Orthodox Church of the Holy Spirit on Tuesday for the funerals of three men killed in a shootout at a roadblock on Sunday.

headline: World’s Fair Relic Deemed a ‘Treasure’
text: Fifty years after the 1964 World’s Fair opened, the New York State Pavilion, one of the last architectural vestiges of the fair, was named a “National Treasure” on Tuesday by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

headline: Introducing the Reader Spotlight: A Teacher’s View of Common Core
text: As I’ve noted, I get mail. Fairly often, a reader’s view, sent to me, stands quite well on its own and deserves a wider audience. Toward that end, I’ll occasionally feature here a letter – possibly lightly trimmed or edited for style – that fits that description.

headline: Scuba Diving in Brooklyn
text: As part of an unusual internship, nine high school students work in a tropical reef, located at the end of the F subway line in Coney Island.

headline: Mariss Jansons to Resign From Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra
text: Mariss Jansons, who has been the chief conductor of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra for nearly a decade, plans to resign his post there after the 2014-15 season, the orchestra announced on Tuesday.

headline: Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom
text: Andrew Sutchen, 18, was keeping his head down, trying to ignore the fish. It was hard to concentrate on the task at hand: underwater housekeeping for the New York Aquarium in Coney Island. “They kept biting my hair,” he said. “I felt a tug and saw that one had pulled some out.”

headline: Marine Vacth, the Frequently Unclothed Star of François Ozon’s ‘Young and Beautiful’
text: In his new film, “Young and Beautiful” (opening April 25 in New York), François Ozon introduces his star, the newcomer Marine Vacth, with a tableau that’s typical of the French auteur: she appears lying naked on a beach in the South of France, seen through the lenses of a pair of binoculars. The voyeuristic shot establishes her character, the affluent high school student Isabelle, as an unknowable object of desire whose motives remain inscrutable even when she starts working nights as a high-class prostitute in Paris hotels (a plot device reminiscent of “Belle de Jour”). The role’s abundant nudity and questionable morality is certain to rocket Vacth into the consciousness of American art-house audiences.

headline: Allergan Bid Adds to Spate of Pharmaceutical Deals
text: The early pairing of the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to bid for the Botox maker Allergan allows Mr. Ackman to leapfrog over a traditional step for activist investors.

headline: Reports of Fraud and Violence Temper Joy Over Election in Chaotic Afghan District
text: ANDAR, Afghanistan — The turbulent district of Andar has been caught in one kind of crossfire or another for years: between American forces and insurgent leaders, between warring militant factions, between those hostile to the national government and those courting it.

headline: Lorde Postpones Australian Tour
text: Lorde, the teenage pop star, has had to postpone her scheduled concert tour of Australia because of a chest infection, Billboard magazine reported.

headline: Oscar Producers Will Be Back in 2015
text: Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, whose production of this year’s largely successful Academy Awards eclipsed their Seth MacFarlane-led show of 2013, will return to produce the Oscar show for the third consecutive year. Where the 2013 show might be best remembered for Mr. MacFarlane’s flat-footed musical ode to actresses’ bare breasts, the 2014 show’s most-enduring image was of the star-filled selfie, above, snapped by a sunny Ellen DeGeneres. This year’s show also drew 45.4 million viewers, according to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the most in 10 years. Dawn Hudson, the Academy’s chief executive, said in a statement that Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron were “masters at tapping into the zeitgeist and capturing the hearts of movie fans around the world.” Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron have a long history of bringing Broadway musicals to the big and little screens: They produced the film versions of “Chicago” and “Hairspray,” are in the process of producing “Pippin,” and for television have made “Annie,” “Rogers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” and “Gypsy.” The 87th Academy Awards will be next Feb. 22, at the Dolby Theater in Hollywood. No host has been named.

headline: Is It O.K. to Mine Real Relationships for Literary Material?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. When Robert Lowell used his ex-wife’s letters for his poetry, Elizabeth Bishop told him, “Art just isn’t worth that much.” This week, Francine Prose and Leslie Jamison discuss what they make of mining actual relationships for literary material.

headline: The Diminishing American Edge
text: Last week, in a tax day post defending the virtues of light taxation, I discussed the various economic advantages that the United States of America has reaped from its lower-than-average tax burden, and the evidence that not only the U.S. but also our developed-world peers have benefited from the American style of free market capitalism. But I concluded by allowing that this argument would look that much weaker the longer the U.S. economy goes without delivering on the second half of the basic American “more risk and more inequality for more growth and jobs and self-sufficiency” bargain — a combination which has held historically, but not so much of late.

headline: No Time to Waste: Students Pursue Environmental Progress Instead of Exam Grades
text: This is an Earth Day shout-out to the dozen undergraduate students in the inaugural semester of our new Pace University Environmental Policy Clinic, a year-round course in which student teams, instead of studying for tests, work with nonprofit groups, communities or other partners to pursue achievable environmental goals.

headline: With Eyes on a Possible Clinton Run, Debate on a 2-Woman Ticket
text: WASHINGTON — Few doubt that Hillary Rodham Clinton’s nomination for president would be good for women. But her candidacy would also probably block the paths for other women running for the White House, and, notably, for those who would like to be vice president.

headline: Chernin Teams With AT&T in Online Video Investment Venture
text: Peter Chernin was stymied in his effort last year to buy Hulu, the online video streaming service. But now, Mr. Chernin, the former News Corporation president, is teaming up with his partner in that bid to form a new investment venture.

headline: Image of the Day: April 22
text: Women cleaning the Dal Lake, in Jammu and Kashmir, on the occasion of Earth Day.

headline: Sherpa Guides Abandon Everest Climbing Season
text: Updated, 1:51 p.m. | Following an avalanche on Friday that produced the worst single-day death toll in the history of Mount Everest, a group of Sherpas announced on Tuesday that they decided to abandon this year’s climbing season, disrupting plans of hundreds of climbers, many of them waiting at the mountain’s base camp.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Gia Coppola Looks Back With Compassion
text: In “Palo Alto,” a feature based on James Franco short stories and  screening at the Tribeca Film Festival this week, first-time filmmaker Gia Coppola follows the lives of a group of cosseted, disaffected teens as they gambol from one soccer game, one hookup and one party to the next.

headline: Moscow Court Rules Navalny Libeled Politician
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow court ruled on Tuesday that Aleksei A. Navalny, the prominent Russian opposition figure, had libeled a governing-party politician, and it fined him about $8,400. The ruling may lead to the reinstatement of a suspended sentence from a previous conviction, landing Mr. Navalny in prison as he awaits trial in a third case.

headline: Obama Tours Site of Deadly Landslide
text: OSO, Wash. — One month after a landslide devastated this community, President Obama promised residents that the nation was still with them in grieving and rebuilding, and would be for the long haul.

headline: Fighting Words Are Rarer Among British Doctors
text: Is a journey better than a battle?

headline: Striving for School-Mom Perfection
text: My eyes nearly popped from my head as I walked into the brunch: of the 12 admitted preschool students’ parents, 3 of us had gone to the same high school, even pre-K—in Canada! I was delighted (this was home) and shocked (was this too “home”?). Mostly, though, I was thrown. At this inaugural parents’ reception I’d hoped to be “school mom extraordinaire.” But seeing myself through the eyes of people I’d known from my childhood, I questioned whether I could really ace parent involvement – something that didn’t come naturally.

headline: Biden Offers Strong Support to Ukraine
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told members of Ukraine’s parliament that the United States was ready to support them in securing a unified Ukraine but warned against the “cancer of corruption.”

headline: The Vice President Who Pulled a Gun on Truman
text: Whatever your views on gun rights and gun safety, this 1938 photograph of a joking vice president, John Nance Garner, thrusting two pistols into Missouri Senator Harry Truman’s chest probably has some element of shock.

headline: Why Economics Failed Us, in 297 Words
text: Thomas Sargent’s 2007 speech to Berkeley graduates is making the rounds on the Internet. Business Insider called it the “greatest graduation speech ever.” Ezra Klein over at Vox says it “teaches everything you need to know about economics in 297 words.”

headline: Forty-Four Years of Earth Day
text: When environmentalists proclaimed the first Earth Day, on this date in 1970, the air was filled with doomsday predictions. At the initial rallies to mark the day, people warned of overpopulation, a denuded planet, hundreds of millions of people starving to death, a new Ice Age or the greenhouse effect. Many — though not all, obviously — of those forecasts were off.

headline: April 22, 1970: The First Earth Day Draws Millions
text: On April 23, 1970, The Times published a front-page article, under a six-column headline, about the first Earth Day. The event drew millions of participants across the United States.

headline: Allergan Bid Charts New Territory in Takeovers
text: The $45.6 billion unsolicited offer for Allergan by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and William A. Ackman’s hedge fund is many things, including bold, novel and mega in all ways. It is a new twist in the struggle between companies and shareholder activists, and could ignite a furious battle not just for Allergan but over the laws governing takeovers and activism.

text: Who says bartenders aren’t looking out for our health? Lately, a fair number seem dead earnest in making sure that patrons get their daily allowance of calcium.

headline: Claims of Chlorine-Filled Bombs Overshadow Progress by Syria on Chemical Weapons
text: Nearly 90 percent of the chemicals in Syria’s arsenal have now been exported and only a few shipments remain, international monitors reported Tuesday, but the progress was overshadowed by growing concerns that the Syrian military may be dropping bombs filled with chlorine, a common industrial compound not on the list of prohibited poisons.

headline: Justices Skeptical of Aereo’s Business
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court signaled on Tuesday that it was struggling with two conflicting impulses in considering a request from television broadcasters to shut down Aereo, an Internet start-up they say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.

headline: MCC Season Will Feature LaBute World Premiere
text: World premieres of new hot-button comedies by Neil LaBute and Robert Askins will bracket MCC Theater’s 2014-15 season, the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: For start-ups looking to disrupt regulated industries, the new strategy is: Ask forgiveness, not permission.
text: Airbnb, the service to let people rent out their basement apartments and spare bedrooms to short-term visitors, is in court on Tuesday fighting an effort by New York State regulators to get a list of clients. The state thinks Airbnb may be violating New York City’s law on short-term rentals. It’s part of a bunch of tangles that digital companies like Uber and Lyft are having with various state and local authorities as they try to disrupt highly regulated industries.

headline: American Reporter Held by Ukraine Separatists
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 3:11 p.m. | Foreign correspondents in the eastern Ukrainian town of Slovyansk, including my colleague Andrew Roth and Roland Oliphant of The Telegraph, report that one of their number, the Vice News reporter Simon Ostrovsky has been detained by pro-Russia separatists who seized power in recent days.

headline: Delaware Is Building a Strategy to Lift Some Cities’ Economies
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — Hoping to generate interest in rejuvenating urban areas, Delaware’s governor wants to offer modest development grants for proposed projects in 15 districts around the state.

headline: Fried Chicken, in Butter Form
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Arkansas Senator Has Unplanned Heart Surgery
text: WASHINGTON — John Boozman, the junior senator from Arkansas, had unplanned heart surgery on Tuesday morning and was recovering in an Arkansas hospital, his spokeswoman said.

headline: Labor Case Filed by Injured Player in ’70s Has Echoes Today
text: BELLEVILLE, Ill. — In a drill at a college football practice, Fred W. Rensing charged downfield, lowered his white helmet and drilled the punt returner in the chest for a thunderous hit. Rensing did not get up, and he never walked again.

headline: The Pregnancy I Endured, and the One I Missed
text: It might have been the photo of the onesie with the due date circled. It might have been the confidential email I got. It might have been all the ultrasound photos, seemingly within days of one another, popping up on my Facebook feed. It might have been when one friend told me her obstetrician said she was a champ, or the day another friend talked about getting 78 pounds of maternity clothes from her best friend, some still unopened, or the latest email from the yoga place that I never go to anymore advertising the prenatal yoga class I never took. It might have been any of those things, or it might just have been the all-too-common effects of depression combined with sleep deprivation, but suddenly I broke down in tears.

headline: Digital Public Library of America Marks a Year of Rapid Growth
text: The Digital Public Library of America, a project aimed at providing free online access to the nation’s cultural repositories, has tripled in size to more than seven million items from more than 1,300 institutions since it opened a year ago, the group has announced.

headline: E.J. Burke
text: Mr. Burke, 58, is chairman of the Mortgage Bankers Association, a national organization based in Washington that represents the real estate finance industry. He is also a newly named co-president of KeyBank’s community bank, specializing in commercial and private banking. KeyBank is based in Cleveland.

headline: Senator Chuck Schumer leaped to the defense of Niagara Falls on Monday.
text: The possibility that some New York cities will get less federal dollars because of declining populations has prompted the New York senator to preserve a carve-out. Cities with at least 50,000 people are eligible for direct community development grants from the federal government, while smaller cities must rely on a pool of money administered by each state. That’s a big concern for Niagara Falls and Troy. (As well as Joplin, Mo.) Each city has slipped under the 50,000 mark, according to Census Bureau estimates, meaning greater competition for the money is likely.

headline: A Craft-Beer Pub Crawl in the ‘Kitchen of Japan’
text: For a long time, drinking beer in Japan meant implicitly supporting one of the country’s four major producers: Asahi, Kirin, Suntory and Sapporo. But in the mid-1990s, when a law prohibiting the operation of small-scale breweries was abandoned, the door was opened for Japanese craft beer, known as ji-biru. Even today, there are only about 200 craft breweries in Japan, so finding domestic microbrews takes some effort. (For comparison, the United States had nearly 2,500 craft breweries in operation as of June 2013, according to the Brewers Association.) But increasingly, the place to taste these relatively rare — but deliciously well-crafted — beers is Osaka, Japan’s third-largest city.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Directors’ Most Memorable New York Minutes
text: It is often said that being in New York City feels like starring in your own movie. Maybe it’s because the Big Apple has set the scene for so many unforgettable films that we can’t help but register its urban landscape as a backdrop for the story of our lives. Or maybe it’s that in this metropolis of eight million — with its screaming energy and melting pot of cultures — “only in the movies” events seem to happen on a daily basis. Here, 14 directors — each of whom is showing a film at the Tribeca Film Festival, which continues through Sunday — recall New York moments when life imitated (their) art.

headline: Monday’s Boston Marathon provides yet more data illustrating that arbitrary numbers can serve as motivating goals.
text: George Wu, who is not only a keen student of the sport, but also a professor of behavioral science at the University of Chicago, spent Monday night downloading the official times of all 31,805 finishers. The distribution of finishing times follows the same pattern I highlighted in this morning’s column, with a statistically improbable clumping of runners finishing just before their goals of 3, 3.5 or 4 hours, and an accompanying “gap” with far fewer runners finishing just minutes after their goals. Befitting Boston’s reputation as a race for truly competitive runners, there’s less evidence of such goals mattering for those aiming to beat 5 or 6 hours.

headline: Hotel Review: Vander Urbani Resort in Ljubljana, Slovenia
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: The Coalhouse in Gower, Wales
text: Let’s face it: Wales isn’t exactly known as a culinary destination. In fact, the country’s diet — high in starches and meats — gets its fair share of criticism. But the Coalhouse on Oxwich Beach, which opened last summer on the gorgeous, windswept Gower Peninsula in South Wales, defies that reputation in a stylish setting.

headline: One Plate, Two Plates, Small Plates All
text: Something happened to me recently at the Cleveland, a small restaurant downtown, that struck me as both unprecedented and inevitable. After a friend and I had finished a small opening snack, the server brought our appetizers and main courses.

headline: At the Auto Show, Vehicles With a New York Connection

Taken from the collection at the New York State Museum, which is in Albany, all four cars are associated with New York governors.

headline: Lytro Goes After Prosumer Photographers With New Camera
text: When the Lytro camera debuted in 2012, it was the talk of techies and photographers. What else would you expect from a camera that was developed in Silicon Valley and used both photography expertise and a lot of fancy programming code?

text: Residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk buried three men killed in a gunfight at a roadblock on Easter Sunday.

headline: Study Linking Illness and Salt Leaves Researchers Doubtful
text: The former commissioner of health for New York City, Dr. Thomas A. Farley, has raised anew questions about the health risks posed by salt in the American diet, citing a new  study from Britain showing significant declines in heart attack and stroke risk after health officials there limited the amount of salt in processed foods.

headline: The Gun Report: April 22, 2014
text: Seven people in Houston have been convicted of running guns into Mexico, where they were used to fuel that nation’s drug wars. State police discovered the pipeline last October, when a trooper in Kingsville stopped a car containing 35 military-style rifles stashed in a hidden compartment. Seven of them were missing serial numbers. Drivers confessed to making 100 trips across the border in six months.

headline: Accusations in Hollywood Sexual Abuse Case Broaden
text: LOS ANGELES — Michael Egan, who in a lawsuit last week accused the director Bryan Singer of drugging him and sexually abusing him, has filed separate suits making similar accusations of forced sex and drug use against three entertainment executives: Garth Ancier, Gary W. Goddard and David A. Neuman.

headline: Beneath the Surface of China’s Great Urban Rush
text: At The New York Times Cities for Tomorrow event today, I led a discussion of some big social and environmental issues that lie beneath the surface of China’s urban rush.

headline: Lax Oversight Cited as Factor in Deadly Blast at Texas Plant
text: DALLAS — Federal investigators have determined that a lack of oversight and regulations at the local, state and federal levels contributed to the deadly fertilizer plant explosion that devastated a rural Texas town last year.

headline: Testing the Limits of Inside Information Cases
text: Much like the game of telephone, the final recipient of inside information may know little about who started the process or how many steps it took before arriving. When prosecutors want to pursue charges against the recipients of confidential information — the “tippees” — the issue is often how far down the chain they can go before they can no longer prove a violation.

headline: Caesars Making Bid for Casino in Upstate New York
text: For more than two years, the major Las Vegas gambling companies have resisted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s call to consider building a casino resort in New York to help him revive an upstate economy wracked by unemployment and declining opportunities.

headline: Paul Takes His School-Choice Message to Chicago
text: CHICAGO — Senator Rand Paul on Tuesday brought his vision for education reform to Josephinum Academy, a small all-girls Catholic high school here. And true to form, he made no attempt to mask his libertarian brand of politics, even in President Obama’s adopted hometown.

headline: Clippers See Griffin’s Growth
text: LOS ANGELES — Before the you-gotta-see-this dunks, before the droll television commercials and before Blake Griffin realized what basketball might bring to a child from the Oklahoma City suburbs, he viewed the sport as an almost academic exercise.

headline: Piketty, Doom Loops and Haymarket
text: My Sunday column, on Thomas Piketty’s revival of the old argument that capitalism tends to enrich the capital-rich Few much, much faster than the laboring Many, didn’t take a position on the plausibility of the French economist’s basic forecast, which foresees upper-tail inequality rising forever absent a sustained political disruption. (For a more qualified observer’s critique of that forecast, Tyler Cowen’s review and follow-up are the place to turn.) Instead, I argued against the view that such a trend would necessarily lead to such political disruptions, or indeed be particularly destabilizing to the developed world’s societies. So long as a rich country’s Many see some real gains, I suggested, whether through modest growth and/or modestly-increasing redistribution, we aren’t likely to see anything remotely like the kind of literal class warfare that the last gilded age produced.

headline: The Broadband Revolution Is Not Nigh
text: Is America on the cusp of a broadband revolution? You might get that impression from AT&T’s announcement on Monday that it is considering providing Internet service of up to 1 gigabit, or 1 billion bits, a second to 21 metropolitan areas including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

headline: Five Great New York Breads
text: The Dining section tasted 20 assorted loaves from recently opened bakeries to find five you should put on your table.

headline: How An Exuberant ’80s Designer Shaped Fashion Today
text: The life and career of the designer Patrick Kelly were as brief as they were brilliant. A singular force in the 1980s fashion scene known for his jarringly bright and playful clothes, Kelly passed away on the first day of 1990 at 35 due to complications from AIDS. This weekend, the Philadelphia Museum of Art opens “Patrick Kelly: Runway of Love” (on view through November 30), the first retrospective of the designer’s prolific output since the Brooklyn Museum’s 2004 exhibition of his works. The show brings together eighty complete looks from his ten collections produced between 1985 and 1990, gifted to the museum by the late designer’s partner in business and life, Bjorn Guil Amelan, and Amelan’s current partner, the choreographer Bill T. Jones.

headline: Abbas Renews Threat to Dissolve Palestinian Authority if Peace Talks Fail
text: JERUSALEM — Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, issued a renewed warning on Tuesday that if the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks fail, he may dissolve the authority and hand sole responsibility for the West Bank back to Israel.

headline: Abbas Renews Warning to Israel on Talks
text: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, renewed warnings that Israel would have to take on the responsibility of governing Palestinian lands if peace talks did not continue.

headline: Everybody Is Playing Somebody Else Here
text: Perhaps James Franco should just stick to acting. He remains embarrassingly clueless when it comes to art.

headline: What Business Spends to Open Washington’s Doors
text: The next time a lawmaker or a corporate executive tries to persuade you that Washington is an even playing field, responsive to the concerns of all constituents, feel free to point them to the quarterly lobbying report of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Its most recent report, filed on Monday, shows the staggering amount of money that the business sector spends to influence legislation and regulation in Washington. No other competing interest group comes remotely close.

headline: Tartine’s Country Bread: Be Patient, Perfection Is Near
text: Chad Robertson’s recipe for country bread, from Tartine, his bakery in San Francisco, has reached cult status among passionate bakers for good reason: As bread recipes go, it’s nearly perfect.

headline: Racial Equality Loses at the Court
text: A blinkered view of race in America won out in the Supreme Court on Tuesday when six justices agreed, for various reasons, to allow Michigan voters to ban race-conscious admissions policies in higher education.

headline: Mixing It Up, Where the Bloody Mary Is Concerned
text: I think I make it pretty clear in my latest Drink column that where the bloody mary is concerned, I like to keep things simple (a poached-shrimp garnish notwithstanding). The drink itself is a study in balance: When you break it down, there’s a lot going on in a good bloody, and the idea is to bring all those components together into one bracing — some would say restorative — cocktail. Then do it up with those garnishes.

headline: Let’s Start With Bread and Water
text: Some people are nostalgic for foam-topped egg creams or Grandma’s buttermilk biscuits or defunct brands of children’s cereal. I miss bread and water.

Consider it when worn unzipped over a sporty layer, though, and it takes on a thoroughly urban, street-ready appeal — like the tracksuits you see on kids in the London neighborhood of Brixton.

text: Auto China 2014 officially opened to the public on Monday at the China International Exhibition Center, Beijing’s convention center, with a glittering, seemingly endless array of new transportation offerings that underscored the growing importance of the Chinese market in the automotive industry.

headline: Upsetting the Gentility That the South Lays Claim To
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In keeping with this city’s veneration of things old, stately and Southern, the College of Charleston remains a genteel enough place that for spring commencement exercises, male students don white dinner jackets while women slip into white dresses.

text: WASHINGTON — Standing before a roomful of economists, policy makers and health care experts earlier this month, Amitabh Chandra, director of Health Policy Research at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, closed a presentation about the slowdown in health care spending over the last decade by citing an article in The New York Times.

headline: 30,000 Golf Carts and 4,000 Heavy Duty Ford Trucks Recalled
text: About 30,000 golf carts and buggies are being recalled because the steering wheel may be loose, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Ford is recalling almost 4,000 of its heavy-duty pickup trucks because they might go into reverse when the driver wants to move forward.

text: The long run of dominance for NBC’s “Nightly News” is showing some cracks, as ABC’s “World News” last week again climbed to the top in the crucial audience category.

headline: Reviving the House Coltrane Built
text: Henry Butler, the New Orleans jazz pianist, released his debut album, “Fivin’ Around,” in 1986. And along with ratifying a major talent — a smartly rampaging virtuoso whose engagement in New York soon afterward drew a smattering of notable pianists — it signaled the reactivation of Impulse Records, the storied former home of the saxophonist John Coltrane, which had then been dormant for nearly a decade. “We had a nice little hand in reviving the label at that time,” Mr. Butler recalled this week.

text: Anyone seeking a large body of water in Pelham Bay would be quickly frustrated: The neighborhood’s namesake no longer exists. Instead, you would find a tidy community with rows of two-story brick homes bearing awnings and grillwork fences immediately adjacent to the city’s largest park.

headline: Pakistan Is Asked to Shut Down News Channel
text: LONDON — The attempted killing of a prominent Pakistani journalist has prompted a bruising public dispute between Pakistan’s powerful army spy agency and the largest media group that has exacerbated tense relations between the country’s civilian and military leaders.

headline: Why Care About McCutcheon?
text: In the food world, change from the ground up is all well and good. We desperately need cooks, gardeners, farmers and teachers. But we also need legislation. The recently passed and almost uniformly abysmal Farm Bill is a lesson in how legislation affects those of us working to change the chaotic so-called food “system.” Pittances were tossed at supporters of local and organic food, fortunes’ worth of agribusiness subsidies were maintained, and much-needed support for the country’s least well-off was slashed.

headline: It’s All About May 25
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The word “maidan” means “square” in Ukrainian and in Arabic. And the “Independence Maidan” of Kiev, like the “Tahrir Maidan” of Cairo, has been the scene of an awe-inspiring burst of democratic aspirations. The barricades of piled cobblestones, tires, wood beams and burned cars erected by Ukrainian revolutionaries are still there — indeed, it looks as if it could be the set of “Les Misérables” — and people still lay fresh flowers at the makeshift shrines for the more than 100 people killed in the Maidan by the old and now deposed regime here. Walking through it, though, I tried to explain to my host that, while I was incredibly impressed, a lot of Americans today have “Maidan fatigue” — too many dashed hopes for democracy in too many squares — from Afghanistan to Iran, Iraq to Egypt, Syria to Libya.

headline: In a Tie, Atlético Madrid Can Still Declare Victory
text: MADRID — There are, technically, hundreds of professional soccer clubs in Spain. Yet for much of the rest of the world, there have really been only two. Barcelona and Real Madrid. Real Madrid and Barcelona. Los Blancos. La Blaugrana. For years, they have felt like monoliths passing trophies back and forth while everyone else jockeyed for a sniff.

headline: Rise of the Milkbots
text: At a farm near Albany, N.Y., robots milk the cows. Dairy operations across New York have been leading the country’s charge into a brave new world of automated milking systems.

headline: Making Airfares Less Transparent
text: A bipartisan group of lawmakers in the House is pushing legislation that would make it easier for airlines to deceive travelers about the true cost of flying.

headline: Abu Ghraib, 10 Years Later
text: Baghdad’s infamous Abu Ghraib prison now stands empty. Its closure, prompted by fears that it could be overrun by Sunni insurgents, along with the transfer of its 2,400 prisoners, was announced last week by the Iraqi government, which resumed control of the facility in 2006.

headline: A.N.C.’s Stature Wanes as Disenchantment Grows in South Africa
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Isaac Ramaifo works as a functionary in the Union Buildings, the seat of state power here, and is a member of the governing African National Congress. But as South Africa approaches watershed elections next month, he, like many, is torn between an instinctive loyalty to the party that has ruled for the 20 years since the end of apartheid and worries about its ability to deliver prosperity.

headline: Rookies in Their First Playoffs Are Already Looking Seasoned
text: ST. PAUL — The most dominant forward in the early stages of the N.H.L. playoffs is an 18-year-old from Nova Scotia who lives in a teammate’s basement.

headline: Lesson for the Police: Be Careful What You Tweet For
text: When the New York Police Department asked Twitter users on Tuesday to share their photographs with police officers, they were perhaps expecting a few feel-good neighborhood scenes or tourists with police horses in Times Square.

headline: At Stake in the Aereo Case Is How We Watch TV
text: WASHINGTON — For most of its two years, Aereo has been an obscure start-up that gained little traction with consumers, partly because it took something that was traditionally easy — watching the broadcast networks — and made it sound complicated. It grabs local over-the-air signals on an array of tiny antennas that users can stream through the Internet to watch and record programming for $8 to $12 a month. Got that?

headline: Passport Diplomacy
text: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a case that touches on Congress’s authority over foreign policy. When is Congress justified in overriding the president’s policy?

headline: G.M. Seeks to Fend Off Lawsuits Over Switch
text: General Motors moved on Tuesday to prevent future safety lapses by expanding its oversight of problematic vehicles even as the automaker continued to take an aggressive legal posture in dealing with its past missteps.

headline: Homs Emerges as Turning Point in Shaping Syria’s Future
text: HOMS, Syria — On the edge of the Old City here, children play beside a house blown open by shelling. An antique wood-framed mirror leans against the wall, so that soldiers can watch for threats from around the corner. A block closer to one of the city’s last front lines, trash, rubble and rusted cars litter streets of charred and sagging buildings.

headline: Manning Says Ankle Will Heal for Camp
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The dreadful 2013 Giants season ended with the left ankle of Eli Manning in a hard boot, protection against the serious sprain that the franchise quarterback sustained in the final game.

headline: With a Mouthful, A&W Hopes to Draw Baby Boomers’ Offspring
text: THE popularity of the A&W Restaurants chain in the United States peaked in the 1960s and 1970s, when the number of locations — many with carhop service — swelled to 2,400, so it is no wonder that the brand stirs nostalgia in the baby boomer generation. But now A&W, which has about 700 restaurants, wants to make an impression on those boomers’ children, and the brand is increasingly turning to social media to do so.

headline: Colleges Seek New Paths to Diversity After Court Ruling
text: Leaders in higher education, upset by Tuesday’s Supreme Court decision upholding Michigan’s ban on race-based preferences in college admissions, said the ruling would nudge them further along the path of finding alternative means to promote diversity in their student bodies.

headline: New York’s Case Against Airbnb Is Argued in Albany
text: There was no room for agreement, and no agreement about rooms, in court on Tuesday in Albany.

headline: Who Will Win the Senate?
text: When Americans go to bed on election night this year, there is a real chance that they won’t know which party has won control of the Senate. For that matter, the country may not know who has won a Senate majority at any time in November.

headline: A Double Standard in Doping Punishments
text: What does it take to receive a lifetime ban from cycling for breaking antidoping rules?

headline: Sherpas Move to Shut Everest in Labor Fight
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Over the years, as Mount Everest attracted larger crowds of amateur climbers from the West, the Sherpas adjusted: to a slower ascent, to traffic jams, to bulging loads of gear. Every spring some new frustration would get them talking, then recede with the end of the season.

headline: D’Souza Case Is Political, Lawyer Says
text: When the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza was charged in January with illegally using straw donors to contribute to a 2012 New York Republican Senate campaign, his lawyer denied that he had acted with any corrupt or criminal intent.

headline: Korea Confronts Tendency to Overlook Safety as Toll in Ferry Sinking Grows
text: JINDO, South Korea — As Navy divers recovered the bodies of dozens of teenagers drowned waiting for a rescue of their doomed ferry, South Korea has begun a national bout of hand-wringing over the country’s tendency to overlook safety precautions in its quest for economic success.

headline: With Farm Robotics, the Cows Decide When It’s Milking Time
text: EASTON, N.Y. — Something strange is happening at farms in upstate New York. The cows are milking themselves.

headline: Prosecutors Describe an Extensive Drug Ring in Affluent Pennsylvania Schools
text: HAVERFORD, Pa. — Boldly describing their enterprise as the “Main Line Take Over Project,” two former students of a private school in this affluent suburb of Philadelphia took on an ambitious business venture, prosecutors said.

headline: Qatar: Sentence of U.S. Couple Was Based on Lesser Charge
text: A panel of judges in Qatar who found an American couple guilty last month in the January 2013 death of their adopted daughter convicted them on the charge of jeopardizing the child, and not the more serious original charge of murder, according to a translation of the verdict provided Tuesday by the couple’s lawyers. The defendants, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, who have not been permitted to leave Qatar, are appealing their three-year sentence, which was announced on March 27. But until Tuesday, their lawyers were unsure how to proceed with the appeal because the judges had never explained the reduced charge. Prosecutors had accused the Huangs of starving their daughter, Gloria, 8, and originally suspected them of being child traffickers because the defendants are of Asian heritage and the child was African. The Huangs, who attributed the child’s death to an eating disorder, said the prosecution was based on flawed evidence, racial prejudices and misunderstandings about Western adoption.

headline: A Saint, He Ain’t
text: WASHINGTON — There were some disturbing elements to the Easter Mass I attended at Nativity, my childhood church.

headline: Red Sox Fans Greet Ellsbury With a Collective Shrug
text: BOSTON — Matt Williams, a graduate student from Cambridge, Mass., figured he would take plenty of abuse Tuesday night when he settled into his bleacher seat in Section 35 at Fenway Park, wearing a Jacoby Ellsbury Red Sox shirt.

headline: Consultant to Scrutinize Detroit Plan
text: By the time Detroit emerges from bankruptcy, it will have seen untold hours of combative negotiations, a thumbs-up or thumbs-down vote from 100,000 creditors and financial projections that one expert recently called little more than “pretty good guesses.”

headline: NASA Vehicle
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Crossword-puzzle constructing, in my opinion, is like a microcosm of the larger workforce. We all have jobs: Some of us are Monday constructors. Some of us go for the big real estate and build the large Sunday puzzles. Some of us hoist the triple stacks. I like to think of the Saturday constructors as the executioners.

headline: A Cold War Casualty, Hot for Freedom (and Heels)
text: Do not be alarmed by recent reports that Neil Patrick Harris, an irresistibly wholesome television presence, has fallen deeply and helplessly into the gap that separates men from women, East from West, and celebrity from notoriety. There’s no need to fear for his safety, much less his identity. Quite the contrary.

headline: India: Court to Hear Appeal Over Restoration of Ban on Gay Sex
text: India’s Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would hear an appeal of its decision in December that re-criminalized gay sex. The hearing is largely a formality and is unlikely to lead to a serious reconsideration of the decision. A lower court ruled in 2009 that an 1861 law mandating a 10-year sentence for “carnal intercourse against the order of nature with man, woman or animal” was unconstitutional. But the Supreme Court overturned the lower court’s decision, holding that only Parliament had the power to change that law.

headline: New York City Gets Selective About Shell Casings Buyer
text: If this were a melodrama called “Bullets Over the Bronx,” the second act of the production would remain in the genre of mystery. But, spoiler alert: The story probably will not end with a shootout.

headline: Amid Politics, Obama Drifted Away From Kin
text: BOSTON — After Zeituni Onyango, the woman President Obama once called Auntie, died in a South Boston nursing home this month, her closest relatives gathered her belongings at her nearby apartment. There, framed photographs of her with the president covered the wall.

headline: A Community Tug of War in Brooklyn
text: If a building complex straddles the intersection of three community districts in New York, which community board should claim jurisdiction over the buildings’ garbage collection, sidewalk modifications and other assorted concerns?

headline: Scandals Republicans Like
text: The decision by the I.R.S. to flag for special review applications for tax-exempt status from organizations with “Tea Party” or “patriot” in their names has provoked sustained outrage on the right for nearly a year.

headline: Scrutiny Over Photos Said to Tie Russia Units to Ukraine
