headline: Phillip Hayes Dean, the Playwright of Divisive ‘Paul Robeson,’ Dies at 83
text: Phillip Hayes Dean, a playwright whose stage portrait of the actor and social crusader Paul Robeson aroused one of the theater’s more unusual controversies and derailed his own promising career, died on April 14 in Los Angeles, shortly after a revival of the play opened at the Ebony Repertory Theater there. He was 83.

headline: Yanks’ New Additions Torment the Red Sox
text: BOSTON — After an October of misery watching their oldest rivals win the World Series while they failed to make the playoffs, the Yankees responded with conviction in the off-season, signing four players they hope will tip the scales back in their favor.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 22, 2014
text: April 22, 2014

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Boots on the Ground
text: In “Fargo,” the characters are defined by their boots.

headline: Rapfogel to Plead Guilty in Scheme to Steal Millions From Charity
text: A community leader with longtime ties to Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, is expected to plead guilty on Wednesday in connection with a scheme to loot more than $7 million from one of New York City’s most influential social service organizations, people familiar with the case said Tuesday night.

headline: Steady Rangers Capitalize on Shaky Game by Flyers’ Goalie
text: PHILADELPHIA — Several Rangers stood out in their 4-1 victory over the Flyers on Tuesday night that gave them a 2-1 series lead. None more, however, than Daniel Carcillo.

headline: L. Jay Oliva, Who Led the Rise of N.Y.U. in the ’90s, Dies at 80
text: L. Jay Oliva, who began his career at New York University as a night school history instructor in 1960 and rose to become its president in the 1990s, helping to transform it from a commuter school into a major university, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Raptors Outlast Nets to Even Up the Series
text: TORONTO — The Nets may seethe for some time about wasted chances and sloppy play, about a missed opportunity to grab a stranglehold on their first-round playoff series with the Toronto Raptors.

headline: Holliday’s Leaping Grab Protects Shutout of Mets
text: Matt Holliday timed his leap perfectly, yanking Chris Young’s home run effort back from over the left-field wall and, in one fell swoop, erasing the Mets’ best offensive effort Tuesday night.

headline: Obama Addresses Oso, Wash.
text: President Obama spoke to first responders in Oso, Wash. on Tuesday.

headline: Flyers’ Mason Back on Ice, if Only to Gauge Readiness
text: PHILADELPHIA — Steve Mason, the Flyers’ No. 1 goalie, spent the first 52 minutes Tuesday night on a stool at the end of the bench, in front of the door that leads onto the ice, before being summoned to play the rest of Philadelphia’s 4-1 Game 3 loss to the Rangers.

headline: Brazil: Deadly Violence Erupts in Rio
text: At least two people died Tuesday after a day of violence in a slum that abuts the Copacabana tourist district of Rio de Janeiro. Local news media reported that the deaths occurred in the slum, or favela, called Pavão-Pavãozinho. The disturbances began after a young man who was a dancer on a television variety show was found dead and residents charged that he had been killed by a police officer, according to the reports. The police said that they were investigating, but that marks on the man’s body indicated that he could have fallen to his death. A protest turned violent, and several officers became trapped in the favela. An elite squad then arrived. Copacabana residents reported hearing gunshots and what sounded like small explosions. A second man was later found fatally shot. Separately, a police officer was shot in another favela in the north of the city. The violence comes less than two months before Rio and other cities in Brazil are to host the World Cup.

headline: Inside a Remote Island Made of Marble, an Artist’s New Abode
text: In the middle of the Lago General Carrera, a lake that stretches from Chile to Argentina, the Swiss artist Not Vital has crafted another minimalist yet innovative home for himself. He bought one of the 13 islands there in 2008 — “It is not big, and it is not small,” he says — and has been working on it since 2009. This month, he finally finished the quiet little island, which he has named NotOna, the first photos of which are featured here.

headline: Times Minute | Modern-Day ‘Rabbit Ears’
text: The Supreme Court considers whether Aereo is committing copyright infringement. Also on the Minute, labor troubles on Mount Everest and the rise of the milkbots at dairy farms.

headline: The Limits of ‘No Pain, No Gain’
text: Exercise makes us tired. A new study helps to elucidate why and also suggests that while it is possible to push through fatigue to reach new levels of physical performance, it is not necessarily wise.

headline: Misfortune Leaves Student Loan Borrowers on the Hook
text: You have been faithfully making your student loan payment each month, and are making steady progress paying down the balance. But then your parent — who co-signed your loan — dies, or files for bankruptcy protection. All of a sudden, your lender is demanding that you repay the loan in full, even though you have never been late with a payment.

headline: Times Minute | Modern-Day ‘Rabbit Ears’
text: In the Video

headline: Word of the Day | quack
text: quack•\ˈkwak\• noun and verb

headline: New York City Housing Push Should Aim at Poorest, Report Says
text: The New York City comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, is recommending that the city focus its affordable housing efforts on the most burdened residents — those in households making $40,000 or less a year — and also invest in “stabilizing” a crumbling public housing system that has risen in importance as fewer low-income New Yorkers can afford to live in private apartments.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 5:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) CHICKEN WITH PLUMS (2012) A celebrated but tormented violinist, Nasser-Ali (Mathieu Amalric, above), in 1958 Tehran retreats to his bed to end his life after his prized instrument is broken, in this drama from Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, based on Ms. Satrapi’s graphic novel of the same title. But in flashbacks — and flash-forwards — starring Nasser-Ali’s wife (Maria de Medeiros) and children (Mathis Bour and Enna Balland; Chiara Mastroianni and Christian Friedel portray them as adults), it soon becomes clear that his melancholy is rooted in a deeper heartache: his long-ago love, Irane (Golshifteh Farahani). “Not that ‘Chicken With Plums’ is gloomy,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Like its swooning, madly melodramatic musical score (by Olivier Bernet), the film takes an almost giddy pleasure in unhappiness, turning even pedestrian moments of boredom or discomfort into occasions for wild invention.” The result, which features a naked Sophia Loren and Edouard Baer as the Angel of Death, “is captivating, but not exactly moving.”

headline: Egypt: U.S. to Deliver Helicopters
text: The United States will deliver to Egypt 10 Apache helicopters that were held up last year after President Mohamed Morsi was deposed, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told the Egyptian defense minister on Tuesday. Mr. Hagel said the helicopters would be used in Egypt’s efforts against terrorism in the Sinai, the Defense Department said in a statement. In a separate call, Secretary of State John Kerry told Egypt’s foreign minister, Nabil Fahmy, that he is certifying to Congress that Egypt is living up to the terms of the 1979 peace treaty with Israel, a move that allows the release of some aid to Cairo, a State Department spokeswoman said.

headline: India Election Digest: April 23
text: What you need to know on Wednesday about India’s elections: Priyanka Gandhi criticizes attempts to “humiliate” her family, India’s financial regulators brace for extreme market swings after the election results, and Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party takes to Twitter to admonish Hindu nationalist supporters for their inflammatory remarks.

headline: Slovyansk Mourns 3 Killed at Checkpoint
text: Anger and questions swirled as residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk buried three men killed in a gunfight at a roadblock on Sunday.

headline: 10,000 ‘Olympic Babies’ Strain the Beijing System
text: Updated, 11 p.m. ET| “Olympic Babies are Coming,” read a headline in Beijing News on Wednesday. With thousands more children than usual born in Beijing in 2008, a year considered by many to be lucky both for the number eight and for being the year that China hosted the Olympic Games, the state is scrambling to find enough school spaces for all the 6-year-olds heading to first grade this fall — about 10,000 more than last September.

headline: Colbert Visits Letterman on ‘Late Show’
text: Once upon a time, the transfer of power from one monarch to another would involve some pomp and ritual, maybe even a passing of a crown. But when Stephen Colbert visited David Letterman Tuesday night on “The Late Show,” the comedy franchise he will inherit next year, they commemorated the occasion in grand 2014 style: With the taking of a selfie. The comedy titans flashed broad smiles, with Mr. Colbert leaning forward.

headline: Women Go Topless for Equal Rights
text: Updated, 7:31 a.m. |

headline: Backlash Over Hong Kong’s Treatment of Mainland Visitors
text: The tensions between Hong Kong residents and mainland Chinese visitors are bubbling up yet again — with a video showing a confrontation involving a mainland family whose child was videotaped urinating on a busy street.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 23, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips
text: In “For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips,” Grant Glickson writes about the subculture of teenage “sneakerheads.”

headline: Get Cracking
text: 12 recipes that take the hard-boiled egg beyond Easter.

headline: Animals Are Persons Too
text: This short documentary follows the lawyer Steven Wise’s effort to break down the legal wall that separates animals from humans.

headline: A Quiet Moment Among Neighbors
text: Lauren Justice is a freelance photographer based in Lincoln, Neb., who also works part time for The Lincoln Journal Star. She has interned with The San Francisco Examiner, The Fayetteville Observer in North Carolina and The Flint Journal in Michigan. Ms. Justice, 26, studied photojournalism and sociology at the University of Cincinnati. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: Should a Chimp Be Able to Sue Its Owner?
text: Just before 4 p.m. on Oct. 10, Steven Wise pulled his rental car in front of a multiacre compound on State Highway 30 near the tiny Adirondack hamlet of Gloversville, N.Y., and considered his next move. For the past 15 minutes, Wise had been slowly driving the perimeter of the property, trying to get a better read on the place. An assortment of transport trailers — for horses and livestock, cars, boats and snowmobiles — cluttered a front lot beside a single-story business office with the sign “Circle L Trailer Sales” set above the door. At the rear of the grounds was a barn-size, aluminum-sided shed, all its doors closed, the few small windows covered in thick plastic.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll
text: In four southern states, Republicans are generally stronger among residents who say they will definitely vote.

headline: ‘Animals Are Persons Too’
text: How does a thing become a person? In December 2013, the lawyer Steven Wise showed the world how, with a little legal jujitsu, an animal can transition from a thing without rights to a person with legal protections. This Op-Doc video follows Mr. Wise on his path to filing the first-ever lawsuits in the United States demanding limited “personhood” rights for certain animals, on behalf of four captive chimpanzees in New York State.

headline: Koreans Bid Farewell to Victims of a Disaster, and Even the North Speaks Up
text: JINDO, South Korea — With hopes of finding more survivors of the South Korean ferry sinking all but gone, some families, as well as the nation, began bidding farewell on Wednesday to the students and other victims whose bodies have been recovered. And in an unusual gesture, North Korea sent its condolences.

headline: Recovery in Euro Zone Gathers Pace
text: PARIS — The economy of the euro zone expanded this month at its fastest rate in nearly three years, according to a private sector survey released on Wednesday, with accelerated output from Germany leading the bloc.

headline: What Have You Learned Playing Video Games?
text: What are your favorite video games? What do you think they have taught you?

headline: Numericable Raises $10.9 Billion in Junk Bond Offering
text: Updated, 12:30 p.m. | Numericable, the French cable unit of Altice, raised 7.9 billion euros, or about $10.9 billion, on Wednesday in the largest junk bond offering in history to help finance the acquisition of Vivendi’s mobile unit, SFR.

headline: High Altitudes May Aid Weight Control
text: Could living in the mountains help with weight control? Maybe.

headline: New York Today: Balloon’s-Eye View
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Ardian Raises $10 Billion, Mostly to Invest in Buyout Funds
text: The private equity firm Ardian said on Wednesday that it had raised $10 billion from investors, including $9 billion for a fund that invests in existing buyout funds.

headline: Pacific Rim Deal Could Reduce Chance of Unintended Conflict in Contested Seas
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A naval code of conduct approved by more than 20 nations around the Pacific, including China, Japan and the United States, could reduce the risk of accidental encounters’ spiraling into conflict, experts said. But Beijing’s firm rejection of President Obama’s comments on Wednesday about islands claimed by both China and Japan underscored the maritime tensions that continue to trouble Asia.

headline: Obama Arrives in Asia as Disasters Complicate Mission
text: TOKYO — President Obama arrived here on Wednesday evening to begin a four-country tour of Asia, after first stopping in Washington State to survey the devastation left there by last month’s deadly mudslide. It was a fitting start, given that everywhere on this trip, he will witness the lingering fallout of disasters, natural and human-made.

headline: Close Races in 4 Southern States Could Tip Senate Power Balance
text: Four Senate races in the South that will most likely determine control of Congress appear very close, with Republicans benefiting from more partisan intensity but a Democratic incumbent, seen as highly vulnerable, holding a surprising edge, according to a New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll.

headline: Diplomatic Efforts on Syria Have Failed, U.N. Chiefs Say
text: GENEVA — Two months after the United Nations Security Council ordered Syria’s warring parties to allow access for humanitarian aid to civilians, the heads of five United Nations agencies warned on Wednesday that diplomacy had failed and that the desperate plight of civilians in many parts of the country was getting worse.

headline: Looking for a Business to Buy? Think ‘Castoffs’
text: Those who have been around businesses a while know a secret of the acquisition world: Occasionally, there are really good deals out there.

headline: Daily Report: New York Argues Case Against Airbnb Before Judge
text: There was no room for agreement, and no agreement about rooms, in court on Tuesday in Albany, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Penetrating a Closed, Isolated Society in Appalachia
text: Trip Gabriel, a national reporter, describes the challenge of winning trust in McDowell County, W.Va., the focus of a front-page article on Monday. The article, headlined “50 Years Later, Hardship Hits Back,” was the first in a series about the poor in America called “Caught in Poverty.”

headline: Anglo-Irish Retailer Primark to Make U.S. Landfall in Boston
text: LONDON – Seeing the recent success of Topshop, Uniqlo and other overseas low-cost retailers among United States consumers, the Anglo-Irish retailer Primark said on Wednesday that it planned to open its first store in the country next year.

headline: In Our Pages: April 24
text: 1889: Fight at a French Fair

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll of four Southern states is based on telephone interviews conducted April 8 through April 15 with 4,152 adults. Of these, 3,594 said they were registered to vote: 857 in Arkansas, 891 in Kentucky, 946 in Louisiana, and 900 in North Carolina.

headline: British Financial Regulator Adds 2 Senior Advisers
text: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain has added a former head of Britain’s Competition Commission and a former executive at Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers Holdings to its ranks as it looks to increase its expertise.

headline: Big Pharma’s Deal Bonanza
text: The pharmaceutical industry is regaining its swagger, Michael J. de la Merced, David Gelles and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook. On Tuesday alone, pharmaceutical companies announced $74 billion worth of potential deals, including an unconventional $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, and a flurry of swaps and sales between Novartis of Switzerland and GlaxoSmithKline of Britain. More deals in the cash-rich industry are expected.

headline: Australia Examines Material Washed Ashore for Link to Missing Jet
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Investigators are examining whether material that washed ashore near the southern end of Western Australia is connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines aircraft, Australian search organizers said on Wednesday.

headline: Russia Warns Ukraine of Potential Military Response
text: MOSCOW — Russia continued Wednesday to ratchet up pressure on the government in Kiev, warning that events in eastern Ukraine could prompt a military response and again accusing the United States of directing events there.

headline: On Combating Government Secrecy: One Step Forward, One Leap Back
text: To put it mildly, President Obama’s early promises of transparency in government haven’t exactly turned out that way.

headline: Australia to Bolster Air Force With More Lockheed Jets
text: SYDNEY, Australia — In a $11.6 billion deal, Australia is ordering 58 more F-35 fighter jets built by Lockheed Martin, increasing the total fleet to 72, Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Wednesday.

headline: Former Executive Sells Aam Aadmi Party as Pro-Business
text: MUMBAI, India — As a truck festooned with broomsticks, the symbol of the Aam Aadmi Party, wheezed in a narrow lane in Kamathipura, the red-light district in south Mumbai, women in floral nightgowns appeared on their doorsteps, curious about the commotion.

headline: Post Office Rules
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Now Nattering on His Own Throne
text: Felicitous timing has powered the steeply ascendant television career of John Oliver since the day he landed in New York from London — July 16, 2006 — and, just 24 hours later, sweaty and jet-lagged, found himself mocking Tony Blair in an exchange with Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show.”

headline: An Artist’s View of Brussels
text: Brussels may be a hub for international business, but the Belgian capital — whose Art Brussels contemporary art fair kicks off Friday — is also full of unexpected pleasures. Creative types are drawn to the city’s relatively low cost of living, multicultural flavor and vibrant art scene, anchored by the Wiels Contemporary Art Center. Here, on the eve of the fair, the New York-based artist Megan Marrin — currently an artist in residence at Wiels — lists a few of her favorite cultural gems in the city.

headline: Amazon to Stream Original HBO Content
text: Amazon will stream a selection of HBO series, mini-series and original movies as part of its Prime subscription service, the latest alliance between technology and entertainment companies trying to capture viewers who are moving online.

headline: Amazon.com is learning the hard way that people care more about price than brand loyalty.
text: In states where Amazon has been forced to begin charging sales tax, households decreased their expenditures on the site by 9.5 percent and by 24 percent on purchases of more than $299, according to a new study by Ohio State University researchers. Although bricks-and-mortar retailers and state governments pushed for Amazon to collect sales tax, they did not necessarily benefit. Sales increased only 2 percent at local stores, but rose nearly 20 percent at competing online retailers that do not charge sales tax. For expensive purchases, the rivals saw a 24 percent increase.

headline: U.S. Military Exercises to Begin in Eastern Europe
text: PARIS — American military exercises in Eastern Europe are to begin Wednesday as part of a move to ease the anxieties of eastern European countries alarmed by Russia’s efforts to reassert its hegemony in the region, Western officials said.

headline: A ‘Lyons’ Reunion at the Vineyard
text: Why mess with success? In 2011, the Vineyard Theater produced a new Nicky Silver family play with a juicy role for Linda Lavin. “The Lyons,” in which she played a neurotic New York wife looking forward to the death of her husband, became an Off Broadway hit and transferred to Broadway. Now, the prolific Mr. Silver is back with a new play, “Too Much Sun,” which starts performances on May 1 at the Vineyard. It once again stars Ms. Lavin.

headline: Justice Dept. Expands Eligibility for Clemency
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department announced a plan on Wednesday to canvass the entire federal prison population for the first time to find inmates who committed low-level crimes and could be released early.

headline: Degrees of Influence Peddling in China and U.S.
text: To understand how money and politics intertwine in the world’s two largest economies, look no further than two important articles in The Times in the last few days.

headline: Pay Gap Is Because of Gender, Not Jobs
text: Are women paid less than men because they choose to be, by gravitating to lower-paying jobs like teaching and social work?

headline: Poetry Profiles: Louisiana State University Press
text: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by MaryKatherine Callaway, the director of LSU Press.

headline: Why Do the Boy Scouts Still Ban Gay Troop Leaders?
text: Robert Gates, the former defense secretary and Eagle Scout, will in May begin a two-year term as president of the Boy Scouts of America. At the Pentagon, Mr. Gates backed President Obama’s call to end the unjust “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that barred gay men and women from serving openly in the military. If he cares to build on that record of inclusion, he could start by publicly voicing disapproval of the B.S.A.’s mistreatment of Geoff McGrath.

headline: Flights of Fancy
text: Mired in reality as adults are, they can find it hard to remember that children’s outsize desires are often best fulfilled imaginatively. Two entertaining new books make this point with a light touch. “The day I discovered I could fly, I knew that I was special,” begins Michaël Escoffier in “The Day I Lost My Superpowers,” illustrated by Kris Di Giacomo. The speaker is a preschooler (seemingly a girl, though boy readers will find there’s nothing to prevent them imagining themselves in her place) who is convinced — in a way quite rightly — of her own superpowers. These include the ability to launch herself off the playground slide into the sandbox, to make cupcakes disappear by sheer force of concentration, and to direct plants and inanimate objects to do her will by staying in one place.

headline: A Fresh Setback for VW in Its Bid for Full Control of the Truck Maker Scania
text: LONDON – The German automaker Volkswagen faced a fresh setback on Wednesday in its bid to take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania.

headline: Palestinian Rivals Announce Unity Pact, Drawing U.S. and Israeli Rebuke
text: JERUSALEM — The faltering Middle East peace process was thrown into further jeopardy on Wednesday, with Israel and the United States harshly condemning a new deal announced by feuding Palestinian factions, including the militant group Hamas, to repair their seven-year rift.

headline: Malaysia on Unidentified Debris on Beach
text: Malaysian officials said they were waiting for verification on whether unidentified material that washed up on the Australian coastline is from missing Flight 370.

headline: A Man of Magic in the Real World
text: In 1983 I was a young would-be film distributor at the Cannes Film Festival looking to find a movie to make my mark. I had gone to film school, I had studied Godard, Truffaut, Visconti and Fellini, and I had stars in my eyes. I wanted to follow in the great tradition of Don Rugoff, the president of Cinema 5, who was everybody’s idol in the film distribution world. But there I was, trying to go to various screenings and having no connections whatsoever with anyone.

headline: Euro Zone Deficit Hits Target for First Time Since 2008
text: PARIS — Euro zone governments have hit an important goal, bringing their combined budget deficits for 2013 in line with their target for the first time since 2008, official data showed on Wednesday. But for some economists, meeting that cost-cutting goal has not been worth the price paid in lost jobs and feeble growth.

headline: With Vaults and Domes, Two Architects Left Their Imprint on City
text: If you think the old Pennsylvania Station has completely disappeared, get off a No. 1 train at 34th Street-Penn Station, walk to the southernmost exit and press your nose to the safety-glass panel at the top of the landing. Then look up.

headline: Six First Ladies Together Backstage
text: Here are six first ladies, 20 years ago next month, at a joint fund-raising appearance at the United States Botanic Garden in Washington. The body language seems revealing. Hillary Rodham Clinton, the incumbent president’s wife, confers with the widow of L.B.J., a Big Daddy for modern Democrats. Betty Ford turns to Barbara Bush, wife of the young Texan whose career her husband, Jerry, had once promoted, and away from Rosalynn Carter, whose Jimmy had thwarted Gerald Ford’s re-election. Former actress Nancy Reagan seems to be waiting for their cue to perform.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Divider Effect
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Despite Poll, Problems Lurk for Democratic Incumbents in South
text: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll offers some encouraging news for Democrats. The incumbent Democratic senators in three states — Arkansas, Louisiana and North Carolina — still hold at least nominal leads. Perhaps the best news for Democrats comes in Arkansas, where the polls show Mark Pryor ahead by a surprising 10-point margin.

headline: Led Zeppelin Releases Two Previously Unheard Recordings
text: LONDON – The Led Zeppelin guitarist Jimmy Page clearly likes to be in control. The British rock group, which is reissuing its first three albums on June 3, has just released two previously unheard recordings that Mr. Page, 70, found while going through the band’s archives.

headline: Piketty’s Book on Wealth and Inequality Is More Popular in Richer States
text: Thomas Piketty’s tome “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” is currently the top-selling book at Amazon.com. It’s also been the subject of intense media coverage from publications with New York, Washington and Wall Street in their names. But has Mr. Piketty kicked off a broad national conversation about inequality, or is the book being read mostly in the East Coast liberal echo chamber?

headline: Health Law’s Middle-Ground Approach Leaves It Unloved
text: The legacy achievement of the Obama administration has also become its largest political conundrum. Many Americans disapprove of the Affordable Care Act — but for different reasons, coming from different sides.

headline: A Briton’s View of Paris: Martin Parr at the Maison Européenne de la Photographie
text: PARIS — In January, the soon-to-be-elected mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, set off a minor wave of cross-Channel outrage when, piqued by the claim of her London counterpart, Boris Johnson, that his city attracted more tourists than hers, she dismissed London as a ‘‘suburb of Paris.’’ (She later tamped down her comment in an open letter in The Guardian.)

headline: FIFA Suspends Barcelona Transfer Ban
text: Barcelona will be allowed to sign new players during this summer’s transfer window after FIFA on Wednesday suspended a ban on acquisitions while the club pursues its appeal.

headline: Philanthropist Admits Stealing More Than $1 Million From Charity
text: For most of his long and very public life as a philanthropist, William E. Rapfogel has been surrounded by powerful friends and politicians, chief among them Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker.

headline: A Different Kind of Super Power
text: The cartoonist Scott McCloud, who wrote about what makes comic books tick in “Understanding Comics” and speculated about their future in “Reinventing Comics,” is returning to fiction for his next project, “The Sculptor,” a graphic novel to be published in February 2015 by First Second.

headline: Gallery | Emerging Fashion and Photography Talents From the Hyères Festival
text: Starting Friday, the 29th International Festival of Fashion and Photography at Hyères in the South of France will be showcasing its annual roundup of young talents to watch and awarding prizes in the fashion and photography categories. The fashion jury, led by the Opening Ceremony founders and Kenzo designers Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, also included Spike Jonze and Chloë Sevigny; the 10 finalists will display their work at seaside runway shows during the festival weekend. The photography jury was presided over by the legendary lensman Steve Hiett. Winnowed from 743 entries, the work of the 10 finalists will be on view at the Villa Noailles in a group show running through May 25.

headline: Underwater Search for Ferry Victims
text: A senior official with the South Korean Coast Guard said rescuers were mobilizing an underwater robot to help with night operations as they hunted for missing passengers.

headline: Why Criticism of Poll Is Misguided
text: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation surveys offer some pretty good results for Democrats — with caveats — so it’s no surprise that polling aficionados are scouring the details for an explanation. They think they’ve found the problem: respondents’ self-reported vote in the 2012 presidential election, which generally found President Obama faring far better than he did in that race. This critique is understandable, but misguided.

headline: Tough Sell for Chinese Pork Producer’s I.P.O.
text: The WH Group’s chopped initial public offering still looks unappetizing.

headline: Bangladesh’s Chance to Get It Right
text: Bangladesh is hardly known for its workplace safety. But one unlikely success story can be found in a leading shipbuilding company called Western Marine, based in the port city of Chittagong. Western Marine makes ships for the domestic market but has also sold vessels to Germany and Denmark.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | The War on Drugs
text: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: Justin Bieber Apologizes After Visiting Japanese War Shrine
text: TOKYO — Justin Bieber got a nasty lesson in Asia’s tangled emotions over history on Wednesday when he apologized to irate Chinese fans for posting photos of himself visiting a controversial Tokyo war shrine.

headline: Film at 9/11 Museum Sets Off Clash Over Reference to Islam
text: Past the towering tridents that survived the World Trade Center collapse, adjacent to a gallery with photographs of the 19 hijackers, a brief film at the soon-to-open National September 11 Memorial Museum will seek to explain to visitors the historical roots of the attacks.

headline: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
text: Also on the Minute, Syria’s humanitarian crisis, and the risks people take to find their iPhones.

headline: Classical Playlist: Carter, Rand Steiger, Mozart and More
text: CARTER, SESSIONS AND ECKARDTMiranda Cuckson, violinist, and Blair McMillen, pianist(Urlicht AudioVisual)The violinist Miranda Cuckson and the pianist Blair McMillen, who are individually brilliant and adventurous artists, bring out the best in each other in their frequent collaborations, including their latest recording of contemporary works. Their incisive, animated playing cuts through the density and complexity of Carter’s Duo for Violin and Piano to reveal the music’s wit and fancifulness. Jason Eckardt wrote his glistening, jittery and playfully frenetic “Strömkarl” last year as a companion piece for this recording. Ms. Cuckson is outstanding in Sessions’s magisterial, technically challenging Sonata for Solo Violin (1953). (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
text: In the Video

headline: A Letter to the National September 11 Memorial Museum
text: A letter sent to Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the museum, from an interfaith advisory group of religious leaders. The letter detailed their concerns about the film “The Rise of Al Qaeda.”

headline: Ice Climbing in an Alaskan Glacial Paradise
text: Standing on a glacier, you expect the world to be a vast expanse of white.

headline: Chasing Elusive Flowers in South Africa
text: It was supposed to be straightforward: Drive north from Cape Town for a few hours until, voilà, I’m engulfed by a rainbow of flowers. That’s what I envisioned when an acquaintance urged me to witness the blooming spring landscape of the Western and Northern Cape: “Never-ending carpets of wildflowers,” he promised.

headline: A New Class of American Academy Fellows
text: The actor Al Pacino, the bluegrass musician Ralph Stanley, the novelists Annie Proulx and John Irving, and the historian Jill Lepore are among the 204 newly elected fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

headline: The Republican Party’s Senate Problem
text: After yesterday’s feature on the American middle class’s (relative) decline, the big newsmaker over at The Upshot today is new polling on four red-state Senate races, which shows Mark Pryor, the Democratic incumbent, with a surprisingly large lead over Tom Cotton in Arkansas, and races in North Carolina, Louisiana and Kentucky all effectively in dead heats.

headline: Race in ‘Waxman’ Primary Involves Donating Dollars
text: The congressional Democrats Frank Pallone and Anna Eshoo have been helping their friends this year, and making new ones, with an eye on a potential payback in 2015. Mr. Pallone, from New Jersey, and Ms. Eshoo, from California, have been giving their colleagues thousands of dollars in campaign contributions as part of what could be called the Waxman Primary.

headline: U.S. Workers Losing Ground in Leisure Time, Too
text: The American middle class is losing ground in more ways than one.

headline: Midsummer Night Swing Offerings Range From Afro-Cuban to Classic Rock
text: Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center’s annual celebration of dance music, will set up its outdoor ballroom at Damrosch Park on June 24 for a performance by Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks, with  Cécile McLorin Salvant, the first of 15 nights of music and dancing at the park. The festival runs through July 12, and includes evenings of African and Cuban dance music, disco, Latin and classic rock, with dance lessons in the style of the evening at each performance.

headline: Risqué Names Reap Rewards for Some Companies
text: Corin and Brian Mullins thought they had a good name for their debut product, a nonallergenic, high-fiber breakfast cereal, until a supremely satisfied customer called to praise the product’s effectiveness.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: The Worst Soccer Loss Ever and a Hollywood Ending
text: Mike Brett and Steve Jamison know what it’s like to be underdogs playing soccer. (From here we’ll call it football.) The future filmmaking partners met as footballers at Cambridge University and went on an Asian tour with the Cambridge squad that included a match against the Thai national team, then ranked 60th in the world.

headline: IBM Opens Chip Architecture, in Strategy of Sharing and Self-Interest
text: IBM’s chip business needs help. So the company has opened up the technology of its Power microprocessors, inviting others to modify and manufacture Power-based designs pretty much as they see fit. This open, liberal licensing initiative is conducted under the auspices of the OpenPower Foundation, which was incorporated in December.

headline: So Many Art Fairs. So Little Time.
text: LOS ANGELES – Scheduling a new art fair these days is nearly as challenging as setting a release date for a feature film in Hollywood, given the steep competition.

headline: New York Financial Regulator Uses Dodd-Frank to Sue Auto Lender
text: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | By his own admission, even New York’s top financial regulator did not know he could use the Dodd-Frank law to enforce consumer protections until very recently.

headline: Federal Prosecutor to Help Lead Justice Dept.’s Criminal Division
text: The Justice Department’s criminal division, which oversees some of the biggest investigations into Wall Street and corporate crime, is adding to its ranks.

headline: Queen’s Day Becomes King’s Day in the Netherlands
text: The Netherlands’ biggest celebration has a new date and name this month, when the former Queen’s Day, held since 1890, becomes King’s Day, or Koningsdag.

headline: Plea Agreement for William E. Rapfogel
text: An agreement that Mr. Rapfogel entered into with the attorney general’s office in which he agreed to plead guilty. He also promised to pay $3 million in restitution.

headline: Dodge Poetry Festival Set to Return to Newark
text: And they said it wouldn’t last.

headline: Are Risqué Company Names Good for Business?
text: We’ve just published an article that recounts the experiences of several companies that have sought to attract attention by giving themselves outrageous names. In fact, several of the companies aren’t sure they would exist if not for their creative names.

headline: Court Information for William E. Rapfogel
text: Mr. Rapfogel pleaded guilty to charges contained in a Superior Court Information document drawn up by the attorney general’s office.

headline: Gallery | Vintage Posters Bring Art-House Appeal to the Auction House
text: Nicholas Lowry, the president and principal auctioneer of New York City’s Swann Auction Galleries, was reminded of the weighty value of niche memorabilia at last year’s Modernist Posters auction: a poster advertising Andy Warhol’s Exploding Plastic Inevitable, a multimedia event held at the Chrysler Art Museum in Provincetown, Mass. in 1966, fetched nearly nine times its estimated selling price — despite not actually having been designed by Warhol himself. “All of a sudden, people who have similar things at home are saying, ‘Wait a minute, this piece of paper is worth $7000?'” says Lowry, who has received a constant stream of inquiries and offers leading up to this year’s sale, happening tomorrow at Swann. “Warhol created such a successful cult of personality around him that it has long succeeded his death.”

headline: Court Information for David Cohen
text: Mr. Cohen plead guilty to the charges contained in the Superior Court Information document.

headline: New York Police Twitter Backlash Spreads Around the World
text: What began as an effort by the New York Police Department to get people to share favorable photos of city police officers on Twitter has turned into an international social media campaign about police abuse.

headline: Image of the Day: April 23
text: Arvind Kejriwal, chief of the Aam Aadmi Party, filed his nomination to contest a seat from the temple town of Varanasi in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Recipes for Kids: Tzatziki
text: Tzatziki (za-DZEE-kee) is a Greek dip that is often served as a snack or an appetizer. It is also great on burgers or tomato sandwiches.

headline: Anthony Can Expect Lower Offer
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson’s first postseason news conference began with the statement that “there is no news.” But Jackson, the Knicks’ new $60 million team president, has been a longtime newsmaker, an N.B.A. lightning rod. He almost cannot help it.

headline: Returning to an ‘Impossible’ Role
text: Leaning against an upright piano, Amber Gray bent her voice and body to a song’s harmonies — tapping her feet, drumming her fingers, bowing her head, and turtling her chin forward and back.

headline: Springing Forward, and Its Consequences
text: This is a busy time of year for Richard B. Primack, a biologist at Boston University. He and his colleagues survey the plants growing around Concord, Mass., recording the first day they send up flowers and leaves.

headline: A Deeper Look at a Study Finding High Leak Rates From Gas Drilling
text: Updated below with Skype chat with the study lead author, 10:07 p.m. | Most efforts to slow the natural gas drilling boom in the United States have focused on questions about the environmental impacts of the process called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, which occurs deep underground after a well is drilled.

headline: Researchers See New Importance in Y Chromosome
text: There is new reason to respect the diminutive male Y chromosome.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Casa Valentina’
text: A scene from Harvey Fierstein’s new play about cross-dressers at a 1960s Catskills resort. The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: A Renter Does the Math
text: Soon after his arrival in New York from San Francisco two years ago, David Park took a rental at the Beatrice, rising high above the Eventi Hotel on West 29th Street. He loved his small studio, 475 contemporary square feet with a great view and a central location.

headline: Proposal to Limit Prosecutions of Marijuana Cases in Brooklyn
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office will stop prosecuting people arrested on charges of possessing small amounts of marijuana, according to a confidential policy proposal that the district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, sent to the New York Police Department this month.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
text: ORCAS ISLAND, WASH.

headline: Mixed Signals: Exploring the Science Behind Nutrition and Disease
text: Overview | The news can sometimes seem as if it is full of conflicting reports on the connection between diet and health: Are fats good for you, or bad for you? What about sugar, chocolate and caffeine? And what kinds of evidence do scientists use in making dietary recommendations? In this lesson, students can explore the science behind nutrition and disease — how strong are the connections between diet and conditions such as heart disease, obesity and even cancer?

headline: Ackman’s Pershing Square Subsidiaries Hint at Future Moves
text: The hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman may be plotting his next big stock move, even as he is on the media circuit explaining his decision to partner with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to make a $45.6 billion hostile bid for the Botox manufacturer Allergan.

headline: Justices Rule Child Pornography Restitution Is Too High
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday set aside a $3.4 million award to a victim of child pornography who had sought restitution from a man convicted of viewing images of her. That figure was too much, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for a five-justice majority, returning the case to the lower courts to apply a new and vague legal standard to find a lower amount that is neither nominal nor too severe.

headline: Experian Study Highlights Differences Between Hybrid and E.V. Owners
text: While it may seem natural to want to shove people who buy electric vehicles and hybrids into the same pigeonhole, there are some slight differences between them.

headline: Genting Group Says It Is Vying for a Casino License
text: The Genting Group, among the biggest gambling interests in the world, announced on Wednesday that it was vying for one of the four licenses that will be available to open a casino in upstate New York.

headline: Nets Dictating Play as the Raptors Rely on a Backup
text: After two games, patterns are emerging in the first-round playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors. The teams are tied at one victory each, but so far it is the Nets who have forced the Raptors to make adjustments.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Nate Parker
text: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Etsy Buys Grand St., a Boutique Electronics Start-Up
text: Etsy, the online marketplace for handmade and vintage goods, is poised to acquire a Brooklyn start-up called Grand St., an online boutique for electronics.

headline: Two New Music Festivals to Enliven New York Stages
text: Two contemporary music festivals – one built largely around stars of the burgeoning downtown and Brooklyn scenes, and one examining unusual corners of the composition world – will keep New York concert stages animated in May and June.

headline: Reporting on Love in the Hindu Kush
text: Rod Nordland, the Afghanistan bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses reporting on a couple on the run from authorities and families who do not approve of their marriage.

headline: Iranian Prison Chief Is Removed After Reports of Attack on Inmates
text: TEHRAN — The head of Iran’s judiciary removed the country’s highest prison official on Wednesday, after what human rights advocates said was a violent raid on political prisoners in Tehran’s largest prison facility.

headline: Study Finds Less Green in the Congo Rain Forest
text: Years of drier conditions in the Congo River basin in central Africa appear to be affecting trees in the region’s vast rain forests, scientists reported on Wednesday.

headline: Siri and Google Now, Meet Cortana
text: Molly Wood tests out mobile virtual assistants, including Microsoft’s Cortana, to see if Siri has met her match.

headline: A Discreetly Charming Women’s Wear Line from Perugia
text: What do women want? Whether the aim is to explore modes of self-expression or to feel invisible, what resonates in fashion today are clothes that feel deeply personal. Perhaps that’s why Sara Lanzi — a self-taught Italian designer based not in the fashion capital of Milan but in the romantic university town of Perugia — is now, after nearly a decade spent quietly producing her pieces, having something of a New York moment. The influential online retailer La Garçonne and the Comme des Garçons store in Chelsea, among others, have picked up her spring collection, a range of softly textured dresses and separates whose clean lines and muted tones are lightened by an exuberant fluidity. “My background is the underground movement of the ’90s,” Lanzi explains. “‘Do it yourself’ was the mood; that’s where it all comes from.” The line, she says, is “a balance of imperfection and rigor. I have a sort of graphic attitude that drives me; nevertheless, I am far from minimalism.” It’s an approach that should please street-style peacocks and normcore enthusiasts alike.

headline: In Allergan Bid, a Question of Insider Trading
text: One trading day after announcing the news that the huge hedge fund he runs, Pershing Square Capital Management, had partnered with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to make an unsolicited $45.6 billion cash and stock takeover bid for Allergan, William A. Ackman is sitting on a paper profit of more than $1 billion on the Allergan shares and options he had been secretly buying over the past two months.

headline: Windows Phone 8.1 Finally Catches Up to Its Rivals
text: WINDOWS PHONE 8.1 is a very good mobile operating system.

headline: Entertainment Executive Denies Sexual Abuse Accusation
text: LOS ANGELES — Gary W. Goddard, an entertainment executive, has now joined three other entertainment figures who explicitly deny the claims of sexual abuse filed against them over the last week by a once-aspiring actor.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas for Braking Problem
text: Based on a single complaint, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether the forward-collision warning system on about 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas from the 2014 model year may malfunction and slow or stop the vehicle when a collision is not imminent.

headline: Scene City: Stars Align, Just North of TriBeCa
text: Sophia Loren, Julianne Moore and others stars attend annual Tribeca Film Festival dinner hosted by Chanel.

headline: Coloring In a Hitchcock Profile
text: Sometimes the best refuge from real trauma is simulated terror. The English playwright David Rudkin remembers cowering under his bunk in an air-raid shelter as a child. It was the early 1940s, and German bombs were raining on his hometown, Birmingham. What dreams may come to a child who fears for his life? Menacing images from Alfred Hitchcock thrillers like “Rebecca,” “Suspicion” and “Foreign Correspondent,” naturally.

headline: The Gun Report: April 23, 2014
text: This afternoon, Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal signed into law the “Safe Carry Protection Act,” which allows guns in more public places than at any time in the past century, including churches, bars, and government buildings that do not have security checkpoints. Which is why critics call it the “Guns Everywhere Bill.”

headline: G.M.’s Bankruptcy Will Probably Shield It From Most New Claims
text: General Motors’ liability for defective ignition switches in its cars is complicated by its bankruptcy in 2009. The federal bankruptcy judge in New York approved a sale order that shielded the “new” company from liability for incidents that took place before July 10, 2009, the day the sale became effective.

headline: Ilaria Urbinati: The Stylist for the Quieter Half of the Red Carpet
text: The New York designer Michael Bastian works with his fair share of stylists. But there is only one for whom he’ll not only roll out the racks, but also move the heavens. “I’ve pulled stuff from my own closet to ensure she has what she needs,” Mr. Bastian said from his office in Chelsea on one chilly afternoon. “She’s the only one I would do that for.”

headline: House Hunting in ... the Canadian Rockies
text: A RUSTIC FOUR-BEDROOM HOME IN THE CANADIAN ROCKIES

headline: Southerners Don’t Like Obamacare. They Also Don’t Want to Repeal It.
text: Despite strong dislike of President Obama’s handling of health care, a majority of people in three Southern states – Kentucky, Louisiana and North Carolina – would rather that Congress improve his signature health care law than repeal and replace it, according to a New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll.

headline: Clip: ‘Locke’
text: A scene from the film featuring Tom Hardy.

headline: U.S. Sends Troops to Eastern Europe
text: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John F. Kirby, discussed U.S. military exercises in Eastern Europe, and the Ukrainian first deputy prime minister, Vitaly Yarema, expressed gratitude.

headline: The Soul of TriBeCa, if Not the Place
text: It wasn’t difficult to find the Tribeca Film Festival’s annual artists dinner on Tuesday night. All you had to do was search out police barricades, the flash of cameras and impermeable masses of assembled fans, all of which required the blockage of an entire city street.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Bronies, Now a Movie Genre
text: “We’re supposed to chug beer, ride motorcycles, be degrading to women and like explosions,” the handlebar-mustachioed man says. “That’s what’s ingrained in our brains from the minute you’re born and put into a blue crib.”

headline: Musings on Identity, From the Assimilated Exile to the Meaning of ‘Maria’
text: If you want a quick thematic summary of any piece in Ballet Hispanico’s repertory, just look at the program notes for its current two-week season at the Joyce Theater. Annabelle Lopez Ochoa’s “Mad’moiselle,” for instance, explores “iconic male/female images and gender identity in Latin American cultures.” Eduardo Vilaro’s “Hogar” is a “moving meditation on immigrant identity and the meaning of home.”

headline: Connie Marrero, 102, Dies; Pitcher Starred in Cuba and the Majors
text: Connie Marrero, a chunky right-hander from Cuba with a windmill delivery and a wicked curveball, was nearly 39 years old when he reached the major leagues with the 1950 Washington Senators.

headline: Richard Serra Wins Architectural League Prize
text: Richard Serra has been awarded the Presidentʼs Medal from the Architectural League of New York, the first time the prize has been given to an artist.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 50
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ukraine’s Military Drive in East Enters Neutral Gear, as Pact on Crisis Is Tested
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The promised Ukrainian military effort to reassert control over the restive eastern part of the country barely registered on Wednesday, but the Geneva agreement to defuse the crisis in the country frayed even further as the United States and Russia exchanged warnings and accusations of meddling in the region.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Sees Biggest Sales Week Yet
text: The sales numbers for most hit albums follow a basic pattern. They crest in the first week they go on sale, a result of front-loaded marketing campaigns, and then trail downward from there; they can lose up to 80 percent of sales in their second week, and rarely recover.

headline: A Boy and His Tall Imaginary Friend Are Back
text: Martin Moone, Irish seventh grader: “Do you see what I see?”

headline: Aspirin Benefits Some at Risk for Colon Cancer
text: Many studies have found that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for colon cancer. Now scientists have found that aspirin may benefit some people far more than others.

headline: Obama’s First Order of Business in Tokyo: Sushi From the Master
text: To all the perks afforded the leader of the free world, add this one: Within about 90 minutes of arriving in Tokyo on Wednesday, President Obama sat down for a meal prepared by an octogenarian sushi chef whom some regard as the master of all masters.

headline: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
text: In order to ride a steep face that received minimal sunlight, Jeremy Jones and Ryland Bell spent an evening nestled on a ledge thousands of feet above their base camp in Alaska’s Fairweather Range.

headline: Video: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
text: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and “Higher.” The films document his efforts to explore and snowboard mountains around the world under his own power. In this companion piece to its “Higher Unplugged” series, Teton Gravity Research provides a glimpse into “Deeper.”

headline: Facebook Profit Tripled in First Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As Facebook reported another quarter of strong revenue and profit growth on Wednesday, its executives made one thing very clear: The company’s money machine has just begun to spit out the cash.

headline: Teamwork Rules the Night
text: Giving a party these days, it seems, takes a village.

headline: App Smart: Selfies
text: Kit Eaton dives into three apps that can take selfies to the next level.

headline: Richard H. Hoggart, ‘Lady Chatterley’s’ Savior, Dies at 95
text: Richard H. Hoggart, a pioneering British cultural historian who was most widely known outside academia as the star witness for “Lady Chatterley’s Lover” in a 1960 trial that ended British censorship of that novel, died on April 10 in London. He was 95.

headline: Making Your Selfies the Talk of Instagram
text: MILEY CYRUS has done many things recently, but I think my favorite among them is elevating the “selfie” photo to something like a modern art form.

headline: S.E.C. Settles With Ex-Nvidia Employee in Insider Trading Case
text: The former Nvidia employee who the authorities contend supplied inside information about the chip maker’s earnings to a group of hedge fund traders and analysts has reached a settlement with securities regulators, the regulators said on Wednesday.

headline: Seeking to Grow, Chobani Secures $750 Million Loan
text: The yogurt maker Chobani has struck a deal with private equity.

headline: 25 Years After Tiananmen, Calls for Officials to Disclose Assets Still Unmet
text: Twenty-five years, two events, one plea: A quarter-century after the crushing of the Tiananmen democracy movement, which was driven in large part by the desire to end corruption, people are still calling on China’s wealthy leaders and their families to reveal their financial assets.

headline: Felix Salmon to Take On Web-Based Role at Fusion
text: Felix Salmon, a prominent writer on finance and other topics who announced this week that he was leaving Reuters, will join the cable network Fusion on Monday in a web-based role that runs across multiple media.

headline: Hamas and the P.L.O.’s Latest Accord
text: The two main Palestinian groups in the West Bank and Gaza agreed on Wednesday to form a unity government.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Albuquerque Police Yet to Find Video of Shooting
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Albuquerque’s police chief said on Wednesday that the authorities had not been able to find conclusive videotape footage of the fatal police shooting this week of a 19-year-old woman who was the 24th person killed since 2010 by members of the department, which is under federal and state investigation for violating use-of-force rules.

headline: 2 Women Who Offer Life Lessons in Very Different Ways
text: “Bad Teacher,” based on the Cameron Diaz movie by the same name, is a CBS sitcom about a middle-school teacher who is a sexy, unscrupulous gold digger.

headline: Bayern Munich Controls All but the Final Score
text: MADRID — Bayern Munich got the ball, again and again and again. But Real Madrid got the goal.

headline: Telling Stories, From ‘Beowulf’ to the Hobo Life
text: As the composer David Lang points out in his program note for “collected stories,” a fascinating series of concerts he has put together through the auspices of Carnegie Hall, music has long been called upon to help tell different kinds of tales. In planning this six-concert series, which opened on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall before a packed house, Mr. Lang was a far-ranging and visionary collector of stories.

headline: Justice Department on Clemency Program
text: James Cole, a deputy attorney general, announced an initiative that encourages inmates sentenced for drug crimes to apply for clemency.

headline: Apple’s Profit Still Climbs, but Pressure is Growing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s remarkable growth streak — now more than a decade old — is starting to fade a little.

headline: In War-Torn Country, Laughing to Keep From Crying
text: Jesus has been declawed. In “Holy Land,” the French-Algerian playwright Mohamed Kacimi’s vaguely absurdist disquisition on the dehumanizing effects of war, now playing at Here, Jesus is a tabby cat who frightens a soldier. The soldier retaliates by maiming his paws.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Ukraine and the Philippines.

headline: The Real Reason Red States Won’t Expand Medicaid
text: By now it’s pretty clear that the states refusing to expand health coverage under Medicaid aren’t really worried about the expense. They’re motivated entirely by ideological stubbornness — “for no other reason than political spite,” as President Obama said last week.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll
text: In four southern states, there are complex and often contradictory views of President Obama’s principal domestic legislation four years after it became law.

headline: Final of White House Junior International Teams
text: The final of the White House junior international team event in the Netherlands on April 4 was between Germany A (Marie Eggeling, Raffael Braun, Paul Grünke and Vemund Vikjord) and Norway (Christian Bakke, Kristoffer Hegge, Harald Eide and Kristian B. Ellingsen).

headline: A Sad and Remarkable Life: Breanne Fahs Talks About ‘Valerie Solanas’
text: Valerie Solanas is most famous for shooting Andy Warhol on June 3, 1968. Solanas, a radical thinker whose “SCUM Manifesto” called for the elimination of the male sex, knew Warhol and was angry because she believed he was going to film a play she wrote without paying her for it. She was also afflicted with paranoid schizophrenia and spent time in several psychiatric institutions. In “Valerie Solanas,” Breanne Fahs, an associate professor of women and gender studies at Arizona State University, argues that Solanas is interesting for reasons other than her notoriety for shooting Warhol and her psychological troubles. In a recent email interview, Ms. Fahs discussed Solanas’s relationship with Warhol, why Solanas’s work is still relevant, the difficulties she encountered in researching the biography, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Some Setbacks for the Sharing Economy
text: Scrutiny of the so-called sharing economy seems to increase every day.

headline: A Badly Bruised Soccer Team Tries to Beat a Reputation
text: That American Samoa has a soccer team, much less one that aspires to compete in world championships, is fairly momentous. In terms of population, it’s something like Pontiac, Mich., or Lynchburg, Va., putting together a local group and sending it to the Olympics. So the nickname “worst soccer team in the world” doesn’t seem that shameful.

headline: Prince George Ascending to the Throne of Trendsetter
text: The Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, wears a dress, and it sells out. The so-called Kate Effect has been noted for years, and though plenty of attention has been paid to the dresses she has worn on the royal family’s tour in Australia and New Zealand (Prince William reportedly said that she looked “like a banana” when she wore a yellow Roksanda Ilincic dress in Sydney), she’s not the only one in the family. On the trip, the royal family has introduced a new teeny style icon: Prince George, who, as a 9-month-old, is already having a big impact on some fashion businesses.

headline: All Aboard the Orient Local
text: During one of last summer’s final high-season weeks, I struck up a conversation with an American backpacker in Milan’s Centrale train station. She was 18, in Europe for the first time, and the itinerary she reeled off resembled a similar trip I took some 15 years ago: Amsterdam, Berlin, Vienna, Venice, Madrid. The difference was that, with my Eurail Pass, I’d made a continuous swoop of it; her backpack, garlanded with luggage tags, revealed that she had availed herself of discount airfare for a more higgledy-piggledy route. I had once arrived in Venice from Munich using the pass; my journey had taken 10 hours. She’d come in from Lisbon in 90 minutes.

headline: Future, the Voice of Hip-Hop Today
text: The old rap star metrics of greatness? Future has no use for them. In his songs, he employs few true narratives, no real wordplay or punch lines. He raps mainly in free associative snippets, which, taken as pure text, can read as mundane.

headline: F.C.C., in a Shift, Backs Fast Lanes for Web Traffic
text: WASHINGTON — The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead.

headline: Spring Shopping: Return to the Trenches, but Softly
text: Milder April temperatures are bringing out a profusion of chic trench coats, which this season look freshest in softer, less structured shapes. The quintessential transition piece, a breezy trench will be a welcome antidote to your winter outerwear, which got way too much play this year. Throw one on with jeans and an easy T-shirt for the weekend, as did Karlie Kloss (shown here), who wore a slouchy gray style and ballet flats to pal around with Taylor Swift, and wrap one over tailored pieces for work or a silky dress or jumpsuit for evening.

headline: Music Mix: Spirituality and Protest
text: The subject matter of “Rebel Music: Race, Empire and the New Muslim Youth Culture” could not be more far-reaching unless its author, Hisham D. Aidi, had unearthed data about youth culture and musical influences on other planets. As far as Earth goes, his highly original and ambitious book has got it covered.

headline: Growlers Finding a Refuge in Dance
text: The days of abrasion are seemingly gone in hip-hop — smoothness of various stripes rules the radio, thanks to years of cross-pollination with R&B and pop. For rappers with real tension and grit in their voices, this shift has made for something of a mini-crisis — they’re no longer welcome in their old home.

headline: Sightseeing With Ears Wide Open
text: Have you planned your summer vacation yet? Any thoughts as to what places you’d like to hear this year?

headline: From Japan, a Jazzy Interpretation of Gershwin
text: Here’s something you don’t see every night at Avery Fisher Hall: the members of the New York Philharmonic tapping their feet and nodding their heads, smiling, during a concerto’s cadenza. And here’s another: the orchestra’s principal trombonist, Joseph Alessi; its bassist David J. Grossman; and the saxophonist Allen Won coming to the front of the stage to join the soloist in a Thelonious Monk encore.
