headline: Limiting the Use of Affirmative Action
Cellphone Cases to Prepare You for Anything, Even a Flat Tire
text: PROTECTIVE phone cases have become practically a necessity since the introduction of smartphones. After all, why pay hundreds of dollars for a phone and not spend a little bit more to protect it?

headline: Apple’s Stock Split: Attracting the Wrong Crowd?
text: Suppose I have a delicious pie (apple, let’s say), that is divided into four slices. And then I decide to divide it again, into eight slices. Do the individual slices become more delicious?

headline: Q. and A. | Christo on Jeanne-Claude, the Art of the Process and Trying to Drape a River in Fabric
text: Christo probably isn’t the first name you think of when considering quintessentially New York artists. Yet he landed in the city nearly 50 years ago, arriving from France with his late spouse and creative partner Jeanne-Claude. They moved into a warehouse in SoHo in the early 1960s, converting the building into a residence, studio, gallery and corporate headquarters, complete with its own generator. (The power didn’t go out during Sandy.)

headline: Lions to the Ballot Box
text: The time for complaining is at an end. Action must be taken. Accountability must be demanded. Muscle must be flexed. Power must be exercised.

headline: The Folly of Saving What You Kill
text: SCAFFOLDING went up last week around the former American Folk Art Museum building on West 53rd Street. It was the first step in the Museum of Modern Art’s widely reviled plan to demolish that admired work of contemporary architecture, which MoMA purchased in 2011. Although most of the building will land in a Dumpster, the saga of dismemberment will be prolonged for the Folk Art Museum’s intimately monumental 82-foot-high facade. In response to protests, MoMA has said it would detach and preserve the facade’s 63 textured copper-bronze panels.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 24
text: Events

headline: At the Met Gala, a Strict Dress Code
text: Gone are the fabled society queens and their blue-blood escorts, replaced by quarterbacks, mannequins and Jimmy Fallon. Forgotten, too, are the days when the fashionable elite made their stately ascent of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s broad stairway, all the Nans and Pats and Micas stopping for air kisses along the way.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Fashion? Big Things
text: Last month, Rihanna arrived at Heathrow Airport in London wearing a humongous star-spangled backpack. In its immensity, it was akin to the giant sack used to pilfer all of Whoville’s gifts in “How the Grinch Stole Christmas.”

headline: Conjuring Images of a Bionic Future
text: Dick Loizeaux recently found himself meandering through a noisy New York nightclub. This was unusual; Mr. Loizeaux, a 65-year-old former pastor, began suffering hearing loss nearly a decade ago, and nightclubs are not really his scene. “They’re the absolute worst place to hear anybody talk,” he said.

headline: Port Authority Again Delays Vote on 80-Story Tower at World Trade Center Site
text: After failing to gain enough support to provide additional subsidies to complete the stalled construction of a $2.3 billion, 80-story tower at the site of the former World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey decided on Wednesday to once again delay a decision on the matter.

headline: Charles James and Me
text: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute opens “Charles James: Beyond Fashion” on May 8, the exhibition will have 70 outfits, making it the largest show devoted to the designer, who died in 1978 at age 72. Among them are the Taxi dress, designed in 1929, which wrapped around the body and fastened with Bakelite clasps, so that a woman could slip into it while in the back of a taxi, and the Clover Leaf dress of 1952, which did not touch the floor but undulated while the woman walked.

headline: Following Armenia’s Global Diaspora
text: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.

headline: Zynga Founder Leaves Daily Role at Struggling Game Maker
text: Mark Pincus, the founder of Zynga, is stepping back from the once-hot social gaming company as its new leader seeks a turnaround.

headline: Welcome to Comcast Country
text: PHILADELPHIA — COMCAST’S executive vice president, David L. Cohen, did not seem fazed when Senator Al Franken warned at a recent Judiciary Committee hearing that the company’s proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable would “result in fewer choices, higher prices and even worse service for my constituents.” Comcast argues that the merger will not decrease competition among cable television or broadband Internet providers because the two companies do not directly compete — though the reason for that is that they already maintain virtual monopolies in many of their service areas.

headline: Estimate of Where Obama Lacks White Support
text: Obama lacks support from white voters in part of the South.

headline: Hot Spots: The Early Buzz
text: Only a quarter of the way into the 2014 election cycle, a variety of political ads are making waves not just for their effectiveness, but also for their zaniness.

headline: Southern Whites’ Loyalty to G.O.P. Nearing That of Blacks to Democrats
text: President Obama’s landslide victory in 2008 was supposed to herald the beginning of a new Democratic era. And yet, six years later, there is not even a clear Democratic majority in the country, let alone one poised for 30 years of dominance.

headline: Ads Look to Stand Out Amid the Political Clutter
text: WASHINGTON — The 2014 election cycle has ushered in a rush of political advertising, with campaign ads airing as early as last spring and record-shattering spending for the first quarter of the election year. Between television commercials (some top-notch nuggets of narrative storytelling) and web ads (which allow for a more madcap approach), nearly every day seems to bring about a new visual treat. Here is a look at some ads that managed to cut through the clutter: the good, the bad, and the zany.

headline: Working-Class Fathers Shouldn’t Be So Easily Dismissed
text: Here’s a headline that appears on Slate: “White Working-Class Women Should Raise Kids Alone.” (The full headline when you open the article reads: “Just Say No/For white working-class women, it makes sense to stay single mothers.” The “should” headline appears as you scroll.)

headline: Gawkers, Welcome: House and Garden Tours
text: Speculating about what lies behind the closed doors and garden gates of homes owned by celebrities — or those who just have money and taste — is something of a national pastime. But once a year, in the spring and summer, many of those properties are open to the public, as house-and-garden tours are organized around the country. In many cases, the tours raise funds for nonprofit organizations. So it’s time to stop wondering and start exploring.

headline: The Unsettling Thing About Ellen
text: Oh, to be Ellen DeGeneres’s decorator. Or her architect. Or her real estate agent. Or even her movers.

headline: Our Mother, the Dictator
text: David Adler accepts the trade-offs of being married to an interior designer. For the pleasure of living in beautifully decorated homes, he cedes nearly all creative control to his wife, Amie Weitzman, a principal of the Manhattan firm Weitzman Halpern.

headline: Essentially Japanese
text: Up until the 15th century, Japan embraced showy ornamentation like other powers. That changed when a shogun with a taste for simplicity moved the country toward the spare aesthetic for which it has become renowned.

headline: Big Fish, in Any Size Pond
text: Japanese koi are domesticated carp prized for their size, color, patterns and luster. They are coldblooded, but the people who nurture them in backyard ponds and enter them in competitions are as passionate as any Pekingese owner. Mat McCann, 40, the British-born manager at Quality Koi Farm, a 43-acre business owned by Joseph Zuritsky, in Carneys Point, N.J., uses Japanese stock and methods to breed international champions. (This ambition is not unlike perfecting American truffles, mozzarella and soccer players.) The farm is open to the public from spring through autumn, and collectors travel from all points to peer into its mud ponds. (The interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: A Return to Nigeria
text: When I was 7 years old my father bought me a Bag of Laughs. It was the early 1980s and, as with most every school morning in Lagos, Nigeria, we were stuck in traffic. My father was at the wheel, listening to Bob Marley on the eight-track. I sat in the back, staring at the street peddlers walking in between lanes jostling can openers, batteries and other random items at car windows.

headline: A Star Awaits Its Applause
text: Spotlight Silver, David Rockwell’s latest design for the Rug Company, seems like a not-so-subtle nod to his theatrical leanings. After all, Mr. Rockwell has created sets for Broadway shows like “Hairspray” and “Kinky Boots,” not to mention the Academy Awards. But in a recent interview, he was more focused on the technical details of the hand-knotted rug, pointing out that its gray shades become darker the farther they radiate from its shimmering silk center. The spotlight motif “came from experimentation, playing with that transition from silk to wool, so it feels like one continuous ombré,” he said.

headline: Embellishments With a Serious Goal
text: More than 60 designers, including Barclay Butera, Sara Gilbane, Miles Redd and James Huniford, have created room vignettes for Design on a Dime, Housing Works’ annual benefit. There’s a party Thursday night, and starting Friday, you can shop those rooms, with prices up to 70 percent off retail. Proceeds go to Hull Street, a housing development for formerly homeless New Yorkers living with H.I.V./AIDS. Since Mr. Huniford conceived the event a decade ago, it has raised $6 million. “It was important from the beginning that the money went directly to the cause,” he said. “I always worked hard to find sponsors to pay for the operating part of it.” (This year’s sponsor is Elle Decor magazine.) The Pierre Frey table, donated by Bungalow 5, and shown in a room by Arlene Angard Designs, is $290. Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Avenue of the Americas); 347-473-7457 or housingworks.org.

headline: Discounts at Gretel Home, John Robshaw, A+R and Miraval
text: Clocks, kitchenware, textiles and many other items are up to 50 percent off at Gretel Home while supplies last (a peeler by Normann Copenhagen, regularly $17, is about $12; a Toc-Toc clock by Koziol, regularly $79, is about $55); 786-247-9003, gretelhome.com.

headline: Jewish Designers and Modernism
text: “Designing Home: Jews and Mid-Century Modernism,” opening Thursday at the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco, offers a multilayered look at the close relationship between Jewish architects and designers and the avant-garde. Curated by Donald Albrecht, the show unpacks a history of American-born and European creators, several connected to the Bauhaus, who were drawn to six nodes of progressive culture in America, including Black Mountain College in North Carolina, the Institute of Design in Chicago and Pond Farm Workshops in Northern California. Its 34 exemplars, including Henry Dreyfuss, Marcel Breuer and Anni Albers, found respectful supporters in these socially conscious institutions that fostered a network that sustained their visions. Featured are more than 120 items, including Julius Shulman’s photo of Richard Neutra’s 1946 Kaufmann House, and Alvin Lustig’s 1949 chair for Paramount Furniture. Until Oct. 6. Information: 415-655-7800 or thecjm.org.

headline: Japanese Design: Conflict in the Far East
text: Japanese furnishings have inspired legions of designers. But while most praise the simplicity of form, Joey Roth, an industrial designer based in Southern California, sees something more.

headline: Puzzled but Positive, Giants Learn Offense That Has Shades of Green Bay
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For 10 years, the Giants’ offensive system was largely unchanged, as familiar to the team’s fans as their work commutes — and, in the end, about as beloved.

headline: Operating Earnings Rise 12% at Boeing
text: Boeing said on Wednesday that its core operating earnings rose 12 percent in the first quarter, beating analysts’ expectations as the company continued to capitalize on the demand for new passenger planes.

headline: Steve Backer, a Force for Jazz at Major Labels, Dies at 76
text: Steve Backer, who ran successful jazz programs at several major record labels, shaping the careers of visionary avant-gardists like the saxophonist-composers Anthony Braxton and Henry Threadgill as well as potent crossover bands like the Brecker Brothers, died on April 10 in Englewood, N.J. He was 76.

headline: Vermont Will Require Labeling of Genetically Altered Foods
text: Going further than any state so far, Vermont on Wednesday passed a law requiring the labeling of foods that contain genetically engineered ingredients.

headline: Eastern Europe Frets About NATO’s Ability to Curb Russia
text: OVER CONSTANTA, Romania — High over the Romanian border, a sophisticated NATO surveillance plane kept a close watch on Russian movements below. Its radar screens came alive with a cat-and-mouse game between a Russian surveillance jet buzzing an American guided missile destroyer in the Black Sea and a squadron of NATO fighter jets that chased it away.

headline: As Wine Fetches Staggering Sums, Fakery Claims Rise
text: When the Atlanta wine collector Julian LeCraw Jr. spent $91,400 on a single bottle in 2006, he was convinced that the 1787 vintage from the renowned Chateau d’Yquem in France was worth the lofty price, then the highest ever for a white wine. Now, Mr. LeCraw says he has been left with the bitter aftertaste of a fake.

headline: Trying to Bolster the Image of Frozen Meals as Sales Lag
text: A NEW campaign is trying to reverse the declining sales of frozen meals in recent years.

headline: Sweeping Measure Expanding Rights of Gun Owners Is Signed Into Georgia Law
text: ATLANTA — A plan to bolster the legal rights of gun owners that opponents have derided as the “guns everywhere” bill was signed into law on Wednesday by Gov. Nathan Deal.

headline: Yanks’ Pineda Ejected After Pine Tar Is Spotted
text: BOSTON — After his start against the Boston Red Sox on April 10, Michael Pineda’s denial that his hand was covered in pine tar was mostly disregarded as absurd. Television cameras clearly showed a brown substance, and no matter what Pineda claimed afterward, people recognized it for what it was: an illegal attempt to get a better grip on the baseball.

headline: Alistair MacLeod, a Novelist in No Hurry, Dies at 77
text: Alistair MacLeod, a Canadian writer whose only novel — composed over 13 years and extracted from him only after a campaign by his publisher involving surveillance, subterfuge and outright bribery — brought him literary fame, a lucrative prize and a bottle of Scotch, died on Sunday in Windsor, Ontario. He was 77.

headline: Meet Me at the Fair
text: Let’s talk future.

headline: In Return to the Pool, Phelps Talks About Fun
text: MESA, Ariz. — Around noon Wednesday, the teenage swimming prodigy Michael Andrew met Michael Phelps, many of whose national age-group records Andrew has broken. After shaking Phelps’s hand and hearing Phelps say, “Nice to meet you,” Andrew walked away beaming. “That was pretty cool,” he said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 23, 2014
text: April 23, 2014

headline: Hynes’s Lack of Curiosity May Come at a Cost
text: Tracking the explanations of the former Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, for his office’s malpractices is like hunting a rabbit: The prey keeps bouncing here and there before disappearing under a hedgerow.

headline: Colombia’s President Reinstates a Mayor He Ousted
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Residents of this capital city may feel as if they are suffering political whiplash after President Juan Manuel Santos on Wednesday reinstated the mayor that he had removed from office only a month earlier.

headline: A Road Movie, but With No Rest Stops
text: How interesting can a film that takes place almost entirely inside a car be? The writer-director Steven Knight asked himself that question when conceiving his road movie “Locke,” which spends its 85-minute running time with just one on-screen character (Tom Hardy in the title role) as he drives to London from Birmingham and conducts phone conversations that are by turns distressing and contemplative.

headline: Strict Cost-Cutters Who Want to Spend $45 Billion on a Takeover
text: Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court.

headline: Moldova, the Next Ukraine
text: CHISINAU, Moldova — If there were an Olympic competition for bravest country in the world, the gold medal might well go to Moldova. Wobbly politicians from Europe and America should come here to get spinal transplants.

headline: Fixes for the Port Authority
text: In what is certainly a departure from standard practice, the normally secretive commissioners at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are asking publicly for advice about how to do their job.

headline: Nepal Tries to Save Season as Everest Tourists Depart
text: NEW DELHI — A delegation of government officials from Nepal’s Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation will visit the Mount Everest base camp on Thursday in an attempt to salvage the expedition season even as Sherpa mountain guides, support staff and foreign tour operators, shaken by an avalanche that killed over a dozen Nepalese guides last Friday, begin to pack up their gear and head home.

headline: Haiti in the Shadow of Cholera
text: The problem of ending Haiti’s cholera epidemic does not stem from an absence of planning. There is a 10-year plan to eradicate cholera from Hispaniola, the island Haiti shares with the Dominican Republic, by 2022. Within the 10-year plan is a two-year plan to get the 10-year plan up and running. The United Nations has its own two-year plan to support that two-year plan. To tackle the crisis immediately, with treatment, vaccinations and other prevention efforts, there was a one-year plan for last year, and a new one for 2014.

headline: Reviving Clemency, Serving Justice
text: Throughout American history, presidents from Abraham Lincoln to Harry Truman to Gerald Ford have used the power of executive clemency to help bring an end to war, or to promote national healing in its aftermath.

headline: Five Men Are Charged in a Brooklyn Beating
text: Five men who prosecutors said were associated with a Hasidic neighborhood watch group in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, were indicted on Wednesday in connection with a brutal beating of a gay black man in December.

headline: At Northwestern, a Blitz to Defeat an Effort to Unionize
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — A National Labor Relations Board official took a historic step last month in ruling that Northwestern’s scholarship football players should be considered employees of the university and therefore had the right to unionize like other workers.

headline: On Whiteboards, in Black Ink, Grim Descriptions of Those Lost as Ferry Sank
text: JINDO, South Korea — No. 150, a boy, had a snaggletooth. No. 111, a girl, was wearing pink slippers, and an elastic hairband on her right wrist. No. 87 had on pajama pants with teddy bears.

headline: Balloon Lets Builders Check Out Future Towers’ Views
text: A big white balloon appeared in New York this week. First on the Lower East Side, then uptown, where 57th Street meets the East River.

headline: Turkey Offers Condolences to Armenians Over Killings
text: ISTANBUL — For the first time, the Turkish government offered condolences on Wednesday to the descendants of Armenians who were killed by the Ottoman Army in 1915. But it stood by its official position that the events were not a genocide, as they have been called by several Western governments and international organizations.

headline: New Labor Contract Will Cost M.T.A. $525 Million
text: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo revealed to great fanfare last week that a deal on a new labor contract had been reached with New York City’s subway and bus workers, officials did not reveal how much it would cost.

headline: Contradictory Reports on North Korea’s Nuclear Preparations
text: A senior South Korean Defense Ministry official said Wednesday that North Korea “has virtually completed all preparations” it would need to conduct a nuclear test. On Tuesday, amid reports of increased activity at a nuclear test site in the North, the website 38 North, run by the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said the country appeared unlikely to conduct a nuclear test during President Obama’s visit to Seoul this weekend. Using commercial satellite imagery, it said that recent operations at Punggye-ri, a test site, had not reached the high level of intensity that occurred before past detonations. The South Korean official, who was speaking on the condition of anonymity at a news briefing, said that the United States and South Korean officials used more powerful spy satellite imagery.

headline: New York Police Twitter Strategy Has Unforeseen Consequences
text: The New York Police Department has long seen its crime-fighting strategies emulated across the country and around the world.

headline: Kenya: Bomb in Nairobi Kills Two Police Officers
text: A bomb exploded outside a police station in Nairobi on Wednesday evening, the Interior Ministry said, killing two officers. The bombing is the latest in a series of attacks to rock Kenya since last month. There have been no claims of responsibility, but many believe that Al-Shabab, a Somali Islamist group, is responsible.

headline: Wrigley Field at 100: Futility’s Friendly Confines
text: CHICAGO — For Wrigley Field’s 100th birthday, baseball’s schedule makers could have included one of the National League’s most senior franchises — the Cincinnati Reds, or the Giants, once of New York and now from San Francisco — to play the Cubs. But they settled on the Arizona Diamondbacks, an expansion team in 1998.

headline: A Place to Slip Into Something Comfortable
text: A beguilingly gentle magic whispers amid the speechifying of “Casa Valentina,” Harvey Fierstein’s prolix play about cross-dressing in the Catskills in the early 1960s. This intermittent, quiet enchantment is generated by men who otherwise tend to obstreperousness. But put any one of them in front of a mirror, with a tube of lipstick and some eyeliner, and he falls into a wordless rapture, as silent and luminous as a newly lighted candle.

headline: On the Lookout
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Stanley Newman is the editor of the nationally syndicated Newsday Crossword and the author/editor of more than 150 books. When last we saw him here in The New York Times, he was making us laugh with a quip theme inspired by his son Marc, and he’s back today with a theme that resides inside the grid.

headline: Britain: Blair Speaks Out on Islamic Extremism
text: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said Wednesday that the spread of Islamic extremism “represents the biggest threat to global security of the 21st century.” Mr. Blair, who is Middle East envoy for the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations, spoke of “a titanic struggle” going on “between those who want the region to embrace the modern world” and “those who instead want to create a politics of religious difference and exclusivity.” Mr. Blair also embraced the military government in Egypt that overthrew the elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, calling it “the absolutely necessary rescue of a nation” despite the repression that has followed.

headline: Debris Not Connected to Missing Malaysian Jet, Officials Say
text: Objects that washed ashore at a small coastal town in Western Australia have been ruled out as debris linked to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, the authorities said Thursday. The material was found on a beach more than a thousand miles from the part of the Indian Ocean where the search for the plane continues. On Wednesday, the Malaysian government said it was forming an international investigation team to assess what had happened to the plane.

headline: For Cuomo and de Blasio, Still Some Good Old Days
text: ALBANY — With disaster recovery as a backdrop, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo played exceedingly nice here on Wednesday during a daylong conference on Hurricane Sandy, adding a brief but mostly sunny chapter to New York’s most hot-and-cold political relationship.

headline: A Defiant Rancher Savors the Audience That Rallied to His Side
text: BUNKERVILLE, Nev. — Cliven Bundy stood by the Virgin River up the road from the armed checkpoint at the driveway of his ranch, signing autographs and posing for pictures. For 55 minutes, Mr. Bundy held forth to a clutch of supporters about his views on the troubled state of America — the overreaching federal government, the harassment of Western ranchers, the societal upheaval caused by abortion, even musing about whether slavery was so bad.

headline: New York City Council Seeks Bigger Police Dept. and Free School Meals
text: The New York City Council is urging Mayor Bill de Blasio to offer free lunch to all public school students, hire 1,000 more police officers and expand the summer job program for teenagers.

headline: Miller Hopes to Bring a Bit of Miami Back to Memphis
text: MEMPHIS — When Mike Miller dressed for work on Wednesday morning, he faced the usual dilemma: blue sweatpants or gray sweatpants? He went with gray.

headline: F.B.I. Informant Is Tied to Cyberattacks Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — An informant working for the F.B.I. coordinated a 2012 campaign of hundreds of cyberattacks on foreign websites, including some operated by the governments of Iran, Syria, Brazil and Pakistan, according to documents and interviews with people involved in the attacks.

headline: Finally Settled, St. Louis Has Found His Form
text: After nearly two months as a Ranger, Martin St. Louis is finally back to being Martin St. Louis. With two goals and three assists in the first three playoff games against the Philadelphia Flyers, St. Louis is back to the form that won him two N.H.L. scoring titles and a Hart Trophy as the league’s most valuable player.

headline: Red Wings’ Speed Trumped by Brains and Brawn
text: DETROIT — The narrative for the Bruins-Red Wings series was plausible and logical. Boston, the winner of the Presidents’ Trophy for the N.H.L.’s best record, would be the aggressor, using its burliness and noted agitators like Brad Marchand to set the tone. Detroit, which survived an injury-marred regular season to squeak into the playoffs as the Eastern Conference’s eighth seed, would use its youthful speed to counterattack.

headline: Forecast Cut on Spending for Health
text: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office has reduced by one-third its estimate of how much more states will spend on Medicaid in the coming decade because of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: the Oliver North Story
text: With Oliver North sharing story credit, Episode 9 finds Philip and Elizabeth finally making it onto the secret United States military base that they’ve had in their sights for months. Considering the number of people they’ve killed to get there, one hopes that their attempt to gather secrets concerning Operation Martial Eagle — the name of the show’s fictional United States military camp that trains Contras to crush Nicaragua’s Sandinista government — is successful.

headline: On a Gusty Night, the Mets Preserve a Victory With a Whirlwind Play
text: For the Mets to preserve their lead in the ninth inning of Wednesday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals, three things needed to happen over the course of about 10 seconds, Manager Terry Collins said.

headline: What Female Voters Say About Women’s Safety in Mumbai
text: While India’s financial capital has long prided itself on being relatively safe for women, the gang rape of a photojournalist in an abandoned mill building in August brought that reputation into question.

headline: Boy, 9, Is Found Dead in the Bronx
text: A 9-year-old boy was found dead on Wednesday outside a 46-story high-rise in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: A Photographer’s Tender Exploration of Fatherhood
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: F.D.A. Will Propose New Regulations for E-Cigarettes
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration will propose sweeping new rules on Thursday that for the first time would extend its regulatory authority from cigarettes to electronic cigarettes, popular nicotine delivery devices that have grown into a multibillion-dollar business with virtually no federal oversight or protections for American consumers.

headline: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
text: On the Minute, the push to regulate e-cigarettes, Northwestern’s football players to vote on a union and Amazon to stream HBO series.

headline: Word of the Day | substantive
text: substantive•\ˈsəb-stən-tiv\• adjective

headline: Why Chocolate Is Good for Us
text: This column appears in the April 27, 2014, issue of The New York Times Magazine.In recent years, large-scale epidemiological studies have found that people whose diets include dark chocolate have a lower risk of heart disease than those whose diets do not. Other research has shown that chocolate includes flavonols, natural substances that can reduce the risk of disease. But it hasn’t been clear how these flavonols could be affecting the human body, especially the heart. New findings from Virginia Tech and Louisiana State University, however, suggest an odd explanation for chocolate’s goodness: It improves health largely by being indigestible.

headline: Investors Bet on Live-Streamed Spinning Classes in the Home
text: At first blush, Peloton’s spinning classes appear little different from those at better-known outfits like SoulCycle: enthusiastic exercise buffs pedaling under pounding loud music and energetic instructor exhortations. But a session last Friday revealed something different: video cameras recording the instructor, Marion Roaman, for the benefit of customers following along at home on their Peloton bikes.

headline: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
text: In the Video

headline: Wright-Phillips’s Hat Trick Leads Red Bulls
text: Bradley Wright-Phillips scored his first goal of the Major League Soccer season, added a second before halftime and then capped his hat trick by converting a penalty kick in the second half as the Red Bulls defeated Houston Dynamo, 4-0, Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J. Wright-Phillips, 29, had not been expected to play after missing training on Tuesday with the flu.

headline: Anti-Corruption Group Finds Fault With European Union
text: BRUSSELS — A prominent anti-corruption group on Thursday plans to report serious shortcomings in the management and governance of the European Union’s core institutions, as public confidence in Brussels remains at a low before elections next month.

headline: India Election Digest: April 24
text: What you need to know about India’s parliamentary elections on Thursday: In the sixth phase of the vote, 117 seats across 11 states and the union territory of Puducherry are at stake. The regions that are going to vote: Bihar (7 seats), Madhya Pradesh (10), Assam (6), Chhattisgarh (7), Jammu and Kashmir (1), Jharkhand (4), Maharashtra (19), Rajasthan (5), Tamil Nadu (39), Uttar Pradesh (12), West Bengal (6), Puducherry (1).

headline: Ex-Head of Blue Angels Faces Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The former commanding officer of the Blue Angels naval squadron was removed from duty at a San Diego base last week after being accused of tolerating sexual harassment and hazing while in charge of the famous aviators’ group, the Navy said Wednesday.

headline: Up Close on Baseball’s Borders
text: An interactive map of the geography of baseball fandom.

headline: A Map of Baseball Nation
text: Facebook data reveals the most popular team in every ZIP code.

headline: Tainted Food in China Cited in Cyclist’s Failed Doping Test
text: An Australian cyclist who tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug has had a potential ban from the sport lifted after the sport’s governing body said he probably consumed the substance accidentally during a race in China.

headline: Report Finds Widespread Water Pollution in China
text: Nearly 60 percent of areas being monitored for water pollution last year by the government had “very poor” or “relatively poor” underground water quality, according to a report by the Chinese Ministry of Land and Resources.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 7 A.M. (Oxygen) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (James McAvoy, above, with Ms. Ronan) of a family servant — and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley) — of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. “The main casualty of the film’s long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme — and also the ingenious formal gimmick — that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “As the title suggests, ‘Atonement’ is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors.” The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianelli’s score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Tamil Nadu Warms Up to Modi and His Party
text: CHENNAI, India — It will take him 12 to 15 hours on a bus, but S. Dorai, a 38-year-old cabdriver in the capital of Tamil Nadu, said he was determined to travel to his native Kanyakumari, at the southernmost tip of India, to cast his vote on Thursday.

headline: Americans Die in Grim Trend in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three Americans were killed at a private hospital in Kabul on Thursday morning when an Afghan police officer turned his gun on them, officials said, in the latest in a string of attacks against Western civilians here.

headline: Obama Suffers Setbacks in Japan and the Mideast
text: TOKYO — President Obama encountered setbacks to two of his most cherished foreign-policy projects on Thursday, as he failed to achieve a trade deal that undergirds his strategic pivot to Asia and the Middle East peace process suffered a potentially irreparable breakdown.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 24, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Britain Moves to Prevent Young People From Joining Syrian War
text: LONDON — The British police said on Thursday that officers would work with charitable organizations to prevent British Muslims from traveling to Syria as fighters in the civil war, urging women in particular to report would-be jihadists “so that we can intervene and help.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom
text: In “Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom,” Lisa W. Foderaro writes about an unusual internship that some New York City high school students have.

headline: Mumbai’s Slum Dwellers Wary of Recycled Promises
text: MUMBAI, India – The slum dwellers who make up 60 percent of this city’s 18 million people are too diverse to vote as a bloc, but they all have one thing in common: their cramped homes, which usually lack running water and electricity.

headline: Do You Support Affirmative Action in College Admissions?
text: The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that Michigan’s ban on affirmative action at public universities was constitutional. Other states have similar bans, and more may follow suit.

headline: The Real House Candidates of Beverly Hills
text: Brent Roske lives on a 45-foot yacht off the coast of Marina del Rey, which is technically on the Pacific Ocean, but for jurisdictional purposes is considered part of the city of Los Angeles and, more to the point, the 33rd Congressional District of California. In January, Henry Waxman, the liberal stalwart who has represented the district with little resistance since the year after Roske was born, announced that he would not seek re-election. Now Roske, who is 39, is part of a field of 18 candidates hoping to represent the heartland of Beverly Hills, Malibu and Bel-Air in the United States Congress.

headline: Following the Global Armenian Diaspora
text: Scout Tufankjian recalls childhood afternoons at her grandmother’s house, paging through Armenian magazines and wondering about the people she saw in photos from all over the globe.

headline: New York Today: The Nanny Van
text: Good morning on this breezy Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Wartime Claim Paid, China Releases a Japanese Vessel
text: HONG KONG — A court in Shanghai released a Japanese commercial ship from impoundment in eastern China on Thursday, after the ship’s owner paid a civil compensation claim dating back to the wartime invasion that remains a source of bitterness in China.

headline: Russia to Start Drills, Warning Ukraine Over Mobilization
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine, government forces on Thursday revived a stalled operation to regain control by force but had little to show for their efforts other than Russian military drills on Ukraine’s border and heightened alarm about Moscow’s next move.

headline: Alstom Denies Report of G.E. Takeover Bid, but Its Shares Surge
text: Updated, 8:11 a.m. | PARIS – Shares of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom, which makes high-speed trains and energy turbines, soared on Thursday on a report that General Electric was seeking to buy the company for about $13 billion.

headline: Newlyweds on the Run: A Challenge in Reporting
text: Since March, The Times has reported on Zakia and Mohammad Ali, a young Afghan couple whose families have fought to keep them apart because of religious differences. Now, as newlyweds they are on the run, fearing for their safety. Afghan laws and customs have made coverage a challenge for the reporter Rod Nordland, the photographers Mauricio Lima and Diego Ibarra Sánchez and the video journalist Ben C. Solomon.

headline: Photos: The Relays That Never Stopped Running
text: When the Penn Relays kick off Thursday, with an expected 22,000 runners and 110,000 fans crowding into Franklin Field in Philadelphia for the three-day event, it will be held on the same site for the 120th straight year. It is quite a run, so to speak, for an event that started as a single relay and was aimed at keeping the University of Pennsylvania’s track team from falling into oblivion.

headline: Offering Thanks to China’s Business Groundbreakers
text: In the Phoenix airport, en route to China, I recently had an encounter with a reader of this blog.

headline: Bieber Apology Over Shrine Visit Falls Flat in China
text: Even after his apology for posting photos of himself visiting the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, which honors thousands of Japan’s military dead but also Class A war criminals, Justin Bieber remains a target of outrage in China.

headline: Trying to Bring Baldwin’s Complex Voice Back to the Classroom
text: James Baldwin’s 1953 novel, “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” about a Harlem teenager’s search for meaning, quickly became a classic, along with his searing essays about race published a decade later in the book “The Fire Next Time.” But in recent years Baldwin’s presence has diminished in many high school classrooms.

headline: Daily Report: F.C.C. to Propose a Web Fast Lane
text: The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Hurt by Vehicle Recalls, G.M.’s Profit Falls 85%
text: DETROIT — General Motors, the nation’s largest automaker, reported on Thursday that its net income in the first quarter fell about 85 percent, mostly because of costs associated with the recalls of millions of vehicles.

headline: The Cloud Industry Needs Aereo to Win. But Consumers Need Something Better.
text: The best way to think about Aereo, the company at the center of this week’s Supreme Court battle over the future of computing, is as an example of legal performance art. Aereo is based entirely on a legalistic leap of faith: If it’s legal to set up an antenna and record a TV show at your own house, which it is, shouldn’t it also be legal to rent an antenna and server space at a big data center, and then stream the show over the Internet to your computer, tablet or set-top box?

headline: Cutting Costs and Plotting Mergers
text: “Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. “The building was previously home to a Y.M.C.A, which deemed it too run-down to host community activities. So when the Y.M.C.A. moved to a new building, Valeant moved in.”

headline: Bare Knuckles at Sotheby’s Auction House
text: Updated, 9:24 p.m. | Directors of Sotheby’s gathered in their wood-paneled boardroom with an urgent goal: how to mollify Daniel S. Loeb, the outspoken hedge fund mogul who is the auction house’s largest shareholder.

headline: CreatureCast: Cuttlefish Camouflage
text: Cuttlefish can alter their color, texture, and apparent shape. This extraordinary camouflage allows them to hide in plain sight against many different backgrounds.

headline: A Cloak of Near Invisibility in an Underwater World
text: For many animals, being noticed can mean being eaten or scaring away a would-be meal. From the tiger’s stripes to the snowy owl’s downy white feathers, camouflage allows animals to hide in plain sight and avoid these perils. But camouflage is often about more than color. Some animals have skin texture that matches the texture of their environment. Other animals have shapes that make it hard to spot the outlines of their bodies.

headline: Most Wanted and Most Haunted
text: A half-century ago this week, the 1964 World’s Fair opened in Flushing Meadows, Queens. With Belgian waffles, Michelangelo’s “Pietà” and a Tent of Tomorrow, the event was a last postwar blast of guilt-free consumption, Sunday school piety and faith in the future as a good place to be. It was also the scene of a smashup in progress, as the America of the 1950s ran into the 1960s.

headline: Plan to Sell Condoms in Schools Encounters Resistance
text: Officials in Xi’an, the capital of Shaanxi Province, want secondary schools to sell condoms on campus to help combat the spread of H.I.V./AIDS, stirring a heated controversy among parents and educators.

headline: Companies Back Initiative to Support OpenSSL and Other Open-Source Projects
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The nonprofit Linux Foundation and more than a dozen prominent technology companies are to announce an initiative on Thursday to fund crucial open-source projects.

headline: K.K.R. Profit Falls, but Tops Estimates
text: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reaped gains in the first quarter from selling some of its investments, reporting profit that beat expectations on Thursday.

headline: Darren Aronofsky on Floods, Fanaticism, the Big Bang, Warming and More
text: I hope you’ll take 40 minutes to catch my onstage interview on Tuesday with Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker known for his obsession with obsession, whether it’s in a mathematician, ballerina or — most recently — Noah. Also weighing in at the capping event at The Times’s Cities For Tomorrow meeting was Ari Handel, Aronofsky’s co-writer on “Noah,” “Black Swan” and “The Fountain” (and a neuroscientist).

headline: Zimmer Holdings to Buy Biomet for $13.35 Billion
text: Updated, 8:47 p.m. | Health care costs are rising as America’s population ages. More people are opting to pay for elective procedures as the economy gradually improves. And the Affordable Care Act is prompting some health care companies to find safety by scaling up.

headline: The Times Co. Reports a 2.6% Rise in Revenue
text: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that its first-quarter revenue rose from a year ago, with an increase in advertising sales and the addition of digital subscribers, but quarterly profit declined because of spending on growth initiatives.

text: Economists talking inequality.

headline: Art Matters | An L.A. Fair Explores the Possibilities of Photography
text: For proof that photography can open your world, look no further than the boundary-pushing second edition of Paris Photo Los Angeles, which runs from Friday to Sunday at Paramount Pictures Studios. Like the medium itself — which freed experience from geography and time, so that viewers no longer had to actually be there in order to see something happen — the very structure of the event is a paean to fluidity. The art fair started 17 years ago in Paris and now has an annual outpost in Los Angeles on a backlot replica of New York City. “The history of photography is made of ambiguity,” says the event’s director, Julien Frydman. “If you look at photography as a self-contained medium you lose 50 percent of it, maybe more. Photography is nourished by other forms of art and in dialogue with other forms of art.”

headline: U.S. Plan for Internet Fast Lanes Contrasts With European Rules
text: LONDON — The battle over whether Internet content should be treated equally is heating up.

headline: On Gattopardo Economics
text: FT Alphaville sends us to Thomas Palley on Piketty and his boosters. Palley raises an interesting point, one that I’m hearing from some other people on the left: they’re disappointed that Piketty’s book relies mainly on conventional, mainstream economics.

headline: In Our Pages: April 25
text: 1914: Blast in Nuevo Laredo

headline: A Ticket to Fame, With Relish
text: JOHN, an inebriated panhandler with a voice pitched somewhere between Harvey Fierstein’s and a dental drill, sprawled recently on the patio of Nathan’s Famous in Coney Island. He delivered a monologue at top volume while, at the next table, Lloyd Handwerker, a grandson of Nathan Handwerker, who founded the place in 1916, tried telling me about “Famous Nathan,” the documentary he made about his grandpa, showing on Friday and Saturday at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Salutation’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “The Salutation” by Thomas Traherne and the Well blog post “Ah, There’s Nothing Like New Baby Smell” by Douglas Quenqua.

headline: The Downside of Registering Outrage
text: Should the United States be devoting so much effort to criticizing the anti-Semitic fliers that appeared last week in Ukraine?

headline: Thinking of Requesting a Specific Teacher for Your Child? Think Twice
text: Dear Mrs. Lahey,

headline: Angus Davis of Swipely, on Working Around Flaws
text: This interview with Angus Davis, chief executive of Swipely, which sells customer-related software to merchants, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Three Shot Dead at Kabul Hospital
text: Witnesses describe the scene after three Americans were shot dead at a hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, by an Afghan police officer.

headline: India’s Weather Agency Forecasts Weaker Monsoon
text: NEW DELHI — As political pundits predict a change of administrations in Delhi after these elections, India’s weather forecasters are already identifying what could be the first serious challenge for a new government — a possible agricultural crisis in the form of a weak monsoon.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Stop ‘I Spy’ Game With Allies
text: We will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission. As we go, we’re tagging them all “editorial winner” so that you can find them all here.

headline: Nine Playwrights to Attend Sundance Theater Lab
text: Nine playwrights have been selected to participate in the Sundance Institute’s 2014 Theater Lab, the institute announced on Thursday. The lab, one of 10 overseen by Sundance, runs from July 7 to 27 at Sundance’s resort in Utah. The playwrights, who are given fellowships based on specific projects, are provided with rehearsal space, an acting company, dramaturges and creative advisers to help them hone their works. The program is overseen by Philip Himberg, the artistic director, and Christopher Hibma, the producing director.

headline: Even After Setbacks, a Musician Insists That the Show Will Go On
text: Hamiet Bluiett should not have even shown up, let alone picked up his musical instrument. He’s had two strokes in the past two months and his doctors have urged him to take it easy.

headline: Israel Halts Talks, Citing Palestinian Unity Agreement
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government decided on Thursday to suspend American-brokered peace talks with the Palestinians because of the agreement the Palestinians announced on Wednesday between two rival factions, one of which refuses to recognize Israel’s right to exist.

headline: Memories of Religious Riots Overshadow Vote in Bihar
text: BHAGALPUR, India – An eruption of religious violence in this district nearly 25 years ago, some of the worst that independent India has seen, weighed on the minds of Muslim voters as they prepared for Thursday’s vote.

headline: Berlin Philharmonic Starts Its Own Record Label
text: The Berlin Philharmonic has long been associated with some of the most prestigious labels in what was once called the record industry — from Deutsche Grammophon, which released a box set last year celebrating a century of its recordings with the orchestra, to Sony, which helped launch the CD era with its recordings of Herbert von Karajan conducting it.

headline: Are Med School Grads Prepared to Practice Medicine?
text: One night early in my internship, I received a frantic page for help from a fellow intern.

headline: Happenings | Designer Miles Redd Channels Matisse for a Worthy Cause
text: For the last 10 years, the New York-based organization Housing Works has been raising money for people who have H.I.V./AIDS by selling consignment clothing and furniture through its high-end nonprofit thrift stores. For six of those years, the designer Miles Redd, the former creative director of Oscar de la Renta Home, has lent his time and talent to the organization’s annual Design on a Dime benefit by assembling entire rooms from donated merchandise, all of which is sold at the event.

headline: Looking for Stories of Non-College-Bound Kids
text: In last week’s Open Thread, a reader asked:

headline: Seven Works Attributed to Banksy to Be Auctioned
text: LONDON — Seven artworks attributed to the street artist Banksy will go on display at the Me London Hotel  until Sunday, before being sold at auction. The works have been removed from public walls and buildings by the Sincura Group, which previously organized the removal and sale of Banksy’s “Slave Labor.” The Sincura Group, described on its own website as “market leaders in V.I.P. concierge, lifestyle, tickets and events,” will auction the works on April 27. Tony Baxter, the director of Sincura, said in a statement that the group does not “steal art, nor do we condone any acts of wanted vandalism or theft.”

headline: Attending Vanity Fair Party, de Blasio Navigates New Terrain: The Red Carpet
text: Flashbulbs popped as Anna Wintour greeted Robert De Niro and Harvey Weinstein. Courteney Cox and Christy Turlington caught up by the bar. John McEnroe and Ron Howard posed for pictures nearby.

headline: Daley, Former White House Chief of Staff, Joins Hedge Fund
text: William M. Daley, a former White House chief of staff, has joined an upstart hedge fund based in Switzerland in a return to the financial industry.

headline: How Can the Opinions of 1,000 People Possibly Represent the Entire Country?
text: Every member of the population has to have an equal or at least a known chance of being chosen for a survey.

headline: Clintons Again Pick Long Island for an August Vacation
text: It is hard to have a laid-back vacation when you are Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, but the former first couple have chosen the comparatively low-key Long Island beach town of Amagansett for their August break.

headline: Co-Founders of Pussy Riot to Appear at Frieze Art Fair
text: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, two of the unmasked founders of Pussy Riot, will appear at the Frieze Art Fair next month in New York, in conversation with the New Yorker editor David Remnick, organizers announced on Thursday.

headline: The Autumn of a Patriarch
text: CHENNAI, India — On Monday evening, Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the 89-year-old chief of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam, arrived in Anna Nagar, a middle-class neighborhood here, to speak at an election rally. Mr. Karunanidhi was campaigning for Dayanidhi Maran, his grandnephew.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Kate McKinnon
text: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: For Women in Tech, Pay Gap Is Unusually Small
text: Technology, with its bro culture, has not been a particularly welcoming profession for women. So it is surprising that in the tech sector, the pay gap between women and men is one of the smallest.

headline: Voting Fraud Hangs Stubbornly Over Afghan Elections, With Runoff Likely
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ahmed Zia proudly recalled how he voted in the Afghan presidential election on April 5, for the first time in his 18 years.

headline: Matthew Weiner: By the Book
text: The creator of “Mad Men” cites the impact of John Cheever’s fiction on the show: “Cheever has a voice filled with irony and comedy and pain that, on some level, I’m always seeking to emulate.”

headline: From an Apple a Day to ‘Energy Balance’ in Cancer Research
text: In my recent Raw Data column about whether fruits and vegetables are crucial to avoiding cancer, I referred to two thick reports, published in 1997 and 2007 by the American Institute for Cancer Research and its affiliate, the World Cancer Research Fund. Sitting side by side on my desk, the books look similar: One cover is blue and the other green, and both are adorned with images of fruits, vegetables, legumes and grains interspersed with people working and playing, all apparently enjoying good health. Presiding over the scene is an image of Mother Earth.

headline: Barclays Shareholders Vent Frustration Over Bonuses
text: LONDON – For nearly three hours on Thursday, shareholders of Barclays aired their grievances with the British bank’s top management, ranging from complaints about the security of debit cards to the length of the lines to get into its annual meeting.

headline: Dodge Viper Repair Requires Mechanics With Small Hands
text: Nearly 3,700 owners of 2003-4 Dodge Vipers have been waiting 14 months for a recall intended to prevent the air bags from deploying without an accident. Chrysler is now ready to make the repair, but owners should hope the dealership has a mechanic with small hands.

headline: A Little Night Snorkeling
text: Scuba divers have long had the opportunity to see nocturnal creatures living among reefs by taking night dive excursions. Now snorkelers can try it too.

headline: Rancher’s Views on Race Send Supporters Fleeing

headline: An iPhone Engineer-Turned-Game Maker Shares His Apple Story
text: When Francisco Tolmasky was just 20 years old and started working for Apple, he took on a challenging task: to create a rich mobile web browser for the original iPhone, back when the device was still a pile of circuits.

headline: That Little Lost Boy in Red, Back With His Family
text: Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuñiga, the little red-suited boy in the Metropolitan Museum’s prize Goya portrait, died in childhood while his parents were still living. But in the Met’s European Paintings galleries, he has long been an orphan, separated from his mother, whose portrait traditionally hangs in the museum’s Robert Lehman wing, and his father, in Spain.

headline: Searching for Poetry in Prose
text: Create your own blackout poem from a recent New York Times story.

headline: After Blast, East Harlem Tenants Are Worried About Dust
text: In Minerva Mendoza’s fourth-floor apartment at 89 East 116th Street in East Harlem, there is tan dust in the cabinets, in the refrigerator and on the floor. Dust covers her 17-year-old son’s television stand, her younger children’s bunk beds and a stroller folded against the wall. The family comes to the apartment to grab things they need, but they live in a nearby apartment provided by the New York City Department of Homeless Services.

headline: Recognizing Outstanding Photojournalism Overseas

headline: Legal Memo Defends Ackman’s Actions in Allergan Bid
text: In the wake of this week’s unusual hostile bid for Allergan, one of the most pressing questions has been whether William A. Ackman, the activist investor who runs Pershing Square Capital Management, engaged in insider trading.

headline: Gorilla Birth Alert!
text: The Bronx Zoo’s gorilla forest was the site of not one but two blessed events recently: Julia, a 33-year-old western lowland gorilla, had a baby on March 10. Her colleague Tuti, 19, gave birth just last Thursday.

headline: Why the Housing Market Is Still Stalling the Economy

headline: Opera Philadelphia to Take On Andy Warhol

The company’s plans for 2015 also include “ANDY: A Popera,” a work about Andy Warhol with music by Heath Allen, a Philadelphia composer and pianist.

headline: Snapping Good Photos With Your Phone
text: Every family has its designated vacation photographer, so it was, to put it mildly, a moment of sheer horror when I arrived at the Naples airport last summer with my wife and two children for a brief stay on the Amalfi Coast and realized that I had forgotten my camera.

headline: Digital Mapping May Be Nokia’s Hidden Jewel
text: BERLIN — For the first time in more than three decades, Nokia faces the future without being a player in the global phone business. On Friday, the company completes the sale of its beleaguered handset business to Microsoft for $7.5 billion.

headline: Things Aren’t Always What They Seem
text: The avocado is still warm from the oven, under improbable layers of puffed rice, yogurt spiked with fermented chile and a brawl of bonito flakes jittery with heat. It has been roasted briefly, enough to absorb some smoke, and with the scaffolding of crunch, cream and brine, it suggests an extraterrestrial’s brilliant mistranslation of a baked potato.

headline: New Tool to Fight Deadly Tsetse Fly
text: After 10 years of effort, a team led by scientists at Yale has finally decoded the genes of the tsetse fly, a bloodsucking scourge of Africa.

headline: Asked and Answered: Commenting on Your Comments
text: Readers are passionate about their comments on NYTimes.com. Last week on Times Insider, Bassey Etim, the community manager for The Times, explained the guidelines for moderating reader comments. Predictably, his piece drew many comments and questions. Here is a selection of your questions and Mr. Etim’s answers. They have been condensed and edited.

headline: Musical Surprises: Beethoven
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludwig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 13 in C minor, “Pathetique.”

headline: More ‘Pinocchios’ for the Koch Brothers, Please
text: The health care ads being run by Americans for Prosperity — one of the many frantically waving arms of the Koch brothers — are a gift to fact checkers everywhere. Because they deliberately twist the truth to persuade people to “stop supporting Obamacare,” they have become a machine for producing “Pinocchios,” the mendacity rating system used by Glenn Kessler at The Washington Post.

headline: Musical Surprises: Beethoven
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludvig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 31 in A-flat, Op. 110.

headline: Prosecutors Cite Stowage and Design in Korean Disaster
text: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors on Thursday officially attributed the sinking of a South Korean ferry to an improper stowage of cargo and a loss of stability caused by a change in the vessel’s design.

headline: Musical Surprises: Debussy
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Claude Debussy’s “Golliwog’s Cakewalk.”

headline: Radetsky to Depart American Ballet Theater
text: Sascha Radetsky’s performance as Franz in the American Ballet Theater’s production of “Coppélia” at the Metropolitan Opera House on July 3 will be his farewell to the troupe, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Radetsky, 37, joined the American Ballet Theater as an apprentice in 1995, became a member of its corps de ballet the following year, and has been a soloist since 2003.

headline: Recognizing Outstanding Photojournalism Overseas
text: Tyler Hicks of The New York Times has won the Robert Capa gold medal from the Overseas Press Club for the “best published photographic reporting from abroad requiring exceptional courage and enterprise.”  The award was given to him in recognition of his coverage of the Nairobi mall terrorist attack last September.

headline: A ‘Corporate Raider’ Tries to Correct the Record
text: In 1985, T. Boone Pickens, a force in the burgeoning business of hostile takeovers, appeared on the cover of Time magazine. He was fresh off an audacious tender offer for Gulf Oil, and the cover illustration showed him playing poker with oil derricks printed on the cards.

headline: American Journalist Released by Ukraine Separatists
text: Separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine released the American journalist Simon Ostrovsky on Thursday, three days after he was taken prisoner in the town of Slovyansk while filming a video report for Vice News. The Brooklyn-based news organization confirmed his release in a statement, which was followed by a tweet from the correspondent.

headline: Investors Enthusiastic About Zimmer’s Deal for Rival
text: American investors are seeing yet another big acquisition. Zimmer Holdings promises that its $13.4 billion deal for its rival, Biomet, will yield savings.

headline: United Nations Report on Delivery of Humanitarian Relief in Syria
text: A report that is part of the United Nations’ assessment of how the Syrian government and rebels have complied with a Security Council resolution ordering them to allow humanitarian aid to enter besieged towns.

headline: U.N. Finds Humanitarian Aid Still Blocked in Syria, Despite Resolution
text: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have no access to medical supplies because the warring sides in the country’s civil war are blocking humanitarian relief, according to an advance copy of a report from the United Nations secretary general.

headline: Google Plus Boss Vic Gundotra Leaving Google
text: UpdatedVic Gundotra, Google’s senior vice president for social and one of the creators of Google Plus, is leaving the Googleplex.

headline: Moments from Obama’s Visit to Japan
text: President Obama kicked off his Asia tour in Japan, meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Emperor Akihito to improve relations in the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Dial Down Your Anger
text: I had a friend for 30 years who lives three blocks away from me. In 2011, I became seriously ill and fell into a coma. She was in touch with my husband by email and knew about my condition, but never followed up to see how I was doing or even if I was still alive. I was devastated by this and cannot forgive her. I keep hoping to run into her in the neighborhood to tell her how I feel so I can move past it, but that has yet to occur. What should I do?

headline: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss
text: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.

headline: Folk Art Museum to Open Queens Annex
text: Ever since the Museum of Modern Art announced that it was going to raze its next-door neighbor, the former home of the American Folk Art Museum, the building has been getting more attention than the Folk Art museum itself. But now that museum has news of its own. The American Folk Art Museum is opening an annex for its collection and library in Queens, near the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center in Long Island City.

headline: Next time you’re at Citizens Bank Park, remember, it’s a hoagie you want.
text: What are you really capturing when you make a map of baseball fans on Facebook, as we did earlier today? It’s something more than just the number of Likes sorted by ZIP code. It’s relationships between things we never saw before. Take the map here, which mashes up the Mets/Phillies rivalry border with the border between people who say “sub” and people who say “hoagie.” Our dialect quiz last year found a significant regional difference. The dividing lines are pretty much the same.

headline: Photos: Buy Me Some Pine Tar and Cracker Jack
text: Billy Martin had one of the best eyes in baseball for catching people who were potentially up to no good.

headline: Ultra Violet, Pop Artist, Has Exhibition at Dillon Gallery
text: The Miser is away enjoying warmer climes, so we rifled through his inbox and found a couple of thrifty activities for the weekend.

headline: When the Seven Sisters Had a Bigger Welcome Mat
text: The Times will soon convert all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. (Nonsearchable images of every New York Times newspaper published before Dec. 31, 1980, can be seen in full on the Times Machine.)

headline: The Gun Report: April 24, 2014
text: Federal funding for research on gun violence has been frozen since 1996. Shortly after Newtown, President Obama urged Congress to allocate $10 million for new research, but Republicans in Congress recently refused, likening the effort to “funding propaganda.”

headline: My Illness, the Third Partner in Our Relationship
text: She was my professor. I was her graduate student. She was 17 years my senior, with a husband and children. And she risked it all to be by my side and in my bed as I closed in on a kidney transplant.

headline: Feeling For | In Madrid, An All-Organic Menu Meets Striking, Surrealist Design
text: When Manolo Yllera first told me last year that he was opening a market and restaurant in Madrid, I had an inkling that the Spanish interiors photographer would create something worthy of any lens. And of course Mama Campo is the kind of bright, airy and quirky place that could only be brought to life by a set of hands belonging to a person with a good eye for design.

headline: Yankees Get Sloppy Win; Pineda Gets Suspension
text: BOSTON — The mess that was smeared across Michael Pineda’s neck on Wednesday was nothing compared with the slop that was on display at Fenway Park one night later. The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox resumed their rivalry Thursday minus the controversy about the pine tar that Pineda applied to his neck, but the game was one of the worst played in the major leagues this season.

headline: The New York Athletic Club: A Proud Sponsor of Meb Keflezighi
text: When Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon at age 38 Monday, the logo of his shoe sponsor, Skechers, was not the only unusual symbol he was wearing. Ironed onto his red and white jersey was the winged foot of the elite New York Athletic Club, a rare sight these days in the lead pack of major marathons, which are usually dominated by swooshes and stripes.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: pricey pills, high altitudes and avocados. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
The Office Space We Love to Hate
text: “The white-collar people slipped quietly into modern society,” C. Wright Mills writes in “White Collar” (1951), his classic sociology text, as if he were describing a race of wan termites. Nikil Saval’s excellent new book, “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace,” was inspired by Mills’s book, and it’s a fresh and intellectually omnivorous extension of its themes.

headline: Senate Panel Faults Ex-Homeland Security Watchdog for Failing to Be Independent
text: WASHINGTON — A Senate subcommittee has found that the official who served as the Department of Homeland Security’s acting inspector general from 2011 to 2013 “jeopardized the independence” of his office by delaying reports and alerting department officials about their contents.

headline: James Earl Jones to Star on Broadway in ‘You Can’t Take It With You’
text: James Earl Jones will star in a Broadway revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy “You Can’t Take It With You” beginning in August, with Scott Ellis on board to direct, the producers of the show announced on Thursday.

headline: Bourbon’s Affinity for Ginger
text: We all know how well fresh mint goes with bourbon. Sean Josephs, one of our panelists, opened my eyes (and palate) to bourbon’s affinity for ginger. The Nor’easter he serves at Maysville and Char No. 4 is a simple, lightly sweetened example of bourbon and lime, topped off with a splash of ginger beer. On the same wavelength, at Philip Marie in Greenwich Village, there’s the Bufala Negra, a bourbon drink seasoned with balsamic vinegar and finished with ginger beer, a slight variation on the original made with balsamic syrup and ginger ale, which was created by Jerry Slater of H Harper Station in Atlanta.

headline: Tarantino’s Infringement Lawsuit Against Gawker Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge has agreed to dismiss a lawsuit by the director Quentin Tarantino that accused Gawker Media of helping to leak his unpublished script, “The Hateful Eight.”

headline: China’s Legislature Votes to Toughen Environmental Protection Law
text: BEIJING — The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the country’s environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: A Maine Lighthouse Welcomes Guests
text: For the first time, the Cuckolds — a pair of granite islands a half mile off the coast of Southport Island, Maine — will be open to guests for overnight stays beginning June 27.

headline: Oregon Panel Recommends Switch to Federal Health Exchange
text: WASHINGTON — With encouragement from the Obama administration, an Oregon panel recommended Thursday that the state scrap the website for its beleaguered health insurance exchange and use the federal marketplace instead.

headline: Phelps Finishes Second in Return, and Winner Is Glad He’s Back
text: MESA, Ariz. — Michael Phelps’s possible pursuit of a fifth Olympics has the swimming world abuzz, but first things first. Before Phelps could entertain thoughts of defending his 100-meter butterfly title in Brazil, there was the matter of qualifying for the national championships in Southern California in August.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Blue Ruin’
text: The writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film featuring Macon Blair.

headline: Climbers Leave Everest Amid Regrets and Tensions Among Sherpas
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Climbers who had hoped to reach the summit of Mount Everest have instead begun the long journey home: a teenager with epilepsy who wanted to inspire others like himself; a banker who quit his job, sold his apartment and used up most of his savings to pay for the trip; a builder from California who was carrying the ashes of his younger brother.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Blue Ruin’
text: In this video, the writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his revenge thriller “Blue Ruin,” starring his best friend Macon Blair. He discusses a getaway that doesn’t quite go the way his protagonist would have hoped.

headline: Video of Rancher Cliven Bundy’s Remarks on Race
text: As my colleague Adam Nagourney reports, on Saturday the Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy veered away from his fight with the federal government to share his views on race, slavery and abortion in remarks to supporters and journalists at a news conference.

headline: Tech Giants Settle Antitrust Hiring Suit
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The workers of Silicon Valley have won an important victory over their bosses. What they did not win is a lot of money.

headline: Nothing to Cheer About
text: It has become possible, these past several decades, to think of Duke as consisting of a professional basketball team to which, bizarrely, a research university has attached itself. But it is the “non­revenue” sports at Duke — and the school’s relentless, aggressive and very expensive campaign to build them into powerhouse brands — that have most radically changed the tenor of that campus. The strange centrality of the athletic program in the life of an academically excellent institution, and the many unintended consequences this situation has wrought, is the subject of William D. Cohan’s “The Price of Silence: The Duke Lacrosse Scandal, the Power of the Elite, and the Corruption of Our Great Universities.” The book is at once a masterwork of reporting and a devastating critique of a university that has lost its way.

headline: Bourbon’s Masters of the Craft
text: With the approach of the Kentucky Derby, you can bet a lot of bourbon will be consumed. Nowadays, that’s nothing new.

headline: Caroline Kennedy Says She Will Back Hillary Clinton in a Run for President
text: Caroline Kennedy, whose endorsement of Barack Obama in 2008 was a major setback for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, as well as a personal blow, said Thursday that she would “absolutely” support Mrs. Clinton should she decide to run for president again.

headline: Eyes on the Prize
text: Big Supreme Court cases produce big books: “Gideon’s Trumpet,” “Simple Justice.” On June 26, 2013, the Supreme Court decided two big ­cases. In United States v. Windsor, it struck down a part of the federal Defense of Marriage Act as unconstitutional, while in Hollingsworth v. Perry it sidestepped the challenge to California’s anti-gay-marriage Proposition 8 on a technicality, leaving the trial court’s original ruling — that Prop 8 was unconstitutional — in effect.

headline: Massachusetts Maverick
text: A couple of months ago, on Connecticut Avenue not far from the White House, I passed a crowd of 20-somethings wearing distressed denim and hoodies. They looked more Williamsburg than Washington and carried placards that read: “I’m from the Elizabeth Warren wing of the party.”

headline: Mind Over Matter: Mastering Daunting Moves
text: OVERACHIEVERS, beware: In the pursuit of a challenging sport or discipline, there will come a time when you confront a move that your mind embraces but your body protests.

headline: The Dumb Jock Stereotype Can Be a Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
text: Social scientists know that in research studies, minority and female students appear to be vulnerable to the phenomenon called “stereotype threat.” Aware that the group to which they belong is often stereotyped as intellectually inferior, their anxiety that a poor showing on a test will confirm the stereotype actually depresses their performance on the test, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.

headline: A Law and the Face of the City
text: On May 19th, it will be 35 years since Grace Gold, a Barnard College freshman, was struck and killed by a falling piece of masonry at 115th Street and Broadway. Her death sparked in 1980 what was then called Local Law 10, requiring facade inspections. Preservationists warned that wholesale stripping of architectural ornament would result. A survey of Upper West Side buildings in 1993 and today indicates otherwise.

headline: Amazon’s Revenue Grew 23 Percent in First Quarter, Nearing $20 Billion
text: Amazon defines corporate prosperity in terms of sales growth rather than profit. By its definition, which has been embraced on Wall Street, the big Internet merchant had a strong first quarter.

headline: Two 40-Year-Olds Set Example for the Mets
text: The repetitive number pairing 40-40 typically refers to one of baseball’s greatest single-season achievements — hitting 40 home runs and stealing 40 bases. The feat has been accomplished by only four players, all in the primes of their careers.

headline: Officials on Suspended Talks in Mideast

headline: No, Obama Didn’t Win One-Third of White Voters in Deep South
text: This morning, I published an article on the decline of Democratic support among white Southerners from West Texas to the Atlantic Coast. In that region, Mitt Romney often won by margins so large that they rivaled President Obama’s advantage among black voters. Larry Bartels, writing for The Washington Post’s Monkey Cage blog, disputes my argument and claims Mr. Obama had widespread white support in the south.

headline: A Rocket Is Aimed at Detroit (Run! Jump!)
text: As is not uncommon with movies of this kind, a certain amount of the dialogue in “Brick Mansions” consists of excited elaborations of the obvious, perhaps for the benefit of viewers who missed something while texting or dozing. During a foot chase, when the pursued parties have succeeded in locking a door from the outside, one of the pursuers remarks, “They locked the door from the outside!” In the midst of a later chase (there are a lot of them), when the guys who locked that door are hiding on an abandoned school bus, someone shouts, “They’re on the bus!” And when it is revealed that one of the chief villains is in possession of a military-grade rocket, the strangeness of this fact does not go unnoticed: “Only a crazy person would have a rocket!”

headline: California Senate Rejects Smartphone ‘Kill Switch’ Law
text: The California Senate on Thursday voted down a state measure that would require smarter antitheft security on smartphones.

headline: Nets’ Bench Is Taking Back Seat in Playoffs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Toronto Raptors were more precise in distributing the minutes of their reserves in their Game 2 victory over the Nets on Tuesday night, resulting in greater contributions from a smaller pool of players.

headline: Global Entry and Company: Worth the Price?
text: Time versus money — there’s no more fundamental trade-off in budget travel. Nonstop or layover, taxi or public bus? Stand in line for half-price theater tickets or buy full-price at the click of a mouse?
