headline: More Public Art for Governors Island
text: When a new 30-acre park opens at the southern end of Governors Island on May 24, it will boast a grove of hammocks, two ball fields, a formal garden and play areas with climbable structures and spray showers. It will also be part of an ambitious backdrop for a new public art program taking shape on this 172-acre island, the former Army and Coast Guard base in New York Harbor. The city took control of Governors Island in 2010, and each year there’s more to do and see, attracting thousands of visitors during the summer months.

headline: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor
text: The title of “The Quiet Ones,” the latest horror movie about supernatural doings set in the 1970s, is explained fairly late. By then its director, John Pogue, has made a modest racket with the usual bumps in the night, some cackling and screaming, a bit of door slamming and table knocking. A fair amount of this noise seems to emanate from Jane Harper (Olivia Cooke), a hollow-eyed young patient of Professor Coupland (Jared Harris). An Oxford University lecturer, Coupland believes that the supernatural occurrences in Jane’s bleak, lonely life have been created by her mind and is using every bad idea he has — including curing her through sleep deprivation — to prove it.

headline: Letters: Another Look
text: Another Look

headline: Tracking Future and Hip-Hop’s Growlers
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the rapper Future and the evolution of vocal style in hip-hop.

headline: Slavery Nostalgia Is Real, and It’s Dangerous
text: Northerners may be a little shocked that anyone could feel a bit nostalgic for slavery, in the manner of the government-hating Nevada rancher, Cliven Bundy. But in the South, such sentiments are hardly unheard of, even if they are usually muttered in private over a few bourbons rather than spoken at a news conference.

headline: Current Events Imperil Ukrainian Museum Show
text: Works by the 19th-century Ukrainian poet and painter Taras Shevchenko are tentatively scheduled to arrive in Manhattan next week, in time for a retrospective opening May 11 at the Ukrainian Museum. But fingers are crossed.

headline: Mom, That Fugitive Nazi Is Making Eyes at Me
text: The quietly jittery art house thriller “The German Doctor” opens in Patagonia in 1960, with a man watching a group of girls playing along a dusty road. Coolly, he zeros in on one child with long, blond hair, his light, clear eyes tracking her as she awkwardly scrambles into her family’s car. He trails after her, pleasantries are exchanged, and the man, who’s moving to a nearby town, arranges to follow the family in his car. Soon after they hit the road, he is murmuring in German, and there’s no doubt that Helmut Gregor (Alex Brendemühl, suave and unnerving), as he calls himself, is no ordinary stranger. Not too long after, he’s setting up an office and measuring the girl’s head.

headline: Microsoft’s Profit Dips Less Than Expected as It Reshapes Itself
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft on Thursday again demonstrated its gift for weathering the turmoil in the personal computer industry, turning in solid financial results for a company playing catch-up in several important markets.

text: The expiration of a federal tax exemption for forgiven mortgage debt appears to be scaring borrowers away from pursuing short sales.

headline: Prickly but Puppyish in San Francisco
text: Youth, they say, is wasted on the young, but it wasn’t on the five artists featured in “Energy That Is All Around: Mission School,” an exhibition at the Grey Art Gallery that bristles infectiously with youthful urgency.

text: Poisons: Scientists condemn a new F.D.A. study claiming BPA, a chemical present in certain plastics, is safe, saying it borders on scientific misconduct.

text: There’s a mirror on a wall and a stepmother who wants to look younger than her daughter. Is it just another day in the life of a dressing room at Forever 21, or Angelin Preljocaj’s version of “Snow White”?

headline: No Time for Audiobooks: He’s on the Road to His Destiny
text: A truism about cinema and television, two tributaries that increasingly flow into one image stream, is that together they have turned the human face into our favorite destination spot. The ubiquity of close-ups, particularly in broadcast television, with its parade of bobbling heads and babbling mouths, could have drained movie faces of their power. Yet we can’t seem to get enough of other people’s faces, whether they’re as frozen as masks or changeable as churning water. We trace stories across these familiar landscapes, becoming geographers of emotion.

headline: Humanity and Hope in a Southern Prison
text: For more than the obvious reasons, Civil War soldiers in both armies despised military prisons. Not only were the inmates held against their will, but the hunger, filth, vermin, rampant disease, overcrowding, brutal treatment and soul-crushing ennui made prison camps slaughterhouses of slow death. Andersonville, the infamous Georgia prison, was the ultimate abattoir; during the summer of 1864 nearly one in three Union inmates died. In other Confederate prisons, the average mortality rate was 15.5 percent; in Union prisons, 12 percent.

headline: Aftermath of Ukraine Photo Story Shows Need for More Caution
text: The Times led its print edition Monday with an article based in part on photographs that the State Department said were evidence of Russian military presence in popular uprisings in Ukraine. The headline read: “Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia.”

headline: June 4th Museum Set to Open in Hong Kong
text: In April 1989, tens of thousands of young protesters assembled on Tiananmen Square, in the heart of Beijing, demanding greater political freedoms and an end to corruption. The protests ended in bloodshed when tanks and troops were deployed the night of June 3-4 to clear the square. By most estimates, hundreds were killed.

headline: How to Kill the Minimum Wage Movement
text: On a visit to the capital a few weeks ago, I was struck by how politically inert the place was. Not just empty, lifeless, devoid of activity in the chambers where great politicians once roamed. Not just a do-nothing Congress living up to its pledge to do even less this year than last. Not just the usual government-by-corporate lobbyists. At the moment, Washington is a dead town.

headline: Putting Pen to Paper, and a Friendship to the Test
text: Do you miss stamps? Or stationery? Or messages free from emoticons? “Address Unknown,” in a brief run at Gould Hall at the French Institute Alliance Française, could make you a lot less nostalgic for letter writing. Based on Kathrine Kressmann Taylor’s short epistolary novel, it concerns two German friends, Max and Martin, on the eve of World War II.

headline: The Insider | Advice From, and For, First-Time Filmmakers
text: When it comes to realizing a work of art, few processes are more challenging than that of making a feature film. Never mind that unlike most art forms, movies are a largely collaborative medium — paintbrushes don’t have egos — but even in our age of digital cameras and home editing suites, filmmaking can get expensive. Not only does a director have to believe in the project from page to screen, but so do the people paying for it. Being a filmmaker, especially in the beginning, is risky business. Here, 15 directors — each of whom are showing their first feature at the Tribeca Film Festival, which runs through Sunday — share with T how they did it.

headline: France Joins Gay Couples by Thousands, Amid Gripes
text: PARIS — Same-sex marriage has been gaining acceptance in France a year after a law allowing such unions was passed following vociferous public opposition and heated debate in Parliament.

headline: Spare Times for April 25-May 1
text: BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN: SAKURA MATSURI (Saturday and Sunday) At last, the cherry trees are in bloom, and the dancers and musicians who will be part of this annual festival of traditional and contemporary Japanese arts are ready to welcome visitors into a garden of earthly delights. More than 60 events will be featured, along with a marketplace and activities for children. Hours are 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The garden is at 990 Washington Avenue, at Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights, 718-623-7200, bbg.org; $25; $20 for those 12 to 17 and 65+; free for children under 12 and members. Let the cherry blossom petals fall where they may. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Just an After-School Job
text: “Young & Beautiful,” the latest movie from the French director François Ozon, begins with a shot, through binoculars, of a young woman sunbathing topless on a beach. Voyeurism is clearly on the agenda, and Mr. Ozon seems to be teasing out some of its creepy implications when he reveals that the binoculars belong to the sunbather’s younger brother. But what is most striking about this movie is how un-self-conscious it is as it conducts a prurient and superficial inquiry into adolescent female sexuality.

headline: A Bit Naughty, This Boy Band
text: Boys will be boys, and sometimes boys will be men, but most often boys will be struggling to figure out how much of each they should be, so they can get away with the most stuff.

headline: What a Life: Bus Tables, Buss Prince
text: Perhaps it’s just coincidence. Or maybe, with the recent public discourse about the struggling middle class, this seems an apt moment to revisit a fairy tale about a good-hearted young woman, miserably oppressed by her family, who finds an unlikely soul mate in a loving prince.

headline: An Opera, Without Singing, in a Museum
text: In 1974 the writer and actress Anne Opie Wehrer, the subject of Robert Ashley’s “The Trial of Anne Opie Wehrer and Unknown Accomplices for Crimes Against Humanity,” wrote to the Whitney Museum of American Art proposing that it present the work as a “living sculpture.”

headline: Silent, Clumsy Avenger Gets to Work
text: Dwight (Macon Blair) isn’t your typical movie avenger, but then “Blue Ruin” — partly named for Dwight’s battered blue Pontiac — isn’t your typical revenge movie. Concealed behind a hill-country beard and shapeless clothing, Dwight is a near-silent, homeless shadow who sleeps in his car on a Delaware beach. When we first see him, he’s enjoying a bath in a stranger’s home, dismayed when the owners arrive unexpectedly. A tidy intruder, Dwight doesn’t like to leave a mess.

headline: Clip: ‘The Other Woman’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Neanderthals Are People, Too
text: LEIPZIG, Germany — I NEVER met my paternal grandfather. He died of the Spanish flu in 1919 at the age of 30, before his children and grandchildren ever got to know him. He was a brilliant mathematician and, as a scientist myself, I feel curious about what he was like. I take consolation from the fact that he lives on in me; after all, a quarter of my genes come from him.

headline: It’s Not You — It’s That You Want to Stay in My Apartment
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, told a reporter last week that he’s done so much good that if there’s a heaven, he won’t have to stop for an interview, he’ll walk right in.

headline: A Female Cooperative Based on Revenge
text: It takes a lot of heavy weather to snuff out the spark of Cameron Diaz who, at 41, still has the twinkle and bounce of an impish high school cheerleader. With her cornflower-blue eyes and mischievous feline grin, she remains every guy’s ultimate gal pal. One of her gifts as an comic actor is a light touch.

headline: Schwab Agrees to Drop Effort to Prevent Class-Action Lawsuits
text: The discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company has agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and give up an effort to prevent customers from participating in class-action lawsuits.

headline: A Ferocious Satirist, With Ink as His Weapon
text: In 1969, Ralph Steadman, a British cartoonist and illustrator, was invited by the editors of Scanlan’s Monthly to attend the Kentucky Derby in the company of Hunter S. Thompson, who was writing an article about the race. This assignment marked the beginning of a long, fruitful and frequently volatile collaboration. Nine years after Thompson’s death, it is nearly impossible to think of his prose without conjuring visions of Mr. Steadman’s drawings — nightmarishly funny compositions in which spidery lines intersect with clouds of spilled and sprayed ink.

headline: Pro-Russian Rebels on Checkpoint Attack
text: Pro-Russian separatists described the scene after a clash with Ukrainian forces at a checkpoint outside Slovyansk, Ukraine.

headline: Cliven Bundy Accidentally Explained What’s Wrong With the Republican Party
text: On Saturday, Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher who has risen to prominence because of his dispute with the Bureau of Land Management, held forth about “the Negro,” and how black people may have been better off under slavery than now.

headline: Paths to Stopping Painkiller Overdoses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 49
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Blithely Risking Discovery of Her May-December Fling
text: Oh, those French! When it comes to adultery, they apparently know how to indulge without tears or recriminations. That is the reassuring but unconvincing message of “Bright Days Ahead,” a lighter-than-air carnal romance.

headline: Pakistan, Ending Its Observance of Cease-Fire, Launches Airstrikes Against Taliban
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Putting an abrupt end to the Pakistani government’s adherence to a cease-fire with the Taliban on Thursday, military jets launched heavy airstrikes against militants in the Khyber tribal region bordering Afghanistan, officials said.

headline: End College Legacy Preferences
text: SOMEONE reading about the Supreme Court’s decision upholding Michigan’s ban on affirmative action — and by extension similar measures passed by voters in California, Texas, Florida and Washington — might develop the misimpression that affirmative action is on the wane. In fact, it’s alive and well: Public and private colleges routinely give preferential treatment to children of alumni.

headline: Searching for the Life That Belonged to a Body
text: A kind of forensic memorial, “Who Is Dayani Cristal?” pieces together the background of a Central American migrant worker who died trying to cross into the United States. With its compellingly multifaceted approach, its earnest compassion and a celebrity presence in the form of the actor Gael García Bernal, the documentary could be enlisted in the perennial battle over immigration law. But for the same reasons, the movie is also in danger of battling itself to a draw.

headline: NYU Langone Reopens Emergency Room That Was Closed by Hurricane Sandy
text: A striking sight appeared earlier this week outside the emergency room of NYU Langone Medical Center: an ambulance. Then another. And then many more.

headline: Mind the Gap? That’s the Least of Their Worries
text: Like a hard-up version of a 1970s disaster movie, “Last Passenger” drops a disparate group of people in the path of a calamity, then watches as they wriggle to escape. But instead of being on a sinking ship or in a blazing tower block, these unfortunates are trapped on a late-night commuter train that has just left London. And if that’s not terrifying enough, they’re headed for the snooty borough of Tunbridge Wells.

headline: China: Legislature Toughens Environmental Law
text: The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the country’s environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. Under the new law, expected to take effect next year, fines against companies would be increased, and company executives deemed responsible for pollution could be detained for up to 15 days. Local officials who cover up for polluting companies can be demoted or fired. Companies that have been ordered by officials to stop polluting but avoid doing so can be penalized with fines that accumulate daily. Until now, the companies had been assessed a one-time fine, Xinhua reported. The legal revisions were approved Thursday by the National People’s Congress, a legislative body that generally agrees to policies already made by Communist Party leaders.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 25, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Brick Mansions,” “The German Doctor” and “For No Good Reason.”

headline: Provision Could Limit U.S. Food Aid
text: WASHINGTON — An obscure provision tucked inside a Coast Guard spending bill could prevent millions of people in troubled countries around the world from receiving American food aid and cost taxpayers millions of dollars in shipping costs, the Obama administration said this week.

headline: If Assad Wins War, Challenge From His Own Sect May Follow
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — As President Bashar al-Assad seeks re-election and promises victory over insurgents by year’s end, Syrian loyalists and regional analysts say that his success, if it materializes, could set him up for a new challenge: demands for change from core supporters who believe he owes his survival mainly to them.

headline: ‘Zero Motivation’ and ‘Point and Shoot’ Take Top Prizes at Tribeca Film Festival
text: Military-themed films won top prizes at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, which announced its awards Thursday night: “Zero Motivation,” which depicts the trials and tedium endured by a unit of young female Israeli soldiers, won best narrative film, and “Point and Shoot,” wherein an American filmmaker records his foray into the Libyan civil war, was named best documentary.

headline: Something’s Burning, and Comedy Isn’t Pretty
text: Pain is everywhere in “Ape,” but it starts with the light. From the bright stab of morning after a rough night to the merciless glare of the spotlight in a pitch-black comedy club, this knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up uses agony like a silent soundtrack.

headline: Clip: ‘The German Doctor’
text: A scene from the film directed by Lucía Puenzo.

headline: Ladies’ Home Journal to Become a Quarterly
text: Ladies’ Home Journal, whose very name evokes a bygone era of women’s service magazines, will no longer publish as a monthly after a 130-year run, its owner, the Meredith Corporation, announced on Thursday.

headline: De Blasio Names Chief of Agency Overseeing Sick Pay Law
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday the appointment of a former regulatory lawyer, well known for her efforts to revitalize Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 attacks, to head the Department of Consumer Affairs — an agency enforcing compliance with New York City’s paid sick leave law.

headline: N.C.A.A. Ensures Athletes Will Get All They Can Eat
text: When the University of Mississippi wanted to improve its athletic performance, Athletic Director Ross Bjork went beyond having the weight room renovated or updating the training facilities. He also drafted plans to build a state-of-the-art cafeteria.

headline: Battling Illness and Royalty for Love
text: “The Girl and Death” is primarily set in that most durable of mysterious settings: a secluded, well-appointed hotel from another era. This particular establishment, tucked outside Leipzig, in post-World War II Germany, has its dotard guests and their routines, its officious and stiffly uniformed staff, and its intimations of secrets and riches. Most important, as discovered by a young visiting Russian doctor, Nicolai, it hosts Elise, the lovely kept mistress of a wealthy prince.

headline: Enemies One Year, Teammates the Next
text: Last year, the School District of Philadelphia, facing a shortfall of more than $300 million, instituted a “doomsday” budget that ultimately closed 24 schools. Those included the 99-year-old Germantown High School, whose students would attend Martin Luther King High, its former bitter rival.

headline: Students File Complaints on Sexual Assaults at Columbia University
text: Pressure on Columbia University to overhaul its approach to sexual assault and harassment reached a new pitch on Thursday, when a group of students filed complaints with the federal government, charging systematic mishandling of assault claims and mistreatment of victims.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Gone Fishing With Dad, Often on Silent Mode
text: “Marvin, Seth and Stanley” aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story, but the father in it is almost an afterthought. It still has sublime moments, but it leaves you wanting more of them.

headline: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death
text: “Walking With the Enemy” is based on the real-life deeds of Pinchas Rosenbaum, a Hungarian rabbi’s son who was able to save Jews from the Nazis and their collaborators by disguising himself in enemy garb.

headline: A Supplement Retailer Pumps Up Consumers
text: MOST people consider themselves above average, something psychologists call illusory superiority and, less formally, the Lake Wobegon effect, a reference to the fictional town of Garrison Keillor’s radio monologues, where he says “all the children are above average.”

headline: Struggling to Escape the Bronx’s Grasp
text: To say that Mikey (Alexander Emmet), the embattled protagonist of “Grand Slammed,” has hit a rough patch understates the matter gravely. An aspiring pitcher, he blows his chance in front of a talent scout, leaving blood spattered on home plate from a wild pitch. That evening, he serves as a getaway driver when his buddy Pete (Dimitri Meskouris) hops out of the car for an unexpected gangland shooting.

headline: Into Africa
text: The documentary “Tanzania: A Journey Within” is two travel diaries woven together. One is somber and moving. The other is distractingly annoying.

headline: A Face of a Brutal Sport Is Trying to Change Its Image
text: Jon (Bones) Jones, the U.F.C. light heavyweight champion, made the rounds earlier this week in Manhattan, promoting his fight Saturday against Glover Teixeira.

headline: A Partnership to Help the Tallest Residents in Yosemite Park
text: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — In an otherworldly grove of cinnamon-colored giant sequoias, workers in June will jackhammer an old mistake: a road and parking lot that impinge on the hallowed forest.

headline: The Regeneration of ‘Degenerate Art’
text: Even on the coolest mornings, the long and patient lines of people outside the Neue Galerie, a small gem of a New York museum, have testified to the unintended consequences of Adolf Hitler’s dictatorial tastes in art. “As for the degenerate artists,” the Nazi leader decreed as he rose to power, “I forbid them to force their so-called experiences upon the public.” He targeted them as criminals — modern masters like Otto Dix, Max Beckmann and George Grosz — and obsessively purged them from sight.

headline: 2 Journalists in Lebanon Are Charged by Tribunal
text: The international tribunal dealing with the killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon has charged two leading Lebanese journalists with contempt of court and obstruction of justice over the publication of confidential information about possible witnesses for the prosecution.

headline: A Questionable Decision on Egypt
text: American policy toward Egypt continued on its tortured, confusing path this week when the Obama administration resumed some aid to what has become an increasingly repressive state. No matter how American officials try to spin it, the decision will come across as a vote of confidence in a military-dominated government with an authoritarian agenda and a track record of violent crackdowns on dissenters and political opponents.

headline: For E-Cigarettes, the Regulatory Battle Now Begins
text: WASHINGTON — At last, Washington is moving to police the multibillion-dollar business of electronic cigarettes.

headline: Tiny Jockeys, Galloping in a Cloud of Despair
text: “There were some men there,” the small boy with the large brown eyes tells us. “You would go and give them your body.” Others around him nod in agreement — and corroborate in more explicit language — but “Desert Riders,” a deeply troubling account of child camel jockeys in the United Arab Emirates, is not primarily concerned with sexual abuse. There are too many other abuses demanding its attention.

headline: Seattle Mayor Says Effort to Build Agreement on $15 Minimum Wage Has Faltered
text: SEATTLE — Mayor Ed Murray of Seattle said Thursday that his effort to build consensus behind raising the city’s minimum wage to $15, more than twice the federal rate, had faltered amid continuing differences between business leaders and labor unions that had been advising him on the issue.

headline: Museumgoers Wonder: Why Doesn’t the Whale Fall?
text: It is one of the biggest attractions — literally — at one of New York City’s most famous destinations: the 94-foot-long blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History. Untold numbers gaze in awe every day at the 21,000-pound creature poised majestically in midair above the Hall of Ocean Life.

headline: Trailing Canada, U.S. Starts a Push for Safer Oil Shipping
text: A day after Canada issued stringent new rules for the transportation of oil by rail, federal regulators in the United States said on Thursday that they would push forward their own tank standards next week, potentially resolving a critical safety issue that has been mired in regulatory limbo for years.

headline: House Majority PAC Ad
text: An ad in West Virginia stressed that so-called black lung benefits for miners could be lost if the law is repealed.

headline: A Bid for Governor
text: Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, a Democrat running for Pennsylvania governor, in an ad saying how proud she is of the health law.

headline: Support for Alaska Senator
text: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 24, 2014
text: April 24, 2014

headline: The Piketty Phenomenon
text: Many people join the political left driven by a concern for the poor. But, over the past several years, the Democratic Party has talked much more about the middle class than the poor. Meanwhile, progressive political movements like Occupy Wall Street directed their fervor at the top 1 percent. Progressive movies and books have focused their attention on conspiracy and oligarchy at the top, not “Grapes of Wrath” or “How the Other Half Lives” stories at the bottom.

headline: A Fight to Keep College Athletes From the Pain of Injury Costs
text: Kyle Hardrick lost his basketball scholarship at Oklahoma after he tore his meniscus.

headline: Rand Paul and Wealthy Libertarians Connect as He Weighs Running
text: Frayda Levin, a New Jersey libertarian activist and former small-business owner, is a woman of many passions: promoting liberty, ending marijuana prohibition and opposing her state’s recent minimum-wage increase. But Ms. Levin has added another cause as well. At gala benefits for free-market research institutes and at fund-raisers for antitax groups, she has urged like-minded donors to help send Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, to the White House.

headline: In Florida Tomato Fields, a Penny Buys Progress
text: IMMOKALEE, Fla. — Not long ago, Angelina Velasquez trudged to a parking lot at 5 each morning so a crew leader’s bus could drop her at the tomato fields by 6. She often waited there, unpaid — while the dew dried — until 10 a.m., when the workers were told to clock in and start picking.

headline: Efforts to Snub the Other Party Rarely Go Well
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Democratic Candidates Grow More Vocal in Supporting Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, Democrat of Pennsylvania, did the seemingly unthinkable on Tuesday: She ran a television ad expressing how proud she was of President Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: The Piketty Panic
text: “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” the new book by the French economist Thomas Piketty, is a bona fide phenomenon. Other books on economics have been best sellers, but Mr. Piketty’s contribution is serious, discourse-changing scholarship in a way most best sellers aren’t. And conservatives are terrified. Thus James Pethokoukis of the American Enterprise Institute warns in National Review that Mr. Piketty’s work must be refuted, because otherwise it “will spread among the clerisy and reshape the political economic landscape on which all future policy battles will be waged.”

headline: D.W.I. Charge for Detective Who Shot Colleague
text: A New York police detective who accidentally shot his partner in the wrist on Thursday while in their unmarked patrol car was later arrested and charged with drunken driving, the authorities said.

headline: Amid Overhaul, Case Questions Agency’s Foster Care
text: As Texas Child Protective Services is working to streamline its foster care system, a lawsuit in federal court could force officials back to the drawing board, costing taxpayers millions of dollars.

headline: U.S. Confronts Consequences of Underestimating North Korean Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Almost everything American intelligence agencies and North Korea-watchers thought they understood two years ago about Kim Jong-un, the North’s young leader, turns out to have been wrong.

headline: Lobbying Efforts Intensify After F.C.C. Tries 3rd Time on Net Neutrality
text: WASHINGTON — In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations — over one a day — have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify.

headline: A Right-to-Bear-Arms Twist: Rallying With a Gun in Hand
text: When advocates for tighter restrictions on guns rallied last week in Austin City Hall, a small group of opponents staged a counter-rally outside, carrying firearms and waving a flag emblazoned with an assault rifle and the caption “Come and Take It.”

headline: Missing on Mound: A Dab of Discretion
text: The circle in the middle of a baseball diamond may as well be in a spotlight on a Broadway stage. Everybody watches the pitcher, because nothing happens until he delivers the ball. Yet with all those eyes on him, in the ballpark and at home, few can really see what he does.

headline: Creating a Two-Speed Internet
text: Dividing traffic on the Internet into fast and slow lanes is exactly what the Federal Communications Commission would do with its proposed regulations, unveiled this week. And no amount of reassurances about keeping competition alive will change that fact.

headline: Judge Rejects New York Limit on Donations to ‘Super PACs’
text: A federal judge on Thursday struck down New York State’s limit on contributions to independent groups that spend money supporting political candidates, a move that could unleash large spending by so-called super PACs in state races.

headline: Alternative to Pap Test Is Approved by F.D.A.
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first alternative to the long-used Pap test as a primary screening method for cervical cancer, in the face of opposition from some women’s groups and health organizations.

headline: Gang Leader From Mexico Gets Life Term
text: MEXICO CITY — A gang leader was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for his role in ordering the 2010 murders of three people associated with the United States Consulate in Ciudad Juárez, killings that rattled both sides of the border as drug violence engulfed the city.

headline: An Ivy League Newspaper May Be Going Mostly Online
text: The battle over the future of newspapers has found an unlikely flash point, above a Pinkberry on the fringes of Columbia University’s Morningside Heights campus.

headline: Labor Board to Review Northwestern Football Case
text: The National Labor Relations Board in Washington announced Thursday that it would review last month’s landmark decision that held that Northwestern University’s scholarship football players should be considered employees. The board said the case raised “substantial issues.”

headline: Justice Dept. Seeks Mortgage Deal With Bank of America
text: The Justice Department, building on a multibillion-dollar mortgage settlement with JPMorgan Chase last year, is now aiming for a deal with Bank of America.

headline: Old Chums Return, Where Club Is Home
text: Hot diggity dachshund, it’s old home week on the campus at Weimar Berlin, otherwise known as the Kit Kat Klub. And if we take off our glasses and squint, we can pretend that life is just as divinely, dangerously decadent as it was when we were all 16 years younger.

headline: Climate Change Onstage: Singing of the Extinction of Fauna
text: The drumbeat of dire reports about climate change has grown so rhythmically regular over the past few years that it’s almost surprising that someone hasn’t set it to song, at least within the confines of a musical. That day has now come. If you’ve long been hankering to hear the bad news about global warming given the full Brecht, hop on that bike and head to the Public Theater, where “The Great Immensity” opened on Thursday.

headline: Puzzle Solver’s Complaint
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s Friday, the beginning of the weekend, and it’s going to be tough to decide whether we want to CHILLAX or CATERWAUL and RAISE HELL. Let’s let constructor Joel Fagliano help us make up our minds.

headline: Kerry Rejects ‘Absurd’ Russian Claims
text: Secretary of State John Kerry denounced Russian actions in Ukraine but stopped short of announcing measures in response.

headline: Effort to Remove Landlord Who Made Units Unlivable
text: In a case that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is holding up as an example of “egregious harassment,” New York state and city officials are moving aggressively against a Brooklyn landlord accused of wrecking the kitchens and bathrooms of occupied apartments to drive out longtime tenants.

headline: Bulls Star With Brooklyn Roots Is the Same as Ever: Different
text: Joakim Noah was an accomplished basketball player at Poly Prep Country Day School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He did many things well. He rebounded. He scored. He led the Blue Devils to two league titles.

headline: Blue-Footed Boobies, a Galápagos Treasure, Under Threat
text: Blue-footed boobies are among the Galápagos Islands’ most beloved boldfaced names. But because of a lack of breeding, their numbers in the region are in serious decline, a new study says.

headline: Prosecutors Deny Targeting D’Souza on Use of Straw Donors
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan vigorously denied on Thursday that their prosecution of the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza for alleged campaign finance violations was politically motivated, and they accused Mr. D’Souza of lying “to mask his criminal activity.”

headline: Against Pesky Flyers, the Rangers Hope Penalties Don’t Mean Trouble
text: Coach Alain Vigneault knows the Rangers may troop to the penalty box in large numbers during Friday’s Game 4 against the Philadelphia Flyers, as they did in winning Game 3.

headline: City Worker Is Charged With Medicaid Fraud
text: He called himself “A.T.M.,” a nickname that matched his initials, but also his habit of spending thousands of dollars on expensive clothes for himself and on gifts for his friends — among them some women at a beauty salon in Upper Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: Seth Meyers to Host the Emmy Awards on NBC
text: Seth Meyers will top off his first season as a host of a late-night show on NBC by serving as host of the Emmy Awards this August.

headline: Pre-K Applicants Up 36% This Year; Mayor’s Challenge Is Finding Seats
text: Applications for prekindergarten programs in New York City schools rose by 36 percent this year, city officials announced on Thursday, as parents took advantage of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s promise to provide free classes to every 4-year-old in the city.

headline: Selling Off the Newark Bears
text: Financial woes have led Newark’s professional baseball team to fold. The Bears’ owners are auctioning off nearly everything, including lawn mowers, office furniture and the team bus.

headline: Newark Bears’ Items Going, Going ...
text: NEWARK — A small white sticker has been slapped onto the portable batting cage that sits just beyond the center-field wall of Riverfront Stadium, among the weeds and a few winter-ruined baseballs. “Auction,” the sticker says. “Lot Number 163.”

headline: Robert Gray, a Powerhouse in Washington, Dies at 92
text: Robert Gray, a powerful Washington lobbyist and public relations expert who began building connections while working in the Eisenhower administration and rose to the peak of his influence when his friend Ronald Reagan became president, died on April 18 in Miami. He was 92.

headline: Confident Kane Renews Blackhawks’ Optimism
text: CHICAGO — Patrick Kane with the puck on his stick in overtime has usually meant good things for the Blackhawks over the years.

headline: Ask Well: Do Foam Rollers Aid Workouts?
text: Question:

headline: Word of the Day | nebulous
text: nebulous•\ˈne-byə-ləs\• adjective

headline: With Durant Struggling, Grizzlies Survive
text: MEMPHIS — Shortly after the Memphis Grizzlies’ Tony Allen checked into Thursday night’s game, following the first television timeout, he located Kevin Durant and attached himself to Durant’s torso like a strip of Velcro. Durant misfired on a shot, and then another.

headline: Times Minute | Real Cost of a Tomato
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Real Cost of a Tomato
text: A novel program to stop abuse of tomato workers in Florida. Also on the Minute, negotiations stalled during President’s Obama visit to Asia and a preview of John Oliver’s new TV show.

headline: Michael Glawogger, Who Filmed Lives of Desperation, Dies at 54
text: Michael Glawogger, an Austrian filmmaker known for globe-trotting documentaries that show people grappling with horrendous circumstances, died on Wednesday in Liberia, where he was planning his next movie. He was 54.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) MATTHEW BOURNE’S SLEEPING BEAUTY In 1992, Mr. Bourne, the British choreographer, reinterpreted “The Nutcracker,” the first of three classic ballets set to scores by Tchaikovsky; in 1995, he unveiled his setting for “Swan Lake.” He completes the endeavor with this reimagining of the fairy tale about a princess who sleeps under a spell for 100 years, originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1890. Mr. Bourne’s version, taped at the Bristol Hippodrome in England, begins in that year with the birth of the heroine, Aurora (danced by Hannah Vassallo, above center, with Edwin Ray, left and Danny Reubens), who falls in love not with a prince but a gardener, Leo (Dominic North), and eventually awakens in the modern day. He also provides Leo with a rival, Caradoc (Adam Maskell), the dashingly vengeful son of the evil fairy who curses Aurora to death. “The love story that Mr. Bourne substitutes isn’t any more emotionally compelling than the original,” Brian Seibert wrote in his review of the production, presented here by Great Performances, in The New York Times. “Poetically, it’s a diminishment. The battle between good and evil is reduced to a tussle between the nice guy and the bad boy.” Still, he said, “Mr. Bourne is not an ungrateful recipient of the gift of Tchaikovsky’s score. He dedicates his ‘Sleeping Beauty’ to the composer, whose work will survive this version. It’s more than 100 years old and still likely to last as long as the undead.”

headline: India Election Digest: April 25
text: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Mumbai’s voter turnout was the highest since 1989, the Aam Aadmi Party finds fans in Punjab, and villagers see the “none of the above” option as a means of protest.

headline: People’s Daily Editorial Fanned Flames of 1989 Protest
text: Twenty-five years ago, on the night of April 25, editors in newspaper offices across China received an editorial that was to run in People’s Daily the next morning, and their papers were ordered to reprint on their front pages the Communist Party newspaper’s pronouncement on the student demonstrators who had occupied Tiananmen Square for nine days.

headline: Real Communist Mouthpiece Rages Against Fake Communist Mouthpiece
text: The official mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party is in a rage over a parody Twitter account that for years has poked fun at the foibles of the Leninist state.

headline: Corrections: April 25, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 25, 2014
text: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

headline: R.B.S. to Drop Bonus Plan After British Agency Balks
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it would drop a plan to pay its bankers bonuses of up to two times their annual salaries after an agency that manages the British government’s stake in the lender refused to back the proposal.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest
text: In “The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest,” David Leonhardt and Kevin Quealy report on how American incomes are losing their edge, except at the top.

headline: Defying Moscow, Ukraine Threatens to Blockade Pro-Russian Militants
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The interim central government in Kiev threatened to blockade the eastern city of Slovyansk on Friday, defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine.

headline: How Common Is Drug Use in Your School?
text: This week prosecutors in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia announced the arrests of eight people on charges of distributing drugs in five public and private high schools and in three colleges. The headmaster at one of the private schools said in an interview that he was “shocked and appalled” by the charges and would re-examine the school’s drug policy.

headline: Far Out and Close Up
text: The San Francisco Chronicle columnist Herb Caen, who coined the term “beatnik” in 1958, saw them as a mass phenomenon, with hordes of young “bearded kats and kits” overrunning a party in North Beach and “slopping up” free booze. The poet Kenneth Rexroth, who introduced the first major reading of Beat poets, dismissed the whole phenomenon as a creation of the Luce magazine empire, carping that “after the first five writers, it produced nothing.” And when the writer Hettie Jones was asked about the Beat generation, she joked that “everyone identified with it could fit into my living room.”

headline: Chinese Vice President Warns Hong Kong Over Protests
text: HONG KONG — In the bluntest warning yet from a Chinese Communist Party leader about possible protests in Hong Kong’s financial district, Vice President Li Yuanchao has called the Occupy Central movement an illegal initiative that would threaten Hong Kong’s prosperity.

headline: The Industrial Art of Those Talented Bugattis
text: OXNARD, CALIF. — Aficionados have argued for ages over which individual has had the greatest influence on the automobile.

headline: Russia Raises Rate to Bolster Economy After S.&P. Cuts Its Debt Rating
text: MOSCOW — With tensions over Ukraine continuing to mount, Russia is scrambling to stem the economic fallout, as its central bank unexpectedly raised a crucial interest rate on Friday.

headline: New York Today: Moving Verses
text: Good morning on this fair Friday. Look out for changing weather.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Inquiry in Ferry Disaster Shifts to Safety Certification
text: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors on Friday barred eight current and former officials from a maritime inspection agency from leaving South Korea, as the investigation of the ferry sinking last week that left more than 300 people dead or missing shifted to the agencies responsible for certifying ships as safe to travel.

headline: Switzerland’s Toxic Prosperity
text: On a warm midsummer night, a few months after my book about industrial pollution in the New Jersey town of Toms River was published, I watched a fireworks show over the Rhine River celebrating Swiss National Day. I was in Basel, the city where the chemical industry first took root more than 150 years ago.

headline: The Global Diabetes Epidemic
text: Twelve years ago, my husband and I packed up all of our belongings and moved to Trivandrum — a steamy, tropical town at the southern tip of India in Kerala. At the time, I was a medical student interested in studying stroke. For the next six months I dressed in a sari and walked to work on jungle roads. At the hospital, I immediately began seeing a steady stream of young patients affected by strokes, many of whom were so severely disabled that they were unable to work. I initially suspected the cause was tuberculosis or dengue fever — after all, this was the developing world, where infections have long been primary culprits for disease. But I soon learned that my hunch was wrong.

headline: Daily Report: Lobbying Surges After F.C.C. Tries Again on Net Neutrality
text: In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations — more than one a day — have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Blurring Boundaries and Meaning
text: The course of Ingmar Bergman’s reputation is a saga all its own. Indifferently received in his native Sweden, Bergman’s early films were championed in France. Jean-Luc Godard hailed him as “the most original of directors” after “Summer With Monika” — a sort of Neo-Realist “Rebel Without a Cause” enlivened by Harriet Andersson’s skinny-dipping and originally released in the United States as an exploitation film — played in Paris in the mid-’50s.

headline: Follow the Money: Gretchen Morgenson on Wall Street
text: Gretchen Morgenson, a Times reporter and business columnist, won a Pulitzer Prize in 2002 for beat reporting. Her column, Fair Game, appears in the Sunday Business section. We asked her to talk about her career and how she works.

headline: Funds and Downloads Dwindling, a Start-Up Is Put on Hold
text: Last July, we wrote about a start-up, NoChains, with a free app designed to help users find the best independent, nonchain restaurants in a particular city.

headline: Alstom Shares Suspended on Reports of G.E. Bid
text: Shares of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate, were suspended Friday on the Paris exchange at the request of the market regulator amid reports that the company is negotiating a multibillion-dollar deal to sell its energy business to General Electric.

headline: Hello, Stranger
text: If you’ve ever been on a subway or public bus, you know the rules. Don’t make eye contact, stay as far away from other people as the space allows, and for the love of God, don’t talk to anyone. But what if the rules are wrong?

headline: Sotheby’s Battle Heats Up
text: BARE KNUCKLES AT SOTHEBY’S  |  The battle between Sotheby’s and Daniel S. Loeb, the outspoken hedge fund mogul and the auction house’s biggest shareholder, is heading to its final stages, Alexandra Stevenson and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. On Thursday, Mr. Loeb gained an advantage in the standoff as the proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended that shareholders vote for two of the three board nominees he has proposed.

headline: Bake and Switch
text: You can tell a lot about a country by its croissants. At least you can tell a lot about America, where croissants don’t rest on their laurels or cling to fussy, Old World norms. Here they innovate. They disrupt.

headline: Obama Administration Plans New Rules to Grade Teacher Training Programs
text: The Obama administration announced on Friday that it was developing ratings of teacher preparation programs to make them more accountable for their graduates’ performance in the classroom.

headline: In Our Pages: April 26
text: 1914: American Woman’s Club Tea

headline: After ‘Cadmium Rice,’ now ‘Lead’ and ‘Arsenic Rice’
text: Soil in China’s leading rice-producing region shows high levels of heavy metal contamination, in a study that suggests that the proximity of mining and industry to agricultural areas is posing serious threats to the country’s food chain.

headline: Using the Foreign to Grasp the Familiar
text: In “The Other Language,” the title story of Francesca Marciano’s new collection, an Italian teenager named Emma falls in love with English. The attraction has a lot to do with the person speaking it, an intriguing English boy at the Greek beach resort where Emma is staying with her family, but it’s hard to separate the strands of desire. Is the boy her entry ticket to English, or vice versa?

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Why I, a Heterosexual Teenage Boy, Want to See More Men in Speedos
text: We are publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission, to honor each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest. You can find the full collection here.

headline: Piketty and Pareto
text: Well, it’s Piketty day at the Times, with David Brooks and yours truly even having more or less matching headlines. And David’s take reminds me of something I’ve been meaning to do: explain one important point in Piketty that even economist readers have, it seems, tended to miss.

headline: New Vehicles and Recalls Cut Ford Profit
text: DETROIT — The rising tide of recalls has made it more expensive for automakers to do business, even in the absence of a major crisis like the ignition switch recall at General Motors.

headline: Guest Post | Get Ready for College Writing by Learning to Revise
text: Do you have your students revise their essays? If so, is their process mostly a matter of adding some commas and correcting spelling errors — or are they actually rethinking their writing to make it clearer and stronger?

headline: A Single Adoptive Mother — in 1937
text: Sometimes it’s hard to remember that adoption (the kind that doesn’t involve orphanages and gruel) is more than a contemporary phenomenon. Reading today’s human-interest stories on the topic can make it seem like adoption is a parenting challenge of our time, like baking gluten-free snacks or finding story books friendly to same sex parenting.

headline: Obama Offers Support to South Korea at a Moment of Trauma and Tension
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Obama arrived here on Friday offering solace to a country traumatized by the sinking of a ferry that killed scores, and showing solidarity at a time when the Korean Peninsula is rife with tension.

headline: Harrods Displays the World According to Prada
text: Art, film, architecture and fashion are frequent bedfellows, but no one has blended the genres as poignantly or provocatively as Miuccia Prada. Now, the legendary London department store Harrods is putting Prada’s interdisciplinary collaborations on display in a monthlong exhibit titled “Pradasphere,” opening April 30. Curated by the graphic designer Michael Rock, who lent his conceptual aesthetic to the house’s spring 2014 runway show, the installation traces Miuccia Prada’s trajectory of influence through fashion, art, architecture, cinema and even sports. Visitors can view a Prada history wall with images from the house’s Fondazione and its partnership with America’s Cup. A screening room will show short films made in collaboration with directors like Wes Anderson and Roman Polanski. The brand’s iconic architectural projects with Rem Koolhaas/OMA and Herzog & de Meuron will also be exhibited. And, naturally, there’s plenty of fashion to see and buy: an on-site pop-up will sell a special capsule collection of clothing, bags, shoes and accessories, inspired by archival designs from the brand’s first 100 years — even before Miuccia joined the family business.

headline: Public Grooming
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Bharatiya Janata Party’s Message Is Muddled By Polarization
text: MUMBAI, India — Even as the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi, has attempted to distance himself from his party’s right-wing Hindu nationalist ideology and focus on economic development, polarizing speeches by party members and allies dominated headlines early this week.

headline: Report Says N.J. Transit, Not Port Authority, Should Run PATH Lines
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should turn the money-losing PATH commuter rail system over to New Jersey’s state-run transit agency to free up money for big infrastructure projects, a report released on Friday recommended.

headline: Bombshells Felt in the Balcony
text: Of all the surprise turns in musical compositions, one stands out as practically a non sequitur. It comes well into the choral finale of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, the composer’s setting of Schiller’s “Ode to Joy.” As part of a recent interactive project I invited readers to share their choices of great surprises in music, and several suggested this unexpected episode in this Beethoven work.

headline: Rarely One for Sugarcoating
text: The smell hits you first: sweet but with an acrid edge, like a thousand burned marshmallows. Then you’re struck by the space, five stories high and more than a football field long. The storage shed of the Domino sugar factory, on the East River in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, was built in 1927 to hold mountains of raw sugar due for whitening. The plant was shuttered a decade ago, yet its crumbling walls still drip with molasses.

headline: Tracking Future and Hip-Hop’s Growlers
text: Popcast this week: how Future became one of hip-hop’s most influential vocal stylists.

headline: Mookie Wilson on Life After the Mets
text: The former New York Mets outfielder Mookie Wilson talks to Dave Itzkoff about his new book, ‘‘Mookie: Life, Baseball, and the ’86 Mets,’’ his career after the Major Leagues and that infamous grounder down the first-base line.

headline: Frustrations of the Heterodox
text: It’s kind of a sideshow in the larger scheme of things, but something worth noting is taking place on the fringes (literally) of economic discussion: an upwelling of frustration on the part of heterodox economists. You see it in Thomas Palley’s complaint about gattopardo economics, which I discussed yesterday; you see it in the demands for a radical change in the economics curriculum, which Simon Wren-Lewis wrote about yesterday.

headline: A Country in Bloom
text: Every spring millions of Japanese visit parks to take in the brief but magnificent bloom of their country’s cherry trees. They gather for so-called hanami parties, setting out elaborate meals of bento boxes with sake. (A smaller celebration in Washington marks the flowering of trees given to the city by the Tokyo mayor in 1912.) In some places, the scene is rowdy with people in their 20s; in others, families wander quietly among trees illuminated by paper lanterns. The photographer Matthew Pillsbury captured the cherry blossoms at their peak in several places in Japan this month. “The crowds are unlike anything I’ve ever seen,” he says. “You see groups of elderly people sitting next to groups of teenagers. They all clap when the blooms start falling off the tree. They’re basically having the very same party.” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 4.13.14 Issue
text: THE BALLAD OF GEESHIE AND ELVIE

headline: Occupy My Condo
text: I know of someone who has lived mortgage-free for three years while the bank foreclosed on his apartment. During that time, the man paid his monthly maintenance to the building but did not pay his mortgage. His rationale: He had been in the furniture business and lost much of his income with the financial crisis, and not one of the bankers responsible for the meltdown has gone to jail. And furthermore, as a result, his apartment was worth less than he paid for it. Does any of that matter? Is strategic loan default ethical? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Could You Repeat That?
text: A new name just under the legal limit; tech specs take on a composer.

headline: Playing the Cards
text: A year ago, I found out that my son, Isaac, won $300,000 playing online poker the previous day. His mother, Francie, was pleased to hear about this on her way out the door for work. The next day, I learned that he won another $62,000.

headline: Who Made That Packing Peanut?
text: In 1960, a research chemist named Maurice Laverne Zweigle packed a raw egg and a few handfuls of skinny, bendy, polystyrene noodles into a small cardboard box, sealed the flaps and tossed it off a third-floor roof. His invention worked: The egg was unscathed.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Brick Mansions,’ ‘The German Doctor’ and ‘For No Good Reason’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the action film “Brick Mansions,” the drama “The German Doctor” and the documentary “For No Good Reason.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: A Cube With a Twist: At 40, It Puzzles Anew
text: JERSEY CITY — A Rubik’s cube can be twisted and twiddled in 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 different ways, and 43,252,003,274,489,855,999 of them are wrong.

headline: How to Get Better Insurance Data, Without Encouraging Conspiracy Theories
text: It has been a week since opponents of health-care reform accused the Obama administration of conspiring with the Census Bureau to undercount the number of uninsured Americans in an attempt to make the Affordable Care Act look more successful than it really is.

headline: Varieties of the Visible World
text: In Barbara Ehrenreich’s new memoir, “Living With a Wild God,” reviewed this week by Parul Sehgal, the author describes a startling moment she experienced as a teenager when “something peeled off the visible world, taking with it all meaning, inference, association, labels and words.”

headline: Vision Quest
text: In May of 1959, Barbara Ehrenreich was taken into the mountains in Northern California by a boy looking for dynamite. They spent the night in the car, and in the morning, she wandered into town on foot. It happened then and there — an onrush of mystical visions — something she’d experienced before but never quite so brilliantly. “The world flamed into life,” she writes in her new book, “Living With a Wild God.” “Something poured into me and I poured out into it.”

headline: Why Everyone’s Talking About the Great Lime Shortage
text: We will all tell our children of the dark days of the Great Lime Shortage of 2014, when Mexican restaurants raised their margarita prices and otherwise respectable bars committed the blasphemy of serving gin and tonics with a slice of lemon. The shortage has become the subject of news media fascination, with the latest piece on the front page of Friday’s Wall Street Journal.

headline: An Unwanted Reprise Riles a Soviet Rocker
text: IN the days before Russia’s annexation of the Crimean Peninsula last month, a state-sponsored television network broadcast a bellicose video montage of events in Ukraine set to “This Train’s on Fire,” a song by the celebrated underground Soviet rock band Aquarium.

headline: Obama’s Comments in South Korea
text: President Obama discussed North Korea’s nuclear threat and offered condolences to the families who lost loved ones in the South Korean ferry incident.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Emmanuelle Seigner Turns the Tables on Roman Polanski
text: Emmanuelle Seigner, the French actress, singer and former model, has a multilayered appreciation for the film “Venus in Fur,” in which she stars as a sadomasochistically savvy, table-turning seductress.

headline: Today in Small Business: Seattle’s Minimum Wage Plan Falters
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rite of Summer Series to Bring Eclectic Music to Governors Island
text: Rite of Summer, an outdoor series of free classical music concerts with an emphasis on contemporary works, will open its fourth season on May 31 with a performance by Dawn of Midi, a Brooklyn piano, bass and percussion trio that performs electronica-inspired music on acoustic instruments. The festival, which is directed by the pianists Blair McMillen and Pam Goldberg, will be held at Colonel’s Row on Governors Island, with performances at 1 and 3 p.m.

headline: Treating Appendicitis Without Surgery
text: For many years, immediate surgery has been considered the only proper treatment for appendicitis in children. Now a small study suggests that in some cases, antibiotics alone may be better.

headline: Unsustainable Living
text: A story of land, water, relationships and love, “The Ogallala Road” is the 100-year history of a farming family in Kansas as well as the second of Julene Bair’s memoirs. The first, “One Degree West: Reflections of a Plainsdaughter,” was well received, but this new one is more polished, touching and engaging.

headline: Ganglands
text: There’s no way around it. To exercise power is to be ridden with guilt. To step is to step on. This, among other things, is the paradox of modern Israel. A nation meant to harbor and normalize the Jews has, in the process, entangled this ancient people with the brutality of sovereignty in a way so old it’s new. For a lot of us, it’s been a thrilling, maddening, disorienting 65-plus years. It’s this mood — pride wrapped in fear, the quest for the ordinary pitted against prophecy — and the violence that accompanies it that Zachary Lazar explores in his brilliant new novel, “I Pity the Poor Immigrant.”

headline: The Upshot, and 45 That Didn’t Make the Cut
text: In keeping with the spirit of this site — which we hope includes transparency, engagement with our readers and, yes, a willingness to publish lists when lists are called for — we’re publishing a comprehensive roster of runners-up for our name.

headline: Director’s Cut
text: A recent Harper’s Index offers the following juxtaposed statistics: In the last 20 years, seven Academy Award winners have thanked God in their acceptance speeches, whereas 30 have thanked Harvey Weinstein. If this troubles you, allow me to offer two thoughts: (1) Relax. While you are in heaven snorkeling through a sea of mai tais, the sinners (Hollywood stars, Harvey, this reviewer) will be stuck in a warmer place for the duration, where only the explicitly Christian films of the former “Growing Pains” heartthrob-turned-evangelist Kirk Cameron are shown, and only fake butter is available at the concession stand. (2) Skip David Grand’s “Mount Terminus,” an impressively conceived, often very entertaining novel that celebrates the oversize talents and ambitions of two cinema pioneers, the (fictional) half brothers Simon Reuben and Bloom Rosenbloom, even as it explores the destruction wrought to construct a home for their fledgling industry. Grand has written a work from which Harvey Weinstein might make a terrific, multilayered film.

headline: Let Us Remember
text: “The tall young men” was Irwin Shaw’s name for the squad of just-­graduated Ivy Leaguers who showed up at his Paris apartment in the American arrondissement in the early 1950s to beat him in tennis, drink his booze and bask in the afterglow of Hemingway and Stein. One of these urbane aspiring writers was 24-year-old Peter Matthiessen, fresh out of Yale and wrestling with his first novel, who, along with George Plimpton, William Styron, Harold Humes, Thomas Guinzburg and a few other hard-partying expats, would go on to start The Paris Review in 1953.

headline: Favorite Sins
text: Kyle Minor wants you to know that “Praying Drunk” — his second story collection, after “In the Devil’s Territory” — is not actually, or only, a collection. In the epigraph, he warns: “These stories are meant to be read in order. This is a book, not just a collection. don’t skip around.”

headline: Status Update
text: Since the word “teenager” was coined 70 years ago, adults have defined adolescents by one extreme or another. They are rebels without causes or activist leaders, mindless consumers or cultural kingpins, digital natives or naïfs. Enter Danah Boyd, a principal researcher at Microsoft Research and a research assistant professor at New York University. In life, Boyd retains the spirit of a youthful rebel, with her pierced tongue and name spelled in anti-Establishment lowercase. And perhaps in part thanks to its author’s identification with youth, “It’s Complicated” avoids many of the typical either-or clichés about adolescence. Boyd’s new book is layered and smart.

headline: Apocalypse Again
text: “The Origin of the Brunists,” published in 1966, is Robert Coover’s first novel, and also his most well behaved. In 1979, he described it as an attempt to “pay dues . . . to traditional fiction,” and as such, it offers a realist account of a cult that develops around Giovanni Bruno, the damaged survivor of a small-town mining disaster. Bruno’s group fixes on April 19 as the date for the Rapture, but as the title’s Darwinian allusion suggests, nothing divine will happen on their chosen mountain. Instead, the book’s climax is a primal eruption of violence, dark testimony to “another flaw in the evolution of mind.”

headline: The Man and the Message
text: In an essay entitled “Reflections on Gandhi,” George Orwell wrote: “Saints should always be judged guilty until they are proved innocent.” While he acquitted Gandhi, he might have been harder on Cesar Chavez, the great farmworker leader. Certainly in this engrossing biography Miriam Pawel, a former editor and reporter with Newsday and The Los Angeles Times, is out to show both the good and bad. In the 1960s and early ’70s, Chavez did seem like a version of Gandhi. Organizing the dispossessed, our own untouchables, he fasted to the point of death, staged mass marches up and down California that resembled religious pilgrimages, and defeated growers with nationwide boycotts that even Gandhi would have found hard to duplicate. Back then, many of the best and saintliest of America’s young quit their jobs or dropped out of school to join up with Chavez and live lives of voluntary poverty.

headline: Retreat and Advance
text: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally ended World War II by surrendering to the Allies aboard the American battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay. As a reminder of Japan’s brutality to captured Allied soldiers, Gen. Douglas MacArthur placed two skeletal survivors of Japanese prisoner-of-war camps — United States Gen. Jonathan Wainwright, whose troops had endured the infamous Bataan Death March, and British Gen. Arthur Percival, who surrendered Singapore — in the Japanese delegation’s direct line of sight.

headline: An N.H.L. Champion Pursues Another Cup, This Time in Russia
text: PRAGUE — When Mike Keenan and the Rangers hoisted the Stanley Cup in 1994, four Russian-born players became the first from their country to achieve the honor. Two decades later, Keenan is trying to become the first North American coach to win a Gagarin Cup title in the Kontinental Hockey League.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: In the Garden
text: THE GARDENER OF VERSAILLES  My Life in the World’s Grandest Garden  By Alain Baraton  Translated by Christopher Brent MurrayRizzoli, $26.95.

headline: Double Game
text: In December 2006, Carlotta Gall visited Quetta in Pakistan, close to the border with Afghanistan, to trace the families of Taliban suicide bombers. Her investigations were not welcome to the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), the main intelligence arm of the Pakistan military, which was determined to hide its close relations with the Taliban. Plainclothes intelligence agents smashed open the door of her hotel room and seized her notebooks, computer and cellphone. She protested when one of the agents grabbed her handbag, and he promptly punched her twice in the face, knocking her down. The officer in charge accused her of trying to interview Taliban members, which he said was forbidden. She learned later that her rough treatment had been ordered by the head of the ISI press department to discourage her from reporting ISI-Taliban links.

headline: Hostile Climate
text: For the first time since 2001, more Americans believe it was a mistake to send troops to Afghanistan than see it as the right call, at least according to a recent Gallup poll. Almost 13 years after the attacks of Sept. 11, we’re conflicted about what we are still doing in Afghanistan and confused about what happened there. Americans are tired of America’s long war, especially as it drones on.

headline: Art Matters | How to Buy a Famous Artist’s Work for $350
text: An exhibition and sale tomorrow night at the Santa Monica Museum of Art mounts a challenge to that pervasive problem of taste: The beholder may have the eye, but not the means. At Incognito 10, the museum’s annual benefit, the walls will be lined with 700 pieces of art — donated by more than 550 artists — whose authorship will be kept anonymous until after each work is sold.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE THIRD COAST: When Chicago Built the American Dream,  by Thomas Dyja. (Penguin, $18.) Dyja’s robust history weaves together the stories of the artists, styles and ideas that made Chicago a crucible for culture and innovation before and after World War II: Mies van der Rohe’s Modernist architecture, Ray Kroc’s McDonald’s franchise, the Chess brothers’ supercharged rock ’n’ roll — all of which flourished despite violent segregation and a rugged, often corrupt, political scene.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Brick Mansions’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brick Mansions.”

headline: Who Killed Anna Mae?
text: On Feb. 24, 1976, a rancher in South Dakota was installing a fence on land situated along the edge of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation when he spotted a body at the bottom of a 30-foot embankment. The badly decomposed corpse, in jeans and a maroon ski jacket, lay with knees pushed up toward chest. A coroner later determined that the woman had been dead for more than two months. The back of her head was matted with blood, and there was a single bullet wound at the base of her skull. She had been shot at close range.

headline: Reading Message Headers in Gmail
text: Q. How do you see the full delivery path of a message in Gmail on the web?

headline: New York City in 17 Syllables
text: The New York Times asked readers to write a haiku about New York City. The response was as impressive as the city itself. A panel of judges chose their favorite entries.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: LOVERS AT THE CHAMELEON CLUB, PARIS 1932,  by Francine Prose. (Harper, $26.99.) Prose, a subtle psychologist, has created a genuinely evil character in Lou Villars, a cross-dressing French racecar driver and Nazi collaborator.

headline: Inside the List
text: Behind the Counter: The protagonist of Gabrielle Zevin’s novel “The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry” — new at No. 15 on the hardcover fiction list — is a cranky bookstore owner, depressed after the death of his wife and the theft of a prized volume, who gradually perks up while caring for a baby abandoned in his shop. Book buyers, it turns out, like to read about booksellers. In the past few years, other best-selling examples include “The Marriage Bargain,” by Jennifer Probst (a billionaire proposes to a bookstore owner), “Murder of a Bookstore Babe,” by Denise Swanson (death by shelving), and “Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore,” by Robin Sloan (a web designer finds a night job at a mysterious shop). Yet Zevin recently told readers of The National Post in Canada that as appealing as the idea of running a bookstore is in theory, in reality she’s just not interested. “I think this is the pet pipe dream of many of us who love books,” she said. “I sometimes like to imagine the kind of bookstore I would run. I have, for instance, a deeply impractical idea for a performance art space/minimalist bookstore. The bookstore would only sell one title a month, and there would be a play or art installation of some kind based around that book. However, this is all just fantasy. Running a bookstore is ridiculously difficult, and the challenges bookstores face — e-books, online competition — are enormous. I suspect the closest I’ll ever come to owning a bookstore is having written ‘The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry.’ ”

headline: On Their Death Bed, Physical Books Have Finally Become Sexy
text: A few years ago, I started noticing a small wave of a new kind of book: highly displayable coffee-table books about the display of books. They had names like “At Home With Books” and “Books Do Furnish a Room,” and felt a bit like an adjunct to that classic, recursive “Seinfeld” gag: Kramer’s coffee-table book about coffee tables that could double as a coffee table.

headline: When the Iron Horse (Almost) Played Tarzan
text: Seventy-five years ago this Fourth of July, Lou Gehrig, known as the Iron Horse, suffering from the fatal neurodegenerative disease that now bears his name, retired at 36 from baseball. Standing in Yankee Stadium before more than 60,000 fans, he made his unforgettable declaration that despite his “bad break,” he was “the luckiest man on the face of the earth.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘For No Good Reason’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “For No Good Reason.”

headline: Monty Python Reunion Show to Be Screened in Theaters
text: If you were dying to catch Monty Python’s reunion show at the 02 Arena in London but were not able to score a ticket, cheer up: the final night of the run, July 20, will be beamed in HD to 1,500 movie theaters around the world. Picturehouse Entertainment announced on Thursday that it had secured the international distribution rights to the show, which will be directed by Aubrey Powell and produced by Fiz Oliver.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The German Doctor’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The German Doctor.”

headline: Obama on Halt of Mideast Peace Talks
text: President Obama said he does not expect a prompt restart to the talks on Middle East peace, saying that neither Israelis nor Palestinians have shown the will to make tough decisions.

headline: Collapse of Peace Talks Gives Israel Easy Exit, but Leaves It in a Precarious Spot
text: JERUSALEM — Less than a month ago, Israel was in Secretary of State John Kerry’s cross hairs, accused of sabotaging the peace process he had championed by continuing construction in West Bank settlements and balking on a promise to release long-serving Palestinian prisoners. But when Israel suspended the stalemated negotiations on Thursday, it did so with Washington’s tacit blessing, providing a fractured government not fully committed to peace a low-risk exit strategy.

headline: A Policy-Making Mystery in the Renminbi’s Decline
text: HONG KONG — As President Obama visits Asia in a bid to shore up American alliances, he faces an emerging challenge from the region’s behemoth, China, whose currency has experienced a gradual but unrelenting decline over the last 10 days.

headline: Election Watchdog Fights Lonely Battle on Paid News Coverage
text: NEW DELHI — One of the biggest threats to a clean voting process in India, as identified by the Election Commission, is not only extremely difficult to police, it’s also perfectly legal.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
text: This week, William D. Cohan talks about “The Price of Silence”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the week’s literary news; Amy Chozick discusses Elizabeth Warren’s “A Fighting Chance”; Ms. Sehgal on Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Living With a Wild God”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: CreepShield Claims to Out the Creeps in Online Dating
text: As facial recognition software proliferates, some developers are bound to test our comfort level with the notion of strangers seeking to put a name to our faces whether we’re online or on the street.

headline: Quiche Meets Whole Wheat
text: I agree wholeheartedly with the Tufts nutrition professor Alice H. Lichtenstein’s recent letter to the editor in this newspaper, in which she writes, “Particularly in an era when dietary restraint is not our strong suit, returning to butter and fatty cuts of meat may likewise return us to the high rates of heart disease we had decades ago.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
text: This week, William D. Cohan, Amy Chozick and Parul Sehgal.

headline: Haiku Challenge: A Poet’s Picks
text: Marie Howe, the state poet of New York, reflects on writing haiku and The Times’s Haiku Challenge, which asked readers to submit a 17-syllable poem about New York City.

headline: The Most Important Question You Can Ask
text: When I heard this week that Michael Phelps was planning to return to competitive swimming, my first reaction was to feel a little sad for him. I honor Mr. Phelps for the discipline, grit and passion he needed to win a record 18 gold medals. But I also sense that he’s going back to swimming because he’s chasing a high that hasn’t held up.

headline: Pakistani Censorship, by Other Means
text: Raza Rumi, a prominent Pakistani journalist, narrowly escaped death on March 28 when his car was riddled with bullets in Lahore. His driver, Mustafa, a 25-year-old newlywed, was killed in the ambush, which took place as they were driving away from the set of Raza’s weekly television show on Express News. The topic that day had been how the country’s blasphemy laws are misused to persecute religious minorities in Pakistan, a regular subject for Raza.

headline: Steamed Clams With Spring Herbs
text: Melissa Clark makes steamed clams with fresh tarragon and minced chives.

headline: Fewer U.S. Graduates Opt for College After High School
text: THE proportion of new American high school graduates who go on to college — a figure that rose regularly for decades — now appears to be declining.

headline: Grilling Jon Favreau
text: In a cellphone video, The Times’s David Carr captured a bit of a recent interview with the director and star of the new film “Chef.”

headline: Jimmy Elliott, a Senior JPMorgan Deal Adviser, to Retire
text: Jimmy Elliott, one of JPMorgan Chase’s most senior deal makers, plans to retire, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: Pasta Is Not Their Only Habitat
