But there is also a tall lamppost, with two streetlights, in a corner by the tracks and beside the chalkboard. What is its significance?

headline: Slaves to Prejudice
text: WASHINGTON — WHEN a cranky anarchist in a cowboy hat starts a sentence saying “I want to tell you one more thing I know about the Negro,” you can be dang sure it’s going downhill from there.

headline: N.B.A. Investigating Racial Remarks Tied to Clippers Owner
text: MEMPHIS — The N.B.A. has promised a swift investigation into remarks attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, after the release Friday night of an audio recording on the gossip website TMZ.com in which a person TMZ identified as Mr. Sterling admonished a female friend to avoid being seen in public with black people.

headline: Scott Walker’s Prospects
text: Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, is being seen as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, and yet five years ago he was little known even in parts of his own state.

headline: Unlikely Cast for Yanks Pieces Together a Win
text: Despite all the Yankees’ off-season spending, there will be days when they will have to piece together a win with parts culled from the minor leagues.

headline: Militants Resist Calls to Free European Military Observers Held in Eastern Ukraine
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Antigovernment militants in eastern Ukraine on Saturday rebuffed international calls for the release of a group of European military observers, but suggested that they would consider a prisoner exchange.

headline: Team Founded by Unhappy Fans May Buy the Club They Abandoned
text: TEL AVIV — Breaking up the soccer club they loved was hard for fans of Hapoel Katamon Jerusalem. Putting it back together may prove even more difficult.

headline: Paul Cedes Some Control, at Least Until Game Is on the Line
text: Los Angeles Clippers guard Chris Paul is widely regarded as the premier point guard of his generation, a Hall of Fame contender who is a genius with the ball in his hands and a disruptive defensive presence. He has made first team all-N.B.A. three times and finished in the top five in most valuable player voting four times. But for all his accolades, Paul lags behind his peers in postseason accomplishments.

headline: Wizards Relish the Playoffs and the Long Lines
text: WASHINGTON — When Richard Galiffa went to grab a snack during halftime of Friday’s Washington Wizards game, he noticed something strange clogging the concourse of Verizon Center: dozens of men standing in a line.

headline: Coaching Duo Adjusts for Family
text: One of hockey’s more unusual coaching arrangements turned out to be one of the most successful, as Clarkson won the N.C.A.A. women’s title last month under the husband-and-wife team of Matt and Shannon Desrosiers.

headline: Recapturing Heart of a Derby Upset
text: When the filmmaker and horse owner Jim Wilson watched on television as the gelding Mine That Bird squirted through a hole on the rail in the homestretch to run away with the 2009 Kentucky Derby, he knew the story was movie material. An even deeper story emerged as Mine That Bird’s jockey, Calvin Borel, succumbed to his emotions, and the horse’s connections, the trainer Chip Woolley and the owners Mark Allen and Dr. Leonard Blach, gathered in the winner’s circle.

headline: Predictable Partings
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people have a high tolerance for puns, and others have a much lower threshold. I consider Tom Swifty-style puns to be the “pie-in-the-face,” slapstick form of puns, because they are just so obvious.

headline: World Champion Shows Vulnerability in Azerbaijan
text: It once seemed almost impossible to defeat a world champion.

headline: In California, a Fevered Rush for Gun Permits
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Pete Alexander celebrated the news that a federal court in California had thrown out this state’s strict requirements for obtaining a concealed-handgun permit — among the toughest in the nation — by calling the Orange County Sheriff’s Department to apply for a permit he had long wanted.

headline: Nature Is All Around, but an Ornate House Is a Draw in Islip
text: The Suffolk County Environmental Center in Islip sees far more outdoor than indoor visitors. Nature enthusiasts flock to the 70-acre property’s expansive salt marsh, forests and freshwater wetlands, as well as to the outdoor education programs put on by the Seatuck Environmental Association, the nonprofit conservation group that runs the center for the county.

headline: Old Story in Politics Resonates in New Era
text: An ambitious female politician, well-regarded by her constituents but not very well known outside of Texas, delivers a galvanizing speech that thrusts her into the national spotlight. Seizing her political moment, she runs for governor — and soon finds herself in a knock-down, drag-out fight with the male, Republican-establishment candidate.

headline: Yonkers as Gallery
text: A video installation in a pop-up gallery, a fashion show in a garden, artist studio tours — these and more are part of the first Yonkers Arts Weekend. Organized by the City of Yonkers, the event next weekend aims to showcase the breadth of artistic activity throughout the city with exhibitions, performances and public art.

headline: Once a Legislator, Now an Underdog Trying to Return
text: EL PASO — In a modest office in east central El Paso, former State Representative Norma Chávez spoke recently of her spiritual journey and weekly prayer group, and how she is 30 pounds lighter after adopting a healthier lifestyle. It is all part of a new perspective on life that she hopes will usher her back into the State Legislature after four years away from Austin.

headline: How a Gulf Settlement That BP Once Hailed Became Its Target
text: NEW ORLEANS — Four years ago the Deepwater Horizon oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 men, spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and staining, seemingly indelibly, the image of BP, the international energy giant responsible for the well.

headline: New Law Is Limiting Standardized Tests, but Not Prep Work
text: When Texas legislators passed a law in 2013 that sharply reduced standardized testing for public high school students, they included a provision aimed at easing the pressure of high-stakes exams for students in lower grades as well.

headline: Easy to Target, but Often Hard to Send Packing
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: A Marriage of Visual Masters
text: “Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it.” These oft-cited instructions were written by Jasper Johns as directives to himself, and they are particularly suited to his work in printmaking, with its multi-stepped process and its toolbox of techniques. But to “do something” and then “do something else” when printing requires skilled assistance.

headline: The History of Religion, Beginning with Noah and his Wife, Joan of Arc
text: My Sunday column looks at the importance of humanities, not least an area that even humanities enthusiasts sometimes scoff at–religious knowledge. My column argues that if we want to understand the world, it helps to know a bit about the world’s religions, including the world of Pentecostals and evangelicals that rarely make the news. I became interested in the role of religion in part in 2000 when I covered the campaign of George W. Bush, for it was clear that he was connecting to a large number of Americans through his faith, and I had only the vaguest idea at the time what an evangelical was. Then in covering America and the developing world alike, I was struck by the extraordinary surge in Pentecostal churches, and by their influence over so many people around the world.

headline: My Head Talks Yet Again
text: On Stephanopoulos tomorrow. As I understand it, William Kristol and I will debate whether multiplicative shocks to wealth accumulation really do cause the right tail of the distribution to approximate a power law.

headline: The Elegance of Clattering Machines
text: The labels alone make a racket: Meiselbach, Blickensderfer, Bar-Lock. No wonder the show-namers at the New Britain Museum of American Art call their fabulous little exhibition of antique typewriters “Click! Clack! Ding!”

headline: One Mother, 7 Dead Newborns and a Stunned Community in Utah
text: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah — For Megan Huntsman, life was a miserable struggle. Her marriage decayed into substance abuse and violence, she told people close to her. Her ailing father’s suicide pitched her into despair and heavy drinking. Illness ravaged her family. She lost her job at a supermarket bakery and spent recent days alone at her boyfriend’s trailer home.

headline: In Poorest States, Political Stigma Is Depressing Participation in Health Law
text: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. — Inside the sleek hillside headquarters of Valley Health Systems, built with a grant from the health care law, two employees played an advertisement they had helped produce to promote the law’s insurance coverage for young, working-class West Virginians.

headline: A Hidden Chapter in World War II History
text: In 2009, Roger Grunwald, an actor, traveled to Los Angeles to interview his aunt, Anne M. Bodenheimer, about her experiences in World War II, including in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. His mother, Lotte, Mrs. Bodenheimer’s sister, had survived Auschwitz and had often spoken to young people about her history.

headline: Mollusks, but No Tiles, No Trains
text: This is not your commuter’s Grand Central Oyster Bar. What gave it away? Is it that at the Brooklyn outpost of the Grand Central Oyster Bar there’s actual space to relax and a decibel level conducive to conversation?

headline: Scots Ponder: Should They Stay or Should They Go?
text: EDINBURGH — The Royal Lyceum Theater here has a modest hit on its hands, a slightly scabrous play that tells the story of Scotland’s parliamentary vote to dissolve itself and join the kingdom of England in 1707.

headline: New York Finds Space for 3 Charter Schools
text: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Saturday that it has found space for three charter schools that had been at the heart of a battle between the new mayor and Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a high-performing charter network.

headline: Bruins Advance and Are Set to Rekindle Rivalry
text: BOSTON — Chants of “We Want the Cup” reverberated through TD Garden on Saturday in the final minutes of the Boston Bruins’ 4-2 Game 5 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. But while the fans were happy to usher the Red Wings out of the arena and the series, they were no doubt looking toward the Bruins’ next matchup, against the vaunted and hated Montreal Canadiens.

headline: George McDonald, 90, Dies; Union Leader Helped Save Newspaper Jobs
text: George E. McDonald, a union leader who helped navigate organized labor’s orderly retreat from its peak of power in the New York newspaper industry at the end of the century and, by some accounts, helped save the city’s surviving tabloids, died last Sunday in Monmouth Park, N.J. He was 90.

headline: South Korean Prime Minister Offers to Resign Over Deadly Ferry Disaster
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, a vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

headline: N.B.A. Commissioner Promises Swift Investigation of Remarks
text: MEMPHIS — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Saturday night that the league planned to pursue a swift investigation of the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, after the release of an audio recording in which Sterling was alleged to have made racially charged remarks.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 26, 2014
text: April 26, 2014

headline: Mahmoud Abbas Shifts on Holocaust
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement on Sunday calling the Holocaust “the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era” and expressing sympathy with victims’ families.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: The Clones Versus the Monitors
text: As he lay dying, a wise man once told Agent Scully on “The X-Files” to “Trust no one.”

headline: David W. Burke, Trusted Aide to Powerful Men, Dies at 78
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy had a habit of taking long walks with his closest aide, David W. Burke, before making big decisions. As secretary to Gov. Hugh L. Carey, Mr. Burke helped New York City navigate the 1970s fiscal crisis, partly by recommending that he hire Felix Rohatyn as financial wizard in chief.

headline: Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade
text: Bill de Blasio, third from left, attended the Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade in Midtown on Saturday.

headline: A Young Pitcher and Catcher Show They Still Need Work
text: Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ 25-year-old second-year catcher, is only eight months older than starting pitcher Jenrry Mejia, but d’Arnaud knows that his input is just as crucial to Mejia’s growth as the blazing fastballs that come out of his electric right arm.

headline: A Disturbing Tape and a Potential Moral Quandary
text: In one of his popular songs of black consciousness, Curtis Mayfield asked: “If you had a choice of colors, which one would you choose, my brothers? If there was no day or night, which would you prefer to be right?”

headline: Reaction to the Remarks Linked to Donald Sterling
text: President Obama condemned the “incredibly offensive racist statements” attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling during a press conference on Sunday in Malaysia.

headline: Ravindra GuneWardena and Frank Escher
text: Ravindra Anthony Sampath GuneWardena and Frank Christian Escher were married Saturday by the Rev. Tom Carey, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of the Epiphany in Los Angeles.

headline: Sheila Rustgi, Corey Morenz
text: Sheila Devi Rustgi, a daughter of Eileen M. Boyle of Potomac, Md., and Dr. Vinod K. Rustgi of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday evening to Corey James Morenz, a son of Carol G. Morenz and Art Morenz of Thomaston, Conn. The Rev. Louis V. Schwebius, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Decatur House in Washington.

headline: Catherine Strzelczyk, Kenneth Vaz
text: Catherine Anne Strzelczyk, a daughter of Maria A. Strzelczyk of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Bruce J. Strzelczyk, was married Saturday to Dr. Kenneth Mark Vaz, the son of Judy J. Vaz and Edward G. Vaz of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. James Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculata Church in San Diego.

headline: It All Started on the Playground
text: Dr. Lark Julie Greenwald and Dr. Zachary David Guss are to be married Sunday evening at the Coronado Community Center in Coronado, Calif., with Rabbi Michael Satz officiating.

headline: Todd Cross, Rodney Wright
text: Todd Franklin Cross and Dr. Rodney Lorne Wright were married Saturday evening at the Eventi Hotel in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Jon Walton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Gabriella de Araujo and Alexander Iannaccone
text: Gabriella Kristina de Araujo and Alexander Lawrence Iannaccone were married Saturday at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Stephanie Shestakow, George Federici
text: Stephanie Lorraine Shestakow, a daughter of Jane M. Shestakow and Nicholas Shestakow of Jackson, N.J., was married Saturday to George Ralph Federici, a son of Lynda M. Federici and Dr. George E. Federici of Maple Glen, Pa. The Rev. Patrick J. Tonry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph’s Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Katherine Hubert, Peter Chan
text: Dr. Katherine Cheney Hubert and Dr. Peter Gar-Jun Chan were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan L. Walton, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard.

headline: Ilyssa McIntyre, Clarke Smith
text: Ilyssa Jenna McIntyre, the daughter of Mary K. McIntyre and Robert W. McIntyre of Florham Park, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Clarke McIntyre Smith, a son of Rebecca B. Smith of Norfolk, Va., and the late John L. Smith Jr. The Rev. Mark R. Collins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

headline: Jordan Carqueville, Marc Wezowski
text: Dr. Jordan Claire Carqueville and Marc Richard Wezowski were married Saturday evening in Naples, Fla. The Rev. John Ludden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church.

headline: Sarah Spigelman, Joshua Richter
text: Sarah Elizabeth Ward Spigelman and Dr. Joshua Ryan Richter were married Saturday by Rabbi Steve Blane at the Essex House in Manhattan.

headline: Daniel Gramkee, Scott Kleinbart
text: Daniel Thomas Gramkee and Scott Neil Kleinbart were married Saturday at the Soldiers’, Sailors’, Marines’, Coast Guard and Airmen’s Club in New York. Michael R. Sonberg, an acting State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, officiated.

headline: Charlotte Evans, Tyler Will
text: Charlotte Fulton Sergeant Evans and Tyler William Will were married Saturday at the bride’s family home in Brookville, N.Y. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Laura Perretta, Alan Tabak
text: Dr. Laura Joanne Perretta and Alan Joseph Tabak were married Saturday at Saint Anthony of Padua Church in West Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher W. Monturo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Julia Emanuel, Eric Feinstein
text: Julia Mae Emanuel, the daughter of Ann M. Emanuel of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Dr. David J. Emanuel, was married Saturday evening to Eric Matthew Feinstein, a son of Jane B. Feinstein and Dr. Peter A. Feinstein of Shavertown, Pa. Rabbi Larry Kaplan officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

headline: Ronit Feldman, Eric Wagman
text: Ronit Feldman and Eric Wagman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Miriam Jerris at the Colony Club in Detroit.

headline: Rachana Dixit, Neeraj Pradhan
text: Rachana Dixit and Neeraj Bahadur Pradhan were married Saturday at Foxchase Manor, an event space in Manassas, Va. Pandit Laksuman Bhandari, a Vedic Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Victoria Corder, Anthony Langelier
text: Victoria Vance Corder and Anthony Charles Langelier were married Saturday at the Dixon Gallery and Gardens in Memphis. The Rev. James Phelan Biedenharn III, an Episcopal priest,officiated.

headline: Marianne Strazza, Jonathan Weinstein
text: Marianne Strazza and Jonathan Daniel Weinstein were married Saturday at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church in Huguenot, Staten Island. Msgr. Vincent Bartley performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Scott Matous assisting.

headline: Whitney Cale, Peter Brejcha
text: Whitney Rawn Cale and Peter Thomas Brejcha were married Saturday at the Parish of St. Matthew in Los Angeles. The Rev. Lester V. Mackenzie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rebecca Aledort, Daniel Ryan
text: Rebecca Joy Aledort and Daniel Andrew Ryan were married Saturday evening at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y. Rabbi Brian Denker-Youngs officiated.

headline: Anne Evans and David Hendrickson
text: Anne Morrill Evans, a daughter of Sarah E. Cogan and Douglas H. Evans of New York, was married Saturday to David Charles Hendrickson, a son of Judy M. Hendrickson and James L. Hendrickson of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. J. Donald Waring, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Church in New York.

headline: Rebecca Kahan and Craig Waldman
text: Rebecca Sarah Kahan, a daughter of Betsy B. Kahan and Dr. Ronald S. Kahan of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Craig Scott Waldman, a son of Joan F. Waldman and Lawrence J. Waldman of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Richard M. Berman, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated, with Rabbi Andrew Gordon taking part, at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Brooke Lyons and Maximillian Osswald
text: Brooke Lyons and Maximillian Antony Osswald were married Saturday in Ojai, Calif., at the home of Helene Gordon, a friend of the bride’s family. Jonathon Fries, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, assisted by Eleanor Rutledge-Leverenz, another friend who became a Universal Life minister.

headline: Muna Shikaki and Clinton Reach
text: Muna Khalil Shikaki and Clinton Bruce Reach were married Saturday at the home of the groom’s mother, Anita A. Reach of Kansas City, Kan. Ryan Callahan, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: A Conversation Began and Never Stopped
text: Clara Bingham and Joseph Gregory Finnerty III were married Saturday at the River Café in Brooklyn. Mayor Bill de Blasio officiated.

headline: Counterpoints to Offensive Remarks
text: A report that Donald Sterling made offensive remarks about black players elicited swift reaction on social media. Current and former players, entertainers and ordinary people chimed in using hashtags like #DonaldSterling, #Sterling and #boycottclippers.

headline: Superstars Come Second to Culture at Jazzfest
text: NEW ORLEANS — If you talk to someone in the music business these days about outdoor festivals, you’ll probably hear a lot about electronic dance music, or E.D.M. Big name-D.J.’s have become part of the formula for any major pop festival, and there is even a publicly traded company, SFX Entertainment, devoted to attracting corporate sponsors to dance events.

headline: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration imposed sanctions on individual Russians last month in response to Moscow’s armed intervention in Ukraine, one of the targets was a longtime part-owner of a commodities trading company called the Gunvor Group.

headline: Corrections: April 27, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: China Orders 4 U.S. Shows Off Streaming Sites
text: BEIJING — Chinese regulators have ordered streaming video websites nationwide to take down four popular American TV series, a move that precedes new regulations seeking to close a loophole that has allowed foreign shows to flourish online, even as censors have limited them on broadcast television.

headline: South Korean Leader Accepts Resignation of Premier Over Ferry Disaster
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, the vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

headline: In Malaysia, Obama Works to Mend Troubled Ties
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The last time a top American official visited this Southeast Asian nation was in 1998, when Vice President Al Gore publicly rebuked its leaders for suppressing freedom and embraced “reformasi,” the rallying cry of the student-led protest movement.

headline: In Our Pages: April 28
text: 1939: Cheese Parties in N.Y. to Promote French Products

headline: A Fully Wrought Life – Stones Pianist, Tree Farmer, Green Blog Pioneer
text: Any time you think you’re packing as much into your life as is humanly possible, you meet someone who has taken things to another level.

headline: On Historic Day, John XXIII and John Paul II Become Saints
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis made history on Sunday, elevating to sainthood John XXIII and John Paul II, two of his most famous papal predecessors, in a ceremony bearing themes of hope and reconciliation for the world’s one billion Roman Catholics.

headline: When a Working Grandma Can’t Afford to Babysit, a Tradition Ends
text: My mother trudged down the stairs of her Staten Island townhouse this past Christmas Day, head slumped down, Eeyore-style. Even with my inherited poor eyesight, I could see from her modest kitchen table that the lenses on her dark, plastic glasses, a pair only a hip 57-year-old could pull off, were fogged up.

headline: France Defers G.E. Plan to Buy Energy Business
text: PARIS – The French government on Sunday sought to put the brakes on General Electric‘s bid for Alstom, one of the largest industrial companies in France, warning that national interest was in play and that the state would have a say in the outcome.

headline: For Fitness Bands, Slick Marketing but Suspect Results
text: My Nike FuelBand read lazy. My friend’s read fit.

headline: U.S. and Philippines Agree to a 10-Year Pact on the Use of Military Bases
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The United States has reached a 10-year agreement with the Philippines that will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the archipelago, American officials said Sunday.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (OWN) RUNNING FROM CRAZY (2013) Mariel Hemingway — in her own words: “tall blonde, no problems” — discusses the famous ancestry and mental health challenges of her family, including the suicides of her grandfather Ernest Hemingway and her sister Margaux, in this documentary directed by Barbara Kopple and commissioned by Oprah Winfrey’s OWN channel. Ms. Kopple follows Ms. Hemingway, above, while she visits her family, including her daughters, Dree and Langley, and other sister, Joan, a.k.a. Muffet; gives speeches on her wellness regime; and works out with a male companion. “ ‘Running From Crazy’ — the title is Ms. Hemingway’s phrasing — doesn’t entirely escape the dangers of the confessional profile,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But Ms. Kopple shows how people in Ms. Hemingway’s position, with a family history of mental health problems, confront a foreboding mirror, whether or not it also reflects a literary heritage and a Kennedy-grade bone structure.”

headline: A String Quartet Sits, in Solidarity, and Delivers Shostakovich
text: The Emerson String Quartet, according to its standard biography, “stands apart in the history of string quartets.” It’s a wink toward one of the things that makes this venerable ensemble special: cellist aside, its members stand, rather than sit.

headline: ‘The Other Woman’ Tops the Box Office But Overall Sales Drop
text: Updated, 12:52 p.m. | Moviegoers took a break this weekend as receipts for the top 10 films dropped 17.1 percent from last weekend, to $96.4 million.

headline: Butterflies (Nearly) Over Brooklyn
text: To Judy Chicago’s list of accomplishments add control of the weather. The rain ended in Brooklyn on Saturday night just in time for a crowd of about 10,000 in Prospect Park to see her pyrotechnic display, “A Butterfly for Brooklyn.” And it started up again just after most spectators would have made it to the subway for the trip home.

headline: Syria Misses New Deadline as It Works to Purge Arms
text: GENEVA — Syria missed a revised deadline on Sunday for completing the export or destruction of chemicals in its weapons arsenal, but the government of the war-ravaged country may be only days away from finishing the job, according to international experts overseeing the process.

headline: Detainees in Ukraine Uncertain of Return
text: A group of European military observers, detained since Friday, appeared before journalists in a news conference in Slovyansk on Sunday.

headline: Pro-Russian Forces in Ukraine Free One of 8 Detainees
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The self-appointed mayor of this breakaway city in eastern Ukraine on Sunday displayed eight detained members of a European military observer mission and later released one for health reasons, but otherwise refused to discuss conditions under which the others might go free beyond mentioning a possible prisoner exchange.

headline: National Pride Swells the Crowds for a Polish Saint
text: VATICAN CITY — Thousands of Polish pilgrims traveled to Rome on Sunday for the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, driven by reverence for a towering historic figure and by national pride.

headline: In New Home, Bronx Dance Academy Seeks to Step Up Its Presence
text: Arthur Aviles knows how to balance. He can jump onto a pedestal, strike a loose-limbed pose then leap to the ground. Once upon terra firma, he confronts an even more delicate balance: how to ensure the future of his group, the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, as it settles into a new home and a new neighborhood and — he hopes — attracts new audiences and backers.

headline: Vows: Orchestrating a Proposal
text: Peter Chan proposed to Kate Hubert with a musical flourish just nine months after they met.

headline: After Pushing Flyers to Brink, Rangers Look to Hone Killer Instinct
text: The Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden on Sunday and grabbed a 3-2 lead in their opening-round playoff series. But if they hope to close out the series when it shifts to Philadelphia on Tuesday night, they will have to face down not only the Flyers, but also their own baffling inability to press an advantage.

headline: New Space, New Conversations for ICP
text: The International Center for Photography may be moving, but its director fully intends to keep it at the center of conversations that explain and explore image-making in the 21st Century.

headline: A European Energy Executive’s Delicate Dance Over Ukraine
text: LONDON — European executives, especially in the energy industry, have been notably wary of ratcheting up economic tensions with Russia over the Ukraine crisis. They see their business interests as too intertwined to risk stiffer sanctions.

headline: A Matriarch With Stories to Tell and a Love of Swing to Share
text: “What a life!” “I’m in heaven!” “Look at what I’ve got!”

headline: Fleeing Conflict in South Sudan
text: Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin, a photographer, followed one family’s harrowing escape to safety.

headline: After a Drowning, Musical Bones Wash Ashore
text: Tragic love stories, whether real or fictional, have provided fodder for poets, playwrights and composers for millenniums. An installment of the composer David Lang’s “collected stories” series at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening highlighted a particularly gruesome story of love gone awry, with a Celtic folk song about sibling rivalry.

headline: Amid Uproar, Clippers Silently Display Solidarity
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Los Angeles Clippers, reacting to recordings of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling, the team’s owner, took the court for their playoff game Sunday with a statement, one of both fashion and politics.

headline: Two Brothers in the Icy Grip of Midlife
text: Michael Cunningham’s resonant new novel, “The Snow Queen,” takes its title from the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale of the same name about the redemptive powers of love and its ability to melt even the chilliest of hearts.

headline: Celebrating a Poem and a Novel by James Baldwin, With Movement
text: With its annual Live Ideas festival, New York Live Arts, an institution generally devoted to dance, opens its doors to a wider range of programming. The curatorial approach, so far, involves unpacking the work of a cultural figure who bridges many fields of inquiry, the body included. Last year’s theme was “The Worlds of Oliver Sacks.” This year, it’s “James Baldwin, This Time!” (with “This” underlined for emphasis). That Harlem-born writer and activist would have been 90 this August, and Live Arts is one of several New York organizations celebrating “The Year of James Baldwin,” an extended (and timely) reflection on his social and literary achievements.

headline: Swiss Teams at the Sagamore Bridge Club in Syosset, N.Y.
text: In a recent column, I mentioned that bridge club attendance has been hurt by the online sites. This is true even in the New York City area and New Jersey, which, according to the American Contract Bridge League, together had five of the top nine most successful clubs in North America in terms of tables in play last year.

headline: Confidence on the Rise for Gee and the Mets
text: When General Manager Sandy Alderson declared before the season that the Mets’ goal was to win 90 games, the statement was mocked and ridiculed (and it may still be). Some fans wondered if the Mets were delusional.

headline: ‘Chef’ and ‘Keep On’ Win Tribeca Audience Awards
text: At the Tribeca Film Festival on Saturday, audience awards were handed out to “Chef,” for best narrative feature, and “Keep On Keepin’ On,” for best documentary. The two films were chosen by festivalgoers who cast ballots on their way out of screenings.

headline: Hoping to End a Dubious Streak
text: One of the most famous and popular American plays, it turns out, is also one of the most slighted in Broadway history.

headline: A Conductor, Rehired, Now Must Rebuild
text: WASHINGTON — Osmo Vanska is suddenly a man in a hurry. Mr. Vanska, the Finnish conductor, bode his time as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra through the first year of management’s lockout of the players (which eventually ran to 16 months, ending in February) during a contract dispute, but resigned out of frustration in October. He was reinstated last Thursday, to start officially this Thursday.

headline: A Gaming Company Devoted to Narrative Tackles ‘Thrones’
text: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — Behind closed doors and papered-over windows here, a half-dozen storytellers have been scrambling to conjure a fantasy world with compelling characters, fierce dialogue and an intricate plot. But this is no ordinary writers’ room: It’s Telltale Games, an independent video game studio that has developed an intense following by prizing nuance and narrative in an industry more often associated with clattering machine guns and screeching getaway cars.

headline: Star Stand-Ins
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — And the award for Longest Hiatus Between Published Puzzles goes to … Jim Modney! I understand how life can get in the way of constructing, but I really think Mr. Modney deserves a round of applause for his nearly 30-year break in puzzle-making.

headline: Museum Draws Donatello From Italy
text: New York City, home to a stunning number of Renaissance treasures, has never had a work in a permanent collection by one of the era’s foremost sculptural masters, Donatello, and major pieces by him rarely leave Europe. But for a few months next year, the city will become a veritable Donatello feast, the one stop for a small show of works from the Duomo museum in Florence, Italy, including several sculptures instantly recognizable from art history textbooks but never before seen in America.

headline: A Caper by the Coens, With a Fake Monet
text: Silently slipped into a single theater like a heist in reverse, “Gambit” is getting the sort of American release you might not expect given its cast and a screenplay written, at some point in the film’s hot-potato history, by the Coen brothers. This nominal remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine has all the fizz of flat soda, but it’s not catastrophically worse than any number of films that open widely.

headline: Updates on Tech Companies and Job Numbers
text: INVESTORS WATCH TWITTER FOR FURTHER STAGNATION

headline: Years After Chernobyl, Building Progress
text: At the Chernobyl nuclear plant, a rising arch is a sign of a cleanup’s progress, and the remains of Pripyat, a city once home to 45,000, is a reminder of the devastation of 1986.

headline: Forced to Flee Radiation, Fearful Japanese Villagers Are Reluctant to Return
text: MIYAKOJI, Japan — Ever since they were forced to evacuate during the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant three years ago, Kim Eunja and her husband have refused to return to their hilltop home amid the majestic mountains of this rural village for fear of radiation.

headline: Few Consumers Are Buying Premise of Mobile Wallets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions of Americans use smartphones for tasks like hailing a taxi or checking in for a flight. But for buying something in a store? That mostly remains a tech entrepreneur’s dream.

headline: Kerr Says He Discussed Knicks Job With Jackson
text: Steve Kerr dined with the new Knicks president, Phil Jackson, in Manhattan on Friday to discuss the team’s head-coaching vacancy, Kerr said Sunday at Barclays Center, where he was preparing to work as an analyst for TNT for a playoff game between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Secular Stagnation
text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Qaddafi Son Appears on Screen at His Trial
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, facing accusations that he aided his father, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in the brutal suppression of Libya’s uprising three years ago, was not allowed to appear in court in person on Sunday to answer the charges.

headline: Wheeldon’s ‘Alice’ to Play in New York
text: The Joyce Theater Foundation and the National Ballet of Canada plan to announce on Monday that they will present the New York premiere of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with choreography by Christopher Wheeldon. Set to an original score by Joby Talbot and with costume and set designs by Bob Crowley, the production of the Lewis Carroll classic is scheduled to run from Sept. 9 to 14 at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center. Mr. Wheeldon’s interpretation of “Alice” had its premiere at the Royal Opera House in London in 2011. Tickets go on sale Monday and will be available at davidhkochtheater.com and by calling 212-496-0600.

headline: New Challenges Chip Away at Cable’s Pillar of Profit
text: For decades, cable television has been an almost magical source of profits, in large part because of the bundle, the packaging of channels that compels subscribers to buy a lot of programming they never watch.

headline: Nuclear Industry Gains Carbon-Focused Allies in Push to Save Reactors
text: Environmentalists and the nuclear industry are beginning a push to preserve old nuclear reactors whose economic viability is threatened by cheap natural gas and rising production of wind energy. They argue that while natural gas and wind are helpful as sources of electricity with little or no production of greenhouse gases, national climate goals will be unreachable if zero-carbon nuclear reactors are phased out.

headline: Putin Rival Takes Message to East Ukraine
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Not for the first time in his life, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian former tycoon suddenly freed from jail in December by President Vladimir V. Putin, was on a somewhat quixotic mission.

headline: John Houbolt, NASA Innovator Behind Lunar Module, Dies at 95
text: On May 25, 1961, President John F. Kennedy told Congress that the United States should commit to landing a man on the moon before the end of the decade.

headline: On Bridges in Paris, Clanking With Love
text: PARIS — Johannes and Melissa. David and Michaela. Ben and Justin.

headline: Despite Big Ambitions, New York’s Tech Scene Is Still Starting Up
text: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely — as New York is slowly finding out.

headline: Soured Mortgages Attract Institutional Dollars
text: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.

headline: Home Décor Retailer CB2 Invites Pinterest Users to Furnish Apartment
text: MORE visitors to the website for CB2, the home décor chain owned by Crate & Barrel, come from Pinterest, the virtual bulletin board, than any other social network. Now CB2 is turning to Pinterest users to weigh in on decorating an apartment the company has rented in New York.

headline: Cholera and Clean Water
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Does Buddhism Require?
text: This is the fifth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Jay L. Garfield, who has taught philosophy at several universities and is currently the Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple Professor of Humanities, Yale-NUS College in Singapore. He is at work on a book called “Engaging Buddhism: Why Buddhism Matters to Contemporary Philosophy.”

headline: The Role of the Clergy in Helping the Mentally Ill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Should Doctors Care About Cost?
By Digitizing Images, Museum Opens a Window Into the Past
text: Fully a century before Sarah Palin declared that Alaska was “just right over the border” from Russia, an expedition fielded by the American Museum of Natural History in New York sought to prove that the first people to reach the Americas had indeed migrated across the frozen Bering Strait.

headline: The War on Truth in Ukraine
text: WASHINGTON — For a moment last week, war seemed imminent. A day after Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned Ukraine’s leaders against using force in the crisis there, the Ukrainian military attacked a checkpoint outside the separatist-held town of Slovyansk. Russian forces across the border responded with maneuvers labeled “exercises,” coupled with statements from the Kremlin that amounted to “you were warned.” Russian television made Slovyansk look like Guernica; Ukrainian news media reported that separatist militants were using kindergartners as human shields.

headline: Epix Plans to Introduce Film on Altman
text: LOS ANGELES — Altmanesque: Possessing a mysterious quality that makes you want to watch more movies.

headline: Health Law’s Pay Policy Is Skewed, Panel Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Federal policies to reward high-quality health care are unfairly penalizing doctors and hospitals that treat large numbers of poor people, according to a new report commissioned by the Obama administration that recommends sweeping changes in payment policy.

headline: The Wire Next Time
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — LAST week’s proposal by the Federal Communications Commission to allow Internet service providers to charge different rates to different online content companies — effectively ending the government’s commitment to net neutrality — set off a flurry of protest.

headline: ‘Smart’ Firearm Draws Wrath of the Gun Lobby
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Belinda Padilla does not pick up unknown calls anymore, not since someone posted her cellphone number on an online forum for gun enthusiasts. A few fuming-mad voice mail messages and heavy breathers were all it took.

headline: A Versatile Shark Quietly Makes a Major Difference
text: LOS ANGELES — San Jose Sharks forward Joe Pavelski has shown as much talent for avoiding the limelight as he has for eluding opposing defensemen.

headline: Milq Aims to Separate Wheat From Social Media Chaff
text: Social media users know the frustration: a deluge of videos, images and music clips flows through their news feeds all the time, some of it precious (Miles Davis discussing Prince!), but mostly not (Here’s what I ate for breakfast!).

headline: U.S. Weighs Harder Line on Russia Than European Allies
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and his national security team struggle to increase pressure on Russia over its intervention in Ukraine, they have become entangled in a tense debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies more reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow.

headline: Supreme Court Taking Up Police Searches of Data Troves Known as Cellphones
text: WASHINGTON — In a major test of how to interpret the Fourth Amendment in the digital age, the Supreme Court on Tuesday will consider two cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of the people they arrest.

headline: Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?
text: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, a lawyer becomes embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

headline: Veteran Rangers Center Provides Big Lift
text: Dominic Moore added an exclamation point to his memorable comeback season when he scored an unassisted second-period goal Sunday afternoon that proved to be the winner in the Rangers’ 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Despite Twitter Backlash, New York Police Dept. Plans to Expand Social Media Efforts
text: For the first few months of his second tour as commissioner of the New York Police Department, William J. Bratton has been consumed in large part with reshaping perceptions of officers.

headline: ‘Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?’
text: In 2012, on my Facebook feed, I stumbled across a hilarious excerpt from a legal transcript. In a deposition in Ohio, a lawyer became embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

headline: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing
text: A few miles from the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn stands an outpost of what, on paper, is a giant of American medicine.

headline: Recovery Has Created Far More Low-Wage Jobs Than Better-Paid Ones
text: WASHINGTON — The deep recession wiped out primarily high-wage and middle-wage jobs. Yet the strongest employment growth during the sluggish recovery has been in low-wage work, at places like strip malls and fast-food restaurants.

headline: No Accounting Skills? No Moral Reckoning
text: SOMETIMES it seems as if our lives are dominated by financial crises and failed reforms. But how much do Americans even understand about finance? Few of us can do basic accounting and fewer still know what a balance sheet is. If we are going to get to the point where we can have a serious debate about financial accountability, we first need to learn some essentials.

headline: In Venezuela, Protesters Point to Their Scars
text: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Clipso Martínez was shot at such close range by a soldier at a protest that his surgeon said he had to remove pieces of the plastic shotgun shell buried in his leg, along with the shards of keys Mr. Martínez had in his pocket, shattered by the blast.

headline: In Complex Mess, a Question of Who Has Leverage
text: Of the two most leveraged presidents to have weighed in on the Donald Sterling audio imbroglio, a fairly loquacious Barack Obama was the less significant voice. What little Chris Paul, president of the National Basketball Players Association, had to say could potentially have far more impact on how the league might proceed on this complex, evolving and exceedingly troubling story.

headline: Gay Rights Push Shifts Its Focus South and West
text: The country’s leading gay rights groups and donors, after a decade focused on legalizing same-sex marriage, are embarking on a major drive to win more basic civil rights and workplace protections in Southern and Western states where the rapid progress of the movement has largely eluded millions of gay men and lesbians.

headline: Experimental Efforts to Harvest the Ocean’s Power Face Cost Setbacks
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — At the Port of Portland sits a 260-ton buoy filled with technology that can turn the movement of the ocean into electricity to power 100 homes. It rolled off an assembly line to great fanfare two years ago and received the nation’s first commercial license to operate.

headline: Caution Ahead for Municipal IDs
text: Two New York City Council members, Daniel Dromm and Carlos Menchaca, have introduced a bill to create a municipal photo-ID card that all New Yorkers could use, even those without legal immigration status. This excellent idea has the strong support of the Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, and Mayor Bill de Blasio, so it seems likely that New York will soon join cities like San Francisco and New Haven in achieving a goal that immigrant-rights advocates have long striven for: documenting the undocumented.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 28
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular Monday auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week bills, one-year bills and two-year floating rate notes on Tuesday.

headline: One Year After Rana Plaza
text: A horrendous building collapse last April in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment workers. Labor groups, Western clothing companies, the Bangladeshi government and others have made some progress toward preventing similar tragedies, but more needs to be done.

headline: Given Cause to Make a Stand, the Clippers Settle for a Gesture
text: Why not remain seated?

headline: Smartphones and the 4th Amendment
text: More than 90 percent of American adults own a mobile phone, and more than half of the devices are smartphones. But “smartphone” is a misnomer. They are personal computers that happen to include a phone function, and like any computer they can store or wirelessly retrieve enormous amounts of personal information: emails, photos and videos; document files; financial and medical records; and virtually everywhere a person has been.

headline: High Plains Moochers
text: It is, in a way, too bad that Cliven Bundy — the rancher who became a right-wing hero after refusing to pay fees for grazing his animals on federal land, and bringing in armed men to support his defiance — has turned out to be a crude racist. Why? Because his ranting has given conservatives an easy out, a way to dissociate themselves from his actions without facing up to the terrible wrong turn their movement has taken.

headline: A Young Mayor Who Likes to Share His View From the Top

Unremarkable, unrevealing and uncontroversial — and destined to fade away with Election Day, which it did.

headline: Chernobyl: Capping a Catastrophe
text: A 32,000-ton arch that will end up costing $1.5 billion is being built in Chernobyl, Ukraine, to all but eliminate the risk of further contamination at the site of the 1986 nuclear reactor explosion.

headline: Vortex of Outrage Has Long Trailed Clippers’ Owner

headline: Suspect in School Attack Once Turned to Victim for Help, Friends Say

headline: All Books Not Equal to Squabbling Family
text: Although it’s roughly the age of a recent college graduate, Jon Robin Baitz’s play “The Substance of Fire” at times seems to have grown some gray whiskers. Watching the sure-footed new revival of the play that opened at the Second Stage Theater on Sunday night, featuring standout performances by the Australian actor John Noble and the ever-vibrant Charlayne Woodard, I kept thinking of dramas about family, money and morality written way back in the early years of the 20th century by Harley Granville Barker.

text: Record Store Day, which began in April 2008, is a self-styled celebration of the “unique culture” surrounding independent record stores. Some titles released on vinyl for the April 19 event, like “Because the Internet,” saw revitalized sales weeks after a release on CD.

headline: Foursquare Chief Apologizes for Wife’s Fake Boston Marathon Bib
text: A co-founder of Foursquare, a popular location-sharing mobile app, issued an online apology after an investigation of unauthorized runners in the Boston Marathon found that his wife had used a fake bib to participate in the race last Monday.

headline: For Politician, an Indictment Looms, and So Does a Campaign for Re-election
text: Republican Party leaders in Staten Island had long heard murmuring about Representative Michael G. Grimm’s possible legal troubles. But Mr. Grimm maintained his innocence, and party leaders stood behind his bid for a third term this November.

text: Ina Garten, the celebrity chef known as the Barefoot Contessa, is hoping to buy the frozen food business that carries her name and brand from Contessa Premium Foods, an unaffiliated food company.

text: Kevin Garnett made a pair of free throws with 4 minutes 58 seconds left in Sunday night’s game. He pumped his fist, and the fans in the sellout crowd erupted as the Nets inched to a precious 1-point lead over the Toronto Raptors.

text: Michael Heisley, the billionaire financier who bought the N.B.A.’s floundering Vancouver Grizzlies in April 2000 and soon moved them to Memphis, where he revitalized the franchise, died on Saturday in Illinois. He was 77.

headline: String of Deadly Storms Hits Across Midwest and South
text: ATLANTA — A violent weather system lashed the Midwest and South with tornadoes on Sunday, killing at least nine people, according to some reports, and leaving vast areas of destruction. Forecasters warned that additional severe storms were likely on Monday.

headline: $1.2 Billion Bid for Australian Food Company Is Rejected
text: HONG KONG — Goodman Fielder, one of Australia’s biggest consumer food products companies, said on Monday that it had rebuffed a takeover bid by Singapore’s Wilmar International and Hong Kong’s First Pacific Company.

headline: After 7-Year Makeover, Bronx Links of Legend Try to Reclaim the Past
text: When William Larkin, a hip-hop producer-turned-golf pro, accepted the position of general manager of the Van Cortlandt Park Golf Course in the North Bronx in 2007, it was because he thought the course could live up to its history.

headline: North Korean Peace Group Insults South Korean Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s committee for peaceful reunification with South Korea, an official mouthpiece, has not been espousing peace lately, and its mouth has turned foul.

headline: Comme des Garçons Creates a Fragrance with Two Art-World Heavy-Hitters
text: Comme des Garçons is back with another fragrance collaboration — and this time, it involves two of the heaviest hitters in the art world. In honor of Serpentine Galleries‘ new Serpentine Sackler space designed by Zaha Hadid, the fashion label has partnered with the London institution on a new fragrance with a bottle and packaging designed by the artist Tracey Emin. The release, simply called “Serpentine,” is the first in an ongoing artist commission project for the Comme des Garçons scent line. A blend of iris leaf, juniper wood and nutmeg, the scent reflects Serpentine’s location amongst the green grass and fresh flowers at Kensington Gardens.

headline: Pop Lighting
text: Trash was the inspiration for Alvaro Catalán de Ocón’s vibrant line of pendant lamps, now on display at the Design Museum in London as part of its “Designs of the Year” exhibition. In 2011, while working on a project to combat pollution in Colombia, the Spanish industrial designer came up with the PET collection, its title a playful abbreviation of the polyethylene terephthalate bottles that contain soft drinks and water. He then hired Bogotá artisans to weave colored fibers into the repurposed bottles.

headline: A Stroke You Must Have
text: My father-in-law had been fishing from rowboats without incident since early childhood. But in August 1970, at age 66, alone on a Minnesota lake, he apparently fell out of the boat and drowned. He couldn’t swim a stroke, yet never wore a life jacket.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 46
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 1 P.M. (Showtime 2) MARGOT AT THE WEDDING (2007) In this cutting comedy from Noah Baumbach two sisters — Margot (Nicole Kidman, above left, with Jennifer Jason Leigh), an accomplished novelist, and the neurotic, needy Pauline (Ms. Leigh) — come together at their family home on Long Island for Pauline’s wedding to the unimpressive Malcolm (Jack Black). The result, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, is “a pileup of exposed secrets, buried lies and moral failures expressed in a cacophony of screams, tears and furious whispers” and a film that is “frequently brilliant, finally baffling.”

headline: Anthony Marriott, Author of ‘No Sex Please, We’re British’, Dies at 83
text: Anthony Marriott, a onetime actor who hit the jackpot as a playwright when he plugged into the British penchant for loopiness and naughty bits, co-writing a farce that became the longest-running comedy in the history of theater in England, died in London on April 17. He was 83.

headline: Pitch Bounces Yankees’ Way, Allowing the Run That Beats the Angels
text: The pitch that sent the Yankees to a 3-2 win on Sunday against the Los Angeles Angels struck the ground several inches short of home plate and caromed toward the backstop. Angels reliever Nick Maronde had attempted a breaking ball in a duel against Brian McCann in the eighth inning of a tie game. It was a pitch that clearly did not break enough, or did not even have enough time to break at all.

headline: India Election Digest: April 28
text: What you need to know on Monday about India’s elections: In a Muslim neighborhood in Gujarat, Bharatiya Janata Party members leave out any mention of Narendra Modi in their speeches; the top aide to Mr. Modi denies trying to appeal to the Hindu vote; and Priyanka Gandhi’s more visible role may mean she’s being groomed for something larger in the Indian National Congress party.

headline: Storms Carve Deadly Path Through South and Midwest

He dashed inside, grabbed a bedspread and headed for the bathroom, where his three daughters were already in the tub. He placed his body over the girls — twin 9-year-olds and an 8-year-old — and waited.

The results could help pave the way for the introduction of the first vaccine to prevent a disease that afflicts an estimated 50 million to 100 million people a year.

headline: Saving China’s Elephants
text: When it comes to cute and cuddly marketing mascots, it’s hard to compete with the giant panda — especially when you have rough, saggy skin, weigh four tons and occasionally stomp to death your admirers. That hasn’t stopped officials and entrepreneurs in the southwestern Chinese province of Yunnan from embracing the Asian elephant as a tourist attraction and merchandising bonanza. Jinghong, the capital of Xishuangbanna Prefecture, is flecked with dancing, prancing elephant statues. Each day, thousands of visitors crowd into a local nature preserve, where they hope to spot a real, live creature — although they are invariably disappointed and end up going home with a stuffed, plush facsimile.

headline: Thinking of Wine as Food With Eric Asimov
text: Eric Asimov, the chief wine critic at The Times, writes three columns: “The Pour,” “Wines of The Times” and the recently started “Wine School,” in which he chooses one type of wine a month and discusses it with readers online. He came to The Times in 1984, joining the national desk as a copy editor, and has edited and written for the Living, Styles, Weekend and Dining sections. He wrote the $25 and Under reviews of inexpensive restaurants from 1992 to 2004, when he became the chief wine critic.

headline: When Amazon Collects Sales Tax, Some Shoppers Head Elsewhere
text: For years, Amazon watchers — especially Amazon’s competitors and opponents — have wondered just how much the company has benefited from not having to collect sales tax on most of its transactions. Now, three economists appear to have answered the question with a new study: In states that recently forced the online behemoth to begin collecting those taxes, Amazon’s sales have fallen sharply.

headline: Macroeconomics and Class Warfare
text: Back when Obama was proposing a spending plan to boost the economy, and some of us were pleading for a bigger plan, it was common to hear people from both the right and the crazy center declaring that it was all a ruse, an attempt to smuggle in liberal priorities under the guise of fiscal stimulus. This was, as it happens, completely false – and in the case of the right-wingers, a case of projection. After all, Obama didn’t try to sell permanent spending increases as short-run stimulus – but Bush did exactly that when pushing his tax cuts.

Mr. Robbins, the actor who has served as the company’s artistic director for more than three decades, will direct the performances scheduled to take place June 10 to 15 at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing as part of its Shakespeare festival and June 19-21 at the Zendai Himalayas Art Center in Shanghai.

headline: France Stalls G.E.’s Alstom Bid

G.E. is looking to buy Alstom’s energy business, and France’s economic minister had been scheduled to meet on Sunday with Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of G.E.

headline: A Monetary Puzzle
text: OK, color me puzzled. I’ve seen a number of people touting this Bank of England paper (pdf) on how banks create money as offering some kind of radical new way of looking at the economy. And it is a good piece. But it doesn’t seem, in any important way, to be at odds with what Tobin wrote 50 years ago (pdf) — indeed, the BoE paper cites Tobin extensively. And I have always thought of money in Tobinesque terms, even if I sometimes use shorthand descriptions that can be misread if you take them out of context; the same is true of many economists.

headline: Sina Apologizes, Twice, for Posting Porn
text: Sina Corporation, owner of one of China’s most visited websites, is sorry. Very sorry. So sorry, in fact, that it has apologized not once but twice to its readers and the national antipornography office, which last week found that lewd material had made its way onto the Sina site.

headline: How ‘Verified Commenters’ Earn Their Status at The Times, and Why
text: Times readers, especially those who comment frequently on articles, often ask me to explain how members of that special class known as verified commenters get their stripes (or their check marks, to be more precise). The comments of these 478 readers are posted without going through the Times’s moderators – about a dozen people who read comments and decide whether they should be posted. The idea is to expedite the process of getting at least some comments posted, which also lowers the overall number of comments that need moderation in advance.Some don’t like it. Michael Simmons, for one, calls it “unfair and wrong.” In a comment on my recent Sunday column, he wrote: “This has created a hierarchy of commenters wherein the same handful of readers have their comments posted before everyone else — sometimes many hours before everyone else can be vetted. This has led to abuse of the comments section, including verified commenters wishing readers happy holidays on occasion. I’m tired of reading the same commenters at the top of the Reader’s Picks by virtue of the fact that they were able to post before everyone else. This system is undemocratic.”

headline: Wounded Mayor Is Both Colorful and Powerful, Loved and Loathed
text: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Fed up with the lifeless and unflattering photographs taken of him by press photographers, Gennady A. Kernes, the mayor of Kharkiv, decided to take matters into his own hands.

headline: All the Rage | Fly Like Rich People
text: Air travel is going the way of Uber. EvoLux Transportation, a new helicopter service, will offer ride-share options and on-call private flights from an array of operators. The program is starting in New York and Miami this month, with other American cities to be added in the fall. Also in the works is FlyJets, through which customers with a little tech savvy and a lot of cash will be able to bid on private jet routes, Priceline-style, or book a standard rate immediately without all the auction fuss. In other flight news, JetBlue, the most democratic of airlines, is getting in on the cabin caste system. Starting in June, flights between J.F.K. and LAX will feature first-class seats and amenities, from lie-flat beds to Saxon & Parole-curated tapas.

headline: Grimm, Staten Island Lawmaker, Is Charged With Fraud
text: For more than two years, federal investigators delved into the background of Representative Michael G. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island now in his second term. They looked into his campaign finances, and examined the potential mob ties of one business associate and the illegal doings of another.

headline: Cannes Film Festival Announces Feature Film Jury
text: The director Sofia Coppola and the actor Willem Dafoe will be among the nine feature-film jurors at the 67th annual Cannes Film Festival, the festival announced on Monday. The New Zealand director Jane Campion will preside over the jury, which will also include the actresses Carole Bouquet of France, Leila Hatami of Iran, and Jeon Do-yeon of South Korea; the Mexican actor and director Gael García Bernal; the Chinese director Jia Zhangke and the Danish director Nicolas Winding Refn. The festival runs May 14 to May 25. Last year’s jury awarded the Palme d’Or to “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” directed by Abdellatif Kechiche, and “Inside Llewyn Davis,” directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, won the second honor, the Grand Prix.

text: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely — as New York is slowly finding out, reports Jenna Wortham on Monday.

headline: Lawmakers Return to Congress With Modest Agenda
text: WASHINGTON — When members of Congress are campaigning for re-election in their districts, they are calling for legislation to address big problems with immigration, taxes, health care, worker pay, climate change and the country’s aging infrastructure. But as they return to Washington on Monday after a two-week break, there is almost no prospect for new legislation in those areas until after Election Day.

headline: George Washington’s Weakness: His Teeth
text: When George Washington opened his mouth 225 years ago this Wednesday at New York’s Federal Hall to take the oath as the first president of the United States, he wore awkward-fitting, painful, face-disfiguring dentures. For years, he had suffered from dental problems; that morning he had swollen, burning gums and only a single original tooth in his mouth. He wore this particular set of dentures during the last nine years of his life. They clacked and creaked open and shut on tight wire springs.

headline: ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Finally Becoming an E-Book
text: The author Harper Lee has agreed to release her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” — one of only a few remaining classics currently available only in print — as an e-book on July 8, HarperCollins Publishers has announced.

text: The American Museum of Natural History in New York will make thousands of images accessible to the public that were previously only viewable at its research library.

headline: N U M + B E R = P L A Y
text: This week’s challenges were suggested by the mathematician Bill Gosper, the brilliant and largely self-taught computer programmer and researcher considered by many to be a modern-day Ramanujan. I asked Mr. Gosper about this comparison and he responded by email with his usual humility:

headline: Search for Flight 370 Enters New Phase
text: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said that the chance of finding floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was highly unlikely and that the search would shift to the ocean floor.

headline: The Illogic of Active Trading
text: Individual investors have been busy the last few months. TD Ameritrade saw a 30 percent jump in daily trading volume compared with the same period last year. Other discount brokers reported a similar increase in daily trading volume.

headline: Paul Simon and Edie Brickell in Court Over Domestic Dispute
text: The singer-songwriters Paul Simon and Edie Brickell held hands in a Connecticut courtroom on Monday and told a judge they were not a threat to each other, after they were both arrested over the weekend in a domestic dispute.

headline: Food Curated: One Tough Cookie
text: More than nine years ago, Gail Dosik started One Tough Cookie, a specialty decorated-cookie company, in her West Village kitchen.

headline: Video: One Tough Cookie
text: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: In Store | With a New Collection and Installation, Dior Homme Tweaks Its Image
text: There is a certain kind of man — often barely out of boyhood — who studies Dior Homme like a holy text, pointedly adhering to the strict minimalism, dark palettes and monastic attention to detail of the collections by the designer Kris Van Assche. These gents — who thronged the brand’s “Autumn” presentation in SoHo last Thursday in sunglasses and complicated ties, with a dedication to black that would be the envy of the Night’s Watch from “Game of Thrones” — should take note: Van Assche was wearing blue jeans. Not black. Blue.

headline: In Our Pages: April 29
text: 1939: Hitler Says ‘No’ to Peace Appeal

headline: I.P.O. Linked to Football Player Opens for Trading
text: Updated, 2:38 p.m. | The football star Vernon Davis has arrived on Wall Street.

headline: Sit-Down Comic Takes His Place as Anchorman
text: John Oliver, a graduate of “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” didn’t exactly break the mold when he rolled out his new show, “Last Week Tonight,” late on Sunday on HBO; he just tugged at it a bit. If Mr. Stewart’s current-events-based comedy is the equivalent of the evening news, Mr. Oliver gave us a satirical “All Things Considered.”

headline: ‘I Wish People Had More Respect’
Russia and Iran Reported in Talks on Energy Deal Worth Billions
text: The Obama administration’s strategy of punishing Russia with economic sanctions over the Ukraine crisis encountered a new complication on Monday with word that the Russians are negotiating an $8 billion to $10 billion energy deal with Iran, another country ostracized by American-led sanctions, which partly depend on Moscow’s cooperation to be effective.

headline: Why Pfizer Needs to Do More to Win AstraZeneca
text: Pfizer will need to pile on more pressure if it wants to buy AstraZeneca. Pfizer has confirmed that it made a $99 billion cash-and-stock approach in January for AstraZeneca, its British rival, and is now renewing its suit. AstraZeneca’s chief executive, Pascal Soriot, may ultimately struggle to resist a takeover, but he ought to be able to extract a better proposal.

headline: Jack Ramsay, Who Led Blazers to 1977 N.B.A. Title, Dies at 89
text: Jack Ramsay, the Hall of Fame coach who took the Portland Trail Blazers to their only N.B.A. championship and who was regarded as one of pro basketball’s keenest coaching minds, died on Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 89.

headline: Pear Smoothie With Spinach, Celery and Ginger
text: I have to admit, this began as a “clean out the refrigerator and (aging) fruit bowl” smoothie. I salvaged some spinach that had seen better days and finally used up the last of the pears I’d bought a few weeks ago for another set of recipe tests. I went out to my garden and grabbed some bolting arugula and some mint. I’ve been drinking kefir, a fermented milk product much like yogurt but thinner and tangier, so that went in, giving the smoothie a pleasantly acidic edge. The two ingredients that the drink needs in order for it to taste like something other than a bland green drink are the half banana and the ginger. If you let your bananas ripen completely, then freeze them, they’ll contribute not only flavor, sweetness and texture but also ice to your smoothies.

headline: Blueberry Kefir Smoothie With Greens
text: This green smoothie is really more blue than green, as the color of the blueberries predominates. . But the greens are there, so in my mind it’s still a green drink. Half a banana wasn’t quite enough to punch up the flavor of the drink, but I found that a whole banana did the trick. I used a baby greens mix that included baby kale, chard (red and green), and spinach.

headline: Green Smoothie With Pineapple, Arugula, Greens and Cashews
text: Pineapple can stand alone as a fruit to combine with greens in a smoothie. No bananas are required. I did add a piece of ginger to this smoothie and loved the way it pumped up the flavor. I didn’t use any dairy in this one, just orange juice. And I found that it required no additional sweetener, though you could add a teaspoon of agave nectar or honey if you wish. It’s best to use the pungent, feathery wild arugula for this. I used a baby greens mix that included kale, chard and spinach.

headline: Pineapple-Basil Smoothie
text: I’m not sure that I would order this just based on the name. But believe me, you’ll be pleased by this herbal concoction. Pineapple has so much sweetness and flavor on its own, and it marries well with the peppery, anisy basil. Very little else is required (no banana in this smoothie). I like to use kefir, but yogurt will work too. Pistachios and chia seeds bulk up the drink nicely, and the pistachios contribute to the pale green color.

headline: Green Smoothie With Cucumber and Cumin
text: This smoothie, the only savory drink in this week’s Recipes for Health, is a bit like an Indian lassi, with a little heat from the pinch of cayenne, and some lovely spice. I used a mix of baby greens – chard, baby kale and spinach, as well as parsley and mint. It makes for a filling lunch.

headline: Hey, Whiny Modern Parents, Tell Us What You Love About the Gig
text: Here’s one for us to run with from  a commenter on last week’s open thread,  Lee Leander:

headline: Why Ron Paul Supporters Were Removed from G.O.P. Leadership in Iowa
text: The ouster of Ron Paul’s backers from Iowa’s Republican Party leadership this weekend might help the state party raise money.

headline: Optimism as Detroit Makes Pacts on Finances
text: DETROIT — As the list of deals being struck by this city grows, the chances of a relatively smooth, swift exit from bankruptcy do, too, city officials say. On Monday, Detroit added tentative agreements with some of its unions to pacts already reached with retiree groups, pension funds and several financial creditors, moving the city closer to a plan that would allow it to emerge from bankruptcy by mid-October.

headline: N.B.A. Announcement on Clippers Owner to Come Tuesday
text: The N.B.A. will make an announcement Tuesday about its investigation of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, the league said in a statement Monday. League officials will hold a news conference in New York at 2 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: A Website’s Chief Plays Down China’s Curb on American Shows
text: BEIJING — After recent Chinese government orders to remove four popular American television shows from websites, the chief executive of one company played down the move’s impact on the industry, even as news emerged that the state broadcaster planned to show one sitcom.

headline: Jay Z and Beyoncé to Tour North America This Summer
text: Most married couples and families hope to get away in the coming months for a calm and quiet summer vacation, but Beyoncé and Jay Z are, safe to say, not a typical married couple. On Monday, they officially announced their summer plans: a joint North American stadium tour called “On the Run.”

headline: As His Tenure Winds Down, Obama Turns Focus to Executive Branch
text: WASHINGTON — John Podesta got a brief burst of attention from his hiring in a White House “shake-up,” Sylvia Mathews Burwell will be in sharp focus in coming confirmation hearings to be health and human services secretary and the cameras loved Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary, during the debt-ceiling wars.

headline: Israel Appears to Raise New Peace Talks Issue With U.S.
text: JERUSALEM — Days after suspending American-brokered Middle East peace talks because of a reconciliation pact reached between the Palestine Liberation Organization and its rival Hamas, the Islamic militant group, Israel on Monday raised a new source of potential tension with the United States over Washington’s approach to the unity government planned by the Palestinians.

headline: Times Minute | What Sanctions Mean
text: Peter Baker, The Times’s White House correspondent, on what this latest round of sanctions targeting Russia means.
