headline: In Fashion | How Stella Got Her Sheep Back
text: The designer continues her eco-quest by sourcing wool from animals that lightly graze the Patagonian farmlands.

headline: Didn’t Read Those Terms of Service? Here’s What You Agreed to Give Up
text: On Twitter, Facebook and other sites that promote sharing of content, users can typically choose whether they want to post their updates publicly to everyone or carefully select their audience.

headline: Is It Time to Broaden the Definition of Insider Trading?
text: William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ hostile bid for Allergen is giving the public a close look at how nonpublic information can be used without breaking insider trading rules.

headline: Rhoden: Swift and Severe Punishment for Sterling
text: The N.B.A. commissioner and the fans are best in position to punish Donald Sterling, should the racist comments on a tape recorder prove to be from the Clippers’ owner, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Living Symphonies
text: Living Symphonies is a sound installation which grows in the same way as a forest ecosystem. Portraying the thriving activity of the forest’s wildlife, plants and atmospheric conditions, it creates a never-ending symphony heard amongst the forest itself.

headline: Science Events: Unusual Vision and D.I.Y. Neuroscience
text: May events at the intersection of art and science.

headline: Video: Swift and Severe Punishment for Sterling
text: The new N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver, and the fans are best in position to punish Donald Sterling, should the racist comments on a tape recorder prove to be from the Clippers’ owner.

headline: Congressman Shown on Video Kissing Aide Won’t Seek Re-election
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Vance McAllister, Republican of Louisiana, who was caught on camera kissing a female staff member who was not his wife, will not seek re-election to the seat he has held for only five months, his office said on Monday.

headline: Even a Few Pills Can Put a Dent in the Malaria Rate
text: A new way to prevent malaria in areas where it waxes and wanes with the weather appears to be working in West Africa, the medical aid organization Doctors Without Borders said last week.

headline: Iraq’s Ailing President Talabani Is Shown Casting a Vote
text: Video of a rare appearance of the ailing president of Iraq, Jalal Talabani, has surfaced on social media pages, just as some voting gets underway for the first parliamentary elections since the United States withdrawal from Iraq in 2011.

headline: Justices to Weigh Finance Law as It Was Applied to Little Fish
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether a Florida fisherman ran afoul of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, a federal law aimed primarily at white-collar crime, by throwing three undersized red grouper back into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Place for Yoga in the Great Smoky Mountains of Tennessee
text: A beloved mountainside retreat branches out with a woodsy new spa.

headline: Middle Seat Nightmare, Stuck Between Mother and Misbehavior
text: I’VE been a business traveler for the past 25 years. Now, with my own company, Kurtz-Ahlers and Associates, I’m traveling more than I ever have. I’m in the luxury travel business and meet with people all over the world. I love what I do, but whether I like business travel is debatable.

headline: Something to Sing About, Finally, at Airport Security
text: OOPS, I’ve lost still another Victorinox Swiss Army Classic pocketknife — the keychain-size one with handy tools, including tiny scissors and an inch-and-a-half blade. They’re $11.97 on Amazon, and I’ve already ordered a new one to replace the one that was confiscated last week at La Guardia Airport in New York.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | April 22-28, 2014
text: A Supreme Court decision, a historic ceremony and a 40th birthday celebration for a popular toy: How many of the questions in this week’s News Quiz can you answer correctly?

headline: Signature to Receive Tony for Regional Theater
text: Signature Theater will become the first New York City theater company to receive the noncompetitive Tony Award recognizing a regional American theater, the Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Monday.

headline: Who Speaks for Pro-Israel Americans?
text: On Wednesday the influential Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations will vote on whether or not to admit J Street as a member. A vote to exclude J Street would, in a word, be crazy — sending an unfortunate signal about its willingness (or unwillingness) to reflect the broadest range of views, especially on a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Edgar Laprade, Center and Gentleman on the Ice, Dies at 94
text: Edgar Laprade, the Hall of Fame Rangers center of the 1940s and ’50s who was known for his playmaking skills and his gentlemanly behavior on the ice, died on Monday at his home in Thunder Bay, Ontario. He was 94.

headline: Overriding Their Animal Impulses
text: When it comes to animal intelligence, says Evan MacLean, co-director of Duke University’s Canine Cognition Center, don’t ask which species is smarter. “Smarter at what?” is the right question.

headline: ScienceTake | Shell Game for Animals
text: Intelligence is hard to test, but one aspect of being smart is self-control, and a version of the old shell game that works for many species suggests that brain size is very important.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 25-27, 2014
text: “Gun control supporters have the blood of little children on their hands.”

headline: Grimm and Prosecutors Discuss Indictment
text: Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island; Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney in Brooklyn; and George Venizelos, an F.B.I. assistant director, discussed the congressman’s indictment.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 45
text: It’s all about timing for Luiz Felipe Scolari, the coach of Brazil’s national soccer team, as the days tick off the calendar toward the start of the World Cup.

headline: Prosecutors Charge Utah Woman in Newborn Deaths
text: PROVO, Utah — Prosecutors on Monday charged a Utah mother with six counts of murder in the choking and suffocation deaths of her babies within minutes of their births. Their tiny bodies were found stuffed into cardboard boxes hidden in the garage of her home in Pleasant Grove, Utah, just south of Salt Lake City.

headline: Fox Plans Live Performance of ‘Grease’
text: No success in television is not worth imitating, as was proved again on Monday with the announcement that Fox will become the second network to commit to a live musical on television — a three-hour production of “Grease.”

headline: Key Justice Dept. Official Is Latest to Join Law Firm
text: Two blocks separate Covington & Burling’s offices in Washington from the Justice Department’s headquarters. Covington’s roster of lawyers shows a closer link.

headline: In the Heat of the Night
text: Q. When I’m having a hot flash, does my core body temperature actually rise, or does it only feel that way?

headline: Political Executions in Egypt
text: An out-of-control government in Egypt has now sentenced more than 680 people to death in a mass trial that lasted a few minutes and is part of an organized effort not just to crush its political opponents but to eliminate them. Last month, a court delivered a similar sentence on 529 others. The sentences further demonstrate that the military-led government’s ruthless disregard for the law and its contrary political views go far beyond anything that former President Mohamed Morsi was accused of doing when he was deposed by the army in July.

headline: These Celebrities Want You to Vote for Marianne Williamson
text: Much has been made of Marianne Williamson — a spiritual adviser and New York Times best-selling author — and her glittering, celebrity-laden campaign in California’s 33rd District. “She is an exotic political animal and perfect media catnip,” writes Mark Leibovich in “The Real House Candidates of Beverly Hills,” his dispatch from the fight for America’s second-wealthiest congressional district.

headline: North Carolina’s Gay-Marriage Ban Is Challenged by Church
text: In a novel legal attack on a state’s same-sex marriage ban, a liberal Protestant denomination on Monday filed a lawsuit arguing that North Carolina is unconstitutionally restricting religious freedom by barring clergy members from blessing gay and lesbian couples.

headline: Bitter Winter Limits the Offerings of Spring
text: For cooks, particularly those in the Midwest and the Northeast, these are brutal days.

headline: And Baby Makes an Unusual Three
text: Think of any of the great television series for which friendship was the defining idea — whether six-sided, four-cornered or a simple pairing — and the word “effortless” might come to mind. The actors and the writers made it all look effortless, and thus the friendships were believable.

headline: Yo-Yo Ma and Audra McDonald Among Offerings at Sonoma Concert Hall
text: The effort to put California’s Sonoma County on the map for high culture as well as viniculture will continue next season when the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Hall at the Green Music Center plans to expand its offerings of classical, jazz, pop and world-music concerts.

headline: Art and Film Luminaries Salute Dennis Hopper at Paris Photo Los Angeles
text: WhoThree of Dennis Hopper’s four children — Marin, Ruthanna and Henry — gathered at Paramount Studios with Hollywood friends like Andrew and Luke Wilson and Todd Phillips (director of the “Hangover” franchise and friend of Ruthanna, Hopper’s daughter with the “Zabriskie Point” star Daria Halprin) and art-world luminaries including Bill Viola and Sophie Calle for a screening of their father’s 1971 lost classic “The Last Movie,” in conjunction with the Paris Photo art fair. Jodi Wille, director of the documentary “The Source Family,” arrived with Hopper’s co-star Stella Garcia. The artist Larry Bell, a friend of Hopper’s since the late ’50s, introduced the film.

headline: An About-Face on a Risky Transplant
text: When the world’s first face transplant was performed in France in 2005, it pushed medical boundaries and made headlines. Yet the procedure’s future was very much in doubt.

headline: British Publicist Convicted of Indecent Assaults
text: LONDON — Max Clifford, Britain’s best-known celebrity publicist, was found guilty on Monday of eight charges of indecent assault, including offenses dating back decades against women as young as 15.

headline: A Rubber Band With a Surprising Twist
text: While working with a complex rubber band, Harvard researchers accidentally generated a shape rarely seen in nature, a hemihelix, according to a new study in PLOS One. The unusual shape is a variation on the helix, which is often represented by a DNA strand. The hemihelix is a helix that changes direction midway, as indicated by the arrow, above.

headline: Muslim Leaders Denounce Police Over Raids in Czech Capital
text: PARIS — Muslim leaders in the Czech Republic on Monday accused the police of abusing their power after armed officers raided Islamic institutions in Prague over the weekend, detaining 20 people during Friday Prayer at a mosque and a community center, and arresting the publisher of a book that law enforcement officials say incites xenophobia and violence.

headline: We Kill Germs at Our Peril
text: You never get something for nothing, especially not in health care. Every test, every incision, every little pill brings benefits and risks.

headline: Visiting the Alps, With Liszt and Goats
text: The titles of David Lang’s compositions are written in lowercase. There’s a self-effacing quality to his work as composer in residence at Carnegie Hall this season, too; among the six concerts he is presenting at Zankel Hall under the title “collected stories,” only one work is by him. But when it comes to the music of composers he has studied, admired, mentored or championed, it’s a different story: Here Mr. Lang’s interests run wide and include the grandiose and the quirky, the sidesplittingly funny and the extremes of virtuosic self-indulgence.

headline: Some Corals Can Adapt to Warmer Waters
text: Warming ocean waters have already devastated many coral reefs. But new research involving a species of coral that is resistant to higher temperatures suggests that others may be able to adapt, too.

headline: Militants Pose Threat on Eve of National Elections in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Snipers line the rooftops across Falluja, waiting for a chance to shoot at government soldiers, should they try to invade. Homes have been wired to explode, too, just in case the government rushes the city. And roads have been studded with countless steel-plated bombs, of the type that killed so many American soldiers here.

headline: Health Care Politics In One Sentence
text: The politics of Obamacare are clearly starting to shift. It’s not that the public is coming to love it — not yet, anyway. But it’s less and less of a bogeyman, with polls suggesting a majority of the public against flat-out repeal. So there’s increasing pressure on Republicans to lay out an alternative — and continuing surprise about their inability to articulate one.

headline: Pakistani Says He Killed 3, Using Gay Site to Lure Them
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The arrest of a confessed serial killer who used the Internet to lure his victims has caused alarm among gay men and lesbians in Pakistan, where social media has been quietly used to widen freedoms in a country where homosexuality is illegal.

headline: Arkansas Governor on Storm
text: Gov. Mike Beebe of Arkansas and David Hogue, a spokesman for Faulkner County, discussed the search-and-rescue operation after a series of deadly tornadoes in the state.

headline: Paradigming Is Hard
text: Mark Thoma sends us to Justin Fox, who tries hard to be sympathetic to the latest hard science/engineering guy bustling in to show those dumb economists how to do it. But as Fox clearly realizes, the reason we don’t have a new economic paradigm isn’t that economists are dumb, or even that all of them are rigid in their beliefs (obviously some are, or I wouldn’t have as many arguments as I do.) The reason, instead, is that it’s hard.

headline: DJ Rashad, Chicago Dance Music Producer, Dies at 34
text: DJ Rashad, a producer who helped bring the Chicago dance music known as footwork to a global audience, was found dead on Saturday in Chicago. He was 34.

headline: Complicated Legacy of a Gospel Singer
text: NEW ORLEANS — When the RAMS gospel choir members took the stage on Friday afternoon at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, they began by swaying to a recorded voice that came out of the loudspeakers like a ghost, imploring listeners about “learning to love yourself.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: How Congress Is Actually Holding Down Medicare Spending
text: It’s a rare health policy wonk who has a good word to say about Medicare’s Sustainable Growth Rate formula. That’s the formula created by Congress to govern the amount that Medicare pays to physicians for various treatments. It is supposed to adjust payments to meet an overall spending target tied to economic growth.

headline: John Oliver’s Premiere on HBO Draws 1.1 Million Viewers
text: HBO’s newest star, John Oliver, got off to a relatively strong start in his debut as a late-night host on Sundays, with 1.1 million viewers for his premiere.

headline: Noma Back on Top of ‘50 Best’ List
text: Two restaurants traded places Monday at the top of a list of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants, an increasingly influential but somewhat arbitrary ranking published by Restaurant Magazine since 2003.

headline: Photo Diary | Cosplay at the Cherry Blossom Festival
text: Scenes from the Sakura Matsuri photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: What Does Today Owe Tomorrow?
text: If you had driven north on Highway 101 toward San Francisco a few summers ago, you might have noticed a banner hanging from a freeway bridge. “What have future generations done for us?” it asked.

headline: Ahead of Tony Nominations, a Look at the Broadway Box Office
text: Will the 2014 Tony Award nominations, which will be announced Tuesday morning, reflect the hottest-selling plays and musicals on Broadway? Or did the Tony nominators, who cast their votes in secret on Monday, favor shows with more artistic merit than box office juice? There is no clear front-runner in any of the four top categories, so anything goes.

headline: Podcast: The Origin of Genes, an Antibiotic Overload, Roommate Math
text:
Genes make you ... you. But where do they come from? Antibiotics save lives, but their overuse is evolving supergerms and could be changing our bodies. Who pays what rent for which room? Just use this handy calculator and never fight at the end of the month again.

headline: The Continuing Evolution of Genes
text: Each of us carries just over 20,000 genes that encode everything from the keratin in our hair down to the muscle fibers in our toes. It’s no great mystery where our own genes came from: our parents bequeathed them to us. And our parents, in turn, got their genes from their parents.

headline: Handel to Mozart to Morris in a Pastoral Tale of Love and Jealous Rage
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Mark Morris has often proved the most life-enhancingly musical choreographer alive. In his latest work, the two-act “Acis and Galatea,” you can’t miss multiple layers of his musicality, but sometimes they tug in opposite directions.  Its premiere here was on Friday; it will be seen in Boston in May and at New York’s Mostly Mozart Festival in August.

headline: Are These People in Real Pain or Just Faking It?
text: We all know what it’s like to experience pain that makes our faces twist into a grimace. But how do you know if someone else’s face of pain is real or feigned? And can only humans tell the difference?

headline: Reading Pain in a Human Face
text: How well can computers interact with humans? Certainly computers play a mean game of chess, which requires strategy and logic, and “Jeopardy!,” in which they must process language to understand the clues read by Alex Trebek (and buzz in with the correct question).

headline: Art Dealer Seeks to Avoid Prison
text: Two disparate punishment options will be among those on the table on Wednesday when the art gallery owner Hillel Nahmad arrives in federal court in Manhattan to be sentenced for his involvement in an international gambling ring.

headline: France Plays an Aggressive Hand in Alstom Deal Talks
text: PARIS — Shortly after news leaked last week that General Electric was working on a multibillion-dollar deal to buy part of the French industrial giant Alstom, Patrick Kron, Alstom’s chief executive, got an urgent summons.

headline: Light Found in Darkness of Wartime
text: Boy meets girl in Anthony Doerr’s hauntingly beautiful new book, but the circumstances are as elegantly circuitous as they can be. The heroine of “All the Light We Cannot See” is blind, but anyone familiar with Mr. Doerr’s work, which includes the short-story collections “The Shell Collector” and “Memory Wall,” will know that its title has many more meanings than that.

headline: For Lab Rats, a ‘Male Scientist’ Effect
text: Male researchers may want to bring a female chaperone when working with rodents, a new study suggests: Rats and mice experience more stress in the presence of men than of women.

headline: From the Bleak Streets to the Ballet Stage
text: “Don’t you think it needs something after he runs after her?” asked J R recently in a studio at New York City Ballet.

headline: A Silver Anniversary, and the Bride Still Wears White
text: It’s tempting to review the new “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” in the style of a “Vows” column in The New York Times: “The bride, a dimwit with a promising future in reality TV, wore a tasteful white gown that contrasted sharply with her bridesmaids’ dresses, which appeared to be on loan from a mid-20th-century jiggle joint.” Or perhaps as a restaurant review parody: “Guy Fieri’s main dish, an indifferent pasta, was garnished with a sprinkling of near-fisticuffs and tangy mother-of-the-bride histrionics.”

headline: Yahoo to Offer TV-Style Comedy Series on the Web
text: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is about to dive into the shark tank of television-style original video.

headline: Moogfest in Asheville

headline: Artificial, With a Human Touch
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — Geekiness reigned, proudly and openly, at Moogfest 2014, the largest iteration yet of a festival created by Moog Music, which makes all of its synthesizers and other equipment by hand at a small factory here in downtown Asheville.

headline: Divide Your Rent Fairly
text: When you're sharing an apartment with roommates, it can be a challenge to decide who takes which bedroom, and at what price. Sit down with your roommates and use the calculator below to find the fair division.

headline: To Divide the Rent, Start With a Triangle
text: Last year, two friends and I moved into a small three-bedroom apartment in Manhattan. We chose it for its relatively reasonable price — around $3,000 a month — and its convenient location. Just finding it was a challenge, but then we faced another one: deciding who would get each bedroom.

headline: Security Flaw Hits Microsoft Browser
text: Updated with more reporting on security flaw. |

headline: After Hours | Bright Light Bright Light Strips Dance-Pop to Its Bare Essence
text: Anyone who’s heard the vocals-only track of Whitney Houston singing “How Will I Know?” can attest to the mesmerizing power of dance-pop reduced to its simplest elements. That was the feeling Friday night at Joe’s Pub when the young Welsh singer Rod Thomas, who goes by the “Gremlins”-inspired name Bright Light Bright Light, performed his entire new dance album, “Life Is Easy,” with only a piano and three backup singers. Thomas, who recently moved to Brooklyn from London, has gained a small, obsessive following for his passionate, moody lyrics paired with shimmering dance-pop arrangements that recall the Pet Shop Boys and Erasure, and house tracks as mixed by Shep Pettibone for the “Vogue”-era Madonna.

headline: Three Contractors Sentenced to 20 Years in CityTime Corruption Case
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Monday sentenced three men to 20 years in prison for their roles in the scandal-ridden payroll modernization project known as CityTime, and he also sharply criticized New York City’s contracting procedures for what he called a lack of “adequate and effective oversight.”

headline: From Volunteers, a DNA Database
text: Abigail Wark wants to see your areolas.

headline: Giving Children of Alumni a Leg Up
Reactions
text: Nutrition

headline: AT&T Plans to Provide Wireless Internet for Airplanes
text: AT&T is looking to expand the reach of its wireless network to devices in the sky. On Monday, the company announced plans to provide in-flight Internet connections for some airlines.

headline: Owners to Invest $800 Million More in Shanghai Disneyland
text: LOS ANGELES — Shrugging off economists’ concerns about a cooling Chinese economy, the Walt Disney Company on Monday announced a deal to increase spending on its coming Shanghai megaresort by $800 million.

headline: Twenty Years After Apartheid
text: Joao Silva came of age as a photographer as South Africa was navigating its path to democracy. Twenty years later, he reflects on what has – and has not – changed.

headline: A Low-Wage Recovery? The Evidence Isn’t There
text: A new report from the National Employment Law Project, the research and advocacy group, argues that we’re in the midst of a “low-wage recovery.” But the evidence for this is thin.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Ukraine, the Philippines and Taiwan.

headline: Lawyers Say U.N. Aid Does Not Need Syria’s Consent
text: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations agencies and other charitable organizations do not need the permission of the Syrian government to deliver humanitarian relief to civilians trapped in the fighting and destruction from the three-year-old civil war there, a group of international lawyers and academics argued in an open letter released on Monday.

headline: How to Back Up iTunes Podcasts
text: How to Back Up

headline: Despite Ethics Pledge, Response by G.O.P. Varies
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Vance McAllister, Republican of Louisiana, under heavy pressure from House Republican leaders since he was caught kissing a congressional aide, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election to the seat he has occupied for only five months.

headline: Singer Steps Into Spotlight as Nation Changes Political Tune
text: TEHRAN — The onetime underground pop singer smiled shyly as the high-pitched screams of his teenage fans drifted into his dressing room, just before his show on Friday. This superstar thing, he seemed to be saying, takes some getting used to.

headline: Finding a Flash Drive in the Sea
text: YESTERDAY, the aerial search for floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was called off, and an underwater search based on possible locator beacon signals was completed without success. Although efforts to find the missing aircraft have not been abandoned, Angus Houston, the man in charge of finding the plane, said, “We haven’t found anything anywhere.”

headline: Bank of America’s Bad Accounting
text: The strange accounting that tripped up Bank of America is on its way to being changed.

headline: Sterling’s Racial Honors
text: Exactly 50 years ago, the Beatles declared that money can’t buy you love.

headline: Toyota Will Shift 4,000 to New Offices in Texas
text: DETROIT — Toyota Motor said on Monday that it would move thousands of employees from California and other locations to new North American headquarters in Texas as part of a broad effort to cut costs and streamline operations.

headline: Justices Appear Willing to Give a Fired Public Worker Only Half a Victory
text: WASHINGTON — After a tangled Supreme Court argument on Monday over the First Amendment rights of public employees, it seemed likely that the justices would render a split decision.

headline: Senate Drops Bid to Report on Drone Use
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate has quietly stripped a provision from an intelligence bill that would have required President Obama to make public each year the number of people killed or injured in targeted killing operations in Pakistan and other countries where the United States uses lethal force.

headline: Echoes of Past May Not Carry as Court Weighs 2nd Abortion Law
text: NEW ORLEANS — For the second time this year, a federal appeals panel here heard arguments about the constitutionality of a new state law governing abortion. But despite much in common between the two laws — one in Texas, and the other, the subject of Monday’s hearing, in Mississippi — their effects would differ substantially, raising the possibility that the same court weighing similar laws might arrive at different conclusions.

headline: Brazilian Telecom Firm Oi Raises $3.7 Billion Via Offering
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian telecommunications carrier Oi raised about 8.25 billion reais ($3.7 billion) on Monday through a global share offering that is part of its merger with Portugal Telecom.

headline: Nash Still Contributes to Rangers Despite His Scoring Drought in the Playoffs
text: There are many ways to measure a hockey player’s contribution to his team, and by almost every one of them, Rick Nash is doing a lot for the Rangers in their playoff series against the Flyers. But there is one area where he is not, and it happens to be the main reason the Rangers traded away so many players to acquire him two years ago: goal scoring.

headline: White House to Press Colleges to Do More to Combat Rape
text: WASHINGTON — Reacting to a series of highly publicized rapes on college campuses, the White House on Monday released guidelines that increase the pressure on universities to more aggressively combat sexual assaults on campus.

headline: Welcome to the Haiyatt. In China, It’s Not the Hotel It Sounds Like.
text: Is the Peninsula Hotel in Yangcheng part of the five-star Peninsula Hotels group known for its Rolls-Royces? Can you accrue Marriott rewards points at the Marvelot Hotel, which includes the Chinese characters for Marriott in its name? Is the Haiyatt hotel in China a Hyatt brand hotel? No, no and no.

headline: Ratings Slip at MSNBC as Jet Coverage Lifts CNN
text: April proved a cruel month for MSNBC, with the news channel hitting some of its lowest ratings in seven years, and its prominent morning show, “Morning Joe,” falling to third place in the cable news competition.

headline: Europe's Mob Economy
text: How serious a threat is organized crime, and what needs to be done to curtail its influence?

headline: Courting Video Advertisers With Infinite (and Growing) Air Time
text: WHICH came first, a rising interest among marketers in digital video as an advertising medium or a decision by a leading trade association to significantly expand an annual series of presentations by companies that offer digital video? If it is a chicken-and-egg question, it would assuredly involve a subservient chicken, in honor of the pioneering online video that Burger King introduced a decade ago and revived last week.

headline: Craig Ferguson to Leave CBS at End of Year
text: Late-night television has one more opening: Craig Ferguson announced on his CBS show Monday night that he will leave “The Late Late Show” at the end of the year.

headline: Trainer’s Hunch on Modest Colt Pays Off
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Jose Garoffalo, who grew up around thoroughbreds on his father’s breeding farm, studied law in his native Venezuela before he listened to his heart. He went to the racetrack the day after he completed his studies in 1988 and pursued a career as a trainer.

headline: 12 Deportation Protesters Arrested at White House
text: In a protest against President Obama’s immigration enforcement, 12 people were arrested Monday morning in front of the White House after they sat down and unfurled banners calling on him to stop most deportations. About 1,500 protesters, including many Latinos, joined the rally, the first of several anti-deportation protests scheduled this week in Washington. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson is conducting a review of the policy with an eye to reducing deportations.

headline: At Meeting, Fed Likely to Again Cut Bond Buying
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is tiptoeing away from its economic stimulus campaign, and so far the broader economy has barely noticed.

headline: Saving the System
text: All around, the fabric of peace and order is fraying. The leaders of Russia and Ukraine escalate their apocalyptic rhetoric. The Sunni-Shiite split worsens as Syria and Iraq slide into chaos. China pushes its weight around in the Pacific.

headline: Buffett Bites Back
text: The first Saturday in May is always a great day for Warren Buffett. That’s the day his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, holds its annual meeting in Omaha.

headline: White House Steps Up Effort to Confirm Federal Judges
text: WASHINGTON — With the possibility that Republicans could take the Senate in November, the White House and Senate Democrats are working swiftly to confirm judges to the federal courts in an effort to allow President Obama to leave a lasting liberal imprint on the judiciary.

headline: Syria Announces Assad’s Bid for Re-election as War Rages
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government announced on Monday that President Bashar al-Assad would compete in a presidential election scheduled for June 3 that is widely seen as an attempt to enhance his perceived legitimacy despite a raging civil war that has pushed his government out of much of the country and displaced millions of citizens.

headline: Lull Prompts Question: What Are Taliban Up To?
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as Afghanistan’s unfolding presidential election has captured the capital’s attention, two related questions have become increasingly urgent among security officials here: Where have the Taliban gone, and what are they waiting for?

headline: G.A.O. Report Sees Deeper Bank Flaws in Foreclosures
text: A new government report suggests that errors made by banks and their agents during foreclosures might have been significantly higher than was previously believed when regulators halted a national review of the banks’ mortgage servicing operations.

headline: LG’s Plan to Deface the Palisades
text: The Palisades, the cliffs that stretch more than 20 glorious miles along the Hudson River north of New York City, have been protected for almost a century by agreement of New York and New Jersey from tall buildings that damage the area’s natural beauty.

headline: Troubling Student Loans
text: College students who borrow from private lenders often assume that private and federal student loans work the same way. The two could not be more different.

headline: White House Details Thinking on Cybersecurity Flaws
text: WASHINGTON — In a rare insight into the government’s thinking on the use of cyberweapons, the White House on Monday published a series of questions it asks in deciding when to make public the discovery of major flaws in computer security or whether to keep them secret so that American intelligence agencies can use them to enable surveillance or an attack.

headline: After 33 Years of Sterling, a Boiling Point
text: Why did it take a tape recording aired on a gossip website to ignite nationwide ire against Donald Sterling?

headline: Schumer Weighs In, Seeking Federal Changes for Structure of Port Authority
text: The controversy over the shutting of traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge last September has spurred widespread calls for reforming the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the agency that operates the bridge.

headline: Snowden Retained Expert in Espionage Act Defense
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who provided journalists a trove of classified documents, retained a well-known Washington defense lawyer last summer in hopes of reaching a plea deal with federal prosecutors that would allow him to return to the United States and spare him significant prison time.

headline: Pfizer Proposes a Marriage With AstraZeneca, Easing Taxes in a Move to Britain
text: Pfizer, the maker of best-selling drugs like Lipitor and Viagra and a symbol of business prowess in the United States for more than a century, no longer wants to be an American company.

headline: Why Did the N.B.A. Long Tolerate Sterling?
text: Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of the Donald Sterling scandal is that virtually no one in the sports world was surprised to hear that Mr. Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, may have been caught on tape spewing racist sentiments.

headline: Sanctions Over Ukraine Cause Headaches in the Energy Sector
text: MOSCOW — Once a year, the chief executives of the world’s largest oil companies fly to St. Petersburg, Russia’s second city, for an economic forum and a rare chance to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin and his lieutenant in the energy business, Igor I. Sechin.

headline: Today in Small Business: When Employees Can Unionize
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Mayor of Kharkiv, Ukraine, Is Shot
text: Ukrainian officials discussed the shooting of Gennady A. Kernes, the mayor of Kharkiv, who was shot in the back while running on Monday.

headline: ‘I Miss Him Every Second of Every Day’
text: The parents of Zachary Tyler said they hoped their son’s death would inspire hospitals and health care facilities to be more vigilant about controlling the spread of deadly infections.

headline: New Guard of Owners Could Be Key in Sterling’s Fate
text: When the N.B.A.’s Philadelphia 76ers were sold in 2011, a group of private equity investors bought the team for $280 million. When the Memphis Grizzlies were sold in 2012, a 34-year-old wireless technology entrepreneur paid $377 million. This month, two hedge fund billionaires shelled out $550 million for the lowly Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: A Deadly Fungus and Questions at a Hospital
text: NEW ORLEANS — The first victim was a premature boy in the intensive care unit whose mother noticed a mysterious irritation in his groin; it grew into an open wound burrowing into the baby’s abdomen. The last patient to die was a 10-year-old girl, whose face was ravaged.

headline: Reconsidering the Saviors of a Hospital
text: In late February, Mayor Bill de Blasio opened a news conference by letting loose an aria of self-congratulation.

headline: One City Falls to Pro-Russian Militants; in Another, the Mayor Is Shot
text: KONSTANTINOVKA, Ukraine — The crisis in eastern Ukraine took dark turns on Monday as the mayor of the country’s second-largest city was gravely wounded in an assassination attempt and masked antigovernment militants seized control of this city almost effortlessly, laying bare the limits of the interim government’s control.

headline: In Israel, Traffic Halts for a Moment of Silence
text: TEL AVIV — Every year, Jews around the world observe Yom Hashoah, a solemn day set aside to remember the millions of people who lost their lives in the Holocaust. In Israel, which became the first modern Jewish state a few years after World War II, the observance of Holocaust Remembrance Day even stops traffic, if only for a moment.

headline: Place to Express an Opinion
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — When people ask what I do for a living, I always make sure to tell them specifically that I write a blog for the web version of The New York Times. It’s fun to watch the range of reactions cross their faces, because most people still think of The Times in term of the print newspaper, and not everyone is aware of our online presence. And while I thank the universe every day that print is still alive and somewhat well, The Times has come a very long way in terms of presenting the news online in ways that I think are both innovative and well-designed. [The preceding paragraph is not an advertorial, opinions expressed here are Ms. Amlen’s alone, your mileage may vary when driving on the highway, if your puzzle solve lasts for three or more days please consult a physician. –Ed.]

headline: Monday Motorsports: Logano Evades the Punchy Competition for Sprint Cup Win
text: As Matt Kenseth, Jeff Gordon and Brad Keselowski were battling one another for the lead, Joey Logano slipped by and took the checkered flag Saturday night in the Sprint Cup event at Richmond International Raceway. Gordon ended up second, with Kyle Busch third. Kenseth was fourth, followed by Keselowski.

headline: Baseball Set Precedent for Disciplining an Owner
text: Any punishment handed down to Donald Sterling, the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, will inevitably be compared with Major League Baseball’s actions in the 1990s against Marge Schott.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 28, 2014
text: April 28, 2014

headline: Nuclear Power’s Promise and Peril
text: More than three decades after the accident at Three Mile Island cast a shadow on the atomic dream, is America again ready to give nuclear energy a chance?

headline: William H. Honan, Journalist and Author, Dies at 83
text: William H. Honan, an author and journalist who directed coverage of the arts at The New York Times as its culture editor in the 1980s, died on Monday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 83.

headline: Three Mile Island, and Nuclear Hopes and Fears
text: There is a certain irony in the shorthand that experts commonly use when discussing this country’s closest brush with nuclear cataclysm: TMI. Today, those letters are widely understood to mean “too much information.” But well before the advent of social media, TMI referred principally to the Three Mile Island Nuclear Generating Station, a power plant on the Susquehanna River in central Pennsylvania. Disaster struck there in 1979, and when it did, too much information — solid, unassailable information — was not part of the mix. Months later, a presidential commission cited a “lack of communication at all levels” as cause for grave concern. Americans were frightened, and not just those in Pennsylvania. Fear was intensified because, as the commission said, their right to know what was going on had been sorely compromised.

headline: Move Over, Tennis Elbow; Wrist Injuries Increasingly Plague Stars
text: What should have been an exciting clash between two tennis titans was instead clouded by a white mass.

headline: U.S. Couple Denied Permission to Leave Qatar While Appeal Is Pending
text: An American couple in Qatar convicted of child endangerment in the death of their adopted daughter from Africa, and not the original charge of murder, were denied permission on Monday to return home while their appeal is pending, and they faced the new possibility that Qatari prosecutors would seek to charge them with human trafficking.

headline: Ending Asia Trip, Obama Defends His Foreign Policy
text: MANILA — President Obama, stung by criticism of his response to turmoil from Eastern Europe to the Middle East, defended his approach to foreign policy as a slow but steady pursuit of American interests while avoiding military conflict, and he lashed out at those he said reflexively call for the use of force.

headline: Kerry Expresses Regret After Apartheid Remark
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry issued an unusual statement Monday evening expressing his support for Israel after a controversy erupted over a politically charged phrase he used in a private appearance.

headline: Creating a 3-D Model of the Arkansas Tornadoes
text: During severe weather, NOAA’s doppler radar stations send out multiple radar beams that slice through the atmosphere at varying angles, creating three-dimensional picture of storms.

headline: A Runway Standoff: Safety vs. Foliage at Westchester Airport
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — Sal Materia and his brother Enzo have made a patch of heaven for themselves here on Greenwich’s western fringe.

headline: No Sign Yet That Cano Can’t Continue Playing Daily
text: On more than one occasion during their years together as Yankees, Derek Jeter discussed with Robinson Cano how he should conduct himself on the major league level. Several years ago, when Cano arrived at the ballpark a little late one day, Jeter told him that was not how the Yankees did things, according to a major league employee who witnessed that clubhouse encounter and other ones that were similar in nature.

headline: Arc of a Failed Deal: How Nine Months of Mideast Talks Ended in Disarray
text: JERUSALEM — There were late-night video conferences with Secretary of State John Kerry, including one from beneath mosquito netting in an Indonesian hotel. Mr. Kerry met a total of 34 times with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, and about twice that with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Penguins Hang On to Eliminate Blue Jackets Behind Malkin’s Hat Trick
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The 10 frenzied final minutes of Monday’s Game 6 seemed like either an eternity or a flash, depending on whether you were rooting for Columbus or Pittsburgh.

headline: Brooklyn Tenants Unionize
text: Residents who have long called Crown Heights home are hoping their complaints against lackluster landlords will go further if they join forces with tenants who have just moved in.

headline: Disparate Forces Align Over Affordable Rents
text: The letter came in the dead of winter, dated Jan. 29. In a written “notice of termination,” Toussaint Wortham’s landlord accused him of violating his lease by making some renovations in his kitchen, and telling him that he had two weeks to leave the rent-stabilized apartment he had lived in for more than 30 years.

headline: India Election Digest: April 29
text: What you need to know on Tuesday about India’s elections: You can’t bet on Rahul Gandhi anymore, the contest in Uttar Pradesh is boiling down to two heavyweights, and overseas Indians are doing their part to promote Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

headline: Times Minute | Congressman Indicted
text: How Federal Authorities brought an indictment against Congressman Michael Grimm. Also on the minute, the quiet passing of a peace deadline in the Middle East and spotting someone in pain.

headline: The New New Basque Cuisine
text: One of only two women chefs named to the 2014 World’s 50 Best Restaurants list announced yesterday, Elena Arzak is a pioneering force in Spanish cooking, mixing modern innovation with a deep commitment to her region’s traditions.

headline: Times Minute | Congressman Indicted
text: In the Video

headline: Met Museum to Offer Malian Music, Theater Works and More in Coming Season
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s shake-up of its live performance program will continue next season when it presents a theater production in the Temple of Dendur, a series of concerts and lectures focused on Mali, and a “site-specific video opera” of “La Celestina,” a work of Spanish literature that is more than 500 years old, in its Spanish Renaissance patio.

headline: Word of the Day | grievance
text: grievance•\ˈgre-vən(t)s\• noun

headline: Administration Begins Search for New Contractors to Run Health Care Site
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has begun a wide-ranging search for companies to run the online federal health insurance exchange, seeking new talent to prevent a repeat of problems that immobilized the website last fall.

headline: No Jail Time for Brooklyn Man Who Threw Bleach on a Rabbi
text: A Brooklyn man who threw bleach at an outspoken advocate for victims of sexual abuse in the borough’s ultra-Orthodox Jewish community avoided jail time in a plea deal that gave him five years of probation, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said on Monday.

headline: Mexico: Mayor Detained in Organized Crime Investigation
text: The mayor of Lázaro Cárdenas, the city with Mexico’s second-largest port, has been detained as part of an investigation into allegations that he is involved in organized crime, as Mexico struggles to regain control of a region under the thumb of a powerful criminal gang. The gang, the Knights Templar, had so infiltrated the port, in the Pacific Coast state of Michoacán, that the military took it over last year. The arrest of the mayor, Arquímedes Oseguera, on Monday came a day after five people were killed on the outskirts of Lázaro Cárdenas when vigilante groups clashed with gunmen who they suspected were criminals. Mexico this week plans to begin to disarm the vigilantes and restore state authority.

headline: Central African Republic: Hospital Raid
text: Doctors Without Borders, the international medical charity that operates in some of the world’s most dangerous conflict zones, expressed alarm and outrage on Monday over the weekend killings of 16 civilians, including three staff members, on the property of a hospital it runs in Boguila, in the Central African Republic. In a statement on its website, the group said former members of the Seleka Muslim militia raided and robbed the hospital on Saturday, opening fire on community members invited to discuss medical access. Stefano Argenziano, who directs the group’s work in the country, said the group had suspended activities in Boguila and was evaluating whether to continue operations in other parts of the country, which has been split by Christian-vs.-Muslim mayhem. The group was forced to curtail work at an encampment of displaced people in Bangui, the capital, because of the violence and the collapse of government authority.

headline: Ethiopia: 9 Media Workers Arrested
text: Nine bloggers and journalists were arrested in Addis Ababa last week, according to local media and Human Rights Watch, just days before Secretary of State John Kerry’s scheduled visit to Ethiopia on Tuesday. Six bloggers for Zone 9, an Amharic-language website whose writers have criticized the government, and three freelance journalists were arrested. No formal charges have yet been filed. “The timing of the arrests — just days before the U.S. secretary of state’s visit — speaks volumes about Ethiopia’s disregard for free speech,” Leslie Lefkow, deputy director of Human Rights Watch’s Africa division, said in a statement on Monday. Getachew Reda, an adviser to Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn, said the arrests had nothing to do with the journalists’ work. “The police have put under custody people who have been suspected of being involved in criminal activities,” he said.

headline: Disney Considered Buying BuzzFeed, but Balked at $1 Billion Price
text: LOS ANGELES – At least for the Walt Disney Company, BuzzFeed quickly became a buzzkill.

headline: A Deal That Collapsed Leaves a Manhattan Synagogue in Shambles
text: Sitting in the plush velvet and mahogany pews inside the Fort Tryon Jewish Center in Washington Heights, ethereal light streaming in through 80-foot stained glass windows, it is possible to be transported back in time half a century, when the sanctuary was built as an addition to the synagogue, established in 1938.

headline: Nokia Announces New Strategy, and a New Chief to Carry It Out
text: LONDON — The Finnish technology company Nokia announced a new strategy on Tuesday that focuses on its core mobile telecommunications infrastructure business, and it named the head of that division, Rajeev Suri, as its new chief executive.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) PRISON STATE “Frontline” reports on mass incarceration in the United States, where a disproportionate number of the 2.3 million people behind bars come from just a few city neighborhoods. This documentary, directed by Dan Edge, visits a housing project in Louisville, Ky., where a significant percentage of residents have been incarcerated, and follows four — including Keith Huff, who has been in and out of prison for 40 years, and Christel Tribble, 15, above, facing juvenile incarceration for truancy — who have vacillated between custody and freedom. “We’ve gone through an explosion of prison construction in this country, costing us billions of dollars to build and billions to operate, and we’ve come to a fork in the road where we just can’t do that anymore,” says Mark Bolton, the city’s director of corrections, who is working to return inmates to the community. “We can’t afford it — and we’re locking up people who don’t need to be locked up.”

headline: A Link Between Fidgety Boys and a Sputtering Economy
text: The behavior gap between rich and poor children, starting at very early ages, is now a well-known piece of social science. Entering kindergarten, high-income children not only know more words and can read better than poorer children but they also have longer attention spans, better-controlled tempers and more sensitivity to other children.

headline: 2nd Publisher Pressured Over Hindu Book by U.S. Scholar
text: NEW DELHI — When Penguin India decided to withdraw a book on Hinduism by the American scholar Wendy Doniger in February, it cast a pall over the Indian publishing industry, which was already vulnerable to lawsuits because of the ambiguous language of Indian defamation laws.

headline: Corrections: April 29, 2014
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Journalist Missing Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
text: HONG KONG — Gao Yu, a prominent Chinese journalist who was imprisoned following the 1989 suppression of the student protests in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, is missing, with friends saying she may have been detained ahead of the 25th anniversary of the crackdown.

headline: Amadeus Capital Partners Leads Funding Round for Brazil’s Bidu
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The British venture capital firm Amadeus Capital Partners has made its first investment in Latin America, it said on Tuesday, leading an $8.9 million funding round in the Brazilian online insurance price comparison and brokerage company Bidu.

headline: In Xinjiang, Xi Pushes Vision of Uighur Integration
text: Two sides of China’s policy in Xinjiang — and two sides of China’s president, Xi Jinping — have been on display during Mr. Xi’s visit to the tense western region, where he enthusiastically endorsed policies to integrate the Uighur ethnic minority while warning that his government would be unforgiving toward separatist violence.

headline: Deutsche Bank Returns to Profit as Legal Costs Ease
text: FRANKFURT – Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, said on Tuesday that it returned to profit in the first quarter as it avoided the huge litigation expenses that characterized the end of 2013.

headline: No Compensation for Parents Who Have Lost Their Only Child
text: Last week more than 240 parents, drawn from about one million Chinese families whose only child has died, gathered in Beijing from around the country to ask the National Health and Family Planning Commission to compensate them for their loss.

headline: Santander Profit Rises 8% on Improving Economy
text: LONDON – The Spanish lender Santander reported on Tuesday that its first-quarter profit rose 8 percent, to 1.3 billion euros, as the bank benefited from an improving economic environment and declining charges for bad loans.

headline: John Oliver on the American Media’s India Blind Spot
text: The premiere of John Oliver’s new HBO news satire show, “Last Week Tonight,” included a segment on the Indian parliamentary election that seemed to speak for the legions of Indian journalists who actually are covering the story, as well as the political junkies here who are avidly tracking every development.

headline: Test Yourself | History, April 29
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Hunt for Survivors After a Night of Tornadoes
text: In “A Hunt for Survivors After a Night of Tornadoes,” Alan Blinder and Motoko Rich report on a string of storms that lashed the Midwest and South.

headline: BP’s Earnings Fall as It Continues to Sell Assets
text: LONDON — The British oil giant BP reported on Tuesday that its first-quarter earnings, excluding extraordinary items, fell 23.5 percent compared with the period a year earlier, as production slipped and it continued to sell assets.

headline: Twenty Years After Apartheid
text: In a sprawling South African township stands a tall slab of polished stone etched with names of people killed in the political violence preceding the country’s first democratic elections. It is dedicated to those from Tokoza, where almost 1,000 people died violently some 20 years ago, and sits on Khumalo Street, the very road where many died.

headline: Should Certain Animals Have Some of the Same Legal Rights As People?
text: Our legal system divides the world into people and everything else. People (and associations of people) have legal rights. Everything else does not. But should animals — or at least certain highly intelligent animals — be given some of the same legal rights as people?In the Op-Doc “Animals Are Persons Too,” Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker tell the story of the lawyer Steven Wise and his campaign to expand the legal rights of certain animals with a high level of intelligence:

headline: Demolition Begins on Church That Triggered Protest
text: Demolition has begun on a church in the southeastern Chinese province of Zhejiang that thousands of worshipers had tried to protect after the authorities said it violated local building codes.

headline: Vowing Changes, South Korean Leader Apologizes for Ferry Disaster
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Under mounting public pressure, President Park Geun-hye apologized on Tuesday for failing to prevent a ferry disaster that left 302 people, the vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing, and promised broad reforms to make her country a safer place.

headline: New York Today: Here Comes the Rain
text: Good cloudy Tuesday morning to you.

headline: Pro-Russian Militants Seize More Offices in Eastern Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Pro-Russia militants seized more state offices in Ukraine’s troubled east on Tuesday, in apparent defiance of the latest Western sanctions announced against them and their presumed backers in the Kremlin, which also showed no sign of wilting in its worst confrontation with the West in decades.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo Plans 2 TV-Style Comedy Series for Web
text: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is about to dive into the shark tank of television-style original video, Vindu Goel and Bill Carter report.

headline: No One Cares About Economic Data Anymore. That’s Good News.
text: If people in your office seem to be tingling with excitement this week, it is probably because of all the big economic news on the way. The two biggest regular United States economic reports are scheduled to come out, with first-quarter gross domestic product on tap for Wednesday and April jobs numbers out on Friday. Federal Reserve policy makers are meeting Tuesday and Wednesday for one of their regular sessions to set the nation’s monetary policy. And a variety of other important data releases are coming, including personal income and spending, manufacturing and home prices.

headline: Anonymous Chatting, Through a Simple Service
text: Secret, the popular mobile application, lets people share their deepest, darkest — and occasionally funniest — confessions anonymously, with their friends.

headline: Sentenced to Death in Egypt
text: The Egyptian government has sentenced 680 people to execution.

headline: Hong Kong Poll Shows Increasing Dissatisfaction With Beijing
text: For the first time in a decade, a majority of Hong Kong’s residents — most notably young people — are dissatisfied with the way the central government in Beijing is overseeing its relations with the former British colony, a newly released poll showed.

headline: South Carolina Resists as U.S. Seeks to Shut Down Disposal Site
text: WASHINGTON — As the Cold War ended, the United States and Russia agreed to each dispose of 34 tons of plutonium that was produced for use in nuclear weapons, with most of it being turned into fuel for civilian power reactors.

headline: Settling the Bets of the Private-Equity Megadeal’s Golden Age
text: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | It has long been the $45 billion corporate buyout that should never have happened.

headline: Intersection | Flatiron Functionality
text: In the Flatiron neighborhood of New York City, Aristotle Torres draws style inspiration from his childhood.

headline: Tony Awards 2014: ‘A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,’ ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’ Lead the Nominations Field
text: The nominations for the 68th Tony Awards were announced Tuesday morning in Manhattan. “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” led the Tony field with 10 nominations. “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” received eight, including one for its star, Neil Patrick Harris.

headline: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility Over Key Patents
text: BRUSSELS — Motorola Mobility broke European Union law by trying to wield unfair control over its basic patents for communications technologies used in smartphones and tablet computers, Europe’s antitrust chief said on Tuesday. But the commissioner did not fine the company, which is owned by Google.

headline: British Economic Growth Accelerates in First Quarter
text: LONDON — Britain’s recovery continues to gather pace with official figures on Tuesday showing growth of 0.8 percent in the first quarter of the year, confirming the country’s place among the world’s fastest-growing developed economies.

headline: Doximity, an Online Network for Doctors, Raises $54 Million
text: Facebook and LinkedIn have found success by gathering broad swaths of users. But several prominent investors are betting that a narrower focus can help a social network prosper.

headline: Finding the Right Early Customers for a Start-Up
text: Before starting my technology company, Posse, I built a music management company in Australia. With each new artist, we would start from scratch with no profile, no fan base and no money to spend on marketing. I’d work out how to develop a brand and how to reach the right community of early adopters.

headline: In Our Pages: April 30
text: 1914: Neutralization of Oil Fields

headline: SOLS, a 3-D Printing Start-Up, Raises $6.4 Million
text: Though SOLS Systems has begun to make a name for itself in the business of 3-D-printed custom orthotics, the start-up has bigger ambitions.

headline: Airbnb Takes to the Barricades
text: A few weeks ago, the renegade Nevada cattle rancher Cliven Bundy became famous for challenging the authority of the federal Bureau of Land Management. He promptly drew many supporters, both on the ground and in the conservative media, before he derailed his cause with racist comments.

headline: A New York Passover Story
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Failure in Texas
text: The troubled Texas utility Energy Future Holdings ‒ which, as TXU, was private equity’s biggest-ever buyout ‒ filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, Julie Creswell and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. After months of on-again, off-again talks between the company, its owners and creditors, Energy Future Holdings went into Chapter 11 protection with a plan meant to avoid months in bankruptcy court in what will be one of the biggest Chapter 11 filings in history.

headline: North Korea Lobs Shells Near Disputed Sea Border
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean military on Tuesday fired dozens of artillery shells near a disputed western sea border with South Korea, prompting thousands of South Korean islanders to flee to shelters.

headline: The Hunt for False Equivalence
text: America, it goes without saying, has a powerful, crazy right wing. There’s nothing equivalent on the left — yes, there are individual crazy leftists, but nothing like the organized, lavishly financed madness on the right.

headline: Dome it! Schools Can Affordably Survive Tornadoes
text: It had been very quiet in America’s tornado zone of late. But the deadly tornado outbreak Sunday night illustrated, once again, why it’s time for communities at risk to consider some new approaches to building — and learning — safely in harm’s way.

headline: MOCA Hosts a Retrospective of Francesco Vezzoli’s Star-Studded Art
text: The old-Hollywood hangout Musso and Frank Grill was an appropriate venue for a dinner last Friday celebrating Francesco Vezzoli’s new retrospective at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art. Decades ago, iconic stars of a screen era that has long inspired the artist — from Charlie Chaplin to Greta Garbo — dined at the wood-paneled restaurant’s signature red booths. The Italian artist is perhaps most famous for his videos featuring stars like Michelle Williams and Natalie Portman; on Friday, a host of L.A. luminaries — including Bret Easton Ellis and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte — turned out to show their support.

headline: Top Officer of Barclays in America Is Leaving
text: For years, Barclays of Britain fought to become one of Wall Street’s elite investment banks, including by buying the remains of Lehman Brothers’ American operations.

headline: 6 Wounded in Shooting at FedEx Warehouse in Georgia
text: A 19-year-old package handler at a FedEx warehouse in a suburb of Atlanta opened fire there on Tuesday morning, injuring six people before killing himself, the police said.

headline: 2014 Tony Award Nominations
text: Scenes from nominated musicals and plays.

headline: Tealium, an Ad Technology Start-Up, Raises $20 Million From Silver Lake
text: A start-up that focuses on the not-so-visible business of tagging Internet ads has secured support from a big Silicon Valley investment firm.

headline: In Performance: Tyne Daly
text: A scene from Terrence McNally’s play “Mothers and Sons,” featuring Tyne Daly in her Tony Award-nominated performance. The show, which also received a Tony nomination, is at the Golden Theater.

headline: Big Chinese Pork Producer Cancels Its $1.9 Billion I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — The WH Group of China, the world’s biggest pork producer, decided on Tuesday to cancel its $1.9 billion initial public offering of stock in Hong Kong because of lackluster demand.

headline: In Performance: Tyne Daly of ‘Mothers and Sons’
text: This week’s video is a scene from the Broadway play “Mothers and Sons,” which today received two Tony Award nominations: for the actress Tyne Daly and the playwright Terrence McNally. Ms. Daly portrays Katharine Gerard, a widow who travels to New York to visit Cal, the former partner of her son Andre, who died of AIDS several years prior, and Cal’s new husband, Will. In this scene Katharine, who lives in Dallas, explains why she’s “angry about almost everything.” The show, directed by Sheryl Kaller, is at the Golden Theater.

headline: 2014 Tony Award Nominations
text: Scenes from nominated musicals and plays.

headline: Pro-Assad Areas Are Attacked in Syria, Pointing to Election Trouble
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 50 people were killed in bomb, mortar and rocket attacks in government-controlled areas of Syria on Tuesday, as the international chemical weapons monitoring group declared that it was sending inspectors to the country to investigate suspected use of chlorine gas.

headline: Where Tornadoes Are a Known Danger, the One That Hits Home Still Stuns
text: LOUISVILLE, Miss. — Ilene Estes sorted through the rubble atop a concrete slab here that used to be her home of 46 years. Like thousands of others in the South whose homes and lives have been devastated by a series of deadly tornadoes this week, she was stunned and weary. Even in parts of the country where tornadoes are commonplace, when they directly hit your street, they are uncommon terrors, their savagery discovered as if for the first time.

headline: New Group Aims to Increase Number of Women in Management
text: A group of about two dozen chief executives and corporate leaders of major companies, along with the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, are joining together to push American companies to voluntarily bolster the number of women in company management, especially senior leadership.

headline: Tony Awards Ballot
text: Make your picks below for the 68th annual Tony Awards, honoring Broadway’s best. The awards ceremony, which will take place in New York on June 8, will be broadcast on CBS.

headline: Rent Too High? Move to Singapore
text: Anyone in the market for a luxury apartment in Hong Kong, London or Washington toward the end of last year was in luck. The rents on prime flats were sagging a bit. Billionaires could lock in leases on pieds-à-terre at a slight discount. You might suppose that those savings would trickle down to regular working Joes, but no — middle-market rents in those cities continued their apparently inexorable upward march.

headline: Mike Leigh to Direct ‘Pirates of Penzance’ for English National Opera
text: More than a few music fans who saw Mike Leigh’s 1999 film “Topsy-Turvy,” about Gilbert and Sullivan’s creation of “The Mikado,” have wondered what Mr. Leigh might do if he ever got the chance to stage one of their operettas. Now they will find out: the English National Opera announced Tuesday that Mr. Leigh would direct “The Pirates of Penzance” next season.

headline: Alliance Battles to Save Fannie and Freddie
text: Updated, 8:31 p.m. | The investor Bruce R. Berkowitz is providing seed money for a new group that is running advertisements in newspapers and on television to support Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage finance companies that lawmakers are trying to wind down.

headline: Market Report | Busy Bodies
text: With splashy prints that are artfully tropical, the classic one-piece is no longer just for conservative moms.

headline: Why Piketty’s Book Is a Bigger Deal in America Than in France
text: The American response to Thomas Piketty’s new book on inequality has been rapturous, with reviews comparing the author, a French economist, to Adam Smith, John Maynard Keynes and Karl Marx.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Intelligence Over Diversity
text: Below, an essay by Ashley K., one of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest

headline: 90 and Facing Eviction
text: Last month, 90-year-old Bella Hornung received an eviction notice from her assisted-living home in Brooklyn. She is determined to stay as long as possible, though aware that her options are dwindling.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Nominees to Help Fill Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday approved the nominations of Stanley Fischer and Lael Brainard to join the Federal Reserve’s depleted board, and it approved the nomination of Jerome H. Powell to a new term.

headline: Up in Years and All but Priced Out of New York
text: Nubia Chavez and Manuel Acuña have been bouncing from rental to rental around New York City like millennials. They recently decamped to a $700-a-month room in a Queens apartment, with a shared bathroom and no access to the kitchen except to make coffee.

headline: More Severe Weather After Deadly Tornado Outbreak
text: At least 11 people died Monday in Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee after a powerful storm system spawned multiple tornadoes and ripped across several states in the South, bringing the total death toll from the severe weather to more than two dozen people since Sunday, as our colleagues report.

headline: The Gun Report: April 29, 2014
text: Guns are being traded for drugs in Vermont and Massachusetts, and it has law enforcement worried, the Boston Globe reports. Vermont is grappling with a heroin epidemic that started for many as a prescription drug habit, and Massachusetts has tough gun laws, creating a toxic opportunity.

headline: Stop Worrying and Enjoy Rising Wages
text: The Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee is meeting this week, and if I may slightly tweak the hit song from the Disney movie “Frozen” so that it’s more relevant to monetary policy:

headline: Justices Back Rule Limiting Coal Pollution
text: WASHINGTON — In a major victory for the Obama administration, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate the smog from coal plants that drifts across state lines from 28 Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.

headline: ‘If You Think Preschool’s Bad, Just Wait Until Kindergarten’
text: I pushed the stroller into our packed elevator. “Did you decide on school?” a neighbor asked, smiling at Zee. But before I could nod, she went on, cackling, “If you think preschool’s bad, just wait until kindergarten.”

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Capture the Writer’s Life on Film?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss the difficulties of conveying what writers do on film.

headline: More Catholic Than the Pope?
text: My Sunday column used the double canonization of two of his predecessors to discuss some of the perils awaiting Pope Francis as his pontificate advances, and it concluded with a fairly stark claim: Some of the proposals on divorce, remarriage and communion that have been put forward by prominent figures in the church, I wrote, might lead to schism if the pope were to adopt and implement them.

headline: South Korea President Apologizes
text: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea apologized for failing to prevent a ferry disaster that left 302 people dead or missing and announced broad reforms to make the country safer.

headline: What Are Tonys Saying by Ignoring ‘Realistic Joneses’?
text: It’s a scandal! It’s an outrage! And it’s utterly predictable.
