text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Obama on Foreign Policy Approach in Asia
text: President Obama defended his strategy, saying “disputes must be resolved peacefully and not by intimidation or force.”

headline: Following K.K.R. on Twitter
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the oldest of the giant private equity firms, is dipping a toe into social media.

headline: How the Struggles of Boys Play Into the Still Sputtering Economy
text: At The Upshot, David Leonhardt links fidgety boys with the poorly functioning economy:

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 44
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Taking On a Pothole Law: In Winter, New York State Rejects Drivers’ Claims
text: Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democratic assemblyman from Westchester County, was driving to Albany on the Taconic State Parkway in January when his car struck a pothole. He made it to the capital, but the tire had to be replaced. A few weeks later, he hit another pothole, this one on Interstate 95. Limping off the exit ramp in Mamaroneck on the dented rim, he pulled into a nearby gas station.

headline: 92nd Street Y Names Two Leaders
text: The 92nd Street Y on Tuesday announced two new major leadership appointments. Henry Timms will become its new executive director and Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein will become director of Jewish community and the Bronfman Center for Jewish Life.

headline: The Folly of Prudence
text: Many American roads are in pretty bad shape — I can attest to that, after driving up to Massachusetts and back for family business last week. When you combine that fact with the underlying macroeconomic situation, of which more in a minute, the case for spending substantial sums on repair seems obvious.

headline: British Parliament Berates Officials on Royal Mail I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Usually it is falling stock prices after initial public offerings that cause headaches for bankers and business executives. In the case of Britain’s Royal Mail, it is the company’s soaring value that has ignited outrage.

headline: Money Talks. Especially Boehner’s.
text: Some House Republicans may feel they have good reason to oust John Boehner as Speaker next year, but there is at least one good reason not to: fund-raising. Mr. Boehner has been an increasingly important source of money for the National Republican Congressional Committee, the party wing that helps the G.O.P. maintain (and increase) its House majority.

headline: After Deriding G.O.P. on Immigration Bill, Boehner Shifts His Aim to Obama
text: WASHINGTON — A week after mocking his Republican troops over their resistance to an immigration bill, Speaker John A. Boehner returned to Capitol Hill on Tuesday with a different message: Any movement on an overhaul will depend on a new White House attitude toward Republicans in Congress.

headline: Image of the Day: April 29
text: Summer season in India is synonymous with the arrival of mangoes.

headline: Pfizer Most Likely Just the Tip of the Tax Sword
text: Pfizer’s $99 billion tax arbitrage bid will encourage copycats. The biggest charm of the United States drug giant’s offer for AstraZeneca of Britain lies in switching to a lower-tax domicile. The latest and largest such deal to hit the headlines raises the odds Congress will tighten rules – but not yet.

headline: For Obama, a Familiar Region With Familiar Troubles
text: MANILA — For President Obama, a visit to Southeast Asia is a homecoming of sorts. Nowhere was that more evident than in the town-hall-style meeting he conducted on Sunday in the Malaysian capital Kuala Lumpur with young people from across the region.

headline: Santander Offers $6.5 Billion to Buy the Rest of Its Brazil Unit
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Banco Santander announced on Tuesday a deal to acquire the 25 percent of its Brazilian unit, Santander Brasil, that it does not already own for 4.69 billion euros, or $6.52 billion.

headline: European Union Demand Lifts Gazprom Earnings
text: MOSCOW — Gazprom, Russia’s largest company, reported Tuesday a solid showing for its yearly earnings, which were up 10 percent in 2013, with most of the increase attributable to growing demand in the European Union.

headline: Instead of Saving for College, We Invested in Our Kids
text: This spring break, I sent my 17-year-old-son and his dad off on a three-state college tour with a dozen hard-boiled eggs, a rolled-up tent and tears.

headline: Even When Expecting Tornadoes, People Don’t Plan Well
text: The recent rash of tornadoes and deadly storms was not unexpected. It is, after all, peak season in the South and Midwest for tornadoes. Polling shows that large numbers of people living in these regions recognize that their communities are liable to be hit by a natural disaster, but most don’t have an emergency plan or an emergency supply kit for their families.

headline: N.B.A. Bars Clippers Owner Donald Sterling for Life
text: LOS ANGELES — The National Basketball Association on Tuesday handed a lifetime ban to the longtime Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, an extraordinary step in professional sports and one intended to rid the league of Mr. Sterling after he was recorded making racist comments.

headline: Art Matters | An Exhibition and Video Puts Art in the Hands of the Beholder
text: In 1919, Marcel Duchamp changed the course of art history when his sister Suzanne got married. Instead of mailing her a porcelain tea set or personalized table linens, the impish Duchamp sent several pages of text: a set of instructions that told Suzanne how to create the wedding present he imagined. (She was directed to hang a geometry textbook by strings from the balcony so that the wind could “choose its own problems.”) Since then, artists like Yoko Ono and Lawrence Weiner have taken Duchamp’s lead and run with it — making art by telling their audience what to do.

headline: Virginia Attorney General Opens In-State Tuition to Students Brought to U.S. Illegally
text: Attorney General Mark R. Herring of Virginia told the state’s public colleges and universities on Tuesday that children brought to the United States illegally and raised here, the so-called Dreamers, qualified for in-state tuition.

headline: Crunching the Numbers to Find the Best Airfare
text: You may have heard that the best day to buy an airline ticket is a Tuesday.

headline: Hotel Review: Belmond El Encanto in Santa Barbara, Calif.
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Ristorante Oreade in Castiglioncello del Trinoro, Italy
text: Tuscany’s food scene has never left visitors wanting improvement, but that hasn’t stopped local restaurateurs from striving for it. One recent addition, Ristorante Oreade, which opened last summer, is evidence that Tuscan cuisine — from food quality and presentation to restaurant design — can be lifted higher.

headline: Britain Outlines Stress Test for Its Banks
text: Imagine that things started to look very gloomy in Britain. The value of the pound falls, inflation rises, interest rates spike to 4 percent. The economy shrinks by 3.5 percent, unemployment reaches 12 percent, and housing prices fall 35 percent, with commercial real estate declining 30 percent. Stocks and bonds weaken and bank funding dries up.

headline: Military Aid for Egyptians Loses Support in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate subcommittee that oversees foreign aid, said Tuesday that he would not support additional military aid to Egypt in the wake of mass death sentences handed out by Egyptian courts this week, adding significant pressure on the Obama administration to shift course.

headline: Times Minute | Tony Award Nominations
text: On the Minute, the theater reporter Patrick Healy breaks down the nominees for the 68th Tony Awards. Find out who was nominated and who got snubbed.

headline: Times Minute | Tony Award Nominations
text: In the Video

headline: Ai Weiwei Erased From Show in Shanghai
text: The name and works of Ai Weiwei have been removed from a show in Shanghai about the history of Chinese contemporary art because of pressure from local government cultural officials, according to Mr. Ai and Uli Sigg, a Swiss art collector who helped organize the exhibition. Mr. Ai said he thought the move was in response to his vocal criticism of the Chinese government.

headline: Revisiting the Racial Gap in N.B.A. Coaching Tenure
text: With race and professional basketball in the news again, we thought it was a good time to revisit an article that Ford Fessenden and I wrote for The Times in 2005. I’d welcome thoughts and predictions on patterns in the last decade and in the future. Here are excerpts from the article:

headline: A Gust of Sesame and Saffron
text: When Ghaya Oliveira was appointed head pastry chef for the restaurant empire of Daniel Boulud, she began a stealth campaign. As she constructed new desserts for Daniel, the very French flagship in a very upscale ZIP code, she started to sneak in the flavors of her childhood in Tunisia: jasmine and sesame, rosewater and saffron.

headline: Listen Up | More Fearless Storytelling from Sharon Van Etten
text: The first song on the singer-songwriter Sharon Van Etten‘s thrilling new album, “Are We There,” out May 27, features this refrain: “I need you/to be afraid of nothing.” She might, perhaps, be referring to herself. Van Etten’s songwriting shows little traces of fear, setting matter-of-fact descriptions of awfully complicated emotions against deceptively simple verse structures. The songs are brave, and bravely unflashy. And that voice of hers — gritty, lilting, with phrasing that suggests that efforts to reveal herself cause just as much of herself to hide — sounds not merely fearless but unafraid of fear itself.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Scott Brown’s Take on ‘Obamacare’
text: Like confused poll respondents, Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts Senator who’s running for Senate in New Hampshire, says he thinks the Affordable Care Act is disastrous, but seems to like everything it does.

headline: A Corporate Paean to Frank Lloyd Wright
text: RACINE, Wis. — If anything is eternal in real estate, it is the dance of desire that exists between chief executives and their architects.

headline: Company Polishes Its Frank Lloyd Wright Collection
text: This week a portion of the Research Tower designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at the headquarters of S.C. Johnson in Racine, Wis., will reopen as a museum. The project is part of an eight-year effort by the company to restore its Wright campus.

headline: After Data Breach, Target Plans to Issue More Secure Chip-and-PIN Cards
text: Still pushing to right itself after an enormous data breach by cybercriminals, Target announced on Tuesday that it would switch its debit and credit cards over to a more secure technology by early next year, most likely making it the first major retailer in the country to do so.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on Cellphone Warrants
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed torn as it considered a pair of cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of people they arrest.

headline: Jaclyn Moriarty Talks About ‘Cracks in the Kingdom’
text: Jaclyn Moriarty, an Australian writer of young-adult fiction, has just published “The Cracks in the Kingdom,” the second volume in her lively and engaging “Colors of Madeleine” trilogy. Book 1, “A Corner of White,” was a Boston Globe-Horn Book honor title. The novels tell the story of a girl named Madeleine, who lives in our world, and a boy named Elliot, who lives in the Kingdom of Cello. They begin writing letters to each other through a crack that opens between their worlds — a crack in a parking meter.

headline: Up for Discussion: Why Have an Advisory Board?
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners continued their discussion of advisory boards.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Tahini
text: Rawia Bishara, the chef and owner of Tanoreen, discusses tahini made from sesame, one of the most universal flavors of the Middle East and the base for many of its staples.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Za’atar
text: Lior Lev Sercarz, a New York spice purveyor, demonstrates how to prepare za’atar, a fundamental Middle Eastern seasoning.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Yogurt
text: Ghaya Oliveira, the executive pastry chef at Daniel, discusses using yogurt as a sweet ingredient in Middle Eastern-influenced desserts.

headline: Before Watchdog Mission, a Trail of Videos Warned of Chlorine Gas Attacks in Syria
text: Syrian activists have been posting multiple videos in the past few weeks showing civilians at medical facilities in the village of Kafr Zita coughing and struggling to breathe, with the narrators during the footage identifying the cause of their condition as coming from the use of chlorine gas bombs.

headline: One Execution Botched, Oklahoma Delays the Next
text: McALESTER, Okla. — What was supposed to be the first of two executions here on Tuesday night was halted when the prisoner, Clayton D. Lockett, began to writhe and gasp after he had already been declared unconscious and called out “oh, man,” according to witnesses.

headline: Cast Is Announced for Next ‘Star Wars’ Film
text: LOS ANGELES — After months of fan speculation, J.J. Abrams on Tuesday finally switched off the cloaking devices protecting the identities of his “Star Wars” cast members. Seven newcomers and six stalwarts will star in the seventh installment of the space epic, which is scheduled for release in theaters in December 2015.

headline: Standing on the Sidelines With Virtual Reality
text: LOS ANGELES — D.J. Roller, a filmmaker and explorer, has captured videos of sharks, taken cameras under the Antarctic ice, and documented the discovery of the remains of a Tyrannosaurus Rex.

headline: N.B.A. Bars Clippers Owner for Life
text: The league commissioner, Adam Silver, called remarks by the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, “deeply offensive and harmful.”

headline: Turks to Seek Extradition of Preacher Living in U.S.
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Tuesday that Turkey would officially request that the United States extradite Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish preacher in Pennsylvania whose network of followers has been accused of trying to undercut Mr. Erdogan’s government through a corruption scandal.

headline: Mercedes Recalls 253,000 C-Class Cars for Fire Hazard
text: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Mercedes-Benz is recalling about 253,000 C-Class cars from the 2008-11 model years because the taillights could fail, according to a report the automaker posted Tuesday on the safety agency’s website.

headline: Godzilla’s Back, With Moral Authority
text: There are at least three versions of Godzilla stalking the landscape this Spring. There’s the campy, frat-boy Godzilla who parties and water skis in the Snickers candy bar commercial. There’s the apocalyptic, computer-generated terror who roars at us with a gale-force voice in the trailers for the Hollywood blockbuster due out next month. And making its way quietly through select theaters across the country is the 60th anniversary restoration of the original Godzilla classic — featuring a mere actor in a latex monster suit.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Resurrection
text: Part 11: John Adams recalls writing the final scene of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Unrest in Venezuela
text: Part 10: Gustavo Dudamel reflects on the political situation and street protests in Venezuela.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Crucifixion
text: Part 9: John Adams talks about composing for chorus and explains how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” was influenced by current events.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: El Sistema
text: Part 8: Gustavo Dudamel explains the impact that Venezuela’s “El Sistema” program had on him, and talks about the program’s continuing impact on the world of classical music.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: ‘Passover’
text: Part 7: The composer and conductor discuss the passage from “Gospel” that incorporates the Primo Levi poem “Passover.”

headline: Dudamel & Adams: The Performers
text: Part 6: John Adams talks about the vocalists and dancers who perform in the staged version of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Hard to Play
text: Part 5: The composer and conductor discuss Adams’ tendency to compose music that deliberately offsets the slickness and skill of the musicians performing it.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: A Living Composer
text: Part 4: The composer and conductor talk about how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” evolved over several performances.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: The Timeless Past
text: Part 3: John Adams explains how classical music can elevate a conventional story to relevance and even timelessness.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Collaborators
text: Part 2: The composer and conductor recall the origins of their collaborative relationship.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the conductor Gustavo Dudamel and the composer John Adams.

headline: TimesTalks | Dudamel & Adams: Preview

headline: Top Cable Lobbyist Argues Against Broadband as Utility
text: America’s infrastructure is crumbling, says Michael Powell, the chief executive of the cable industry’s trade association. Roads are in poor condition, bridges are structurally deficient, drinking water systems are near the end of their useful life and portions of the electric grid suffer regular blackouts.

headline: Alliant Techsystems’ Break-Up and the Return of the Morris Trust
text: It’s rare enough to see companies use the reverse Morris trust, a somewhat esoteric corporate finance maneuver used to cut down on taxes in a merger. But it warmed DealBook’s heart on Tuesday to see a company use the even less common Morris trust.

headline: The Quirk That Bolsters Allergan’s Defense
text: In the $45.6 billion takeover battle for Allergan, there has been much speculation about what will be the next steps.

headline: Pfizer’s Move Poses Challenge. Here’s a Solution.
text: This is what strange behavior our corporate tax policy produces: The pharmaceutical company Pfizer has offered $100 billion to buy AstraZeneca, a British competitor, and avoiding taxes has a lot to do with it.

headline: Shirley
text: Shirley Austin speaks about how her therapy dog has helped her.

headline: The Voices of Schizophrenia
text: Amber (who did not disclose her last name,) talks about how the voices of schizophrenia impact her life.

headline: Alice
text: Alice finds that painting helps her deal with the stress of schizophrenia.

headline: A Texas Bankruptcy Seeks a Home in Delaware
text: Energy Future Holdings, the big Texas utility company formerly known as TXU, and its myriad related companies filed their Chapter 11 bankruptcy petitions in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday morning.

headline: A Grande Dame Branches Out
text: The day of reckoning came on a recent Tuesday for the tacos, enchiladas verdes, cactus salad and pork posole served at Tortilleria Nixtamal in Corona, Queens.

headline: Battery Park City: Quasi-Suburban
text: Battery Park City, the 92-acre planned community developed since 1980 on landfill along the west side of Lower Manhattan, is for many New Yorkers akin to a new guest bedroom added to the side of a beloved old house. It’s sleeker and more functional than the main residence, but it lacks the character and inspired disorder of the creaky old place, and you never set foot in there without a very specific reason.

headline: Bending Tradition, and Bowing to It
text: “The chef calls this one the gun, because it hits you,” our server at Cagen said promisingly as she set the night’s last bite, a stubby little handroll, on the table. Glossy and dark, it looked, if you had a suggestible turn of mind, something like the barrel of a snub-nose revolver, with a metallic sheen it got from its seaweed wrapper, a rare blend of green and black kelp. The gunpowder was inside: an extra-hot, nostril-punishing slug of wasabi implanted alongside strands of sweet squash, waiting to go off when I bit into it.

headline: How Tax Laws Distort the Pfizer Deal
text: The United States tax code is fueling Pfizer Inc.’s $98.7 billion bid to take over the London-based pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca. If the deal goes through as proposed, a new parent company in Britain would own the combined entity, making it easier for the new firm to strip income out of its American tax base. The deal is one of several recent transactions known as “inversions,” where a multinational company like Pfizer, based in New York, becomes an expatriate by acquiring a smaller foreign target.

headline: Vancouver Art Gallery Names New Building’s Designer
text: The Vancouver Art Gallery has selected Herzog & de Meuron to design its new and expanded home in downtown Vancouver, the gallery announced on Tuesday. The new building, which doubles the museum’s current space, will be the Swiss architects’ first project in Canada.

headline: Heroin and Alcohol Led to the Deaths of Ex-SEALs
text: The authorities in the Seychelles said Tuesday that they had determined that a combination of heroin and alcohol was responsible for the deaths of two former members of the Navy SEALs working as guards on board a container ship in February.

headline: Reaction to Donald Sterling’s Punishment
text: N.B.A. players have a publicly united message for Adam Silver, the league’s new commissioner: Thanks, boss.

headline: ‘The Velocity of Autumn’ to Close
text: The new Broadway play “The Velocity of Autumn” will close on Sunday after just four and a half weeks of performances, the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Decoy Opens Beneath RedFarm in the West Village
text: Headliner

headline: Baseball, Happiness and Immigration: Exploring American Society and History With New York Times Maps
text: Like other images — whether photographs, charts or graphs — maps can tell a complicated story.

headline: Raw Feelings, With an Aesthetic of Naïveté
text: Frankie Cosmos’s songs are alive with the raw pink of new feeling, tender to the touch. “I’m the kind of girl buses splash with rain” were the first words she sang on Monday night at Glasslands Gallery, and she didn’t even look that sad about it, because just being aware had its own power.

headline: Hot Flashes? Great News.
text: Most male directors would think twice before wading into a comedy about menopause, but not Henry Jaglom. For his 19th film, “The M Word,” this warmly humane and unfailingly indulgent observer of women and their distractions — as celebrated in “Babyfever” (1994) and “Going Shopping” (2005) — proves as comfortable with hot flashes as with cooling desire.

headline: A Circle of Composers, Intimate and Epic
text: There is an operatic quality coursing through the work of the Second Empire sculptor Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux (1827-75), the subject of a powerful exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, through May 26, that inspired a concert of French vocal music at the museum on Saturday evening.

headline: An Indie Spirits Shop, a History Book on Ramen, Real Baby Carrots and More
text: To Shop: Independent Spirits With a Story to Tell

headline: Celebrating Higher Powers With Performers Here on Earth
text: “Dancing the Gods,” an annual festival of Indian dance presented by the World Music Institute, has a record of attracting some truly godlike dancers. In the first year, there were Rama Vaidyanathan and Shantala Shivalingappa. Then came Surupa Sen and Bijayini Satpathy (who, it happens, will perform in an unrelated concert at Baryshnikov Arts Center on Thursday and Friday). These are all stars, dazzling and recognized.

headline: Wheelies: The Solo Alfa Romeo Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Withdrawn Chinese I.P.O. Is the Least Bad Outcome
text: This little piggy isn’t going to the market after all.

headline: N.B.A. Players, Coaches and Executives React on Social Media to Sterling’s Ban
text: On Facebook  and Twitter, N.B.A. players, coaches and executives heaped praise on Adam Silver, the league’s new commissioner, for his decision to ban the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, for making racist remarks that became public in an audio recording.

headline: U.S. Announces Actions to Enforce Iran Sanctions
text: The United States government escalated enforcement of its Iran sanctions on Tuesday, adding eight Chinese companies, a Dubai company and two Dubai-based executives to blacklists for evading American restrictions on Iranian weapons, oil and banking transactions.

headline: Alstom’s Board Is Said to Back $13 Billion G.E. Bid for Energy Unit
text: The board of Alstom, the French industrial giant, voted on Tuesday to accept General Electric’s bid for its power and energy unit, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Boehner Recasts Immigration Blame
text: Speaker John A. Boehner addressed the comments he made about the G.O.P. and immigration and said any movement forward on immigration hinged on President Obama’s attitude toward Republicans.

headline: China’s Ruling Party Expels and Investigates Official
text: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party has authorized a criminal investigation of Li Chuncheng, a disgraced senior official who was close to Zhou Yongkang, the former domestic security chief at the heart of an extensive graft inquiry.

headline: Definitely Not a Groupie, but Always With the Band
text: There are a pair of sentences on the first page of Lisa Robinson’s memoir, “There Goes Gravity: A Life in Rock and Roll,” that make you think her book is going to be a gift, in a Nora Ephron meets Chrissie Hynde sort of way.

headline: Blast in Gaza Damages Boat Meant for Protest
text: GAZA — An explosion before dawn on Tuesday partially sank a small boat that Palestinian and foreign activists were planning to use to challenge the Israeli-imposed naval blockade of the Gaza Strip. Organizers of the protest said they suspected sabotage. The boat, Gaza’s Ark, an old fishing trawler refurbished as a cargo vessel, was docked in the Gaza harbor used by fishermen. In a statement, the organizers said a security guard received an anonymous phone call warning him to leave the boat shortly before the explosion. Palestinian fishing boats are permitted to sail up to six nautical miles from the coast under Israeli restrictions. The boat was scheduled to sail in June from Gaza to European ports carrying Palestinian goods for export. Attempts to breach the blockade have usually involved boats trying to sail to Gaza. In 2010, Israeli naval commandos killed nine activists during a raid at sea on a Turkish vessel after clashes broke out on board.

headline: A Bag in the Overhead Bin? There’s a Charge for That
text: Looking to save money on a flight? Pack light.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: What’s In It | Veggie Blend-Ins
text: Green Giant Veggie Blend-Ins offer vegetables in puréed form to those who routinely avoid them. Are there any potential pitfalls?

headline: Stealth Vegetables
text: For years, the government has been urging Americans to eat more vegetables for better health, with little to show for the effort. Consumption has been stuck at barely half the recommended amount. Now, from private enterprise, come two very different strategies. One aims to make vegetables more attractive and easier to use. The other would actually make them less visible, slipping them into other foods.

headline: A Marathon Performance (Aches, Too)
text: The music of Morton Feldman, for me, is like an acquaintance you don’t really click with but whose virtues you can appreciate in small doses. I can admire Feldman’s spare, slow-moving aesthetic in moderation, but I find his larger works unbearably tedious. And large, by Feldman standards, is gigantic: His String Quartet No. 2 lasts around six hours. When I learned I’d been assigned to review a performance of the piece, I had a brief vision of being trapped in a never-ending Feldman loop, a sort of Sartrean aural damnation.

headline: Revenue Up at Twitter, but Growth Is a Worry
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter is struggling to convince Wall Street that it is still a company with plenty of potential to grow.

headline: Prana Living, Yoga Gear Maker, Is Sold to Columbia Sportswear
text: As more Americans practice yoga, a booming market has sprung up for stretchy pants designed to accommodate poses like downward dog.

headline: Behind Focus on College Assaults, a Steady Drumbeat by Students
text: WASHINGTON — In March, two women who were sexually assaulted when they were students at the University of North Carolina arrived unannounced at the office of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand with a request: Help us stop sexual assault on college campuses.

headline: The N.B.A. Shifts to Maximum Outrage
text: The N.B.A.’s decision to ban Donald Sterling for life — to be followed shortly by the deletion of the Los Angeles Clippers from the Sterling family of mismanaged properties — was all the more impressive because of the huge reversal it represented. After decades of neglect regarding Mr. Sterling’s well-documented racial attitudes, the league suddenly threw everything it could find at him, the maximum penalty, the maximum fine, the maximum language of official fury.

text: South Korea and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Real Madrid Routs Bayern Munich in Champions League
text: MUNICH — Cristiano Ronaldo sprinted toward the end line, his arms shaking and his eyes wide. Suddenly he stopped in front of a wall of Bayern Munich fans at the Allianz Arena, and held up 10 fingers. Then he dropped one hand and raised five fingers again.

headline: Artists Hold Up a Glass to a City’s Changing Face
text: The idea of a Dan Graham pavilion in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s roof garden is so obvious, so perfect, that it really should have happened years ago. But late is better than never, and Mr. Graham’s execution of the project more than makes up for lost time.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Korea, Philippines, Washington and Mississippi.

headline: For the Whitney’s Move, Boxes and Burly Men Just Won’t Do
text: Anyone who has ever unwrapped a chipped piece of Wedgwood understands the headaches and peril associated with moving.

headline: For a New Mother, an Illness and a Legacy
text: Tucked into the program for Oni Faida Lampley’s “Tough Titty,” at the Paradise Factory Theater, is a pamphlet for a major breast cancer research charity, which brings to mind an early scene in this mordantly funny, quietly wrenching, semi-autobiographical play.

headline: Unfinished Revolution: The Artists Soldier On
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The National Art Museum of Ukraine has just opened an exhibition of objects from the compound of former President Viktor F. Yanukovych, including a folk-art portrait of him made of poppy seeds and beans. A folk-rock group, all women, performs a raucous cabaret at night, while other artists busily produce videos about the aftermath of the mass uprising.

headline: A Shot. A Man Falls, Clutching His Chest ... Etc.
text: Eugene O’Neill — what a bully! His stage directions go on for pages at a time, dictating every aspect of a play’s set, costumes and performance.

headline: Fieldwork of Total Immersion
text: When newly minted Ph.D.s go on the job market, they usually have questions about the teaching load, research money and tenure prospects.

headline: Tony Nominations Spread Across a Wide Stage
text: The major races for Broadway’s Tony Awards will be unusually wide-open this spring, with the nominations, announced on Tuesday, showing more love for Shakespeare than for Hollywood and for popular songs by Carole King and Duke Ellington than for original musicals. Ambitiously conceived productions like “Rocky” and “If/Then” fared poorly, and some of the season’s most praised performers — including the boldface names Daniel Radcliffe and Denzel Washington — were edged out.

headline: A $15 Minimum Wage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ball Is in the N.B.A. Owners’ Court
text: It’s the owners’ ball now. They are on the clock. Shame on them if they do not run the play that sends Donald Sterling out the N.B.A.’s back door within the procedural equivalent of a 24-second possession.

headline: Yahoo Chief’s Pay Tied to Another Company’s Performance
text: Marissa Mayer has hit it big in the executive compensation lottery.

headline: A new bill will make it easier to spot wasteful federal spending.
text: In a year or three. The House and Senate this week unanimously approved a bill — the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) — that will provide detailed information to the public on federal programs and checkbook-level payments for both internal agency spending and outside grants and contracts. That’s a big deal for researchers and watchdogs — when the changes show up on USASpending.gov.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Peter B. Hennessy
text: Mr. Hennessy, 53, is the president for the tristate region at Cassidy Turley, a commercial real estate services company that was formed about four years ago after the merger of eight firms, including four former Colliers affiliates. The tristate division is made up of offices in New York and New Jersey and has about 470 employees.

headline: PEN World Voices Festival Opens ‘On the Edge’
text: The 10th annual PEN World Voices Festival got underway Monday night with a series of brief politically focused speeches by prominent international writers at the Great Hall at Cooper Union. The festival’s program promised that the evening, called “On the Edge,” would feature bouts of “unrestrained intellectual fury,” and the line to get in stretched around a corner of the building.

headline: The Basis for Sterling’s Punishment
text: The Times sports reporter Harvey Araton asked the N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver, whether the Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, was punished for a single incident or multiple acts.

headline: White House Wants to Lift Ban on Interstate Tolls
text: WASHINGTON — Drivers on the nation’s Interstates could soon be paying more to travel.

headline: Clip: ‘Neighbors’
text: A scene from the film featuring Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne and Zac Efron.

headline: Everyday People in Everyday Asia
text: Inspired by a project that challenges stereotypes about Africa, a Delhi-based freelancer aims to portray daily moments in Asia.

headline: Trailer: ‘Tammy’
text: A preview of the film.

text: This is not what you were looking for, but nice try.

text: A preview of the film.

headline: Growth in Global Trade Is in Ideas, Not Stuff
text: Most of us have a mental image of what globalization looks like. It’s garment workers in an overcrowded Bangladeshi factory, making clothing that will end up on sale at a discount store in a strip mall. It’s container ships stuffed with consumer electronics from China headed for American ports, or tankers full of Middle Eastern oil fulfilling the world’s demand for energy.

headline: Obama’s Pop Culture Legacy
text: Michael D. Shear examines how popular culture has incorporated the issues that President Obama has faced.

headline: Trailer: ‘A Million Ways...’
text: A preview of the film.

headline: In Game 7, Sharks Are Going to Need a Bigger Effort
text: LOS ANGELES — For the San Jose Sharks and the Los Angeles Kings, Game 7 Wednesday night will feel familiar, for different reasons.

headline: The Rise of the Drone Master: Pop Culture Recasts Obama
text: WASHINGTON — In Marvel’s latest popcorn thriller, Captain America battles Hydra, a malevolent organization that has infiltrated the highest levels of the United States government. There are missile attacks, screeching car chases, enormous explosions, evil assassins, data-mining supercomputers and giant killer drones ready to obliterate millions of people.

headline: Geno Smith’s Progression Is Key to Jets’ Quarterback Competition
text: Marty Mornhinweg, the Jets’ offensive coordinator, will manage the quarterback competition between Geno Smith and Michael Vick with one objective in mind.

headline: Jaromir Jagr Is Set to Return, Devils Say
text: Jaromir Jagr is set to return to the Devils next season, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said Tuesday. Jagr, 42, led the Devils in scoring last season with 67 points on 24 goals and 43 assists. He played all 82 games, as well as each one of the Czech Republic’s six games at the Sochi Olympics. He is tied for sixth place with Steve Yzerman in N.H.L. career scoring, with 1,755 points, and is the league’s leading scorer among active players.

headline: A String of Violent Storms Across the South and Midwest
text: Severe weather across the country affected states from Michigan to Florida.

headline: The Right Way to Develop Shale Gas
text: LISTENING to the polarized energy debate in the United States, you might think natural gas was an economic and geopolitical cure-all — or an environmental curse. Too many oil and gas executives behave as if this newly abundant resource, released from underground shale deposits by the combination of horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, has no environmental challenges. Opponents often act as if it has no economic and environmental benefits.

headline: Nurses Are Not Doctors
text: EARLIER this month, the New York State Legislature passed a bill granting nurse practitioners the right to provide primary care without physician oversight. New York joins 16 other states and the District of Columbia in awarding such autonomy. (Most states still require nurse practitioners to work with physicians under a written practice agreement.) The bill’s authors contend that mandatory collaboration with a physician “no longer serves a clinical purpose” and reduces much-needed access to primary care.

headline: Report Finds Deportations Focus on Criminal Records
text: WASHINGTON — A program of cooperation between federal immigration authorities and state and local police departments has been effective at focusing deportations on immigrants with a criminal record, according to a report published Tuesday by the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research organization here.

headline: Do You Live Near I-35? Contribute to Our Reporting
text: A New York Times reporter, Damien Cave, and photographer, Todd Heisler, are traveling the length of I-35, chronicling how immigration is changing the U.S. Where should they visit?

headline: Bagels, Lox and Me
text: On Sunday, I put on my running clothes, went out to the elevator, and pushed the button. In the time it took for my finger to travel from the wall back to my side, I’d decided that it was not a day for a run but for a trip to the market. I slipped a coat over everything and went to the store, where I bought bagels, lox and cream cheese, along with some badly needed staples. I then came home and ate. (While, of course, reading The Sunday Times. Sigh. Sometimes it’s tough to be a cliché.)

headline: Amid a Revived East-West Chill, Cold War Relics Draw New Interest
text: MOSCOW — Stand in a dark tunnel as a red light flashes overhead and an air raid siren howls.

headline: New York State Makes New Efforts to Combat Payday Lenders
text: Curbing abusive payday lending practices can sometimes resemble a game of Whac-A-Mole: every time regulators manage to push down one method the industry uses, another new method seems to crop up.

headline: Jewish Groups Consider Including J Street
text: The American Jewish community, increasingly vexed by debate over Israel within its ranks, faces a closely watched test this week: The major umbrella organization of Jewish groups plans to vote on whether to admit a dovish lobbying organization that has been critical of some Israeli policies.

headline: Official Slams Brazil’s Olympic Planning
text: The International Olympic Committee’s vice president, John D. Coates, said Brazil’s preparations for the 2016 Olympic Games were “the worst” he has ever experienced.

headline: Massachusetts: Under Fire, Leader of Children’s Agency Steps Down
text: After the deaths of three children and an outcry by officials, Olga I. Roche, commissioner of the state Department of Children and Families, resigned Tuesday. Gov. Deval Patrick had defended Ms. Roche in recent months, but on Tuesday he said, “She can no longer command the trust of the public or the confidence of her line staff.” In one case, the police in Grafton had sent a fax to the agency warning that a baby, Aliana Lavigne, might be in danger. But the police failed to make a follow-up phone call, and no one at the agency saw the fax for six days. By then, the baby was dead. The governor named Erin Deveney, a former motor vehicles official, as interim commissioner.

headline: Preparations for Rio Olympics ‘the Worst,’ Committee Official Says
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A top International Olympic Committee official on Tuesday called Rio de Janeiro’s preparations to host the 2016 Summer Olympics “the worst I have experienced,” adding to a growing chorus of doubts about the city’s ability to get ready for the Games without international help.

headline: Wooing Advertisers by Using Laughs
text: THE growing interest on Madison Avenue in digital video as an advertising medium is putting a new twist on 1980s-era television, as “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” gets remixed online as programming that is rich in lifestyle content or programming that tries to become famous by being funny.

headline: Hagel Seeks Review of Military Policies on Hairstyles
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Tuesday ordered the American military to review its policies concerning hairstyles popular with black women, telling critics of new Army regulations banning large cornrows, twists and dreadlocks that he takes “very seriously” concerns that military rules on hair have unfairly targeted black women.

headline: Two Giant Banks, Seen as Immune, Become Targets
text: Federal prosecutors are nearing criminal charges against some of the world’s biggest banks, according to lawyers briefed on the matter, a development that could produce the first guilty plea from a major bank in more than two decades.

headline: Christie Nominates Ex-Attorney General to Lead Port Authority
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey nominated a former state attorney general on Tuesday as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as he seeks to disentangle the agency and himself from the scandal surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closings.

headline: With Peace Talks Off, Netanyahu Looks at Unilateral Moves
text: JERUSALEM — After halting peace talks with the Palestinians last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has asked his cabinet to bring forward alternative approaches to the intractable conflict, which are likely to include annexing parts of the West Bank or withdrawing from some settlements and shoring up others.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Wisconsin Law Requiring Photo ID at Polls
text: A federal judge on Tuesday struck down Wisconsin’s law requiring voters to produce state-approved photo identification cards at polling places, advancing a new legal basis — the Voting Rights Act — for similar challenges playing out around the nation.

headline: In the U.S., Punishment Comes Before the Crimes
text: Few things are better at conveying what a nation really cares than how it spends its money. On that measure, Americans like to punish.

headline: Spotify Teams With Sprint on a Mobile Music Plan
text: Spotify, the streaming music company, has struck a deal with Sprint to help market and promote its service, which offers millions of songs free and by subscription.

headline: Challenging Putin’s Values
text: While you can talk about Ukraine until the cows come home, this story is 95 percent about Vladimir Putin and how he has chosen to define Russia’s interests. The truth is, Russia and its neighbors need a different definition of Russia’s interests. That, however, raises a series of questions: Can Moscow ever define its interests differently under Putin? If not, how do we deter him without also weakening Russia to the point of instability? And if we do induce such instability over time with sanctions, do we know what comes next and will we be better off?

headline: Developer Scales Back Plans for Muslim Center Near Ground Zero
text: The developer whose proposal to build a Muslim community center and mosque near the World Trade Center failed amid a national controversy three years ago said Tuesday that he now plans to construct a museum devoted to Islam in the same location.

headline: Commissioner Sees Basis for Ousting Clippers’ Owner
text: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver deployed the nuclear option on Tuesday to force the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, out of the league for racist remarks he made in a recorded conversation. Now, will Silver’s actions — banishing Sterling for life from team and league business, and urging the other owners to vote to force him to sell the club — withstand any legal challenges?

headline: Voter ID Is the Real Fraud
text: For the first time since the Supreme Court junked a core provision of the Voting Rights Act in June, a federal court has used the strongest surviving part of the act to strike down a state’s voter-identification law, and, in the process, has set out a detailed road map for upcoming challenges to similar laws around the country.

headline: Milder View of Suspect in U.S. Case on Terror
text: It was around a year ago that the government unsealed charges against a Tunisian citizen named Ahmed Abassi, saying he had come to the United States to develop a network of terrorists and commit acts of terror. Prosecutors said he had “radicalized” one supposed terrorist and spoken of killing 100,000 people through bioterrorism.

headline: Amid Iraq’s Unrest, Maliki Campaigns as Strongman
text: BAGHDAD — When a well-known journalist was shot dead at a checkpoint here last month, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki rushed to the scene. Speaking to a television camera, he promised “blood for blood.”

headline: Not Getting Through to Mr. Putin
text: The United States and the European Union announced another round of sanctions against Russia on Monday and Tuesday: the Americans against Russians close to President Vladimir Putin, including the president of the state-owned oil company Rosneft; and the Europeans against senior Russian officials and secessionist leaders in Ukraine. The stated reason is that Russia has fulfilled none of the commitments it made at a meeting with Ukraine, the United States and the European Union in Geneva on April 17, and that Russia’s “involvement in the recent violence in eastern Ukraine is indisputable.”

headline: Is Barry Whiffing?
text: WASHINGTON — Stop whining, Mr. President.

headline: New York City Council Backs New Rules on Discretionary Money and Bills
text: Members of the New York City Council united on Tuesday behind proposed rules that would democratize the bill-drafting process and the way in which discretionary funds are apportioned to individual lawmakers — steps that fell short of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s call to do away with such spending entirely.

headline: Author of the Book ‘Gravity’ Sues Warner Bros. Over Credit
text: LOS ANGELES — The best-selling author Tess Gerritsen filed a lawsuit against Warner Bros. on Tuesday that claims the studio at least partly based “Gravity” on one of her books and as a result, owes her 2.5 percent of the blockbuster film’s net profit.

headline: Cano and the Yankees Are Secure in Their Decisions
text: At the end of the 1990s, when the Seattle Mariners lost more often than they won, their marquee player often grew exasperated when asked about the team’s struggles. Ken Griffey Jr. would sigh and say, “I bat third,” three words that spoke an essential truth about baseball.

headline: An Alarm Over the Incursion of Foreign Words
text: Few major languages have felt the effects of globalization and modernization more acutely than Mandarin. The increasing use of keyboard devices, for example, has caused many Chinese to forget how to write characters by hand, to the extent that there is even a popular television show in which contestants compete to write complicated characters from memory.

headline: Can Voluntourism Make a Difference?
text: As students, retirees and others head abroad this summer in search of experiences volunteering, are they really looking to help others or just themselves?

headline: An Early Skyscraper Becomes a Hotel With a View
text: For years, development plans came and went at 5 Beekman Street like City Hall workers filing in and out of their nearby offices in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Grabbing the Derby Roses a Second Time Is a Tricky Task
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The trainer Chip Woolley made an arduous drive when he took Mine That Bird from Sunland Park in New Mexico to Churchill Downs here five years ago. He had to use his left leg instead of his right, which had been fractured in a motorcycle accident, but he was comforted by the thought that he would be competing in his first Kentucky Derby with a horse that he believed belonged.

headline: Emails Show Sotheby’s Board Shared Some of Loeb’s Concerns
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — Directors of Sotheby’s have expressed concern about compensation and the board’s performance, according to emails disclosed on Tuesday during a hearing in a dispute with the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: Social Media in Afghanistan Takes On Life of Its Own
text: WASHINGTON — Afghans have long been resistant to central authority — as the United States has found to its frustration — with Afghanistan divided along tribal, cultural, religious and linguistic lines. Its mountains and valleys have stood in the way of communications breakthroughs that have unified other societies.

headline: Reinventing Rye Playland Ignites an Unexpected Battle
text: RYE, N.Y. — It seemed, on its face, an unassailable approach to reinventing Rye Playland, the Art Deco amusement park in this wealthy shore town, for the 21st century — innocuous even. Spiff up the amusement rides, expand the green space, and draw year-round visitors to the county-run park with new playing fields and restaurants.

headline: Epic Battle in Technology
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Full disclosure: I am an unabashed MAC fangirl. Yes, I have used both PCs and MACs. This isn’t a case of “Oh, she’s just never tried using a PC …”. I have, and I have very strong opinions about this subject. Even so, I’m a professional, and I’m fairly certain that I will be able to cover this topic in a way that will not affect today’s blog post at all. [Uh oh. –Ed.]

headline: Old and Familiar Rivals Are Squaring Off in Texas
text: DALLAS — As Manu Ginobili ambled off the court at American Airlines Center on Monday night, it was fairly evident that playoff game No. 161 for him had taken its toll. At this stage, they all do.

headline: Williams Once Again Shows That He Is His Toughest Critic
text: Late Sunday night, shortly after the Nets fumbled away a close game to the Toronto Raptors, point guard Deron Williams, unprompted, said he put the burden of the loss on himself.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 29, 2014
text: April 29, 2014

headline: At Sentencing Hearing, Killer Hears From Police, and His Victim’s Mother
text: The mother’s voice began to break as she described her daughter’s 19 stab wounds, the blood, the abrupt end of dreams. She leaned over the court railing, her body rigid, her voice rising and splintering. The tears came.

headline: Slow Going on Overhaul of Mortgage Finance
text: WASHINGTON — In the long, boggy work of overhauling the nation’s mortgage finance system, Tuesday morning was supposed to be an important milestone: the Senate Banking Committee was scheduled to meet and put the finishing touches on a bipartisan bill that would affect the ability of millions of Americans to buy a home.

headline: For Clippers, Transition in Decision Making Begins
text: LOS ANGELES — Soon after N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver handed down a lifetime ban to Donald Sterling on Tuesday, the Clippers’ website, the one still owned but no longer operated under the direction of Sterling, went black.

headline: Allstate Case Shows Risk of Signing Away the Right to Sue
text: When his children were young, Nathan Littlejohn was a regional salesman in search of a position that would allow him to spend more time with his family. So when he heard about Allstate’s neighborhood agent program in 1990, he was intrigued.

headline: 20 Killed in Southern Yemen as Ground Assault Begins
text: The first day of a government ground offensive aimed at dislodging militants from Al Qaeda in southern Yemen led to the deaths of 20 people on Tuesday, mostly Yemeni soldiers, officials said. The assault by the army and allied militias on militant hide-outs in Shabwa and Abyan Provinces came days after heavy airstrikes in the area by Yemeni warplanes and American drones. The deadliest clash on Tuesday occurred in Shabwa Province when militants ambushed a convoy carrying security officials. A medical official in the provincial capital said the hospital there had received the bodies of 15 soldiers and treated 10 wounded soldiers. The Defense Ministry denied losing any soldiers in Shabwa, and the state-run news agency said that five militants were killed in fighting there. In neighboring Abyan, army convoys moved in without any reported resistance.

headline: Apple and Samsung Cite, and Rebut, Internal Memos in Patent Case
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When Steven P. Jobs introduced the iPhone in January 2007, he said the device’s new touch-screen technology worked like magic. He also said, “And boy, have we patented it!”

headline: Two Rulings May Curb Lawsuits Over Patents
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of unanimous decisions, the Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for the winning side in patent cases to recover its legal fees from the loser. The decisions were welcomed by some technology companies, which said the rulings would help address what they say are abusive and coercive lawsuits brought by “patent trolls,” or companies that buy patents not to use them but to collect royalties and damages.

headline: Yet Again, Rangers Seem Averse to Prosperity
text: PHILADELPHIA — Some streaks defy logic, but the Rangers’ current run of futility may be the strangest of all: an N.H.L.-record 12 straight defeats while holding a lead in a playoff series.

headline: Will Liberal Cities Leave the Rest of America Behind?
text: How can governments adopt substantial, effective policies in order to benefit the poor and the working class when corporations, the affluent and owners of capital can pull up stakes and relocate with ease?

headline: Yanks Fall, Then Lose Pineda to Injury
text: On a cold, raw evening in the Bronx, with only a few thousand people in the stands, the focus of a dreary game was squarely on the return of Robinson Cano, who was roundly booed during each of his at-bats.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Dead Dogs, Spiders and Pestilence
text: O.K., after watching the third episode of “Fargo,” I am packing my “go bag” with Bactine, and perhaps a machete, a few guns and a helmet to wear in the shower, all in case of the apocalypse.

headline: Simmonds Sweeps In Puck 3 Times While Taking Care of Dirty Work
text: PHILADELPHIA — When the Flyers are on the power play, it is not difficult to find Wayne Simmonds. He is the player stationed by the net, screening the goalie, buzzing across the crease, absorbing slashes and elbows and crosschecks, positioning himself in case the puck finds its way to him.

headline: India Election Digest: April 30
text: What you need to know about India’s election on Wednesday: This is the seventh of the nine phases of the parliamentary elections, with 89 seats up for grabs over seven states and two union territories. The areas going to vote are: Andhra Pradesh (17 constituencies), Bihar (7), Gujarat (26), Jammu and Kashmir (1), Punjab (13), Uttar Pradesh (14), West Bengal (9), Dadra and Nagar Haveli (1), Daman and Diu (1).

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Drop Everything
text: When worn with a slicked-back bun and a fresh face, a pair of dazzling pendant earrings is the perfect mate for a sunset stroll.

headline: Nearly Half of New Yorkers Are Struggling to Get By, Study Finds
text: New York City’s share of poor people appears to have plateaued since the recession, at 21.4 percent, with more people working in 2012 than the year before, but at lower wages, according to a new city study. Contributing to the city’s economic problems were increases in the number of Asian-Americans, immigrants and residents of Queens slipping into poverty.

headline: Want to Be More Creative? Take a Walk
text: From our archives.

headline: Word of the Day | grate
text: grate•\ˈgrat\• noun and verb

headline: Frederic Schwartz, 63, Dies; Designed Sept. 11 Memorials
text: Frederic Schwartz, an architect whose plan to rebuild the World Trade Center site finished second among hundreds of entries, and who went on to create memorials in New Jersey and Westchester County to victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Niese Again Rises Above the Gloom
text: By ZACH SCHONBRUN

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (FX) THE AMERICANS A new mission with global stakes forces Philip (Matthew Rhys, who stars with Keri Russell, above) to seek help from Annelise (Gillian Alexy), just as an old enemy returns to Washington with a vendetta. Stan (Noah Emmerich), meanwhile, makes a discovery that could help the F.B.I. close in on the K.G.B. illegals. The episode also features “It Must Be Done,” an original song written by Pete Townshend of the Who — his first for a television series — and the show’s composer, Nathan Barr.

headline: Insurance Site and Walmart in Deal to Sell Auto Policies
text: Walmart plans to add a new consumer service to its arsenal of offerings on Wednesday, teaming up with a website that helps customers comparison shop for auto insurance.

headline: Wizards Oust Cold-Shooting Bulls
text: CHICAGO — The Bulls scored on their second possession in Game 5 Tuesday night against the Washington Wizards when Carlos Boozer knocked down a high arcing jump shot. The ensuing cheer for the 2-0 lead at United Center was as much relief as excitement. In Game 4, the Bulls did not score until they spotted the Wizards 14 points in a blowout loss.

headline: Times Minute | Clippers Owner Banned
text: Sam Dolnick, the deputy sports editor, on what Donald Sterling’s ban means for the Los Angeles Clippers and the new N.B.A commissioner.

headline: Times Minute | The Clippers’ Next Steps
text: In the Video

headline: Alstom Backs G.E.’s Offer Despite French Government’s Concerns
text: Updated, 3:43 p.m. | PARIS — General Electric and Alstom, the struggling French conglomerate at the center of a politically charged takeover battle, finally said publicly on Wednesday what the business world has known for a week: G.E. is ready to acquire Alstom’s energy business in a $13.5 billion deal.

headline: Shell Profit Falls 45 Percent as Oil Production Drops
text: LONDON — The European oil giant Royal Dutch Shell reported Wednesday a 45 percent decline in first-quarter earnings compared with a year earlier, as production fell sharply and the company took a large write-off in its refining business.

headline: BNP Paribas Says U.S. Penalties May Top the $1.1 Billion It Set Aside
text: The French bank BNP Paribas warned on Wednesday that it might have to pay penalties higher than the $1.1 billion it had set aside for an investigation by the American authorities into whether it processed payments for countries facing United States sanctions, including Iran.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 30, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: European Court Rejects British Challenge to Tax on Trading
text: BRUSSELS — The top court in the European Union on Wednesday cleared a legal obstacle to a proposed tax on financial transactions, a plan bitterly opposed by bankers in London.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear
text: In “A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear,” Marisa Meltzer reports on teenagers breaking with prom-fashion tradition.

headline: In Xinjiang, a Call to Report Extremism – and Long Beards
text: “Intelligence information” is the “essential factor” in safeguarding citizens’ lives and property, the Shayar County government in the far-western region of Xinjiang has said, announcing rewards ranging from 50 to 50,000 renminbi ($8 to $8,000) to anyone who reports people planning violent attacks or hoarding guns and bullets, men growing long beards, women wearing veils or youths under 18 visiting a mosque. Such activities are considered signs of Muslim extremism by officials who are grappling with rising violence in the region that is home to ethnic Uighurs, a mostly Sunni Muslim, Turkic-speaking people.

headline: Why Only One Top Banker Went to Jail for the Financial Crisis
text: This article is a collaboration between The Times and ProPublica, the independent nonprofit investigative organization.

headline: Everyday People in Everyday Asia
text: It was June 2013 when Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist, inspired by the work of the Everyday Africa project, registered the Instagram account @everydayasia. As a Delhi-based freelance photographer, he saw a chance to carve out a space similar to the @everydayafrica feed, which showcases mobile photography that captures familiar moments, even mundane ones, to counter a media narrative too often shaped by images of extreme famine and poverty.

headline: Do We Need New Ways to Identify Gender and Sexuality?
text: Non-binary, intersex, neutrois, androgyne, agender, gender questioning, gender fluid, gender variant, genderqueer: these are among the 50 possibilities and permutations of gender identification Facebook will now include in a drop-down menu for people who feel the binary choices “male” and “female” aren’t enough.

headline: With Election, Many Reminded of Horrors of 2002 Gujarat Riots
text: AHMEDABAD, India — Gulbarg Society, a complex of 18 bungalows and two apartment blocks once occupied by upper-middle-class Muslims in the largely Hindu neighborhood of Chamanpura, is now a cluster of doorless burned shells.

headline: Volkswagen Extends Offer to Acquire Full Control of Scania
text: LONDON – Volkswagen said on Wednesday that it had extended its offer to take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania, in hopes of coaxing more of the company’s shareholders to sell.

headline: Euro Zone Inflation Edges Up in April
text: FRANKFURT — Inflation in the euro zone rose slightly in April, according to a preliminary official estimate, but probably not enough to ease fear of a damaging downward price spiral, nor enough to take pressure off the European Central Bank to undertake new measures to stimulate the economy.

headline: By One Measure, China Set to Become Largest Economy
text: For years, Americans have told Gallup pollsters that China was the world’s pre-eminent economy. They were mistaken. The United States has held that spot for more than a century. A new report suggests they may soon be mistaken no more.

headline: New York Today: Umbrellas on Parade
text: Good wet Wednesday morning to you. It will rain all day.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Xbox One to Go on Sale in China in September
text: SEATTLE – Microsoft says its latest game console, Xbox One, will go on sale in China in September, after a long ban on such products in the country.

headline: By Its Own Yardstick, the Fed Is Falling Short
text: The Federal Reserve is failing to meet its basic responsibilities.

headline: The Politics of Gift Giving in India
text: LUCKNOW, India – Every time second-year undergraduate law students at Lucknow University open up their 14-inch Hewlett-Packard laptops, they are reminded of the generous benefactors who gave them their computers.

headline: Verbatim: From Transcript to Performance
text: In our latest Op-Doc, for the Editorial Department’s section for short, opinion-piece videos, an incensed lawyer deposes a beleaguered witness. “When you say ‘photocopying machine,’ what do you mean?” the witness responds again and again. In its absurdity, the question becomes almost profound.

headline: BNP Paribas Says U.S. Penalties May Top the $1.1 Billion It Set Aside
text: The French bank BNP Paribas warned on Wednesday that it might have to pay penalties higher than the $1.1 billion it had set aside for an investigation by the American authorities into whether it processed payments for countries facing United States sanctions, including Iran.

headline: The Urbane Face of the B.J.P. Nervous in Electoral Debut in Amritsar
text: AMRITSAR, India – On Sunday afternoon, Arun Jaitley, a senior leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party and leader of the opposition in Parliament’s upper house, was driven to Lawrence Road, a busy thoroughfare in Amritsar, the second-largest city in the western state of Punjab.

headline: House Budget Committee to Hold Hearing on Poverty
text: WASHINGTON — Is the federal government responsible for lifting millions of Americans out of poverty or trapping them in it?

headline: Daily Report: Twitter’s Revenue Rises, but Wall St. Worries About Growth
text: Twitter is struggling to convince Wall Street that it is still a company with plenty of potential to grow, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: App Smart: Running Partners
text: Several smartphone apps can add a helpful boost of motivation, or just provide some fun information, to a run or walk.

headline: While on a Run, Apps to Match the Playlist to Your Pace
text: IF you are headed out for a walk or jog, consider adding an app for your trip. Several smartphone apps can add a helpful boost of motivation, or just some fun information, to a workout or leisurely walk.

headline: 1964: Beirut is Travel Hub of the Middle East
text: BEIRUT — Lebanon is as old as time and as new as tomorrow, and its face is constantly changing. This narrow strip of the eastern Mediterranean seaboard, which lies between Syria and Israel, has been an important trading center ever since the days when it was a stop on the spice route.

headline: Ukraine Says That Militants Won the East
text: KIEV, Ukraine — It is by now a well-established pattern. Armed, masked men in their 20s to 40s storm a public building of high symbolic value in a city somewhere in eastern Ukraine, evict anyone still there, seize weapons and ammunition, throw up barricades and proclaim themselves the rulers of a “people’s republic.” It is not clear who is in charge or how the militias are organized.

headline: Profit at Carlyle Falls 18% as Real Estate Investments Underperform
text: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | Private equity may be a booming business, but that was not enough to lift the Carlyle Group’s earnings in the first quarter.

headline: Cloud Complexity, Simplified
text: It’s hard in technology to make things simpler, but there is usually good money in it.

headline: Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival Sets Lineup
text: The lineup for the 36th annual Celebrate Brooklyn! outdoor festival in Prospect Park has been announced and will feature free performances by acts like St. Vincent; the jazz and hip-hop fusion artist Robert Glasper, who will appear with Talib Kweli; the rock group Dum Dum Girls; and the Brazilian singer Bebel Gilberto.

headline: Why Dangerous Supplements Linger on Store Shelves
text: The first cases of liver problems linked to a popular weight loss supplement called OxyElite Pro began in Hawaii last May. But it wasn’t until four months later that the Food and Drug Administration, the agency responsible for getting dangerous products off the market, learned of the outbreak, and the product was finally recalled in November.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: The New Normal
text: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Countering ‘Too Big to Jail’
text: “Federal prosecutors are nearing criminal charges against some of the world’s biggest banks, according to lawyers briefed on the matter, a development that could produce the first guilty plea from a major bank in more than two decades,” Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. In doing so, prosecutors are looking to address public outrage and alter the belief that Wall Street institutions are “too big to jail.”

headline: On Progressive Econoblogging
text: Chris House replies graciously to my critique of his critique. However, I have some further thoughts here. The crucial question, it seems to me, is what econobloggers — and in particular, those who happen to be political progressives — are doing, and what they should be trying to do.

headline: Tested Out Upstate: Classical’s Future
text: Two hours into the drive from Buffalo to Albany on the New York State Thruway, you pass Syracuse, a city with dark associations for classical music lovers.

headline: Hoping for Stability, Utility Operator Exelon Agrees to Buy Pepco for $6.8 Billion
text: The utility operator Exelon has again turned to deal making to expand, agreeing on Wednesday to buy Pepco Holdings for $6.8 billion to strengthen its operations on the East Coast.

headline: Once More, Economy Exhibits Weakness
text: As has happened so many times since the recovery began nearly five years ago, the economy turned in another disappointing quarterly performance, surprising even the most pessimistic observers as growth in the first three months of 2014 slowed to a near-standstill.

headline: Congress Party Faces Uncertain Prospects in State It Helped Create
text: HYDERABAD, India — Ever since the bill recognizing Telangana as the nation’s 29th state passed unanimously through Parliament on Feb. 18, politics in this heart-shaped region of south India have been as muddled and dramatic as a soap opera, with failed alliances and accusations of broken promises and backstabbing between lawmakers.

headline: When a Restaurant Calls to Confirm a Reservation
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Voters in City of Srinagar Heed Calls For Boycott
text: As Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, voted on Wednesday, the election was taking on a familiar pattern: In the first four hours of polling in the city, turnout was 5 percent, compared with 31 percent in Vadodara in Gujarat, where Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party was running for Parliament.

headline: Glisten in the Sun
text: Heavy moisturizers are so last summer, thanks to new body oils that are as weightlessly refreshing as a summer breeze.

headline: Intrade Co-Founder Opens Fantasy Sports Site
text: The online betting and prediction market Intrade shut down last year after discovering financial problems and running afoul of regulators.

headline: Why U.S. Growth Slowed to a Halt at the Start of the Year
text: Well, that could have gone better.

headline: Energizer to Split in Two
text: After years of buying up brands, Energizer Holdings has decided not to keep on going as a single consumer-products conglomerate.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | National Parks: Ecology and Economy
text: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

headline: More on Drones and James Risen — and a new AnonyWatch entry
text: I’m heading off to the International Journalism Festival in Perugia, Italy where I’m one of the (many) speakers this week. My speech has an admittedly unwieldy title: “What I’ve Learned at the New York Times (And What That Says About Journalism).” I have copious notes — and a long flight to get them in order.

headline: A Korean City With 250 Holes in Its Heart
text: ANSAN, South Korea — The cluttered store next to the gate of Danwon High School in the drab industrial city of Ansan is jammed with school necessities. White gym uniforms hang in the window, behind dusty glass. Pens and pencils are sorted neatly into cubbyholes, and a freezer full of ice cream sits outside as a lure for passing students.

headline: Test Prep Endures in New York Schools, Despite Calls to Ease It
text: For several weeks, Reanna Bhola and her sixth-grade classmates at Intermediate School 126 in Astoria, Queens, spent part of nearly every day focused on test preparation. First it was reading, with sample passages, questions and review sheets mirroring the actual tests.

headline: Teach the Teachers Well
text: When Yvonne Ford started teaching at P.S. 133, a public elementary school in Brooklyn, her classroom wasn’t an easy place to learn. Students with behavior problems struggled to remain on task. Teasing and name-calling were common. Many students came to school angry and anxious. Ford wasn’t satisfied with how students treated each other or her. “I knew I needed to build a positive community in my classroom,” she recounts, but she didn’t know how. “The things they have to deal with on a daily basis are not things I had to deal with as a child,” Ford says of the students at P.S. 133, about 80 percent of whom are eligible for free or reduced price lunch and some of whom live in shelters or foster homes. She worried that she would say or do something that made students’ problems worse.

headline: A Seeger Fest to Honor Pete and Toshi, and It’s Free
text: “My grandfather didn’t leave a blueprint about the kind of memorial he wanted,” Kitama Cahill-Jackson, whose grandfather was Pete Seeger, said in a telephone interview. “But when my grandmother died, just a few months earlier, I planned her memorial with him, and nothing says more about what someone would like than to see what they planned for a loved one.”

headline: Stern Talk From Chief of F.C.C. on Open Net
text: LOS ANGELES — The Federal Communications Commission’s chairman delivered a tough message to cable and broadband executives Wednesday, saying a lack of competition in their industry has hurt consumers.

headline: In California, Governor Pushes a Rainy-Day Fund
text: SACRAMENTO — After overcoming years of fiscal dysfunction that stemmed in part from an antitax ballot referendum, Gov. Jerry Brown is trying to call California voters to the ballot again — this time to approve a constitutional amendment requiring that surpluses be used to pay down municipal debt and create an emergency fund.

headline: Alone at Sea
text: In two new picture books, stories of giant turtles and tortoises take different tacks, one casting facts aside to revel in the imaginative possibilities of such a creature’s life, the other taking a long view of its evolution over the course of a million years. One starts in isolation and ends companionably; the other begins in a community, and ends alone. They’re books for different age groups to be sure, but neither entirely succeeds as a picture book.

headline: Breaking From Her Norm to Connect With Her Tradition
text: At a sleepy ocean-side restaurant in Brighton Beach, a Russian enclave in Brooklyn, the singer-songwriter Olga Bell peered across the table stacked with traditional dishes — sliced herring with onions, hearty borscht, blini with red caviar. Her smile broadened at the sight of the pelmeni (meat dumplings). “The way my mom makes these, we put them in a broth with a little bit of soy sauce,” she said, spooning another helping onto her plate. “But we’re into fusion like that.”

headline: A Wide-Ranging Lineup for Lincoln Center Out of Doors
text: The world premiere of a work by the Pulitzer Prize winner John Luther Adams; a celebration of the 50th anniversary of John Coltrane’s “Love Supreme”; a memorial concert for Pete and Toshi Seeger; and performances by Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell; Rosanne Cash; and the Paul Taylor Dance Company are among the offerings at the year’s Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival. All told, the 44th season of the festival will offer nearly 100 free events on Lincoln Center’s plazas between July 20 and Aug. 10.

headline: Assailants Attack Train Station in Restive Western China
text: HONG KONG — Assailants with explosives and knives killed three people and wounded at least 79 Wednesday evening outside a railroad station in Urumqi, the capital of western China’s restive Xinjiang region, where President Xi Jinping had just concluded a visit, state news media reported, calling it a brazen terrorist assault.

headline: Church Band With a Legacy
text: In 1970, the Fairview Baptist Church Brass Band — first called the Fairview Baptist Church Christian Marching Band — was created in New Orleans by the banjoist and guitarist Danny Barker, and the story of its evolution and influence is pretty much the story of how a cultural tradition rallied and flourished at a critical moment of declining interest. Those who passed through the Fairview band in the early years include Wynton Marsalis, Lucien Barbarin, Leroy Jones and Herlin Riley.

headline: Campaign to Save a Carny Mainstay
text: “Zipper: Coney Island’s Last Wild Ride,” Monday night at 10 on WNET/13, documents a way of life that increasingly seems as if it’s from another era, and now that film itself has a bit of that aura. It was shot in a distant time when some guy named Bloomberg was mayor of New York and developers ruled the land. It documents the emergence of an ambitious redevelopment plan for Coney Island, one that critics contend would destroy the character of the place, and it does so through the eyes of the operators of the Zipper, an old-school ride that becomes a symbol of the carny world endangered by the plan.

headline: ‘Alice’ Lives, Right Here
text: At the Academy Awards in Los Angeles in April 1975, Martin Scorsese had to accept Ellen Burstyn’s best-actress Oscar for her because she was busy starring in a play, “Same Time, Next Year,” in New York. Less than two weeks later, she won the best actress Tony for that play. Pretty good April.

headline: Whirling Forward Beyond a Founder
text: Since time dances ever on, modern-dance groups must eventually decide how to continue when their charismatic founding choreographers retire or die. One troupe that keeps thriving is the Limón Dance Company. Since the death of its founder, José Limón, in 1972, it has not stopped moving forward, and its director, Carla Maxwell, adroitly balances Limón revivals with premieres by other choreographers.

headline: Violin and Chorus In Unusual Hybrid
text: The composer Jennifer Higdon is best known for works that reflect old-school values of sturdy American craftsmanship and optimism, with ruminative currents running just beneath their polished surfaces. Those qualities apply to “The Singing Rooms,” which receives its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. Ms. Higdon wrote this unusual hybrid oratorio-concerto for the brilliant violinist Jennifer Koh, who recorded it in 2011 with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra.
