At Carnegie, Ms. Koh will perform with the New York Choral Society and Orchestra, conducted by David Hayes. (8 p.m., 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: A Lamentation for Assyria
text: Prepare to be rattled one way or another by “Roberto Cuoghi: Suillakku Corral,” if not by the onslaught of sound — described by one writer as “an assault without respite of music, chants, animal verses, animal sounds, noises and the sound of spitting” — then by the empty galleries in which it is presented or by its disturbing analogies. Opening at the New Museum on Wednesday, this show presents the latest from Mr. Cuoghi, a driven, often perverse Italian polymath who works in painting, sculpture, performance and animation. After several years of mind-boggling immersion into ancient Assyria, he has created an imagined lamentation for the fall of that militaristic civilization.

headline: Funds for Troubled Mortgages Are on the Rise
text: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | In the world of hedge funds, distressed mortgage funds are suddenly hot, but it is unclear whether the strategy will live up to the marketing hype.

headline: N.B.A.’s Move Is Not Little, but It’s Late
text: After the conga line of support spawned by N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver’s banishment of Donald Sterling on Tuesday — a carnival led by validated players, relieved owners and a Los Angeles Clippers staff that acted as if it had just been released from Guantánamo — there ensued a natural pause. Because in celebrating the first move to excise Sterling from the N.B.A. and pry the Clippers from his grubby hands, the next thought had to be why it had not been done sooner.

headline: Rescuers Turn to Boat as Storm Rocks Florida
text: PENSACOLA, Fla. — His city stunned and saturated by floodwaters, Craig Hindsman, a pastor at the Marcus Pointe Baptist Church here, suddenly became an amateur rescuer on Wednesday.

headline: Remembering President Giuliani and President Brown
text: Hillary Clinton has a commanding lead over Jeb Bush, 53 percent to 41 percent, in a hypothetical 2016 matchup between the two, according to a Washington Post/ABC News poll Wednesday.

headline: Ishigaki, a Japanese Natural Wonderland
text: Unruly stalks brushed against the windows of the white Suzuki minivan as it bumped down an unmarked dirt road through a field of sugar cane. When the road abruptly ended, we continued on foot down a barely perceptible path through thick tropical foliage, fighting through branches and brush.

headline: A Remote Colombia City That Really Does Exist
text: The first time I heard of Mompós, officially called Santa Cruz de Mompox, was about a decade ago, while reading Gabriel García Márquez’s novel “The General in His Labyrinth.” “Mompox doesn’t exist,” Mr. García Márquez wrote, “we sometimes dream about her, but she doesn’t exist.” For years, I assumed that to be true.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Almaty, Kazakhstan Fall/Winter 2014 Shows
text: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: I’m Not a Cheese
text: Part 15: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall describe how they make decisions about future projects.

headline: Yes, Silicon Valley, Sometimes You Need More Bureaucracy
text: The dirtiest word in Silicon Valley is bureaucracy. Tech executives want to move quickly — a Facebook company motto is “move fast and break things” — and layers of bureaucracy, such as human resources departments, are seen as the enemy of speed and efficiency.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Taking on an Iconic Role
text: Part 14: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explain their rehearsal process.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: The Importance of Naps
text: Part 13: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams talk about what draws them to the roles they choose.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Alan’s Fragrance
text: Part 12: The director Rob Marshall reflects on returning to theater after working exclusively in film for 15 years.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Kander & Ebb
text: Part 11: The director Rob Marshall talks about the important role John Kander and Fred Ebb played in his career; Alan Cumming describes meeting Joel Grey, who originated the Emcee role.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Marilyn Monroe
text: Part 10: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams reveal what their “Cabaret” roles share in common with other parts they’ve played.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Not Just a Period Piece
text: Part 9: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss the historical context and relevance of the show’s story and setting.

headline: Children’s Art at Syria School, and Then a Bomb
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Organizers had worked until dawn hanging children’s artwork on the wall of an elementary school in Syria’s largest city: a bright green tank under a round yellow sun, a girl in pigtails defying a soldier’s bullets, a missile plunging from a warplane toward the school building.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Broadway Has Changed
text: Part 8: Michelle Williams talks about how her daughter influences her career choices; the director Rob Marshall reflects on what Broadway has lost.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: A Lie Down
text: Part 7: Alan Cumming describes what it’s like to work simultaneously on “Cabaret” and “The Good Wife.”

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Rob Marshall’s Special Skill
text: Part 6: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explore their collaborative process.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Sally and the Emcee
text: Part 5: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams discuss their “Cabaret” characters and the difference between musical and non-musical theater.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: De-Liza-fication
text: Part 4: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall talk about how the 1972 film of “Cabaret” transformed the production.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Concept Musical
text: Part 3: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss why the show was groundbreaking when it first premiered and why it continues to be important.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Evolution
text: Part 2: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall each recall how they first encountered “Cabaret” in their lives and careers.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall.

headline: TimesTalks | ‘Cabaret’: Preview
text: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and “Cabaret” co-director Rob Marshall talk about bringing the Tony-winning musical back to Broadway.

headline: Don’t be surprised that people still say racist things.
text: The condemnation of remarks by the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling is almost unanimous. But racism is still more common than you may realize. In surveys, more than one-fifth of whites volunteer views consistent with negative racial stereotypes. While many fewer Americans express animosity toward blacks than they did 40 years ago, a CBS News poll from March showed that 46 percent of Americans thought racial discrimination would always exist.

headline: Cruise Line Will Return to Persian Gulf
text: Royal Caribbean International cruise line will return to the Persian Gulf next year, with 16 cruises planned between December 2015 and March 2016.

headline: N.Y.U. Appoints a Dean for the  Tisch School of the Arts
text: Allyson Green, a dancer, choreographer, designer and curator, has been named the new dean of  the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, the university announced on Wednesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘My Idea Is Just Too Far Ahead of Its Time’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,800,000
text: BEND, ORE.

headline: The Once-Groovy Future of Flight
text: It looks as if Austin Powers should be the next lucky passenger to descend into this scene — a prototype for a first-class Tiger Lounge, residing inside the belly of the first jumbo passenger jet, the Boeing 747, which was introduced in 1970.

headline: In 1918 Flu Pandemic, Timing Was a Killer
text: Sometimes a virus can cause more devastation than all the world’s armies. In 1918, at the end of World War I, influenza spread around the planet, reaching even Pacific islands and Arctic villages. The virus infected a third of all people on earth, and caused an estimated 50 million deaths — more than three times the number of people killed  in World War I.

headline: The Rent Is Too High
text: New York City stands at the epicenter of a national housing crisis that has placed low-income people at a steadily greater risk of homelessness. As Mireya Navarro and Vivian Yee of the Times reminded us on Tuesday, that risk is increasingly apparent to elderly New Yorkers who hoped to retire in the city, but who now find that their modest incomes will not cover the cost of decent housing in even marginal areas.

headline: Communion, Catholicism and Conscience
text: As a companion to my last post, I want to say something about an argument made by my friend Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry, like me (if I may so label him) a conservative Catholic with some heterodox tendencies, in defense of divorce-and-remarried Catholics taking communion, because I think it gets at a distinction that’s important to my own understanding of Catholic doctrine and practice. Here (I’ll be quoting at length) he’s discussing how advocates of communion might deal with the fact that the remarried, if their marriages aren’t annulled, are living in what the church considers a persistent state of public adultery, which they don’t intend to leave:

headline: New Award Recognizes Two Young Choreographers
text: A group of independent performers and choreographers that includes Dean Moss, Kimberly Bartosik and Joshua Lubin-Levy have established the Award, a mentorship prize for young choreographers, based on what the prize’s web page describes as “the goodwill of New York City’s experimental dance community.” The group describes its nomination and selection process as confidential – nominators are anonymous – with aesthetic rigor and innovation as the principal criteria.

headline: From Making Bagel Baskets to Thinking Much Bigger
text: In the mid-1990s, Drew Greenblatt started dialing his way down a list of 800 brokers, lawyers and accountants, looking for a business to buy. He had sold a security alarm installation company, and he was looking for four qualities in his next venture: an honest seller, a viable market, a rational purchase price, and a business that sold to other businesses. He was through with coddling consumers.

headline: It’s a small world, after all.
text: At least on Facebook.

headline: Times Minute | A Botched Execution
text: The renewed debate about death penalty procedures. Also on the Minute, black women’s hairstyles in the Army and scientific evidence that walking increases creativity.

headline: What’s Your Comfort Food?
text: I should’ve known comfort food would strike a chord, because as I wrote in today’s column, everyone has a favorite. Friends have been emailing, saying things like this: “For me, comfort food is caldo de fideo with a few stewed tomatoes and a good dose of lime juice. If the angel hair has first been toasted with onions to near burning, so much better for the nostalgia.” (Another told me that toasting bagels was heresy.)

headline: Times Minute | A Botched Execution
text: In the Video

headline: The 21st Century Is Calling, With Wi-Fi Hot Spots
text: In the era of smartphones, pay phones look increasingly dumb.

headline: The Other Christie Scandal
text: What is it that makes self-proclaimed centrists such easy marks for right-wing con men? Actually, it’s not that much of a mystery: the centrist creed is that the two parties are symmetrically extremist, and this means that there must, as a matter of principle, be Serious, Honest Republicans out there — so such people must be invented if they don’t actually exist. Hence the elevation of Paul Ryan despite clear evidence of his con-artist nature.

headline: Bob Hoskins, Actor Who Combined Charm and Menace, Dies at 71
text: Bob Hoskins, the bullet-shaped British film star who brought a singular mix of charm, menace and cockney accent to a variety of roles, including the bemused live-action hero of the largely animated “Who Framed Roger Rabbit,” has died. He was 71.

headline: Do You Think Small American Manufacturers Can Compete?
text: We’ve just published a Conversation with Drew Greenblatt, chief executive of Marlin Steel Wire Products, which a decade ago manufactured only $12 wire baskets for bagels. Marlin now makes 80 to 100 varieties baskets a month, including customized designs for the aerospace and medical industries that cost as much as $5,000 apiece.

headline: Stop Worrying About Your Child Getting Into College. Worry About What Happens Next.
text: As a college professor, former admissions officer and researcher on what happens to youths after high school, I believe the current panic over the increasing selectivity of elite schools misses the point. So much energy goes into getting into college. Many families can’t see that getting through college is far more important, and that graduating prepared for adult life will be more valuable than the name arched over the top of the degree.

headline: Democrats Assail G.O.P. After Filibuster of Proposal to Raise Minimum Wage
text: WASHINGTON — With the Republican-led filibuster of a Senate proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to $10.10 on Wednesday, Democrats moved swiftly to frame the vote as an example of the gulf that exists between the two parties on matters of economic fairness and upward mobility.

headline: ‘Mom, This Looks Like the End of Me’: Doomed Vessel’s Last Minutes
text: SEOUL, South Korea — As a ferry carrying 476 people was badly listing off the southwestern coast of South Korea two weeks ago, one of the students on board asked, “Are we becoming a Titanic?”

headline: A Chelsea Apartment: The Reward of Staying the Course
text: Having owned property in London, where they had lived and worked, Craig Manson and Daniel Brass were interested in investing in the New York market. When the couple moved to New York for work a year and a half ago, they sublet a two-bedroom in Chelsea. It was well located, though small and dark, and rented for around $3,400 a month.

headline: A Store Where Everything is Made in the U.S.
text: Boosting the domestic economy is as easy as the click of a mouse with The MiA Project, a new online marketplace that exclusively stocks goods made in America (hence the name). The site, which launches today, was founded by Micha Thomas, a former creative marketing director for an independent music-booking agency, and Jaime Lawson, whose fashion background includes a stint at Rodarte and her own bridal accessory line, Bleu Garters. The L.A.-based duo have curated a roster of designers and makers both traditional (Pendleton Woolen Mills) and new (Earth tu Face, Baggu) and will be telling some of their stories through studio visits and other editorial content on the site. The vast retail component, with price points ranging from $10 to about $3,000, includes men’s, women’s and children’s casual wear and accessories, decorative items for the home, an organic beauty apothecary and such only-in-America gifts as an aromatherapeutic “throne spray” (if you have to ask…). It’s an assortment as diverse and democratic as the U.S. itself.

headline: Stars’ Newest Must-Have Item: The Clippers
text: LOS ANGELES — For most of the Clippers’ 30-year tenure in Los Angeles, they have been viewed as a punch line in hightops.

headline: Take My Buyout, Please …
text: Four decades ago, Thomas H. Lee was one of the pioneers of leveraged buyouts.

headline: Man Charged With Killing a Developer in January
text: The New York Police Department has arrested a 26-year-old man in connection with the kidnapping and killing of a Brooklyn developer, whose body was found smoldering in a trash container at a gas station in Nassau County on Jan. 3.

headline: U.S. Attorney Subpoenas Records of Ethics Panel
text: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, who sharply criticized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s shutdown of a commission he had formed to investigate political corruption in New York State, is now seeking records from the state’s ethics panel.

headline: Oklahoma Vows Review of Botched Execution
text: McALESTER, Okla. — As Clayton D. Lockett writhed and groaned on the gurney on Tuesday night after a large dose of sedatives had apparently not been fully delivered, the Oklahoma chief of corrections rushed to call the governor and the attorney general. Something had gone disastrously wrong with the lethal injection, he told them, and the execution of a second man must be delayed. Gov. Mary Fallin instantly agreed.

headline: Whither Dan Brown? Poll Lists Americans’ Favorite Books
text: Good-bye “Da Vinci Code,” hello “Moby-Dick”!

headline: Scenes from Severe Flooding in the Florida Panhandle
text: A section of the Scenic Highway near Pensacola, Fla., collapsed after more than 20 inches of rain caused severe flooding early Wednesday in the Florida Panhandle and in southern Alabama, as my colleague Alan Binder reports.

headline: Image of the Day: April 30
text: A worker navigating across a salt pan on the eve of Labour Day in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Facebook to Let Users Limit Data Revealed by Log-Ins
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Trying to become even bigger — and make more money — Facebook will allow users to reveal a little less.

headline: Hottest Hostess in Washington
text: If politicians brought the same clarity to their public positions that Jan Maxwell brings to her acting, the lives of voters would be so much easier. Whether portraying a scurrilous British witch in the days of the Crusades (in Howard Barker’s “The Castle”), a stroke survivor (Arthur Kopit’s “Wings”) or a self-dramatizing stage star (in “The Royal Family”), Ms. Maxwell has an unfailing gift for making you understand where her characters are coming from, even when they don’t seem to know themselves. So the idea of her going to Washington, to lend a little transparency to the capital of opacity, is irresistible.

headline: Everything’s Up-to-Date (or at Least From the Late ’80s)
text: As New York City Ballet opened its spring season at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, one man in the audience stood out in a conspicuous disguise of fedora and sunglasses. Those in the know could recognize this as the costume of J R, the artist responsible for the giant photograph of City Ballet dancers that covered the floor of the theater’s promenade earlier this year.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 43
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Forecasting a Speedup in Growth, the Fed Again Cuts Bond Purchases
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve continued to retreat from its stimulus campaign on Wednesday, saying it was looking past the economic slowdown during an unusually cold winter because growth already was rebounding.

headline: Big Banks Erred Widely on Troubled Mortgages, U.S. Regulator Confirms
text: Updated, 8:14 p.m. | A federal regulator confirmed on Wednesday that the country’s biggest banks committed widespread errors in dealing with homeowners who faced foreclosures at the height of the mortgage crisis, but the findings are unlikely to put to rest questions from lawmakers and others about the extent of the problems.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
text: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions. At the last meeting, in mid-March, Fed officials saw economic weakness as being driven by winter weather. This time, they affirmed that view, and now view the economy to be growing faster.

headline: Is Your Pension Plan Stupid? Nebraska’s Isn’t
text: Imagine you were 25 years old and considering a job with a company, and your employer told you these were the terms of the retirement plan:

headline: Building Firm Pleads Guilty to Defrauding Its Customers
text: Structure Tone, one of the nation’s largest construction firms, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to corruption charges and agreed to forfeit $55 million for a scheme in which the company defrauded a roster of prominent financial institutions, law firms and ad agencies out of tens of millions of dollars.

headline: The Voice of the Clippers
text: LOS ANGELES — When Doc Rivers walked into a conference room Tuesday night that was so packed that dozens of reporters were turned away, he took a deep breath and exhaled as he sat behind the microphone. He then proceeded to do what he had spent much of the previous three days doing: answering question after question about his employer, the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling.

headline: Barenboim Goes Digital
text: BERLIN — As digital music consumption becomes the norm the classical recording industry is looking to new models, from video apps to digital singles. Now the conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim, in partnership with Universal Music, has created his own exclusively digital label.

headline: John Paul Stevens Gets That ‘Money Is Not Speech’
text: Former Justice John Paul Stevens’ appearance before the Senate Rules Committee this morning was remarkable, and not just because retired Supreme Court justices rarely show up at Congressional hearings. It was remarkable for the clarity with which made the point that unlimited and undisclosed money are eliminating fairness from the American political system.

headline: Moving On, Even if It’s Back in Time
text: ASHFIELD, Mass. — Visiting Ray LaMontagne is like going back to another century. The question is, which one?

headline: Alibaba I.P.O. May Unleash Global Fight Over Users
text: The largest technology stock offering in history is looming, but few in Silicon Valley seem to care.

headline: Energizer Split Leaves Biggest Problem Intact
text: Energizer’s split into household and personal care companies should improve the $7 billion company’s focus. It could also make one of the newly independent businesses an acquisition target. But the proposed transaction doesn’t address the batteries-to-tampons conglomerate’s bigger challenge: mustering more resources to take on industry gorilla Procter & Gamble.

headline: Where Did You Get Those Genes? Researching Advances In Genetics
text: From junk DNA that, as it turns out, is not so junky after all, to the unique signatures in different cancer genes, our understanding of genetics is changing so rapidly that textbooks can’t always keep up. In this lesson, we offer a collection of teaching ideas using recent Times coverage about how genes work, how we can work with them and where they come from.Rethinking Junk

headline: Thailand Says It Will Try to Hold an Election in July
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s election commission on Wednesday said it would try to hold a vote in July but opposition leaders refused to say whether they would participate, underlining the country’s political paralysis.

headline: House Hunting in ... Cuernavaca, Mexico
text: A MEXICAN COLONIAL-STYLE HOME WITH POOL IN CUERNAVACA

headline: Classical Playlist: Stravinsky, Mendelssohn, Harrison Birtwistle and More
text: STRAVINSKY: ‘Oedipus Rex’ and ‘Apollon Musagète’London Symphony Orchestra, Monteverdi Choir; John Eliot Gardiner, conductor(LSO Live)As a dramatic work, Stravinsky’s “Oedipus Rex” is a riveting hybrid: both one-act opera with a Latin libretto and homage to the Baroque oratorio. It makes sense that the conductor John Eliot Gardiner, a pioneer of the early music movement, and the impressive Monteverdi Choir, founded by Mr. Gardner in 1964, would have a special feeling for the old-world musical elements of “Oedipus Rex,” all of which come through on this gripping recording taken from live performances with the London Symphony Orchestra last year. The actress Fanny Ardant delivers the narration in the original French version by Cocteau. Among the excellent soloists are the tenor Stuart Skelton as Oedipus and the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnston as Jocasta. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: New York City Police Officer Is Arrested in Westchester Shooting
text: PELHAM, N.Y. — An off-duty New York City police officer shot a motorist six times at a stoplight in Westchester County this week, in what an official called a “completely random” attack.

headline: South Sudan’s Warring Leaders Draw Rebuke From U.N. Rights Chief
text: GENEVA — Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, sharply rebuked South Sudan’s warring leaders on Wednesday, saying they had to stop “blindly dragging their people down the path of self-destruction” and warning that they would face investigation for possible war crimes and crimes against humanity.

headline: Future’s New Album Hits the ‘Frozen’ Ceiling
text: Another week on the music charts, another couple of victories for “Frozen” and “Happy.”

headline: Stalking the Role of an Operatic Stalker
text: Say a wish out loud enough times, and it might come true. It worked for the Broadway baritone Norm Lewis, anyway. For years, when Mr. Lewis, the star of 2012’s “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” was asked what his dream roles would be, he often mentioned Harold Hill in “The Music Man” or Billy Bigelow in “Carousel.” Yet the role he invariably named was the title character in the long-running musical “The Phantom of the Opera,” and at last it has come his way. Mr. Lewis will don the cape and mask for a six-month run starting May 12.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage Is Popular, but Voting on It Is Another Matter
text: Pollsters have known for decades that the public supports raising the minimum wage, and this past year has been no exception. What remains unknown is whether the Senate vote Wednesday killing the proposed minimum wage increase will affect the election in November.

headline: Time Warner’s Profit Rises On Strength in Film Unit
text: Time Warner reported on Wednesday that its first-quarter profit increased 7 percent, thanks largely to the successes of the Warner Bros. studio and Home Box Office.

headline: The Transformation of St. Agnes
text: A video documents how a decommissioned church in Germany has become a nexus of contemporary art and culture.

headline: A Fight for Marriage Equality, and Over History
text: Who makes history? That’s the essential question raised not so much by “Forcing the Spring,” Jo Becker’s account of the same-sex marriage struggle, but by the controversy that has surrounded the book since its publication last week.

headline: A Verdict on Comments, but the Conversation Isn’t Over
text: Adam Silver did what he had to do Tuesday.

headline: Finding Too Much of Nothing on an Irish Farm
text: Jane isn’t built for country life. Stuck on her parents’ farm in Ireland, she longs for Dublin. “Swap the tractors for tour buses,” she commands, “the quiet for noise, the slowness for speed, the loneliness for no space to think.” Yet as Lisa Tierney-Keogh’s “Four Last Things” progresses, Jane’s rural exile seems less and less the problem. Jane may not be built for life at all.

headline: Bits and Pieces That End Up a Life
text: The role of music in telling stories will of course change depending on the type of narrative being told. In planning “collected stories,” the fascinating series of six concerts at Zankel Hall that concluded on Tuesday night, the composer David Lang explored the various approaches composers have taken to relate tales of adventure, love, longing and spiritual questing.

headline: A Sneak Peek at a New Exhibition Co-Curated by Pharrell
text: Pharrell Williams is swiftly moving toward total cultural domination. Is it any surprise, then, that the multi-hyphenated man of the moment has been chosen to inaugurate a new art space in Paris next month? The 41-year-old first met the gallerist Emmanuel Perrotin seven years ago in Miami, and together, Perrotin says, they have been on an art adventure ever since: “meeting artists and visiting studios, brainstorming all along those great moments of artistic synergies and true happiness and friendship.” So it’s no surprise that Williams was present at the opening of Perrotin’s New York gallery late last year, where he treated Perrotin and friends to an early listen of his album “G I R L.” As one would expect, the tracks made Perrotin happy — a feeling he knew could transcend the record and fill his new art space, Salle de Bal, which opens on May 27 in a former ballroom in the 17th-century Hôtel du Grand Veneur in the Marais. So he invited Pharrell to collaborate on the inaugural show, also called “G I R L.”

headline: What Bank of America’s Accounting Mistake Can Teach the Market
text: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: An Uneasy Inheritance of India’s Political Dynasty
text: NEW DELHI — On a visit to the rural constituency that has sent him or his relatives to Parliament for decades, Rahul Gandhi, the scion of India’s most powerful political dynasty, was asked a simple question: Can you name five party workers from the area?

headline: The Gun Report: April 30, 2014
text: Just before 6 a.m. yesterday, Geddy Kramer, a 19-year-old package handler, opened fire with a shotgun at a FedEx shipping facility in Kennesaw, Ga. He wounded a security guard outside the building and five people in the warehouse, and was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in a trailer behind the FedEx site.

headline: Scene City: 100 Boldfaces in the Crowd
text: Celebrities toast Time magazine’s annual list of 100 influencers (and themselves.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Palestine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Palestine, India, Florida and Spain.

headline: High Culture in Colorado
text: Far from being bummed out by Colorado’s burgeoning legal marijuana market, the Colorado Symphony Orchestra is planning a series of BYOC (bring your own cannabis) concerts this year. Entitled “Classically Cannabis: The High Note Series,” the performances represent the orchestra’s attempt to reach a new, younger audience, so as to bolster its shaky finances and future. “You have to program your orchestra for the community you’re in,” Justin Bartels, a trumpet player in the orchestra, told the Denver Post, noting the classical ensemble has long caught the aroma of pot threading through its concerts. Why not go with the flow?

headline: Posing and Rubbing and Rolling and You Name It
text: At the start of Levi Gonzalez’s “The Craft of the Father,” you can’t see anything. But in near-total darkness, you can hear breathing. Then you hear groaning, croaking, slurping. It sounds like indigestion, and then, as the noise grows louder and wilder, more like someone pretending to be possessed.

headline: Polished Yet Casual in the Flatiron District
text: Whether it’s tourists taking selfies under the Flatiron building, foodies wolfing down Eataly gelato or fashion enthusiasts flocking to buy the latest arrivals at boutiques, the Flatiron district offers some of New York’s biggest draws. The area is also packed with young entrepreneurs hustling to meetings at the towering office spaces nearby. Aristotle Torres was among them. The born-and-bred New Yorker from the Bronx was on his way to a company meeting wearing a waxed trench, a cashmere crew neck, a striped button-up and Jordan 8’s.

headline: A Playoffs’ Worth of Overtimes Already
text: Serge Ibaka of the Oklahoma City Thunder caught the rebound of Kevin Durant’s missed 3-pointer and tipped the ball back toward the rim with the buzzer sounding at the end of overtime Tuesday night. As the ball fell through the hoop, Ibaka hit the ground with his arms raised. The Chesapeake Energy Arena crowd erupted in celebration. Ibaka’s teammate Reggie Jackson dived in for a hug. The Thunder had seemingly outlasted the Memphis Grizzlies to take a 3-2 series lead in their first-round playoff series.

headline: Florida State’s Jameis Winston Is Cited for Shoplifting Shellfish
text: Jameis Winston, Florida State’s Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback, found himself in off-the-field trouble once again on Tuesday night when he was cited for shoplifting seafood from a grocery store in Tallahassee, Fla.

headline: Voices on Iraq’s Election Day
text: Iraqi officials and voters discussed Iraq’s election as they cast their votes for the country’s new Parliament.

headline: Murderers Are Shown With Warts Aplenty
text: Television loves the myth of smart, stylish murderers and the enigmatic detectives who pursue them, and if you enjoy those types of shows, don’t watch “The Killer Speaks.” The reality in it just might put you off those gritty, pretty fantasies.

headline: Senators Express Concern on Reverse Mortgage Rules
text: Updated, 10:20 a.m. |

headline: Nail Salon Lamps May Increase Skin Cancer Risk
text: Nail salon dryers, which use ultraviolet light to speed the drying and hardening of nail polishes and gels, emit varying levels of radiation that can lead to risky skin damage in as few as eight visits to the manicurist, a new study shows.

headline: Life in Canada, Home of the World’s Most Affluent Middle Class
text: The Canadian middle class may now be the world’s richest, but it has its anxieties, too.

headline: Garden Ice Does the Trick
text: There must be ghosts in the rafters at Madison Square Garden, like those who once roamed the old Montreal Forum, even if they only come out for Game 7s.

headline: Political Preferences on Social Media Sites
text: Social media’s promise was that people with different views and political ties could mingle in digital bliss. But some social sites are more popular with one political party than another.

headline: When College Isn’t in the Cards
text: If college isn’t in a high school student’s plan for any reason, the sense of pressure and judgment that some families feel at this time of year can be overwhelming. Many seniors are deciding where they want to begin college in the fall, decisions that will be final on May 1. “I feel judgment like I haven’t felt since my kids were babies,” Adrienne Jones posted on Facebook (where many parents are proudly posting acceptances and decisions). Her son does not plan to enter college.

headline: 10 Spice Blends to Enliven Any Dish
text: Sure, you can spend a lot of money on the perfect spice. Or you can make your own.

headline: Calling With Clarity
text: Molly Wood describes what you can do to improve the sound quality of your cellphone calls until new technologies like HD voice become more widely available.

headline: With HD Voice, Better Call Quality Is Coming. Text Your Friends.
text: CELLPHONE calls sound terrible.

headline: Headphones That Make Smartphone Calls Easier
text: SMARTPHONES offer a lot of conveniences, especially for people on the go, but using one for its most basic function — making a phone call — can tie up your hands and actually limit your mobility.

headline: The Action of Adverbs, the Pathos of Prepositions
text: As a fun thing to do on a Friday night, attending a show about grammar is not an obvious choice. But grammar is the theme of “Sen•tence,” a collection of sketches in word, movement and music by the longtime dance comedian Claire Porter. And as presented by DanceNow at Joe’s Pub on Friday, the parts of speech cleverly parsed in “Sen•tence” made for a charming entertainment, at least in parts.

headline: No Extradition for Franco-Era Police Inspector
text: MADRID — Spain’s National Court on Wednesday dealt a setback to victims seeking justice for the abuses of the Franco dictatorship by refusing to extradite to Argentina a former police inspector accused of torture during the 1970s, the final years of the Franco regime.

headline: Redrawing ‘Map,’ From Different Angles
text: If you’re a regular at Judson Memorial Church you might not recognize the space this week. Filling the usually bare-bones sanctuary are multiple levels of seating, towers of theatrical lights and, sprouting up from the expansive floor, seven gargantuan balloons (cubes, globes) painted with arrows and other symbols, indecipherable maps.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Unions’ Giant Video Near White House Urges Halt to Deportations
text: WASHINGTON — Labor leaders who normally side with President Obama planned to vividly demonstrate their anger and frustration with his immigration policies on Wednesday by projecting a 90-by-60-foot video onto the side of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters two blocks from the White House.

headline: Wheelies: The Don’t Clone Me Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Happy Times
text: Retro-feeling swimwear under an early summer haze harkens back to stolen weekends and simpler days.

headline: Atlético Bolts Past Chelsea and Mourinho
text: LONDON — Ten years ago, José Mourinho set off running on the big stage for the first time, his celebratory sprint in a designer suit and bulky overcoat serving as the indelible moment of Porto’s Champions League upset of Manchester United. It was bold. It was brash. It was perfect.

headline: More on the Life and Times of Anna Mae Aquash
text: In last weekend’s magazine Eric Konigsberg wrote about the investigation into the 1975 killing of the Native American activist Anna Mae Aquash, which has gone on for decades. Despite the fact that two lower-level members of the American Indian Movement were convicted of her murder, many people, including the prosecuting district attorney, still consider the crime to be unresolved. For those who would like to learn more about Aquash and the turbulent years of mid-’70s America, there are a couple of biographies and a history book that have been inspired by her case.

headline: Racism and Punishment in the N.B.A.
April 30, 1939: The New York World’s Fair Opens to the Public
text: On April 30, 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt officially opened the New York World’s Fair in Flushing Meadows, Queens. Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers and visitors gathered in the Court of Peace, near the park’s Trylon and Perisphere structures, to see the parade of uniformed soldiers and national flags waved by representatives from 33 countries.

headline: High Price in Utility Deal
text: Just about any way investors crunch the numbers, Exelon looks to be overpaying for Pepco.

headline: Values and Data Meet at a Vatican Workshop on Sustaining Humanity on a Flourishing Planet
text: I’m headed to the Vatican to participate in a novel workshop at which economists, theologians and seasoned researchers from many branches of science convene under the auspices of the Pontifical Academies of Sciences and Social Sciences to consider a subject that transcends the realms of data and values: Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Planet, Our Responsibility.

headline: White Beans and Greens with Garlic and Olive Oil, or “Emma’s Beans”
text: We’ve gotten some requests for this recipe, adapted from The VB6 Cookbook, so I thought I’d post this as well.

headline: Gelb Joins French Legion of Honor
text: There have been plenty of chevaliers portrayed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera in recent years: the Chevalier des Grieux in Massenet’s “Manon,” the Chevalier de la Force in Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites,” and, earlier this year, a Viennese prison warden pretending to be a French chevalier in Strauss’s “Die Fledermaus.”

headline: A Suicide Stalks Young Spalding Gray
text: Ghosts are captured on camera in “Rumstick Road,” the genuinely haunting new work that runs through Wednesday at Anthology Film Archives. Described as a “video reconstruction” of a performance from the mid-1970s by the Wooster Group, the New York experimental theater troupe, Elizabeth LeCompte and Ken Kobland’s film is by its very nature phantasmal.

headline: Starry, Starry, Starry Night
text: The Time 100 gala is one of those events where industries collide. There’s media (Rupert Murdoch), there’s tech (Eric Schmidt), there’s Hollywood (Alfonso Cuarón), there’s the Washington Beltway (Kirsten Gillibrand).

headline: Headwaters for a River of Stand-Up
text: When Steven Wright started appearing on “The Tonight Show” in the early 1980s, he was such a change of pace that Johnny Carson once introduced him with the tone of a teacher taking a class of jittery kids to their first play. “Just let your mind go at ease here to follow Steven Wright,” he said, gingerly preparing the audience. “He’s unique and you have to listen to what he says.”

headline: Infidelity Under Wraps? They’d Rather Share
text: Scene from one kind of celebrity uncoupling, a few weeks ago on “Mary Mary”: Tina Campbell, who with her sister Erica makes up the revered gospel duo Mary Mary, is in full meltdown mode. She’s just learned that her husband has been unfaithful on several occasions, and she’s venting to her sister and mother: “I’ve got to go out here and sing ‘Go get your blessing.’ I’ve got to stand in front of these people and be inspirational, and it’s so hard, because they don’t have a clue.”

headline: Nicaragua: In Shadows of Pain and Glory
text: In the poetic documentary “Palabras Mágicas (Para Romper un Encantamiento)” — “Magic Words (Breaking a Spell)” — the director Mercedes Moncada Rodríguez meditates on the fraught history of Nicaragua, starting with the years preceding the Sandinista overthrow of the Somoza dictatorship in 1979. Ms. Rodríguez, a sociologist turned filmmaker, has examined the country’s history before: Her 2005 documentary, “El Inmortal” (“The Immortal”), examined the scars left on a family whose members fought on opposing sides in the Contra war in the 1980s. Her new film, presented as part of the Museum of Modern Art’s series “Iberoamérican Images: The State of the Art,” covers decades, juxtaposing period footage with the director’s reflective narration and gorgeous images.

headline: Nigerians Hold Second Day of Protests Over Mass Abductions
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Hundreds of protesters marched in the streets of the Nigerian capital on Wednesday, demanding that the government do more to find scores of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants more than two weeks ago. Parents of the girls have turned up sick in hospitals, overcome with worry. Some have even gone into the bush to search for the girls themselves, armed only with bows and arrows in the heartland of an Islamist insurgency.

headline: Augie Boehm at Honors Bridge Club
text: Augie Boehm of New York City is a well-known bridge player, teacher and writer. He is also an excellent concert pianist and on May 12 will be giving his 36th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall.

headline: Agnostic Lyricism in an Exploration of Spirituality
text: A program about spirituality and theological doubt would seem to be a natural for the Cecilia Chorus of New York, which was known as the St. Cecilia Chorus from its founding, in 1906, until it dropped the heavenly honorific — and, presumably, the religious connotations that accompanied it — in 2012. The centerpiece of the chorus’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening was a new work, Tom Cipullo’s “Credo for a Secular City,” intended, in its composer’s words, as “a statement for the believers and for the nonbelievers as well.”

headline: Deconstructing Charles James
text: “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” at the Met, includes animated videos that virtually peel garments, like his “Ribbon” dress, here, from their mannequins to illustrate how they were assembled.

headline: A Shortcut to Spring
text: In early April, a week before she was due to leave for South Africa to run an ultramarathon, Cortney Harding decided to get her hair cut. Ms. Harding, who is 33 and lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, went from hair that hit just above the shoulder to a short jaw-length bob with bangs. “I wanted to feel the sun on the back of my neck,” she said.

headline: Architectural Underpinnings of Cinderella
text: Charles James, the fabled fashion designer, once declared, “I’m the most copied person in the world.” But that Anglo-American couturier, who died in 1978, could never have imagined why his glamorous 1953 “Clover Leaf” dress was being meticulously recreated and scrutinized now — all 10 pounds of it.

headline: The Execution That Was Botched in Oklahoma
text: To the Editor:

headline: Guides to Four Flowers for Those Already Smitten
text: Garden books devoted to a single genus run the risk of simply being mind-numbing lists of species — this one found in the mountains, by the opening of a hermit’s cave; that one crossed with a Labrador retriever to win Plant of the Year at the Chelsea Flower Show. Timber Press is fond of publishing such books, because after all, gardeners tend to be a greedy, obsessive lot. If they fall in love with a snowdrop, they want every kind of snowdrop.

headline: A ‘Cabin’ in the Hamptons
text: For years, Peter and Kathryn Mattis rented a house in the Hamptons for their family every summer, an annual ritual that is not without its challenges. But buying a home there, they recently discovered, can be even more trying. Particularly if you don’t want a traditional Hamptons showplace.

headline: Teenagers’ Risky Behavior
text: To the Editor:

headline: ¿Vive cerca de la I-35? Contribuya a nuestro reportaje
text: En las próximas semanas, un periodista del New York Times, Damien Cave, y un fotógrafo, Todd Heisler, viajarán a lo largo de la I-35, relatando cómo es que la migración y las cambiantes tendencias demográficas transforman a comunidades enteras a lo largo de esta ruta. ¿A dónde deberían de ir él y el Sr. Heisler?

headline: Discounts at Madeline Weinrib, Niche Modern and Intérieurs
text: Carpets, pillows, furniture and fabric are up to 60 percent off during Madeline Weinrib’s sample sale though Sunday (a Brooke cotton carpet in hot pink and orange, originally $1,075, is $699; an 18-inch-square Ikat pillow, originally $525, is $259); ABC Carpet & Home, 881 Broadway (East 19th Street), second floor, 646-602-3780.

headline: The East Blows into the West
text: The historic Bradbury Building in downtown Los Angeles is known as a setting for “Blade Runner.” But on Saturday it will present another kind of future when Gallery ALL, a contemporary design space, opens in a 2,400-square-foot storefront there. The inaugural show is of works by Naihan Li and Zhoujie Zhang, Chinese designers who hint at the creative promise of East Asia.

headline: Fighting Cholera in Haiti
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rocking the Palazzo
text: Mudejar tiles, the appetites of Francis Cardinal Spellman and a colossal sculpture by Ron Arad made from a whorl of steel rods that cost more than $1 million are just a few of the colliding, often ravishing visions now on view in the elegant spaces that once held the Urban Center in the Villard Houses at Madison Avenue and 51st Street — the home, for the next month, of the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

headline: Let Us Eat Bagels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shake-Up at Repsol, as New Chief Is Named
text: MADRID — Repsol, the Spanish oil company, announced Wednesday that its longstanding executive chairman, Antonio Brufau, would hand over the job of chief executive to Josu Jon Imaz San Miguel, who has been running the company’s upstream operations.

headline: Dressing the Man of Means
text: The lexicon describing male shopping has been lately enriched with newly minted acronyms and portmanteaux, following in the vaunted (and derided) footsteps of “metrosexual.” Bain & Company calls this spender-to-be Henry (High Earner, Not Rich Yet); the bank HSBC, more cringe-worthily, calls him a Yummy (Young Urban Male). But if you christen him, will he come?

headline: If Pollock Could Whinny
text: Metro Meteor is a retired thoroughbred racehorse with congenitally bad knees and a fidgety personality. He was a star in his heyday, but after four and a half years of running hard (and winning big), and two operations to remove bone chips from his knees, he was not only no longer able to race, but he couldn’t even hold a rider.

headline: Parents Safely in the Closet
text: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — By way of introducing her parents, Roz Chast opened her closet door and rummaged through some stuff on the floor. This is where she keeps them, amid miscellaneous boxes and general bedroom marginalia: her mother’s ashes in a maroon velvet pouch; her father’s in the Channel 13 tote bag he took with him everywhere.

headline: Whose Glass Is Whose? Now, No Excuses
text: Lifefactory has taken the silicone-wrapped glass it uses in its popular water bottle designs and applied it to wineglasses and food storage containers, both introduced this week. The colorful stemless wineglass “was on our original patent application,” said Daren Joy, a designer and founder of the company, which is in Sausalito, Calif. “They feel good in the hand, and are a great way to keep track of who has whose wineglass,” he added.

headline: The Raw and the Cool
text: Phyllis Bobb met Emilia DeVitis 29 years ago while both were handing out audio tour devices at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Through the years, Ms. Bobb (a photographer and fourth-generation Brooklynite) and Ms. DeVitis (an artist who was born in Italy but raised in Astoria) stayed close friends. They are now opening Reclaimed Home, a salvage and restoration shop in Crown Heights.

headline: Cool Your Heels on an Ottoman
text: When it comes to ottomans, bigger is often better.

headline: Spring Dresses to Rival Art
text: The Frieze art fair and others descend on New York next weekend. Since splurging on some of spring’s graphically complex creations can cost the equivalent of an actual work of art, it makes sense to opt for a dress that will stand out in a sea of black and Céline (which are, of course, never less than chic). The interplay of geometric patterns, abstract brush strokes and scribble print in this selection could prompt even art-world grandees to pause. The model Soo Joo Park (shown here) had the right idea with her Chanel, rendering it extra cool with a bomber and a beanie.

headline: Deep in the Heart of Don
text: Don Sterling’s racist rant, on a recording published by TMZ, has earned him a lifetime ban by the N.B.A. and cost him a second — second? — lifetime achievement award from the Los Angeles chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. The N.A.A.C.P.?!

headline: New York Said to Be on Verge of 9-Year Deal With Teachers’ Union
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and New York’s main teachers’ union are on the verge of announcing a deal to settle a nearly five-year labor dispute in which the union has sought more than $3 billion in back pay from the city.

headline: Attorney General in Guatemala Excluded From Re-election Bid
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemala’s attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, whose prosecution of a former dictator for genocide earned her the enmity of powerful members of the country’s political and business elite, has lost her bid for a second term.

headline: Abercrombie Settles Board Fight With Engaged Capital
text: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had settled a proxy fight with the activist hedge fund Engaged Capital, agreeing to add four new independent directors to its board.

headline: Microscope and Telescope
text: As anyone I’ve talked with during the past week knows, I have been obsessed with trying to get my mind around the Supreme Court’s 6-to-2 decision to uphold Michigan’s voter-approved ban on affirmative action in admissions to the state’s public universities.

headline: Clip: ‘The Amazing Spider-Man 2’
text: A scene from the film directed by Marc Webb.

headline: White House on Oklahoma Execution
text: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said the botched execution fell short of the humane standards required when the death penalty is carried out.

headline: When Black Hair Is Against the Rules
text: AMERICA has always had trouble with black hair. The United States Army is only the latest in a long line of institutions, corporations and schools to restrict it. On March 31, the Army released an updated appearance and grooming policy, known as AR 670-1. It applies to all Army personnel, including students at West Point and those serving in the R.O.T.C. and the National Guard.

headline: The Problem With Free Health Care
text: HANOVER, N.H. — NOW that it’s clear that Obamacare is here to stay, its supporters should focus on making the program better. Fixes are not a sign of weakness. They are a sign of responsiveness and of good management. And the Affordable Care Act does have its flaws. Here’s a big one: It favors screening over diagnosis.

headline: Clip: ‘Palo Alto’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Gia Coppola.

headline: Mother’s Day Shopping Starting the Week of May 1
text: Mother’s Day

headline: A Mystery Beyond Price Tags
text: I’ll tell you this: I miss not knowing things.

headline: Clip: ‘Beneath the Harvest Sky’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Farfetch, an Online Boutique, Enjoys Its Moment
text: José Neves has a certain way of shopping, one that may make him very rich.

headline: Nicole Richie: Candid About Pushing Boundaries
text: Raised and now based in Los Angeles, Nicole Richie, 32, is known for her fashion line House of Harlow 1960 and reality TV shows, including “The Simple Life” and “Fashion Star.” In July, she’s scheduled to add another, “#CandidlyNicole,” on VH1. The adopted daughter of Lionel Richie and Brenda Harvey, Ms. Richie is married to the musician Joel Madden, with whom she has a daughter, Harlow, 6, and son, Sparrow, 4.

headline: So Many, You Could Have a Beauty-Booking App a Day
text: It was a beauty emergency in search of an app.

headline: Rains Flood Florida and Alabama
text: Torrential rain overnight in Pensacola, Fla., and parts of Alabama left hundreds stranded in apartments and cars. The storm drenched the area with nearly 20 inches of rain.

headline: Sephora and the Upstarts
text: “When I was 29, I lived in Boston and had to drive 30 miles to get my M.A.C. lipstick,” said Marla Beck, who owns Bluemercury with her husband, Barry Beck. “It was frustrating. In 1999 you couldn’t find what you wanted, which was a friendly neighborhood store that sold highly selective cosmetics and skin care products.”

headline: I’ll Have What She’s Wearing
text: The Sicilian designer Fausto Puglisi was sitting at breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel this week, his Mike Tyson sweatshirt and foghorn stream of enthusiasms marking him out from the crowd. “I like to work very calm and uptown,” he explained of his taste in hotels, “while someone in Miami in my miniskirt is drinking.”

headline: El Salvador: Ex-President Faces Charges
text: Former President Francisco Flores will face embezzlement and other corruption charges related to what prosecutors said Wednesday was the misappropriation of at least $5.3 million in loans from Taiwan during his tenure, from 1999 to 2004. The country’s chief prosecutor, Luis Martínez, told a television interviewer that charges had been filed in court against Mr. Flores, who has been summoned to a court hearing on Friday. He has not been seen publicly in several months, but in a hearing in January called by the nation’s Congress, which is also investigating him, he denied any wrongdoing. President Mauricio Funes has said Mr. Flores received $10 million in donations in the final months of his term without accounting for them.

headline: China: Criticism of U.S. Move on Iran
text: China on Wednesday sharply criticized an American move to enforce sanctions against Iran that penalized eight Chinese companies and their owner, Li Fangwei, accused of supplying parts for Iranian ballistic missiles. The move, announced on Tuesday by the Treasury, State and Justice Departments, also offered a $5 million reward for information leading to Mr. Li’s arrest or conviction. China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, told reporters in Beijing that “China resolutely opposes the U.S. citing domestic laws to unilaterally impose sanctions on Chinese companies or individuals.” He said the American move “will not help resolve the issue and will harm bilateral cooperation on nonproliferation.” It was unclear whether China’s anger would have an impact on the effectiveness of the American-led sanctions against Iran, which are mostly a response to the Iranian nuclear program. China and the United States are both in the group of big powers negotiating with Iran over its nuclear activities, seeking guarantees that the Iranians will not develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Veterans Agency Is Sued Over Handling of Trauma Cases
text: Two veterans groups and a Yale legal clinic sued the Department of Veterans Affairs on Wednesday, charging that veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder from sexual assaults during their service have more difficulty proving their illness to the department — and thus obtaining disability benefits — than veterans with other forms of PTSD. The federal lawsuit asks the court to order the V.A. to adopt rules making it harder to reject sexual-assault PTSD claims, which plaintiffs say were granted 17 percent to 30 percent less often than other PTSD claims from 2009 to 2012. According to the V.A., in fiscal year 2013, these claims were granted about 6 percent less often than all PTSD claims combined. The suit was brought by the Yale Law School Veterans Legal Services Clinic, the Service Women’s Action Network and Vietnam Veterans of America.

headline: Parallel Lives
text: AGE 34.
